title: Lockheed Finds No Basis For Australian's Charges
description: A spokesman for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that to the best of Lockheed's knowledge there was no basis for the charges by the former Prime Minister of Australia, Gough Whitlam, that in the late 1950's a former government minister received large sums of money from the company to promote sales in Australia.

title: POLICE SEIZE MAN ON PISTOL CHARGE
description: The state police in Sullivan County said they had arrested Darryl Stewart, a member of the family of Devernon LeGrand, a selfstyled Brooklyn Bishop, after finding a. 38caliber pistol and ammunition in his possession.

title: Dividends Announced
description: xxrecord and payble dales unannounced.

title: SABOTEUR BLAMED FOR PEKING BLAST
description: PEKING, April 30China tonight blamed a counterrevolutionary saboteur for an explosion outside the Soviet Embassy here that the Soviet Union said killed two Chinese soldiers.

title: Marilyn Casselman, S.O.J. Spivey Wed
description: Marilyn Casselman, manager of special programs for Warner Bros. Television, was married yesterday afternoon to Samuel Oscar Johnson Spivey. The civil ceremony was performed by a city clerk at the Municipal Building.

title: Honest Pleasure 1 2 Choice in Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 Two fast, aggressive colts who resent having anything In front of them except open spaces are expected to provide the major drama tomorrow in the 102d running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Merry Thoughts For May
description: PARISMay Day has been widely observed since preChristian times, starting as a pagan celebration of spring sowing and eventually gaining acceptance simply as an occasion of happiness and dancing around bedecked May poles. Only in 1889 was it internationally designated by a Socialist congress as an occasion to honor labor.

title: BOZ SCAGGS OFFERS RICH VOCAL RHYTHM
description: Boz Scaggs, a Texan who became part of the first wave of San Francisco rock during the late 1960's, may be the most convincing white rhythm and blues singer now working. Unlike the hordes of variously affected English and American soul vocalists who have been performing around town lately, Mr. Scaggs never strains and never overcompensates.

title: Hughes Institute to Grow Bigger If Courts Back Purported Will
description: MIAMI, April 30The Howard Hughes Research Institute here could become the country's largest private foundation devoted to biomedical research and a major world force in the medical attack against a wide variety of diseases if the document filed in a Las Vegas court yesterday proves to he Mr. Hughes's genuine last will and testament.

title: Burton to Portray Dr. Martin Dysart In Film of Equus
description: Richard Burton has signed contracts to star as Dr. Martin Dysart in the film version of Peter Shaffer's play Equus, which will be produced by Elliott Kastner and Lester Persky for release by United Artists.

title: United Airlines Will Pay $1 MillioninBias Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 30United Airlines agreed today to pay more than $1 million in back pay to settle discrimination complaints brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on behalf of members of minority groups and women.

title: Albany and CityDiffer Over Progress in Municipal Budget Cuts
description: The city and state issued conflicting reports yesterday on whether New York City was meeting the $200 million in cuts for this fiscal year imposed by the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: ASBESTOS DETECTED IN WATERIN 5 CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had found traces of asbestos in drinking water supplies of Boston, Philadelphia, Atlanta, San Francisco and Seattle.

title: GAF GETS PERMISSION TO OPERATE PINCNFM
description: The GAF Corporation will take over the operation of WNCNFM, the classicalmusic station, within 30 days, a spokesman said, following approval by the Federal Communications Commission on Thursday of GAF's application to purchase the station for $2.2 million. The application has been pending since Aug. 19.

title: Dutch Bid Juliana, 67, Happy Birthday
description: SOESTDIJK, the Netherlands, April 30Queen Juliana of the Netherlands celebrated her 67th birthday today with thousands of her subjects at a carnivallike party on the lawn of the royal palace here.

title: Soviet's New Minister of Defense
description: MOSCOW, April 30When the Soviet astronauts in Soyuz and the Americans in Apollo linked their craft in space last July, a husky, sandyhaired man wearing metalrimmed spectacles intently followed the docking feat from the Soyuz mission control center in a Moscow suburb Dmitri.

title: Major League Baseball
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES New York 3. Houston 1. Chicago 5. San Francisco 2. Cincinnati 7, Montreal 2. Philadelphia at Atlanta, rain. Pittsburgh 4, San Diego 3.

title: High Court Again Bars Election Fund Release
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)The Supreme Court refused today, for the second time in eight days, to clear the way for payment of some $23 million in Federal matching funds to Presidential candidates.

title: Violence of Youth Gangs Is Found at a New High
description: Violence by youth gangs has reached new heights in the major cities of the United States, and gang members are increasingly attacking ordinary citizens, according to a major new study released yesterday in Washington.

title: FNTRUDER SOUGHT IN BRONFMAN CASE
description: A composite drawing is being prepared to help identify a gunman seen near the Albany hospital room of Mel Patrick Lynch, an accused kidnapper of Samuel Bronfman 2d, according to the Ulster County sheriff.

title: 4 Share Golf Lead With 67's
description: HOUSTON, April 30The Houston open, dedicated in equal parts to the institutions of Texas golf and Texas real estate got off to a soggy start today, delayed a day by a heavy rain that had left the Woodlands Country Club course in unplayable condition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times recently reported that blacks and Puerto Ricans now form majority in the Bronx and that there is a continuing white flight from the city. Manhattan also experienced a net decline in black population of nearly 90,000 from 1970 to 1975.

title: Arlington CryptVacant, AwaitingVietnam Unknown
description: ARLINGTON, Va., April 30For all the life it shattered, for all the deaths it spuawned, the Vietnam War still has no unknown soldier.

title: Small Reform of the Fed
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss's bold effort to overhaul the Federal Reserve System in order to make it more responsive to elected political authorityboth the Administration and in Congresshas been almost completely undermined. The bill that Mr. Reuss, chairman of the House Banking Committee, introduced early this year was passed by the committee this week in a form that will effect only the most modest changes in the structure and functions of the Fed.

title: BROWN, ALI SPAR NEAR BALTIMORE
description: LANHAM. Md., April 30Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California clowned with Muhammad Ali, wooed labor leaders, shook hands with field workers and toured a Baltimore housing project, as he roamed across Maryland today in his late bid for the Democratic. Presidential nomination.

title: Wheeling to Pare Increase To 6% Level of U.S. Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, which led an industry move to higher prices Monday, expects to pare its increase to the lower level set by the United States Steel Corporation, Wheeling announced today.

description: ALBANY. April 30Counsel for Assemblyman Alan Hochberg today sought a dismissal of the Bronx Democrat's indictment on a bribery charge by contending that this alleged violation of election laws was not within the jurisdiction of the special state prosecutor who indicted him.

description: Federal Judge Robert L. Carter kept the pressure on the National and American Basketball Associations yesterday to reach an outofcourt settlement of their lawsuit that could lead to a consolidation of the leagues.

title: FORD AGAIN SCORES VIEWS OF REAGAN
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., April 30President Ford completed his Texas primary campaign today after charging that Ronald Reagan's credibility is severely at stake in the debate over national security policy.

title: In Rome, Minor Scandals and Major Ills
description: ROME, April 30The Italians are doing well this week in the International Horse Show, the azaleas are ablaze on the Spanish Steps, the longdistance operator is answering the phone and the sun is out in this coldest spring in 70 years. All that, however, has hardly generated any national euphoria.

title: CUNNINGHAM CASE BEGINS NEW PHASE
description: A special grand jury is looking into whether Patrick J. Cunningham used his political influence as the Democratic state chairman to obtain the transfer of certain interestfree state accounts to favored banks.

title: Jersey Labor Chief Hails Carter In First Hint of Shift by Unions
description: TRENTON, April 30The New Jersey A.F.L.C.I.O. had its first kind words today for Jimmy Carter.

title: Byrne Is Heckled At Bridge Opening
description: PENNSAUKEN TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 30Governor Byrne was heckled today as he opened the $105 million Betsy Ross Bridge linking Pennsauken and Philadelphia.

title: ITALIAN CABINET RESIGNS, OPENING WAY FOR ELECTION
description: ROME, April 30The Italian Government resigned tonight, opening the way for general elections this June that could bring the Communist Party a share of power.

title: Italian Bridge Team Is Accused Of Playing With Smoke Signals
description: ROME, April 30 (AP)Italy's world championship bridge team, accused last year of using foot signals under the table, is being charged this year with using smoke signals in a case that has grown into a nationwide scandal.

title: Intelligence, Morality and Foreign Policy
description: STANFORD, Calif.From de Toqueville to Walter Lippmann, democracies have been faulted for their inability to conduct timely and intelligent foreign policies. Nonetheless, it is apparent that in the long run no foreign policy in a democracy can be successful unless, it has popular support.

title: U.S. STEEL SCORED ON AIR EMERGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The Environmental Protection Agency has prepared a report on the fiveday air pollution episode in the Pittsburgh area last November that severely criticizes the handling of the emergency by Allegheny County's Bureau of Air Pollution Control.

description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 30Carol Semple, a Curtis Cup player from Atlanta, trimmed Lauren Howe of Colorado Springs, 5 and 4, to win the North and South Amateur golf tournament.

title: McDonald's Declares First Cash Dividend as Net Rises 27%
description: The McDonald's Corporation. the nation's largest fastfood restaurant chain, achieved 27 percent increase in firstquarter profits on a sales gain of 26 percent, Ray A. Kroc, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: Kareem Abdul Jabbar stopped off here yesterday to pick up a $10,000 check for being the most productive and most consistent player in professional basketball. The check was awarded by the Seagram's Company as part of its Seven Crowns of Sports program.

title: U.S. to Oversee Texas Bilingual Votes
description: WAHINGTON, April 30The Justice Department's civil rights division sent 116 Federal observers to Texas Today to overse the first mandatory use of a bilingual ballot in that state's primary election tomorrow.

title: Strike by jockeys Valets Delays Start at Big
description: Post time for yesterday's first race at Aqueduct was delayed 15 minutes as a result of a picket line established by some of the track's valets in front of the entrances.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: A Father's Charge of Campus Promiscuity Upsets Wellesley
description: WELLESLEY, Mass.  A father's charges that sexual immorality and promiscuity are being taught Wellesley College students 24 hours a day, seven days a week through unlimited dormitory visiting hours have provoked shock, anger and dismay both on and off this centuryold campus.

title: Control Board TurnsDown Transit Contract on Raise
description: The state's Emergency Financial Control Board rejected the transit workers contract yesterday and instructed New York City's Transit Authority to negotiate and submit a revised wage pact by May 15, taking into account the ban on costofliving increases.

title: Takeover Adds to Peru's Economic Trouble
description: LIMA, Peru, April 27Though United States corporations after a decade of economic and political upheaval, may no longer enjoy the formidable clout they once had in Latin America, it is nevertheless difficult to expropriate a large American company in this continent.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey Food Council has announced on behalf of its grocer members that there will be no change in conventional pricemark ing. Consumer groups and le gislators had expressed concern that prices might be removed from items in those stores converting to electronic checkout systems.

title: PAUL ELY, 76, HEADED BROOKLYN SAVINGS,
description: Paul French Ely, who retired in 1974 as board chairman of the Brooklyn Savings Bank, died yesterday in Stamford, (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Darien.

title: Johan Willem Beyen Dies at 78; A Leader in the Unity of Europe
description: Johan Willem Beyen, former Foreign Minister of the Netherlands and an architect of European unity after World War II, died Thursday evening in The Hague after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and had been living in the south of France since his retirement a few years ago.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday sentenced Murray Weiss, the accountant for Eugene Hollander, the nursinghome owner, to a suspended oneyear jail term, a year's probation and a $1,000 fine. Mr. Weiss, 49 years old, of White Plains, pleaded guilty Feb. 20 to charges of misrepresenting the expenses of the Congress Nursing Home at 300 Henry Street, Brooklyn, in connection with Medicare reimbursement.

title: Profiles of Horses Running in Today's Derby
description: The horse the others must beat if they hope to win. Has won 10 of 12 races, the last nine in a row, and has not yet been turned loose this season. Has not been hit with whip since last September, when he came from eighth place to win Arlington Futurity. Since then, has never had a horse in front of him after first few yards. Took Flamingo, Florida Derby and Blue Grass in easy, frontrunning style. Was last season's champion 2yearold, heading Experimental ratings and building bankroll that now stands $626.803. A Floridabred son of What a Pleasure, sire of last year's Derby winner, Foolish Pleasure. Like Bold Forbes, a grandson of Bold Ruler. Was considered a lock to win Derby until Bold Forbes emerged as challenger, but still regarded as solid choice. Trainer was critical of jockey for not letting colt run harder in slow Blue Grass, but horses who win 11/4mile Keeneland race in moderate time tend to run big in Derby. Post position, outside Bold Forbes, will enable Baeza to keep an eye on main challenger during run to first turn. Only uncertainty colt does not like to he restrained, a quality that could lead to hazardous early speed duel with Bold Forbes or some other frontrunner.

title: LATIN SUPPORTERS OF CARTER VEXED
description: SAN ANTONIOThere is no evidence of it, but the small, white frame house at 2106 El Paso Street is the campaign headquarters for Jimmy Carter in the west side barrio of San Antonio.

title: U.S. Opening to Africa Finds Nigerian Doors Shut
description: LAGOS, Nigeria. April 30Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's dual policywarning against further CubanSoviet incursions in southern Africa on the one hand and voicing increased support for majority rule there on the otherarouses only anger in Nigeria.

title: Screen: Renoir Chienne
description: This is neither a comedy nor a tragedy. It proves no moral at all. It's simply another story about He and She and The Other Guy.

title: Late Offer May Save Landmark L.I. Tower
description: ST. JAMES L. I.A dramatic, lastminute offer by a local carpenter may save a landmark water tower on the Stanford White estate here from destruction.

title: 2% Rise in Most Domestic Air Fares Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to let airlines raise their domestic fares by 2 percent and some North Atlantic fares to Europe up to 10 percent.

title: Dybbuk Variations Has Superb Stars, Still Fails to Satisfy
description: Jerome Robbins's Dybbuk Variations has never quite pleased its creator, and he has tinkered with it relentlessly since the premiere. In its present form the balance calls for less story and decidedly more dancing, but the total effect is yet far from satisfying despite superb interpreters. The flawlessly articulate Patricia McBride was the possessed young woman and Bart Conk was the demon at the State Theater on Thursday evening as the New York City Ballet showed the work for the first time this Season.

title: Five Win Hillman Awards For Work in Mass Media.
description: The Sidney Hillman Foundation announced yesterday five winners of its 26th annual awards for outstanding achievemants in mass communications.

title: CHAMBER SOCIETY TO ADD BUSWELL
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will add James Buswell, violinist, to the list of its permanent personnel next fall, bringing the total number to 11.

title: Music: From Marlboro
description: The Music From Marlboro ensemble currently appearing in this area is a string quintet, and Thursday night it appeared at the Metropolitan Museum to play Mendelssohn's Quintet in A (Op. 18) and Beethoven's Quintet in C (Op. 29).

title: Expert Calls Howard Hughes Will Signature Authentic
description: A prominent autogtaph expert examined yesterday the signature on the will purportedly written by Howard Hughes and pronounced it authentic.

title: Events Today
description: THREE PENNY OPERA, the New York Shakespeare Festival production of the Ralph ManheimJohn Ih'iliett translation; directed by Richard Foreman, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: Canada Signs Pact For Lockheed Plane
description: OTTAWA, April 30The Canadian Government and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation signed tonight a $750 million contract for the company to build 18 longrange patrol planes for the Canadian defense forces.

title: Women Try Boxing on the Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 29In Southern California, where they pioneered the frisbee and the skate board, the drivein movie and the encounter group, they have rolled out something else new for America's leisure time  the female prize fighter.

title: ExAide to Hughes Is Seeking Probate Of Purported Will
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30Initial moves to try to carry out the provisions of a purported will of Howard R. Hughes were made today by Noah Dietrich, an 87yearold former Hughes aide. Mr. Dietrich was named as executor of the document that turned up mysteriously Tuesday on the 25th floor of the world headquarters of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints (Mormon) in Salt Lake City.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AWAY WE GO Outoftowners interested in seeing architectural and historical highlights of our town, along with New Yorkers eager for a refresher course, will have their chance in a new series of Sunday bus and foot tours organized by the Municipal Art Society and the Department of Cultural Affairs, which will start tomorrow.

title: SOVIET RADIATION OF NIXON REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Heavy radiation was discovered at the American Ambassador's residence in Moscow during Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit there in 1959 but was halted after detection, according to two former Secret Service agents.

title: Tom Jones Tour of U.S. Starts Off in Westchester
description: TARRYTOWN N.Y., April 29 Tom Jones, the Welsh pop singer now securely embarked into his second decade of show business, began a long American tour at the Westchester Premier Theater here tonight.

title: People and Business
description: Henry Kaufman, a general partner of Salomo nBrothers, the international investment banking house, warned yesterday that the nation's banking system was being politicized and that urgent steps should be taken to halt the process.

title: INDIA ASKS TRANSFER OF U.P.I. NEWSMAN
description: The Indian Government yesterday asked United Press International to transfer "forthwith its correspondent in New Delhi, John F. Needham; for, having reported on communal disturbances in violation of censorship regulations.

title: Kissinger Suggests Path to Angola Ties
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 30 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said here tonight that the United States would be willing to normalize relations with Angola if the 15,000 Cuban troops there were withdrawn.

title: City's Festival of Theater Starts Today for a Month
description: The second annual monthlong New York City Theater Festival, cosponsored by the Department of Cultural Affairs and the Andora Hodgin Total Theater Inc., gets under way today.

title: The Board Says No
description: Following the lead of Governor Carey and backed by a legal opinion from Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Emergency Financial Control Board has formally rejected the transit pact.

title: Yanks, Hunter Beat Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, April 30The New York Yankees stole five bases tonight, got a sixhitter from Catfish Hunter and a tworun homer from Thurman Munson as they defeated the Kansas City Royals, 53, in the opener of a threegame series.

title: Soviet Bars BBC Chief, Cites Solzhenitsvn Talk
description: LONDON, April 30 (AP)The Soviet Union today barred a visit by the head of the British Broadcasting Corporation in a protest over views expressed by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the exiled writer, during an interview.

title: FARMERS' PRICES UP 2% FOR MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Prices farmers get for raw agricultural products rose 2 percent from March 15 to April 15. the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Build your bridge
description: Bridge players can sharpen their game with the bridge columns of the weekday New York Times and the Sunday Times Arts and Leisure Section.

title: Dr. Ruth Mermod of Newark, Led U.S. Medical Women
description: Dr. Ruth Camille Mermod, twice president of the American Medical Women's Association, which gave her the Elizabeth Blackwell Award for her work, died Wednesday in her home in Maplewood, N.J. Site was 75 years old.

title: Profiles of Italy's Parties
description: Seven major parties are represented in the Italian Parliament. They are listed here in order of their power in the Parliament, which consists of 630 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 315 in the Senate.

title: Portuguese Act to Grant Some Autonomy to Islands
description: LISBON, April 30Portugal moved today to grant a measure of autonomy to its Atlantic islands of the Azores and Madeira as a counter to separatist campaigns there.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday. London: Morning fixing $128.15, up $0.25; afternoon fixing $128.40, up $0.50.

title: Recital
description: Guadalupe Parrondo, who made her local debut in the Concert Artists of Mexico series at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night, is a very fine pianist who needs only at this point to extend her range of tonal color to make her a complete one. She played three works that were taxing enough technically but were even more so musically. They included Prokofiev's Sonata No. 1, Beethoven's Appassionata Sonata and Schumann's Carnaval.

title: Ali Wins Narrowly
description: Muhammad Ali, looking sluggish and out of shape, scored a unanimous but close decision last night over unheralded Jimmy Young at Landover, Md., to retain the world heavyweight boxing title. Page 17.

description: PODORFFrederick. C. arly loved. Always In our hearts, always is with us. JO and FRED

title: Jackson, Unsigned, to Play for Orioles
description: Reggie Jackson, who held out for four weeks while asking his new team, Baltimore, for a higher salary, agreed to join the Orioles last night.

title: Paranormal Phenomena Facing Scientific Study
description: Twentyfive scientists, philosophers and others, responding to what they see as a rising tide of superstition and uncritical acceptance of paranormal phenomena, have formed a committee to investigate such claims and publish scientific reports on their validity:

title: CUNNINGHAM CASE BEGINS NEW PHASE
description: A special grand jury is looking into whether Patrick J. Cunningham used his political influence as the Democratic state chairman to obtain the transfer of certain interestfree state accounts to favored banks.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 30A Federal District Court judge has ruled that the state has been mistreating convicts at the maximumsecurity prison here.

title: Turkish Hijacker of Jet Surrenders at Paris
description: PARIS, Saturday, May 1 (Reuters)A Turkish man who hijacked a Turkish Airlines DC10 gave himself up at Orly airport here early today, officials said.

title: Books of The Times
description: Geoffrey Stokes's new book is two things at once a detailed look at the way the pop music business works, and a more implicit comment on the relationship between ex1960's idealistic dreams and workaday mid70's corporate conglomerate realities. The second aspect doesn't work quite so well as the first, but the first is so good that anybody interested in popular music must read this book.

title: PHONE COMPANY SCORED BY P.S.C.
description: The Public Service Commission yesterday criticized as unjust and unreasonable al New York Telephone Company effort to induce Yellow Pages advertisers to take larger advertisements.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCAM: Morning Solitude. Gaude Maria Virgo, Ockeghem; Madrigals, Motets and Instrumental Music, Nenna. 6.9, WQXR: Breakfast Symphony. Symphony No. 81, Haydn; Old Dances and Airs Suite No. 3, Respighi; Overture No. 8, Arne; Violin Concerto No. 4, Vicuxtemps; Invocation of Alberich and Entrance of the Gods into Valhalla from Das Rheingold, Wagner; Overture to Il Giardino di Rose, Scarlatti; Death and Transfiguration, Strauss; Montagues and Capulets from Romeo and Juliet, Prokofiev; Bourree Fantasque, Chabrier.

title: Rabbi Korff Finds Nixon Is Depressed By Publicity on Book
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon was described today as depressed about recent news accounts of his relationship with his wife and his purported heavy drinking in the days belore resigning.

title: BRITISH AMERICAN WIDENS HOLDINGS
description: LONDON, April 30 (Reuters) The BritishAmerican Tobacco Company, the world's biggest tobacco concern, announced today it would merge with the Tobacco Securities Trust, an associated investment company, in a move that will tidy up a complicated crossshareholding.

title: Brokers End Bid to Pack Board of Stock Exchange
description: In a strong display of support for William M. Batten, newly elected chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, a 700 member maverick group of stockbrokers disclosed yesterday that it had withdrawn a proposal that would have packed the exchange's board of directors in their favor.

title: LISA A. FAIRBANKS
description: Lisa A. Fairbanks, a former librarian in Rutherford and Passaic. N.J. died Thursday at the Raritan (N.J.) Health and Extended Care Center. She was 78 years old and lived with her sister and only survivor, Mrs. Otto H. Rohrberg, in Cokesbury, N.J.

title: $1.5 BILLION DUE IN NEW OFFERINGS
description: In an unusually heavy flurry of financing announcements yesterday, more than $1.5 billion of securities were filed with Government regulatory agencies in preparation for sale to investors in May.

title: U.S. COURT DIRECTS BUFFALO END BIAS
description: BUFFALO, April 30 A Federal District Court judge ruled today that the city government and state education officials had intentionally perpetuated racial segregation in Buffalo's public schools, and he ordered them to meet with him on May 19 to begin preparing an integrat:on plan.

title: About New York
description: The name of H.R. Haldeman figured in an unexpected way in a recent letter from Otto W. Schafenberg of East 73d Street.

title: Women's Interclub Golf
description: Women's Interclub

title: Mexico City Airport Strike
description: MEXICO CITY, April 30 (AP) A wildcat strike by airport employees today forced 21 airlines to cancel flights to Mexico City. Only Aeromexico and American Airlines were able to operate. Airport employees walked out to protest dismissal of 35 airporttax collectors for disciplinary reasons.

title: Wellfleet Oysters: Comeback Time?
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., April 30  The We Meet oyster, once world famous, is trying to make a comeback.

title: Wilkins Charges Coverup by F.B.I.
description: Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, charged yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had conspired to cover up the bureau's involvement in a raid in 1969 on a black Panther Party office in Chicago in which two party Members were killed.

title: Mystery in Peking
description: The explosion at the gates of the Soviet Embassy in Peking is being denounced as counterrevolutionary sabotage by Chinese authorities. But why should dissident Chinese forces feel it necessary to stage such a demonstration?

title: Cowboys Sign Thomas Again
description: DALLAS, April 30 (AP)Duane Thomas, who led Dallas to the Super Bowl in 1971 and 1972, was signed today to a standard twoyear contract with the Cowboys, whose coach, Tom Landry, was once called a plastic man by Thomas.

title: Slump Afflicts Mexico's Tourist Industry
description: ACAPULCO, MexicoBernardo Sanchez, who sells Tshirts printed with happy tropical scenes on the beach in front of the luxurious Acapulco Princess Hotel, is less than happy. Business is so bad that some of the Tshirts fade in the bright sun before he can sell them.

title: Quick Repeal Asked On New Estate Tax
description: The new Council on the Economy, whose chairman is Governor Carey and whose cochairman is Mayor Beame, decided yesterday to seek immediate repeal of the city's estate tax and an easing of the stocktransfer tax burden on brokers and dealers as the first steps in a program to dramatically improve the business climate of the state and the city.

title: Ali Wins Narrowly
description: Muhammad Ali, looking sluggish and out of shape, scored a unanimous but close decision last night over unheralded Jimmy Young at Landover, Md., to retain the world heavyweight boxing title. Page 17.

title: CITIBANK REDUCES ITS PRIME TO 6%
description: Despite widespread predictions that interest rates are heading up, Citibank yesterday reduced its prime rate to 6 percent from 6 percent, effective Monday.

title: Stocks Are Mixed InTradingonAmex; OTC Issues Down
description: Stock prices weakened yesterday On the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: With Liberty and  uh  uh  uh
description: Law Day, U.S.A., is a serious and in some ways, awesome celebration. I salute the goals of Law Day: To advance equality and justice under law; to promote citizen support of law observance and enforcement; to foster respect for law.

title: Chris Evert and Old Conqueror Gain
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., April 30Chris Evert, the queen of clay, and Mary Struthers, a relatively obscure  25yearold professional from La Jolla, Calif., advanced toward a strange showdown today in the quarterfinal of the $100,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup.

title: Hotchner to Get$125,000 in Hemingway Suit
description: A F. Hotchner author of the ???selling biography Papa Hemingway, won a $125.000 ??? award yesterday for a defamatory characterization of ??? in a book about Ernest Hemingway that was published by Doubleday & Company.

title: Carter, in Texas, Asserts Ford Has Failed to Give Leadership
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 30Jimmy Carter, on his final campaign swing through Texas before the Democratic Presidential primary tomorrow, accused President Ford today of failing to provide the necessary leadership for the country in either domestic or foreign affairs.

title: Jungle Covers All but the Memories at Refugee City on Guam
description: OROTE POINT. GuamThe big silver jet plane screamed in low off the bright Philippine Sea, its giant rubber wheels screeching as they hit the hot tarmac.

title: BROOKLYN DOCTOR IS KILLED IN PARK
description: A 49yearold family doctor having lunch with, a friend in a park in Brooklyn was stabbed to death yesterday by one of two knifewielding young thugs who robbed him of more than $200 and fled on foot.

title: BYRNE IS HECKLED AT BRIDGE OPENING
description: PENNSAUKEN TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 30Governor Byrne was heckled today as he opened the $105 million Betsy Ross Bridge linking Pennsauken and Philadelphia.

title: Notes on People
description: There is a time to quitI qua when I was doing well. said 81yearold John S. Knight, explaining yesterday in Miami why he was retiring as editorial chairman of the KnightRidder chain of 33 newspapers. Mr. Knight built it up from The Akron (ohio) Beacon Journal, which was debtridden when he inherited it from his father in 1933. Many awards, including the Pulitzer Prize, came to Mr. Knight as a publisher and for more than 2,000 weekly columns he wrote. Ile is resisting writing any more of them. I'm a bleeder, he confessed. I used to sit here and struggle with the typewriter, smoking cigarettes and drinking soft drinks and ruining my gut. I'd go home from the office drained. This work

title: Ford Believed to Have Cut Reagan Strength in Texas
description: HOUSTON, April 30Political leaders here believe that heavy lastminute campaigning by President Ford has cut substantially into Ronald Reagan's early lead in Texas, turning tomorrow's Presidential primary into a cliffhanger that they said was too close to call.

title: Jersey Senate to Seek Cause of High Cancer Rate,
description: TRENTON. April 30A special State Senate committee will begin an investigation on May 21 of New Jersey's high incidence of environmental cancer.

title: Matlack Defeats Astros
description: No wonder the Mets keep winningthey play with 10 men on the field. Well, actually it's nine men and a girl.

title: Lessons of the Broomstick Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30During the post parade Collegiate Downs, the track announcer introduced the field: Number One, Elocutionist, ridden by Catherine. The surname was lost in a burst of cheering as Catherine, wearing a dark blue Tshirt and shorts and sitting high in the saddle like Braulio Baeza, galloped her broomstick horse once around the course. Number Two, the announcer said, Cojak, ridden by Robin and again cheers drowned her out. This was the 12th running of the Broomstick Derby at the Louisville Collegiate School, an event that foretells the result of the Kentucky Derby with a degree of accuracy that turns touts and handicappers pink with envy. Two or three years ago a janitor at the school said winners at Collegiate Downs had repeated at Churchill Downs seven times in eight years, and since he was a horseplayer who did a little bookmaking on the side, the chances are his memory was reliable.

title: Control Board Turns Down Transit Contract on Raise
description: The state's Emergency Financial Control Board rejected the transit workers contract yesterday and instructed New York City's Transit Authority to negotiate and submit a revised wage pact by May 15, taking into account the ban on costofliving increases.

title: Dance: Laura Dean's Rigorous Song
description: When the Brooklyn Academy of Music presented its first experimentaldance series last year, the joint concert by the choreographerdancer Laura Dean and the composer Steve Reich was easily the most spectacular program.

title: LONG STRIKE ENDS AT CHESTER PAPER
description: A 23week strike at the Delaware County Daily Times in Chester, Pa., ended yesterday when members of Local 10 of the Newspaper Guild of Greater Philadelphia voted, 57 to 14, to accept a contract agreement.

title: Decontrol of $300aMonth Apartments Is Opposed
description: Nearly 40 elected officials and a tenants group denounced yesterday suggestions that rent control be removed from apartments in New York City that rent for $300 or more a month.

title: O'Connell Sets 4:09.2 Mile Mark
description: A touch of psychology and a flat tire helped to win and lose races yesterday at the 11th annual New York Relays in Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. The meet continues today with field events at 9:30 A.M. and track events starting at 11 A.M.

title: Bertram Bongard, Lawyer And Race Horse Breeder
description: Bertram F. Bongard, lawyer and former director of the New York State Thoroughbred Breeders Association, died yesterday, after a short illness, in White Plains Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Scarsdale N.Y.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 51311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY TIIROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY 1701) MARKET 3.390e: WESTCHESTER CO. ALIT NOR:.:ERPI NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES 19141 WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 74/.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (5161 6691800; CONNECTICUT 12031 348.7767.

title: Prospect Park Zoo Head Accused of Killing Animals
description: The acting supervisor of the Prospect Park Zoo was arrested yesterday and charged with killing eight cats, some pigeons and a guinea pig that he allegedly took from the Children's Farm at the zoo and fed to his pet python.

title: Prices Hold Steady In Corn and Wheat; Potatoes Fluctuate
description: Corn and wheat prices held steady yesterday on the Chisago Board of Trade in light trading.

title: In Rome, Minor Scandals and Major Ills
description: ROME, April 30The Italians are doing well this week in the International Horse Show, the azaleas are ablaze on the Spanish Steps, the longdistance operator is answering the phone and the sun is out in this coldest spring in 70 years. All that, however, has hardly generated any national euphoria.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP; DOW OFF BY 5.28
description: Stocks drifted lower yesterday in slow trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was off 5.28 points at 996.85.

title: Oscar Winners Return For Passaic Festivities
description: PASSAIC, April 30  Porky Zaentz and Beansie Lieberman came home today, and Mayor Gerald Goldman, members of the City Council and 200 others gathered on the steps of City Hall to honor the two local boys who had made good.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, April 30 (Reuters)Twentytwo cardboard carton manufatturers, defendants in the biggest Federal antitrust suit in more than a decade, moved today to withdraw their riot guilty pleas to charges of price fixing. The 22 entered motions in United States District Court asking to be allowed to change their original pleas to no contest to charges contained in an antitrust indictment returned by a Federal grand jury in February.

title: JACKSON EXPECTED BY AIDES TO QUIT CAMPAIGN TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Senator Henry M. Jackson is expected to announce tomorrow that he is abandoning his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to key members of his campaign staff.

title: Chinatown to Get Bank Owned by Its Community
description: Chinatown will soon have its first commercial bank owned largely by ChineseAmericans and organized to serve the special needs and interests of the city's Chinese community.

title: Japan to Send Aide to U.S. To Study Lockheed Case
description: TOKYO, April 30 (Reuters)Japan today named Shizuo Saito, a former representative at the United Nations, as a special envoy to the United States to seek further cooperation in the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payments case.

title: In Bicentennial Year, the Colonial Dames Have a Lot to Cheer About Here
description: One of the country's most exclusive organizations, the Colonial Dames of America, held its annual luncheon meeting here yesterday, and this time it was more than just another catered luncheon of cold fried chicken and ratatouille.

title: Mexican Students Detaining 17 Demand Marxist Rector Resign
description: MEXICO CITY, April 20A group of rightwing students today demanded the resignation of the Communist rector of the University of Puebla in exchange for the release of about 117 hostages being held in a campus building.

title: Chappaquiddick Span Funds
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., April 30 (AP)The Edgartown town meeting on the island of Martha's Vineyard has voted to appropriate $3,600 to reinforce Ithe Chappaquiddick Bridge. The bridge, linking Chappaquiddick Island to Edgartown proper, was the scene of an automobile accident involving Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Mary Joe Kopechne in 1969.

title: A Mechanical Memory Is Used to Connect Pipes
description: WASHINGTON. April 30Certain plastics have what is called a mechanical memory and engineers for the Phillips Petroleum Company of Bartlesville, Okla., have invented a way of using this quality in connecting pipes. For the process and product, James C. Carroll and Arthur H. McElroy were granted this week patent 3,953,059, assigned to Phillips.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an item in Business Briefs in The Times yesterday said that the Federal Energy Administration would remove price and allocation controls on heavy fuel oil today. The correct date is June 1.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Bridge:
description: After almost six months of strenuous competition, in which 390 teams took part, the New York district Grand National competition ended Thursday night in a victory for Sam Stayman, Marty Scheinberg, Matt Granovetter and Jerry Shakofsky.

title: Republicans Ask Reevaluation of Canadian Ties
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) A 15member panel of Republican Representatives said yesterday that deteriorating relations between the United States and Canada force us to reevaluate the friendship that we have long taken for granted.

title: Warriors In West Finals
description: DETROIT, April 39 (UPI)Jamaal Wilkes put in a rebound onehanded with 1 minute 43 seconds left in overtime tonight to give the Golden State Warriors a 118116 victory over the Detroit Pistons and send the defending National Basketball Association champions into the Western Conference finals against the Phoenix Suns.

title: Market Place
description: On June 3. the Allied Thermal Corporation plans a special meeting of its shareowners that promises to be a pleasant occasion. The New Britain. Conn.based company. a producer of airconditioning and heating equipment. will ask its owners to approve a 2for1 split in the currently outstandim 680.080 shares of common stock.

title: Vote of Confidence Is Won By New Thai Government
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 30 (AP)Thailand's third civilian Government since World War II won a vote of confidence in the lower house today, ending almost a month of postelection political maneuvering.

title: Giglio Quits as Finance Chief of Hospital Agency
description: Joseph M. Giglio, the first vice president for finance of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, turned in his resignation yesterday, becoming the fifth top official of the troubled corporation to resign in the last six months.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an item in Business Briefs in The Times yesterday said that the Federal Energy Administration would remove price and allocation controls on heavy fuel oil today. The correct date is June 1.

title: Pipe Patent Issued
description: A patent was issued this week for a new method of connecting certain plastic pipes. Page 31.

title: Lowell Thomas Is Giving Up Nightly Radio Show
description: Lowell Thomas, who has been broadcasting news on the radio for 46 years, announced yesterday that he was giving up, on May 14, his nightly program Lowell Thomas and fife News, which has run on CBS Radio for three decades.

title: Baeza, jolley Pals After Oaks Score
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 Braulio Baeza and LeRoy Jolley buried the hatchet long enough today for Optimistic Gal, under a perfect ride, to win the Kentucky Oaks by more than four lengths.

title: ITALIAN CABINET RESIGNS, OPENING WAY FOR ELECTION
description: ROME, April 30The Italian Government resigned tonight, opening the way for general elections this June that could bring the Communist Party share of power.

title: Courthouse Now a Historic Site
description: NEWARK, April 30  The 70yearold Essex County Courthouse, a majestic marhle structure overlookins from a discreet distance the commercial heart of downtown Newark, was formally dedicated today as a National ??? Site.

title: Brink's Truck Rains A Shower of Coins Over Lexington Ave.
description: Boxes of quarters tumbled out of a Brink's armored truck moving down Lexington Avenue at 77th Street yesterday afternoon when the back door suddenly popped open. Virtually all the money, perhaps as much as $2,000, was believed recovered.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Italian Government, led by the Chris. tian Democrats, the country's dominant party since 1948, resigned last night, opening the way for general elections in June that could give the Communist Party a share of power. The Government had been severely damaged by charges that some of its leading figures were involved in bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, but its collapse was directly caused by a dispute over an abortionreform bill in which the Christian Democrats lost the crucial support of the Socialist Party. Prime Minister Aldo Moro was asked by President Giovanni Leone to remain as head of a caretaker cabinet. President Leone still has to dissolve Parliament and set a date for the elections. [Pagel, Column 8.]

title: Pilot Cites Engine Problem in Virgin Islands Crash
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., April 30The pilot of the American Airlines boeing 727 jet that crashed here Tuesday noticed a lack of reverse engine thrust when he tried to slow the plane after lending far along on the unusually short airport runway, according to investigators of the National Transportation Safety Board. Thirtyseven of the 88 persons aboard died in the crash.

title: U.S. COURT DIRECTS BUFFALO END BIAS
description: BUFFALO, April 30 A Federal District Court judge ruled today that the city government and state education officials had intentionally perpetuated racial segregation in Buffalo's public schools, and he ordered them to meet with him on May 19 to begin preparing an integration plan.

title: Portuguese Act to Grant Some Autonomy to Islands
description: LISBON, April 30Portugal moved today to grant a measure of autonomy to its Atlantic islands of the Azores and Madeira as a counter to separatist campaigns there.

title: Hartford Foundation Asks A. & P. to Plan a Stock Sale
description: The John A. Hartford Foundation, a charitable foundation that owns about eight million shares of common stock of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, said yesterday that it asked A. & P. to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 1.75 million shares of its stock. A. & P. has 24,878,524 shares outstanding.

title: Copter Traps Suspect In Robbery in Queens
description: A young man who allegedly robbed a Queens liquor store owner at gunpoint of $82 was spotted and tracked for about six blocks by a police helicopter that pinned him down behind a mound of dirt in a Long Island Rail Road yard where he was counting the money, the police in the 108th Precinct reported late yesterday.

title: What Might Have Been
description: When political historians take the long look at this year's Presidential campaign, they may well conclude that Congressional fumbling of the campaign finance law played a major role in the result.

title: LEBANESE DEFER VOTE ON LEADER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30The Speaker of the Lebanese Parliament tonight announced a week's postponement of a special session for the election of a new president.

title: GEORGE WYCKOFF CLARK
description: George Wyckoff Clark, a retired management consultant, died Thursday of a heart attack in his home on Sunswyck Road in Darien, Conn. Mr. Clark, a former director of industrial relations for the Riegel Paper Corporation of New York, was 64 years old.

title: A.O. Martinez Weds Patricia Donnelly
description: Patricia A. Donnelly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Donnelly of Jersey City, was married there yesterday evening to Arturo O. Martinez, also of Jersey City. The ceremony was performed in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Stephen Towell of Cleveland, who in 1939 performed the Wedding ceremony of the bride's parents.

title: Chief Justice Asks New Ways to Settle Suits Courts Handle
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger last night defended his proposals to remove familiar types of lawsuits from the courts as a way of widening the availability and enlarging the access of all peope to dispute resolving mechanisms.

title: C.I.A. Weather Study Cites Global Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) A report from the Central Intelligence Agency warns of global political and economic upheaval almost beyond comprehension because of climatic changes that have already oc???

title: Albanian Reports Plot in Party To Turn From China to Soviet
description: VIENNA. April 30 (AP)The Albanian Communist Party has uncovered a faction that conspired to promote a policy It break ties with China and to lead Albania back into the Soviet bloc, the party chief, Enver Hoxha, said today.

title: BOB AND RAY END RUN OF 3 YEARS ON WOR
description: It's goiing to be Write if you get work for Bob and Ray, the lowkey Massachusetts  born comics who were hosts to their last afternoon comedy show yesterday on WORAM.

title: ExAide to Hughes Is Seeking Probate Of Purported Will
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30A purported will of Howard R. Hughes was offered for probate here tonight amid speculation that a protracted court fight would ensue over its authenticity.

title: Everybody Said, Amen:
description: The sinners took their places on the benches and when they were all seated, their new leader spoke.

title: MABLE HILLERY, SANG SPIRITUALS
description: Mable Hillery, a singer of blues and spirituals who was known for developing teaching manuals and audio tapes that preserve traditional folk songs of the South, died Tuesday of a heart attack at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived at 504 West 110th Street.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Italian Government, led by the Christian Democrats, the country's dominant party since 1948, resigned last night, opening the way for general elections in June that could give the Communist Party a share of power. The Government had been severely damaged by charges that some of its leading figures were involved in bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, but its collapse was directly caused by a dispute over an abortionreform bill in which the Christian Democrats lost the crucial support of the Socialist Party. Prime Minister Aldo Moro was asked by President Giovanni Leone to remain as head of a caretaker cabinet. President Leone still has to dissolve Parliament and set a date for the elections. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: March Inventories And Orders Surged
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Manu facturers inventories rose in March by the largest amount since a huge inventory liquidation associated with the recession came to an end last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: All Struggles but Keeps Title on Unanimous Decision Over Young
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 30 Overweight and overconfident, Muhammad Ali retained the world heavyweight boxing championship tonight with a unanimous 15round decision over Jimmy Young that was loudly booed by most of the 12,472 spectators attending the hometelevised bout at the Capitol Centre.

title: Argentine Golfer Leads After 68
description: ATLANTA, April 30 (UPI) Silvia Bertolaccini of Argentina, in only her second year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot a fiveunderpar 68 today and took the firstround lead in the Lady. Tara classic. miss Bertolaccini birdied the first three holes and four of the first five as she wound up a stroke ahead of Sally Little of South Africa.

title: Threadneedle St. Gang
description: The Bank of Englandthe Old Lady of Threadneedle Street that is the very core of British probity and financial integrityis reportedly investigating its staff to find out whether any members have been involved in bribery, forgery, currency smuggling and illegal foreign securities dealing. The suspicion may prove baseless, but, if it does not, Tories will rush to blame the decay of mosality on loose budgets, bloated social services, greedy trade unions, rapidly growing money supplies and the sinking poundwhile Socialists will blame the decadence of Capitalism and the Old Establishment.

title: Education Board Threatens to Sue City
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that it would sue the city if $121 million were not added to its new budget in accord with the newly adopted StaviskyGoodman Law.

title: 100,000 Throng Saigon Palace On Anniversary of War's End
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (Agence FrancePresse) One hundred thousand people paraded in the main courtyard of the former presidential palace in Saigon today on the first anniversary of the end of the Vietnam war.

title: Hechinger Is Editorial Page Aide
description: Fred M. Hechinger has been appointed assistant editor of the editorial page of The New York Times, John B. Oakes, the editor of the page, announced yesterday.

title: Yugoslav Paper Closes Bureau In Prague Amid New Tensions
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30The Belgrade newspaper Politika announced today that it would close its office in Czechoslovakia, a measure that appeared to reflect growing Yugoslav irritation with Moscow's campaign to tighten its hold over all European Communist parties.

title: Fat Kid Who Almost Won
description: Jimmy Young started boxing when he was 14 years old because he had to lose weight.

title: Cunningham's Isolation From Power
description: Despite Patrick J. Cunning ham's reelection as Democratic state chairman, he is still cutl off from direct communication with Governor Carey in a crucial period when the state Democratic party will start the process of selecting a candidate for the United States Senate and prepare to serve as host to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nearly all the 20,000 employees of the state's Department of Institutions and Agencies were given layoff notices because it was too difficult for officials to determine which 500 to 700 employees may actually be let go. The notices went with paychecks to Deputy Commissioner Robert Hulcally right down through the department, said Public Information Officer James Stabile, who also received a notice.

title: JACKSON EXPECTED BY AIDES TO QUIT CAMPAIGN TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Senator Henry M. Jackson is expected to announce tomorrow that he is abandoning his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to key members of his campaign staff.

title: HUMPHREY GETTING HOSPITAL CHECKUP
description: WAHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Senator. Hubert H. Humphrey was in Bethesda Naval Hospital today undergoing a regular sixmonth medical examination.

title: CASTRO FOE INJURED IN MIAMI CAR BLAST
description: MIAMI, April 30  Emilio Milian, a Cubanborn radio commentator known for his antiCastro editorials, was seriously injured tonight when a powerful bomb exploded in his car.

title: Reagan Attacks Kissinger For His Stand on Rhodesia
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 30Ronald Reagan said today that time was needed to resolve the political and social issues of Rhodesia, and he cautioned the Ford Administration to avoid impulsive reactions that could incite bloodshed there.

title: Titanium Ores Found On Adirondack Frinte
description: ALBANY, April 30Titanium ores have been discovered in upstate New York on the western edge of the Adirondack Mountains, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: Madrid Military Forces on Alert on May Day Eve
description: MADRID, April 30Military forces were placed on the alert today in the Madrid area as the Government continued to crack down on all efforts by opposition labor groups to demonstrate in observance of May Day, a tradition common to most European countries.

title: Contracting In
description: The Became administration's plan to establish profitmotivated garbagecollecting cooperatives in two sanitation districts represents a boldly innovative attempt to improve the productivity of a shrinking, and notoriously unproductive, municipal workforce.

title: Communist Youth Group Is Established in Poland
description: WARSAW, April 30 (Reuters) Poland has merged groups in the army, in rural communities and in work places to form a 2,000,000strong centralized youth organization better adapted to implement Communist programs.

title: U.S EASING CURBS FOR TWO IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 President Ford issued two more decisions today under the 1974, trade law, both of which will reduce import restraints that now exist to protect a domestic industry.

title: Smith Says Cabinet With Blacks Provides a Coalition for Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rtiodcsia, April 30 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia said today that he had created a national coalition by naming African tribal chiefs to his Government and denied that the move was mere window dressing.

title: Deaths
description: INTELISGertrude Rose. Beloved daughter of the late Nathan and Sophie Antelis. Dear sister of Dr. Eugene. Cherished sister In law of Marilyn. Services Sunday, 10 A.M. Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave., loop. Kings Plaza), Bklyn.

title: Margaretta Starrett Bredin a Bride
description: At Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del., yesterday afternoon, Margaretta Starrett Bredin was married to Thomas Clarkson Taylor Brokaw by the Rev. John O'Hear, assisted by the Rev. Thomas L. McClellan.

title: Bomb Charge Dismissed
description: MILWAUKEE, May 1 (UPI)One of five charges against David S. Fine, accused of setting the fatal bomb at the University of Wisconsin's Madison campus in 1970, was dismissed by a Federal judge yesterday. The charge involved use of a destructive device (a bomb) to commit a felony crime.

title: No.Amer. Soccer League
description: No.Amer. Soccer League

title: The New Cuba
description: In January 1974 Ronald Radosh published an article in Liberation, a periodical of the Left, that raised a number of questions about the Castro regime in Cuba. Though basically friendly to the Cuban revolu tion, Radosh, a historian of the New Left, was clearly troubled by the authoritarianism, male supremacy, repressive morality and competitiveness he found in Cubaand said so with unusual bluntness.

title: Cooperative Housing Ruling Reversed
description: Federal laws that regulate securities do not apply to the sale of shares in privately owned cooperative apartment houses, a Federal appeals court has ruled in New York City, reversing a lower court.

title: Rowing
description: Rowing

title: Dwight Erskine 2d Weds Mary Degan
description: Mary Ann Degan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Degan of Goshen, N.Y., and Dwight. Raymond Erskine 2d of Effingham, Ill., were married yesterday at noon by the Rev. Edmund Netter in St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Goshen.

title: History Test Had Origins In 43 Exam
description: In 1943, The New York Times tested 7,000 college freshmen and reported in a Pulitzerprize winning article that the survey revealed the students' striking ignorance of even the most elementary aspects of United States history.

title: Brown Suggests a Debate With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California suggested today that at some point in the Democratic Presidential nomination campaign he and Jimmy Carter are going to have to have a public debate.

title: BRIDGE
description: A Trial Run; In the last 19 years Italy has won 16 world team titles with its famous Blue Team. In the next three weeks in Monte Carlo it can boost that string to 18the longest in any, sport or recreation.

title: Black Rule in Rhodesia: Some Implications
description: PRINCETON, N.J.Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's action in associating this country with the heavy pressures already being brought to bear on the white Rhodesian regime to accept what is optimistically called majority rule is of course receivingwide acclaim throughout the Western liberal world, including the editorial columns of The New York Times, and appears even to have won from African leaders elsewhere on that continent those grudging nods of approval that American policymakers seem to find so important to the interests of this country.

title: Carey and Legislature Still Skirmish On Budget Despite FiscalCrisis Lull
description: ALBANY. May 1Although the fiscal emergency has subsided, Governor Carey and the Legislature are still engaged in budget skirmishes focusing on the removal of key executives in his administration and the impact of the state's bread spending cuts.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayRice Farms, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, L.I. Regular. Green, AmateurOwner and Junior Working Hunters; Intermediate and Junior Jumpers, Ponies, Equitation. 8:45 A.M.

title: Unraveling a Bit of Red Tape
description: GLEN RIDGE THE Romans had an expression that has come down to our own days: Omne trinum est perfectum. Roughly translated, it means All good things come in threes. Bureaucracy is no exception; it comes in a local, a state and a Federal variant.

title: TV VIEW
description: New York's Channel 13 recently presented an hourlong documentary called Christina's World. Written and directed by Sonja Gilligan, the program was supplied by the Hardtimes Movie Company, an independent producing organization. Filmed in 1972 and completed 1973. the documentary was made at a cost of $80,000. For the showing on Channel 13, the filmmakers were paid $2,000. The dramatic discrepancy between cost and eventual return provides a sadly accurate reflection of the current plight of most independent filmmakers and documentarians in their dealings with the broadcast industry.

title: The Framers Would Not Recognize Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe Constitution of the United States empowers Congress to make all laws, and the framers of the Constitution expected that lawmaking would he the principal function of the legislative branch of the tripartite Government. But the making of laws is no longer clearly the most important function of the United States Congress. It certainly is not what Congress now does best.

title: Georgia Tucker And C. J. Tuttle Wed in Suburbs
description: The sanctuary of the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Georgia Dean Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Tucker of Bronxvale, to Christopher John Tuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Tuttle of New Haven.

title: Headliners
description: Many Western military experts were surprised by the naming of Dimitri F. Ustinov, a civilian formerly in charge of the Russian militaryindustrial complex, the new Soviet Defense Minister. It was expected that a military man would be named to replace Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, who thought that Mr. Ustinov was selected in part to avoid adding a new member to the ruing Politburo and upsetting its meticulous political balance. Mr. Ustinov was a nonvoting member of the Politburo: his new post makes him a full member. It has also been hinted that the naming of a civilian to a key military post strengthens the Brezhncv policy of tentc with the West. Mr. Ustinov has been instrumental in the evolution of Soviet defense and acrospace programs since 1941.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Fire Department has disbanded its five squad companies and one of its five marine units to save $3 millicn a year. The five squad companies, with one engine each, were assigned to the Bronx and Brooklyn, providing reinforcement units for emergency use, and the marine unit, Marine Engine Company 6, was stationed next to Gracie Mansion.

title: Yankee Doodle
description: As the Bicentennial parade of children's books nears the reviewing stand, two more recruits have joined the ranks, although they are not exactly marching in step.

title: Radio
description: 77:20 A.M. WNEWAM: Yale

title: The Students in 1943 vs. the Students Now
description: College freshmen know as much American history overall as did their counterparts 33 years ago, although the content of what they know has shifted somewhat.

title: State's Jobless: Who They Are
description: ANYBODY out of work knows what it's like, but for the general public the state has now compiled a list of the characteristics of those workers who are unemployed but are receiving jobless pay.

title: Gliderman Is Sad As His Era Fades
description: When Robert Redford gets round to playing Ross Briegleb in the movies, he will have to fictionalize the truth a little.

title: INDIA BIRTH CURBS GROWING STRICTER
description: NEW DELHI, May 1  A municipal bulldozer knocks down a slum resident's shack, and as he surveys the rubble, he is told that he can have a ??? new nouse on a bigger plot in the suburbs if he will undergo a vasectomy.

title: Henri A. Belfon Jr. to Marry Sheila Ann Moncure in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Moncure of White Plains and Middlebury, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Ann Moncure, to Henri Arthur Belfon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Belfon of the Bronx. An August wedding is planned.

title: Outhouses Aweigh!
description: WE are notorious for mistreating our waters. We asphalt our land, allowing oil residue, pesticides and fertilizers to wash off into the water. We discharge municipal sewage wastes into our lakes and bays, depleting our groundwater supply. We install cesspools that all too often leach through the ground into our watersupply system, and we dump our garbage along the shorelines.

title: Diagramless, 16 by 25
description: ACROSS 1 Like dells

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Earlier this yearpresumably because publishers either think alike or perhaps just steal one another's ideastwo books were published, one in the United States and one in Britain, in which people, most of them well known as I recall, described their first love affair. The English version was called You Always Remember First Time, and while I am not convinced that you always do, the idea is undeniably a cute one. In any event I will always remember my first ballet company.

title: Miss Murphy Plans Bridals
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Murphy of Potsdam, N. Y., have ve made known the engagement of their daughter. Therese Irene Murphy, to John Carver Burditt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Burditt of Bedford Hills, N. Y. The wedding is planned for Oct. 16 in Potsdam.

title: Robert J. Dwyer Becomes Fiance Of Muffy White
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bradley White of Watch Hill, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marice Eleanor White, to Robert Jeffrey Dwyer of New York, son of John Edward Dwyer of Elizabeth. N. J., and the late Mrs. Dwyer.

title: New Head for Jewish Group
description: Sydney J. Schwartz, a Manhattan lawyer, has been elected president of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, which represents 101 temples throughout the New York City area. Mr. Schwartz, who is a member of the firm of Schaeffer, Dale & Vogel, succeeds Irvin Husin.

title: Joan G. Ogilvy Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Hunter Ogilvy of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Giffin Ogilvy, to Robert Johnson Holden Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Holden of Cambridge, Mass.

title: The World
description: Prime Minister Aldo Morn's Christian Democratic Government in Italy has resigned, clearing the way for June elections in which the Communist Party has a solid chance to end the threedecade domination of Italian politics by the Christian Democrats. Mr. Moro's was the 33rd government since World War II.

title: Adventures of a poet
description: In 1974 the American poet Paul Zweig loaded tinned sardines, Pernod, tea, spark plug; a car jack and other items of physical survival into his 2CV auto and set out for a solitary journey into the African desert. He was led to undertake this voyage by that Faustian need for rebiith, that melancholic search for meaning which often assails men in early middle age blessed with all the material trappings of success. How often have we heard words similar to his! I loved my wife; I had a reasonable job; several of my books had been published and acclaimed  but somehow it wasn't good enough.

title: Came the Revolution
description: The Bicentennial is producing an abundant harvest of children's books. Among the more interesting encountered are the three listed above. As points in common, all are concerned with the Revolution, the principal characters of each are a boy and his friend, and each is written in the first person.

title: Semington Captures Steeplechase Race
description: WARRENTON, Va., May 1 (AP)William Wallace Lanahan Jr.'s English import, Semington, took the lead four fences from the end and breezed to a sixlength victory today in the rainsoaked 51st running of the Virginia Fenwick Jr., needed 9:17 to Gold Cup steeplechase race.

title: Election in Italy
description: Italy is now on the road to its most critical election since the founding of the Republic in 1946with no assurance that the contest will dissolve the political stalemate or produce a government capable of leading an economic revival. With the failure last week of a lastditch bid by the ruling Christian Democrats for allparty backing of an emergency economic program, the fall of Prime Minister Moro's minority Government became inevitable and June elections all but certain.

title: Ford and Carter Favored In Indiana Race Tuesday
description: INDIANAPOLIS. May 1 President Ford and Jimmy Carter are favored to win the Indiana Presidential primary on Tuesday in personality contests marked by an absence of issues and a lack of strong voter interest.

title: Gettysburg Takes League Track Title
description: CARLISLE, Pa., May 1 (AP)Mark Roddy won the threemile run by 40 yards today to lead Gettysburg College to I he Middle Atlantic Conference College Division track and field championship.

title: Mirrors of conflict
description: Raymond Williams was born in 1921 in Pandy, a border village in Wales. I do not know at what age he crossed the border and started making his way into English life, but he has been a major presence in English intellectual life for many years. He is now professor of drama at Cambridge University. Skilled in the discrimination of borders and hinterlands, he is particularly concerned with the interaction of ideas, values and attitudes in social life. As a teacher, he loves to show where ideas begin and end, in principle, only to emphasize that in practice their beginnings and endings are incorrigibly wayward. It is congenial to him to demonstrate that ideas have consequences. In his major books, Culture and Society (1958), The Long Revolution (1961) and The Country and the City (1973), Williams has been writing the social and cultural history of England, and now in Keywords he proposes to show how that history is disclosed in the way certain words have come to be used. Keywords, he says, is not a dictionary or glossary of a particular academic subject, it is not a series of footnotes to dictionary histories or definitions of a number of words; it is, rather, the record of an inquiry into a vocabulary, a shared body of words and meanings in our most general discussions, in English, of the practices and institutions which we group as culture and society.

title: PIANO RECITAL GIVEN BY THEODORE EDEL
description: Theodore Edel, in his New York recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night, displayed a clear dynamic pianism that hit its stride with the last work he played. Mr. Edel possesses a fine technique in which both hands move as one, a dancing angularity ideal for broken phrases and a flexlible rubato whose power lies in its spontaneity. His drawbacks lare a rather stolid approach to (dynamic gradations and a hard tone.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: OUR nation not only has been moving toward two societies, black and white, as warned by a Presidential Commission In 1968, but also has been further dividing itself into two geographic camps: suburbs and cities. The recent Supreme Court decision concerning lowcost housing for minorities is welcome attempt to stop both these invidious divisions.

title: Queer monsters
description: The monsters who began to roam through English and European literature in the Age of Enlightenment attracted and allured readers because like the earlier figures of the high wayman and whorethey embodied urges that were ignored or actively repressed by a society fervently dedicated to industrialization, social order and scientific progress. Through Gothic fiction, readers could for a while escape from the cold demanding daylight into the almost unthinkable thrill of the night.

title: Frederick W. Clarke 4th Is Fiance of Joan Welles
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold N. Welles of Greenwich, Conn., and Northeast Harbor. Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan Esther Welles, to Frederick W. Clarke 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke 3d of Rockford, Ill.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE American Conservative Union struck a sensitive nerve last week when it included Representatives Jerome A. Ambro of East Northport and Thomas J. Downey of West Islip, both Democrats, on list of 20 winners in what the group calls its first Annual Ostrich awards.

title: Microwave Sales Sizzle as the Scare Fades
description: When, one day 31 years ago in Waltham, Mass., Dr. Percy L. Spencer felt some heat on his hand from a nearby radar vacuum tube, he placed a Hershey bar he had heen eating alongside it. The chocolate turned to goo.

title: Fashion
description: Fashion

title: The Thomas Berryman Number
description: Another hit noveltopheavy with detail, but surefire nonetheless. James Patterson lays on the specifics of an assassination plot with an impasto of minutiae. His hired gun, who has the title role, is a method killer in the way others are method actors; he actually lives the role, a different one each time. For the murder of Jimmie Lee Horn, the black mayor of Nashville, this virtuoso of homicide creates a local identity, a workable plan and an elaborate getaway, about which we are told perhaps a bit too much. But these are complications, some of which work for the killer and some against him Unfortunately, nothing works for the mayor, who is fated to get it in the sweetbreads on July 4th.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe Lion in Winter. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through May 22). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: U.S. COSTS IN SINAI EXCEED ESTIMATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The Americanoperated Sinai earlywarning system has been working effectively for two months with less staff than expected but at more than double the expected firstyear cost, the Administration reported yesterday.

title: Legal Casinos: Business Says Yes, The Church No
description: THE New Jersey A.F.L.C.I.O. supports the concept of casino gambling for many reasons, not only because of the additional and revenues that it would pump into the state's treasury.

title: SIGNS OF DISSENT ABSENT IN TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Although Taiwan, like South Korea and the Philippines, has an authoritarian Government, the absence of dissension and opposition to the regime here is remarkable when compared with the two other countries.

title: Challenge to Carter
description: Perhaps the most dangerous threat to a Carter nomination is the candidacy of Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California. In Governor Brown's appearances in Maryland last week, his first political swing outside his own state, the handsome young California Governor drew sizable crowds and a lot of enthusiasm. Since he, too, is a nonWashington outsider with a fresh, unorthodox style, Governor Brown competes with Mr. Carter on his own around.

title: Europe's African Legacy: Mostly Bad, Some Good
description: At midday on Tuesday, Central African Time, Secretary of State Henry Kissinger drove an American nail into the coffin of European colonialism. The unrelenting opposition to the recalcitrant whites in Rhodesia that the American Secretary of State then promised underlines the fact that Europe's era in Africa is at an end. Only one colony on the entire continent is now willingly held by a European power, the tiny French territory of Mars and Issas, and, though Most of the four million whites in southern Africa are there to stay, they must do so as Africans not Europeans.

title: Center for DeafBlind Nearly Ready on L.I.
description: SANDS POINT, N. Y.The overhead lighting just inside the front door is brilliant. The floor in the gym slopes upward to meet the walls. Fans switch on automatically when doors open. And a fire would start alarms shrieking and lights flashing, and beds would vibrate to jolt occupants from slumber.

title: TOP PEKING AIDES IN SHOW OF UNITY
description: HONG KONG, May 1China's senior leaders made an unusual appearance together on television at a May Day celebration today, in what analysts believed was an effort to demonstrate unity despite the country's current bitter political atmosphere.

title: POST OFFICE ROBBED; POLICE SEIZE 3 MEN
description: Thee men were arrested yesterday and charaged with robbing an East Harlem post office branch earlier in the morning of more than 1,000 blank money orders and the equipment to validate them, $2,500 in postage stamps, an undetermined amount of savings bonds and $360 in cash, the police reported.

title: Tara Mitton Has Nuptials
description: Tara Corinne Mitton and Alvaro Luiz Bocayuva Catao Filho were married early yesterday evening In the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Lawrence Prast.

title: How the Fight Was Scored
description: REFEREE TOM KELLY

title: 28 Die in Crash Near Manila
