description: MANILA, May 1 (Rcuters)At least 28 people were killed in a hug crash north of Manila yesterday, the day after 22 people died in another bus crash in the same area the official Philippine news agency said today.

title: Chief of the Air Force in Bangladesh Resigns
description: NEW DELHI, May 1 (Reuters) Air Vice Marshal Mohammed Gholarn Tawab, chief of the Bangladesh Air Force and one of the country's three deputy chief administrators of martial law has resigned, Samachar, the Indian news agency reported from Dacca today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The article by Charles Kaiser [The Truth is, Columbia Owns Rockefeller Center Buildings, Too, March 21] brings to mind the interesting history of the underlying land, almost all of which is also owned by Columbia.

title: United Church of Christ Asks Effort to Strengthen the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1The United Church of Christ has asked President Ford and all political candidates to work for a strengthened United Nations and to save the world organization from disintegration.

title: 63 Decorated by Israel For Bravery in 1973 War
description: JERUSALEM, May 1 (AP)Israel has decorated 63 participants in the 1973 Middle East war, including an Arab tribesman, two women soldiers and a jet pilot allegedly tortured to death in Syria.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: Answers/Questions
description: ACALIFORNIA SEQUOIA (April 18) R.R.G., Old Bridge, N.J. would like to grow giant sequoia (Sequoiadendron giganteum) in his central New Jersey yard. He asked what the chances are for survival. Chances for survival are good for the giant sequoia in New Jersey which is in hardiness Zone 6, the same as the tree's native region, in Southern California. This species is hardier than its cousin, the giant redwood and does not grow as tall. In its youth the tree is an attractive needled ornamental but in time the seedling needs growing room. Ed.

title: BARGAINING LAW MAY BE REVISED
description: The city administration is considering changes in the collective  bargaining law that would give the City Council the power to make a final determination in labor contract impasses, rather than the Board of Collective Bargaining.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Rude Awa ??? For State Taxpayers

title: BILLS ARE PROPOSED TO BOOST TOURISM
description: JOHNSTOWN, N. Y., May 1 (UPI) Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut has announced a series of bills aimed at boosting tourism in New York State, including one that would guarantee loans for developing and imoroving tourist facilities.

title: D.K. Ludwig: The Man and the Money
description: When Howard Hughes died, tycoonwatchers immediately passed his titlethe world's most eccentric and reclusive billionaireto D. K. Ludwig.

title: A HEAVY TURNOUT
description: DALLAS, May 1Ronald Reagan crushed President Ford in the Texas Republican prmary tonight, giving his challenge for the White House huge boost.

title: Track and Field
description: Track and Field

title: Bob Marley's Reggae Style Is Polished and Slicker
description: The Bob Marley who appeared last summer at the Schaefer Music Festival and the Bob Marley who did the first of four soldout shows at the Beacon Theater on Friday night may have been the same person, and ultimately the effect of his sinuous reggae music was the same. But the packaging most definitely was differentmore polished and ultimately slicker.

title: Midwest Is Set for Record Corn Harvest
description: VAN METER, Iowa, May 1The sodden fields on the Baur farm were still glistening like coal in the spring sun after two of the wettest April weeks in memory.

title: Doing Business With the People
description: IN nearly all American governments, and the one in Washington is no exception, there has been an inevitable concern about any correlation between those who do business with the people in office and those who have contributed to their Political campaigns.

title: REV. DR. E. S. JAMES
description: The Rev. Pr. E. S. James, retired Southern Baptist ministereditor, died Monday in Dallas of cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Leone Closes Parliament; Election Expected June 20
description: ROME, May 1  President Giovanni Leone dissolved Italy's Parliament tonight in a formal prelude to an announcement setting the date for elections that could result in a share of power in the Cabinet for the Communist Party.

title: State Gambles On Legalizing Casinos
description: TRENTON LEGALIZING casino gambling is akin to grabbing the tail of a wild tiger, or so says the man who manages casinos in three British cities. The important thing is that, having caught the tail, you then know how to handle the animal to get him into a cage, said Victor A. Lownes, a vice president of Playboy Enterprises. What I can tell you is [that] getting into the cage with him is not the way.

title: Isaac the pure, the just, the cop
description: What's to be done with this foolish thing, the father? Let him circle himself to zero, as Joseph Heller does Bob Slocum in Something Happened. Drag him mumbling and dead to a far part of the land as Donald Barthelme does in The Dead Father. Orbit him out into transcendent space with Saul Bellow's Charlie Citrine of Humboldt's Gift.

title: Cards to Save and Savor
description: Playing cards were first Introduced by the Chinese about 1,000 years ago and they have never lost their popularity even among those who don't care much for card games. Their diversity of design, coupled with their colorful history, has drawn collectors over many years and in many lands.

title: Week of Decision
description: The dramatic political events of the last week brought the Democratic Party's Presidential picture into sharp focus. By winning the Pennsylvania primary, former Gov. Jimmy Carter reached a dominant position in the struggle for the nomination and forced Senator Henry M. Jackson to suspend his campaign.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The General Foods Corporation has leased Red Oak Plaza, a 102,000 squarefoot office building on Red Oak Lane in Harrison, N.Y., for 10 years at an aggregate rent of more than $6 million.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: Although it may not be politic to admit it, fame is as much of a spur to most politicians as the exercise of power. If they can't achieve fame, politicians very likely will take publicity. I don't care what you say about me, just spell my name right, as former Gov. James (Kissin Jim) Folsom of Alabama used to say.

title: INVESTING
description: A few weeks ago it seemed that nobody had anything good to say about the drug stocks.

title: LAWN ECOSYSTEM FOUND PRODUCTIVE
description: To a suburban homeowner, a lawn is a patch of grass requiring raking, mowing, fertilizing and watering at considerable expenditure of time, energy and money that usually brings, in return, a dividend of esthetic pleasure.

title: It Will Be Fought Over by Mayoralty Candidates
description: The next mayoral election is a year and a half away, but there already exists on paper what is likely to be the seminal political document for the numerous contenders expected to seek the office. It is the city's threeyear austerity plan, the painful and controversial regimen for slicing $1 billion in services and personnel from the budget by mid1978.

title: Roosevelt Island Becoming a Reality
description: In the year since she moved to Roosevelt Island, the new town risen like Atlantis on a twomilelong islet in the East River, Sharon Keilin has seen enormous changes. It was an active construction site, and now it has the feel of a real town, said the former West Sider. It's beginning to become what we all moved here for.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ONE should not, ever, attempt to drive into New York from New Jersey by way of the Lincoln Tunnel during the morning rush hour, particularly since they've begun tearing up the North Bergen viaduct and thereby rendering that ramp impassable.

title: Benefit for Arts Center
description: The Creative Arts Rehabilitation Center will benefit from the May 10 performance of the musical 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue at the Mark Hellinger Theater. Tickets may be obtained from the agency's headquarters ??? 251 West 51st Street.

title: 15 Bind 3 in Family in $200,000 Theft on 9th Avenue
description: Five young men wearing ski masks forced their way into a fourstory private residence on Ninth Avenue near 43d Street early yesterday morning, handcuffed the elderly owner of the building and his wife, bound their daughter and escaped with stocks, savings bonds, jewelry, cash and a coin collection with a total value of $200,000.

title: 9 Ask Orioles to Restore Pay
description: BALTIMORE, May 1 (UPI) Nine members of the Baltimore Orioles informed the club management today they believed they should have a 20 percent pay cut restored from last year's salary even though they haven't signed their 1976 contracts because the Orioles restored a similar cut for Reggie Jackson.

title: U.S. RADIO SPYING IN SOVIET SUFFERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Continued Soviet beaming of microwaves at the American Embassy in Moscow has impaired the efficiency of electronic tening devices on the roof and upper floors of the building Administration officials have reported.

title: Est answers
description: In the course of its expansion the Erhard Seminars Training (est) organization has come under harsh journalistic criticism from professional fad watchers. Some of their major charges and est's replies:

title: TRACK EVENTS
description: TRACK EVENTS

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Kids stuff. A year ago we lamented that tew good books for young children were available in paper covers where parents could buy them readily. Some day, we wrote hopefully, thousands of firstrate titles will be available at moderate prices through bookstores and variety stores.

title: A Year And a Day
description: At first, a William Mayne story always sounds to me as if it had been translated from some other tongue by someone with a rather thin gift for languages. The structures are awkward, and sometimes passages have to be paraphrased to reveal their meaning. But after a few pages, the reader grows accustomed to all this and forgets it, because Mayne's style has a strength all its own and the strength takes over.

title: ART VIEW
description: This year the United States is sending a seminar to the Venice Biennale. It is, to be sure, a seminar in the form of an exhibition, but it is a seminar all the same, and everything about it betrays its academic origin. Its very title, Critical Perspectives in American Art, sounds like an entry for a course in a college catalogue, and the show itself was, in fact, originally conceived to mark an academic occasionthe opening of the new Fine Arts Center on the campus of the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. It is currently on view at the Fine Arts Center Gallery (through May 9) before being dismantled and reduced in size for shipment to Venice.

title: Morristown Turns Out for a Festival
description: IT'S MORE than just a showcase for talent. It's a bringing together of all kind of people on a common ground. I don't know of any place that has anything like it. Seems like everyone in town is involved one way or an other. B. A. Sykes, choir director of the Church of God in Christ, was talking about Morristown's Festival on the Green, a week of cultural, educational and entertainment events that will he held from next Saturday through May 16.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Few of the 400 photographs included in Image Before My Eyes at the Jewish Museum would qualify as works of art all by themselves. They are like the individual tesserae of a mosaic which are only little bits of colored stone and glass until they are put together in a certain order. And yet the show as a whole is a work of art of a kind no longer made by painters: a commemorative portrait intended to preserve the memory of a beloved past.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We would like to remove the rough surface on our plaster walls, a surface that was created by the application of a sand finish latex interior paint. What method do you recommend?R.P.M., Flushing, N. Y.

title: POLITICS
description: RALPH G. CASO and John V. N. Klein are pleading for help hut, at least for now, no one seems to be listening. The Nassau and Suffolk Executives sound genuinely concerned when they talk about the fiscal plight of the two counties that has resulted from a combination of skyrocketing social welfare costs and an inflation that has ballooned the normal operating costs of government and the costs of borrowing to finance longterm projects.

title: JAMES STAHIMAN, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: NASHVILLE. May 1 (UPI)James G. Stahlman former publisher and president of The Nashville Banner, died today of a massive stroke. He was 83 years old.

title: PEOPLE
description: WHEN the participants stepped off last Sunday along the route of the Nassau County March Dimes Superwalk '76 Dr. Alvin Kanegis of Westbury was present for the fifth consecutive year to treat any blisters, strains and cramps. Dr. Kanegis, the president of the Podiatry Society of New York, led more than 30 Long Island podiatrists who were stationed at checkpoints along the 20mile route that began in Eisenhower Park. The doctor himself doesn't worry about straining, his feet when he oversees the march. Preparing for his annual stint, he said: I'm taking the car.

title: Picture Books
description: Looking over this new batch of picture books for little children, I rejoice again that there is a market for this sort of thing. Book publishers, of course, have always profited from books that deal with rape and incest, murder and war, but because of the happy fact, that hundreds of thousands of small American consumers keep right on being born and climbing into people's laps to be read to, the publishing business also keeps grinding out products to fit this pintsized market. And this enterprise panders to innocence: it packages mice riding paper airplanes, and magic baseball gloves in jolly colors; and stories that carry the wonderful news that cleverness and goodness will overcome evil in the end.

title: Spring in Seefeld: For Sore City Eyes
description: The whole world has discovered SeefeldinTyrol by now, courtesy of the Winter Olympics and satellite TV. But my first encounter with this mountain village came last spring, via the printed page. Specifically, in a paragraph of a 1962 British guidebook called Austria, by an author with the doubly simian name of Monk Gibbon.

title: Simplicity of Science
description: Physicists have begun questioning one of the fundamental postulates of modern science, the notion that nature is inherently simple at the most basic level and that the seeming complexity at any given moment is merely the consequence of man's ignorance. One theoretical physicist speaking at the recent American Physical Society meeting in Washington suggested that the ultimate reality may turn out to be as chaotic the most unstructured of Jackson Pollock's paintings.

title: What Makes Barbara Walters Worth a Million?
description: Dinner was franks and beans, the house specialty, a carryover perhaps from humbler times. But it came with candlelight and a good Bordeaux, and Barbara Walters spoke of never having to confront again her old demon, insecurity. One might have expected manic conversation from a hardworking woman who had just struck it rich, but instead she was reflective in a muted tone that seemed out of character with her aggressive, and even at times shrill, television persona.

title: Design: The national ALA. awards
description: The jury entrusted with selecting this year's American Institute of Architects Honor Awards  a prestigious accolade given, this time, to six of 500 submissions the awards will be presented Wednesday at the A.I.A. convention, in Philadelphia) came out of the selection process with no clear sense of where American architecture stands. Said the jury's report: The old formulas are no longer valid. Walls become opaque while roofs are transparent; much equipment becomes decoration while structural systems are hidden. Form follows function, so long as it has a form, or function follows form. It doesn't seem to make much difference. We are in a searching period, questioning the rules, purposefully breaking from convention. There is no direction that is right, and no direction that is wrong.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Jewish Singles a New Problem After Years of Focus on Family
description: We have no traditions by which to be guided, Rabbi Eugene Sack said, We're really at the beginning of dealing with the problem.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK SPATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION raised the price of sheet steel by 6 percent and most other steel companies followed suit. WheelingPittsburgh, which earlier announced an 8 percent Increase trimmed it back to 6 percent. President Ford had said he would ask the Council on Wage and Price Stability to look Into the WheelingPittsburgh rise Citicorp lowered Its prime rate to 6 percent from 6 percent The Composite Index of Leading Indicators dropped 0.4 percent In March to 105.1 [1967=100] the first decline in five months.

title: Factory Noise Is Unions Targets
description: CHICAGO HEIGHTS, III Studies show that excessive noise can bring anxiety, bizarre bodily sensations, and personality disintegration  decibel longexposure level now sanctioned by Federal interim regulations or the much quieter 85 decibels demanded by major unions and recommended by the Environmental Protection Agency. reductions that unions seek are in general either technologically or economically Infeasible and that adequate protection can be obtained from regelar use of earplugs or earphonelike earmuffs.

title: POLITICS
description: FOR most of this century, political parties in New Jersey have been precluded from endorsing candidates in primary elections. The assumption was that the party's official support in a primary would virtually preempt the field, thereby giving the organizationbacked candidate an unfair advantage over insurgents.

title: Bold Forbes, 31, Captures Kentucky Derby by a Length
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 Angel Cordero calls him my Puerto Rican RollsRoyce, but even Cordero didn't know until today at Churchill Downs just how much horsepower Bold Forbes could generate.

title: The TV Kid
description: Lennie is a television junkie. When not actually getting a tube fix, he lives in anticipation of the next one. Friendless and lonely, he inhabits a spacedout fantasy world of advertising jingles, series reruns, and game shows from which he will emerge the Big Winner. His mother scratches an offseason living from their resort motel and frets over Lennie's neglected studies, especially science. (His test results have been running a dismal gamut from 23 to 59.)

title: GUY GABRIELSON, G.O.P. FIGURE, DIES
description: Guy George Gabrielson, who as Republican national chairman opened the 1952 Republican National Convention in Chicago that nominated General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency, died yesterday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: MAINE CONVENTION FAVORS PRESIDENT
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 1 Maine Republicans elected 20 delegates to the national convention today, ostensibly with uncommitted labels, but at least 14 of the delegates were said to favor President Ford.

title: Greek Who Tried To Kill Junta Chief Dies in Car Crash
description: ATHENS, May 1 (UPI)Alexandros Panagoulis, who was once convicted of having tried to assassinate George Papadopolos, the former junta leader, was killed in an automobile accident today. He was 87.

title: DINING OUT
description: OFTEN, in my experience, the fewer the selections on the menu, the better the chances of a good meal. The Joshua Tree is a case in point. It's strictly steak, roast beef and lobster tails here. This is link in the Marriott chain and for a large, popularpriced restaurant, the quality is commendable.

title: Major League Baseball
description: New York 3, Houston 1. Chicago 5, San Francisco 2. Cincinnati 7, Montreal 2. Los Angeles 5, St. Louis 1. Pittsburgh 4, San Diego 3.

title: Humphrey Reports Rockefeller Rejected Role as Running Mate
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota said today he had offered Nelson A. Rockefeller the VicePresidential spot on the Democratic ticket in 1968 and the Vice President confirmed the offer had been made and rejected.

title: Police Seek Aid From Public in Search for Slayers of Doctor in Park
description: The big redbrick and stucco house at Foster Avenue and Westminister Road in Brooklyn was dark and shuttered yesterday, and a small card taped to the front door informed callers: Doctor's office closed.

title: If You Go
description: to Jekyll, you can fly nonstop to Jacksonville, Fla., rent a car and drive 60 miles due north on Interstate 95 to the island. You'll want a car there anyway. Or fly via Atlanta to Brunswick, Ga., and the Jekyll people will pick you up. If you come from the north by car, drive down I95 to Brunswick and take the causeway to Jekyll. If you have a private plane, you can land at Jekyll's private airstrip. If you have a yacht, you can come by way of the inland waterway.

title: Carey Asks for a New Agency To Stress Consumer Advocacy
description: ALBANY. May 1Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to create a new Division of Consumer Advocacy with the power to represent consumers before other agencies, but without the broad regulatory and rulemaking powers the Governor sought unsuccessfully for a consumer agency last year.

title: Postman Rings Often for Legislators
description: WHEN Frank Hague was Mayor of Jersey City and the undisputed boss of New Jersey, his inner circle had a code to assure that letters sent to City Hall would get his personal attention. The code called for putting a postage stamp on the back of the envelope, rather than on the addressed side, and all letters so received were given priority by Mr. Hague.

title: Geoffrey Michael Weds Miss Brinster
description: Margaret Walton Brinster, danghter Of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Brinster of Princeton, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Geoffrey Townsend Hichael, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Robert Michael of Fox Chapel, Pa., formerly of Princeton.

title: Scotland Yard's School for Dogs Has Criminals Barking Up the Wrong Tree
description: A rash of purse snatchings and muggings in London's Hyde Park shortly after World War II was giving Scotland Yard no end of trouble. A decision was made to use dogs to help apprehend the assailants, recalled Benjamin Wainson, chief inspector of the Metropolitan Police Dog Training School. With a halfdozen Labrador retrievers and officers, we started a trialanderror program. In industry, it would have been called onthejob training. It proved so effective that a section was set up in 1948.

title: A Necessary End
description: In his prefatory note to A Necessary End, Nathaniel Benchley writes, This is the story of one extremely small unit in a way that is hearsay to a whole generation A few lines later, The men at the lower levels have no sense of global strategy; they have, very simply, the fervent hope they will survive the twin enemies of man: hostile action. and boredom. How they survive or don't survive the twin enemies is the subject of his story.

title: To Probe $2 Bill Ads
description: David McDonald, Assistant Secretary or the Treasury for Enforcement, Operational and Tariff Affairs, has announced that his office has requested a Federal Trade Commission investigation into certain advertising promotions for the $2 bill which was reintroduced into circulation April 13. His official announcement follows: The Columbia Mint of Washington, D.C. ran several fullpage advertisements in nationally distributed newspapers, beginning on March 28, advertising the sale of official firstdayofissue $2 bill philatelicnumismatic folio collectors items. The items offered by the Columbia Mint are in no way connected with the Department of the Treasury. The department neither encourages nor endorses the sale of these items. Because the Columbia Mint's advertisements state that the firm is issuing the $2 billfolios through the cooperation of the Treasury Department, I have referred this matter to the Federal Trade Commission for consideration and review of the possibility of misleading advertising.

title: American League
description: Kansas City 4, New York 1 (n.).

title: The Little Engine That Did
description: It has been 50 years now since The Little Engine That Could first went puff puff, chug chug up that hill to glory; that's a lot of I think I cans out the smokestack (and over 5 million copies sold). To commemorate this cultural milestone Platt & Munk has brought out a largesized Golden Anniversary Edition, ($3.95) charmingly illustrated by Ruth Sanderson though not as childhandy as the old one with its pawky, little pictures.

title: Armstrong, With 69 for 136 Leads Houston Open by Shot
description: HOUSTON, May 1Wally Armstrong copes with pressure by ignoring it, by paying no attention to what other players are doing. Cruising through the second round of the raindelayed Houston open this afternoon, he did not make a mistake until the 17th hole, when a spectator called, Armstrong, you've got two shots!

title: Prudence Schlesinger Bride of Douglas Adler
description: Prudence Schlesinger and Douglas Ochs Adler were married yesterday noon in the South Presbyterian Church, in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. Swann of the South Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Almus M. Thorp Jr. of St. Francis Episcopal Church in Potomac, Md.

title: The Mother of The American AvantGarde Film
description: The gospel of the lowbudget, personal, experimental film was first preached in this country by an explosive, dedicated young woman named Maya Deren. From the early 1940's until her death in 1961 Miss Deren both invoked and exemplified the American avantgarde move ??? ??? ??? ???as filmmaker, distributor, lecturer, ??? and promoter, all in one fiery personality. in the 15 years since her death, hundreds of new experimental filmmakers have shown their films around the country; yet in contrast to modern music dance, architecture, and painting, the avant  garde film has re mained almost invisible to the American public. This week, a series of avantgarde films at The Museum of Modern Art ushers in what may he a new era of visibility.

title: An American Seeks Business in Arabia
description: JEDDAH, Saudi ArabiaLong horned cattle scattered, and Arab laborers stared as a column of hulking steel vehicles rumbled inland earlier this month from the turquoise edge of the Red Sea.

title: A Few Pests and Diseases May Be Trouble For Trees This Year
description: My tree had a severe disease last year. Will it have the same problem this year? What other tree diseases can I expect? Will they be as serious as they were last year?

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices moved fitfully in the equities and credit markets last week: up somewhat early in the period but closing on Friday below where they stood last Monday.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article The Businessman versus The Journalist (Mar. 7 was plain silly.

title: Social Announcements
description: Engagements

title: DueDiligence, BarreraTrained, Pays $12.40 in Aqueduct Victory
description: Harbor View Farm's Due Diligence, who had shown last March that he didn't mind an off track, raced to victory yesterday in the $56,350 Carter Handicap at rainsoaked Aqueduct.

title: In Most Cases It's Not Dirt
description: When white or light colored paints develop dark looking, discolored stains that look like dirt, more often than not the trouble is not dirt at allit is mildew. Mildew can develop on painted surfaces only weeks after they have been freshly coated, or it may not show up until two or Three years after the paint has been applied.

title: Medical Nemesis
description: The great steelandglass structures of our hospitals, medical centers and research institutesthe new cathedrals of industrialized societyrear up on our urban skylines from Stockholm to Wichita, and in the developing world as well. Inside, brigades of physicians and armies of technologists command computers, rebuild our bodies with scalpel and graft, make molecules dance to order, preside over incredibly complex machines that breathe for us, or pump blood or wash our innermost cells. They are defying death, and conquering disease and disability.

title: DOCTOR CHALLENGED ON HIS CREDENTIALS
description: ATLANTA, May 1A Georgia physician with 22 years of experience, who has been a member of the state's Board of Medical Examiners for the last 12 years, has been removed from office pending an investigation into allegations that he obtained his medical degree through fraudulent documents.

title: Yankees Records
description: Yankees Records

title: Islanders Lose, Fall Behind, 30
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May By scoring three goals in the final period tonight, the swift Montreal Canadiens beat the Islanders, 32, and placed the New Yorkers in the kind of perilous situation they know only too well.

title: Ch. Baba Is Named Best Dog
description: ERWINNA, Pa, May 1An unusual dog won an unusual trophy today at the 35th show of the Bucks County Kennel Club at Tinicum Park. The dog was a komondor, Ch, Sununithill Baba, and the trophy was the Philadelphia Bowl, a beautiful piece of WedgeWood, a collector's item, commemorating the nation's Bicentennial.

title: Footing Is Firmer as W.T.T. Slips Into Its Third Season
description: Q. How strong is World Team Tennis?

title: Bringing Back the Biennale
description: I've already booked a room at Cipriani's, and I'll see you at Harry's Bar, said a New York art dealer, elated over the news that the Venice Biennale will probably be staged again this year.

title: HOUSE MOVE BEGUN TO RESTORE MEDAL
description: Washington, May 1 (AP)Two members of Congress want the Medal of Honor restored to Dr. Mary Walker, a surgeon who won it in the Civil War and was the only woman ever to have received it.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mats will play the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium at 8:05 P.M. Tuesday and Wednesday and 4:05 P.M. Thursday. Then they will meet the San Diego Padres at 8:05 P.M. Friday and 2:15 P.M. Saturday. The Yankees are on the road all week.

title: The Recommendations Rely on the Constitution
description: For more than a year this country's intelligence agencies have been the focus of sensational disclosures, strong criticism, and powerful defense. Last week the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, ending its investigation, tried to put the issues into a more studied and philosophical perspective. It was the perspective of the American Constitution.

title: Giants Beat Cubs, 31; 2 in Brawl Ejected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (AP)Chris Speier's triple and Bobby Murcer's single in the eighth inning broke a 11 tie and led San Francisco to a 31 victory over Chicago today in a game marred by a pair of benchclearing brawls that resulted in the ejections of Jose Cardenal and Bill Madlock of the Cubs.

title: Zenas and the Shaving Mill
description: The year is 1780. Zenas Coffin, alone at the helm of the Lively Abbytwixt Falmouth and Nantucketis running for his life. Smuggling, that's what the boy is doing Potatoes and onions mostly, for his hungry Quaker kinfolk. The wind's against him. An American privateer, called a shaving millis after him. If the shaving mill doesn't get him, some British manofwar will. Quakers, being pacifists, are fair game for both sides. Zenas, in an unarmed sloop, must lead the shaving mill aground. While doing this, he tellsin prose or poetry, it's a little hard to saywhat can only be caned the story of his life.

title: MARCHERS PROTEST TRIP BY KISSINGER
description: South Africa's racial policies, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and American companies operating in South Africa were all condemned yesterday during an antiapartheid ??? at Broadway and 34th Street.

title: Letters: The Obsession Of a Cricketer at Sea
description: To the Editor: Your article on cricket, A Googly Won't Get You to First Base (Travel Section, April 11), was particularly refreshing to us Englishmen playing in the orchestra aboard the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line's Song of Norway sailing out of Miami. What a game! And what reading to an Englishman in an American newspaper!

title: Rutgers's Critical Basketball Coach and What He Really Meant
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Amana Sues Consumers Union
description: Microwave ovens are at the heart of a controversy that's erupted between Amanaa major producer of the ovensand Consumers Union, the nation's bestknown product tester and publisher of Consumer Reports magazine.

title: Never To Forget
description: Milton Meltzer's book is an act of desperationan act of piety and pity, wrath and love, despair and homage; but the motive force, the terrible sense of urgency which drives and animates it, is desperation. In an atterword, he notes that an authoritative study of American high school history textbooks, conducted nearly 30 years after World War II, revealed that their treatment of Nazism was brief, bland, superficial, and misleading, that racism, antiSemitism, and the Holocaust were ignored or dismissed in a few lines, and that textbooks designed for colleges and universities were not substantially better. Darkness, said the historian Golo Mann, hides the vilest crime ever perpetrated by man against man.

title: In the Tremont Area, a White Family That Didn't Flee Is Content
description: Not far from where Anne and Henry Kallem live in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, neighborhoods like theirs are undergoing the strains of racial transition. But for the Kallems, comfortable in their 13room Victorian frame house on quiet Mount Hope Place, the crisis has passed.

title: Will You Sign Here, John Hancock?
description: The pantheon of the Founding Fathers is a daunting place. Crowded with idealized statuary, swept by the drafts of legend and infested with humbugs, it challenges honesty at every turn. Refreshing, then, to come upon this nicely executed miniportrait of John Hancock, whose chief claim to our Bicentennial attention is the size of his signature on the Declaration of Independence. Hancock wrote his name so boldly that it entered the vernacular as a synonym for signature. George the Third can read that without his spectacles! is what history tells us he said.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: BOLD FORBES WINS KENTUCKY DERBY: Angel Cordero guiding Bold Forbes across the finish line with Honest Pleasure (15) finishing second. Details appear in Section 5.

title: The lives of two novelists
description: Jessamyn West, by temperament a novelist, has in her books rung innumerable changes on the lives of characters based on her large, originally Quaker, family in California. The dynamic mother, Grace; the partIndian father, Eldo; the glamorous sister, Carmenthese, among others, readers have come to know as friends, real people. Yet Miss West does something a little different from portraying real people. Truth is stranger than fiction, but what makes the lives of her characters strange and wonderful lies in something more than in their being real.

title: Centrowitz Ahead Of Training Pace
description: Most of the athletes invited to the United States Olympic Trials in June will be housed in dormitories on the campus of the University of Oregon. But Matt Centrowitz of the Bronx will have more comfortable quarters during the trials  his own apartment in Eugens.

title: Letters
description: If Colette Dowling (Getting out, March 28) saw nothing but juiced and exuberant dancers, whacked out on booze, sitting on the islands of Broadway, her vision will be equally opaque if she returns [from Rhinebeck]. As a resident since 1950, who plans to stay, I have participated in the community life of a unique neighborhood which is still an intellectual and social dynamo. It is, indeed like much of the city, falling into anguish and despair. The island sitters are the most despairing of all.

title: Obscurity Now Cloaks Thieu Aides
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The police chief runs a restaurant. The ambassador has come home. The president lives in a row house in a London suburb. The general is still at the Pentagon.

title: GARDENING
description: REOENT articles referring to certain problems inherent in the sandy soils of the Island have brought responses from gardeners seeking more complete information on handling problems associated with these soils. Since spring is the time of soil preparation for most planting, this is an appropriate time to reply.

title: She's Mistress of Every Medium
description: She enters in a gown of cherry red, all ruffles and fringe, and for an instant she seems the perfect romantic heroine, ready to blush prettily at the drop of a flattering remark. But soon it is clear that the young woman in question is an emotional cripple whose own talents have been suppressed or undermined in honor of her dead mother's memory. In the words of her cruelly domineering father, she is a mediocre and defenseless creature without a shred of poise.

title: Festival Gives Youths Chance on Stage
description: Teenagers interested in the theater will have a monthlong opportunity to learn and to perform during the second citywide Youth Theater Festival, which started yesterday.

title: White Sox Honor Fox
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)The Chicago White Sox today retired the No. 2 Jersey of Nellie Fox, the second baseman, who died of cancer last December. It was only the second number retired in White Sox history, The other was No. 4 worn by Luke Appling, the Hall of Fame shortstop.

title: D'Oyly Carte Tradition vs. The Hot Mikado
description: Ever since 1879, when the Pinafore craze swept the country and the number of H.M.S. Pinafore produc tions reached epidemic proportions, New York has been a second home for the Gilbert and Sullivan operas.

title: Four Biographies
description: The truth in a biography hangs on a slim thread. One small fictional tug and the strand is broken. Knotted up again, it can never be completely trusted. In order to keep the truth pure, biographers often believe they must forsake lyrical or poetic prose, substituting instead a workmanlike style that tells the plain facts but little else. Yet biography can be beautifully written: persuasive, lyric, moving. Boswell and Churchill were prose stylists as well as accurate reporters, and put their subjects like diamonds into a crown.

title: In Kingsbridge Manor, Residents Are Struggling to Maintain the Balance
description: Since its construction at the turn of the century, Kingsbridge Manor, a dignified neighborhood of private homes in the northwest Bronx, has always been stable and serene. Few, if any, owners came here expecting to find themselves living on an outpost. But that is the situation they find themselves in today.

title: The Fishing Clinic
description: Every, year at this time, a spate of letters arrives asking what gear to use when surf fishing for striped bass or bluefish in the northeast.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Economic Indicators

title: Editors Choice
description: BLOODSHED, by Cynthia Ozick. (Knopf, $6.95.) The title story and three novellas by an adventurous writer with a lot on her mind and a feeling for life as mystery and riddle.DETAILS OF A SUNSET, by Vladimir Nabokov. (McGrawHill. $8.95.) Stories, 19241935, much concerned with exile and loss, yet exhilarating in their verbal play, perversities of plot and black humor.

title: DINING OUT
description: SOME time ago, a reader complained that a favorite restaurant of his had been ignored while another place, L'Affaire, had been mentioned several times. Well, it is going to be mentioned again.

title: Producing and reproducingA Chorus Line
description: It is a day in midMarch, and deep in the bowels of New York's City Center, Michael Bennett, the 33yearold exchorus boy, has just been teaching a complicated sequence of jazz and ballet steps from A Chorus Line to 60 young dancersduplicate and triplicate Cassies, Zachs, Sheilas, Vats, Pauls, Bobbys, Dianas and Company. The dancers have collapsed onto chairs, sweating and panting, for a fiveminute break, and Bennett is alone, now, on the shiny, bare, black floor that serves as the stage in the vast rehearsal hall. Unselfconscious, he faces the long, mirrored wall and does a taut and graceful stepbrushhopstepturn. It is a slight variation on the sequence he has been teaching the 60 dancers. Although he choreographed that combination many months ago and the Broadway company has been performing it at the Shubert Theater since last fall, something about it has suddenly bothered him.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: BOSTONOn the wall outside the office there's a picture of Vince Lombardi and the tough guy's account of What It Takes To Be No. 1.

title: Pay attention, turkeys!
description: It is a moneymaker that has so far turned out 75,000 mostly enthusiastic graduates, each of whom paid $250 for 60 hours of training and probably more for additional followup seminars. And its charismatic leader is able to draw crowds in the thousands. But after four years of success and growing national fame, as more people are taking a closer look, est (Erhard Seminars Training), is becoming increasingly controversial.

title: Mets May Day: Rain
description: Currently on a sevengame winning streak and leading the National League East race after their best April ever, the New York Mets were rained out of their first game in May yesterday. The postponed contest against the Houston Astros will be played today in Shea Stadium as part of a doubleheader beginning at 1:05 P.M.

title: Barrera Proves A Triple Threat
description: Laz Barrera, the Cuban  born trainer, had a big day yesterday. His horses won three major stakes. races in three states: Bold Forbes in the $217,700 Kentucky Derby, Life's Hope in the $129,075 Illinois Derby and Due Diligence in the $56,350 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Emerson H. Miller Jr. Will Wed Arielle Wolflisberg
description: Mrs. Hans Joseph Wolflisberg of Southbury, Conn., has announced that her daughter, Arielle Amalie Wolflisberg, and Emerson Huxley Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Cincinnati, will be married on June 19.

title: Endpaper
description: Lawyer advertising is not new. Lawyers have always managed to find indirect ways to get themselves known. Some represent controversial clients, then hold press conferences and go on television. Others write best sellers about their lives in court or their readiness for the defense.

title: Au Revoir to Sag Harbor
description: SAG HARBOR THINGS are getting back to normal here after 24 youngsters returned to AixenProvence, France, following three weeks as guests in the homes and schools of Eastern Long Island teenagers who had visited them in France.

title: Waterbury Vehicles Faulty
description: WATERBURY, Conn., May 1 (AP) The Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles says 17 of the city's 19 Street Department vehicles are defective and 12 of them should not be used. Department vehicles inspected Thursday at the request of the city's Blue Coital Union include pickup trucks, dunin trucks rind pavioaders.

title: The Remarkable Ride Of Israel Bissell
description: Here's how one nearly9 described this book:

title: Expert on Cars Prefers to Bike
description: PRINCETON ENOCH J. DURBIN has never built the better mousetrap. But if he ever started to, it would be only a short order for a man who already has invented a better tennis racquet and a device that works better than a carburetor.

title: Lining Up on the Issues
description: THE unpopularity of busing to promote racial integration in public schools now cuts across virtually every economic, ideological and age groun on the Island.

title: Lonely Heart Suppers
description: Major food processors are testing the single serving market.

title: A Room of His Own
description: When I was very young my family occupied two floors of a modest fourstory house, close to Amsterdam's RykMuseum and not far from Wilhelmina Park. I had a room of my own on the top floor. The room was at the end of a long corridor. The door next to mine opened into an enormous attic filled with trunks, suitcases, crates, broken furniture, discarded toys and, during the summer months, my sled and skates. There was laundry hanging from ropes strung across. I seem to remember that one corner of the attic was more orderly than the rest an island of sortsan imaginary room within a room. I see a bed, a dresser and a chair, neatly arranged against nonexistent walls. I believe that a young woman slept there. I seem to recognize the smell of soap, cheap cologne, starchy aprons, and pink cheeks and fluffy blond hair. And forbidden mysteries which, before sleep haunted my pounding heart.

title: Comment: New Boy on a Burning Deck
description: When the Titanic has already hit the iceberg, its a little late to fire the captain.

title: Shirley's Beau Is Victor; Young Quinn Withdrawn
description: YONKERS, May 1Overcoming a driving rain and a waterlogged track, Shirley's Beau splashed home tonight as the winner of the richest harness purse in the nation thus far this year, the $75,000 Old Glory Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Pro Softball Debut May 28
description: The establishment of the International Women's Professional Softball Association has caused mixed, if not strong, reactions among sports enthusiasts who applaud the formaLion of a women's pro league, but are uncertain of its chances for survival.

title: L. J. Pugatch Fiance Of Marjorie A. Berg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell J. Berg of Kings Point. L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Ann Berg to Leonard Joseph Pugatch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Pugatch of New York and Hallandale, Fla.

title: Guerney Hurt in Crash
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 1 (AP)Chuck Guerney was listed in satisfactory condition today at Terre Haute Regional Hospital after his car flipped over on the last lap of the 40lap Hulman Classic. He's all right, said Dr. Manuel Cacdac. He suffered a few minor burns. We're going to take some Xrays to make sure nothing is broken.

title: A Day on the Ocean
description: IT was 6 o'clock on Saturday morning, but the party boats already were chugging down the the channel toward the ocean, loaded with anglers who believe that it is the early worm that catches the fish.

title: Calling the Signals From Jay,
description: AMID the welter of tracks that carry everybody's favorite railroad between Woodside and the East River Tunnel sits a stolid, ugly, brick structure with a sign on its side that says: Harold.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR two decades the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been at the center of assorted corporate dramas. There were the failures with the Electra turboprop in the 1950's, the Central Intelligence Agency links with the U2 spy plane, the huge cost overruns on the C5A military transport, the crashprone F104's in West Germany, the cliffhanger on marketing the widebodied L1011 jetliner with RollsRoyce engines, the extraordinary Governmentguaranteed loan in 1971 to avert bankruptcy and the continuing battle to achieve financial viability, given a grotesque burden of debt.

title: Cosmos and Pele Return Today for Yankee Stadium Opener
description: The successful show the New York Cosmos and Pel have displayed throughout the nation will open at Yankee Stadium at 2 o'clock this afternoon. It will be the first soccer game at the Stadium since its renovation, and it will cost the Cosmos almost as much as it cost to play the whole last season at Randalls Island.

title: Domestic Intelligence
description: The report on domestic activities of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence reveals a past pattern of governmental lawlessness.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In most companies an employee who feels he has been wronged has little recourse. He can go to his boss, who may be the source of the problem, he can go over his boss's head, which may pay off in the short term, he can suffer silently or he can quit.

title: Elise Catharine Wed in Suburbs To J. L. Johnson
description: Elise Holliday Catharine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Catharine Jr. of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to James Larry Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Loammi Johnson of Ramseur, N. C.

title: The Rolling Stones of Teaneck
description: TEANECK IT looked as if a party was in progress at the Joseph Stone house. There were cars in the driveway and at the foot of the sloping lawn, along the street. tra, and next Saturday they will he the guests of honor at the sixth annual Allegro Ball, a dinnerdance to be held at the Edgewood Country Club in River Vale. The ball is a benefit for the orchestra.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The Second of a Series

title: Carpet Concerns Agree to Bar Unfair and Deceptive Practices
description: The Federal Trade Commission has announced its acceptance of a consent agreement with the Kaufman Carpet Company and two carpet inspection concerns in which all three are prohibiting from using certain unfair and deceptive practices.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Ronald Kadin makes a good point in his article, What's Under the Rock at the Bottom of the Budget? [(Anion page, April 18]. The Nassau Infclget, now close to $1, billion dollarsa year, does indeed merit closer scristiny. But not only by County officials; residents of Nassau County also have a vital role to play.

title: Welfare: Use of Computer Is Helping
description: VIVID green letters and numbers begin to appear on the milkwhate glass of the video screen. They run like frightened bugsrapidly and squigglinglyfrom left to right. trols, the less the fraud. Our object is to set up as many controls as possible.

title: 20 Leading Citizens Average 81% in Times History Test
description: A panel of 20 prominent Americans in fields from major league baseball to politics scored almost 50 percent higher than college freshmen did on the 24 basic questions in the New York Times American history survey.

title: U.S. Climber in Britain Dies
description: BRISTOL, England, May 1 (Reuters)Stephen Blake, an American student at Oxford who was injured in a ??? accident here Wednesday, died in a hospital here last night. The 20yearold Mr. Blake, of Port Byron, N. Y., and Jonathan Gross, 19, of New Jersey, fell 100 feet to the bottom of Avon Gorge, a landmark here. Mr. Gross was killed in the fall. They had been climbing the gorge with 20yearold Thomas Beaton, of Lincoln, Mass., who was unhurt. All attended Oxford.

title: New Novel
description: Liberty Tavern (known before 1776 as Stranger's Resort) is a New Jersey inn from which Thomas Fleming looks into the hearts and minds of some patriots and poltroons caught up in the Revolution. The author of 1776: Year of Illusions seems to delight in pointing out the paradoxes that underlie politics. His protagonist is Jonathan Gifford, the tavern's owner, an excaptain in a Brit ish Infantry regiment to whom life has dealt some hard knocks. Gifford is a moderate and decent man, which makes it hard for him to live with the local vigilantes who use patriotism as a screen for spite. It also widens the schism between Gifford and his stepson. Kemble, an idealistic nothead who confuses his father's realism with cynicism.

title: Another Upheaval Rocks the Big Board
description: Can a 66yearold former merchandiser save the embattled citadel of capitalism?

title: Iran Hotel Blast Kills 24
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 1 (AP) A hotel on the PakistaniIranian border exploded, killing 24 Pakistani nationals, according to news reports here. Teheran newspapers said the explosion, on Wednesday, in Zahedi was caused by gun powder Pakistani travellers had brought into ???. The powder was to be sold for use in fire crackers.

title: The Taylor Law Fits. Everyone
description: THE prolonged impasse over the 1975 contract for the Nassau County Police highlights some serious, basic flaws in Taylor Law provisions for labor negotiations in the public sector, a set of volatile circumstances that have been and will continue to be detrimental to the interest of the public, the county, the police department, and the individual police officers.

title: Conflict Laws and Their Limitations
description: The practical and political difficulties of living up to the demands of what is called the postWatergate era have been clearly demonstrated by Governor Carey's yearlong effort to require full financial disclosure of high officials in his executive departments. The disclosure effort has already met with open bureaucratic resistance and court challenges, and figured in the controversy that preceded the resignation last week of state Environmental Conservation Commissioner Ogden Reid.

title: Playoff Results
description: W.H.A. Playoffs

title: Rose for RunnerUp From the Winner
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 Angel Cordero Jr. swept into the jockeys room at old Churchill Downs wearing red silks and a milewide smile and carting an immense bouquet of red roses, called Braulio and bestowed one of the longstemmed beauties on Braulio Baezathe man he had just beaten in the sizzling Kentucky Derby.

title: Fiction Apparently by Hughes Is Found
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 (AP)Efforts to judge the authenticity of a purported will of Howard R. Hughes have brought to light a crudely written manuscript that is possibly a draft of a novel by the late billionaire.

title: Minority Workers Gain In Higher U.S. Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)Although the overall number of nonwhites in the Federal work force is decreasing, the number of minority workers employed in higher grade Government jobs is rising, according to a study by the Civil Service Commission.

title: Testimony on a Bank's Search for Security
description: THE trial of the nowdefunct Security National Bank and three of its former top officers on charges of illegally diverting hank funds to political contributions is expected to go to the jury this week. did not resolve the Issues In the trial, it touched on the key questions confronting the jury: Whether the bank officials had been advised by counsel that their plan for political contributions was legal, and whether bank funds had been used for the contributions.

title: Susan Wayne Bride of Stephen G. Weil
description: In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Susan Gusty Wayne and Stephen George Weil, 1974 graduates of George Washington University, were married by the Rev. Charles Mahoney.

title: The Misery of Match Making
description: It hasn't been the brightest of years for one industry whose business is making lights.

title: SENATE IS FACING CLEANAIR CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 A crucial battle in the continuing dispute between major American industries and environmental organizations will begin Tuesday when the Senate takes up a bill to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Book Ends
description: The Book. Back In the dear, dead Watergate days we had the White Rouse tape controversy; now the authors of the smash book about those days, Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, have been faced with what might be called The Source Controversy. That is, some reviewers have complained about the authors practice of putting all the 394 persons interviewed for The Final Days on background  newsmen's parlance for reporting what they were told but not who told them.

title: A Wise Choice For H. H.
description: DALLASTexas provides a better example than most states of how difficult it would have been for Hubert Humphrey to have wrested the Democratic Presidential nomination from Jimmy Carter of Georgia in a latestarting campaign in the last few primaries and for the uncommitted delegates.

title: SCIENCES ACADEMY ADDS 75 MEMBERS
description: WASIHNGTON, May 1The ??? Academy of Sciences this week announced the elec??? ??? 75 new members. Elec??? to the academy is recogni??? of a person's important ??? to scientific ???

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: This is the season that wasthe opera season in New York, anyway. So, as always, statistics are in order. But, first, a comment or two. It was just about a year ago that the Metropolitan Opera announced its reorganization. Schuyler Chapin was out. Anthony Bliss was incontinuing as executive director, and given in addition the title of principal administrative officer. Which meant, of course, that the Metropolitan Opera was dropping the title of general manager. The reorganization involved a troika, with Bliss on top, and James Levine and John Dexter at the bottom. Levine was music director, and Dexter was director of productions.

title: A Stranger In the Mirror
description: In the prologue to this novel of show biz a character pinpoints the exact moment he knew something terrible was about to happen. For him, it was when he saw a damaged wedding cake. For me, it was when I read that New York City was a mecca for the theater. Then, when the author confided that Hollywood was the film capital of the world, it became a certainty that really awful things were in store. For example, an agent whose customers ran the gamut of who's who in the entertainment field. His leading client, Toby Temple, a standup comedian who claws his way to the top of the TV ratings without making real friends. (And the more people there were around him, the lonelier Toby became.)

title: Forum: Canada's Monument to Hockey
description: MONTREALA crowd of 16,461 rises, its attention focused below whore a diminutive, silverhaired gentleman steps onto the ice.

title: Huskies Crewmen Triumph
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1  Northeastern's varsity crew defeated Brown and Columbia today on the Charles River. The Huskie eight defeated a stubborn Brown boat by one length while Columbia trailed 27 seconds behind the victors.

title: Youth Killed, 6 Hurt In Lisbon Explosion At Reds Building
description: LISBON, May 1 One person was killed and six were inured early today when a powertul explosive went off outside a Cminenist Party office, rocking central Lisbon.

title: Modification Urged in Disclosure Order
description: ALBANY, May 1Faced with 700 vacancies on state boards and commissions, Governor Carey is under increasing pressure from within his own administration to modify the strict fiInancialdisclosure requirements that apparently pose the major obstacle to inducing qualified people to take state jobs.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: If there's any field that loves awards more than journalism, it's architecture. Journalism awards are usually a simple, straightforward good job; architecture awards tend to be fraught with cosmic connotations. Every architecture jury comes up with a Where are we going? statement along with the prizes, and an arduous analysis of trends, philosophy, and the present and future state of the building art. Good job can signify the direct solution of a basic building problem or the broadest kind of concern about human and environmental impact. How the profession views its peers and its products is one way of reading the times.

title: Mary Ann Siegel Wed To Louis J. Trotter Jr.
description: Mary Ann Siegel, a lawyer in Washington, and Louis Joseph Trotter Jr., a student at the Yale Law School, were married early yesterday evening at the Clearbrook Clubhouse in Cranbury. N. J. Mayor Peter Garibaldi of Cranbury performed the ceremony.

title: Rules for Water and Toilets For Farm Workers Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May I (AP) The Labor Department has proposed job health standards that would require farmers to provide drinking water and toilet facilities for workers in the field.

title: Spare the Rod, Spoil With Sprinklers
description: If you think the lightningrod business has gone the way of the buggy whip industry, you're wrong. The construction of taller and taller buildings has meant a resurgence in lightningrod installations.

title: The Chief Awards
description: The Chief Awards

title: Take the Money and Run
description: Yanqui Come Home may be the future motto of America's big multinational corporations.

title: Best Father Ever Invented
description: Best Father Ever Invented is the autobiography of Mark Harris, a long attempt to express the terms of a successful career and an unhappy life that also may have been an unsuccessful career and an unhappy life. Harris is best known for Bang the Drum Slowly, a novel he wrote in 67 working days in 1955 because the rejection of another novel that he cared much more about, Something About a Soldier, forced him to retreat to secure. familiar terrain. Bang the Drum Slowly is a charming, funny, affirming hook, and Harris, as he sees himself, has been mostly an acerbic, humorless and corrosive man. Little wonder he hates the terms of his fame, if not the fame itself. Little wonder his autobiography is terribly at war with itself, at once moving, distasteful and inarticulate.

title: Erving Buzzer Shot Is Winner for Nets
description: DENVER, May 1  Julius Erving, who has already found at least a hundred ways of winning games for the New York Nets, found another here tonight and gave the Nets a 120118 victory over the Denver Nuggets in the opening game of the American Basketball Association finals.

title: Kitchen Remedies Will Chase the Bugs.
description: The old home remedies for keeping bugs out of the garden are being rediscovered now that modern chemical insecticides are becoming suspect, and in some instances are no longer effective. Even today's agricultural researchers have found scientific basis for many of the old customs.

title: Linda Rand Married
description: Linda Ann Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Rand of North Babylon, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Gary Anthony Ladolcetta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Ladolcetta of Deer Park, L.I. The Rev. John B. Mulgrew performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Dix Hills, L.I. The bride is an account representative with the Chase Manhattan Bank. Her husband is a management trainee with the Chemical Bank.

title: Hedy Ann Hartman to Be Married
description: Joan M. Hartman and Alan S. Hartman, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter. Hedy Ann Hartman, to Jon Abbott Mersereau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilder Bryant Mersereau of Glen Rock, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Report Urges Curbs on Profit Abuses in Nonprofit Health Care
description: Two Columbia University sociologists have urged legislative and regulatory controls over socalled voluntary or nonprofit health and humanservice institutions to combat profitmaking abuses that are not necessarily frauds.

title: TAX AIDES IN INDIA SEEK GOLD HOARD
description: MEIVAZHICHALAL India Tax men, using pickaxes and bulldozers, are unearthing gold from this desolate South Indian hamlet that has been the exclusive retreat of a sect of holy men.

title: MAYOR GIBSON URGES FUNDSHARING STEPS
description: DENVER, May 1 (UPI)Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark N. J., warned today that time is running out for the nation's cities. He urged the Democratic Platform Committee to stress swift action on revenuesharing.

title: Italy Beats Poland in Davis Cup
description: FLORENCE. Italy, May 1 (AP)Adriano Panatta and Paolo Bertolucci beat Henryk Drzymalski and Jerzi Jasinski 61, 64. 86, today, giving Italy an unbeatable 30 lead over Poland in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition. Italy will face Yugoslavia in the next round.

title: The Bakers
description: Breadmaking is one of those yeasty subjects that lends itself naturally to reflection and anal ysis and, to paraphrase Emily Dickinson, I find it at once one of the simplest yet most complicated of industries enacted in the kitchen. Over the years I don't think any two loaves of identical texture, flavor smell and so on have ever been taken from my oven. Breadmakingexcept for the professional, working according to longestablished formulas, temperature controls, yeast quality and so onis frustrating, tantalizing, gratifying and endlessly challenging.

title: All to Cut Weight After Close Call
description: LANDOVER. Md., May 1 Acknowledging that his world heavyweight boxing championshiphad been in jeopardy against Jimmy Young in a controversial but unanimous 15round decision, Muhammad Ali outlined today trimmer weight objectives for his next three opponentsRienard Dunn of England, a Japanese wrestler named Antonio inoki and Ken Norton.

title: ShortCircuiting Welfare Cheats
description: VIVID green letters and numbers begin to appear on the milk white glass of the video screen. They run like frightened hugs, rapidly. squigglingly, from left to right. They blink off. They blink back on, almost instantaneously, having multiplied many times over in the splitsecond interim, They fill the screen. The letters are arranged in words and abbreviations of words. The numbers appear in neat, tabular form.

title: Kentucky Derby Chart
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: A Child's History Of America
description: This is the book about Ameri ca for the two hundred birthday party of the Bicentennial.

title: Budding Authors Hear
description: MICHAEL AVALLONE sits at the typewriter in his East Brunswick home and writes mystery stories. He has sold well over 30 million paperback copies. John Fitzin likes to write mysteries, too. From his Hasbrouk Heights home, he turns out television scripts and magazine pieces. He hasn't sold one.

title: Vivian Lyons Married To Patrick S. Hernon
description: Vivian Farrar Lyons of Pelham, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to Patrick Sheridan Hernon. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N. Y., by the Rev. David Hoag.

title: ART
description: GREENVALE ADVERSITY often fosters a kind of unexpectedly distinctive achievement; such is the case with the current exhibition at the C. W. Post Art Gallery of Long Island University's C. W. Post Center.

title: Hollywood Has Seen the FutureAnd Hopes It Works
description: Los ANGELES Steven Spielberg, the young director who made Jaws, the 1975 hit that was the most financially successful motion picture ever, is now filming his next projectClose Encounters of the Third Kindand instead of focusing on a killer shark, it is about Unidentified Flying Objects.

title: Infidels
description: Fidel Castro generally has nasty things to say about poets: In our countries we've always had poets who did nothing for the revolution but later jumped on the bandwagon while still in exile and then wrote the words for the national anthem. In effect, many will recall the cruel treatment that the Cuban regime gave to the young poet Heberto Padilla, author of mildly surreptitious poems that a local literary commissar took to be counterrevolutionary. Fidel, who often delights in turning his bureaucracies on their collective ear, did not disagree this time with the underlings and called Padilla a traitor. What Castro was talking about in the above remarks, and in that extraordinary homily of 1961 entitled Words to the Intellectuals, was the conflict between the opposing dominions of poetry and power, between the apparent indiscipline and unreliable wealth of the poetic imagination and the exigencies of raison d'ett.

title: A Library's Reply to Censors
description: COPIES of the books that were recently removed from Island Trees school libraries have been put on display in the Merrick Public Library, under a sign that asks Have you read these hooks?, a letter from Governor Carey ??? Library Week and a poster declaring, Free People, Free Libraries. been planned for National Library Week, April 4 to 10, but the director of the Merrick library decided to keep them on display in conjunction with the banned books, which included two Pulitzer Prize winners Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse Five,and Laughing Boy, by Oliver LaFarge  because she was disturbed when Island Trees remove the books from the school library shelves.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There's a curious locution used frequently toward the end of David Rabe's Streamers, together with one unexpected epithet, that no one seems to have called attention to. The locution and the epithet may both be important in trying to grasp the metaphor that Mr. Rabe has been struggling to capture in his fist during his constantly promising but thus far unsolidified young career.

title: SADAT BIDS SYRIA EXTEND U.N. FORCE
description: CAIRO, May 1President Anwar elSadat made an implied appeal to Syria today to renew the mandate of United Nations peacekeeping forces on the Golan Heights. The present mandate is to expire at the end of the month.

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, May 1When Angel Cordero rode back toward the winner's circle, wave upon wave of applause rolled out from the bulging old stands of Churchill Downs. The jockey had the reins in his left hand and he held his right out in front of him, jabbing the forefinger down toward his mount's head. Applaud him, the gesture said. He did it. Bold Forbes. The cheering swelled, and Cordero brandished his red cap high.

title: Jersey Backers of Jackson Released
description: NEWARK, May 1The chairman of Senator Henry M. Jackson's Presidential campaign organization in New Jersey released pledged delegates from their commitment to the Washington Democrat today and several of them immediately lumped ahoard Jimmy Carter's bandwagon.

title: SCHOOLAID DATA ASKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 1Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority ???, said today that the State Education Department was failing in its responsibility to give the Legislature and the Governor accurate information about state aid to local schools.

title: Miss Reeves Plans To Wed Next Year
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donal C. Reeves of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Reeves, to Kevin Martin Morrissey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Morrissey of Bayside Hills, Oucens.

title: REX O'MALLEY DIES; STAGE, FILM ACTOR
description: Rex O'Malley. Britishhorn actor who had featured roles in films with John and Lionel Barrymore as well as with Greta Garbo in Camille, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, where he had lived for the last three years. He was 75 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAN JUAN (PRMMI), San Juan May 3; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill a West Bank Arab Protester
description: NAZARETH, Israel, May 1 (AP)Soldiers shot and killed an Arab protester in the occupied West Bank of Jordan today as new violence erupted throughout the territory, the Israeli military command said.

title: Rosalind G. Lidstone Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herrick Kenley Lidstone of Pelham, N.Y., and Slater, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosalind Grace Lidstone, to Alan Swain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Swain of London.

title: Clamma Dale Won't Settle for Spirituals
description: When I was preparing my program, I thought about including spirituals, says Clamma Dale, the soprano who, as winner of the 1975 Naumburg Award, gives her debut recital tomorrow night at Tully Hall. I love spirituals; they're beautiful songs. But I think many black singers come under pressure to include them just because they're black. I'm insulted when white singers say to me that Marian Anderson never came into her own until she sang them. When Paul Robeson died, people forgot he sang Chinese and Russian songs in their original languagethe television obituaries showed him singing Let My People Go.

title: Antonia du Pont Bayard Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Asheton Bayard of Greenville, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Antonia du Pont Bayard, to Milford Lewis Phinney 2d. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Milford Phinney of Medina, N.Y.

title: No More Tickets To AllStar Game
description: PHILADELPHIA. May 1 (UPI)The Philadelphia Phillies have announced that no seats are left for the July 21 AllStar baseball game and that the mailorder sale of tickets to the game is conceled.

title: Tax Dies, Confusion Lives
description: NEGOTIATIONS over the attempt by Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, to raise the county's sales tax by a penny on the dollar broke off last week, leaving Nassau's immediate financial future unclear.

title: How to Campaign On TV Without Much Money
description: On Monday, April 21, at approximately 10:55 P.M. EST, Senator Frank Church performed a neat bit of surgery on CBS's Medical Center. The Idaho Senator, who had recently announced his decision to run for President, did not appear as a character in the doctor drama. Instead, he sliced, or rather prompted CBS to slice, close to five minutes of hospitalroom dialogue and shots of dripping glucose bottles out of the script on this particular evening in order to make way for a paid political commercial in which the Senator appealed for money for his Presidential campaign.

title: Music: Choral Society
description: It is rare for a large vocal ensemble to give a whole program of 20thcentury music. The hazards of singing the difficult intervals in contemporary works are increased with the size of the singing group. It is usually left to vocal chamber groups to deal with them. On Friday night, however, the 175member New York Choral Society offered an evening of music in Avery Fisher Hall by Benjamin Briten, Warren Benson, Charles Ives and Carl Orff, and brought it off admirably under the astute direction of Robert DeCormier.

title: Landlords Meeting Employees Today To Continue Talks
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, called negotiators for apartment house employees and the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations to a meeting at 11 A.M. today at the Belmont Plaza Hotel in an effort to avert a strike threatened for Tuesday.

title: Peru's Land Distribution Stirs Suspicion
description: CICICAYA, Peru, April 28 Owners of small and mediumsized farms are viewing with increasing suspicion an agrarian reform program instituted by the leftwing military Government here.

title: Nina BenAvi, Student, Plans Bridal to Stephen Purshouse
description: Dr. and Mrs. Avrum BenAvi of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina BenAvi, to Stephen Purshouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon H. Purshouse of Sheffield, England.

title: European Football
description: European Football

title: Speedy Justice Brings Downfall of a Judge
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 1 (UPI)An Illinois judge who made a citizen's arrest, then held a midnight court and, within 20 minutes, sentenced the arrested man to 80 days in jail, was removed from the bench for official misconduct.

title: Find Debbie!
description: The cool rationality with which the best British writers so frequently treat the irrational proves extraordinarily refreshing in Roy Brown's novel of suspense and character, Find Debbiel

title: Capers Over Coffee
description: The Green (meaning unroasted) Coffee Association of New York City alerts its members that 335 bags of beans at 132 pounds per bag, were stolen from Port Newark April 14. From Columbia come reports of a step up in coffee smuggling with small boats slipping out to sea and heaping north towards the United States. The reason,. of course, is the jump in coffee prices. Green beans that sold to roasters for 87 cents a pound at the start of this year now cost about $1.30 a pound, which has triggered expectations of $2 a pound coffee soon at the supermarket shelf.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: ARGENTINA FACES A HARD RECOVERY
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 1The full extent of Argentina's economic calamity, now being disclosed by the new military Government, points toward a very hard road to recovery.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Old Days
description: To the Sports Editor: As Red Smith and Dave Anderson appear to see it, everything Marvin Miller does is right, everything baseball does is wrong.

title: Special Envoy of U.S. Returns to Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 L. Dean Brown the special United States envoy in the Lebanese crisis, returned today from Washington as heavy shelling and fighting raged on all fronts of the city.

title: What's Doing it HONOLULU
description: the outskirts of Waikiki, for a swim and a suntan or pack their surfboards on their car tops and head for the big surf beaches at Makaha or the North Shore. Watch out for dangerous tides; most areas are posted. If you are a snorkeling fan, rent a car (rates begin at about $11, plus gas) and drive to Hanauma Bay, about 15 minutes from Waikiki, for a leisurely swim in the state's only underwater aquatic sanctuary. Leave your spear gun at the hotel because it is kapu (prohibited) there, as are all forms of fishing.

title: Removing Br'er Rabbit
description: BR'ER RABBIT, Miz Possum and Sister Tarrypin are playing to audiences of children here, but Uncle Remus, the fablespinning former slave who narrated the animal tales in the original books by Joel Chandler Harris, is not part of the action.

title: Hillary Opens Nepal Hospital
description: KATMANDU, Nepal. May 1 [Reuters)Sir Edmund Hillary, the conqueror of Mount Everest, has seen the opening of a 20bed hospital that he built in a remote Himalayan village for the Sherpasand that cost him the lives of his wife and daughter. They died in March 1975 when their small plane crashed near Katmandu while on their way to Pharpul, where the hospital was being built.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Medicine, Physics
description: Whenever the simplest known explanation for the observed facts becomes more complex, scientists have suspected that a yet simpler explanation is still to be discovered. The view has now been expressed that quarks, thought by many physicists to be ultimately indivisible units of matter, may eventually be found to be another intermediate structure.

title: MISJUDGMENT SEEN IN KENNEDY CRASH
description: The Government's accident, agency said yesterday that the ??? Airlines crash here last time occurred because all con ??? failed to appreciate the ??? of the weather and neglected to draw the proper conelusion that the runway in use was unsafe.

title: U.S. Agents Hint $45 Million in Excessive Grain Inventories of Three Companies
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Federal investigators have found more than $45 million worth of alleged overages, or excessive grain inventories, in a review of five to six years of records of the three largest American grain companies.
