title: R. Bruce Mosbacher to Marry Nancy Ditz, Stanford Reporter
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Adams Ditz of Atherton, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Ditz, to R. Bruce Mosbacher, son of Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., yachtsman and former United States Chief of Protocol, and Mrs. Mosbacher of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows at Nearby Sites
description: TodayTrenton K.C. allbred and obedience, Mercer County Park, Edinburgh and Old Post Roads, West Windsor Township, N.J.: 3,060 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: American History Test
description: Following are the first 24 questions. Answers appear on following page.

title: Synthetic Oil vs. the Real Thing
description: Mobil Oil Company's new synthetic motor oil, Mobil 1, has been on the market one month and sales are promising, spokesmen say, but it's still hard to tell how successful it will be, the company admits.

title: Off the Ticket, but Out Raising Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTONNot since Alben W. Barkley coasted serenely through his single term 24 years ago has the nation enjoyed the services of a lameduck vice president, a man who knows his career in national office almost surely will end with the approaching election.

title: The specter that still haunts Germany.
description: COLOGNE. When Americans and Germans, or Englishmen and Germans, discuss inflation, I am not sure whether they mean the same thing. If the price of bread, butter, coffee and cigarettes were suddenly to double, it would still not remind me of the two total inflations I have experienced.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Historical mysteries can often be labored, but not as Francis Selwyn writes them. About a year and a half ago Selwyn, with Cracksman on Velvet, started a series of mysteries set in the Victorian England of the 1850's, which featured Sgt. William Clarence Verity of the PrivateClothes Detail, Whitehall Office. Newest to arrive is SERGEANT VERITY AND THE IMPERIAL DIAMOND (Stein and Day, $7.95), and it has the same combina tion of good research, skillful writing and ingenious plotting as CracIpman on Velvet.

title: CARTER IS CONFIDENT OF FAST NOMINATION
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 1Senator Henry M. Jackson's withdrawal from active pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination makes a firstballot nomination for me much more sure, Jimmy Carter said today.

title: Tennis Is Making a Comeback on the Cruise Liners
description: Tennis at sea, in vogue on a few large transAtlantic liners in the late twenties and thirties, is making a comeback aboard cruise ships sailing out of New York. Recognizing the growing popularity of the game, Flagship Cruises and Home Lines have made tennis facilities available on two liners, the Kungsholm and the Doric. In addition, the lines provide tennis lessons at sea and arrange for play ashore at ports of call.

title: West Europe's Communists Irk Soviet, Too
description: MOSCOWFor all its ambitions elsewhere in the world, the Soviet Union has always seen its first interests in Europe. The priority is rooted in more than an historical fear of invasion from the West, as was realized twice in this century. It also reflects an envy of Western technology and culture, coupled with the desire to win Europe's acceptance as an equal.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: EAST ISLIPJapanese flower arrangement, first in a series of lectures about the ancient art form. Wednesday. 8 to 10 P.M. Islip Town Art Gallery, 50 Irish Lane. Call 5812448 for details.

title: Italian Communists Schooling Workers for Elections
description: ROME, May 1  As Italy headed for elections, a group of men and women in their 20's and 30's met this week on the outskirts of Rome in a treeshaded villa with clinging vines, neat classrooms, a closedcircuit television network, two billiard tables and a lovely view of the countryside.

title: Stamp Stories
description: Several of these books about postage stamps may seem to you unnecessary. After all, you might plausibly argue, there are more fruitful ways for young people to learn about history, the Bible or space travel than to stare at a tiny portrait of General Pulaski or a renroduction of Michelangelo's Fall and Expulsion no bigger than a quarter of a credit card. Stamp collecting is narrowing. you might say with considerable justification (although there are always magnifying glasses to broaden things for the philatelist), so why send your children on such roundabout routes to knowledge?

title: Barbara Lawrence Wed
description: Barbara Jane Lawrence, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew Wilson Lawrence of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Chester Waszkiewicz 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waszkiewicz Jr. of New Hartford, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Fitzgerald in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington. Mr. and Mrs. Waszkiewicz were both graduated from St. Lawrence University.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger yesterday proposed a $7.5 billion rescue operation to roll back the desert in a droughtdevastated region of West Africa. He made the proposal in a speech in Dakar, Senegal, on his sixth visit to an African country in his twoweek tour. The international aid would be used to develop additional water resources, increase crop acreage and build foodstorage facilities. Traditional aid levels and methods will not be enough, Mr. Kissinger said. Nor can any one country or any single donor provide the resources necessary to meet the critical, longterm needs of the parched subSahara region known as the Sahel. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: FOLLIESA revival of the 1971 musical about two nostalgic couples who attempt to relive their past In order to cope with the present. Book by James Goldman music and lyrics by Stephen Sondhelm. Directed by Russell Treyz. Equity Library Theater, 103d St. and Riverside Dr. (6632028) Opens Thur.

title: ADALBERT VON CONTARD
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI)Adalbert von Gontard, vice chairman of the Board of AnheuserBusch Inc., died last night at the age of 75.

title: Cozy Vault
description: Is it possible for a bank vault to look like a lady's boudoir? With framed pictures of Dutch windmills, potted plants, flowered wallpaper, and oriental rug, a Manhasset Long Island, branch of the National Bank of North America is trying.

title: Hazards Of Being A Goalie
description: As Tony Esposito spoke, his hands still shook as he unlaced his goaltending equipment after a game. Despite his success, the Chicago goalie is a jittery, nervous man who cannot conceal the tension and pressure that go with the most demanding job in sports.

title: The Expanding Empire of a Quiet Tycoon
description: BELEM, BrazilAbout 250 miles west of this northern Amazon jungle capital, one man has carved out for himself the largest private landholding in Brazil, and perhaps in the Americas.

title: SelfAssertion in Suffolk
description: IN an effort to save about $2 million annually, the Suffolk Legislature has decided that the county must have a selfadministered insurance program. But, in addition to economic considerations, its decision is based as much on the Legislature's determina tion to flex its political muscle and to assert its growing independence from the County Executive.

title: Charts of Aqueduct Races
description: Charts of Aqueduct Races

title: CIVIC GROUP URGES SAVINGS FOR CITY
description: With deadlines approching for city fiscal changes mandated by the new Charter, the Citizens Budget Commission has urged savings to stretch the crry's limited ftmds available for a startup.

title: NO GROWTH HAS TO MEAN LESS IS LESS
description: There is an immense contradiction at the heart of the political attitudes of many Americansthose for whom the abolition of poverty and racial inequality rank together with environmental protection as the highest social priorities of the immediate future. The vast majority would agree that the country is now facing a historic national crisis: There is mass unemployment, a sizable and expanding black underclass comprising persons whose lives were scarcely touched by the civilrights revolution, and a declining standard of living for millions of working people. Yet many of those who profess concern about unemployment and poverty also actively support the concept of limiting economic growth in order to protect the environment. That notion, if translated into conscious policy, would measurably worsen the nation'sand the world'seconomic plight. And its promoters would hear the responsibility for having shattered the hopes of those who have never had a normal role in the world economy, among whom the darkerskinned people of the world rank most prominently.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: The Nation
description: With a surprising degree of consensus, the House of Representatives has passed a resolution that establishes a target for Federal spending in the next fiscal year. The figure in the resolution. $415.4 billion, is expected to be reconciled easily with a slightly different total already approved by the Senate, meaning that the new Congressional budgetary procedure is functioning smoothly so far.

title: Motorcycle Squad Formed
description: BOSTON, May 1 (UPI)The formation of a 60man motorcycle police unit was announced by Mayor White and Police Commissioner Robert DiGrazia to fight sporadic nighttime violence that has seriously injured severa persons in Boston in recent weeks.

title: Elizabeth Pfunder Fiancee of Lawyer
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Gilkey Pfunder to J. Baur Whittlesey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Gilkey Pfunder of Wayzata, Minn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Whittlesey of Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: PANEL DISAGREES ON CITY'S FUTURE
description: It began with a lament by State Senator Franz S. Leichter, Democrat of Manhattan, for the diminished powers of elected officials, and it ended with a denunciation of the Concorde supersonic airliner as a monumental idiocy by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Sleeve Lengths: Fewer Options
description: Dress shirts with exact sleeve lengths an item of clothing taken for granted by more than a generation of American menare being challenged for space on the shelves of many of the country's stores.

title: Madrid Communists Hold May Day Rally With 2,000 in Park
description: MADRID, May 1The outlawed Spanish Communist Party succeeded today in massing more than 2,000 people in a park clearing outside Madrid in defiance of a ban on demonstrations observing the May Day holiday.

title: Leeks, Parsnips And Celeriac For Winter
description: A gardner can have a variety of fresh vegetables even in winter. Leeks in January for a cockaleekie. beets for borscht. Just last month, I was digging up parsnips and salsify that I planted last May.

title: Tryout Day for Women's Team and Male Coach
description: Last fall, I coached the women's tennis team at Clark University, a small New England college. Although the tennis season was scheduled for nine matches In six weeks, my toughest day as coach was the first: team tryouts.

title: Uncollected Lardner
description: The introduction to Some Champions, which contains previously uncollected journalism and stories by Ring Lardner, reminds us that he was tremendously popular. Indeed, among the best known names in America. Lardner was paid as much as $4,500 for a story. He was admired by Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Faulkner, Sherwood Anderson, Edmund Wilson, H. L. Mencken and millions of others, including Virginia Woolf, a woman. Today he is remembered for a few stories and the way he gave interest to sports reporting. Only scholars, however, remain seriously concerned with him. Richard Bridgman, for example, in The Colloquial Style in America, compares Lardner's style to that of Gertrude Stein, and discovers remarkable similarities between high and popular culture in our literary tradition, or what Bridgman neatly calls the American way of using language. If there is a national voice, greater than any writer, Lardner has an essential relation to it.

title: Food
description: If we had always thought of Halifax, Nova Scotia, as a frozen outpost sonic where to the north, we discovered to our considerable delight on a recent visit that it is a quite admirably habitable place and, with equal delight, that it is the haven for two restaurants whose kitchens (and dcors) deserve enthusiastic applause. The establishments are the Five Fishermen, whose fare includes an excellent fish soup a l'Acadian, and Fat Frank's, where a firstrate oyster and spinach bisque is served. We print here two recipes inspired by the dishes we dined on. Our feeling is that the Acadian soup really had its origins in the Provencal legion of France.

title: Weather Disrupts Schoolboy Track
description: Rain, wind and low temperatures hampered the final day of the 11th annual New York Relays yesterday, but like the postman, the schoolboy track and field athletes would not be kept from their appointed rounds. Some were able to turn In solid efforts under those conditions.

title: Times Test of College Freshmen Shows Knowledge of American History Limited,
description: A nationwide test of college freshmen conducted by The New York Times shows that they generally know the high points of American history but that their knowledge of the details and the context of these epochal events does not run deep.

title: The Missing Piece
description: Charm and a poignant honesty, an almost painfullycal view of the world marks Shel Silverstein's fables for children of all ages. The hero of The Missing Piece is a circle with a pieshaped wedge gone. It happily rolls along searching for its missing piece, exploring the world as it goes. finding wedges too large, too small, too independent. It has adventures with butterflys, holes and stonewalls. At last it finds the perfect piece the one that wants to join with it, the one that fits exactly. But now it rolls too fast, it misses the daily pleasures of the search and since it has become whole it can no longer sing its happy song. The wise circle releases its piece and goes on its merry way.

title: Record Rainfall Floods New York Area Roads
description: Sections of several major thoroughfares in the metropolitan area were flooded and inbound flights were delayed at two major airports here last night as an allday rain intensified last night, more than doubling the previous record rainfall for the date.

title: REV. DR. OTTO A. OLSON
description: The Rev. Dr. Otto A. Olson, president of the Central Canada Synod of the Lutheran Church in America, died of a heart attack Monday in Glace Bay, Nova Scotia, where he was attending a meeting of the Canadian Council of Churches. He was 56 years old.

title: OSCAR SHERWIN, BIOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Oscar Sherwin, professor emeritus of English at the City College of New York, died Friday evening, apparently of a stroke at his honic, 207 West 106th Street. He sync 73 years old.

title: Paul A. Ruisi Marries Helen Suydam
description: Helen Gunhild Suydam, daughter of Mrs. Marjorie Nardon Suydam of Washington and the late Henry West Suydam Jr., and Paul Allan Ruisi, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L.C. Ruisi of Watch Hill, R.I., were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Anschutz, a retired Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Henry O'Meara, a Roman Catholic priest, at the bride's family farm in Huntly, Va.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Modern photojournalism, which may be defined as a fusion of visual and verbal (printed or written) methods of communication, is pretty much taken for granted by readers and viewers these days. Every news photographer Is an eyewitness reporter who tries to combine picture and caption in a unique way that will most effectively reproduce the actuality of the original event. As a result, photographic coverage of the news has become one of the most realistic and informative aspects of modern journalism.

title: Kansas Democrats Provide Carter With 13 Delegates
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 1 (AP) Jimmy Carter, continuing his success in nonprimary states, picked up 13 Democratic delegates today in Kansas.

title: Television This Week
description: 5:30 (13) IF YOU DON'T COME IN SUNDAY, DON'T COME IN MONDAY. A history of the struggles of the American worker as seen through photographs, documents and rare film footage.

title: Brecht, Weill and the Birth Of The Threepenny Opera
description: The chaos of Germany during the 1920's produced a volatile artistic legacycertainly one of the most expressive and stimulating of modern times. But amid all the cultural landmarks of that period (the Bauhaus, The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, Wozzeck, and countless others) The Threepenny Opera retains a special place.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON WHY do we prefer certain forms or art to other forms? Why have we developed prejudices against various visual expressions? Why are some types of art popular and subsequently lose their appeal?

title: Priscilla Cole Wed To Thomas Perkins
description: Priscilla Agnes Cole, daughter of Kenneth R. Cole of Hyannis, Mass., and the late Laura Hughes Cole, was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas Cole Perkins, son of Mrs. Leon Blair Perkins of Oklahoma City and the late Mr. Perkins.

title: Minnesota Bans Phosphates
description: ROSEVILLE. Minn., May 1 (AP)The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency hoard has voted to ban the use of household phosphate detergents as of next Jan. 1. The action Tuesday makes Minnesota the third state to ban household use of phosphates in an attempt to slow algae growth in lakes and rivers. Bans are also in effect in Indiana and New York.

title: Blacks Anger Rising in South Boston as Violence Over Schools Spreads
description: BOSTON, April 30The longer they talked, the more the 10 black Hyde Park high School students seated around a long table showed their anger.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors in the metropolitan area will be offered a small taste this week of the giant sixday American Numismatic Association convention coming here this August. This cameo is the fourday, fourth annual Greater New York Coin Convention, which has become a major event In Its own right. It opens Thursday at 11 A.M. in the New York Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street. The registration desk opens at 10:30. There is no admission charge, but registration is requiredfor security reasons.

title: Tour Earnings
description: Tour Earnings

title: Paper backs
description: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY, by Judith Viorst. (Atheneum/Aladdin, $1.95.) But everything's O.K. with this book: a child's complaints expressed with rueful good humor, illustrated by Ray Cruz's pictures.CONVERSATIONS WITH KENNEDY, by Benjamin C. Bradlee. (Pocket. $1.95.) An airing of Camelot's less classy linen by a newspaperman who was privy to some of what went on after hours.

title: STAMPS
description: Interphil 76, an international philatelic exhibition taking place when the host country is celebrating one of the most momentous events of its history, the 200th anniversary of its independence, is now only one month away.

title: An Endangered Species
description: MANY of the Island's carrousels are transplants in trouble. These relocated merrygorounds have survives for a half century or more in at least two different settings, but now they are slowing or stilled or so maimed that they are in desperate need of restoration.

title: letters to the editor
description: My Apple trees have been in several years and are growing beautifully but we get no fruit. Why?

title: Stock Car Racer to Stay Put
description: Cale Yarborough competed in the Indianapolis 500 four times and spent two full seasons on the United States Auto Club championship car eircult, and now he's back home In stock car racingto stay.

title: Powerboat Race Gets Strong U.S. Fleet
description: The throaty gurgle and roar of highpowered engines will drown out Miami's marine traffic next Saturday as the second offshore powerboat race sponsored by Bacardi gets under way. The foreign entries will face an unusually stiff American fleet, for this is the year of the new hulls. Not in the last 10 years have so many new designs appeared on the offshore circuit.

title: Politics And Religion
description: FIERY RUN, Va., May 1With Hubert Humphrey and now Scoop Jackson on the sidelines, the attention of the nation is turning to Governor Carter. He has overwhelmed his opponents and the labor leaders and political leaders of his own party.

title: Sidney Franklin, 72, Dies; Matador From Brooklyn
description: Sidney Franklin, the Brook??? hullfighter whose ex??? in the arena made news ??? the world, died Monday the Village Nursing Home. 607 Hudson Street. He was 72 ??? old and had lived at the home for the last seven years. left New York equipped with a Spanish course at Columbia University's extension department and a desire to open an art shop in Mexico City. He had had a small shop in Manhattan after three years of schooling at Brooklyn's Commercial High School. He was the fifth of 10 children of Russian Jewish immigrants.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: A legend and a reality
description: The Golem is a beautiful piece of work, a book of wonders casting off so many shadows of meaning and leaving behind such a wake of afterimages and afterthoughts that words can only faintly suggest how different it is from the kind of kiddieKitsch celebrated by critics and prize committees during any average publishing season.

title: Ray Charles Adds Gospel Overtones To His Repertory
description: Ray Charles's recent transformation of America the Beautiful into a gospel moan is the latest in the series of transformations that has constituted his remarkable career.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: Quartet No. 3, Siegmeister.

title: Maine Puts Its New Criminal Code Into Use, Effecting First Major Change Since 1820
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 1 (AP) Prostitutes in Mairie now will not have to worry about jail terms. In addition, possessing a small amount of marijuana will no longer be a serious crime But a fiveyear prison sentence will mean just that, with no early release on parole.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In general I try to stay out of the various controversies surrounding Charles Lindbergh, but I can't help being annoyed by the simplistic characterizations of him presented by each biography as it comes along. As his daughter, understandably enough, I can accept neither the view of Lindbergh as a flawless Olympian hero nor that of the prewar reactionary, witless dupe, as described by Kenneth Davis in his review (April 11) of the current Mosley biography, and/or bigot. None of these tallies with my own memory of my father as a complex human (as opposed to sub or superhuman) being of whom a truly accurate and balanced, to say nothing of excellent, biography has yet to appear.

title: Catholic black humor
description: A retired football coach, his wife recently dead, decides to radiate his senility by avenging the death of Sterling Lloyd Kasprzck 23 years ago, murdered by prep school pranksters who locked him in meat cooler. Coach Magruder travels about the country, waking up old boys and murderers, camping out with the men and their wives. In return, the murderers try to kill him, he makes friends with a crazy Italian semipoet, and a kind of justice gets done.

title: Traffic Jams and How to Avoid Them
description: WHERE are New Jersey's worst traffic jams? The Garden State Parkway gets a heavy vote for a number of stretches. Drivers are often caught in snarls that can back up traffic three cars abreast for a dozen miles or more on warm weekends.

title: Behind the Great Wall of China
description: PARIS  Russia has always been difficult for foreigners to understand, as confirmed since the early nineteenth century in such memoirs as those of France's Marquis de Custine or diplomatic dispatches like those of American Minister Neill Brown.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to delete a provision for a Federal grain inspection agency which was rejected, 39 to 34, April 26.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Proposals to eliminate vertical integration in oil companies call for regulations on one industry not imposed on other industries. Politically motivated schemes that create discriminatory barriers against one segment of U.S. industry set precedents that are not in the public interest. They will result in less efficiency in the oil industry and in reduced ability to compete for supplies of oil with foreign companies. Further, they fail to address a major problem facing the nation.

title: ATHENS DIPLOMACY STIRS CRITICISM
description: ATHENS, May 1Greece's recent moves to forge new agreements with the United States and Turkey have set off a debate over this country's foreign policy and illuminated sharp divisions between the Government of Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis and his leading onponents.

title: Balanced Forces
description: BEIRUTThe savage effects of a yearlong civil war have turned Lebanon into something that nature abhors and diplomats exploit: a vacuum.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  United States Auto

title: The Lemming Condition
description: Lemmings are rodents, roughly six inches long. They look like mice, breed like rabbits and commit suicide like Scandinavians, which most of them are. (Lemming derives etymologically from various Norwegian and Iceland IC WORM meaning loon and to revile and to blame and to bark.) This idea of going west until you fall off a cliff into the sea is generally used as a simile for describing political behavior of which we disapprove. It has been turned by the actor Alan Arkin into a book for children, the second  after Tony's Hard Work Daythat he has perpetrated, and a nice one.

title: WHITE ACADEMIES LIKELY TO REMAIN
description: ATLANTA, May 1In the 22 years since the United States Supreme Court ruled that segregation in public schools violates the Constitution some ??? allwhite academies have been established in the South.

title: A Bid for World Fame
description: HE burden of trying to wrest a world bridge title from Italy during the next three weeks lies substantially on the broad shoulders of a Paramus resident. He is Ira Rubin, known affectionately throughout the world of bridge as The Big Beast.

title: PARIS COMMUNIST SEEKS WIDER BASE
description: PARIS, May 1 The French Communist Party is accelerating its efforts to gain political support among millions of Franch people who have been traditionally antiCommunist for political or religious reasons.

title: Where Morgan, Rockefeller and Vanderbilt Got Away From It All
description: Off the coast of Georgia lies Jekyll Island, nine miles long and barely two miles wide, its beaches uncrowded and unspoiled. These days it is open to the public, but once it was the boast of the Jekyll Island Club that no uninvited foot stepped ashore. Who was the Jekyll Island Club? A group of friends: J. P. Morgan (If y'have to ask how much it costs to operate a yacht, y'can't afford it.), Bill Rockefeller (brother to John D. and founder of an export firm that became Standard Oil of New Jersey), Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jo Pulitzer, et al. In 1886 they were looking for a perfect warm climate, good water, natural beauty and isolation not more than 24 hours from Wall Streetby private train, of course.

title: Peru's Economic Setbacks Erced Revolution's Image
description: LIMA, Peru. April 29Severe economic setbacks have tarnished the image of Peru's model for development in the rest of Latin America, and have eroded the confidence of Peruvian military officers in the leftist revolution they proclaimed in 1968 vate enterprise, than on carrying out an equitable distribution of wealth.

title: Joining the Majority
description: After years of nearneglect by the United States of black African nations and sympathy for, or cooperation with, minoritywhite governments, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has announced a major reversal of those policies.

title: Ancient Craft Revived In Loft
description: Under the harsh fluorescent lights everyone seems to have the concentration of a chess player although the room is so crowded with equipment, as well as people that to walk through it is like going through an obstacle course. And the decibel count must be close to that in a boiler factory.

title: Job Rights Panel Faces Mismanagement Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, hit two weeks ago by the sudden resignation of its chairman, is now beset by fresh charges of mismanagement and hints of criminal misdeeds, and faces scrutiny by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, two committees of Congress and the General Accounting Office.

title: Gabriella Hack Bride of John Hall
description: Gabrielle ??? Hack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at noon to John Samuel Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Hall of Malvern, England.

title: PEOPLE
description: Remember Maria Pepe? She's the Hoboken girl who shook up the previous allmale world of Little League baseball in 1974. After being tossed off her local team because of her sex, Maria went to court to win the right to play ball. On June 12, 1974, Little League Baseball Inc. reversed its 35yearold policy and allowed girls to play on L.L. teams, but by then Maria was too old13, that is  to be a team member. Yet, she did clear the way for other girls to be Little Leaguers, and for her efforts she's one of the heroines of a new book, A Special Kind of Courage, by Geraldo Rivera, the TV personality.

title: Scouting Out Edible Plants
description: EAST NORTHPORT AFTER just a few minutes of tramping through Crab Meadow with Ruth Valentine, you begin to share her enthusiasm for edible wild plants. Like the members of Boy Scout Troop 225 from Merrick, you begin to notice what is growing underfoot and suddenly y ou are a budding field botanist.

title: New York Is Facing Welfare Aid Loss On Ineligibility Rate
description: New York stands to lose millions of dollars in Federal funds because the ineligibility rate among recipients of aid to dependent children rose in the second half of last year both upstate and in New York City, according to an audit by the State Department of Social Services.

title: Mets Records
description: Mets Records

title: ackstage With Balanchine
description: George Balanchine was frowning, while Lincoln Kirstein was smiling, even though Mr. Kirstein is ordinarily the more worrisome of the two and frequently does Mr. Balanchine's frowning for him. Mr. Balanchine had just been told that the socks he wanted his dancers to wear in part one of Union Jack, his new ballet that will premiere on May 12, would cost $50 a pair. He said this was too much. Mr. Kirstein, however, was thinking about semaphore flags. He said they enchanted him.

title: Burma Reports Rebel Clash
description: RANGOON, Burma, May 1 (Reuters) Government troops, backed by air and artillery support, killed nine rebels and seized large quantities of heroin and opium during clashes in Eastern Burma, the official Burmese news agency reported today. Two soldiers were reported killed.

title: Zia
description: In Island of the Blue Dolphins, which won the Newberg Award in 1961, Scott O'Dell recreated the life of a young Indian girl, Karana, who lived for 18 years alone on an island off the California coast. Set in the 1800's, his semihistorical tale had all the ingredients of a classic: a strong heroine, suspenseful narrative, and language as clean and taut as a drawn bow.

title: Especially, the Startling New Man From Texas
description: WASHINGTONRepresentative Robert Krueger of Texas has a most unlikely background for one who is the chief spokesman in the House for the oil and natural gas industries. He holds a doctorate in Elizabethan literature from Oxford and was the dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Duke Unversity. He had not lived in Texas for 15 years before he returned there to run for Congress two years ago, and he has retained not a trace of a Texas accent. He knew almost nothing about oil and gas matters before he was elected to the House.

title: Harvard Crew Is Victor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Miss., May 1 It was the same old story at tile Compton Cup race on the Charles River today as the Harvard varsity crew won the prize for the 14th year in a row. The undefeated Crimson eight heat Princeton by 6.5 seconds, or one and onehalf boat lengths, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology by 10.4 seconds.

title: Horse Shows
description: Horse Shows

title: Ballet: 2 Master Artists
description: If one had to think of a perfect ballet programthe one program that you would want more than any otherIt Is surely not inconceivable that one might at least consider Rudolf Nureyev's staging of Petipa's La Bayadre and Sir Frederick Ashton's La File Mal Gardee. They are both, in their different ways, perfect, they both show off dancers as a Cartier showcase shows off jewels, and they both demonstrate something very special about the British style of dancing which is partly Russian and partly Ashton, a mixture of the two, and what combination could be more perfect than this program was.

title: New Family in Town
description: NINE months ago, I moved to New Jersey with my wife and 5yearold son at my employer's request and expense. We came east from Los Angeles, where we had lived for a very long and contented time. Our decision to move was based on several things, the most important being my work.

title: Big Thicket: 8 Separate Worlds, Side by Side in Texas
description: It was like that: Four sodden souls huddled in a small metal boat, drinking black coffee and nibbling sugarfrosted cookies under an immense cypress tree while rain poured down in black, heavy sheets and lightning laced the sky with electric spiderwebs.

title: And So Will Selected SafetoUse Pesticides
description: The following check list of pesticides includes most of those reasonably safe to use and available to home gardeners without permit in 1976. If problems are not solved by crop rotation, resistant varieties, proper location and cultural methods, companion planting, and beneficial insects, a few basic chemicals may be handy. It is very important to choose the right chemical for the specific problem and to apply it In the right dosage at the proper time, after reading all directions on the label. If directions suggest use of protective clothing use a safer material.

title: Major League Averages
description: Records Include Games Played Friday Night

title: The Alcoholic Attorneys
description: AMONG the formal hearings conducted by the State Supreme Court last year on alleged misdeeds by attorneys were three that focused on a common problem: alcoholism. The three cases were the tip of the iceberg, according to one state official, who said that many of the complaints that clients filed against their attorneys each year could he traced to a drinking problem on the part of the lawyer.

title: National News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP)  The Justice Department yesterday charged New Hampshire's lottery Commission with operating through a pattern of racketeering by illegally mailing tickets and renewal applications across a state line into Maine.

title: GARDENING
description: IT is fairly safe to plant nasturtiums, cleome, fireonthemountain, sweet alyssum, portulaca and other lowcare annuals in most New Jersey gardens now. However, in the northernmost areas, it is safer to hold off for a few days.

title: DANCE COMPANY USES REPETITION
description: The Zero Moving Dance Company is a group of hardworking, totally dedicated performers exploring ideas of repetition to a hypnotic level. The odd thing is that none of the pieces given at the American Theater Laboratory on Friday evening had the right psychological length. They were either too long or too short.

title: Unpopular Poplars
description: JEFFREY and Starlet Tobin returned from a vacation two years ago and discovered their front yard looking like a tree nursery.

title: Rhodesia, Planning Offensive, To Call Up PartTime Soldiers
description: SALISBURY Rhodesia, May 1 (Reuters)Rhodesia's security forces, committed to a new offensive against African nationalist guerrillas, today announced that they were calling up parttime soldiers of their territorial units.

title: Planning a Ball Calls for Wit, Charm, Worry And 6 Months
description: I go right for the busiest people I know when I'm drafting help for jobs like this one, Mavis Marsh was saying the other morning as she sat, dressed in a lemoncolored Tshirt and a matching printed skirt, in the sunroom of her Bernardsville home.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Dicamba will control chickweed and ground ivy. Use captan for crabapple scab and peach brown rot. Last call to start tuberous begonias and caladiums indoors for planting in shady areas. Sow outdoors all hardy annuals: stock, bachelor buttons, larkspur, poppies. Feed peonies and roses. Last call to feed woody ornamentals.

title: Benefit for Boy Scouts
description: Proceeds from next Thursday's performance of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? at the Music Box Theater will go to the Boy Scouts of America's Manhattan Council. Tickets, at $16, may be obtained from the theater committee of the beneficiary at 25 West 43d Street.

title: The OrangeFog Peril
description: PEDRICKTOWN THERE is an orange fog that envelops various neighborhoods here from time to time. In recent months it has come almost weekly. Now it has the high towners riled.

title: JACKSON IS OUT
description: SEATTLE, May 1  Senator Henry M. Jackson announced today that he was ending my active pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Woolf Is Selected as the Director Of Institute for Advanced Study
description: The Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J., has asked Dr. Harry Woolf, a historian of science and provost of John Hopkins University, to be its director.

title: Peru Plans Amnesty For Political Prisoners
description: LIMA, Peru, May 1 (AP)Peru's military government will carry out a general amnesty for political prisoners soon and allow exile to return home, according to President Francisco Morales Bermudez.

title: Baldwin on movies
description: A decade ago, as an undergraduate, my colleagues and I spent hours poring over the works of James Baldwin. He seemed so surefooted, then, so certain in his vision of this country, that his lacerating words were like balm to the black students who were on a whirligig in search of their identities. Because he existed we felt that the racial miasma that swirled around us would not consume us, and it is not too much to say that this man saved our lives, or at least, gave us the necessary ammunition to face what we knew would continue to be a hostile and condescending world.

title: A Growing Field Has Some Opposition
description: When the Supreme Court outlawed devotional Bible readings and prayer in public schools in 1963, objections were heard from those who believed religion had been banished from the classroom. Since that time courses in religion have been introduced extensively in elementary, junior high and high schools as objective studies. This trend is now a subject of debate.

title: Game in Diamonds
description: Elizabeth Cadell's novels are as dependable harbingers of spring as tulips. More dependable, because sometimes the tulips are late.

title: Stavisky Seeks to Soften Impact of Bill
description: Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavlsky, whose bill mandating a restoration of cuts in the city school budget recently became law over Governor Carey's veto. said yesterday that he would seek a meeting in Albany to soften the fiscal impact of the law.

title: Chilndren's Boolcs Spring1976
description: I once prepared as a school project a notebook on poetry, and on the cover I pasted the picture of a majestic carved gate that I had cut from a magazine and to the top of the gate I attached a bright feather; inside my notebook I copied out my favorite poems and the definitions of poetry by a number of great poets. I realize now that my cover was itself my own definition, for poetry is indeed a splendid gateway to intense and rewarding experience, offering, throughout one's life, magnificence within a frame.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Cesar Cedeno, Houston Astro centerfielder, asked who is the best player in the National League: I am.

title: Mayaguez's Captain Looks Back On Capture With No Ill Feelings
description: MANILA, May 1(UPI)The old vessel needs a coat of paint, and her captain agrees she looks worse than an old Greek tramp, but the Mayagilez is still plying the Gulf of Siam where she was seized by Cambodians on May 12, 1975.

title: SpenceChapin Benefit
description: SpenceChapin Services to Families and Children are sponsoring a theater party for the May 12 performance of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue At the Mark Hellinger Theater Tickets, at $50, $45, $35 and $25, may be obtained at SpenceChapin's headquarters at 6 East 94th Street.

title: Will Enroll Women
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., May 1 (AP)  Massachusetts Maritime Academy, faced with a Justice Department sex discrimination suit, said today it will reverse an 85yearold tradition and enroll women in September 1977.

title: Ford and Advisers Weighing Big Rise In Naval Spending
description: WASHINGTON. May 1President Ford and the National Security Council weighed today a multibilliondollar decision on whether to embark upon an ex panded Navy shipbuilding program, with a consequent major increase in the defense budget in future years.

title: Hello to Bodega
description: Dig it. If public opinion and popular culture lag a decade or so behind the events that subsequently determine their character, the same may be noted of serious books for young people as well. Hello to Bodega is a case in point, showing us a slice of life in the 1960's already stale around the edges but just now appearing on high school bookshelves leavened for general consumption.

title: KISSINGER URGES DRIVE TO DEVELOP SUBSAHARA AREA
description: DAKAR, Senegal May 1Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today proposed a $7.5 billion rescue operation to roll back the desert in a droughtdevastated region of West Africa, and appealed to the world's industrial countries to join it.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONNow that the dust has settled on the calamities that befell the American economy in the last few years, it is possible to perceive a striking feature of the episode that was not altogether understood at the time.

title: Music: Composer Guild Performance
description: The Composer's Guild for Performance gave a concert at McMillin Theater on Friday night that offered premieres of Bruce Hobson's Sonata for Two Pianos (1971). and Robert Pollock's Third Duo for Violin and Piano (1973), the first complete performances of Maurice Wright's Cantata for Tenor, Percussion and Tape (1974) and Alexander Zamlinksy's Six Songs (1934) and also included Webern's Four Songs (191517). The Messrs. Hobson, Pollock and Wright are three of the seven members of the Composer's Guild for Performance. The other four had their concert a week earlier.

title: UNITED PARCEL. HIT BY 13STATE STRIKE
description: Some 14,000 teamsters' union members in 13 states struck United Parcel Service yesterday, United Press International reported.

title: Miss Evert Wins, 60, 60; Mrs. Reid Also in Final
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., May 1  Chris Evert drew even today with Mary Struthers.

title: UNDER HIS SOCIALISM, CAPITALISM FLOURISHES.
description: BONN. The story of the German Federal Republic falls into chapters headed by the names of its Chancellors. Konrad Adenauer made peace with the West and rooted the new German institutions in Western soil. Ludwig Erhard directed the economic comeback. Willy Brandt made peace with the East, knelt in atonement at the old Jewish ghetto of Warsaw and ushered in the era of detente. Now a Hamburg pragmatist whose plain speaking has earned him the nickname Schmidt Schnauze (Schmidt the Lip) is moving West Germany out of the guiltridden postwar era of apologetic, niceguy policies into a more selfassertive phase more in keeping with the country's economic power.

title: MANES SADDENED BY JACKSON STEP
description: The decision of Senator Henry M. Jackson to drop out as an active candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination was greeted with disappointment yesterday by Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, chairman of the Jackson campaign for New York State.

title: Synod of Catholic Bishops Set for September 1977
description: ROME, May 1 (AP)The fifth synod of the world's Roman Catholic bishops will he held in the second half of September 1977, the Vatican has announced.

title: Dave Anderson
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 1The beauty of boxing, as Muhammad Ali and Jimmy Young proved, is that it's the most subjective soon of all.

title: National League
description: Houston at New York, rain.

title: I remember Hughes
description: Until early spring. 1948, I had never seen Howard Hughes except in newsreels or newspaper photos. My job at that time was vice president in charge of production at R.K.O. Studios and the studio had been doing very well. My immediate chief was Peter Rathvon, a dignified and intelligent executive for whom I had a warm respect. The head of the R.K.O. board was Floyd Odium, the extraordinary financier.

title: A Palace for the Sheik
description: American homeowners who have wrestled with rooters. electricians, plumbers and their like for decades are accustomed to the vagaries of the building business. And the hard hats are used to ignoring the stranger ideas of their customers, too.

title: Charter Tours: Protests Move 2 U. S. Agencies to Action
description: Thus, within little more than a week, after many months of mounting consumer protest without definitive Federal action, two arms of the Government have moved to grapple with alleged abuses in the tour charter field. The Federal Trade Commission has unanimously authorized its Boston regional office to conduct an investigation of tour operators, tour wholesalers, travel agentsto determine whether such industry members have been or are now violating the Federal Trade Commission Act.

title: Newport Is Lobster Capital
description: NEWPORT, R. I., May 1 (UPI)  Newport has quietly become the lobster capital of the United States, according to the state natural resources director, Dennis J. Murphy. Statistics from the National Marine Fisheries Service showed that over 2.1 million pounds of lobster worth $3.74 million were landed at Newport in 1975, nearly twice that of the top port in Maine, Mr. Murphy said.

title: Miss Herdrich Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Linda M. Herdrich of Greenwich, Conn., to William G. Tankoos Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John T. Herdrich of McHenry, III., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Elizabeth B. Tankoos of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Tankoos.

title: The Region
description: Despite layoffs, wage deferrals and modest contracts, New York City has managed to maintain peace with its labor unions. Now that peace is in jeopardy and the city's threeyear austerity plan threatened because of two rulings concerning wage agreements.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: After the Internal Revenue Service rejected a $576,000 incometax deduction that former President Richard M. Nixon had claimed for the gift of his Presidential papers to the United States, Mr. Nixon paid $284,706.16 in back taxes and penalties for 1970, 1971 and 1972. But as of May a year ago, $148,080.97 in back taxes for 1969 were not paid, Donald C. Alexander, the I.R.S. Commissioner, told a Congressional subcommittee.

title: The Final Daze
description: WHEN HAIG ENTERED the Oval Office to drop off the candy bars he found his President in a playful mood, sitting between the legs of an overturned easy chair and making automotive noises.

title: Acosta Receives Yale Net Award
description: Mike Acosta, a senior and captain of the Yale tennis team, has been presented the James A. Hutchinson Award, given to the player who has done the most for tennis at the school. Acosta had a 54 wonlost record in singles play for the Ells, who finished with a 64 mark.

title: L. I. Nursing Home Aide Pleads Guilty on Records
description: The administrator of a Long Island nursing home pleaded guilty yesterday to falsifying records and charging Medicaid for nonrelated expenses, the special state prosecutor, Charles Hynes, announced.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: World News Briefs
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 1 (UPI)ATurkish hijacker arrived home today aboard the game Turkish Airlines jet he seized at knife point and held for five hours in an effort to stay in France with the woman I love.

title: If You Go
description: to the Big Thicket, you can expect good weather (unless it rains) from about mid  March through midNovember. Spring, starting right about now, is Most people's favorite time for a trip, because the incredible profusion of flowering dogwood, magnolia, smoke trees, silver bells, snow bells, violets and early orchids makes the woods a showplace.

title: CHESS
description: Since its inception before the turn of the century, the CaroKann Defense has been recognized as the tortoise of the openings, but that image does not do justice to some recent developments.

title: Robin Hood: He Was a Real Live Bloke
description: Robin Hood? The moonfaced occupant of an adjoining stool at the Coach and Horses pub in Nottingham considered my question. You want to talk Robin Hood? Rightyho. I could talk Robin Hood up to closing time. Like practically every other resident of Nottingham I encountered during the next few days, my neighbora local car salesmanwas a potluck authority on Robin Hood. Apparently it comes with the territory. He treated me to a colorful monologue that ran to more than two hours by the clock on the far wall. At evening's end, he and my tape recorder were spinning still.

title: The Pineapple Bay Hotel
description: The Pineapple Bay is a Grand Hotel in search of a story. Jane Gardam, an English journalist, has given her Jamaican tourist trap a fine cast of characters who introduce themselves in 10 separate interludes. But they touch only tangentially, leaving unplumbed possibilities for catalytic action. The two episodes with the most direct connection deal with the anxieties of a lawyer's wife whose husband has gone to Jamaica for a convention. In The First Declension, Anne Shaw finds disturbing messages between the lines of her husband's suspiciously effusive letters. In Monique, it turns out that Mrs. Shaw's worst fears were justified.

title: Tomatoes, Eggplants and Peppers
description: The solanums, pepper, eggplant and tomato, have much in common. They are all warm weather vegetables and should not be planted until all danger of frost has passed. Otherwise, they would be stunted by long periods of chilly weather.

title: Britain's Unusual AntiInflation Program of Limiting Incomes Is Going Into Its Second and Critical Phase
description: LONDON. May 1Britain's remarkable experiment to cure inflation by limiting incomes??? experiment that has bypassed Parliament and made a mockery of collective bargainingis now entering its second and most critical stage.

title: Will Lerner's New Musical Sing?
description: Whether writing about outsiders looking in (I Wonder What the King Is Doing Tonight?) or insiders looking out (What Do the Simple Folk Do?), Alan Jay Lerner, the lyricist, has been at no loss for words.

title: Soviet Tails Aide Who Served in U.N
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1Leading officials of the United Nations and 1,400 staff members here and abroad have initiated a campaign to seek the release from a Soviet prison of Vladimir Balakhonov, a Russian formerly employed as a translator.

title: Roses Grow Best With T.L.C.
description: Gardeners who grow roses usually spend a great deal of time and effort on them not because they must but because they want to There also are those gardeners who have learned to get the most out of their roses with the least time and effort. I am one of them.

title: Maine Maritime School Graduates First Woman
description: CASTINE, Me., May 1The Maine Maritime Academy's top ranking graduate this year is the school's first female student.

title: Jody Gaylin Fiancee Of a News Producer
description: Jody Gaylin, a researcher with Psychology Today magazine, and Andrew Heyward, producer of the 10 o'clock news program on WNEWTV, Channel 5, will be married May 23 at the home of the bride's parents, Dr, and Mrs. Willard Gaylin, in HastingsonHudson, N.Y.

title: Ballet: Jewels Is a Gem
description: Everyone can use words to write, but not everyone can write like a genius. In dance, the genius of George Balanchine lies not only in the fact that he has expanded the ballet vocabulary itself, but also in the new ways in which he has used the idiom of classical ballet as it existed before him.

title: Three By Lionni
description: In a reminiscence following the review Leo Lionni compares the children's books he has created in recent years with the terrariums he delighted in as a child. These miniature worlds whether enclosed in yesterday's walls of glass or in today's cardboard covers, are surprisingly alike  predictable alternatives to a  terrifying universe. While this analogy is especially applicable to Mr. Lionni's work it can be extended. Books in general and perhaps children's books in particular not only express an individual view of the world but, by miniaturizing, control what is otherwise chaotic and unmanageable.

title: Royals Cool Off Yanks by Winning, 41
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 1The New York Yankees started a new month tonight the way they started the last month, by losing their first game. But if the rest of May turns out as productive as the rest of April did, the Yankees, will have no complaints.

title: P.S.C. Orders Utilities Studies To Reduce Rates by Efficiency
description: The New York Public Service Commission has a series of management studies under way in an effort to reduce utility rates by making the state's companies more efficient.

title: State and Local Governments Challenge Social Security System
description: WASHINGTON, May 1New York City's announced intention to pull its employees our of the Social Security system has raised new questions about the future and the financing of the 41yearold Federal retirement insurance program.

title: Miniature Jumbo Jet Seeks Speed Record
description: The newly christened Clipper Liberty Bell, a miniature hotrod version of the Boeing 747 Jumbo jet, set out yesterday, from Kennedy Airport to establish a world speed record by circling the globe in less than 40 hours with only two slops, at New Delhi and Tokyo, according to united Press International.

title: H. G. Billings to Marry Miss Woodward
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Runyan of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Runyan's daughter. Deborah Coolidge Woodward, to Harry Griffin Billings, son of Dr, and Mrs. William C. Billings of Pine Orchard, Conn. Miss Woodward is a daughter also of the late Robert Woodward, also of Dayton.

title: Legislature Is Urged to Enact a Law Defining Death
description: A 10member group of leaders in medicine and other fields, including the municipal hospital system's president, yesterday announced a drive to have the Legislature enact New York State's first statutory answer to the Question what is death?

title: Vietnamese Working for Kids After Settling in Northwest
description: CAMAS, Wash,  The air was clear and crisp here, across the Columbia River from the Portland Airport, on a recent Sunday afternoon, as half a dozen neighborhood children played in the yard at 1308 Northwest Ash Street.

title: More the anguish than the joy of sporting life
description: Among basketball players, and maybe in fact among professional athletes of every stripe, Bill, Bradley excites our curiosity the most. He's the square peg; he doesn't belong. And he's the most private and enigmatic figure in a public and straightforward occupation. He shuns publicity where every word and picture is convertible to cash. He's the only New York Knick and the only athlete who stubbornly refuses to capitalize on his celebrity, even when he can make as much as $30,000 for a day's work endorsing commercial products. Taking money for hocking products, he writes, demeaned my experience of the game.

title: College Scores
description: College Scores

title: A vice president explains the ABC's of television
description: This look at the television industry from a straighttalking insider serves two useful functions, at least one of them intentional. First, The Cool Fire offers more information about how television works than any single volume I have encountered. Bob Shanks has rendered the technical, logistical and corporate mysteries of the TV business into a dear, coherent and entertaining package. He covers the waterfront: how a television signal is transmitted; how talent agencies, advertisers, producers, directors and technicians work, and what exactly they do. He describes how to present a show to a producer or a network; how ratings work (or don't); what the industry jargon means.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I have nothing against people who don't smoke. I stopped smoking myself for five years once and it didn't do me any noticeable harm. If people want to sit around not smoking, it doesn't offend me in the least. I certainly wouldn't bully them and try to make them feel absolutely terrible about not taking up the habit.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NEW YORK CITY had rarely seemed as remote from Long Island as it did at 80 the other Monday morning when I reported to the Sivuth Side Senior High Si:hool on Shepherd Street in Rockville Centre. There were 80 11thgraders in the auditorium, all about to make a tour of Manhattan's Lower East Side, a world they never made and certainly never knew.

title: Notes: Taming The Wilds
description: Wilderness treks, those vacation forays into the great outdoors, are increasingly aimed at city slickers, and sometimes the creature comforts are enough to make strong men weep.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Film directorsgreat film directorsare not peripatetic as jugglers. Though film directors carry fewer props they are surrounded by baggage that is not always to be packed up and crated without causing certain damage. To anyone in this country who admires Ingmar Bereman's films which appear to be as much a product of Swedish society, landscape, language, custom, expectation and heritage as of the director's unique sensibility, the news of his decision to leave Sweden and settle abroad must be as disturbing as it is to his countrymen. It's not a matter of sentimentality or even of politics, though Bergman's treatment by the bureaucrats of the Swedish socialism he admired is the material of a 21st century nightmare. One worries about how well the Bergman genius will travel.

title: White Sox Set to Drop Cleon Jones
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI) The Chicago White Sox announced plans today to release unconditionally Cleon Jones, their starting left fielder, who earned a spot with the club in spring training. The Sox purchased the contract of a hothitting second baseman, Hugh Yancy, from the Iowa Oaks of the American Association.

title: Judith Pesin Is Married
description: Judith Ann Pesin, daughter of Councilman Morris Pcsin and Mrs. Pesin of Jersey City, was married yesterday afternoon to Lawrence Guy Donofrio of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Donofrio of Southport, Conn. Civil Court Judge Sheldon S. Levy performed the ceremony in the Tower Suite of the Time and Life Building. The bride is a marketing analyst with the Citibank N.A., where her husband is manager of corporate management support.

title: Odometer Fraud Called Widespread
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 29A Westchester County special grand jury has found evidence of widespread odometer fraud in the sale of cars in the state, which it said was costing consumers incalucuable sums.

title: Books of The Times
description: Does professional football represent the best in American life, as the National Football League recently asked in an essay contest? Here are one good nonfiction account and one exceptional first novel to provide some theoretical answers. Dr. Arnold J. Mandell must have thought so when Gene Klein and Harland Svare, respectively the owner and coach of the San Diego Chargers, came to him and asked him to work parttime with the team for the 1973 season. Dr. Mandell was (and still is) a practicing psychiatrist, cochairman of the psychiatry department at the University of California at San Diego Medical School, a researcher in brain chemistry and psychopharmacology, and a football fan. The San Diego Chargers were trying to turn a bad team into a good one overnight by trading for troublesome and dissatisfied players and nursing them to victory with understanding. A place for a good psychiatrist was seen in the mix. And when Dr. Mandell was propositioned, he felt a warm and maternally protective gush. The psychiatric version of functioning breasts when the milk comes in. I knew I would work for the welfare of this man [Coach Svare] and his men.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Obituary 3  No Title

title: EXLINDSAY AIDE FACES TAX COUNT
description: Sid Davidoff, an administrative assistant to former Mayor John V. Lindsay, has been indicted by a state grand jury for alleged violation of state tax laws in the operation of his now defunct midtown restaurant, Jimmy's.

title: New York City Budget Cuts Said to Hurt Children
description: Threefourths of the budget cuts resulting from the city's current fiscal crisis are being made in areas affecting human services, the chairman of the city's Crisis Task Force said yesterday.

title: Cunningham Will Waive Rights and Testify to Jury
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, Democratic state chairman, said last night that he was ready to address the grand jury or an swer grand jury questions and was waiving his right to appeal against a subpoena of his personal financial records.

description: OXFORD, EnglandOxford has emerged from the university turmoil of the last decade sedate, its classic facades unsmeared, its lawns unruffled, its dons and students still talking to each other in a spirit of mutual tolerance.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KALINOWSKI (Polish), Gdynia May ??? ?? from ??? N.J.

title: Carter a Threat to Wallace In Home State Tomorrow
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 For Gov. George C. Wallace, the 1976 Presidential race has deteriorated to the point that he is trying to stave off political embarrassment in the state he has governed and dominated for more than a decade.

title: Mets Beaten in 9th by Astros, Then Win
description: The New York Mets found themselves in a contradictory position yesterday after splitting a doubleheader with the Houston Astros before a crowd of 34,642 (29,846 paid) at Shea Stadium.

title: A Bicentennial Event Stirs Bistate Rivalry
description: TITUSVILLE, May 2  if Pennsylvania does not interfere, New Jersey's major Bicentennial event will be a reenactment of Washington's crossing the Delaware and winning the battles of Trenton and Princeton.

title: RUMSFELD TO CHECK RECRUITS TRAINING
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld says he has ordered a review of recruit training practices in all the armed services in the wake of the death of a young marine in a close combat drilll.

title: Mrs. Carner Golf Victor
description: ATLANTA, May 2 (UPI)Jo Anne Carner came out of the woods to make an eagle today to vault ahead of Silvia Bertolaccini of Argentina, and win the Lady Tara Classic by three strokes with a 10under 209.

title: PRICE SPLIT HELD A THREAT TO OPEC
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 2Iran's chief oil negotiator, Jamshid Amuzegar, declared today that the issue of price differentials for differing grades of crude oil could have grave consequences for the unity of the organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: March Inflows Near Peak At Savings and Loan Units
description: The nation's savings and loan associations received $3.68 billion more in deposits than withdrawals last March, the Federal Home Loan Bank announced yesterday. The inflow in March was only a touch below the record $3.69 billion posted in the 1975 month.

title: Dave Anderson
description: TRENTON, May 2In the pit area at Trenton International Speedway today mechanics in fireproof clothes were tinkering with the right wheel on the empty blue racing car. Above the seat, a white driver's helmet had JAN marked with black tape on each side. On the back of the helmet were four small whiteonblue identification strips:

title: Personal Finance: Ways To Reduce Estate Taxes
description: More and more people who have reached retirement age are considering the use of discounted dollars  dollars that buy instruments that are worth more than their original cost when they mature at the holder's death.

title: New Energy, Old Habits
description: Inertia in taking novel or imaginative approaches to this country's future energy needs remains one of the most formidable bottlenecks in the Federal bureaucracy in devising a rational energy policy. Two senior energy aides have resigned in recent months, mincing no words about their frustrations in obtaining a hearing at the highest levels of Government for unconventional measures to alleviate potential shortages.

title: Miss Mellone Wed To W. H. Phillips Jr.
description: Christine Frances Mellone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Joseph Mellone of Barrington, RI., was married yes terday afternoon to Wilson Haywood Phillips Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips of Henderson, N.C.

title: Roberta Melton Bride Of Dr. R. J. Hirschman
description: Roberta Christine Melton, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Melton of Vancouver, British Columbia, and the late Mr. Melton, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard James Hirschman. He is the son of Mrs. Sol R. Hirschman of New York and the late Dr. Hirschman, a physician.

title: Flyers Crush Bruins
description: BOSTON, May 2  The Philadelphia Flyers defied their boisterous reputations tonight, as well as their past performances here, and defeated the Boston Bruins, 52, to take a twotoone lead in their National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Israeli President Cancels French Visit Over Protocol
description: JERUSALEM, May 2 (Reuters)Israel's President, Ephraim Katzir, has cancelled a private visit to France next month because it was felt here he was not going to get the treatment due a head of state.

title: Jane Manus Married to Harry Jonas Jr.
description: Jane Elizabeth Manus and Harry Jonas Jr. of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., were married yesterday evening in the Colony Hotel in Palm Beach by Circuit Court Judge John R. Berenek of Palm Beach County.

title: State Democrats Challenged on Women and Young Delegates
description: A challenge to New York's atlarge delegation to the Democratic National Convention, on the ground that it does not include enough women and young people, was drawn up yesterday.

title: Correspondents to Leave
description: TOKYO, Monday May 3 (AP) Saigon's ruling Revolutionary Committee has told two Japanese correspondents and a French reporter to leave South Vietnam, an official of the Japan Broadcasting Corporation said today.

title: Buyers Find Signs Of Brisk Economy
description: American businesses are experiencing a gradual tightening of supplies, slower deliveries and a rise in pricesall evidence of a quickening pace in business activitythe National Association of Purchasing Management saidyesterday.

title: Juvenile Crime Laws
description: The state legislators are under heavy pressure to approve new laws designed to stiffen punishment for juveniles arrested for serious crimes. The report released yesterday by the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services suggests major deficiencies in the juvenile justice system and demonstrates the need for a searching review of the juvenile justice laws.

title: Instruction of History Displays Shift Away From Factual Content to Concepts
description: Many of the students who took the New York Times American History Knowledge and Attitude Survey test reported, often with a mixture of shame ur bitterness, that it had shown them how much history they did not know.

title: 2 Studies Conclude That New York City Should Substantially Increase Its Contributions to Pension Systems
description: Two recent studies of the city's pension systems agree that substantially larger annual contributions are required by the city to keep the retirement programs adeauatelv funded.

title: DATA SHOW NAVY LEADS IN BIG SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Previously secret information supplied by the Pentagon to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, shows that in the last 15 years the United States has built twice as many large combat ships as the Soviet Union.

title: Reagan, Ford And Carter
description: BOSTON, May 2Remember the condescending talk about Ronald Reagan after New Hampshire and Florida? He had done Gerald Ford a favor by running, the political sages saidhad given the President a chance to prove himself an effective national campaigner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your April 26 editorial B1 Politics indicates a serious lack of understanding of the weapon system acquisition process of our Government.

title: Oxford Remembers the Past Decade's Turmoil Dimly
description: OXFORD, EnglandOxford has emerged from the university turmoil of the last decade sedate, its classic facades unsmeared, its lawns unruffled, its dons and students still talking to each other in a spirit of mutual tolerance.

title: Price Trend Up for Many Metals
description: Last week's steel price increases, affecting automobiles, appliances and other products, have overshadowed the recent wave of price rises in nonferrous metals. The upsurge in aluminum, copper, brass, lead and cadmium in the last several weeks bodes ill for maintaining a low rate of inflation.

title: Building Workers Threaten to Begin Strike Wednesday
description: Negotiations failed to resolve a contract dispute between 20,000 building workers and their employers yesterday, prompting a state mediator to declare that a strike now seemed inevitable on Wednesday in 4,000 apartment buildings in New York City.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Obituary 5  No Title

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MAY 3, 1976

title: H. GRAHAM MORISON, U.S. PROSECUTOR, 69
description: H. Graham Morison, an assistant United States Attorney General from 1948 to 1952, died Saturday at Sibley Hospital in Washington after a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at Great Falls, Va.

title: PANAGOULIS FAMILY CHARGES MURDER
description: ATHENS, May 2 (Reuters)The family of Alexandros Panagoulis, a Greek opposition politician and resistance hero who was killed in a car crash yesterday, said today that he had been murdered and accused the Government of covering up an assassination plot. The police have said the crash was an accident.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rents for longterm residents of rentstabilized hotels are subject to maximum increases of 6 percent between last Jan. 1 and April 30, 1977, under an order by the Rent Guidelines Board. The increases may be collected retroactively to Jan. 1 in monthly installments. The Housing and Development Administration said that the order covered about 17,600 hotel units that had been occupied by the same tenants for more than six months but that it would not affect tenants qualifying for senior citizen rent increase exemptions, for which owners axe given credit against their real estate taxes.

title: Film: Day in Life of Bissie Hapgood:Karen Arthur 'Legacy' at Cinema Studio
description: Bissie Hapgood has problems. Her mother is semle and calls her on the telephone simply 10 cry Bissie's husband does not satisfy her sexually. Her 8-year-old son wets his bed, and her best friend has an annoying habit of wandering away from the telephone when Bissie is in the midst of one of her non-stop, free-association phone calls about her weight, her Japanese gardener or some other self-absorbed topic.When Bissie calls Her analyst to describe her latest suicide fantasy, the analyst, apparently bored, suggests that she keep busy,Bissie tries, God knows she tries. In the day in the life of Bissie Hapgood conered by "Legacy." which opened yesterday at the ???n ema Studio, Bissie makes preparations for a formal dinner party.Busy-ness, however. leads directly to disaster when she finds that she is missing one sterling silver butter knite. Not only has Black, Starr & Gorham discontinued the pattern, there is no longer any Black, Starr & Gorham. Which is enough to send a woman as obsessed with trivia as Bissie is over the edge into lunacy."Legacy,' which was directed and produced by Karen Arthur (her first feature) and written by Joan Hotchkis, who also plays Bissie is a most peculiar sort of movie but not, a very good one. It also seems uncommonly cruel for a film about a woman made by women. It might. I think, have made a very funny movie if Miss Hotchkis had allowed herself the grace of humor, which is another way of saying compassion, instead of treating Bissie as a foolish, four-star nut.Bissie has problems, and they are real ones, but "Legacy" only catalogues them without making them seem important or moving. Miss Hotchkis, the actress as well as the writer, displays some talent, for satire and none at all for comedy or drama.The form of the film doesn't help. "Legacy" is said to be based on a play by Miss Hotchkis, which I suspect actually to have been the kind of Ruth Draperish monologue that is best delivered from a lecture platform.Although we do see Bissie's mother briefly (in the film's only arresting sequence) and Bissie's husband and children (in short flashbacks). "Legacy" is still a one-woman move. a 90-minute monologue that might easily have been reduced to a quarter of an hour Nothing that either Miss Hotchkis or Miss Arthur does can disguise the awkwardness and artificiality of this monologue form, which finally destroys any serious thoughts the film makers might have about women, the bourgeoisie, sex, America and the difficulty of getting good domestic help in Southern California.Eventually, the whole thing comes to look like an act of immense vanity.

title: Boston Busing Foes Rally as Blacks and Whites Voice Concern Over Worsening Racial Situation in the
description: BOSTON, May 2The antibusing whites of this city's embattled neighborhoods rallied again today at the foot of the Revolutionary War monument on Bunker Hill.

title: GOLDWATER CALLS REAGAN IN ERROR
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Senator Barry Goldwater, appearing increasingly worried that the Presidential quest of Ronald Reagan will irreparably divide the Republican Party, charged today that Mr. Reagan did not fully understand the Panama Canal issue he was raising and suggested that the Californian stop talking about it.

title: High Schools Cut Priority For Teaching U. S. History
A Public Reproach In Peking Reported For Three Rioters
description: TOKYO, May 2 (AP)A public scolding was given to three Chinese for counterrevolutionary conduct during a riot in Peking's main square last month, a Yugoslav newspaper reported today.

title: A Reply to I. F. Stone
description: To the Editor: A red herring, according to the Doubleday Dictionary, is an irrelevant topic introduced in order to divert attention from the main point under discussion. Harry S. Truman used the term in 1948 to describe the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities Communist spy probes, including the HissChambers inquiry.

title: PROF. E. J. BROWDER, A NEUROSURGEON, 81
description: Dr. E. Jefferson Browder, professor emeritus of neurosurgery, at the Downstate Medical Centr in Brooklyn of the State University of New York, died Saturday at his home in Hackettstown, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Pakistani Irrigation Dam Suffers Erosion in Test
description: TARBELA, Pakistan, May 2 (Reuters)The government has disclosed a setback to an earthfilled dam on the Indus River.

title: Carter Seems Angry
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 2 Mr. Carter reacted with what appeared to be cold anger today to questions about the criticism leveled against him by Mr. Shrum.

title: SAIGON BIDS CONSULS TRANSFER TO HANOI
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2 (UPI)The yearold Communist Government in Saigon has asked foreign consulates and news bureaus and most international agencies to close their South Vietnamese oocrations and move to Hanoi, capital of the new unified Vietnam.

title: WNEW to Sample Opinions of Viewers
description: As a special feature in its nightly newscasts at 10, WNEWTV will sample viewer opinions on controversial issues by means of the Votrak Information System, a highspeed polling device capable of handling 100,000 phone calls an hour and tallying the results. The system had been tested last week on two publicaccess channels of the Manhattan Cable Television system and will be used on Channel 5 for the first time tonight.

title: Scott Standout as Celtics Oust Braves
description: The offseason trade that had brought Charlie Scott from the Phoenix Suns to the Boston Celtics for Paul Westphal was never more productive than yesterday afternoon in Buffalo.

title: Illinois College Defies Premature Reports and Clings to Life
description: MOUNT CARROLL, Ill.Like Mark Twain, who said that the news of his ?? was greatly exaggerated, Shinier College has been plagued by premature reports of its having gone out of existence.

title: May Misses a NoHitter in 9th, Yankees Downed in 11th, 21
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 2 Gold turned to dross right before the eyes of the New York Yankees today as they lost an 11inning 21 decision to the Kansas City Royals after Rudy May had entered the ninth with a nohitter and a 10 lead.

title: Neighborhood: Center Square Reviving
description: ALBANY, May 2  Good organization, luck and an accommodating Federal housing policy appear to have saved the Center Square section of Albany.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE FOUND DEFICIENT IN NEW YORK CITY
description: A study by a state agency disclosed yesterday that only 4.4 percent of the juveniles arrested for violent crimes in New York City over a oneyear period were sent to institutions.

title: A City in Florida Wins Suit Over Noise Pollution in Zoo
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 2 (UPI)  in what may prove to be a landmark decision on control of noise pollution, a Circuit Court jury has ordered the State of Florida to spend $1.7 million on a 22foot wall to keep the noise of Interstate 95 from disturbing a park and a zoo.
