title: BUSINESSMEN ASK VOTING BILL VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Nlay 2Big ??? is pressing President Ford to ??? legislation recon??? the Federal Election??? arguing that the ??? gives too much political power to organized labor.

title: Buckley Joins Fight to Toughen Air Act
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, has joined the four Republican members of the Public Works Committee in a letter urging party colleagues to support a committee amendment to the Clean Air Act of 1970 that would prohibit industrial pollution in national parks and wilderness areas.

title: Tens of Thousands Join March to the Dag Hammarskjold Plaza on Behalf of Soviet Jewry
description: Tens of thousands of people from all over the metropolitan area marched on behalf of Soviet Jewry yesterday, carrying the ancient cry, Let my people go, from 65th Street and Fifth Avenue to the shadow of the United Nations, where speaker after speaker proclaimed it the duty of Americans to speak out against oppression.

title: Advertising
description: After a year and a half, the relationship of Young & Rubicam with the Continental Can Company bore visible fruit last week. Now the client is called the Continental Group, and that first fruitan ad in several publications announced that the name change had been approved by the stockholders.

title: Electronic System Urged For a U.S. Stock Market
description: An electronic system for handling stock transactions without the need for stock exchanges has been proposd to the Securities and Exchange Commission by a New Jersey consulting firM in a 50page report made public today.

title: GOLDWATER CALLS REAGAN IN ERROR
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Senator Barry Goldwater, appearing increasingly worried that the Presidential quest of Ronald Reagan will irreparably divide the Republican Party, charged today that Mr. Reagan did not fully understand the Panama Canal issue he was raising and suggested that the Californian stop talking about it.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE FOUND DEFICIENT IN NEW YORK CITY
description: A study by a state agency disclosed yesterday that only 4.4 percent of the juveniles arrested for violent crimes in New York City over a oneyear period were sent to institutions.

title: Underwater Houdini Ends Up in Hospital
description: ONEIDA, N.Y., May 2 (AP) A wouldhe Houdini was in fair condition here today after failing to make good an underwater escape from four pair of handcuffs and a padlocked burlap bag.

title: DEMOCRATIC VOTE PROPELS REAGAN TO TEXAS SWEEP
description: DALLAS, May 2A massive Democratic crossover vote helped Ronald Reagan capture all 96 Republican delegates in the Texas primary yesterday, stunning President Ford's campaign with victory margins of more than 2 to 1 in virtually every district.

title: Marching
description: BOSTON  The trauma afflicting Boston is a direct result of the myth that has seen the light of reality through the edicts of Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. in the city's schooldesegregation case.

title: 14 Die in Slide in Colombian Andes
description: FRESNO. Colombia. May 2 (UPI)  An early morning landslide brought on by rains buried a highway in central Colombia today. Killing at least 14 people and injuring 20 in an avalanche o mud and stones.

title: Rusk Endorses Carter
description: ATHENS, Ga., May 2 (UPI)Dean Rusk, former Secretary of State endorsed Jimmy Carter for President today, saying that the former Georgia Governor offers the nation a chance for a fresh start somewhat in the spirit of John F. Kennedy. I think lie has the makings of a very good President, said Mr. Rusk, a professor of international law at the University of Georgia, who served as Secretary of State to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson from 196169.

title: Consumerism Alive
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs proved last week that consumer issues could still draw a crowd and politicians, even though the financial crisis has placed consumer affairs well down the list of spending priorities. The events of Consumer Week, including a news conference at City Hall and a luncheon and series of workshops at the New York Sheraton Hotel, were attended by more than 700 people, including many business representatives, highranking state officials and, most significantly, Mayor Beanie and Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: DEMOCRATIC VOTE PROPELS REAGAN TO TEXAS SWEEP
description: DALLAS, May 2A massive Democratic crossover vote helped Ronald Reagan capture all 96 Republican delegates in the Texas primary yesterday, stunning President Ford's campaign with victory margins of more than 2 to 1 in virtually every district.

title: Illinois College Defies Premature Reports and Clings to Life
description: MOUNT CARROLL, Ill. Like Mark Twain, who said that the news of his death was greatly exaggerated, Shimer College has been plagued by premature reports of its having gone out of existence.

title: Japanese Scale Nepal Peak
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 2 (AP)Thirteea Japanese climbers and three Sherpa guides have scaled the 22,920foot Lainjung Himal peak in western Nepal, Nepal's Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: SCHOLARS OPPOSE UNESCO AT TALKS
description: A conference of intellectuals concerned with the future of UNESCO met yesterday to discuss the organization and spent most of the time assailing its actions against Israel.

title: Poll by Time Finds Carter Would Defeat Ford Today
description: New York, May 2 (Reuters)Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia would defeat President Ford, 48 percent to 38 percent, if the Presidential election were held today, according to a Time magazine poll.

title: Tall Ships Start Atlantic Race
description: PLYMOUTH, England. May 2 The statesmen of the world who have had trouble finding the right formula for international brotherhoo:i might wish to try a combination of sailors, ships, the sea and Scotch whisky. These were some of the ingredients tossed together here today in the Tall Ships race, and the result was detente of a high order. Even Henry Kissinger would have been pleased.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on international trade law  10:00 A.M. ??? 3 P.M.

title: LSD Suspected as 20 In Parade Are Hysterical
description: FOWLER, Calif., May 2 (UPI)The authorities are trying to discover what caused 20 teenagers to break into hysterics during a weekend junior high school parade and scream wildly. The assumption by the police and the doctor who treated them at the Fowler Hospital is that they were slipped some LSD in their cold drinks.

title: Building Workers Threaten to Begin Strike Wednesday
description: Negotiations failed to resolve a contract dispute between 20,000 building workers and their employers yesterday, prompting a state mediator to declare that a strike now seemed inevitable on Wednesday in 4,000 apartment buildings in New York City.

title: CARTER PROMISES TO NAME BLACKS
description: CHARLOTTE. N. C., May 2Arriving here from his sweeping victory yesterday in the Texas primary, a confident Jimmy Carter asked black Democratic leaders today to draw up a list of positions to which they would like to see blacks appointed if he became President.

title: Hunt Set Down, Lauda Wins Race
description: MADRID. May 2 (UPI)James Hunt of Britain finished first today in the Grand Prix of Spain but race officials later disqualified him on a technicality and declared Niki Lauda of Austria the winner.Hunt and Laffitte [Jacques] have been disqualified, officials said at the end of a jury meeting. Hunt's McLaren team immediately appealed the disqualification which was that the aerofoil was fiveeigths of an inch too wide.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Obituary 6  No Title

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Is Growing in Power
description: AGRA, India, May 2Sanjay Gandhi, who has become one of the most important people in Indian politics, came to this ancient capital today to shake some hands, make some decisions and demonstrate, as he does regularly these days, his growing power and influence.

title: Beirut Engulfed in New Wave of Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, May 3 Beirut is suffering a new surge of violence, spurred by the political deadlock over the election of a new president.

title: San Francisco Strike Enters 2d Month but Residents Don't Seem Concerned
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2The strike by 1,800 municipal craft workers has entered its second month, with only slight prospects of an early settlement and few indications that many residents and commuters are concerned.

title: Rutherford Wins at Trenton; Miss Guthrie In 15th Place
description: TRENTON, May 2Janet Guthrie, one voice in the crowd of 16,232 at Trenton International Speedway suggested this morning, Go back to the kitchen.

title: Irishtocrat Is Top Dog At Trenton
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N. J. May 2The Irish water spaniel is frequently called the clown of the dog show world. But one of the livercolored dogs was all business today at the 47th Trenton Kennel Club. He was Ch. Oaktrees Irishtocrat, owned by Anne Snelling of Ottawa.

title: Protests Rise in Paris Among Alien Workers
description: PARIS, May 2After decades of virtual silence and accept ance of the lowest place in French society, the foreign workers in this country, who do many of the menial, dirty jobs the French no longer accept, are turning to militant action to attract public attention to their complaints.

title: Farmers, in Squeeze on Costs, Cut Fertilizer Buying
description: Farmers, squeezed by rising costs, falling prices, huge unsold stocks of the key 1975 crops and, in some regions, idled by drought, are sharply reducing their purchases of fertilizer this spring.

title: BOMBINGS ERUPT IN SOVIET GEORGIA
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., April 30The smooth veneer of political unanimity has been cracked in Soviet Georgia recently by a series of fires and bombings in Government buildings.

title: Egypt Moves Ahead in Westernizing of Economy
description: CAIRO, May 2The Government of President Anwar elSadat is pressing ahead quietly with its efforts to bring the political and economic institutions of Egypt into closer harmony with American and Western European concepts.

title: U.S. JURY TO HEAR SUFFOLK OFFICIALS
description: The County Executive leading Republican and Democratic officials and legislators and administrators in Suffolk County will be among those asked to appear before a Federal grand jury being convened in Brooklyn to investigate alleged improprieties in the $1.4 billion Southwest Sewer District project.

title: Rufus B. Smith. Economist. ExForeign Service Official
description: Rufus Burr Smith, holder of the William It. Kenan Chair of Economics at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., since 1967 and a former senior Foreign Service inspector for the State Department, died Friday night after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Winter Park.

title: BOMBINGS ERUPT IN SOVIET GEORGIA
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., April 30The smooth veneer of political unanimity has been cracked in Soviet Georgia recently by a series of fires and bombings in Government buildings.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: TitleClouded Bronx Site Sold to City
description: An examination of Bronx Terminal Market transactions has brought to light another unusual arrangement in which the city bought land for which it had no immediate use, and which had a cloud on the title.

title: About New York
description: My boys look so cute in those white uniforms, so so clean, Lucy Donatiu was saying yesterday. No one has nicer uniforms than mine.

title: Editor of Detroit Free Press Wins Award for Editorials
description: Joe H. Stroud, editor of The Detroit Free Press, yesterday was named the winner of Columbia University's 1976 Paul Tohenkin Memorial Award for his editorials dealing with the problems of age discrimination, rare relationc, drug addletion end the needs of the nation's cities.

title: Concert: Four Germans
description: Lukas Foss can he a willful and eccentric conductol and his Brooklyn Philha rmonia hardly ranks among the great ensembles of the world, the country or even the city. But Mr. Foss has been blessed with a genuinely lively musical mind. and thus the orchestra's annual Carnegie Hall concert. yesterday afternoon proved an invigorating experience.

title: High Schools Cut Priority For Teaching U. S. History
description: American high schools are giving decreasing priority to the teaching of American history, and in what they do teach there has been a gradual shift away from traditional factual content toward the teaching of basic concepts.

title: Elder Golf Victor by Stroke As Rivals Falter in Houston
description: HOUSTON, May 2Lee Elder won the Houston open this afternoon without, so to speak, swinging a golf club.

title: Phils Top Braves
description: Philadelphia Phils fans, the ones who go out to the ball park to watch their heroes in action, may not believe it. But, although they have won only three of nine games in Veterans Stadium, the Phils are in first place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Crosland Leaves for Peking
description: LONDON, May 2 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland left here today for Peking and Tokyo on his first ??? missinn since taking office three weeks ago.

title: Oakland's Port Business Grows
description: OAKLAND, Calif. While no one is yet singing about leaving his heart in Oakland, the maritime industry is increasingly leaving here a more substantial economic commodityits ships and business.

title: Carter Says He'll Trim Campaign Time And Step Up Bid to Unite Party Chiefs
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 2Jimmy Carter said today that he would spend fewer 16hour clays on the campaign trail and more days in the reconciliag, role of Democratic Party leader, which he now clearly expects to become.

title: Rev. William J. Mulcahy. 71. ExFordham Vice President
description: The Rev. William J. Mulcahy, vice president of Fordham University for business and finance from 1953 to 1966, died Friday at St. Peter Hall, the residence for members of the Society of Jesus at St. Peter's College in Jersey City. He was 71 years old.

title: Radio
description: 67:30, WNYCFM: Masterwork Hour. A Short Overture, Kay; Symphonic Sketches, Chadwick; Piano Concerto, Carter; Symphony on a Hymn Tune, Thomson.7:3010:25, WKCRFM. String Trio in G, Beethoven; Violin Concerto, Barber; Concerto for Two Pianos, Bach.

title: Newspaper Publishers Start ThreeDay Meeting at WaldorfAstoria Today
description: More than 1,400 newspaper publishers will asemble at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel today for the start of the threeday 90th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association to examine the range of problems that face the Amerlican press.

title: Shucking the Tamale
description: WASHINGTON  There were two things I learned in Texas, President Ford said to White House correspondents after his rout by Ronald Reagan on Saturday. One is  never underestimate your opponent, and two always shuck the tamale.

title: Hearnes Sues Justice Dept. Over Investigation of Him
description: ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP)Charging that he has long been the target of flagrant abuse of Government authority, a former Governor of Missouri, Warren E. Hearnes, has filed suit against the Justice Department and Attorney General Edward H. Levi.

title: Rutherford Wins at Trenton; Miss Guthrie In 15th Place
description: TRENTON, May 2Janet Guthrie, one voice in the crowd of 16,232 at Trenton International Speedway suggested this morning, Go back to the kitchen.

title: 8 Thai Soldiers Killed
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2 (AP)  Communist guerrillas killed eight Thai soldiers and seriously wounded three others in an ambush in a southern border province, military Sriurces said today.

title: RhodesiaSouth Africa Road Reopens to Convoys Today
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 2 (AP)Rhodesia will reopen the main road connecting with South Africa to convoys of motorists with armed escorts tomorrow, according to a police spokesman.

title: Students of Hughes's Life Doubt Will s Authenticity
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2Among many people who have studied Howard R. Hughes as closely as they could during his almost 20 years in seclusion, serious doubts have grown about the validity of the purported Hughes will that turned up mysteriously Tuesday.

title: Soviet Jewry Backed
description: Tens of thousands of people marched on behalf of Soviet Jewry and rallied near the United Nations, where speakers proclaimed it the duty of Americans to speak out against oppression. Governor Carey designated yesterday as Solidarity Sunday in New York. Page 61.

title: Walk Traces Hackensack's Past
description: HACKENSACK May 2Hackensack residents learned about 300 years of their history today as they took part in a walking tour sponsored by the Bergen Community Museum.

title: Wayne Mixes Hyacinths and History
description: WAYNE, May 2  What better gift to the people of a town rich in Dutch history, including living descendants as numerous as tulips along the Zuyder Zee, than 3,000 hyacinth bulbs from the Netherlands Government?

title: Cornell Study Finds 11% of Surgery Is Unnecessary
description: A Cornell University Medical College study suggests that 11 percentand perhaps as many as 13 percentof persons who are told by their physicians to have an operation may not need the surgery after all.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Obituary 4  No Title

title: Soviet TeenAger Takes Diving Title
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 2 (AP)  Irina Kalinina, a 17yearold from the Soviet Union, stamped herself as a top Olympic prospect today by finishing first and second in an international diving meet here.

title: A CARTER WRITER QUITS IN PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON. May 2Robert M. Shrum, a speechwrit??? who entered Jimmy Carter's inner circle last month, jumped off the Georgia Democrat's Presidential bandwagon last week, a disillusioned man.

title: Reagan's Big Need Now
description: DALLAS, May 2Ronald Reagan inflicted upon PresiI dent Ford yesterday the worst trouncing ever suffered by an incumbent in a Presidential primary. However atypical Texas may be, however dubious it may be that the former California Governor can repeat his performance elsewhere, the magnitude of Mr. Ford's defeat in Texas will inevitably have an impact on the course of the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination. The President had expected to losealthough, temporarily bewitched by his crowds, he predicted victory a couple of times last weekout not by better than 2 to 1 in most areas, not by 96 to 0 in the delegate totals.

title: John Orr Young Is Dead at 89; CoFounded Young & Rubicam
description: John Orr Young, a founder of the Young & Ruhicam advertising agency and the man who was credited with starting a movement in 1947 aimed at the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President, died Saturday at his home in Heritage Village. Southbury, Conn. He was 89 years old.

title: Reagan's Bid Need Now
description: DALLAS, May 2Ronald Reagan inflicted upon President Ford yesterday the worst trouncing ever suffered by an incumbent in a Presidential primary. However atypical Texas may De, however dubious it may be that the former California Governor an repeat his performance elsewhere, the magnitude of Mr. Ford's defeat in Texas will inevitably have an impact on the course of the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: In Texas, a Reunion Ladybird Johnson Happily Calls Her Last Great Roundup
description: L.B.J. RANCH, Stonewall, Tex., May 2Horses whinnied cattle bawled the steam calliope almost blew its boiler and there was a terrific amount of Texas kissing and carrying on by the banks of the Pedernales River this afternoon.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Improved taxi service at the Newark International. Airport will be the subject of talks Friday aimed at encouraging greater use of the airport, according to a spokesman for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson. The spokesman said that discussion would center on group ridership and reciprocal agreements between Newark and New York City cabdrivers, which would permit for the first time a driver to pick up airport fares in both directions. Because the Newark airport is easier to get to, the spokesman said, we're going to try to convince people in downtown New York that it makes more sense to come to Newark for flights.

title: Egypt to Pay Compensation
description: The agreement was signed Yesterday by the Egyptian Minister of Economy. Mohammed Zaki Shafei, and the American Deputy Secretary of Stale, Charles W. Robinson.

title: National Merit Awards Go To 1,000 More Students
description: One thousand high school seniors from across the country have been named winners of $1.000 scholarships by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: Papp's Threepenny Echoes Original
description: For its final offering of Its Vivian Beaumont season, Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival is staging the Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill modern classic Threepenny Opera. This somberly blazing masterpiece opened Saturday night and for admirers of the old Marc Blitzstein version, which ran for many years off Broadway at the Theater de Lys, it could be quite a shock. It is also the most interesting and original thing Mr. Papp has produced since he set up shop at the Vivian Beaumont three seasons ago.

title: CARTER PROMISES TO NAME BLACKS
description: CHARLOTTE. N. C., May 2Arriving here from his sweeping victory yesterday in the Texas primary, a confident Jimmy Carter asked black Democratic leaders today to draw up a list of positions to which they would like to see blacks appointed if he became President.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The first leg of the biennial international transAtlantic Tall Ships race began yesterday at Plymouth, England. The first ship across the starting line was the Soviet Union's Kruzenshtern, a 3,000ton squarerigged, fourmasted bark manned by a crew of 236, of whom 160 were naval cadets. The first leg will end in about 18 days in the Canary Islands, the second in Bermuda in midJune, the third in Newport, R.I., at the end of June, and the fourth in Plymouth in August. The entire fleet will sail into New York Harbor on July 4 to celebrate the Bicentennial. [Page 1, Columns 13.]

title: Paper Names New Editor
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., May 2; (AP)Paul H. Tracy, 59, of Goffstown, has been named: editor in chief of the Manchester Union Leader and the New Hampshire Sunday News. Mr. Tracy, who has been managing editor for the past seven years, succeeds. B. J. McQuaid, who died two weeks ago.

title: A Tasty Memory of the Old Days in Chicago
description: Years ago in Chicago, Milton Schwartz of Westport, Conn., wrote us, I used to enjoy a delicious dish called shrimp de Jonghe. At that time, this was quite a popular dish in the Chicago area and was, I believe developed by a Chicago chef.

title: STOLEN CAR CRASHES IN WEST SIDE CHASE
description: A highspeed car chase yesterday through streets on the Upper West Side ended in front of Lincoln Center when a stolen car crashed into a phone booth.

title: U.S. to India in 13 Hours
description: NEW DELHI, May 2 (Reuters)A Pan American airliner landed here today from New York to complete the world's longest nonstop flight for commercial aircraft, Pan American ??? said. The plane, a shortened version of the Boeing 747 carrying more than 100 passengers, made the first nonstop flight from the United States to India, covering 8,088 miles in 13 hours and 31 minutes, the airline officials said.

title: U.S. Companies Cut Back Operations In Europe as Risks and Costs Multiply
description: PARIS, May 2The investment wave of the 1960's is receding, with American corporations trimming their European operations and selling off subsidiaries.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Is Growing in Power
description: AGRA, India, May 2Sanjay Gandhi, who has become one of the most important people in Indian politics, came to this ancient capital today to shake some hands, make some decisions and demonstrate, as he does regularly these days, his growing power and influence.

title: Bridge:
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 2  The world team championship began here today and, as in 1975 in Bermuda, accusations of cheating involving the Italian players have bedeviled the atmosphere.

title: Congress in Prague
description: On the surface at least, the recent 15th Czechoslovak Communist Party Congress in Prague was one of the less noteworthy such gatherings in Communist history. The chief theme was the allegedly inexhaustible loyalty the Czech and Slovak peoples to the Soviet Union.

title: 28,436 at Stadium See Cosmos Lose
description: The New York Cosmos showed off their major problem to 28,436 fans at Yankee Stadium yesterday  they have trouble scoring goals.

title: CAMPAIGN CURBED BY MRS. M'CORMACK
description: SILVER SPRING Md May 2(AP)Ellen McCormack the antiabortion candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomina, tion has decided to curtail her campaigning because of the freeze on Federal matching funds but she said will not withdraw.

title: Top 2 Scorers on Times History Test
description: David Evans, a freshman at Augustana College in Rock Isiand. 1H., was the highest scorer on the New York Times American history test, which was administered to 1.556 students across the country. He missed only one of 42 questions, sharing with many other students a misconception of the South during Reconstruction.

title: A Day in Beirut: Death Begins in Afternoon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2 The Beirut day has established itself with wearisome, deadly familiarity.

title: Miss Evert, Back in Groove, Takes Final
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla., May 2Wet or dry as long as the surface is clay, Chris Evert is invincible.

title: Texas Tornado
description: Texas voters have given former Governor Ronald Reagan the victory he had to have if his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination was to stay alive. But by giving him a victory of such stunning magnitude, they have done more than revive his campaign. They have wiped away much of the damaging effect of his early primary losses in New Hampshire and Florida.

title: Mummenschanz Incisive In Their Mime Program
description: Mummenschanz might want. to change its name some day, but the three young artists who compose this fabulous mime group from Switzerland should remain exactly as they arehrilliant hilarious and profound.

title: Guam Battles Unemployment and Rising Costs as Tidal Wave of 7Year Industrial Boom Begins to
description: AGANA, GuamIn 1521, when Ferdinand Magellan dropped anchor by the Guam beach where Loling's hamburger diner now stands, he probably seased the island's strategic significance for Spain's global empire. Guam made an ideal supply base for Spanish galleons sailing between the Americas and Asia.

title: Kathe Schoenberg Offers Literary and Folk Songs
description: Kathe Schoenberg, a mezzosoprano who has appeared here several times in recent years, came back to Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night for another recital. Her program was arranged according to subject matter, and there were groups of songs about spring and about the night, a group devoted to Roger Quilter's settings of texts by Shakespeare and another made up of Bartok's and Kodaly's folksong arrangements. Donald Hassard was the piano accompanist.

title: Bombs Start Belfast Fire
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 2 (UPI)A fire caused by bomb explosions gutted a city block on Belfast's main shopping thoroughfare today Incendiary devices planted on two floors of a department store on Royal Avenue touched off the fire just after midnight. Most of the offices and stores on the block burned to the ground.

title: For the Royal Ballet's Lynn Seymour, Dancing Is Not Just Tiaras and Tutus
description: The tragic heroines that Lynn Seymour has portrayed range from Anne Frank to Shakespeare's Juliet, which she dances tonight opposite Rudolf Nureyev in Kenneth MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet.

title: SIMON HELPS TRIM I.M.F.'S PAY RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 2In a campaign apparently without precedent, and with little publicity, Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon last month won the support of finance ministers of most of the world's major countries to cut back a salary increase for employees of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Tall Ships Start Atlantic Race
description: PLYMOUTH, England, May 2  The statesmen of the world who have had trouble finding the right formula for international brotherhood might wish to try a combination of sailors, ships, the sea and Scotch whisky. These were some of the ingredients tossed together here today in the Tall Ships race, and the result was dtente of a high order. Even Henry Kissinger would have been pleased.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OFF CENTER The picture in the window of the Assembly Steak House (5813580), at 16 West 51st Street, shows a pianist identified only as Effie. Effie knows her business. Seated at the lounge keyboard, in a spotlight, she plays for the lateafternoon and evening bar and table crowd with sprightly numbers, also beaming tender ballads off right to a more secluded table section of murmuring couples and handholders. artery of Rockefeller Center traffic, It's also the kind of lounge where smiling young waitresses automatically deposit a plate of hors d' oeuvres alongside a vodka martini ($2.15).

title: The New Leaves
description: The early flowers are bright in meadow and woodland, but the overwhelming beauty as May begins is in the new leaves on trees and bushes. We take leaves for granted; but when they are seen individually and fresh from the bud they are in no sense commonplace.

title: Miss Rice Ivy Victor
description: NEW HAVEN, May 2Topseeded Linda Rice of Princeton defeated Yale's Sue Graham, 60, 76, and capured the singles title in the Ivy League women's tennis championships at Yale today. Princeton and Yale tied for the team title.

title: DONALD G. MILLAR
description: Donald G. Millar, who retired in 1968 as chairman of the executive committee of the InitedGreenfield Corporation, tool and die manufacturers, died Friday at his home at 113 Buffalo Bay in Madison, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: Conservative Party Remains Unalterably Opposed to Rockefeller
description: Although Senator James L. Buckley said last week that he could, however reluctantly, support a Republican national ticket with Vice President Rockefeller in the secand spot, the Conservative Party, which nominated Mr. Buckley six years ago and will do so again this year, is still unalterably opposed to Mr. Rockefeller.

title: Beguiling Reading of Hollow Crown Presented by 5 Royal Shakespeareans
description: Out of chronicles, histories. journals, letters and miscellaneous writings, John Barton once composed a verbal pageant that traces the course of British monarchs from wiliams the Conqueror in the 11th century to Queen Victoria in the 19th. Called The Hollow Crown. after Shakespeare, it has been for some vears a showcase for English olavers. In a Saturday matinee J41 the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Royal Shakespeare Company presented five of its members in a flawless reading for as satisfying and beguiling an hour as one could wish in the theater.

title: PROFITS OF TOP 500 OFF BY 13.3% IN 1975
description: Profits of the 500 largest corporations in the United States dropped 13.3 per cent in 1975, the largest decline in 17 years, Fortune magazine reported yesterday.

title: SLAIN PHYSICIAN MOURNED BY 500
description: Some 500 mourners, many of them patients of Dr. Walter Blumenson, attended his funeral in Brooklyn yesterday and remembered the slain physician as a warm and uncommonly dedicated man.

title: Broadway Friends Honor Abbott
description: George Abbott, who achieved his record of 116 theatrical credits largely by keeping his eye firmly on the production of the moment, was lured into a rare posture of nostalgia at the Shubert Thraler last night when his Broadway friends staged a special retrospective of the grand old man's 63 years in the theater.

title: Television
description: John Wayne and Kim Darby in True Grit, to be shown on the ABC Monday Night Movie, Ch. 7 at 8:30 P.M.

title: 120 Feet of Track Stolen. Train in Michigan Derailed
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., May 2 (AP)A locomotive and four railroad cars derailed yesterday because someone apparently stole 120 feet of track, the authorities said.

title: Robyn Goodman Wed to Walter McGinn
description: Robyn Goodman, daughter of Vera and Sol Goodman of Short Hills, N. J., was married here yesterday to Walter McGinn, son of Waiter McGinn of East Providence, R. I., and the late Gertrude E. Walker. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne performed the interfaith ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Marcoses Visit London
description: LONDON, May 2 (Renters)President. Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, arrived here today on ??? threeday private visit.

title: Chase Is Filing $200 Million Offering
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank will file a public offering of $200 million of notes today with the Controller of the Currency, a spokesman for the huge banking institution announced yesterday.

title: Soviet Jewry Backed
description: Tens of thousands of people marched on behalf of Soviet Jewry and rallied near the United Nations, where speakers proclaimed it the duty of Americans to speak out against oppression. Governor Carey designated yesterday as Solidarity Sunday in New York. Page 61.

title: Bid to Shift Alaska Gas Line Assailed
description: WASHINGTON. May 2Two Federal Power Commission officials opposed last week as costly and impractical a rerouting for environmental reasons of a proposed overland natural gas pipeline from Alaska's North Slope.

title: Ford Prepares for a Difficult Fight For Nomination After Texas Defeat
description: PORT WAYNE, Ind., May 2The White House, startled by the magnitude of Ronald Reagan's victory in the Texas primary, prepared today for an increasingly difficult contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Jazzmobile Concert Offers Suite by Saxophonist
description: Jimmy Heath, a consistent, dependable jazz saxophonist and composer for the last 30 years who has passed most of that time in the shadow of his bezter known brother ???.

title: New Books
description: Arthur Rackham by Fred Gettings (Mcmillan, $20). The illustrator's life, illustrated.

title: Reagan Says Texas Shows He Is the Best Candidate
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 2Still astonished at the magnitude of his clean sweep in the critical Texas primary, Ronald Reagan contended today that the result showed him to be the best candidate the Republicans could field against the Democrats in a Presidential campaign.

title: DR. MARK E. FOX
description: Dr. Mark E. Fox, retired medical director of the Long Island Rail Road, died Saturday in New York Infirmary. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 2Governor Byrne has invited the 21 Democratic county chairmen to a cocktail party Tuesday at Morven, the Governor's Princeton mansion, to discuss the future.

title: Peruvian Regime Dismisses 50 Mayors and Other Aides
description: LIMA, Peru, May 2 (Reuters) The Peruvian military Government has dismissed 50 civilian mayors and other officials in a move to break away from the policies of the leader it ousted last year.

title: French, Irish Horses Triumph in Rome
description: ROME. May 2 (UPI)Gilles Bertrand de Balanda rode Bearn to France's first victory of the 44th Rome International Official Horse Show today on the final day in the prize winners competition.

title: American History Test
description: 40. The picture right reflects the nineteenth century view that (A) art was the handmaiden of technology (R) nature was the source of moral values in the West was a safety valve for urban discontent (D) American civilization was superior and its expansion inevitable 41. Which of the following information would be most useful to test the validity of the viewpoint expressed in the cartoon left? (A) The political affiliation of the eartoonist (B) The size of the farm vote in the presidential election of 1896 (C) The factors that determined farm prices (D) The proportion of Wall Street firms that endorsed William McKinley for president 42. in the first half of the twentieth century, the best ??? of social mobility in the ??? States as a whole is found in the increase in the (A) number of new millionaires from decade to decade (H) average per capita Income from decade to decade (c) percentage of lutecollar workers whose fathers worked at bluecollar industrial ??? (D) percentage of agricultural workers who migrated to the cities

title: M.T. A. Hears Residents Proposals Today On 63d St. Subway Work Halted by Protests
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will face angry East Side residents today to hear counterproposals on a $154 million subway construction project. The start of construction has been stalled for nine days by neighborhood leaders who have charged the authority with escalating its plans for the project without informing the community.

title: Students of Hughes's Life Doubt Will'Authenticity
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 2Among many people who have studied Howard R. Hughes as closely as they could during his almost 20 years in seclusion, serious doubts have grown about the validity of the purported Hughes will that turned up mysteriously Tuesday.

title: Kissinger to Urge Resources Bank for Third World
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 2 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger flew to Nairobi today to propose the formation of an international resources bank to help stabilize the incomes of nations of the third world.

title: 'Birch Interval,' Tale About Children
description: There is no possible way to make a good movie about??? children if you don't know how to direct children. This is the main reason why "Birch Interval???" instead of being a sentimental but effective film about, growing-up pains in bucolic America, on the order of "To Kill a Mockingbird," is a painful embarrassment.Directing children, essentially, is telling them what not to do. They shouldn't??? in fact, do anything??? they should simply be. They certainly shouldn't act. Children's faces are totally revealing and the camera is terribly sharp??? when a child is allowed to act, what we get on the screen is not a child but a child acting.The central figure in "Birch Interval???" which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse??? is a child named Jesse. She is sent to stay with her grandfather's family in the Amish country of Pennsylvania. It is all love and peacefulness, but there are conflict and tragedy underneath.Her beloved Uncle Thomas??? a fey eccentric married to a perplexed and unfaithful wife??? is manhandled off to an asylum, where he dies. Her grandfather??? whom she adores, shows unexpected weakness in letting it happen. Her Amish friends are harassed by the government for not sending their children to school. The neighborhood holds a witch, a mad girl, a band of sadistic children.The story of a preadolescent girl learning pain and forbearance among the green hills and red barns might have worked, if done with skill and restraint. But there is nothing but excess, self-indulgence and bathos.Susan McLung, who plays Jesse, is thin and freckled, with a hungry look and expressive dark eyes. She looks fine??? but she is never real. She is a catalogue of gestures and expressions.She pushes her mouth in and out to depict tenderness??? Anger??? grief. She doesn't walk: she strides. Her uncle and grandfather sit on the porch and talk life to her??? she assumes an expression of hostessy understanding. There's nothing she doesn't: hear, register and react to. What happened to the painfully won dscovery by American directors???the Europeans always knew it???that children look blank most of the time?The dialogue doesn't help. In quick succession. Jesse has to announce that her uncle, her grandfather and the community of Birch Interval are "the best (uncle/grandfather/place) in the whole world." Her grandfather???played like a wet sunset by Eddie Albert???tells her. "Life is just a bit of eiderdown and a bit of mealy apple."The photography does some lovely things???there is a good shot of Amish wagons crookedly lined up in the mist???but the loveliness is as excessive as everything else. The camera??? almost as "self-conscious as Miss M???Clung??? reacts???it all but double-takes??? in fact???to every pretty thing it shows."Birch Interval" is what the word "icky" has been waiting for all its life. Nobody who sees the film will ever be able to condescend to "icky" again??? it rises from cant to lexi???ographical indispensability.

title: DANCING WILL HONOR CLARK CENTER HEAD
description: Tomorrow night they will be dancing for Louise Roberts. Kei Takei, considered by many to be one of the rising young stars of avantgarde dance, will be joined in a program of solo dances at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by friends Daniel Nagri Annahelle Gamson, Nlariko Santo and Violet te Verde in works of their own.

title: In New York, a Big Party for Texans
description: A group of New York Texans, as they like to call themselves, got together deep in the heart of Manhattan the other night to celebrate San Jacinto Day, the last famous battle for Texas independence, and also to reinforce that certain something they call their Texaneity.

title: Pizza Hut Seeking a New Agency
description: NobleDury & Associates of Nashville and Memphis has gotten the word from Pizza Hut Inc. The fastfood chain is going to be looking for a new national advertising agency to handle its $4 million slice of business.

title: Panel Studies Ways to Combat Crime
description: PRINCETON, May 2The National Committee on Criminal Justic, meeting here over the weekend under the chairmanship of Governor Byrne, is attempting to establish new and more effective methods for dealing with crime in this country, including acts of terrorism, juvenile delinquency, organized crime and private security.

title: U. S. Steel Chief Expects No 2d Round Of Price Increases for Balance of Year
description: ATLANTA May 3The United States Steel Corporation does not see the likelihood of a second round of price increases this year, Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the company, indicated nere today. Replying to a question at a news conference before the corporation's annual meeting, in the Atlanta Hilton Hotel, Mr. Speer said: Even though the market for steel is improving considerably. I'd judge there would have to be a nearshortage of steel before anyone could contemplate further increases.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Cleveland 5, Oakland 4 (10 inn.) Other teams not scheduled.

title: Reagan Evokes Fervor in an Indiana Town
description: PLAINFIELD, Ind., May 3Paul Kellum was standing in his front yard with his wife, Louise, who was holding their new American flag by a shiny aluminum pole as if waiting for a parade to pass down the otherwise deserted street.

title: $500 MILLION LOAN SOUGHT BY IRANIANS
description: LONDON, May 3 (AP)Iran is seeking a $500 million Eurocurrency loan that would involve financing by the United States ExportImport Bank.

title: MOYNIHAN DENIES DEMOCRACY SAGS
description: Daniel P. Moynihan, former United States representative to the United Nations, asserted yesterday that the Soviet Union was becoming the undeserving but inevitable beneficiary of the contention by some intellectuals here and abroad that democracy was declining as a force in world affairs.

title: Sorbonne's President Is a Blend of Elan and Egalite
description: PARIS. May 3 For the first time In its 700year history, the Sorponne has a woman president.

title: RHODESIA ACCUSED OF REPRESSIVE RULE
description: LONDON, Tuesday, May 4 (Reuters)  The International Commission of Jurists said today that white supremacy in Rhodesia was founded on racial discrimination and exploitation, backed up by security legislation that infringed on individual liberties.

title: Kissinger, in Kenya Park, Weighs South Africa Talk
description: KEEKOROK, Kenya, May 3A meeting between Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and white South African leaders has been suggested as a possibility after the Secretary completes his tour of black African countries.

title: Notes on People
description: Ideology has nothing to do with itwe're going to make money, said Charles W. Sandman, the former New Jersey Congressman, announcing yesterday that he and Muhammad All were about to no into the fastfood business together. Mr. Sandman said in Cape May that the chain of Muhammad Ali Restaurants, to be located in black neighborhoods of big cities, will have black managers and employees and offer hamburgers, fried chicken and fish.

title: The Day Care Vote
description: The House today will have an opportunity to override what may be President Ford's least comprehensible veto. The bill would have provided money to enable the states to meet the standards for day care programs which Congress had mandated more than a year earlier. Mr. Ford said that the bill would be too expensive and that he was opposed to the Federal intrusion into state affairs that such a measure would represent. Unfortunately. Presidential reasoning missed the mark on both counts.

title: Referendum on Private Casinos Approved by Jersey Assembly
description: TRENTON. May 3The State Assembly passed today a resolution to place a referendum on the November ballot asking voters whether they want casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Corn, Wheat and Soybeans Rise In Light Futures Trading Pace
description: Corn, wheat and soybeans gained in price in light trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, each responding to a different influence.

title: Ernie Nevers Dies at 73; Star Fullback at Stanford
description: Ernie Nevers, rated by many football experts as one of the greatest fullbacks ever to play the game, died of a kidney disorder yesterday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: About the Yankees
description: For the first time this season, the Yankees will be carrying a twogame losing streak when they open a threegame series with the Angels in Anaheim, Calif., tonight. Dock Ellis, Catfish Hunter and Ed Figueroa are the scheduled starters. The 11inning 21 loss at Kansas City Sunday, charged to Sparky Lyle, marked the first time this season the bull pen failed to save or win a game.  The true test for the pitching staff will start only now.  The first 15 games were spread over 26 days; beginning tonight, the Yankees have 34 games scheduled for tile next 34 days. In their 15 games, the Yankees stole 28 bases in 35 attempts, an 80 percent efficiency that is outstanding. Mickey Rivers is 910, Willie Randolph 78, and Roy White 45.

title: Issues in Building Strike
description: Local 32B of the Service Employees Union, representing 20,000 superintendents, handymen, elevator operators, porters, mechanics and guards in 4,000 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. The Realty Advisory Board represents the building owners.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Are professional athletes overpaid? In the month of April alone, a baseball pitcher (Andy Messersmith) and a football player just out of college (Chuck Muncie) signed multiyear contracts for more than $1 million in compensation, and a collective bargaining agreement by the National Basketball Association with its players called attention to the fact that the league's 216 players had an average salary of $107,000 a year.

title: Soviet Purchases Welcomed by Butz
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he would welcome more Soviet purchases of American grain. He predicted that even with such sales, American food inflation would be cut to 3 or 4 percent this year.

title: Grand Dame Of the Right Takes a Bow
description: A long time ago when the whole family was living abroad, Aloise Buckley worried that her children would forget America. So she invented some little stories; George Washington, for one, she said, was sleeping in the chimney of their home in Connecticut and someday they would return to see him.

title: DEMOCRATS BEGIN TO CLOSE RANKS FOR CARTER DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Leaders of the Democratic Party establishment have begun to rally around Jimmy Carter, a candidate whom they scorned until recently, in the belief that the Georgian's nomination for President is virtually assured.

title: Head Winds at the U.N.
description: An international flotilla of Tall Ships set sail from the Old World for the New on Sunday, in a spirit of amity on the oceans that unfortunately has not yet been attained by the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, which is winding up its third and most crucial substantive session here this week.

title: The Real Military Issues
description: Ronald Reagan's remarkable triumph in the Texas primary probably assures a battle for the Republican Presidential nomination right down to the Kansas City convention in August. Since Mr. Reagan has made American military strength the central issue of his campaign, the dangerous possibility arises that major questions of military policy will be heavily influenced by shortterm political considerations.

title: People and Business
description: Robert A. Beck, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurer, said yesterday that a proposed sales tax on insurance premiums in New York State would be unfair to all affected.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that a property in the East Bronx that was sold to the city in 1970 had been appraised by Henry Waltemade, a leading real estate man. The appraisal was by Henry Waltemade Inc. Mr. Waltemade, president of the Dollar Savings Bank, sold the business in 1965, and the name was retired in 1970.

title: Cordero and Barrera Come Home Winners
description: The conquering heroes returned from Louisville yesterday and conquered again. Angel Cordero, who rode Bold Forbes to victory in the Kentucky Derby, returned to New York in time for opening day at Belmont Park and rode two winners in two races.

title: Jerusalem Blast Leaves 30 Injured; Arabs Threatened
description: JERUSALEM, May 3 (AP)A boobytrapped motor scooter exploded on Jerusalem's main commercial thoroughfare tonight, injuring 30 people and bringing on acts of vengeance by Jewish youths against Arab cars and buses.

title: Fed Cuts MoneyGrowth Target Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Federal Reserve Board has slightly lowered its targets for growth of the nation's money supply in the next year as a small but prudent step toward further reducing inflation, Arthur F. Burns, its chairman, disclosed to the Senate Banking Committee today.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Talking Calculator: 1 Plus 1 Equals
description: At the age of 3 months, it not only adds, subtracts, multiplies and divides, but does square roots and other mathematical calculations. But what's really unusual, it also talks.

title: Davidoff Pleads Not Guilty To 45 Charges on Taxes
description: Sidney Davidoff, a former special assistant to former Mayor John V. Lindsay, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 45 charges of grand larceny and failure to file withholding taxes for employees at his nowclosed West Side restaurant, Jimmy's.

title: Reagan Nears Fund Crisis Over Lack of Federal Aid
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 3Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign will face a financial crisis unless Federal matching funds are freed for it, top Reagan aides said today.

title: Hialeah Bid Rejected
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 3A New Jersey land developer and contractor, John Brunetti of Maywood, has failed in his third attempt to purchase Hialeah (Fla.) Race Course and the track's future was in doubt today.

title: Street Name Change Stirs A Tempest in Melting Pot
description: After a group of ItalianAmerican residents from Brooklyn appeared at City Hall yesterday morning to argue for the preservation of a British street name in their WilliamsburgGreenpoint neighborhood, Mayor Beame set aside a bill that would have given a portion of the streetnow Graham Avenuethe name Avenue of Puerto Rico.

title: Students Stress the Positive in U.S. Past
description: A New York Times survey of 1,856 college freshmen found that students had a generally positive view of their national heritage.

title: Another Country
description: New York City is closing hospitals. public schools and colleges. Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan are worried about the Panama Canal.

title: Recital
description: Schubert's Sonata in D (Op. 53) is a wonderful monster that few pianists ever discover how to tame. Besides agile, tireless fingers, it requires unusual patience and a talent for controlling rhythmic ebb and flow, without which the score can seem long and shapeless. Kazuko Hayami, a Japanese pianist who made her official debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday evening, chose this demanding sonata as the major work on her program and justified her brave decision.

title: Pentagon Aide Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The Senate approved today the nomination of Eugene V. McAuliffe of Massachusetts to be an Assistant Secretary of Defense. The nomination was approved by voice vote and sent to the White House.

title: Summary of U.S. Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Unemployment Incubus
description: But steel and other industrial prices are being pushed up more rapidly, although industry is operating at less than threefourths of capacity. Seven million workers7 percent of the labor forceare still jobless. If anything, the economy requires a faster rate of expansion than the President's budget for fiscal 1977 would provide. Once again, Mr. Fordand the economyseem likely to benefit from the extra budgetary stimulus that a Democratic Congress will furnishand for which the President will criticize it.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS DIVIDED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Campaigning here the other day for the District of Colum's dl 7 elegate votes at the Democratic National Convention, former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia called the bitter, parochial infighting that has become the hallmark of factional Democratic politics in Washington a frivolous local struggle.

title: An Influx of Tourists Clogging the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON. May 3Americans by the tens of thousands are streaming to Capitol Hill this bicentennial year to see their Congress in action  or, as some local wags insist, their Congress in Maction.

title: G.M. Adds Dividend As Net Nears Mark
description: DETROIT, May 3The General Motors Corportion, which reported nearrecord firstquarter earnings last week, announced today the that the board of directors had declared a special 50cent quarterly dividend to go with the regular 60cent dividend.

title: Italy Votes June 2021
description: The Italian Government set June 20 and 21 as the dates for national elections that could give the Communist Party a share of power. Page 7.

title: The Vagrancy Handicap
description: The Vagrancy Handicap

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Diagram of microwave communication system installed by Weeden & Company in Jersey City to link offices there with Manhattan without reliance on telephone equipment.

title: McLaren Threatens to Ouit Grand Prix
description: MADRID, May 3 (UPI)The manager of the McLaren auto racing team said today that unless the disqualification of James Hunt as winner of the Spanish Grand Prix yesterday was reversed, his cars would withdraw from the Formula One circuit. Hunt was disqualified because the aerofoil of his McLaren was found to be about a halfinch too wide under new regulations. Niki Lauda, in a Ferrari, became provisional winner of the race, pending a final ruling on an appeal lodged by the McLaren manager, Teddy Mayer. The ruling was expected within a month. It's like getting the death penalty for speeding, Mayer said. If Formula One is so badly governed, it's ridiculous to compete. It shows total incompetence by the governing body. If the decision is upheld, we would have to give serious consideration pulling out.

title: More TeenAged Girls Are Turning To Prostitution, Youth Agencies Say
description: Faced with a rapidly declining number of legitimate job opportunities and lured by promises of earning big money fast, more and more teenaged girls here are turning to prostitution as a means of survival, according to, the police and city youth agencies.

title: Move Across Hudson Paying Dividends
description: JERSEY CITY, May 3When Weeden & Company became the first major Wall Street firm to move across the Hudson River, officials said $1 million would be saved each year on New York City's stocktransfer tax.

title: Young Quinn Responding
description: YONKERS, May 3Charlie Hunter, trainer of Young Quinn, said yesterday the 7yearold gelding should be able to resume racing within three weeks. On Saturday, an inflamed left knee prevented Young Quinn from racing in the $75,000 Old Glory Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Elizabeth Woman Is Held In Death of Newark Man
description: NEWARK, May 3 (AP)An Elizabeth woman is to be arraigned tomorrow on homicide charges in connection with the death of a man outside his home here, the police said.

title: Agrarian Reform In Latin America Gets Low Priority
description: CANTON COLTA, EcuadorTwo years ago, the Minister of Agriculture promised 625 acres of farmland to Manuel Lautibur and his fellow Indians in this rural hamlet about 160 miles south of Quito, the capital.

title: Gladys B. Thayer, Donated Chandelier to White House
description: Gladys Brooks Thayer, who devoted much of her late years to philanthropy, died Saturday at her home in the Carlyle Hotel. She was 94 years old.

title: ALFRED HARBAGE, SCHOLAR, IS DEAD
description: Alfred B. Harbage, a leading Shakespeare scholar and emeritus professor of English literature at Harvard University, died Sunday in Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia following a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived in Stone Harbor, N.J., and Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Helping New York
description: Joanne Teitelbaum leans over the metal rail of Gail Katz's hospital bed at Bellevue to get as close to Gail as I can. They begin another of the intimate hourlong conversations that have helped Miss Katz, who is chronically ill, to talk about angers, fears and wishes that she has kept locked inside for years.

title: Cambodia Pilot Flees To Thailand in Copier
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 3 (AP)A pilot who served in the air force of the Cambodian Government overthrown a year ago stole a helicopter at the Phnom Penh airport last week and escaped to Thailand, officials said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The captain of a shipwrecked yacht goes on trial today on charges he refused to throw his dog overboard to make room for two crewmen in a lifeboat. The crewmen drowned. Cyril E. LaBrecque, 51 years old, of Santa Ana, Calif., skipper of the schooner Sadie and Edgar, is to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter charges before Judge Stanley Brotman in United States District Court in Camden.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: 25 Delegate Candidates Back Brown in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3Twentyfive Maryland delegate candidates previously committed to Fred Harris endorsed Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California today.

title: Symphony Afloat Starts Tour
description: GULFPORT, Miss., April 30 As an undergraduate working his way through Boston University, Robert Austin Beaudreau, later to become director of the American Wind Symphony Orchestra, served as a pitchman in the old Clyde Beatty Circus.

title: Chorus Line Is the Product of Five Minds
description: A Chorus Line, the innovative musical that won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama, is the collaborative creation of five men  Michael Bennett, James Kirkwood, Nicholas Dante, Marvin Hamlish, and Edward Kleban.

title: Economic Respite
description: The performance of the United States economy during the first quarter of this year was better than virtually anyone, including the Administration, had expected. Real output of goods and services climbed at an annual rate of 7.5 percent, and inflation slowed to a rate of 3.7 percent. So impressive were these results that most observers now consider the year 1976 to be in the bag. The prime question has become whether the economy will run into trouble in 1977 or 1978and what form that trouble will take.

title: Textron in FreeEnterprise Plan Plan
description: Now it's Textron that is mounting an ad campaign to instruct all and sundry on the free enterprise system. The conglomerate, however, chooses to refer to it as the American private enterprise system, and the campaign will mark its first use of television for corporate advertising.

title: Rhodesians Reopen a Main Road With Armed Convoys
description: FORT VICTORIA, Rhodesia, May 3The main road from Rhodesia to South Africa was reopened today, with paramilitary policemen running armed convoys to protect motorists from black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Beame Approves Salary Increases For Budget Aides
description: Beame made an exception in its wagefreeze policy yesterday for 104 budget employees, granting them raises ranging up to $6,294 a year on the ground that they had worked exceptionally hard and deserved a reward.

title: LowCost Computers Beginning to Move Into the Home
description: TRENTON, May 3The computer, once an awesome, mysterious and incredibly expensive machine of superhuman powers, has become the hottest new toy of electronics hobbyists, some of whom predict that within a few years computers will be commonplace in American homes.

title: Building Walkout Has Little Effect
description: A woman doubledparked a Cadillac outside the luxury apartment building at 580 Park Avenue, at 65th Street, shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday. She walked back, threw open the trunk, and looked around for someone to lift out the flats of plants she had brought in from the country.

title: COURT RECORDS LINK SCOTT TO GULF OIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  Gulf's former chief lobbist has told a Federal grand jury about 11 years of alleged payments to Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott, Federal court records showed today.

title: Son Born in Greenwich To ExRussian Actress
description: Viktoriya Fyodorova Pouy, the former Russian movie actress, gave birth to an 8pound boy last night at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Delegates Tally
description: Following is the atest tally for delegates to the Republican and Democratic National Conventions, including primaries and caucuses over the weekend:

title: Pulitzer Prizes to Bellow, Chorus Line, 2 on Times
description: Saul Bellow, who once lost a Pulitzer prize for fiction despite a jury's recommendation, yesterday received the premier await for his latest novel, Humboldt's Gift, while A Chorus Line won the prize for drama.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that a property in the East Bronx that was sold to the city in 1970 had been appraised by Henry Waltemade, a leading real estate man. The appraisal was by Henry Waltemade Inc. Mr. Waltemade, president of the Dollar Savings Bank, sold the business in 1965, and the name was retired in 1970.

title: House Votes to Restore Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission.

title: Tried for Forgery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3Mr. Dummar, a beneficiary in the mysterious will attributed to Mr. Hughes, once was tried for forgery in Nevada, according to information received here.

title: Marshall Pleads Cities ' Case at Law School
description: NEWARK, May 3Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court of the United States, today urged law school graduates not to become legal guns for hire for big corporations but to devote at least part of their legal careers to the solution of community problems.

title: EDITH GARDNER OF GIBBS SCHOOL
description: Edith L. Gardner, president of the Katharine Gibbs School Inc., with headquarters at 200 Park Avenue, died yesterday of cancer in Wilbraham, Mass. at the home of her brother, Warren Gardner. She was 60 years old and lived at 510 East 23d Street.

title: Market Place
description: Is there a showdown in the cards over the cost of the research that many brokerage firms have traditionally supplied institutional investors in exchange for commissions business?

title: Kent State Questions
description: Unlike judicial scrutiny in the Watergate experience, such scrutiny of the evidence in the sixyearold Kent State University case has failed to provide us with answers to many of the nagging questions that remain as burning as ever, just as the possibility that the Ohio National Guard shootings resulted from some kind of decision reached at the national level remains as haunting a skeleton in the Kent State closet as it was two years ago.

title: About Morris Heller
description: BALTIMORE  My father, Morris Heller, will soon be 82. Each weekday he leaves the small real estate office he shares wih my brother to take a threemile walk through the town of Cedar Grove, N. J. If, for some reason, he is off schedule or neglects to make the tour, concern is expressed among those accustomed to seeing and greeting him.

title: G.S.A. Says It Held Title To Plane in Hughes Wilt
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A Government spokesman said tolay that the Spruce Goose, a elebrated airplane bequeathed to the city of Long Beach, Calif., in a will attributed to Howard R. Hughes, was owned by the General Services Administration at the time the will was purportedly written.

title: That Was His Daddy Was Dead
description: For the first time in many years, the dogwood and redbud on Claiborne Farm had bloomed and faded before Derby Week brought the beauty and chivalry of liverystable society to the blue grass country and everybody who could wangle an invitation made his way to the great breeding farm at Paris, Ky. Usually at this season there are swans on the creek just inside the main gate but in this advanced spring they seemed to have disappeared with the blossoms. They're settin on the nest, Snow said. The robins and blackbirds got little ones and the redbirds are building nests. See here? He pointed to an evergreen bush where cardinals had a halffinished pad. Snow is Frank Snowfields, a stud groom. He is on firstname terms with all the stallions at ClaiborneTom Rolfe, Sir Ivor, Forli, Buckpasser, Hoist the Flag, Round Table, Riva Ridge, Judger and the restand his principal charge was Bold Ruler until that perennial leader of the American sire lists died of cancer. Now, of course, Snow's most famous ward is Bold Ruler's most famous son, Secretariat.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on International Trade Law10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Purge of Ministers Believed Linked to Possible Drop in Chinese Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Albania, an isolated Eastern European country with strong ties to China, has been undergoing domestic political turmoil because of a possible falling off of Chinese economic aid, according to United States officials specializing in Albanian affairs.

title: Knicks Sift Merger Indemnity
description: The Knicks will seek to obtain the first choice in the upcoming or the 1977 National Basketball Association draft as their indemnity should there be consolidation with the American Basketball Association.

title: Credit Markets Drop, Then Rebound; Dow Declines 6.53 Despite Late Gains
description: The bond market's recent pronounced setback, which was (particularly severe last Friday, continued yesterday morning and then prices bounced back. At the close of the market, most prices of fixedincome secuities were little changed from their final levels last week, and the market appeared to have dispelled the extreme pessimism that was widespread Friday. The recovery came after the Federal Reserve came into the money market twice yesterday to lend funds overnight to nonbank Government securities dealers when Federal funds were trading at 5 1/16 percent.

title: A Drought Casts Cloud On British
description: LONDON, May 3Britain, noted for its lush greenery and cold rain, is in the grip of a water shortage that could become a calamitous drought.

title: Rodino Withdraws From Uncommitted N.J. Slafe
description: TRENTON, May 3Demoicratic resistance to Jimmy Carter's presidential drive in New Jersey continued to crumble today as Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr, and the president of the New Jersey State A.F.L.C.I.O. withdrew as leaders of slates of opposition delegates in the June 8 primary.

title: New Pattern in Strike
description: Strikes are no novelty in New York City's towering apartment houses, but the one that started yesterday is upsetting tradition in two important respects. It represents a sharp departure from a pattern, begun well over a decade ago, in which it was hard to tell whether walkouts by unionized building service employees were directed primarily against realty owners or were part of a joint unionlandlord squeeze on city and state rentcontrol authorities.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Richard Dunn at a news conference in Munich yesterday

title: ISRAELIS THWART MARCH BY ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, May 3  A threatened protest march on Jerusalem by West Bank Arabs failed to materialize today after the Israeli occupation authorities broke up several small demonstrations in Ramallah and cordoned off the scheduled starting point with border guards.

title: Islanders Are Back At Elimination Point
description: FARMINGDALE. LI., May 3Is Glenn (Chico) Resch crazy?

title: Calandra Says He's Considering Race for Mayor
description: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Republican leader in the Bronx, said yesterday he was thinking of running for Mayor.

title: Emergency Help
description: Recorded information on the strike can be had by calling 9991234. Those seeking emergency aid or additional information will be referred to the appropriate agency.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CINCINNATI (AFC)Signed Reggie Williams, linebacker, and thirdround draft selection from Dartmouth.

title: New Faces on City Ballet's Pop Bill
description: For more years than many of us dare to remember, New York City Ballet has had a special pop program, usually given at a Saturday matinee. It starts with George Balanchine's version of Swan Lake, continues with Firebird and ends with Jerome Robbins's Afternoon of a Faun and Mr. Balanchine's Western Symphony. Now for experienced balletgoers this is not perhaps the greatest of programsmany would have reservations about the three Balanchine works and, although the Robbins is a masterpiece, it is not one perhaps especially evident to the casual eye.

title: LEONARD ETZ
description: Leonard Etz, a lawyer, died Sunday at St. Peter's Medical Center. New Brunswick, N.J. He was 44 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Shimen Ruskin, Yiddish Actor Who Went to Hollywood, Dead
description: Shimen Ruskin, an actor who spent 18 years in the Yiddish theater before moving on to Hollywood and roles in 60 films, radio, television and the Off Broadway theater, died of cancer April 23 in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

title: Davis Cup Group Votes Mexico Ban
description: LONDON, May 3 (UPI) The Davis Cup Nations committee recommended today that Mexico be barred from the 1977 international tennis competition and called for a threeyear ban on countries withdrawing from matches on political grounds.

title: Nadjari and Cunningham Dispute Records Status
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, denied yesterday that the Democratic state chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, had volunteered to turn over to Mr. Nadjari's office personal and political recordsand his statement immediately was chat. lensed by Mr. Cunningham.

title: Stock Market Indicators
description: (The tables for the most active trading, percentage Changes dollar leaders and the market diary pertain to the consolidated tape for all activity yesterday In listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. The market averages, however are based on the 4 P.M. New York closing prices.)

title: Russia's Defense Chief
description: Nine years ago, when Soviet Defense Minister Malinovsky died, there was a twoweek hiatus before his replacement, Marshal Grechko, was named. There is mason to believe that the succession debate within the Soviet hierarchy included the name of a civilian candidate, Dmitri Ustinov, longtime head of the nation's militaryindustrial complex. But Marshal Grechko finally was given the job, evidently on the insistence of Russia's military leaders, and later was elevated to the country's ruling Politburo.

title: New York City Still a Convention Lure
description: Despite New York City's highly publicized fiscal problems in 1975, the number of delegates to conventions held in the city rose to the secondhighest level in history.

title: Pulitzer Prizes to Bellow, Chorus Line, 2 on Times
description: Saul Bellow, who once lost a Pulitzer Prize for fiction despite a jury's recommendation, yesterday received the premier award for his latest novel, Humboldt's Gift, while A Chorus Line won the prize for drama.

title: LowCost Computers Beginning to Move Into the Home
description: TRENTON, May 3The computer, once an awesome, mysterious and incredibly expensive machine of superhuman powers, has become the hottest new toy of electronics hobbyists, some of whom predict that within a few years computers will be commonplace in American homes.

title: Portugal Leaning to General as New President
description: LISBON, May 3Portugal's political and military leaders are seeking a consensus candidate to run for the presidency of this deeply divided country.

title: Jerome Snyder, 60, CoAuthor Of Underground Gourmet, Dies
description: Jerome Snyder, the awardwinning illustrator and graphic designer who won his widest fame as coauthor of the Underground Gourmet guide to inexpensive New York City restaurants, died Sunday after having suffered a heart attack in Central Park.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fierlinger, ExPremier of Czechoslovakia, Is Dead
description: PRAGUE, May 3 (AP) Zdenek Fierlinger, the first postwar Prime Minister of Czechoslovakia and the man said to have led his Social Democrats into the Communist Party, died yesterday, the Communist Party Central Committee announced today. He was 85 years old.

title: House Subcommittee Gets Bank Bill for Redrafting
description: WASHINGTON. May 3The House Banking Committee, unable to pass a major bill to expand the powers of savings institutions and to permit interest on checking accounts, sent the measure to subcommittee for redrafting today in hopes of salvaging some of its elements.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Following the collapse of Prime Minister Aldo Moro's Cabinet last week, the Italian Government set June 20 and 21 as the dates for national elections that could give the Communist Party a share of power. The Christian Democrats, the dominant party, also decided to hold regional elections in Sicily and local elections in various cities, including Rome and Genoa. The local voting is expected to result in a city administration in Rome run by the Communists, who already control the major cities north of Rome. [Page 7, Column 1.]

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Citing Nassau County's inability to grant salary increases now because of its fiscal plight, Philip J. Ruffo, a factfinder in negotiations between the county and the 580 members of the Nassau Community College Federation of Teachers, has recommended that the college personnel receive no salary increase this year. The union had requested a 12 percent salary increase in the second year of its twoyear contract with the county.

title: PROF. JOHN W. NICHOLS
description: ORONO, Me., May 3John W. Nichols, a professor emeritus in psychology at the University of Maine, died Friday in the Eastern Maine Medical Center here. He was 61 years old.

title: EDGAR LEROY BRYANT
description: DEARBORN, Mich., May 3 (AP)Edgar Leroy Bryant, brotherinlaw of Henry Ford and an original stockholder of the Detroit Lions of the National Football League, died Saturday at a Dearborn hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: CAREY PROPOSES A SINGLE COURT FOR STATE TRIALS
description: ALBANY, May 3Governor Carey today proposed merging most of the courts in the state into a single, statewide trial court, with judges to be appointed by the Governor after recommendation by bipartisan nominating panels.

title: FORMER STATE AIDE CLEARED OF LARCENY
description: State Supreme Court Justice Peter T. Farrell yesterday acquitted Albert S. Pacetta, former member of the state's Human Rights Appeal Board, of four counts of grand larceny following a nonjury trial in Queens, in which Mr. Pacetta represented himself.

title: PEKING AIDE IS DEAD; A CAMPAIGN TARGET
description: PEKING, May 3 (Reuters)China's bitterly criticized Education Minister, Chou Junghsin, was said today to have died of a brain hemorrhage, but an official spokesman declined comment.

title: The Issues Facing UNCTAD in Nairobi
description: As more than 2.000 representatives of 130 nations gather this week in the Kenyan capital of Nairobi, for the monthlong United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, the prospects that their deliberations will produce immediate or tangible results seem dim. But a number of diplomatic observers from various sides believe that the conference can nevertheless mark a watershed in the northsouth dialogue between the rich nations and the poor that began two years ago with a fiery attack on the industrialized world by President Henri Boumedienne of Algeria during the United Nations sixth special session.

title: MILAN
description: (In Italian line)

title: Prices on Amex And OTC Decline On Rate Outlook
description: Concern over the possibility of an increase in interest rates sent prices lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over  the  counter market.

title: FORD SAYS CARTER DOES A FLIPFLOP
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 3President Ford, suddenly confronting the shadow of a Democrat on the Republican primaries, charged today that Jimmy Carter backtracks and does a flipflop on issues in his pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Corporation Affairs
