description: Consolidated Rail Corporation (ConRail) said it would spend $454.9 million the rest of This year in an accelerated program to rehabilitate the rolling stock of the six bankrupt roads that make up the new railroad.

title: 2 Food Trade Units Back Retention of Item Pricing
description: DALLAS, May 3The boards of directors of the National Association of Food Chains and the Supermarket Institute have voted unanimously to support the recommendation that individual item pricing he retained by stores that install electronic checkout systems.

title: Italian Film Man Kidnapped
description: ROME, May 3 (AP)  Pietro Maleno Malenotti, 62 years old, a retired Italian film producer and a wealthy landowner, was kidnapped yesterday in his villa near Pisa, the police reported today. Mr. Malenotti's family, living in Rome, received a phone call asking for ransom money, the police said. The amount of the requested sum was not disclosed.

title: THOMAS MACKESEY, EXDEAN AT CORNELL
description: Thomas W. Mackesey, vice president emeritus for planning at Cornell University and retired dean of the university's College of Architecture, died Sunday of cancer at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS BEGIN TO CLOSE RANKS FOR CARTER DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Leaders of the Democratic Party establishment have begun to rally around Jimmy Carter, a candidate whom they scorned until recently, in the belief that the Georgian's nomination for President is virtually assured.

title: Apartment House Workers Strike at Many Buildings
description: Building service employees seeking higher pay and improved benefits went on strike at numerous apartment houses in New York City yesterday in a walkout that surprised many owners and tenants.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: DOW IS UNDECIDED ON JAPANESE PLANT
description: After a ninemonth struggle, the Dow Chemical Company has won approval to build a caustic soda plant in Japan but now says it has not decided whether to build the plant.

title: Playoff Results
description: W.H.A. Playoffs

title: 2 COURT RULINGS AID PROSECUTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Supreme Court ruled today that a defendant held in jail pending trial may not be compelled to wear his jail uniform to trial.

title: White Consolidated Ends Merger Plan With White Motor
description: In a surprise move, the proposed merger of the White Motor Corporation into White Consolidated Industries was called off yesterday. The cornbination would have created $2.4 billion manufacturer of home appliances, heavyduty trucks and farm equipment.According to an announcement by White Consolidated, the directors of the home appliance company determined that White Motor's financing arrangements did not meet the conditions of the merger agreement between the two companies.

title: Bridge
description: MONTE CARLO. Monaco, May 3The Italian world champions, recovering after a shaky start in the first day of play yesterday, hit their best form against the United States team in the world team, championship this afternoon, and overwhelmed them in a session of 16 deals.

title: Nixon Papers Case Due Before Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon was scheduled to take the case for the return of his papers and tapes before the Supreme Court today.

title: Recital
description: Catharine Crozier, who appeared in recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, may be an honored veteran among organ playersshe joined the Eastman School organ faculty 38 years ago and became the head of the organ department in 1953. But she can still run rings around much of her younger competition, not only in interpretive style but in sheer technique as well.

title: CAREY PROPOSES A SINGLE COURT FOR STATE TRIALS
description: ALBANY, May 3Governor Carey today proposed merging most of the courts in the state into a single, statewide trial court, with judges to be appointed by the Governor after recommendation by bipartisan nominating panels.

title: BOSTON SCHOOL PLAN RELEASED BY JUDGE
description: BOSTON, May 3 (AP)School desegregation plans released today by a Federal judge would keep Boston students in the same schools they attended this year and would be designed to attract those who have fled the system, an adviser to the judge said.

title: DR. JOHN R. BURBIDGE
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 3Dr. John R. Burbidge, medical adviser for the Educational Testing Service, died Saturday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 75 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Blueprint for Justice
description: The chief administrator of the New York State courts recently offered this illustration of why the judiciary article in the State Constitution needs updating: If a family's existence is at stake in a support case, the Family Court handles it; if a multiple homicide takes place, the accused gces to Criminal Court; but if an ordinary threecar fenderbender occurs on the highway, it goes right to the [Slate] Supreme Court.

title: CARTER IS QUERIED ON SPEECHWRITER
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 3Jimmy Carter was smiling, not scowling, when he was questioned today about the case of the disillusioned speechwriter. But there still seemed to be questions and uncertainties about the incident.

title: Symphony Afloat Starts Tour
description: GULFPORT, Miss., April 30 As an undergraduate working his way through Boston University, Robert Austin Beaudreau, later to become director of the American Wind Symphony Orchestra, served as a pitchman in the old Clyde Beatty Circus.

title: Proliferating Beauty Salons Put on Happy Face
description: It every woman in town Isn't looking her best these days, it's not because of the lack of emporiums anxious to make her over. They will cut and color her hair, massage her wrinkles and paint on a new face her mother might have trouble recognizing.

title: DietrichPetition Filed
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3 (UPI) Mr. Dietrich, Mr. Hughes's former assistant, filed a petition in Superior Court here today to be named executor of Mr. Hughes's $2 billion estate under a will purportedly written by the reclusive billionaire in 1968.

title: FORD SAYS CARTER DOES A FLIPROF
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 3President Ford, suddenly confronting the shadow of a Democrat on the Republican primaries, charged today that Jimmy Carter backtracks and does a flipflop on issues in his pursuit of the Demccratic Presidential nomination.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: POE SHOW It seems apt as Bicentennial time pears that Edgar Allan Poe should be spotlighted, hence a oneman, interpretive evening with Conrad Pomerleau assuming his subject's identity and reciting such classics as The Raven and The Bells along with autobiographical musings about Poe's life and the New York of his time.

title: Pain Is Game Plan For Hughes of Nets
description: DENVER, May 3  The latest trophy of Kim Hughes's rookie season in the American Basketball Association is a clear set of David Thompson's teeth marks imprinted in his right forearm.

title: Sets Lose Opener In Tennis
description: UNIONDALE, LT., May 3World Team Tennis returned for Year No. 3 tonight, unveiled its new overtime thriller and turned the Nassau Coliseum into a frenzy.

title: 63d St. Residents And M.T.A. Discuss Restoration Work
description: Community leaders trying to win a revision of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's construction plans for the section of the new Queens63d Street subway line from Park to Third Avenue met yesterday with the authority. They received assurances of cooperation by the M.T.A. in the replacing of trees and sidewalks after the construction is finished and the reconsideration of ventilation grilles, which, under current design, would line the sidewalks.

title: Flyers Try To Avoid Penalties
description: BOSTON, May 3The National Hockey League couldn't have come up with a more appropriate pair of playoff opponents for the Bicentennial year than the Philadelphia Flyers and the Boston Bruins, who play their fourth game here tomorrow night.

title: DISCRETION URGED IN PRESS POWER
description: The Vietnam War and Watergate have touched off an investigative reporting binge of monumental proportions that is causing many readers to look upon the press as a multivoiced shrew nitpicking through the debris of government decisions for scandals but not solutions, the general manager of The Associated Press said yesterday.

title: Grand Dame Of the Right Takes a Bow
description: A long time ago when the whole family was living abroad, Aloise Buckley worried that her children would forget America. So she invented some little stories; George Washington, for one, she said, was sleeping in the chimney of their home in Connecticut and someday they would return to see him.

title: Students Stress the Positive in U.S. Past
description: A New York Times survey of 1,856 college freshmen found that students had a generally positive view of their national heritage.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New Bond Issues

title: Chess:
description: A new wave of exploration of the Maroczy bind is sweeping the ranks of the tournament players. While the Maroczy bind  defined by white pawns at QB4 and K4 opposed by a black pawn at Q3formerly gave rise to a doctrinaire dispute between the proponents of superior pawn structures and the proponents of explosive dynamic counterattack, an everincreasing number of players now regularly try both sides of the formation.

title: Valiants and Darts Recalled To Check Brake Problem
description: DETROIT, May 3 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling 8,310 1975 model Plymouth Valiants and Dodge Darts to check for a problem that could cause loss of front braking power.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Court Rejects Homeowners Suit To Bar the Mentally Retarded
description: A suit brought by a group of homeowners in Little Neck, Queens, that would prohibit the use of a onefamily home by a group of mentally retarded children was dismissed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

title: Tennis Results
description: Third RoundRick Strandskov, Hamilton. N I., defeated Tom Pirodsky, Freendrt, L.I., 60. 61: Bob Weise, Serino Lake, N.J., defeated Gene Breaznelt, Garden City, 62, 64; Jeff Hull, Mountain Lakes, N.J. deteted Roger Wootton, Manhasset. L.I., 63, 63; left Panell, Great Neck, L.I., defeated Steve Goldman, Monsy, N.Y., 63. 75; Adam Rosen, Roslyn, L I., de feated Milton Root, Port Washington, L.I., 61, 61.

title: Agrarian Reform In Latin America Gets Low Priority
description: CANTON COLTA, EcuadorTwo years ago, the Minister of Agriculture promised 625 acres of farmland to Manuel Lautibur and his fellow Indians in this rural hamlet about 160 miles south of Quito, the capital.

title: Odds Are Against Sweeping Court Reform
description: Court reform, a law school dean once observed, is not for the shortwinded, and in the last 30 years, scores of proposals for restructuring New York State's courts have been made. only to be rejected by the Legislature and then recede into the realm of distant possibilities. Governor Carey's proposal yesterday, for a new judiciary article to the State Constitution represents the most sweeping set of changes yet suggested.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.(TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWNEW, 8 P.M.)

title: League of Women Voters Gains $30, a Governor and a Mayor
description: The League of Women Voters opened a fiveday convention here yesterday with two new membersGovernor Carey and Mayor Beanie.

title: He's Back, He's 1970's, He's Tiffeau
description: Welcome back, Jacques Tiffeau. After absenting himself for almost five years from Seventh Avenuemost of the time was spent working with Yves Saint Laurent's men's clothing division in Paristhe pacesetting designer of the 1960's is back. He's joined up with Originala, which had its own hand in setting the direction of fashion in the 60's, and the result is good news for women who about clothes.

title: Congress: Signals for A Squeeze
description: WASHINGTON, May 3An angry group of Representatives, rebuffed once again in its fiveyear effort to bring back a major league baseball team to Washington, is preparing to exert some Congressional pressure to obtain a team.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% State tax)

title: G.S.A. Says It Held Title To Plane in Hughes Will
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A Government spokesman said today that the Spruce Goose, a celebrated airplane bequeathed to the city of Long Beach, Calif., in a will attributed to Howard R. Hughes, was owned by the General Services Administration at the time the will was purportedly written.

title: Publishers Group Gets Sundry Advice and a Sunny Forecast
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 3 What you are about to read is about the only news so far from the sixth annual meeting of the Association of American Publishers.

title: Eritrean Rebels Free 2 Americans and a Briton
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)Two Americans and a Briton have been released by Eritrean rebels who kidnapped them in Ethiopia last year, the State Department announced today.

title: Charles Mack Dies at 74; Cameraman for Murrow
description: Charles J. Mack, a leading newsreel and television cameraman who retired in 1971 from CBS News, died Sunday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 71 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DEEP. By Peter Benchley. 301 pages. Doubleday. $7.95.

title: Scott Joplin: From Rags To Some Belated Riches
description: In the mythic tradition of classical composers, Scott Joplin died penniless and mad, with his major work still unappreciated. Now that work, the opera Treemonisha, has been produced on Broadway and elsewhere, and his ragtime piano pieces have enjoyed a bestselling revival. One of his tunes, through its use as the theme of the film The Sting, became a national craze.

title: Boston Players, In Carnegie, Give Schubert Trios
description: Faced with a hall too large for the music on their stands, sensitive performers know they have only two feasible choices. Either they must exaggerate everything in hopes of filling the space or they must pull back and try to draw the audience into their world of sound, creating an intimacy that is pure illusion. Either way is dangerous, of course.

title: Building Workers Union Chief
description: John J. Sweeney, the president of the building workers union, had been thinking since last week of calling his members out on strike before tomorrow's deadline and attacking with the element of surprise. Late Sunday afternoon, he secretly told the union's other officers of his plan to start the walkout yeterday morning, and they went along.

title: Hohenberg Wins Special Citation
description: Won award for services for 22 years as administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes and for achievements as teacher and journalist.  Born in New York Feb. 17, 1906. Reporter, editor, teacher. Reporter with The Seattle Star, The New York World, assistant city editor, The New York JournalAmerican; Washington and foreign correspondent for The New York Post. Graduated from Columbia School of Journalism, 1927. Lecturer in English, associate in journalism, professor of journalism at Columbia. Discussion leader, International Press Institute, New Delhi, 1966. Author of The Pulitzer Prizes, The Pulitzer Prize Story, The Professional Journalist, The New Front Page, Between Two Worlds, A Journalist Looks at His Profession.  1974 winner of Sigma Delta Chi award for distinguished teaching of journalism  With wife, Dorothy, a classmate at Columbia, lives at 90 Morningside Drive.

title: Paris: Landscapes Changing Nature
description: PARISNature is a matter of culture. Reviewing a group show in 1855, the Goncourt brothers noted the high percentage of landscapes, not long before that the lowest, most despised genre in painting. Remarking that this new interest occurred precisely at the time when technology was beginning to destroy the ecological equilibrium, they suggested that landscape painting was a protest, an antidote or, at least a nostalgic reaction against the Industrial Revolution.

title: Advertising
description: The 38th annual Premium Show opened its fourday stay at the New York Coliseum yesterday filling all of its four and a half floors of exhibit space with every conceivable type of incentive item to make consumers buy and salesmen sell.

title: Italy Votes June 2021
description: The Italian Government set June 20 and 21 as the dates for national elections that could give the Communist Party a share of power. Page 7.

title: Crosland Arrives in Peking To Hold Talks on Relations
description: PEKING, May 3 (Reuters)Britain's new foreign Secretary, Anthony Crosland, began his first overseas assignment today when he arrived here for talks with Chinese leaders.

title: U.S. DRAWS PLAN ON SOLAR ENERGY
description: Plans are being drawn for a pilot plant that, by 1980, would generate 10 million watts of electricity from steam heat by converging beams of sunlight.

title: Executives at NBC and CBS Play Musical Chairs
description: The annual changing of the guard in network television, which at times resembles the postseason managerial switches and player trades in baseball, has in the last two or three weeks yielded one new president, two executive vice presidents, two program chiefs, a sports chief, a head of daytime programs and a West Coast vice president of programs.

title: New Citizens Get Community Welcome
description: HADDONFIELD, May 3The Federal District Court in Camden moved to the blue and gold auditorium of Haddonfield High School todayjudges, clerk, bailiff and all.

title: Ernie Nevers Dies
description: Ernie Nevers, star football running back for Stanford University and the Chicago Cardinals, died yesterday in San Rafael, Calif., at the age of 73. Details on Page 40.

title: 2 in Indiana Face Stiff Primary Tests
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 2Two longtime Democratic members of Congress from Indiana, Senator Vance Hartke and Representative Ray J. Madden, are facing strong challenges Tuesday in the state's first Congressional primary in nearly half a century.

title: REGINALD COOMBE, HEADED HOSPITAL
description: Reginald G. Coombe, a banker who was president and chairman of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases for 20 years died Sunday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: London Satirical Magazine Faces Threat
description: LONDON, May 3Britain's widely read magazine of political satire, Private Eye, is facing the first serious threat to its threadbare existence in the form of a rare criminal libel suit threatened by a socially prominent financier.

title: Keith Fuller Chosen As A.P.'s President At Annual Meeting
description: Keith Fuller, the deputy general manager of The Associated Press, has been chosen to succeed Wes Gallagher as president and general manager of the wire news service, the directors announced yesterday at A.P.'s annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Jersey's Assembly Votes Referendum On Private Casinos
description: TRENTON, May 3The State Assembly passed today a resolution to place a referendum on the November ballot asking voters whether they want casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Reagan Nears Fund Crisis Over Lack of Federal Aid
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 3Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign will face a financial, crisis unless Federal matching funds are freed for it, top Reagan aides said today.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: CarterReagan Georgia Victory Seen
description: ATLANTA, May 3Georgia voters are expected to hand a Democratic primary victory tomorrow to their former Governor, Jimmy Carter, and in a closer Republican contest to give Ronald Reagan his third Southern victory over President Ford.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Beware of Blues
description: For the second time in three years, swimmers off Florida's East Coast have been injured by bluefish.

title: Women and Youths Challenge Makeup Of New York Slate
description: Women and young people challenged yesterday  the makeup of the New York atlarge slate to the Demociatic National Convention. But they declined to say which of the 16 uncommitted atlarge delegates, the target of their challenge, they would like to see ousted, and they indicated that what they really sought was compromise that would give their groups more representation.

title: E.C.A.C. Baseball
description: E.C.A.C. Baseball

title: Belmont Entries
description: Belmont Entries

title: LykesYoungstown Raises FlatRolled Steel Price 6%
description: The LykesYoungstown Corporation said yesterday that it was raising its price for flatrolled steer, used in automobiles and appliances, about 6 percent, effective June 14. The increase is similar to those announced last week by other producers. The company also announced a 6 percent increase on continuous weld standard and line pipe.

title: Lester Horton Duet Restaged by Truitte And Danscompany
description: Excruciatingly slowly, but at least steadily, the work of the late West Coast choreographer Lester Horton is becoming more widely performed. The effort at reconstruction is being made by former pupils, in particular James Truitte, who is approaching the task like a crusade and most recently restaged To Jose Clemente Orozco. It was performed over the weekend at the Theater of Riverside Church by Danscompany directed by Joyce Trisler, herself a Horton dancer and alumna.

title: Study Finds a Decline in Shipbuilding for Soviet Navy
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A Library of Congress study has found that the number of ships built for the Soviet Navy has declined substantially in recent years, portending a possible reduction in the size of the Soviet fleet.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: A BAND FOR ALL OCCASIONS: The Mulberry Street Band practicing Street. A member of the band said they play for everything from fiestas Yesterday outside the Charles Bacigalupo Funeral Home on Mulberry to funerals. Here they were waiting for a funeral cortge to appear.

title: People in Sports
description: Jack Ramsay, coach of the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association for the last four years will not he rehired for the 197677 season. Paul L. Snyder, the owner of the Braves, announced yesterday that he and Ramsay had reached mutual agreement that the man who had built the Braves into a playoff contender would step down.

title: Lawyer Charges Bribery to  Fix Verdicts in Cadet Cheating Cases
description: WEST POINT, May 3A lawyer defending West Point cadets who face expulsion for alleged cheating said today he had uncovered evidence of bribes in fixing verdicts of cadet boards.

title: Beirut Fighting Continues Despite Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3Fighting for possession of the port of Beirut continued today, as did heavy artillery duels in other parts of the city and in the countryside in spite of last night's declaration by the leftist Moslem alliance that it was renewing the truce that officially expired last Friday.

title: CocaCola's Profits Up by 22.9% in First Quarter Despite Decline in Sales
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest softdrink producer reported record firstquarter earnings with an increase of 22.9 percent, despite a second successive quarterly sales slide.

title: Egypt to Act in U.N.
description: CAIRO, May 3 (AP)Egypt called today for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss atrocities alleged to have been committed by Israelis against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank of the Jordan Rivers.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 3Efforts are under way in the State Legislature to curtail the relative freedom lobbyists have enjoyed here.

title: CAPITAL OUTLAYS FOR SUFFOLK CUT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 3Citing severe and unprecedented economic problems, the Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, announced today that he was slashing his 197779 capital program by $430 million.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: A TIME TO STUDY, A TIME TO PLAY: There's a time for all things, according to Ecclesiastes, and yesterday Eddie Finer, 13, found time for at least two of them at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Title Fight Postponed
description: MEXICO CITY. May 3 (AP) The World Boxing Council announced today it has approved postponement or the world lightheavyweight title bout between John Conteh of Britain, the W.B.C. champion, and Alvaro Lopez. The fight, originally scheduled for April in Kampala, Uganda, has been postponed to June 11 because of a hand injury suffered by Conteh.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1978 by Triangle Publications, Inc. The Daily Racing Form Monday, May 3. First day, Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Columbia Nine Breezes to a Crown
description: When cold March and April winds spill over the Palisades, race down the Hudson and make the first quick left turn to whip up Souvren Duvvil. Baker Field becomes a miserable place to play baseball. Columbia's baseball teams have battled the elements and the opponents on this cold and windy diamond for more than half a century with the Lions usually losing to both.

title: India Sues 5 American Grain Companies
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Government of India filed suit today against five large American grain companies, charging fraud in grain shipments over the last 15 years and seeking $215 million in damages.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Yonkers Entries

title: Sketches of the Winners of the 60th Pulitzer Prizes in Journalism and the Arts
description: Sometimes called the most intellectual of novelists  His work is concerned with the realization of the self confronted by the demands of society  His early tight, spare writing moved to more open, rich and rhetorical manner of the later novels. Canadianborn, he grew up in Chicago, where he attended the University of Chicago and Northwestern  Has been credited with doing for Chicago Jewish life what James T. Farrell did for the Irish  He is now a professor at the University of Chicago and is chairman of the university's Committee on Social Thought. He has taught at Princton, Bard, University of Minnesota. Three times married and twice divorced, he had one child with each wife. Whitehaired, heavylidded, his mournful demeanor is balanced by his warmth and humor. Has an interest in nature not always present in an urban intellectual.

title: Cahn Acts as His Own Lawyer In Retrial on MailFraud Charges
description: Acting as his own lawyer William Cahn, Tormer Nassau County District Attorney, told a jury at his retrial yesterday that his first trial on mailfraud charges had been a saga of claim forms in which my judgment has been twisted and tortured in an effort to fit the square peg of guilt into the round hole of innocence.

title: A partment House Workers Strike at Many Buildings
description: Building service employees seeking higher pay and improved benefits went on strike at numerous apartment houses in New York City yesterday in a walkout that surprised many owners and tenants.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: My Juliet winning the Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, OCO omitted)

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)The Justice Department filed today a proposed consent decree to settle a 1670 suit charging six manufacturers of refrigerant gas and a trade association with monopoly practices. The proposed decree filed in United States District Court in Cleveland would forbid the companies from restricting sale of replacement refrigerants to refrigeration wholesalers and fullline airconditioning wholesalers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Following the collapse of Prime Minister Aldo Moro's Cabinet last week, the Italian Government set June 20 and 21 as the dates for national elections that could give the Communist Party a share of power. The Christian Democrats, the dominant party, also decided to hold regional elections in Sicily and local elections in various cities, including Rome and Genoa. The local voting is expected to result in a city administration in Rome run by the Communists, who already control the major cities north of Rome. [Page 7, Column 1.]

title: In Memoriam
description: LEESamantha. In your three brief years you touched so many lives, our love and appreciation deepens.

title: Messersmith and McNally Given Integrity Credits
description: In these days of free agents and rising salaries, baseball's club owners have contended that players forever more will see nothing but dollar signs at the ends of their bats, whereas in the good old days. when the game was played purely for fun, they saw only hits and strikeouts. From now on, the owners have suggested, the players will not let any sense of loyalty and integrity interfere with their avaricious ambitions.

title: DISC TAX BREAK ASSAYED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A. study by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service concluded today that there would be little or no adverse effect on jobs or exports from repealing the special tax break for explorers known as DISC. The tax is currently saving United States corporations $1.4 billion annually.

title: U.S. Stock Abroad Totals $37.2 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Foreign holdings of United States stocks amounted to $37.2 billion at the end of last year, roughly 5 percent of the value of publicly traded stocks, a major new Treasury study disclosed today.

title: Scores Followed Normal Curve
description: The scores students received on The New York Times American History Test clustered neatly under what statisticians call a normal, bellshape curvesome very good students and some very bad students at the extremes and the rest in between.

title: Talks Resumed by Bunker Over Panama Canal Issue
description: PANAMA, May 3 (UPI)Ambassador at Large Ellsworth Bunker resumed talks today for eventual transfer of the Panama Canal to Panama.

title: ITALY SETS VOTING ONJUNE 20 AND 21
description: ROME, May 3The Italian Government today set June 20 and 21 as the dates for national elections that could yield the Communist party a share of power.

title: Ford's Nomination For Consumer Unit Rejected by Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee rejected today President Ford's nomination of S. John Byington to be chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Need for Coordination
description: From the start last month, Governor Carey's decision to name a Council on the New York Economy invited a degree of skepticism, coming as it did on the heels a series of apparently uncoordinated gubernatorial moves to fight what he has correctly labeled New York's Number One problemthe declining economy of bath city and state.

title: New Violence in Corsica
description: AJACCIO Corsica, Wednesday, May 5(Agence FrancePresse)A wave of new bombing attacks swepts Corsica last night and early today. Fourteen attacks wewe made in the cities of Ajaccio, Corte, and Bastia. Most were against official buildings, though the headquarters at the Corsian autonomist movement was also hit.

title: Egypt Assails Israel in U.N. Session on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 4Egypt accused Israel of barbaric measures against Palestinians today as the Security Council opened another debate on the situation in the occupied Arab territories.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1976, by Trianzle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Tuesday, May 4. Second day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: For Troubled Adolescents, a Place to Turn To
description: Maria was an alcoholic at the age of 16. Two and a half years ago she found The Door, a free service center for young people, and she has been making the onehour trip from her Staten Island home to The Door in Manhattan five nights a week ever since.

title: Hollander Ordered to Jail To Serve 5 Nights a Week
description: Eugene Hollander, the nursinghome operator, was sentenced yesterday to spend five nights a week in jail for up to six months and was ordered to sever all connections with nursing homes for inflating Medicare reimbursement claims by more than $100.000.

title: Herman Neuman, Early Leader In Classical Music on Radio, 80
description: Herman Neuman, a pioneer in radio broadcasting of classical music; died late Tuesday night while attending a dinner in his honor at the Roosevelt Hotel. He was SO years old and lived in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

title: Cultural Aide Named
description: Henri Claude Shostel was appointed by Mayor Beame yesterday as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. A Man in the News article appears on page 20.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was erroneously reported in The New York Times yesterday that the Giant food chain was one of two that had refused to guarantee that it would continue to mark prices on individual food items. The chains that refused to make such a guarantee were Lucky Stores Inc. of California and WinnDixie.

title: Tenants in Struck Buildings Sharing the Work
description: Residents of Parker Towers, a complex of three 22story apartment buildings on Queens Boulevard in Queens, felt the first effects of the building service employees walkout yesterday. They were told, among other things, not to move out or have parties until the strike is over.

title: JERSEY AIDE WARY OF APLANT AT SEA
description: TRENTON, May 4David J. Bardin,'the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said today that the state would try to block the construction of the world's first floating nuclear plants off Atlantic City unless the Federal Government carefully analyzed all the risks invoved in the event of a major accident.

title: House Overrides the Veto Of Day Care Bill, 301101
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The House overrode today President Ford's veto of the $125 million child daycare bill, which would give federally supported centers money to meet the costs of yearold, unenforced program standards.

title: Park Travesty
description: New York never loses its sense of the ludicrous. But a particularly fine pitch of foolishness has been reached with the Parks Departmentendorsed artistinresidence program for the city's parks. The artistinresidence will balance logs, stones, boulders and tree boughs in compositions called Accents on Nature on a oneaday basis in May and June in Battery Park and the Bronx Botanical Gardens, in what the prograT's sponsor, the Public Arts Council of New York City, considers a significant first. The creative act will be photodocumented and accompanied by mime, ballet, music and video art.

title: Islanders Triumph, 52
description: UNIONDALE, L.L, May 4  The New York Islanders, who have a history of being at their best when facing elimination, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 52, tonight in the fourth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A private detective running for the City Council in Orange was indicted on charges of kidnapping, assault and threatening the lives of two men. Mims Hackett Jr., 31 years old, of Orange, was charged in a fourcount indictment with assaulting Lawrence Moss, 18, and with kidnapping him last Aug. 29. Mr. Hackett was also charged with threatening the life of Brian Watkins, 22, of Plainfield and Mr. Moss's brother, Anthony, 20, of Orange, on the same day. Mr. Hackett, arraigned in Orange Municipal Court, was released on bail.

title: Rep. Moss Quits Atom Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, resigned from the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee, saying the press of other work forced his decision.

title: TV STAR ACCUSED IN A DRUM CASE
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF., May 4 (AP) Television's Mary Hartman has been booked for investigation of possession of cocaine: Louise Lasser, 37 years old, star of the Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, series, is free on $1,631 bond posted after a series of problems that began with her arrest Saturday on a charge of creating a disturbance at a houtioue.

title: CARTER LEADING COLORADO RIVALS
description: DENVER, May 4A plurality, of Colorado Democrats appears uncommitted to any Presidential candidate, but former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia made a strong showing yesterday in precinct caucuses, according to a sampling of precincts.

title: Hollander Ordered to Jail To Serve 5 Nights a Week
description: Eugene Eollander, the nursinghome operator, was sentenced yesterday to spend five nighs a week in jail for up to six months and was ordered to sever all connections with nursing homes for inflating Medicare reimbursement claims by more than $100,000.

title: How Pay Curb Could Ease Inflation
description: WASHINGTON. May 4Tho Ford Administration, officially at least, professes unconcern about the trend of wages in the economy. For example, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, explicitly declined to criticize the fairly hefty settlement recently negotiated by the Teamsters, and the same position has been taken by the Secretary of Labor. W. J. Usery Jr.

title: Playoff Results
description: N.B.A. Playoffs

title: Apollos to Face 3 New Teams
description: The New York Apollos will face three of the new American Soccer League franchises this week, starting tonight with a game at Tacoma. The Apollos then will play at Sacramento on Friday night and at Utah on Saturday.

title: Pact Sought in Dumping Of Foreign Autos in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Volkswagen, Volvo, Renault and other leading foreign car manufacturers have dumped their automobiles in the United States the Treasury Department announced tonight.

title: PBS Head Appeals to Networks For Use of News Documentaries
description: Looking for ways for public television to increase its public affairs programming while operating on a starvation budget, Lawrence K. Grossman, president of the Public Broadcasting Service, suggested that the noncommercial systern seek the cooperation of the commercial networks news di visions.

title: Sets Beat Lobsters
description: BOSTON, May 4The New York Sets scored a 3220 World Team Tennis victory tonight over the Boston Lobsters before 2,488 fans at Wazlter Brown Arena.

title: Food Stamp Rules Tightened To Drop 5 Million Recipients
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Agriculture Department announced today adoption of new regulations designed to eliminate at least five million Americans from the food stamp program by tightening eigibilitv standards.

title: Why Was the Dragon Slain?
description: PARISSomething very unusual going on in Britain's nuclear program. It is difficult to conclude from available details on this highly classified subject whether recent developments should be linked to London's strategic planning.

title: Payments Abroad Disclosed by SCM
description: The SCM Corporation disclosed yesterday that some of its foreign subsidiaries had made questionable payments totaling about $895,000 to foreign government officials and employees of customers since the beginning of 1971.

title: Monday's Fight
description: Topeka, Kan.James Martinez, 122 pounds, Dallas outpointed. Melvin Johnson, 120, Clovis, N.M., 10 rounds.

title: Rep. Madden Loses
description: Representative Ray J. Madden of Indiana, the 84yearold chairman of the House Rules Committee, was defeated in the Democratic primary by State Senator Adam Benjamin Jr., 40. Mr. Madden's age was a major campaign issue. Page 24.

title: Marginalia: Bloom, Pinter Set for Play
description: Two major theater talents, Claire Bloom, as star and Harold Pinter, as director, have been sot for a new production of The Innocents, which Arthur Cantor will bring to Broadway in the fall after five weeks on the road.

title: In Memoriam
description: In Memoriam

title: Democrats in Capital Give An Early Lead to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 5Democratic voters in the predominantly black Disrict of Columbia appeared on the basis of preliminary returns early today to have given former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia substantial backing in today's local Presidential primary.

description: Major League Box Scores

description: So now there are going to be bus tours of Jewish New York, and the first, demonstration, hurryupalreadyandfinish tour was held yesterday.

description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWNEW, 7:50 P.M.)

title: Reagan Catching Up
description: Ronald Reagan proved in Indiana yesterday that his devastating defeat of President Ford in Texas last Saturday was no fluke. His narrow victoey over Mr. Ford demonstrated for the first time that the California conservative could win outside the South and put the President into a political hole from which he will extricate himself, if at all, only after a struggle.

title: Confidence in the Press
description: The experience of Watergate is the most recent demonstration that a free press is essential to a free demccracy. Yet, ironically just as government because of its size and complexity has distanced itself from the individual citizen, the press has been distancing itself from the individual reader at the very moment when democracy needs it most.

title: OPTION DEALS DUE IN COMMODITIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The commodities Futures Tradimg Commission appears headedloward a decision to permit trading in options on commodity futures contracts, according to draft recommendations to be presented for commission consideration early next week.

title: Cash Prices
description: Tuesday, May 4, 1976

title: Sales and Earnings Data Reported by Companies
description: Sales and Earnings Data Reported by Companies

title: Cultural Aide Named
description: Henri Claude Shostel was appointed by Mayor Beame yesterday as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. A Man in the News article appears on page 20.

title: Councilmen Seeking Bigger School Voice
description: Members of the New York City Council's Finance Committee said yesterday that they intended to assert their authority to make significant changes in priorities for spending tax dollars on education.

title: Uniroyal Increasing Prices On ABS Kralastic Plastic
description: The Uniroyal Chemical unit of Uniroyal announced yester day that it was increasing prices on its ABS Kralastic tic, effective June 1.

title: News Summary and Index
description: James R. Schlesinger, the former Defense Secretary, said in a Washington speech that the Ford Administration was undermining American moral support for Israel by undue pressure for Israeli eoncessions to the Arabs. He said that Israel, like. South Vietnam in 197273, was being blamed for failure to make progress toward a settlement. Without mentioning Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, he seemed to be criticizing his negotiating tactics. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Jurors Chosen in Lifeboat Case Against a Skipper
description: CAMDEN, May 4 (AP)Twelve jurors were impaneled today to hear the case against Cyril E. LaBrecque, the yacht captain charged with involuntary manslaughter for allegedly refusing to throw his dog overboard and make room in his lifeboat for two crewmen.

title: How the Federal Reserve Decides How Much Money to Put Into the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Only one thing is entirely agreed, accepted and understood about the somewhat mysterious and often controversial subject of the Government's monetary policy, which is conducted by the semiindependent Federal Reserve Board.

title: ANNE V. McKITTRICK
description: Anne Versteeg McKittrick, organist and choir director of Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights since 1938, died Monday at LeRoy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. She was 71 years old and lived at 2 Grace Court in Brooklyn.

title: TRADING IS MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: A late afternoon rally reversed earlier losses and enabled stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market to finish mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

title: 50 Millionth Guest Feted At Empire State Building
description: Ingo Eileis paid 51.70 for a ticket for his wife. Helfa and $1.70 for himself to visit the 66thfloor observatory of the Empire State Building yesterday morning  and then came the avalanche.

title: Israelis on Guard After Arab Bomb Mars Celebrations
description: TEL AVIV, May 4 (Reuters)Strong police reinforcements checked all vehicles entering Jerusalem today at the start of Israel's Independence Day celebrations after an Arab guerrilla bomb blast.

title: Assembly in Albany Will Debate Measure on SavingsBank Checking Today
description: ALBANY, May 4The State Legislature will face its last chance this year to pass a bill allowing savings banks to grant checking account privileges when debate starts on the banking measure tomorrow.

title: Hurok Concerts Ousts Sheldon Gold as Its President
description: Sheldon Gold was replaced yesterday as president of Hurok Concerts Inc in an action that be said took him by surprise.

title: Incurnbency Helping Ford On Campaign Travel Cost
description: WASHINGTON, May 4President Ford made political trips for three months this year without paying any travel bills, an advantage of his incumbency that has proved especially important because of the delay in allocation of Federal matching funds to the Presidential candidates.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designdles OTB listing

title: JAPAN CHARGES TWO IN MERCURY DEATHS
description: KUMAMOTO, Japan, May 4 (Reuters)Two businessmen were charged with involuntary manslaughter here today in Japan's most famous pollution case  mercury poisoning in the village of Niinamata.

title: GEORGIANS BACK CARTER, REAGAN
description: ATLANTA, May 4Former Gov. Jimmy Carter swept to victory over two principal rivals in the nonbinding Democratic Presidential preference primary here tonight.

title: South Korea Begins Trial Of 18 Opposition Leaders
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 4 A group of 18 religious and political leaders of South Korea went on trial today on charges of having violated the country's emergency decree prohibiting all acts of dissent against the Government.

title: A Cleveland Ward Turns to Carter, But Commitment Seems Lukewarm
description: CLEVELANDJoe Mazzeo is a tall stringbean of a plumber who lives with his wife and children upstairs over St. Rocco's Parish Credit Union in the middle of Cleveland's Westside Fifth Ward, in the house where he was born 48 years ago. He is also Ward Five's Democratic leader, a man who is listened to in matters political.

title: American New Car Sales Show a Rise Of 55% in the Final 10 Days of April
description: DETROIT. May 4American new car sales were up 55 percent in the last third of April from the yearearlier level as the domestic industry's comeback completed its seventh month. Sales of American cars ended a twoyear slump with the start of the 1976 model year in last October.

title: ExPentagon Chief Assails Ford Pressure on Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the Ford Administration was undermining American moral support for Israel by putting undue pressure on it to make concessions to the Arabs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled that the plans of the Levittown (L.I.) School District for a 10 percent staff reduction, the furloughing of teachers without pay, and a moratorium on all sabbatical leaves did not have to be submitted to binding arbitration. The justice, James F. Niehoff, said an arbitration provision in the teacher's contract was unenforceable because of the school district's financial plight.

title: Miss Phipps Wins Title
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 4 (Reuters)Joan Phipps a rider from Edmonton, Alberta, won the $1,000 first prize in the women's world jockey championships, that ended here last night. Miss Phipps, 24 years old, finished the fourrace series with 22 points. Marina Lezcano, a 19yearold Argentine, won last night's final race to finish runnerup in the series contested by 16 riders.

title: Architects Postpone Action on Advertising Ban
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 4Delegates to the American Institute of Architects convention at the Sheraton Hotel here voted overwhelmingly to postpone changes in the institute's standards of ethical practice that would have permitted architects to advertise.

title: Pop Warner's Greatest Player
description: Back in New York for the opening of Yankee Stadium II, Joe DiMaggio reported that he had seen Ernie Nevers out on the Coast and the blond bull of Stanford's second Rose Bowl football team was in poor shape physically. That was less than a month ago. On Monday came news that Nevers had died of a kidney disorder in San Rafael, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: Connecticut Assembly Passes Bill for a Single Court System
description: HARTFORD, May 4  The Connecticut State Senate gave final legislative approval to a bill today that would merge the existing lower trial courts in the state into a single court system to achieve administrative flexibility and efficiency.

title: Memorial Boycott Held At Kent State Campus
description: KENT, Ohio, May 4 (AP)A memorial boycott of classes was held today at Kent State University on the sixth anniversary of its bloody Vietnam War protest. While some students picketed, others attended class.

title: What's Nu? BagelandBus Tours of Jewish New York
description: So now there are going to be bus tours of Jewish New York, and the first, demonstration, hurryupalreadyandfinish tour was held yesterday.

title: Senator Long Hints He'd Restore A Tax Credit Big Concerns Lost
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, indicated today that he would try to get Congress to restore to at least a few oil producers the depletion allowance they lost last year when Congress repealed it for the big producers.

title: Gifts Rain on 50 Millionth Empire State Visitor, From Germany
description: Ingo Eilers paid $1.70 for a ticket for his wife, Helga, and $1.70 for himself to visit the 86thfloor observatory of the Empire State Building yesterday morning  and thencame the avalanche.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Ketchikan Pulp Company said yesterday that it would close its pulp mill in Ketchikan, Alaska, by July 1, 1977. The company is owned equally by the LouisianaPacific Corporation and by the FMC Corporation.

title: Study Finds Sterilization Gains Fastest of BirthCurb Methods
description: Sterilization, which only recently began to lose its stigma as an extreme and undesirable method of birth control, has emerged as the decade's fastestgrowing contraceptive technique among married Americans, according to findings of a nationwide survey released, yesterday.

title: GEORGIANS BACK CARTER, REAGAN
description: ATLANTA, May 4Former Gov. Jimmy Carter swept to victory over two principal rivals in the nonbinding Democratic Presidential preference primary here tonight.

title: TV: Curious Aspects of a Talk With a Mercenary
description: Last Sunday, 60 Minutes. the CBS News magazine that is presented weekly at 7 P.M., presented an essay entitled Hired Hand. Produced by Joe DeCola and reported by Dan Rather, the piece featured an interview with a mercenarya selfdescribed killer and terrorist for international hire. He went on to tell about an alleged effort by a Los Angeles member of the Jewish Defense League to purchase his services for $250,000 to assassinate Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Taxing the Markets
description: Governor Carey's new Council on the New York Economy is off to a mixed start in its first recommendations for tax relief to improve the business climate of city and state. The goal is commendableto avoid seemingly onerous taxes that only have the effect of forcing productive enterprises out of the region and thus reducing the effective tax base. But two of the first taxes singled out for correction, the city estate tax and the stock transfer tax, are quite different their respective impacts.

title: $1.2 BILLION MORE ASKED FOR NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Ford Administration asked Congress today to add $1.2 billion and five ships to the Navy's shipbuilding budget as the first step in a longterm buildup that it said was necessary to maintain a naval balance with the Soviet Union.

title: Madden, Oldest House Member, Defeated
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 4Representative Ray J. Madden, the 84yearold charman of the House Rules Committee, was defeated tonight by State Senator Adam Benjamin Jr. in the Democratic primary in Indiana's 1st Conaressional District.

description: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures

description: Yonkers Raceway Results

title: Adolph S. Ochs Stamp Will Be Issued in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, May 4A 13cent commemorative stamp to be issued next fall will honor Adolph S. Ochs, former publisher of The New York Times, the Postal Service announced today.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: MELVIN BROWN DIES; FOOD EXECUTIVE, 56
description: Melvin M. Brown, senior vice president of the Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago, died yesterday of cancer in SloanKettering Memorial Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Hillsdale. N. J.

title: Offer of Pontiac Jobs Draws 2,400 in a Day
description: PONTIAC, May 4 (UPI)For the first time in two years, the Pontiac Motors Division of General Motors accepted applications for job openings yesterday, and more than 2,400 persons applied.

title: Helen Keller Center Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) A national center to rehabilitate persons who are both deaf and blind would be named after Helen Keller under a bill passed by the House yesterday. The center, which was created tinder a 1973 act, is in Sands Point, N.Y.

title: BOND YIELDS UP, BUT SALES DRAG
description: Yields on highgrade corporate and taxexempt bonds rose significantly yesterday in the first real tests of the credit markets since they headed into their current slump last week. Aarated utility bonds were priced to yield 8 percent, up from 8.70 percent last Thursday. Honolulu's new $35 million bond issue yielded as much as 25 basis points more than Aarated municipal bonds sold last week.

title: RHODESIANS DECRY NAMING OF CHIEFS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 9Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's new initiative of bringing four African chiefs into his Cabinet has met with widespread opposition and appears unlikely to aid a political settlement of the Rhodesian crisis.

title: Team America Begins Practice
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 4Candidates for Team America showed their talent today before Ken Furthy, coach of the Cosmos.

title: Shackles on Poland
description: The 35nation EastWest Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe last year was seen by many as a harbinger of Communist polycentrism even in Eastern Europe. Rumanians, Yugoslays, Hungarians, Czechoslovaks and other East European Communists urged Western diplomats to complete the difficult negotiations and to attend the summitlevel signing in Helsinki not only to consolidate detente and increase EastWest human contact, but to shore up East European independence against Soviet hegemony.

title: Crossovers Aid Reagan
description: Ronald Reagan owed his slender lead in the Indiana primary yesterday largely to independents and Democrats who voted in the Republican contest, according to a poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: About Education
description: Although the period of expanded access to college that began during the 1960's succeeded in propelling greater numbers of black as well as white students into college, many blacks in higher education are worried by other indications that blacks may actually be losing ground.

title: JERSEY AIDE WARY OF APLANT AT SEA
description: TRENTON, May 4David J. Bardin, the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said today that the state would try to block the construction of the world's first floating nuclear plants off Atlantic City unless the Federal Government carefully analyzed all the risks involved in the event of a major accident.

title: Congress Clears Measure To Revive Election Panel
