description: The RollsRoyce of RollsRoyces, which is to say the ultimate ultimate of motor cars, is a brand new twodoor hardtop model that goes by the name of Camargue. It looks very much like other RollsRoycesbut sells for $90,000.

title: Dow Average Up by 3.38; Canada Southern Adds 10
description: A late rally, led by energyrelated and glamour issues, lifted stock prices yesterday after a twoday downtrend. Wall Street analysts said that the market showed a bit of life as selling activity seemed to dry up.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Books of The Times
description: In his latest book, The Uses of Enchantment: The Meaning and Importance of Fairy Tales. the noted child psychologist Bruno Bettelheim is out to turn the clocks back. He believes traditional folk fairy tales, such as Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood and The Frog King, are far more valuable to children than modern realistic stories. Therefore he intends in this study to reveal the deep psychological content of fairy tales, and to demonstrate how it aids children in solving certain enduring existential predicaments, most prominent among them separation anxiety, sibling rivalry and oedipal conflict. His ultimate hope is that a proper understanding of the unique merits of fairy tales will induce parents and teachers to assign them once again to that central role in the life of the child they held for centuries.

title: Rosewall Doubts a Bid at Wimbledon
description: It might have been the last time New Yorkers would see the flashing backhand, the marvelous footwork, the perfect rhythm of man, racquet and ball flowing together in classic style. And only a few hundred were on hand as Ken Rosewall came to Tennisport to play an exhibition match to help promote his book, Twenty Years at the Top.

title: Wallace Takes an Early Lead in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala, Wednesday. May 5Gov. George C. Wallace, his homestate political credibility at stake, was leading former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia early today in scattered early returns from the Alabama Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Convicted Union Aide Quits
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) Irving Stern, who was sentenced to four months in prison stemming from a New York supermarket kickbacks scandal, has resigned as vice president of the Amalgamated Meatcutters Union. A union announcement today said that Mr. Stern's resignation had been accepted by the union executive board April 27 in a meeting in Chicago.

title: Food Costs Dip Slightly In a Week
description: Although the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week dropped below the previous week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported that the price of meat was still high and that meat counter specials were becomipg scarce.

title: Britain Reaches an Agreement With Unions on PayRise Limits
description: LONDON, Wednesday, May 5 (Reuters) Britain's Labor Government reached an agreement early today with trade union leaders on wage restraints.

title: Funniest Show in Town
description: The funniest thing that has happened in the Presidential election so far is the emergence of Ronald Reagan as an expert on foreign and military policy. Not since Julie Andrews turned Eliza Doolittle into My Fair Lady has there been such an amusing and unlikely transformation.

title: Mets Seaver Beats Reds, 53
description: A crowd of 18,528 ignored 48degree weather last night and showed up at Shea Stadium to see the Cincinnati Reds in their first New York appearance as baseball champions. They saw the Reds and they saw the Mets defeat the Reds. 53, for Tom Seaver's fourth victory without a loss.

title: Police in Mexico Free 10 Held by Students for Week
description: MEXICO CITY, May 4The Mexican police today freed 10 hostages held by armed rightwing students at the University of Puebla for a week.

title: For Four Days, All Their World's a Stage
description: CAPE MAY, May 4While schoolchildren in Colonial costumes cheered and their elders adjusted powdered wigs, a stagecoach left here today on the first leg of a fourday, 100mile overland trip to Philadelphia, its driver unconcerned about highway brigands.

title: WILLIAM KIEFER, 54, OF TIMELIFE BOOKS
description: William C. Kiefer, a senior copywriter for TimeLife Books, died yesterday of a heart attack, after surgery at United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Recital
description: Clamma Dale is a name easy to remember, and, as her first New York recital demonstrated on Monday night, that is as it should be. The soprano, who had previously made a good impression in appearances at the City Opera and the MiniMet, appeared at Alice Tully Hall as firstprize winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's 50th anniversary voice competition. Rarely does a young singer carry off a solo recital with such easy authority and stage presence, or please as consistently as Miss Dale did.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW TAPESTRY EXHIBITED: Visitors to the South Tower of the World Trade Center at ceremony to hang the 35by20foot tapestry by Joan Mire. Threeton work of art will be on display until July 5.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Film: Mindless Drugs:Tranquilizers for Disturbed Patients Are Scored in Documentary at Whitney
description: "Hurry Tomorrow" which opened a week's run yesterday at the Whitney Museum, is a spare, angry documentary feature about the use of various kinds of tranquilizing drugs in the treatment of disturbed patients in a men's ward at Metropolitan State Hospital in Norwalk, Calif. It is a drama of particulars, of individual patients and individual doctors, and it is enough to make you swear off anything stronger than warm milk forever.The point of the film makers, Richard Cohen (director and editor) and Kevin Rafferty (chief camerman and assistant editor), is clearly stated within the film by a former patient, a member of an organization called the Network Against Psychiatric Abuse, who sees the administration of any drugs, without the consent of the patient, to be a violation of the body equivalent to rape.This is putting the film makers' case much less emotionally than the film itself does. Though "Hurry Tomorrow" has some technical deficiencies, which are understandable considering the conditions under which it was made, it is an agonizing, involving spectacle to watch, with more bitterness and outrage in any three-minute sequence than in all of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest."With the apparent cooperation of the ward's chief doctor, a man who seems so arrogant, vain, self-assured and high on himself that he doesn't realize what sort of film is being made, the cameramen wander the clean but miserably barren halls of the ward, picking up the stories of the patients, some of whom seem much less neurotic than the people treating them.We watch a young black man being badgered by the doctor, who notes that the patient has a peculiar way of getting angry when he is either hungry or locked up. The patient agrees, "Sometimes you sound just a bit grandiose," says the doctor. "What's grandiose?" says the patient helplessly, which seems to please the doctor. "I want to go home," the young man says. The patient will go home, the doctor tells the film makers, only when he stops asking towhich is this doctor's catch-22.The film makers attend a get-together of drug salesmen and the doctors where a representative of one company announces fatuously: "No more napalm. We're out of the war business and into the health business." The health business, as the representative of Network Against Psychiatrist Abuse tells us, includes the pushing of tranquilizing drugs that turn patients into zombies, which we see, and that have such possible side effects as dizziness, liver damage and cardiac arrest, which are listed on the drugs themselves.Nevertheless some things about "Hurry Tomorrow" bother me. The doctor may well be a first-class creep, but the film makers nudge him along. As he is answering one of their qestions, the camera pans to one side to show us his two Siamese cats lying on a bench covered with imitation leopard skin. What does that tell us? That he's a fur fetishist? His pseudohip jargon is bad enough, we don't have to have a scene in which he proudly shows us his car and the California license plate. MAGIAN, which, he explains, was his second choice. after MAGI. At another point the cameraman, who is never acknowledged by the film, seems to be locked up in solitary with a patient who is being punished.A documentary always has a point of view, sometimes called a bias, and there is nothing wrong with that as long as it is admitted. "Hurry Tomorrow" makes its feelings so apparent, and raises so many important questions, it doesn't need to overstate the nuttiness of the doctor, nor to convince us its cameraman was somehow locked up for hours with a single patient These are small points, but a documentary as good as this one must be above such things.

title: Pound Support Cuts Reserves Of Britain to Lowest Since 71
description: LONDON, May 4. (Reuters)The cost of supporting the pound has reduced Britain's rnonetary reserves to their lowest level in nearly five years, the Treasury disclosed today.

title: Notes on People
description: Making the rounds to publicize his new book, Spiro T. Agnew said on a television show to be seen May 31 that his relationship with Richard M. Nixon was never close.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Kahn Sees Hope for World Poor
description: The message is unfashion ably optimistic, delivered by a man who became famous analyzing the most pessimistic of possibilities: nuclear war.

title: Brown's Thoughts Sell 7,000 Books
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (Reuters)  City Lights, the poetry publishing company that brought out a little red book of the thoughts of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, reports the book has become its biggest best seller since Howl, by Allen Ginsberg, the Beat poet.

title: Australia Chooses Waltzing Matilda As Official Anthem
description: CANBERRA, Australia, May 4 (UPI)Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser announced today that Australia had decided to make Waltzing Matilda its national anthem although God Save the Queen will still be played for royal occasions.

title: Squires:
description: The Virginia Squires situa tion is one of total confusion, and it becomes more of a problem every day. Some players have not been paid since April 15, others since May 1, and Jack Ankerson, the general manager of the American Basketball Association team, said yesterday, There is no money to pay them.

title: REAGAN DEFEATS FORD IN INDIANA AND ALSO WINS GEORGIA PRIMARY; CARTER IS VICTOR IN BOTH STATES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, May 5Ronald Reagan added momentum yesterday to his recent Texas primary triumph by defeating President Ford in the Indiana, Georgia and Alabama Republican Presidential primaries.

title: Major Grain Concern Is Fined $500,000 on 50 Shortweightin0 Cases After Pleading No Contest
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 4The Continental Grain Company was fined $500,000 by'a Federal judge today after pleading no contest to charges of false declarations on the weights of foreign shipments while scales used to weigh the cargoes were rigged.

title: Beame's Culture Chief
description: When Henri Claude Shostal learned yesterday that Mayor Beame had selected him to be the city's new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, he said, It came as a real surprise to me. Mr. Shos tal, who has been director of the Mayor's Office of Lower Manhattan Development for the last two years, had no more than an inkling that he was under consideration for the cultural post.

title: Bengals Sign Griffin
description: CINCINNATI, May 4 (UPI)Archie Griffin of Ohio State, the only twotime winner of the Heisman Trophy as college football's top player, spurned a lucrative offer to play Canadian hall tonight and signed a multiyear contract with the Cincinnati Bengals of the National Football League.

title: Death of Greek Hero a Political Issue
description: ATHENS. May 4The death in a car crash of Alexaodros Panagoulis, resistance hero and member of Parliament, has provoked charges here of an assassination plot and caused the Greek Government a major political headache.

title: About New York
description: When the curtain goes up at this afternoon's performance of Very Good Eddie, Charles F. Maurice will be in the audience as usual.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: 3 Named by Deadline Club To Journalism Hall of Fame
description: Three New York reportersPeter Kihss of The New York Times, James L. Kilgallen of The Hearst Headline Service and Gabe Pressman of WNEWTVhave been named to the Deadline Club's Journalism Hall of Fame.

title: Business Briefs
description: HARRISBURG, May 4 (AP)The state filed a suit in the United States Middle District Court today against the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh, charging the state's biggest bank with fraud and mismanagement in its handling of public school money. The civil suit also seeks the ouster of the Mellon Bank as trustee for the state Public School Building Authority's funds, which amount to hundreds of millions of dollars. The suit accused the Mellon Bank, in part, of cheating the state of interest paid on deposits.

title: Africa Tour Resembles Stampede
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 4The first week of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's African visit was paced like a stampede, and one veteran of many Kissinger trips said he thought it was more of an endurance test than a diplomatic mission.

title: Crop Is Down, So Maple Syrup Prices Are on the Way Up.
description: ALBANYConsumers will have to pay more for the maple syrup on their pancakes later this year as a result of a poor 1976 crop and short supply of good quality syrup, according to reports from both producers and roadside stand operators.

title: Jolley Fills His Barn Here
description: Bertram Firestone's Hones. Pleasure who as the oddson favorite was beaten by Bold Forbes in last Saturday's Kentucky Derby, was an unexpected arrival at Belmont Park late yesterthe day afternoon. He was accompanied on the cargo plane and in the van by LeRoy Jolley hi trainer. It had been anticipated that the 3yearold colt was going to be shipped directly from Louisville to Maryland for the Preakness. The second jewel in throughbred racing's Triple Crown will be held at Pimlico a week from Saturday.

title: Ashe Upset By Solomon In Opener
description: DALLAS, May 4 (UPI)Harold Solomon, with brilliant passing shots, upset Arthur Ashe, the defending champion, in the opening match of the $10,000 World Championship Tennis singles finale tonight, 75, 36, 61, 63.

title: WINE TALK
description: It was just an ordinary shopping excursion, a search for some inexpensive but good white wines. In all, a dozen different whites were purchased at several different storesand also a couple of reds, just because they looked interesting.

title: OneActers By Simon Due June 10
description: After more than a year of writing for the screen, Neil Simon is returning to Broadway with a new work. California Suite, which encompasses four oneact comedies set in a Beverly Hills hotel.

title: U.S. Tour of McCartney and Wings Is Off to Triumphal Start in Fort Worth
description: FORT WORTH, May 4Paul McCartney has long since proved himself the most steadily professional, commercially viable of the former Beatles. But that was all through recordings. Last night, in beginning an American tour at the Tarrant County Convention Center Arena here with his first performance in this country in 10 years, Mr. McCartney established himself and his band, Wings, as concert artists in their own right.

title: Jim Robinson Is Dead at 86; Trombonist With Jazz Bands
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 4 (AP) Jim Robinson, who played trombone for some of the best New Orleans jazz bands for more than half a century, died of cancer today in Touro Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: ExEnvoy Charges U.S. Ignored An Offer on Soviet Somalia Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The former American ambassador to Saudi Arabia told a Senate subcommittee today that a Saudi proposal to reduce Soviet influence in Somalia had been ignored by the United States.

title: Portuguese Communism: The Soviet Roots Run Deep
description: LISBON, May 1The Portutuese Communists and their [intense, dramatic leader, Alivario Cunhal, have sometimes been called Europe's last Stalinists because of their rigidity and unblemished fealty to Moscow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While the cleanair plan recently supported by the U.S. Court of Appeals has noble objectives, one wonders if the powers that be are really in touch with the people that are.

title: 1970's East Side School on Scrap List
description: An airconditioned school with the latest in educational equipment and facilities is among 37 schools the Board of Education announced recently that it planned to abandon for other use in an effort to save money.

title: Shrimp Strawberries
description: 1 cup hulled sesame seeds

title: The Phoenix, the Dragon and 10 Titillated Palates
description: Oh, for the life of a food writer, friends and acquaintances say longingly, imagining, as they do, days of caviar and Scotch salmon and one heavenly meal after another. For the most part, of course, the meals are less than heavenly, averaging about 10 that are mediocretoterrible for every one that is even neargreat. But fortunately, there are just enough highspots to make it all worthwhile.

title: Court Backs Moratorium On New York City Notes
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday unanimously upheld the threeyear moratorium on New York City's obligation to pay the principal on $1.6 billion in shortterm notes.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Labor M.P. Dies in Britain; Party in 3Seat Minority
description: LONDON, May 4 (AP)A Labor member of Parliament collapsed at the House of Commons today and died after being rushed to a hospital.

title: MINORITY BUSINESS OUTLINES ITS CASE
description: Well over 900 minorityowned and operated supplier companies in the metropolitan area were represented yesterday at the second annual Business Opportunity Fair sponsored by the New York/New Jersey Minority Purchasing Council and the Purchasing Management Associations of New York and New Jersey.

title: Thruway Revenues Rise
description: ALBANY, May 4 (UPI)The Thomas E. Dewey Thruway Authority said yesterday that revenues during the first three months of 1976 were up 11.7 percent over the previous year. The authority said the increased revenues, which totaled $26,404,476 in the first quarter, primarily resulted from toll increases instituted last summer. Operating and other expenses totaled $19,775,578, up 11.9 percent, said Gerald Cummins, chairman of the authority.

title: Kennecott Copper
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation's longterm debt rose to $416 million from $281 mil lion a year earlier, Frank R. Milliken, president, told shareholders yesterday.

title: $1,776 a Week for Life Won by Shipping Cleric
description: McAFEE, May 4A 54yearold shipping clerk who said he had told his boss I'm going to win did just that today, taking the third and final grand prize of New Jersey's 1776 Instant Lottery, which will pay him $1,776 a week for life. The winner, Henry Smykowski of Parsippany, said he had assured his employer, the Bloomfield Manufacturing Company in Fairfield, that he would win and I won't be in tomorrow.

title: Trenton Tonics
description: TRENTON, May 4In what may eventually be a boon to home building in the state, Attorney General William F. Hyland ruled today that variableinterestrate mortgages were legal.

title: Church Seeks to Get Name Off Ballot in Connecticut
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, will not campaign in Connecticut and will try to have his name removed from the May 11 ballot, a spokesman said today.

title: Yanks Turn Back Angels, 21 On White, Chambliss Homers
description: ANAHEIM, Calif. May 4Sixthinning homers by Roy White and Chris Chambliss gave the Yankees a 21 victory over the California Angels tonight in a moment of reversion to old ways from the new onfield personality Manager Billy Martin has imposed on the team in less than a year.

title: Utah Man Plans to Press For Hughes Inheritance
description: WILLARD, Utah, May 4Melvin Dummar said today that he intended to press for the onesixteenth share of the $1.5 billion estate of Howard R. Hughes that is allotted to him in a purported will that turned up in Salt Lake City last week.

title: Mexico, in Shift, Plans to Join OilExporting Nations Group
description: MEXICO CITY, May 4 (AP)Mexico in a sudden change in its oil policy, announced today that it plans to join the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the first opportunity.

title: Flyers Win, Lead Series by 31
description: BOSTON, May 4The bell began to toll for the Boston Bruins tonight as they lost their third game in a row to the Philadelphia Flyers after having won the opener of the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup hockey semifinal series. The score was 42.

title: Clements Leads by Stroke
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., May 4 (AP)John Clements of Hilton Head Island, S. C., carded a par 72 today to take a onestroke lead in the threeday, 28th annual 54hole strokeplay championship of the Western Senior Golf Association being played here on two local courses. A total of 180 seniors from 29 states are participating in the event on the Arcadia Shores and Dunes Club courses.

title: Councilmen Seeking Bigger School Voice
description: Members of the New York City Council's Finance Committee indicated yesterday that for the first time since the publicschool system was decentralized six years ago they intended to assert their authority to make significant changes in priorities for spending tax dollars on education.

title: Bright Handpainted Wisps
description: It's hard to say whether the first thing you notice about the fashions now on display at Julie is the depth of their color or the vividness of their pattern.

title: Pope Names New L.I. Bishop and 3 Newark Auxiliaries
description: CHICAGO, May 4The Most Rev. John R. McGann, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diccese of Rockville Centre, ??? since 1971, was formally named today to succeed Bishop Walter P. Kellenberg upon his ??? on June 3.

title: Reagan Conclusion
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Wednesday, May 5Ronald Reagan said today that his apparent victory in the Indiana primary yesterday had freed him of the accusation that he was a regional candidate who could win only in Southern and Western states.

title: Carey Names Panel to Find Out Why Bank Fell 30% Short Last Year, Unbalancing Budget
description: ALBANY. May 4Governor Carey today created a task force to investigate why receipts from the state's new bank tax fell 30 percent short last year, throwing the budget out of balance to the surprise and dismay of state fiscal aides.

title: ExPentagon Chief Assails Ford Pressure on Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the Ford Administration was undermining American moral support for Israel by putting undue pressure on it to make concessions to the Arabs.

title: Market Place
description: Alaska, which already taxes petroleum companies more heavily than most states, is considering several new oil taxes.

title: Congress Clears Measure To Revive Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Congress sent to President Ford today legislation to revive the Federal Election Commission and, in the process, to clear the way for restoration of primary subsidies to Presidential candidates.

title: Advertising
description: Coming away from the annual meeting of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau one has the feeling that there is no gathering of advertisers anywhere, anytime at which there isn't a representative of the bureau making a pitch for newspapers.

title: 1,440 VOTERS POLLED IN INDIANA SURVEY
description: The New York Times and CBS News polled 1,440 Indiana voters yesterday as they left the polling places. Of these, 634 were Republicans and 806 were Democrats.

title: Issues in Building Strike
description: Local 32B of the Service Employees Union, representing 20,000 superintendents, handymen, elevator operators, porters, mechanics and guards in 4,000 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. The Realty Advisory Board represents the building owners.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: IN GOOD HANDS: The son of Viktorya and Frederick Pouy at hospital in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday. Mrs. Pouy, the former Viktorya Fyodorova, is the daughter of Zoya Fyodorova, the Russian actress and Jackson R. Tate, stationed in Moscow during the Second World War. Mrs. Pouy came to America in 1975 to see her father whom she had never seen.

title: KISSINGER WARNS ON TRADE TALKS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 4 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger cautioned thirdworld nations today against using bloc: economic power to narrow the economic gap between rich and poor countries. At the same time he pledged American cooperation in their development efforts.

title: New RCA Head Sees Gain After 2Year Drop in Profit
description: After two consecutive years in which net income of the RCA Corporation fell. Anthony L. Conrad, the new chief executive officer, told the 800 stockholders yesterday that every major part of RCA is moving ahead. The 53yearold executive conducted his first annual meeting since taking over last Nov. 5 from Robert W. Sarnoff, who resigned as chairman effective Dec. 31. Stockholders had to cross picket lines set up at 30 Rockefeller Plaza by members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, who have been on strike since April 1.

title: Green Pepper Fritters
description: 2 medium size firm green peppers

title: REAGAN LEADING FORD IN INDIANA AND IS WINNER IN GEORGIA RACE; CARTER IS VICTOR IN BOTH STATES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 4Ronald Reagan maintained a steady but narrow lead tonight over President Ford in the Indiana Republican Presidential primary.

title: Bill Embodying Divorce Law Changes Is Sent to the Floor of Albany Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 4The Assembly Judiciary Committee, by a 15to4 vote, today cleared for floor action a bill embcdying changes in the state's divorce law that would require equitable distribution of the property of a marriage and for the first time make it possible for either party to pay alimony.

title: People in Sports
description: Somewhere above the Shea Stadium pitcher's mound, Chuck Wepner will battle Andre the Giant as a prelude to a closedcircuit showing of the Muhammad AliAntonio Inoki match from Tokyo.

title: HOUSE PANEL PACKS BILL TO CUT JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The House Education and Labor Committee, after sharp debate, voted today. 25 to 10, to approve a bill designed to cut the nation's jobless rate by more that half in the next four years.

description: Memorial Seruires

title: $1,776 a Week for Life Won by Jersey Clerk
description: McAFEE, N. J., May 4 A 54yearold shipping clerk who said he had told his boss I'm going to wilt did just that today, taking the third and final grand prize of New Jersey's 1776 Instant Lottery, which will pay him $1,776 a week for life.

title: Levi and Aides to Confer
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Attorney General Edward H. Levi and 36 other Justice Department officials will hold a threeday policy conference this week at the National Park Service's retreat at Big Meadows, Va., it was announced today. They will discuss such topic as management problems, a proposed statistical information system, freedom of information and privacy and relationships with United States attorneys.

title: Bail Cut for Reilly, Charged With Murdering Mother
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., May 4Peter A. Reilly won one point and lost several others as initial proceedings got under way today to try him again for the murder of his mother almost thte'e years ago.

title: Pact Sought in Dumping Of Foreign Autos in U.S
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Treasury Department halted its investigation of dumping by foreign car manufacturers in the United States tonight and said that although dumping existed, it would seek an amicable solution with the companies involved rather than impose penalty duties.

title: INOUIRIES ON C.I.A ROCKEFELLER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3Vice President Rockefeller criticized today the recently concluded Congressional investigations of the Federal intelligence agencies for having exposed American foreign intelligence operations to the world, to the great profit of potential enemies and the grave distress of foreign friends.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HARVEST TIME In a free Bicentennial fair, the city today is displaying the skills of the elderly in arts, crafts and foods representing 150 centers for persons 60 years old and over, with continuous entertainment running from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. The midtown site is Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library on Avenue of the Americas between 40th and 42nd Streets.

title: News Summary and Index
description: James R. Schlesinger, the former Defense Secretary, said in a Washington speech that the Ford Administration was undermining American moral support for Israel by undue pressure for Israeli concessions to the Arabs. He said that Israel, like South Vietnam in 197273, was being blamed for failure to make progress toward a settlement. Without mentioning Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, he seemed to be criticizing his negotiating tactics. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: EXRADICES CASE DECIDED IN FRANCE
description: AMIENS, France, may 4Ten thousand French people had written letters declaring their faith in a former revolutionary who was serving a life sentence as a convicted murderer, and his lawyers had won him a new trial on a technicality. Tonight he was cleared.

title: South Africa Plans Sweeping Measure To Tighten Security
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, May 4 (AP)Plans for sweeping new powers to reinforce South Africa's security laws were announced today. They would enable the Government to hold suspects up to a year without trial or contact with lawyers.

title: RHODESIANS DECRY NAMING OF CHIEFS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 4Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's new initiative of bringing four African chiefs into his Cabinet has met with widespread opposition and appears unlikely to aid a political settlement of the Rhodesian crisis.

title: Reserve Mining Fined $1 Million In Pollution Case
description: ST. PAUL, May 4 (AP)The Reserve Mining Company was ordered today to pay fines totaling more than $1 million for polluting Lake Superior.

title: A Zoo Of Furs, All Fake
description: The woman who wears her snow leopard coat this winter had probably better get a sign explaining it's a real fake. Manmade furs have gotten to be such duplicates of the real thing that the wearer may find herself defending the coat against the wrath of conservationists.

title: Carter Says Reagan Would Be A Divisive Figure for G.O.P.
description: ATLANTA, May 4  Jimmy Carter, with another generally successful round of primary elections behind him, mused tonight on the strengths and weaknesses of the two Republican Presidential contenders, President Ford and Ronald Reagan.

title: U.S. JURY WEIGHING GOV. MOORE CHARGE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 4The Federal extortion case against Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr went to the jury here tonight.

title: LANDLORDS UNITE ON COMMON GOALS
description: While New York City's real estate industry has found it difficult to unite behind any common goals In Its battles with the city and state governments, or in its negotiations with labor unions, new economic realities are changing the industry's outI look.

title: 23 Persons Killed As 2 Trains Collide In the Netherlands
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 4 (AP)The Rhine Express bound for Germany and Austria and a Dutch committer train crashed head en during the morning rush hour today, killing 23 persons and seriously injuring five, authorities reported.

title: Italy's Christian Democrats Pin Hope On Voters Fear of Communist Rule
description: ROME, May 4A Roman woman in her late 40's said the other day that she had voted for the Communist party here for years but would not do so in the elections next month because they might win.

title: For American Tourists, Cooking Schools in Europe
description: A cook's tour is hardly what it used to be. Once relegated to the tourist itineraries arranged by the travel agents Thomas Cook & Son, the phrase now has more pertinence when applied to the everincreasing number Americans who go abroad each summer to take cooking lessons in one glamorous locale or another.

title: Christopher Columbus Making Return Trip
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 4Christopher Columbus is corning to America this summer.

title: Plane Skids in Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 4 (AP)A Turkish plane with 71 passengers and crew aboard skidded off the runway on landing at Munich's Riem Airport today and bogged down in rainsoaked ground, a flight control spokesman reported. Those aboard the Boeing 707, on a regular flight from Istanbul, escaped without injury, he said.

title: Jaycees: Gridiron to Grid
description: The year the New York football Giants move to New Jersey the New Jersey Junior Chamber of Commerce is moving to Pennsylvania and auto racing.

title: BUILDING STRIKE SPREAD BY UNION; NO PROGRESS SEEN
description: The strike of building service employees, centered primarily in Manhattan on the first day, spread to many apartment houses in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday with no signs of an early settlement.

title: Shareholders Tumultuous At White Motor's Meeting
description: CLEVELAND, May 4 (UPI)The White Motor Corporation's directors got an early adjournment of a tumultuous shareholders' meeting today in the wake of White Consolidated Industries' lastminute cancellation of a planned merger between the companies. Rumors spread that White Motor's chairman. Semon E. Knudsen, former president of the Ford Motor Company was on his way out. The truck manufacturing concern was $52 million delinquent in payments to its suppliers as of March 12.

title: Building Union Had Rough Beginning
description: Thomas G. Young, who is vice president of striking Local 32B, was one of the original 26 people who founded the union in 1934. When Mr. Young, who is now 70 years old, was discharged from a job at 501 Seventh Avenue for organizing, his fellow workers walked out to support him, and the union was under way.

title: About Real Estate
description: Five years ago the trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company set out to sell the company's extensive midManhattan realestate holdings, sometimes called the Park Avenue properties. They included both the land and buildings of the Commodore, Barclay, Biltmore and Roosevelt Hotels. They also included the land under many other buildings. Title to the buildings themselves usually is held by a longterm lessee, generally the major tenant.

title: REPORTERS CHIDED ON BUSINESS NEWS
description: The two major complaints by businessmen about financialnews reporting are that many reporters are out to get business and that some of the many reporters are over their heads when reporting business news, Frederic W. West Jr., president of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, told members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: SOVIET INCREASES U.S. GRAIN ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Soviet Union has bought an additional 625,000 metric tons of American corn and wheat, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Nuggets Top Nets By 127121
description: DENVER, May 4The Denver Nuggets survived a New York zone press and a whirlwind named Julius Erving tonight to gain a 127121 victory over the Nets and even the American Basketball Association championship series at one game apiece.

title: Critic's Notebook: Copyright Bill Tries Publishers
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 4 The weather has improved, spirits are risible and wit rattled in its scabbard like a thirsty quill this morning, on the third day of deliberations by the Association of American Publishers at its annual rainedon convention.

title: UDALL IN MICHIGAN ON INTENSE DRIVE
description: DETROIT, May 4Representative Morris K. Udall began here today what was planned as a twoweek campaign blitz that he said would give him a very good chance, as a progressive candidate in a state with a long liberal tradition, to defeat Jimmy Carter oneonone.

title: Morris and Rowe Join A.P. Directors Board
description: William S. Morris 3d, president of Morris Communications Corporation of Augusta, Ga., and Charles S. Rowe, editor, managing editor and copublisher of The Free LanceStar of Fredericksburg, Va., have been elected to The Associated Press board of directors.

title: Beirut Dispute Over Syrians May Halt Vote Again
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4A growing dispute over Syria's role in Lebanon makes it likely that the election of a new president tentatively set for Saturday, will have to be postponed a second time. It was originally scheduled for last Saturday.

title: ROBERT FARRAND, 67, PUBLISHING OFFICIAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Robert Kitchel Farrand, a former vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, died of a heart attack last night in his home in Potamac, Md. He was 67 year olld.

title: New Books
description: A Mantis Carol, by Laurens van der Post (Morrow, $6.95). The role of the praying mantis in the life of the African bushman.

title: NEW RULES SOUGHT ON DAYCARE PLAN
description: ALBANY, May 4New regulations to allow about threequarters of the families recently ruled inelgible for free public day care in New York City to keep using the service by paying up to $40 a week was proposed today by New York State.

title: Bridge:
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 4The United States team moved into the lead in the world team championship here this afternoon by crushing Hong Kong, which has yet to win a match, by 19 victory points to 1.

title: FRANCISCO GARCIA, SPANISH PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Francisco Garcia Lorca, retired professor of Spanish and younger brother of the late Federico Garcia Lorca, the poet, died Saturday at his home in Madrid. He was 72 years old.

title: BUILDING STRIKE SPREAD BY UNION; NO PROGRESS SEEN
description: The strike of building service employees, centered primarily in Manhattan on the first day, spread to many apartment houses in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday with no signs of an early settlement.

title: Czech Duck Yields Gold
description: PRAGUE, (AP)A Czechoslovak farm worker killed a duck she had been feeding for some weeks for Sunday dinner. When emptying its stomach she saw a curious goldishcolored piece, which she put into her pocket. A trip to the local apothecary confirmed she had enough gold for a ring.

title: Lewis R. Taylor Jr. Dies; Retired Cartoonist Was 67
description: Lewis Randolph Taylor Jr., a former cartoonist and staff artist for Associated Press Features in New York, died Monday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 67 years old.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Allen Grp

title: Politics of Retribution
description: In 1968, the right wing of the Republican Party led by Senators Barry Goldwater of Arizona and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina made possible the nomination of Richard Nixon because he seemed to be the best bet to win the election. In making this expedient judgment, the right wing rejected its own sentimental and ideological favorite, Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: Craft. Expected to Endure 8 Million Years, to Check Planet's Slight Shifts
description: A sparkling golf ball with a heart of solid brass was launched into orbit yesterday to serve as a laserreflecting beacon to record subtle movements of the earth.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was erroneously reported in The New York Times yesterday that the Giant food chain was one of two that had refused to guarantee that it would continue to mark prices on individual food items. The chains that refused to make such a guarantee were Lucky Stores Inc, of California and WinnDixie.

title: Music Reaches Out to Children
description: The West End Little Symphony, under the direction of Eugene R. Gamiel, played at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center yesterday for handicapped children from 100 Manhattan school districts. In addition to the Thunderbird American Dancers, the youngsters were treated to pop, jazz and a dash of classical music. Obviously, they seemed to enjoy the experience.

title: SAMUEL H. WANG, SHIP OPERATOR, 59
description: Samuel H. Wang, shipping executive and philanthropist, died Sunday of cancer, at his home in Great Neck, L. I. He was 59 years old.

title: Thomas McDermott Dies; Broadcast Ad Executive
description: Thomas J. McDermott, for 39 years a broadcast advertising executive with N. W. Ayer ABH International, an advertising agency, died Saturday at his home in Forked River, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue Arrives
description: What is one to say about the new Alan Jay Lerner and Leonard Bernstein musical 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, which opened at the Mark Hellinger Theater last night? Bting back Rex! Possibly? Or if this is meant as a Bicentennial offering  and it is, as the historically and topographically inclined will realize, about the White House  maybe we should wait for the Tricentennial.

title: Britain Says 9 Countries Violate Rhodesia Sanctions
description: LONDON, May 4 (Reuters)In a complaint to the United Nations, Britain has said nine countries, including some in Europe and in Africa, were involved in the breaking of sanctions against Rhodesia by the airline Affretair, the House of Lords was told today.

title: TwoYear Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Treasury Department sold today $2 billion of twoyear notes at an average return of 6.61 percent. The department received $4.4 billion of tenders for the notes, which will carry a coupon interest rate of 6 percent. Accepted tenders included 61 percent of the bids at the highest yield.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: 92 Small Bus Companies May Seek to Cut Services
description: TRENTON, May 4Ninetytwo small bus companies that have formed an association announced today that they might try to cut some service.

title: Oil Spill in Houston Channel
description: HOUSTON, May 4 (Reuters) A 290foot barge broke apart and sank in the Houston Ship Channel today, spilling nearly 200,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil into Galveston Bay at the end of the channel. The resulting oil slick, two and onehalf miles long and a mile wide, forced officials to close the channel, a canal that was about 50 miles from Houston to the bay.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: WASHINGTON. May 4Shrewd consumers in the New York area can save substantial sums of money by carefully choosing their banks, according to data recently compiled by the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Helen Keller Center Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) A national center to rehabilitate persons who are both deaf and blind would be named after Helen Keller under a bill passed by the House yesterday. The center, which was created under a 1973 act, is in Sands Point, N.Y.

title: Pacific Closing Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Commodities Futures Trading Commission announced today that it was seeking to close the Pacific Commodities Exchange because volume had dwindled so much the exchange had become unable to conduct proper surveillance and otherwise function as a market. The San, Francisco Exchange, which began operations in 1972, had contracts in cattle, coconut oil, eggs, palm oil and silver. It is the smallest of the nation's 14 registered commodities exchanges.

title: Ford Aides See More Setbacks; Morton is Certain of a Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, May 4President Ford's campaign leaders said tonight that his setback in the latest prmaries may be only part of a series of reversals this month.

title: ARDSLEY DONNELLY, EXDELEHANTY HEAD
description: Ardsley J. Donnelly, former president and chairman of the Delehanty Institute, died Monday in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Bronxville and Fort Lauderdale. Fla.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 5 (UPI)The Control Data Corporation paid more than $2 million to greatly underpaid government employees in foreign countries, the concern disclosed today at its annual meeting.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5Egypt and the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization, after nine months of bitterly strained relations, have reached a broad understanding for cooperation in Lebanon and on the international scene, according to informed Arab officials.

description: JERSEY CITY, May 5Asked by a legislative committee today why some bus companies were able to survive financially while others needed state subsidies, James LeFante, the head of an association of independent bus lines, held up his two calloused hands. Look at these hands, he said. We work for what we get.

title: A Whooping Crane Chick
description: LAUREL, Md., May 5 (UPI)A wnooping crane chick was hatched today at the Government wildlife center here, said Dr: Cameron Kepler, who heads the program at Patuxent Wildlife Research Center to save the endangered species. The male chick expands the whoopers world population to 85. It the chick survives, he will be the first whooper successfully hatched and grown from parents raked in captivity.

[companion dog] degree, so we decided our dachshund would go to obedience school and have a chance to earn one, too, said Mrs. Quimby.

Grossi, the powerful New Jersey Democrat who resignid last February as chairman of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J., after having been stricken with what was described as a massive heart attack. He was 70 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment for more than a decade.

title: Newsmen Score C.I.A. Policy
description: ST. LOUIS, May 5 (UPI)The National Conference of Editorial Writers said today that it opposes the Central Inligence Agency's clandestine use of journalists and called on the agency to release the names of newsmen in its employ. A statement released by John J. Zakarian, conference president and an editorial writer for The St. Louis PostDispatch, said the group opposes the clandestine employment of American and foreign journalists by the C.I.A. and urges that all such relationships be terminated immediately.

description: BOSTON, May 5 (UPI)Joseph McKenna has been suspended from riding at Suffolk Downs for 60 days after track stewards ruled the jockey had an unsatisfactory ride last Sunday.

title: Results in Alabama Show Wallace Strength Fading
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 5 The Democratic Presidential primary held yesterday in Alabama was only halfdecided today, but that in itself seemed proof enough that Gov. George C. Wallace's political strength was eroding not only nationally but also in his home state.

description: Aline Lewis Goldstone, a poet, died Monday at her home at 1172 Park Avenue. She was 97 years old.

title: British Cheer
description: Not for a long time has there been good economic news out of Britain. The pay deal between the Trades Union Congress and Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey represents a major triumph for financial good sense, and brightens the prospect for genuine reversal of Britain's economic decline.

title: Music: Mozart Series
description: Exactly at the midway point in his Mozart concerto series, Daniel Barenboim took himself and the English Chamber Orchestra through three fullscale works last night in Carnegie Hall. One says fullscale because none of the juvenile concertos were on the program. There was, however, No. 9 in E flat (K.271), the work that marks the break between Mozart's innocence and full maturity.

title: George Mintzer, Lawyer, Dies; Arbiter of Industrial Disputes
description: George J. Mintzer, a lawyer who was highly regarded by labor and industry as an impartial arbitrator over the last 38 years, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home at 275 Central Park West. He was 77 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, May 5The defeat of Representative Ray J. Madden yesterday in the Indiana Democratic primary has made Representative James J. Delaney, a 75yearold Queens Democrat, the leading contender to be chairman of the House Rules Committee when the next Congress convenes in January.

title: HOME OPERATOR GIVEN 10 YEARS
description: Frank Tripi Jr., a 68yearold operator of nursing homes, was sentenced yesterday in Buffalo to three consecutive prison terms totaling. 10 years.

title: Guerrillas Attack Moroccans
description: ALGIERS, May 5 (Reuters)Guerrillas of the Polisario Front independence movement killed 25 Moroccan soldiers and wounded 18 in an attack on a post guarding the phospate mines at Bu Craa in Western Sahara, The Algerian news agency A.P.S. reported today. No Polisario losses were given.

title: RICHARD O. HERMAN
description: Richard O. Herman, an insurance salesman, died Monday while at work in San Francisco. He was 63 years old and lived in that city.

title: Hofstra Beats Post
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 5 Bob Hiller scored four goals as Hofstra defeated C. W. Post, 139, in lacrosse today. It was the Dutchmen's seventh victory against four losses; Post is 57.

title: Rhodesia Is Extending Military Service to Meet Threat of Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 5 Rhodesia extended the length of service for its armed forces today from 12 months to 18 months to combat an upsurge in guerrilla activity.

description: Officials of foreign auto makers that were accused of illegal dumping of cars in the United States expressed surprise and relief yesterday at a Treasury Department announcement Tuesday that it was prepared to discontinue its investigation if assurances were received that would midgate price differentials between home market and export sales.

title: Angolans Said to Split on a Cuban Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Strains have reportedly developed in the Angolan leadership over proposals for a gradual withdrawal of 15,000 Cuban troops in the country, a truce with South Africa and a reopening of Angolas to Western business interests.

description: BRUSSELS, May 5 (UPI)Anderlecht, inspired by its Dutch World Cup winger, Robbie Rensenbrink, rallied today to defeat West Ham United, 42, and win the European Cup Winners soccer cup in sparkling style.

description: CocaCola will be starting a new advertising campaign on May 11 as most people watching prime time network television that night will see.

title: 'Breakheart Pass' Is Good Fun Film
description: Either Charles Bronson's movies are getting better or my resistance has worn out. Last year a string of unremarkable but immensely popular Bronson movies was suddenly made interesting with the appearance of "Hard Times," a terse, tough, unsentimental melodrama directed by Walter Hill.This year we have "Breakheart Pass," a western written by Alistair MacLean and directed by Tom Gries. In between there have been other forgettable items. Though "Breakheart Pass" is not "The Great Train Robbery," it's a highly efficient entertainment of the sort sometimes labeled escapist, a general use of the word that doesn't recognize who's doing the escaping or what's being escaped from. For someone working in a Manhattan laundry, The New York Review of Books could be a month in the country."Breakheart Pass," which opened yesterday at the Guild and other theaters, is a western that spends a lot of its time inside a train, a fine smoky antique snaking its way through the snowy mountains of Utah to a date with a destiny that includes outlaws and angry Indians. The time is the virtually mythical 1870's (as someone once wrote, all westerns are set in 1870) and the MacLean story is about gunrunning and a cache of gold.Time and place require that "Breakheart Pass" be described as a western, though it also contains a few elements that might have been suggested by a close reading of "Murder on the Orient Express." Purists may object to this crossbreeding of genres, but the result is good fun with some spectacular action footage directed by Yakima Canutt, the Hollywood stunt genius who is still playing with dynamite and rolling entire trains off trestles in his 81st year.The train on which most of the action is set is a special being sent to the relief of a remote mountain fort in the grip of a diphtheria epidemic. On board are a detachment of soldiers, a governor, the daughter of the fort's commander (didn't they ever have sons?), an old-timey sort of Western sheriff (played by Ben Johnson), the train's cook, who's no better than he cooks (played by Archie Moore) and a mysterious outlaw, a former university lecturer in medicine who's wanted for everything, arson and murder and probably parking tickets.This fellow, played by Mr. Bronson, seems already to have passed through his own time into history. The great physique is no longer young, but it is more powerful than ever, as if transfused by age with some kind of supervigor that affects brain as well as brawn. Needless to say, he is the film's hero-figure, but how he assumes the role is the point of the screenplay's twists that owe more to Agatha Christie than to Zane Grey.Mr. Gries, who some years ago directed "Will Penny," a very different kind of western that attempted to recreate a feel for frontier time and place, doesn't permit these mystery-story elements to slow down the film's physical action. "Breakheart Pass" moves, therefore it is.The movie is rated PG, in reference, I suppose, to a couple of fight scenes, and one murder that might possibly upset a very young child who's never had a chance to watch prime-time TV.

title: East Siders Begin Drive To Block LeFrak Project
description: Three hundred East Side residents who do not want Samuel J. LeFrak, the city's biggest private landlord, to construct a 29story luxury apartment building in their area, began a drive last night to preserve the quality of their neighborhood.

title: Books of The Times
description: On more than one occasion in Fort Apache police officers running up a fire escape in the South Bronx to confront an armed suspect on the roof of a building have noticed that quite a few people were looking out of their windows at the show. It was better than television. The man or men on the roof might be suspected of murder, felonious assault, robbery, rape or arson. When the police finally cornered them, as they often did, it was a question of who would be shot and who would survive, but some of those at the windows did not seem to care. For them, it was an entertainment.

description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)President Ford signed a $17.5 billion twoyear extension of the Federal Highway Assistance Act today, saying it would provide many, many thousands of jobs.

Louise Roberts, currently of the Clark Center and permanently among the friends and supporters of dancers and choreographers, was honored for her contributions to the field by an enjoyably mixed program that included both modern dance and ballet.

I., May 5Doug Barrow of Bayside, Queens, upset fifthseeded Stanley Matthews of England, 76, 64, in the opening round of the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championships today at the Roosevelt Field Tennis Club. description: DALLAS, May 5 (UPI)Bjorn Borg finally wore down Eddie Dibbs tonight and gained a 36, 63, 64, 62 victory to move into the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Engelhard Minerals to Double New York Headquarters Size
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, with 500 New York City employees, announced yesterday that it was planning a major expansion of its headquarters here and would soon sign a 25year lease for 155,000 square feet of space in the McGrawHill Building in Rockefeller Center.

title: Salvaging Asset of Incumbency
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The central asset of President Fond's candidacy, his White House incumbency, appears to have been neutralized and perhaps ravaged by four successive losses to Ronald Reagan in Republican primanes. He's literally squandered an immense advantage, a distraught Ford campaign official said today.

title: I. M. F. GOLD SALE PLANNED JUNE 2
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The International Monetary Fund will sell 780.000 ounces of gold at its first auction of gold, scheduled for June 2, it was reliably reported today.

title: Senate Endorses Detente Based on U.S. Arms Might
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)The Senate today adopted a resolution favoring continuation of dtente with the Soviet Union based on unchallengable United States military strength.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The suspect in the killing of a Chatham Township architect by a stray bullet last Independence Day pleaded guilty in Superior Court in Morristown to obstructing the inquiry into the incident.

title: 11 Jersey Areas Ordered To Zone for Less Affluent
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., May 5The State Superior Court struck down today as unconstitutional the zoning ordinances of 11 Middlesex County imunicipalities and ordered the communities to make plans immediately providing a total of 18,697 low and moderateincome housing units by 1985.

title: Bombs Explode in Panama
description: PANAMA, May 5 (Reuters) Five homemade bombs exploded here today in widely separated districts. The police said there had been no reports of injuries or major damage. They had no clue as to who planted the bombs or whether there was any political motive.

title: The Sunshine Boys
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Barry GoldWater and Nelson Rockefellerthose implacable foes of the sixtieshave become the Sunshine Boys of American politics.

title: Indiana's Verdict
description: For the first time in many months it becomes distinctly possible to envisage the Republican Party denying its nomination to President Ford. Although Ronald Reagan won narrowly in Indiana, the pattern of his victory makes the outlook ominous for the President in most of the remaining primaries.

title: Engelhard Minerals to Double New York Headquarters Size
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, with 500 New York City employees, announced yesterday that it was planning a major expansion of its headquarters here and would soon sign a 25year lease for 155.000 square feet of space in the McGrawHill Building in Rockefeller Center.

title: People in Sports
description: A practice session has proved costly to the Cleveland Cavaliers. Jim Chones, their center, broke the little toe on his right foot and will miss the first game in Boston tonight in the Eastern Conference final of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: A Test of Faith
description: BOSTON, May 5If angels were to govern men, James Madison wrote, no controls on government would be necessary; but in a nonangelicrworld there had to be safeguards against abuse of power. On that theory rose the American constitutional system: government limited by law and divided among branches meant to watch each other.

title: Gov. Moore Cleared At Extortion Trial
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 5Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia and his former top aide were acquitted by a Federal jury today of charges that they had conspired to extort $25,000 from a businessman who was seeking a slate bank charter.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BOSTON (AlPlaced Gene Michael, Infielder, on waivers.

title: City Retail Sales Up Only 3.3%
description: April sales of New York City's largest department stores, which had been expected to reflect the benefits of a later Easter this year, registered a disappointing 3.3 percent advance from the yearearlier level. This was less than the inflation rate in general merchandise.

title: ISRAELIS WOUND 2 IN THE WEST BANK
description: TEL AVIV, May 5 (AP)Israeli troops shot and wounded two Arabs in the West Bank of the Jordan today as Palestinians demonstrated against Israeli occupation of the territory conquered in the 1967 war.

title: Frances Jeller
description: Frances Jeller

title: Dance: Elite Syncopations Premiere
description: We were amuseq. Even Queen Victoria would have giggled at Tuesday night's premiere of Kenneth MacMillan's ragtime ballet, Elite Syncopations for the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. In the first place, the ballet is fun. In the second, there is in fact something Victorian about it. Mr. MacMillan takes a rather prim approach to the 12 rags most by Scott Joplinthat have been arranged into the ballet's score. American choreographers have been more exuberant about Joplin but this change of pace is not out of tune, so to speak, with ragtime's own adherence to form.

title: William V. Lawrence 2d Bronxville Realty Man, 71
description: William V. Lawrence 2d, a Westchester realestate executive whose grandfather was the developer of Bronxville, died Tuesday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: University of Bologna More Open Now Yet More Elitist
description: BOLOGNA, ItalyThe Via Zamboni in the center of this old city is the closest thing Europe's oldest university has to a campus.

title: CAREY PLAN ASKS CITY U. TUITIN
description: Governor Carey has called on the Board of Higher Education to approve a plan for the City University of New York that includes the same tuition charges as at the State University, a spokesman for the Governor said yesterday.

title: Building Strike
description: The tenants and resident owners of more than 2,500 apartment houses affected by the striking building employees union face mounting inconvenience and increasing health and safety hazards as the talks between the union and the landlords negotiating committee remain deadlocked. Mayor Beame has appropriately pointed to the serious hardship imposed by the walkout, particularly on the aged, disabled and sick. This warning appears at least to have led to an agreement by both parties to go back to the bargaining table today.

title: A Judge Judges Family Court
description: With mixed feelings, I tender my resignation as a judge of the Family Court, effective May 14, 1976. I plan to return to the practice of law. I also expect to be active in public affairs and politics as I have been in the past.

title: PRICES ARE LIFTED BY NATIONAL STEEL
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, yesterday joined the United States Steel Corporation and others, in raising prices for hotand coldrolled sheet and galvanized sheet, effective June 14.

title: PRESIDENT'S VETO OF DAY CARE BILL UPHELD IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Senate failed by three votes today to override President Ford's veto of the $125 million bill on child day care, and federally supported child care centers around the country are now in danger of closing. The vote was 60 to 34.

title: Cash Prices
description: Cash Prices

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to vote June 15 on the oil company divestiture bill approved last month by the antitrust sub committee. The subcommittee will hold one additional da of hearings later this month to take testimony from opponents of the bill.

title: Primary in Indiana Ended Mad den's 34Year Career
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 5The Indiana primary yesterday ended the 34year political career of the oldest member of Congress and portended a grueling contest for a United States Senate seat between the Republican and Democratic primary victors. The primary was the state's first involving a United States Senate seat and state offices in nearly half a century.

title: Orantes Is Victor
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 5 (AP)  Topseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain beat Chris Letcher of Australia, 60, 64, in the first round of the $50,000 Bavarian International tennis championships today.

title: L.I. CONCERN SUED BY SEC. ON STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Securities and Exchange Commission filed today its first suit against a company seeking to buy back its outstanding shares in order to return to private ownership.

title: Business Records
description: MARCELLA B. MEAD, Brothers Road, Poughquag, N.Y. Liabilities, $11,161; assets, $400. IRA E. GREIFF, 30 Waterside Plaza, N.Y. Liablities, $13.796; assets, $2,720.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent U.S. attempt to impose our ideals of government on a certain Southeast Asian nation came to grief. Economic, political and cultural conditions in that nation are not similar to our own. Neither the leading people in the U.S. Government nor the average U.S. citizen had anything in their experience qualifying them to judge what was right for the people of that nation.

title: INDIANA INDICATES GROWING 6.0.P. RIFT
description: If voters in the Republican primary in Indiana are any indication, the ideological cleavage between the conservative and moderate wings of the Republican Party is widening.

title: Panama Blocks 2 U.S. Vessels In Canal, Citing Illegal Fishing
description: PANAMA, May 5 (AP)A Panamanian gunboat has bottled up two United States tuna boats that are now in the Panama Canal Zone, and the Government has demanded that they pay fines of $100,000 each for, having illegally fished in Panamanian waters.

title: SAFETY BID MADE ON GAS TERMINALS
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5New York, New Jersey. Pennsylvania and Delaware petitioned the Federal Power Commission today to establish standards for selection of sites for liquefied natural gas terminals to minimize the perils of fire and explosion in heavily populated or industrialized areas.

title: Italy Curbs Trade
description: Italy has imposed strong curbs on foreignexchange dealings, including stiff deposit requirements for all imports except grain, to aid the ailing lira. Page 55.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Florence Podolsky looked out at the Hudson River from her ninthfloor apartment on the Palisades and reproached herself.

title: FORD IS REVIEWING STRATEGY IN LIGHT OF REAGAN'S GAINS
description: President Ford ordered a major review of his campaign strategy yesterday after four straight primary losses to Ronald Reaganthe most damaging series of electoral reversals suffered by an incumbent President since William Howard Taft lost 12 primaries to Theodore Roosevelt in 1912.

title: Convention Center
description: The Regional Plan Association is correct in saying that new construction could turn Times Square around, but a convention center is the wrong construction. The longplanned Portman Hotel is the kind of new building the area needs, not a threesquareblock monolith, which is what even the bestdesigned convention center will be. The variety of shops, restaurants and new theaters in the hotel plan would infuse the right mixed activities into the area, in the kind of lively building complex that would enhance rather than deaden the street and its surroundings. The idea is to upgrade Times Square, not destroy it.

title: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities
description: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities

title: 11 Jersey Areas Ordered To Zone for Less Affluent
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 5The State  Superior Court struck down today as unconstitutional the zoning ordinances of 11 Middlesex County municipalities and ordered the communities to make plans immediately providing a total of 18,697 low and moderateincome housing units by 1985.

title: CAREY PLAN ASKS CITY U. TUITION
description: Governor Carey has called on the Board of Higher Education to approve a plan for the City University of New York that includes the same tuition charges as at the State University, a spokesman for the Governor said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Colleen Dewhurst broke into uncontroliableand ??? hearsedlaughter at Tuesday night's performance of Who's ??? of Virginia Woolf? Miss Dewhurst relates the incident to difficulties she has been having in giving op smoking while playing a role in which she must carry a cigarette in many scenes and to the impishness of her fellow troupers. They know I'm very tender these days, she said.

title: Music: Vigorous Pianist
description: Diane Walsh is a young pianist who has won a string of significant competitions, most recently the 1975 International Mozart Competition in Salzburg, Austria, and the 1975 Munich International Piano Competition in West Germany. The recital she played Tuesday night at Hunter College Playhouse was a brilliant demonstration of her prizewinning style, though it often fell short of persuading this listener that Miss Walsh had more on her mind than astonishing her audience. Her recital was part of the 15th Young Concert Artists Series.

title: PRESIDENT'S VETO OF DAY CARE BILL UPHELD IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Senate failed by three votes today to override President Ford's veto of the $125 million bill on child day care, and federally supported child care centers around the country are now in danger of closing. The vote was 60 to 34.

title: Parochial Students Face Bus Cutbacks
description: The New York City Board of Education is planning to halt free school bus service for 725 children who are transported from their homes in Queens to parochial schools in Nassau County and for 200 other pupils who are taken to parochial schools across borough lines.

title: Payoffs by PitneyBowes
description: PitneyBowes Inc. disclosed yesterday at its annual meeting in Stamford, Conn., that it made questionable payments" last year totaling $1.100.

title: New Jersey Will Increase Marlboro Hospital Security
description: FREEHOLD. N.J. May 5 (UPI) The state has agreed to increase security at the Marlboro State Hospital to prevent escapes by dangerous inmates.

title: Bureau Also Weighed Plan to Harass His Widow, Senate Study Reports
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation tried to smear the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. even after his death, treating him much like a Soviet agent, and had a plan to harass his widow as well, the staff of the Senate Select Committee and Intelligence Activities reported today.

title: Ford Delays Veto of Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) President Ford today delayed, for a day or two, his planned veto of a $1 billion foreign aid hill that would impose Congressional controls on foreign sales of military equipment, while opening trade with Vietnam for a trial period.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Because of some protests by riders of Its new kneeling buses, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided to remove a horizontal rail down the center aisle that was designed to be of assistance to passengers, particularly elderly ones. The rail to be removed is in the front part of the bus. A horizontal rail in the rear will be retained, as will all vertical posts.

title: Refugees in Lisbon Threaten Violence If Aid Isn't Revived
description: LISBON, May 5Portuguese colonial refugees threatened today to take violent action the Government did not restore food subsidies.

title: Tower Declines to Ran For Convention Delegate
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)  Senator John G. Tower of Texas announced today that he would not be a candidate for delegate to the Republican National Convention in Kansas City.

title: Dearly Precious Is Upset by Jerkens Filly
description: H. Allen Jerkens, the wellknown giantkiller among thoroughbred racing trainers, helped cut down another feared campaigner yesterday. The talented Long Islander from Islip saddled Bobeau's Tell Me All before the 27th running of the Comley Handicap at Belmont Park. Then he watched the 3yearold daughter of Cyane snap the 10race winning streak of Richard Baik's Dearly Precious and return $15.40 for a $2 win bet in the process.

title: PUBLIC HEARINGS SET ON BRIDGE TOLLS
description: The Federal Highway Administration has scheduled a public hearing Aug. 9 in New York City on the higher tolls in effect for a year at six bridges and tunnels of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey The place will be announced later.

title: NEW CHIEF NAMED BY DOW CHEMICAL
description: Zoltan Merszei was elected president and chief executive officer of the Dow Chemical Company yesterday after the annual meeting at Midland Mich. Mr. Merszei, who had been executive vice president, was also named chairman of the executive committee.

title: BOND PRICES SLIP AND THEN RECOVER
description: Fixedincome security prices declined modestly early yesterday and then recoveredall in light trading activity. The Federal Reserve helped steady prices by supplying some temporary tunas, but the dominant characteristics of the market were its lack of a pronounced sense of direction and its quietness.

title: Bicentennial Follies
description: When the People's Bicentennial Commission initially appeared to be taking aim at some of the more commercial and hypocritical manifestations of the nation's 200th anniversary observance, such puncturing of stuffedshirt chauvinism did not seem a bad idea. But the P.B.C.'s lofty proclamations about a reaffirmation of the principles of democracy have long since been superseded by sophomoric pranks.

title: Freeing Campaign Funds
description: After inexcusable delays that had more to do with politics than reform, Congress has sent President Ford its revised version of the campaign finance law. It is not an ideal piece of legislation; among other deficiencies, it reduces the independence of the Federal Election Commission, restoring too much control over the regulations to Congress itself  that is, to the body least equipped to deal objectively with the elective process.

title: FORD IS REVIEWING STRATEGY IN LIGHT OF REAGAN'S GAINS
description: President Ford ordered a major review of his campaign strategy yesterday after four straight primary losses to Ronald Reaganthe most damaging series of electoral reversals suffered by an incumbent President since William Howard Taft lost 12 primaries to Theodore Roosevelt in 1912.

title: U.N. Trade Talks Opened In Nairobi by 150 Nations
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 5Delegates from 150 countries began serious lobbying for their views of a new world economic order as the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development began its formal sessions today at the Kenyatta Conference Center.

title: EGYPT AND PLO. SAID TO RESOLVE POLICY QUARREL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5Egypt and the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization, after nine months of bitterly strained relations, have reached a broad understanding for cooperation in Lebanon and on the international scene, according to informed Arab officials.

title: Belmont Race Charts; Wednesday, May 5. Third day. Weather clear, track fast.
description: Belmont Race Charts;

title: Some Tenants in Strike Find It's Almost Fun
description: Lyn Revson runs the service elevator, Dick Tuck takes out the garbage, Joan Sovern lugs her own groceries and, somehow, in spite of the service employees strike, life on the East Side goes on.

title: A Misuse of U.S. Housing Aid?; New York Seeking to Divert Subsidies for Tenants
description: Like an unexpected and unwanted intruder, the city's fiscal plight has stepped between housing theory and reality. That is the clear implication of the city's request to the Federal Government to use the bulk of socalled Section 8 housing subsidies to offset as much as possible its own subsidy contribution to public housing for lowincome people.

description: N.Y. Ruzby Union

title: RUMSFELD DENIES CHANGE IN POLICY
description: The Ford Administration has not changed its policies in the Middle East and has not lessened its commitment to the security and survival of Israel, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said yesterday.

title: SMALL CRACK FOUND IN A B1 TAIL SECTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP), The Air Force told Congress today it had discovered a small crack in a test model of a tail section for the controversial B1 bomber.

title: Dodgers Take 11th Straight
description: All 1 feel is remorse for the Cubs pitching staff that has to play 81 games here every year, said Don Sutton, the winning pitcher, after his Los Angeles teammates had won their 11th straight game, 1412, yesterday. They did it by blasting a club recofd seven home runs against Chicago pitching in Wrigley Field.

title: Sets Beat Strings With Rally, 2721
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 5Virginia Wade decisively defeated Diane Fromholtz, 60, in the women's singles event tonight to rally the trailing New York Sets to a 2721 victory over the Los Angeles Strings in a World Team Tennis match at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Draper's 146 Paces Golf
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., May 5 (AP)Tom Draper of Boca Raton, Fla., who won the title in 1971 and 1973, moved into the lead today of the Western Senior Golf Association's 28th annual tournament with a 73 for a 36hole total of 146. Des Sullivan of Myrtle Beach had the day's best score, a oneunderpar 71, for a 147 total in the 54hole event.

title: Stage: Serenading Louie Harks Back
description: In Lanford Wilson's Serenading Louie, there are four old friends and two marriages each on the rocks. They get together and talk about the past (Everything was an event then. The smallest thing was an event).

title: LISBON REBUFFED ON AZORES PLAN
description: LISBON, May 5Portugal's proposal for broad political and administrative autonomy for the Azores was rejected today by the regional authorities of the islands as clearly unsatisfactory.

title: Innovative Firm Puts Its Imprint On Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5Just in front of Independence Hall, a new glass and granite pavilion houses the Liberty Bell. Across Independence Mall a new museum, called the Living History Center, has just been opened. And a 22story skyscraper, a powerful  form of glass and concrete, has Just been finished behind Independence Hall. That this group of buildings exists is not so special. What is unusual is that they, and a great many more structures scattered about the rest of the Philadelphia area, were designed by one of the nation's more innovative architectural firms.

description: Florence Podolsky looked out at the Hudson River from her ninthfloor apartment on the Palisades and reproached herself.

description: KROLL  Danny Lovingly remembered achingly missed.

title: 2 SIDES TO MEET IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: At the urging of Mayor Beame, negotiations for the striking building service employees and apartmenthouse (meetagreed yesterday to meet together today in an effort to resolve their bargaining istalemate.
