description: THERE will be a lot of lively action on the rock club scene Ills weekend, with talent ranging from such name attractions as John David Souther, Brian Auger, Eric Andersen and Thin Lizzy to such promising local bands as Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes, the Good Rats, the Miamis and the Heartbreakers.

title: Books of The Times
description: You don't have to be Jewish to appreciate the manifold talents of Cynthia Ozick, but as she herself would be the first to nod, it helps. Here is a Talmudic, an Old Testament mind. Law and tradition are her backseat drivers. The Second Commandment is as real to her as a red light: Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image, nor any manner of likeness, of any thing that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth below  And yet she guns her motor and roars across the intersection. She's an artist as well as a mind, a salesman of images and likenesses, full of stories, births of tellings, narratives and suspenses, turningpoints and palaces. foam of the sea mermen sewing, dragons pullulating out of quicksilver. the bloody and the demonic.

title: Carnegie to stress Quality and. Variety
description: Saying that he did not believe Carnegie Hall had ever had such a concentration of serious music before, Julius Bloom yesterday announced the leading attractions to aooear there next season.

title: U.N. Trade Unit Dates From 1964
description: The United Nations Conference Trade and Development was established in December 1964 at the insistence of poorer countries seeking a forum in which they could press their campaign for a more equitable share of the worlds resources.

title: Kreisky Warns on Detente
description: STRASBOURG, France, May 6 (Reuter)Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria says any changes in the relative military strength of the United States and the Soviet Union would alter the nature of EastWest dtente. He told delegates of 18 West European countries at the parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe here that dtente existed only because there was relative parity in the military might of the two superpowers.

title: It's Still the League of Women Voters
description: The League of Women Voters, which has accepted men as members in the last two years, considered dropping Women from its name yesterday, but finally voted overwhelmingly to keep the old name after deciding that it was more valuable than it was sexist.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A crewman testified that a California yachtsman had repeatedly refused to let three other crew members enter lifeboat in which the yachtsman sat with his wife and dog.

title: Louis Falco's Caravan Is a Dance of Life
description: It's about a character taking a path in life, Louis Falco said about his new work for the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. It's as if you see him coming in the door and out the door. In between he will pause and remember one aspect of his life.

title: F.B.I. Files Say Informer Got Data for Panther Raid
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported in internal memorandums that one of its informers was the sole source of information that Ied to the 1969 Chicago raid in which Black Panther Fred Hampton was killed.

title: Haves, Never a Winner, Leads With a 66
description: DALLAS, May 6 (AP) Mark Hayes, often a challenger but never a winner, lopped five shots off par for a 66 today and a onestroke lead in the first round of the $200,000 Byron Nelson golf tournament.

title: Advertising
description: Soaring ???quarter television prices are not only driving agencies and their clients up the wall, they are also forcing far more serious consideration of other media than in the past.

title: Mac Kinnon At Sweeney's
description: Raun MacKinnon, who is opening for Marc Allen Trujillo at Reno Sweeney's through Sunday, overshadows the star performer rather decisively. Mr. Trujillo, a pop singer with a narrow emotional range and a somewhat thin voice, has a recently negotiated recording contract to his credit. Miss MacKinnon has a repertory that encompasses pop, folk ballads, gospel, and jazz scatting, a lessismore backing trio with a great deal of personality, an innately musical ability to express herself vocally, and, as yet, no recording contract.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON  Business, lahor, Congress and the Administration are moving toward an electionyear battle over legislation dealing with the minimum wage.

title: Vilas and Stockton Advance
description: DALLAS, May 6Guillermo Vilas did it the easy way: he changed a shirt and changed the course of his match. Dick Stockton did it the hard way; he changed his pace and almost got shortchanged.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: Transit Agency Still Pays Banned LivingCost Raises
description: The Transit Authority is continuing to pay a costofliving raise to its 34,000 unionized workers despite a ruling from the State Attorney General that such payments are in violation of the state's wage freeze law.

title: Climb Was Largest Since OctoberThe Industrial Sector Up Moderately
description: WASHINGTON, May 6An upturn in farm and food prices after several months of decline pushed the Wholesale Price Index up by eighttenths of 1 percent in April, but the index of industrial commodities continued to show only moderate inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Carey Pressing Plan on Sale of StateHeld Mortgages
description: ALBANY, May 6Although it has yet to win formal approval from Washington, Governor Carey's office is redoubling its efforts to get the Legislature to enact a $30 million program implementing the sale of stateheld housing mortgages that are supposed to be insured by the Federal Government.

title: Expert Calls Hughes Will A Textbook Forgery Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6A handwriting expert today called the purported will of Howard R. Hughes a textbook example of forged handwriting, and in Las Vegas, the District Attorney said that if the document was shown to be forged, he would try to prosecute those responsible.

title: Carter's Union Supporters Plan Plea to Labor Chiefs
description: Union supporters of Jimmy Carter, encouraged by a major breakthrough yesterday in the Michigan base of the independent United Automobile Workers, say they will seek to push the A.F.L.  C.I.O. into some expression of sympathy for the Carter candidacy at the May 19 meeting of its executive council in Washington.

title: Market Place
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose shares are the most widely held of any corporation, rarely gets rave notices from Wall Street.

title: Jackson Renews Quest for Votes; Opens Campaign in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, May 6Senator Henry M. Jackson opened a threeday campaign in Connecticut today, hoping to make a strong enough showing in the Presidential voting here next Tuesday to stem the drift of voters away from him.

title: Sixth Fleet Chief Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Vice Adm. Harry D. Train was named today to become commander of the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean. Admiral Train, currently director of the joint military staff in the Pentagon, will replace Vice Adm. Frederick C. Turner who has commanded the Sixth Fleet since September, 1974.

title: In Barcelona, a Silent Protest to Free the Prisoners
description: BARCELONA, Spain, May 6 A line of 60 people leaned against a block of houses on the Calle de Entenza yesterday evening looking fixedly across the busy street.

title: BonnParis Relations Undergoing Strain
description: PARIS, May 6For weeks, there have been reports of political tension between France and West Germany and a cooling of the oncewarm friendship between their leaders. The rumored irritation has now broken into the open.

title: Playoff Results
description: Playoff Results

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)American consumers increased their borrowing by $1.5 billion in March, a sign that consumer activities continue to gather strength. the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The increase in consumer borrowing, compared with a $1.2 billion gain in February, The board said overall consumer borrowing increased by an average of $1.3 billion a month during the first quarter of this year, compared with monthly gains of $643 million in the previous threemonth period and a monthly decline of $260 million during the recession low in the first quarter of 1975.

title: Records: Stravinsky's Epic Work
description: Stravinsky's brief but mon umental operaoratorio is one of his most moving works. Composed in 1926 and 1927, it has never really entered into the international operatic repertory. Aside from its STRAVINSKY: OEDIPUS REX. Jean Cocteau, Peter Pears, Martha Mod!, Heinz Rehfuss; Igor Stravinsky, conductor; Cologne Radio Symphony and Chorus. Columbia Odyssey Y 33789 (mono only). Michael Wager, Rene Kollo, Tatiana Troyanos, Tom Krause; Leonard Bernstein, conductor: Harvard Glee Club and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Columbia M 33999.

title: Notes on People
description: Facing assertions at home that on his recent visit to the United States he acted stiff and overformal, King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden defended himself in Stockholm's conservative newspaper, Svenska Dagbladet.

title: Hamilton's Moving Drums
description: Chico Hamilton's strong feeling for subtle colorations and dramatic construction sets him apart from most other jazz drummers and, over the last 20 years, has given the various groups he has led a strong and continuing identity. His quintet at an Interludes concert at Town Hall on Wednesday was not one of his most distinguished, but with Mr. Hamilton at the drums and with his almost Ellingtonian feeling for ensemble playing, it still stands out among current jazz groups.

title: Mother and Son Duel Through 3 Acts
description: Bunched absurdly into the middle of the Ambassador Theater's wide stage, the set is shabby and looks like a moth's dinner. The three diners aren't moths, though; they are fireflies.

title: Art: After Grooms, BMT Is Bucolic
description: IT is no longer a secret that Red Grooms is one of the funniest people in New York, or that he has found in New York his funniest subject. Six months ago, when his magnum opus in progress, Ruckus Manhattan, was first shown downtown at 88 Pine Street, it struck many New Yorkers as the most hilarious account of their city that any artist, in any medium, had attempted in years.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Ken Griffey, the Reds right fielder, making a running catch on Jerry Grote's firstinning line drive. Dave Kingman, left, was one of the two Mets on base at the time.

title: 1600 Pennsylvania Will Close Tomorrow
description: The new Alan Jay Lerner and Leonard Bernstein musical, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, which opened at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Tuesday, will end its Broadway engagement tomorrow, after seven performances.

title: PRINCIPAL ACCUSES SEMINARY OF BIAS
description: One of the three principals at the Friends Seminary on East 16th Street in Manhattan has filed a complaint alleging that she has been dismissed, as of next semester, because of her sex and age.

title: Bronx Democrats Pay Tribute to Cunningham
description: Patrick J. Cunningham berated elitist newspapers and public  relations prosecutors before a receptive audience of his fellow Bronx Democrats last night.

title: INTEREST RATES UP AS FED DRAINS OFF SOME BANK RINDS
description: Interest rates rose fairly sharply in the money market yesterday, first as the Federal Reserve temporarily drained some money from the banking system and later after the central bank disclosed that the nation's more broadly defined money supply had increased during the week ended April 28. The Federal Government also disclosed that its wholesale price Index had risen substantially, and that, too, depressed fixedincome security prices.

title: Lockwood Helps Mets Down Reds, 42
description: One team won the 42 game at Shea Stadium yesterday and one team lost. It wasn't discernible in the clubhouses, though, which team did which.

title: Yanks Beat Angels, 42 For Sweep
description: ANAHEIM, Calir., May 6Switching back to their running offense after a couple of longball victories, the New York Yankees completed a threegame sweep of the California Angels tonight with a 42 victory.

title: Bridge:
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 6The United States and Italy qualifed here tonight to play each other in the final of the world team championship, but not before the great Rattan Blue Team and its supporters had had some very nervous moments.

title: Erving Excels as Nets Win
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 6It was another stellar night for. Julius Erving tonight at the Coliseum as the New York Nets defeated the Denver, Nuggets, 117111, and took a 21 lead in the Amercan Basketball Association final playoff.

title: RECALL IS DISPUTED BY BISCUIT COMPANY
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 (AP)The president of Bremner Biscuit Company of Louisville said today that his company had not been ordered by the Food and Drug Administration to recall thousands of cases of cookies and Graham crackers because of possible contamination by rodent hairs.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 0.8% IN APRIL, SPURRED BY FOOD
description: WASHINGTON, May 6An upturn in farm and food prices after several months of decline pushed the Wholesale Price Index up by eighttenths of 1 percent in April, but the index of industrial commodities continued to show only moderate inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Police Death Benefits Voted
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  The Senate Judiciary coinmittce yesterday approved a hill to provide Federal death benfits to survivors of policemen and other public safety of ficers killed in the line of duty. The measure would provide a $50.000 Federal death benefit when a policeman, fireman, correctional official or other safety official was killd as a result of a criminal act.

title: Italy Fears 95 Are Dead, 1,000 Injured in Quake
description: VENICE, Friday, May 7A severe earthquake struck northeastern Italy last night, collapsing entire sections of towns northeast of Venice near the Yugoslav border, killing at least 95 persons and injurng at least 1,000, the Italian Interior Ministry reported.

title: REFUGEES PROTEST NEW MOVE BY LISBON
description: LISBON, May 6  Portugal today announced revisions in the aid program for refugees from its former African colonies, and hundreds thereupon staged sitins in Lisbon's luxury hotels in protest.

title: Restaurants
description: PEOPLE frequently ask how we choose the restaurants reviewed in this column. Well, several ways. Sometimes its a matter of having noticed a new one that looks promising from a taxi window. This Was the with Toscana which has been in operation about three weeks now on the southwest corner of Second Avenue and 54th Street. It was a good find.

title: Air Disc Brakes for Trucks Is Introduced by Goodrich
description: DETROIT, May 6The B. F. Goodrich Company introduced today the first totally air actuated disc brake system for heavy duty trucks and trailers.

title: RADIO
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM: Mornings With Music. Light Cavalry Overture. Suppe; Violin Concerto in A, Leclair; Pavane pour tine infante, Ravel; Piano Concertino, Francaix; Symphonic Poem No. 13. Liszt; Tales from the Vienna Woods, Strauss.

title: KISSINGER OFFERS PROGRAM TO HELP POOR LANDS GROW
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 6 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today outlined an intricate and comprehensive American approach to economic relations between rich and poor countries that laid heavy stress on free enterprise and private initiative.

title: Flyers Gain, 63; Leach Tallies 5
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6A recordtying five goals by Reggie Leach led the Philadelphia Flyers to a 63 victory over the crippled Boston Bruins tonight.

title: Hemingway Unit Gives First Prize
description: Loyd Little, of Frog Level, N. C., a former Green Beret, has won the first Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award of $6,000 for his novel Parthian Shot.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: Friday, May 7, 1975

title: Publishing: What Makes Sheldon Run?
description: YOU may have noticed that Sidney Sheldon's A Stranger in the Mirror, which was reviewed on page 62 of last Sunday's Book Review section, had jumped on to the best seller chart by page 69. That quick success, virtually on publication, is an indication that Mr. Sheldon, a longtime playwright, screenwriter and Hollywood factotum, is a man to watch.

title: GARBAGE PILING UP IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: Piles of garbage in the fourdayold strike of building service employees continued to rise yesterday, and so did complaints from tenants and apartmenthouse owners.

title: by Legislative Veto
description: The bill was drafted in consultation with top Defense and State Department officials, including Secretary Kissinger, who reportedly had indicated that the Administration could live with the measure. Now a provision lifting the trade embargo against Vietnam for six months is suddenly considered too onerous. It is seen by the White House as ammunition for former Governor Reagan's campaign. But the bill was drafted to provide Hanoi with an incentive to supply information on persons missing in action from the war; Mr. Reagan is unlikely to make political capital out of attacking that provision.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
description: Horses listed in order or post positions Letter desionates OTR listing.

title: 12Carat Diamond Stolen
description: Burglars yesterday took a 12carat, $75,000 diamond ring and other jewelry, valued at $25,000, from the unoccupied apartment of Jane A. Holmes at 650 Park police reported.

title: Extortion in Nassau
description: Neither of the two major political parties on Long Island holds a monopoly on corrupt activities. The conviction of former Nassau County Democratic Chairman Marvin D. Cristenfeld for extortion and fraud in multimilliondollar engineering contracts exposes an elaborate system of political kickbacks. Payoffs disguised as business expenses went to law offices that provided no legal services, to Democratic workers on noshow jobs, printing firms as payment for the party's bills.

title: 78 Feared Dead, 500 Hurt In a Strong Quake in Italy
description: VENICE, Friday, May 7A severe earthquake struck northeastern Italy last night, collapsing entire sections off towns northeast of Venice near the Yugoslav border, killing at least 78 persons and injuring at least 500, the police said.

title: Albany Republicans Ask Tax Refund if Revenues Rise
description: ALBANY. May 6The State Legislature's Republican leadership has announced legislation that would refund $300 million in personal and business taxes starting this fall if the state's income exceeds Governor Carey's estimates by a certain amount.

title: Red Smith
description: On the third Saturday of the baseball season, a veterinarian looking at the Los Angeles Dodgers would have recognized a textbook case of the blind staggers. They had played 12 games against the Giants, Padres, Braves and Aytros, whom they are accustomed to regard indulgently as poor relations, and they had lost nine times and were beginning to look natural in the slums of the National League West. That Saturday night, April 24, Don Sutton beat the Cubs, 2.1. The next day the Dodgers won aeain. 54, in 10 innings. They haven't looked hack since. That battle royal they won in Chicago Wednesday there were seven pitchers in the game and nine home runs and the Cubs made 21 hits while losing, 1412  that was their 11th straight victory and now they are on top. So what's the difference, Walter Alston was asked over the phone yesterday, between 39 and 149 the wonlost tables? In his 22 years as manager, Alston has displayed a variety of talents, none more striking than his gift for understatement.

title: PAUL HAMMOND, YACHTSMAN, DIES
description: Paul Hammond, an internationally known yachtsman who served in the Navy in both World Wars, died Wednesday at his home, I Sutton Place South. He was 93 years old.

title: Business Records
description: SANDRA A. CASO, Sunset Garden Apts., K: nestan, N.Y, Liabilities $3,280; assets none

title: Yonkers Welcomes Nero, a Sleepy Star
description: YONKERS. May 6Nero, the crack pacer who recently was syndicated for $3.6 million, a record for standardbreds, arrived at Yonkers Raceway at 4:08 A.M., today and did what all smart pacers should do at that hour. He went to sleep immediately.

title: Winds Break Up Oil Slick
description: TEXAS CITY, Tex., May 6 (AP)A milelong oil ??? has been broken up into small globs of heavy crude by high winds in Galveston Bay, according to the Coast Guard.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Subcommittee on small territories10:30 A.M.

title: CHINESE EXPRESS DOUBTS ABOUT U.S
description: PEKING, May 6 (Reuters)The British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Crosland, said tonight that Chinese leaders had expressed doubts about the United States commitment to West European defense.

title: Hunting The Rare Art Book
description: TO run a great art bookstore takes a special kind of craziness. The books are difficult, the clients are impossible, the economics don't bear thinking of. (The archetypal good art book is out of print, takes forever to find, and was ordered by someone who has gone off on a year's sabbatical, leaving no address.) But a great city is only as great as its bookstores, and among bookstores the art bookstore has a place all its own. To run one is a vocation. almost a martyrdom; to run one successfully is to be somewhere among the saints.

title: New Data on Depletion of Ozone Hint at Lower Aerosol Threat
description: New observations bearing on how ozone is broken down and replenished in the stratosphere have raised the possibility that fluorocarbons, used in spray cans and airconditioning systems, may be depleting the protective ozone layer at a far slower rate than was supposed.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times on Tuesday that the Convent of the Sacred Heart is the oldest school in New York City. Collegiate School claiths the distinction of being the oldest. Collegiate was founded in 1638 but was closed during the Revolutionary War between 1776 and 1783. Trinity School, founded in 170, says it is the oldest in continuous operation.

title: Drama's Story Retold at Museum in Yonkers
description: Sarah Bernhardt can be seen this weekend in the role of Queen Elizabeth 1. Her voice tremulous, her arms outstretched, she portrays the strongwilled Queen of England, grieving over the lifeless body of Robert Devereux. Earl of Essex, the man she loved, but ordered put to death.

title: Rooted in the West
description: For me to deny a lifelong love of the West would be impossible. There's an old saying that states, You can take the boy out of the country, but you can't take the country out of the boy. I know good and well that it applies to me.

title: Reagan Predicts FirstBallot Victory
description: BATON ROUGE, La., May 6 Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, basking in the glow of his recent primary victories over President Ford in Alabama, Georgia and Indiana, said today that he believed he could go to the Republican Natonal Convention with enough delegates to win the party's Presidential nomination on the first ballot.

title: It's Still the League of Women Voters
description: The League of Women Voters, which has accepted men as members in the last two years, considered dropping Women from its name yesterday, but finally voted overwhelmingly to keep the old name after deciding that it was more valuable than it was sexist.

title: Presidential Debates on TV Are Planned
description: The League of Women Voters announced plans Wednesday to sponsor this fall a series of four debates between major Presidential candidates. The forums would be available for coverage by the television networks so they might turn out to be the first such series since the Great Debates between Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy in 1960.

title: To Our Readers
description: The New York Times now appears on Fridays in four parts. Part A today includes the editorial and OpEd pages and sports. Part B includes real estate news and classified advertising. Part C is Weekend, a new entertainment section that will appear each Friday. It includes Books of The Times, the crossword puzzle, the bridge column and television and radio news. Part D be. gins with business and financial news, including new features, and also contains obituaries and weather news.

title: The Crossover Vote
description: Hank Grover is a voluble Texas conservative who ran for Governor of that state in 1972 and who is an ardent supporter of Ronald Reagan for President. As soon as the George Wallace campaign began to collapse after the Florida primary, Mr. Grover thought he sensed opportunity in Texas for Mr. Reagan.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: 43d60th Streets

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: The Labor Scene
description: PRESIDENT FORD'S Labor  Management Committee is back in business, but it is no longer the President's committee. The 16 top corporate and union executives who make up the panel have cut their formal tie to the Administration and are now holding periodic meetings on thir own to seek consensus on issues of basic policy.

title: Mrs. Peron Reported Indicted With 3 on Corruption Charges
description: BUENOS AIRES May 6 (AP) Isabel Martinez de Pern, the deposed Argentine President, has been indicted on charges of mishandling public funds, reliable judiciary sources reported tonight.

title: Senators Seeking Law to Curb U.S. Business Bribery Abroad
description: WASHINGTON. May 6In legislative proposals that call for major reforms to end bribery by American companies doing business abroad, Senator Frank Church has recommended that all major companies have outside directors to monitor questionable payments.

title: Art People
description: BIGGER than life, but something less than natural, the faces of a dozen pioneer Abstract Expressionist painters are causing a stir in Soho. The facesJackson Pollock, Barnett Newman, Adolph Gottlieb, Franz Kline, Mark Rothko, Willem de Kooning, Robert Motherwell, Arshile Gorky, Theodbros Stamos, Ad Reinhardt, Clyfford Still and Hans Hofmann  were done from photographs by Garey Riester, a young superrealist who wields a snappy airbrush. They are intended to make up a mural on the outside wall of a building at 393 West Broadway, site of the James Yu Gallery  which handles Mr. Riester's work.

title: W.H.O. Is Urged by Syrians To Impose Sanction on Israel
description: GENEVA, May 6 Syria called on the World Health Organization today to impose appropriate sanctions on Israel, charging that the Israelis had grossly disregarded the rights of the Palestinian people.

title: Chile Said to Stars Freeing Prisoners In Tie to Simon Trip
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Treasury Secretary William E. Simon left today on a tour of Latin American countries, including Chile, and an aide said he had made the release of political prisoners a condition for his Chilean visit.

title: Money Growth Shows a Mixed Change
description: The nation's money supply Mowed a mixed change last week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday, with one measure showing an increase, while the other declined.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.3 From WeekAgo Leve
description: The commodity spot market price index of toodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 202.9 from 203.2 last week

title: Books of The Times
description: DOBIS KEARNS'S Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream is finally so unusual in its thoughtfulness and sense of responsibility to the past that it seems almost unfair to it to recall the fairy tale that led to its conception. Yet the fairy tale, told by Professor Kearns in her prologue, is integral to what makes the book unusual. For what would most of us have done if we had been a 25yearold woman from Harvard singled out by President Lyndon B. Johnson at a dance for new White House Fellows, and then asked to come to work on his staff, with an office two doors away from his? If we had been asked to visit him in retirement on his Texas ranch, and then, at 5 A.M. meetings that would become almost ritual, to be spoken to by him of the past, of the beginnings and ends of things, of dreams and fantasies"?

title: Miss Wright Tests Her Game, Cards 72
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 6A little old lady in tennis shoes came out of semiretirement today, showed her younger colleagues how to shoot a cool 72 and offered some observations on the state of women's professional golf.

title: U.S. BISHOPS SEEK TO SPUR VOTERS
description: CHICAGO, May 6The nation's Roman Catholic bishops called on churchgoers today to become involved in the 1976 Presidential campaign by studying and debating the issues and then voting according to their consciences,

title: OzoneDepletion Reactions
description: Two series of chemical reactions, one involving chlorine, the other based on nitric oxide, deplete stratospheric ozone as the latter is replenished by other reactions.

title: S. E. C. Drops 2 Environment Data Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Securities and Exchange Commission withdrew today two of three proposals it put forward last fall that would have substantially expanded the amount of environmental compliance information available to investors.

title: A Fashion Debut for Gloria Vanderbilt
description: Gloria Vanderbilt, surrounded by family, friends and executives from stores all over the country, made her debut on Seventh Avenue yesterday afternoon. It was a dazzler. The clothes were not the stiff, uptight variety society women frequently affect. They were supple, inventive and imaginative, reflective of her own personal style.

title: Justice in Suffolk
description: Now that an independent special state prosecutor and grand jury have exonerated District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien of various charges of misconduct, lawenforcement officials at all levels from police to courts can get back to work on a number of investigations that have been in a state of confusion in Suffolk County.

title: Nadia Gray Is a Chanteuse at Spindletop
description: Nadia Gray, the actress who did the striptease in La Dolce Vita, is making her nightclub debut at the Upstairs Cabaret at the Spindletop, 254 West 47th Street, where she is playing the role of a Continental singerfully clothed.

title: Tourist Invasion of Sinai Shatters Cherished Solitude Of Greek Orthodox Monks
description: TARFA, Israeli  Occupied SinaiTo escape the droves of tourists who descended on Sinai recently, a small group of travelers set off on a camel safari into the rugged and normally inaccessible hinterland southwest of the historic and crowded Mount Sinai area.

title: Islanders Eliminated
description: The New York Islanders lost, 52, to the Montreal Canadiens and were eliminated from the National Hockey League playoffs. The Canadiens will face the Philadelphia Flyers for the Stanley Cup. Page A 19.

title: It's On On for Off Off Broadway
description: This weekend more than 80 different plays will be performed Off Off Broadway, which is almost twice the number of plays that open during an entire Broadway season. Because the performances of Off Off Broadway shows are strictly limited by Actors Equity (the average run is 12 performances over a period of three weekends), within weeks there will be a new set of plays.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market ended mixed yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

title: Bias Ban for Banks
description: The Treasury Department is expected to announce soon, perhaps today, that banks and thrift institutions with Government accounts may not pay dues to social clubs or organizations that exclude women or minorities. would not be deductible for incometax purposes.

title: Greek Cabarets Changing
description: Afew years ago there were a number of rather seedy Greek nightclubs clustered mostly on Eighth Avenue between 28th and 30th Streets. If a nonGreek ventured into one of them, it was to watch the belly dancers practice their art, which is not Greek at all, but Turkish.

title: Teachers in Farmingdale Go on Strike
description: FARMINGDALE, LI., May 6 The Farmingdale Federation of Teachers went on strike today after the union and school board failed to reach agreement on a contract for the next two years.

title: The Rise in the Minimum Wage
description: The minimum wage was initially set by the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. It now applies to more than twothirds of the civilian labor force, though mostly among nonfarm workers.

title: Sets Win Third Straight
description: CLEVELAND, May 6The New York Sets defeated the Cleveland Nets, 2521, in the World Team Tennis tonight, their third victory following an openingnight loss. The Sets never trailed after Phil Dent and Billie Jean King combined to win their opening mixed doubles match from Haroon Rahim and Wendy Overton. 6I.

title: Tates Locke New Coach:: of Braves
description: BUFFALO, May 6 (UP1)Tates Locke, vowing to build one hell of an aggressive basketball team, was named head coach of Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Assocation today. He received a twoyear contract.

title: A New Face
description: Raul Julia. This weekend people are going to come out of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center having seen Joseph Papp's somber, tawdry and yet magnificent production of the BrechtWeill Threepenny Opera and ask: Who is that man? That man is Raul Julia, and he is playing. with a brooding intensity, the leading role of Mack the Knife.

title: Management
description: B USINESSMEN who have lost highlevel executive jobs at major corporations in the aftermath of bribery and payoff scandals are also being dropped from boards of directors of other companies.

title: Pirates Conquer Giants, 30
description: PITTSBURGH. May 6 (AP) Jim Rooker and Larry Demery combined for a fivehitter to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 30 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight. It was the Giants 10th loss in 11 games, and their fifth in a row.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: COMMUNIST LEADERS MEET IN MOSCOW: Cuba's Defense Minister, Ratil Castro, meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet party leader. An official announcement said they discussed current international issues of mutual interest. It did not indicate whether Cuban actions in Angola were among those issues.

title: Robert Levin, Editor Who Wrote On Sexuality and Marriage, Dies
description: Robert J. Levin, a writer who specialized in the subjects of sex, marriage and family relationships, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his home at 222 East 35th Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Broadway
description: AL PACING wants to do Richard III next season, and he will, he says, if he has the time. Irene Worth will certainly be in The Cherry Orchard, just as Lynn Redgrave and Sam Waterston probably will be in Man and Superman. Bibi Anderson will in Strindberg's The Creditors, which, incidentally, is something that Mr. Pacino has sometimes said he would like to be in, too. For that matter, Dustin Hoffman is saying that he wants to do Hamlet, although Glenda Jackson, in a triumph for unisex, most likely will do it first. She may open in London and then come here. Ingmar Berman is at least talking about directing Ibsen's Rosmersholm, or Strindberg's Ghost Sonata. And the man behind all these productions and conversations about productions is Joe Papp.

title: Child Guidance Office to End Work in 17 Districts
description: Proposed New York City and State budget cuts will mean the elimination of services provided; by the city's Bureau of Child Guidance to 17 ccrmmunity school districts next fall and reductions in services to the remaining 15 districts, a top Board of Education official disclosed yesterday.

title: Rabbi Bernard Heller, 77, Dies; A Scholar, Author and Teacher
description: Rabbi Bernard Heller, Sceholar, author, teacher and lecturer, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 425 Riverside Drive.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN TO CONFER MAY 1214
description: NEW DELHI, May 6Indian and Pakistani officials will meet in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, May 12 to 14 to discuss outstanding issues, the Government announced here today.

title: The Message on Beef: Increased Prices
description: Wray Finney, who owns a 4,000acre cattle ranch in southwest Oklahoma does not see much of it these days. He is too busy giving a message to American housewives: beef prices will start going up soon and will continue rising through the summer and into the fall.

title: Budget of Conferees Is $17.5 Billion Over Ford's
description: WASHINGTON, May 6A joint HouseSenate conference committee agreed today to a target ceiling of Federal spending of $413.3 billion, a figure that is $17.5 billion higher than President Ford proposed but about $10 billion spent if all Federal programs were continued unchanged.

title: Berle Asserts First Job Is to Gain Confidence of Agency Personnel
description: ALBANY, May 6Peter A. A. Berle, who took office today as Acting Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said that his first order of business was to gain the confidence of the department's 3,000 employees and to see if we can get this institution functioning.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEEN GAINING SUPPORT
description: Despite a threatened defection by Brooklyn Republicans, the overwhelming majority of New York delegates to the Republican National Convention are ready to follow the lead of Vice President Rockefeller and thus enhance his bargaining power at the convention, state Republican leaders agreed yesterday.

title: About Real Estate
description: In the heyday of the Urban Development Corporation a few years ago Edward J. Logue occupied a pleasant office near the top of a midtown skyscraper. He could find only one flaw in the panoramic view it afforded. His beloved Roosevelt Island project was partially obstructed by buildings.

title: Barenboim, A Wizard Of Music, Hails Another
description: Playing piano concertos and simultaneously conducting from the keyboard is often held to be an ego trip on the part of the musician involved. But in the 1780's and 1790's the musician's name might have been Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. In those days it was customary for the composer to play and conduct. Thus when Daniel Barenboim does that very thing this weekend, in two Carnegie Hall programs of o Mozart concertos, he is but following distinguished precedent.

title: Special Stamp to Mark Sizning of Declaration
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Postal Service announced today that it would commemorate the signing of the Declaration of Independence by issuing a special 13cent stamp in Philadelphia July 4.

title: The Bankruptcy Option
description: Representative Herman Badillo recommends bankruptcy for New York as an alternative to the stiff fiscal disciplines imposed by Mayor Beame's threeyear financial plan.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Off Off Broadway, a kaleidoscope of basements, lofts and backrooms, has ventured into the transept of the beautiful Little Church Around the Corner, 11 East 29th Street (6797174). The Joseph Jefferson Theater Companynamed for the 19thcentury actor who had a friend's funeral here when a fancy church wouldn't bury stage folk, will offer Philip Barry's John in the play's first local revival since 1927. It is about John the Baptist, in a political rather than a religious sense. At 8 tonight, before the curtain rises, the critic Brendan Gill will speak about the playwright. Admission: $3.50.

title: 2 GRAIN CONCERNS FINED IN THEFTS
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 6 Two large grain companies were fined a total of $430,000 in Federal court today after pleading no contest to conspiracy charges in systematic thefts of grain from foreign commerce.

title: SUIT THREATENED OVER RIVER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The American Electric Power Company held before Congress and the President today the likelihood of a $500 million suit if a bill blocking the company's construction of a hydroelectric project on the New River on the North Carolina  Virginia border becomes law.

title: Stocks Up a Bit in Slow Trading
description: The stock market, adhering to its recent pattern of small daily advances alternating with small declines, edged up yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Humphrey Terms Brown A New Dimension in Race
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N.J., May 6Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said tonight that Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had injected an exciting new dimension into the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1976, By Triangie Publications. Ins. (The Dally Racing Farm)

title: In Memoriam
description: KALUSKIZeltel. In cherished memory of a wondeful mother, died 1930 Daniel.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WPIX!Channel 11 has a new monthly series called Black Conversation, one of the station's gestures toward the requirement for minority programming. This formai happens to have two remarkably good hosts: Lindsay patterson and Orde Coombes, two young writers who have had a longrunning interview program on radio station WRVR. Their guest at 1 P.M. is Cicely Tyson, the actress who garnered innumerable honors for Miss Jane Pittman.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.9 bition tonmiles, 8.2 percent above the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 485,715 cars, up 6.4 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity truck tonnage was 16.9 percent higher than last year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 33yearold Californian, Gaylord Anguish, was sentenced to 10 years in prison after his conviction for robbing one Long Island bank and his plea of guilty to robbing four others. The defendant was said to have commuted between California and New York in 1974 to carry out the robberies, which netted him nearly $32,000. Judge Edward R. Neaher said in Federal Court in Brooklyn that he was postponing execution of the sentence for 80 days to allow Mr. Anguish to undergo psychiatric tests.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: More couples than ever appear to be postponing childbearing.

title: News Summary and Index
description: An intricate and comprehensive American approach to economic relations between rich and poor countries that put heavy stress on free enterprise and private initiative was outlined by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in an address yesterday to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Nairobi. The most dramatic proposal was for an International Research Bank, an institution that, Mr. Kissinger said, would promote rational, systematic and equitable development of resources in developing nations. [Page A1, Column 8.]

title: A DELAY IS URGED ON NUCLEAR PLANT
description: SALEM, May 6The State Public Advocate asked the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board today to delay construction of a nuclear power plant here until it held hearings on whether a fire on a passing tanker loaded with liquefied natural gas could set off a catastrophic accident at the niant.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter dasianatas OTR lisline.

title: Real Estate Panel Official Assails Board's Members
description: TRENTON, May 6The executive director of the State Real Estate Commission charged today that board members were more concerned with protecting the industry than in protecting the public.

title: U.S. Curb Due on Banks Paying Clubs
description: The Treasury Department is expected to announce soon, perhaps today, that banks and savings and loan institutions with Government accounts may not pay dues to social clubs or organizations that exclude women or minorities.

title: To Our Readers
description: The New York Times now appears on Fridays in four parts. Part A today includes the editorial and OpEd pages and sports. Part B includes real estate news and classified advertising. Part C is Weekend, a new entertainment section that will appear each Friday. It includes Books of The Times, the cross word puzzle, the bridge column and television and radio news. Part D begins with business and financial news, including new features, and also contains obituaries and weather news.

title: G.0.P. Leaders Tell Ford He's Harmed As Criticism of Kissinger's Moves Rises
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Several Republican leaders have advised President Ford in recent days that criticism of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's handling of foreign policy issues was hurting Mr. Ford among Republican voters and had played a significant role in the primary victories of Ronalti Reagan.

title: Brokers Speed Plans To Begin Put Trading
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 6The Securities Industry Association said today that it was revising an earlier proposal for a goslow approch on trading in put options, Instead it said it would tell the Securities and Exchange Commission that stockbrokers were ready to proceed by August with such trading. A put is the right to sell stock at a set price in a set period. Call options (the right to buy stock) are already traded.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported In The New York Times on Tuesday that the Convent of the Sacred Heart is the oldest school in New York City. Collegiate School claims the distinction of being the oldest. Collegiate was founded in 1638 but was closed during the Revolutionary War between 1776 and 1783. Trinity School, founded in 1709, says it Is the oldest In continuous operation.

title: Curbing Arms Sales
description: President Ford is making a foolish effort to thwart improved Congressional oversight of American arms sales abroad by threatening a veto of the foreign aid bill which contains this reform.

title: Fresh Diagnostic Data Sought In Tests Begun on Miss Quinlan
description: DENVILLE, N. J., May 6Karen Anne Quinlan's physicians have begun a series of diagnostic tests in order to describe her condition accurately for a hospital ethics committee, which must determine that there is no reasonable possibility that she will recover and thus can be allowed to die.

title: KEY DECISION NEAR IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6The 37dayold strike by 1,800 city craft workers here has entered a crucial phase that could result in a quick settlement or lead to an even longer walkout.

title: D. Hayden Takes Medal With a 71
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, LT., May 6Golfers find it difficult to post good medal scores at the Seawane Club, a beautiful course sliced here and there by Thixton Creek, Mallow Reach and a short canal leading to Lake Kathellen, which is only a pond back of the third green.

title: Critic's Notebook: Watching That Electronic Cookie
description: CHILDREN are telephones. They ring until they are answered, even if, especially if it is a Saturday or Sunday morning, and you have been out stormtrooping in the service of the pleasure principal the nieht before. And although you may have trained them to leave you alone, in some mysterious way that the radical feminists have yet to explain, you are aware of their upandaboutness. There's an ear in the hallway, attached by neutral wire to an alarm circuit in your brain. You hear them creep around at dawn like Arab refugees, eating mayonnaise and fudge; watching, on T1,7, Air Force documentaries, religious shorts, farm reports and lessons in Portuguese. The StarSpangled Banner is the first jingle of their day.

title: Squires Given a Deadline
description: The American Basketball Association announced yesterday that it would terminate the troubled Virginia Squires franchise if it could not pay its substantial outstanding debts by Monday.

title: Subtletiesatthe City Ballet Gregg Smith's New Songs
description: LOOKING at the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the State Theater, one realized again what fiendishly difficult things its two chief choreographers like to cook tip for their dancers and how well their dancers nerform in them.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger Address to U.N. Conference on Trade and Development
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger as prepared for delivery today in Nairobi, Kenya, to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development:

title: Reactivated Bayonne Drydock Gets 820Foot Customer, the Lash Turkiye
description: The newly reactivated drydock at the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, leased from the Navy earlier this year by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, was at work yesterday on its first commercial repair job.

title: New York City Congress Members Below Average in Vote Frequency
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The 18 members of the New York City Congressional delegation, long chided by their colleagues for an allegedly casual attitude toward legis lative duties last year cast fewer votes, on the average, than most other delegations,  except for those beset by illness.

title: Taciturn Prosecutor
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 6 His chief calls him the Sphinx. Cornelius Robert Heusel, the tall normally congenial First Assistant United States Attorney in New Orleans has earned the sobriquet by turning taciturn and enigmatic whenever he is questioned about any case that his office has under investigation. Sometimes it's tough even to get him to talk to me, his chief, United States Attorney Gerald J. Gallinghouse, remarked recently.

title: Emergency Phone Is Busy As Building Strike Goes On
description: Yesterday morning the Nutrition and Health Association on the West Side called the emergency city center handling complaints arising from the building service employees strike.

title: How Maitre d Keeps Patrons in Place
description: New Yorkers are generally aggressive and demanding, selfassured and quite often impatient. They dress fashionably and tip wellunless they are doctors, smoke pipes or play professional baseball and it pleases them to preen publicly.

title: West Point Officers Ask Army to Check On Cheating Inquiry
description: WEST POINT, May 6Ten officers on the legal staff of the United States Military Academy have written to the Secretary of the Army, Martin R. Hoffmann, asking for an investigation of the manner in which West Point is handling its cheating scandal.

title: Canadiens Oust Islanders in 5 Games
description: MONTREAL, May 6On the lengendary rink that was the focus of most of their boyhood dreams, the New York Islanders lost a National Hockey League semifinal playoff series to the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: PRESIDENT DELAYS ON BILL TO RESUME PRIMARY SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The White House indicated today that President Ford would not decide until next week whether to sign or veto pending campaign legislation, delaying still further the potential resumption of primary campaign subsidies to Presidential candidates.

title: MT. LAUREL IS SUED ON HOUSING AGAIN
description: TRENTON, May 6The New Jersey Public Advocate charged today that the Township of Mount Laurel, the subject of a landmark court decision barring restrictive zoning, had failed to comply with an order by the State Supreme Court to provide more housing for the poor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Prof. H. Gary Knight, in his April 29 letter in the Times, makes serious charges against United States policy at the Law of the Sea Conference, questionable assumptions about present U.S. ocean rights and dubious recommendations for U.S. policy. Do these stand up under analysis?

title: PPG to Lift Chemical Prices
description: PPG Industries said yesterday that it would raise prices on chemicals used in making paint, rubber and paper by 3 percent to 7.4 percent, effective June 1. The company said it was following other producers in the industry.

title: Mr. Kissinger in Kenya
description: Secretary of State Kissinger has concluded his first African tour on a positive note, with extensive proposals at an international conference in Kenya for assisting economic development of the poorer nations on a broad front. His suggestions pick up where he left off at the special United Nations General Assembly last September and probably represent the maximum advance that could be expected in an American Presidential election yearthough they fall well short of thirdworld desires.

title: F.T.C. Finds Public Misled by Chrysler On Fuel Economy
description: WASHINGTON. May 6 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that Chrysler Corporation misled the public about the fuel economy of its small cars two years ago and ordered the auto giant not to do it again.

title: Briton Says U.S. Tried Hard to Halt Concorde Project in 1964
description: LONDON, May 6The United States Government came close to forcing the British to stop development of the Concorde supersonic airliner, a former Aviation Minister says in a book published here today.

title: Elisabeth Moore Honored for Work In Asian Education
description: Blending downhome religion with uptown society, Vice President Rockefeller and scores of leading New Yorkers gathered at the Pierre Hotel last night to pay tribute to Elisabeth Luce Moore for her 38 years of devotion to the United Board for Christian Higher Education in Asia.

title: U.S. Rent Subsidy Ruling Upholds Housing Experts
description: The Ford Administration's rejection of Mayor Beanie's proposal to divert tens of millions of dollars in anticipated Federal housing subsidies represents a victory for housing specialists who considered the Beame proposal destructive to private housing in the city.

title: PANAMA RELEASES 2 U.S. TUNA BOATS
description: PANAMA, May 6 (Reuters)Two United States tuna boats have left their refuge in the Panama Canal after paying the Panamanian Government a reduced fine of $43,000, officials have reported today.

title: FISHERY LINK IS SET BY U.S. AND CANADA
description: OTTAWA, May 6Canada and the United States will work together in regulating fishing operations off both coasts of the two countries following claims in Ottawa and Washington to control of economic resources up to 200 miles from shore.

title: Business Trends
description: LOS ANGELESAmericans have returned to the housing market in large numbers this spring helping to lift the nation's battered housing industry out of its worst slump in decades.

title: New Data on Depletion of Ozone Hint at Lower Aerosol Threat
description: New observations bearing on how ozone is broken down and replenished in the stratosphere have raised the possibility that fluorocarbons, used in spray cans and airconditioning systems, may be depleting the protective ozone layer at a far slower rate than was supposed.

title: Reagan Now Favored By London Bookmaker
description: LONDON, May 6, (Reuters) Ronald Reagan has replaced President Ford as the favorite with a London bookmaker to win the United States Presidential election.

title: Issues in Building Strike
description: Local 32B of the Service Employees Union, representing 20,000 superintendents, handymen, elevator operators, porters, mechanics and guards in 4,000 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. The Realty Advisory Board represents the building owners.

title: Flaherty Bars This Term As Mayor of Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, May 6 (UPI)Mayor Peter Flaherty said today that he would not seek reelection to a third term next year but refused to rule out a bid for the Governorship in 1978.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: GEORGE E. GILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 6George Ernest Gill, an executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America, died today in Arlington, Va., Hospital, after a heart attack on April 29. He was 62 years old.

title: CONSUMER BUYING AT RETAIL CHAINS SURGED IN APRIL
description: Consumer buying of clothing, home furnishings, garden and leisuretime equipment surged in April across the nation, giving several of the country's 10 largest retail chains their most sizable sales gains in months.

title: Black Groups Plan Voter Drive In 15 to 20 Cities and Counties
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 6Some 15 to 20 heavily black cities and rural counties will he targeted by a national coalition of black organizations for massive voter registration and education drives before the November elections.

title: Kissinger's TradeOff on Aid
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's speech to the United Nation's Conference on Trade and Development in Nairobi yesterday, like his dramatic address at the United Nations last fall, combined a willingness to negotiate a limited number of changes in international financial arrangements with a rejection of the poorer nations most sweeping demands.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday. London: Morning fixing $126.90, down $0.35; afternoon fixing $126.90, down $0.35. Paris afternoon market quotation $126.75, down $0.57.

title: Celtics Top Cavaliers, 11199
description: BOSTON, May 6  Tom Heinsohn paced in front of the Boston Celtic bench more than usual tonight in the closing minutes of the third quarter here at Boston Garden.

title: The Wife Abbie Hoffman Left Behind: Lonely, but With Hope
description: Two years have gone by since ??? HoffmanYippie, Establishment ??? massmedia guerrilla  went underground, becoming a fugitive after his indictment on cocaineselling charges.

title: REVENUE SHARING INN HOUSE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Legislation to extend the fiveyearold general revenuesharing program, which is important to many hardpressed cities, cleared its first major hurdle today when the House Government Operations Committee approved it. 39 to 3.

title: Mt. Laurel Case Far From Settled
description: MOUNT LAUREL, May 6The battle to force this New jersey suburb of Camden and Philadelphia to provide housing For the poor has not abated despite five years of often highly emotional court fights.

title: Antiques
description: WHEN American 19thcentury quilts became collectibles a decade ago, few of us realized that a major revival had begun and that 10 years later there would be so much for experts, museums auctions and shops to unravel.

title: NINE GUARDS SLAIN BY MEXICAN GUNMEN
description: MEXICO CITY, May 6Nine people, all policemen or private security guards, were murdered today in a bizarre incident that police here attributed to an apparent act of vengeance rather than a leftist guerrilla attack.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 6State childcare centers are likely to be unaffected for at least a year by the failure yesterday of the United States Senate to override President Ford's veto of $125 million to hell) such centers.

title: At the Movies
description: O N Monday residents of Long Island's South Fork may catch sight of a man making a movie and trying determinedly to be inconspicuous. Since filming involves a lot of very visible activity, the inconsnicuousness will be hiehly noticeable.

title: Ballet: Royal Does MacMillan Manon
description: One of Kenneth MacMillan's invaluable assets as choreographer in chief to the Royal Ballet has been his skill at turning out a series of fulllength ballets of opera house scope and grand design. His version of Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet is typical of his ability to organize and orchestrate huge and gorgeous masses of dancers. One of his major works, created slightly more than two years ago and first seen in New York a month or so later, is Manon.

title: West Point Officers Ask Army to Check On Cheating Inquiry
description: WEST POINT, May 6Ten officers on the legal staff of the United States Military Academy have written to the Secretary of the Army, Martin R. Hoffmann, asking for an investigation of the manner in which West Point is handling its cheating scandal.

title: Boy, 5, Falls to Death
description: A 5yearold boy fell to his death last night from the window of a sixthfloor apartment at 467 West 159th Street, the police reported. The boy was identified as Kenneth Peet. The police said he had been playing at the open window, which had no protective sccreens or bars. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Parliament Bypassed by New Wage Pact
description: LONDON, May 6There is a story told about a visitor to Dublin who loses his way and asks a local resident how to find a certain street. Well, says the Irishman after a thoughtful pause, to begin with, I wouldn't start from here.

title: ISRAELI OIL DEAL STIRS CRITICISM
description: TELAVIV, May 6The Israeli Government has given a foreign company a partnership in a promising oilfield that is being developed in occupied Egyptian territory in the southern Sinai region, according to a high Government source.

title: Test Service Widens Field
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 (AP)  Educational Testing Service announced it had set up a new regional office to service educators in the five Middle Atlantic states. The testing service said the new office, at its headquarters here, would be di rected by Robert J. Cleary and would service New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware.

title: Bribery Is Alleged In Meat Inspection For the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Congressional investigators have uncovered evidence that some Defense Department meat inspectors allegedly accepted bribes or sexual favors for approving substandard meat for military consumption, Senate sources said today.

title: Penney's Chief Confirms 3 Ousted for Infractions
description: Donald V. Seibert, chairman and chief executive officer of the J. C. Penney Company, confirmed yesterday published re ports that three Penney executives had recently been discharged for alleged wrongdoing.

title: No Improvement in Concert Bad Manners
description: People who go around saying that things are getting worse become intolerable bores even if it is the demonstrable truth. So let it merely be suggested here that so tar as audience manners are concerned, things are getting no better fast. Based on one constant concertgoer's experience this season, it would be safe to bet that in whatever hall you might find yourself this weekend a flashbulb will go off at some point during the performance.

title: Monastery Is Lure
description: ST. CATHERINE'S MONASTERY, IsraeliOccupied SinaiThe Greek Orthodox monks who live in this ancient monastery deep in the southern Sinai Mountains closed their doors for a brief respite the other day after an invasion of tourists that one monk described, only half in jest as our busiest fortnight in 1,000 years.

title: People and Business
description: George L. Shinn, chairman of the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking house, warned yesterday that unless stockbrokers got together to develop a proposed national stock market, the Securities and Exchange Commission would do it for them.

title: Costs Are Found Similar In National Health Plans
description: An exhaustive analysis of pending national health insurance plans by two Rand Corporation researchers has come up with an unexpected finding that they suggest could pave the way for political compromise over how to finance and administer such a plan.

title: In Memoriam
description: KRAFTMANDr. Morris L. Darling brother, for all time you A re missed and loved. LEE and HELEN.

title: Israel Studies Charge TV Crews Pay Arabs for  Demonstrations
description: TEL AVIV, May 3 (UPI)Israeli authorities said today that they were investigating reports that Arabs in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan had offered to stage, in exchange for payments from foreign newsmen, fireburning demonstrations and blocking of roads.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES AID BILL, CHARGING IT RESTRICTS HIM
description: WASHINGTON, May 7President Ford vetoed the $4.4 billion foreignaid bill today, saying that unprecedented restrictions in the authorization measure would seriously inhibit my ability to implement a coherent and consistent foreign policy.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Alice Sperling Wed To Mark A. Senn
description: Alice DeBoer Sperling, an art director in Denver, and Mark Albert Senn, a Denver lawyer, were married there yesterday afternoon in the Town Club by Rabbi Raymond Zwerin.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: BATTEN SAYS ROLE ISNOT TEMPORARY
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 7Moving swiftly to check widespread reports that he had been chosen to serve in a caretaker capacity, William M. Batten, newly named chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who will be 67 years old next month, said today that such reports were untrue.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The known death toll in the earthquake that struck northeastern Italy Thursday night climbed yesterday into the many hundreds. Several hundred people were reported missing and more than 1,000 were injured. The quake turned villages at the foothills of the Alps into rubble and its tremors were felt in six countries.

title: Citibank Rate Is Stable
description: Citibank said yesterday that it was holding its prime lending rate unchanged at 6 percent for the coming week.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Commission of Investigation said it would hold public hearings on the shocking nature of abuses in the interim preparole release program. The program allows inmates to leave the prison for work, education or civic duties, or on escorted and unescorted furloughs for family visits. Joseph H. Rodriguez, chairman of the commission, said the hearings would be the result of six months of closeddoor testimony. Earlier this year, Governor Byrne suspended the programadministered by the Department of Institutions and Agenciesuntil harsher criteria for releases could be implemented. Furloughs under the new guidelines resumed in March.

title: Draths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 5.4311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK SIATE CO (914) WHITE PLAINS 94300; NASSAU CO. ($16) 1410500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3447767.

title: Concert
description: In 1610, when Claudio Monteverdi seems to have been shopping around for a new job, he published a remarkable collection of sacred pieces under the title of yespro della Beata Vergine, and dedicated the volume to an influential cleric of the time, Pone Paul V.

title: Everybody Gets Involved as the Garbage Continues to Pile Up
description: Garbage collections on the fifth day of the strike of building employees fomented bitter arguments between pickets and city authorities and resulted in a new union policy that effectively stalled City Hall rulings.

title: JAMES COSMAN DIES; FOUNDER OF WPAT, 71
description: James V. Cosman, an electronics expert and founder of radio station WPAT, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Denville, N.J.

title: Experts Agree on Flu Vaccine Policy
description: ATLANTA, May 7A group of experts on immunization policy have wrestled here for the last two days with the problems and intricacies of the most ambitious program of its kind ever attempted in the the United States.

title: Soviet Stresses View Warsaw Pact's Role Is to Quell Revolts
description: MOSCOW, May 7The late Chief of Staff of the Warsaw Pact forces, Gen. Sergei M. Shtemenko, said in an article published today that the main military purpose of the alliance was to suppress counterrevolutionary activity in Communist countries.

title: City Funds for Lindsay Drive Alleged
description: Three investigative agencies are seeking to determine whether some of the money spent on the 1972 campaign of then Mayor John V. Lindsay for the Democratic Presidential nomination came from New York City municipal funds.

title: Conservative Opposition Gains In Local Elections in Britain
description: LONDON, May 7The Conservative Party made substantial gains in yesterday's local elections throughout Britain, but analysts were undecided as to whether, in national terms, the results meant a shift toward the right.

title: PRICE FIXING LAID TO LEVI STRAUSS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today accused Levi Strauss, which says it is the world's largest clothing manufacturer, of price fixing in the sale of its blue jeans and other products.

title: Paper in Nashville Dismisses Writer Linked to the F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  A newspaperwoman whose al. leged special relationship with the Federal Bureau of Investigation was reported to Congress last week has been dismissed by her employer, The Nashville Tennessean.

title: Amstar and Gulf in Accord On Purchase of Sugar
description: The Amstar Corporation has signed a fouryear agreement to purchase one million tons of raw canesugar directly from Gulf & Western Industries Central Romana subsidiary in the Dominican Republic.

title: Radio
