description: The Week's Concerts

title: Flanagan's Dream to Become a Reality
description: Mike Flanagan delights in reaching for the impossible. With an outward calm born of stubbornness, he built a construction business by taking on jobs, no one else dared tackle. Now he has applied this tenacity to a racethe Singlehanded TransAtlantic.

title: Villagers Ordered To Leave
description: SAN DANIELE, Italy, May 8Paolo Querini was moving out of 22 Via Roma today, stacking his mattresses on the roof of his car, piling his clothes in the back seat and treading carefully each time he emerged from his house with its cracked walls.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: While stock prices basically marked time last week, the bond market took its worst drubbing of 1976.

title: Round One In a Fight For Sports
description: IN looking at New Jersey's position as the eighth most populous state in the United States, thinking citizen begins to wonder why all of our cultural and entertainment institutions have all but disappeared, and our resources in these areas, for the most part, have been undeveloped.

title: Leningrad Shows the Way in Making Use of Trash
description: LENINGRADIn the flatlands seven miles southwest of this historic city of 4.3 million residents sprawls a nondescriptlooking factory that thrives on garbage.

title: Better than James
description: The first thing to be said about Jan Morris is that she has emerged from her experiences as a firstclass writer. This was not something one could say with any great conviction about her previous persona, James Morris. Although there are good passages in The World of Venice, for instance, there are also some shockingly bad ones; possibly the affectation and pretentiousness, the occasional descents into Lawrence Durrell whimsy, were products of the insecurity he felt in his earlier role. Possibly we writers should all undergo the occasional sex change as a means of keeping us on our toes and generally toning us up. At all events, she now writes in a fine, robust, selfconfident style. If one can without offense. attribute sexual characteristics to prose style, I should say the new Morris was noticeably the more masculine, and it comes as something of a shock, when she is describing a journey across Singapore harbor, to read: Spray got in our eyes, oil got on our skirts.

title: SCHMIDT ASSAILED BY FRENCH REDS
description: PARIS, May 8  The French Communist Party, intensifying its flamboyant new campaign of nationalism, took after Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today, saying he behaved like a disdainful sovereign toward France, and attacked President Valry Giscard d'Estaing for transforming France into a German American protectorate.

title: Tentative NBC Pact Is Set by Writers And Technicians
description: WASHINGTON. May 8 (AP)  Tentative agreement was reached early today to end a fiveweek strike of 1,700 technicians and newswriters with the National Broadcasting Company, according to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: ROBERT CALDWELL, EDUCATOR, 93, DIES
description: Robert G. Caldwell, former minister to Bolivia and to Portugal and Dean of Humanities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died of a heart attack yesterday in the Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 93 years old and lived in Fishkill, N.Y.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: GERTRUDE STEIN and William Shakespeare both commented, perhaps definitively, on the problem of psuedonymetry. What's in a name? asked the great English bard. A rose by any other name will smell as sweet.

title: Cancer and Pollution
description: AS New Jersey officials weaken the state's stringent environmental pollution controls in an effort to prevent industries from moving to states with weaker standards, the Cancer Institute of New Jeriey reports that cancer deaths in the state occur at a higher rate than anywhere else in the country.

title: Joe Namath's Shoes
description: TAKE your picka day atthe races; Joe Namath's sneakers (autographed); a Caribbean cruise; a cocktail party (with six waiters) for you and 99 friends; a 19thcentury dollhouse; a balloon voyage for two; a side of beef, cut and wrapped for your freezer; a sailing lesson; your choice from a host of paintings, books, clothes and objets d'art and objets white elephant.

title: May Margaret Stokes Dies; Volunteer Worker in 3 Wars
description: May Margaret Stokes, a volunteer worker in three wars and widow of J. Stogdell Stokes, a Philadelphia industrialist and former president of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, died Thursday at her home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. She was 89 years old.

title: DINING OUT
description: HALFWAY between what? Hoboken and Somerville? Two Howard Johnsons? Great food and mediocre food? Probably had something to do with stagecoaches. No matter. Halfway House is a good place to keep in mind if circumstances put you on Route 22, one of New Jersey's foremost neon jungles.*Halfway House, Route 22. Mountainside. (201) 2322171.

title: FOOD
description: IF food, like clothing, was judged according to excellence, French puffpastry, that flakev, buttery basis for pattyshells, cream horns and croissants, to mention a few of its uses, would surely rank as the haute couture of baking.

title: Adventures Of a Mathematician
description: Biographical history, as taught in our public schools, is still largely a history of boneheads: ridiculous kings and queens, paranoid political leaders, compulsive voyagers, ignorant generalsthe flotsam and jetsam of historical currents. The men who radically altered history, the great creative scientists and mathematicians, are seldom mentioned if at all.

title: Men Who Stand Out And Why
description: THEIR professions coyer a broad range: salesman and aerospace engineer, lighting designer and marketing executive, copywriter and college counselor.

title: Mrs. Twining, Harold Fates Marry on L.I.
description: Margery Gerdes Twining Laurel Hollow, Syosset, L. I., daughter of Mrs. John Gerdes of New York and the late Mr. Gerdes, was married yesterday morning in Cold Spring Harbor. L.I., to Harold Leighton Fates of Cold Spring Harbor, and Winhall. Vt., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Fates of Orange, N. J.

title: What's New? Old Shows
description: When one goes to the theater these days, it is often a step into a time machine. Thus far, half of this season's shows24 out of 48have been revivals. Of that number, 20 have been plays and four musicals. Among those still playing are My Fair Lady, Who's Afraid of Virinia Woolf?, The Royal Family, Very Good Eddie, The Threepenny Opera, The Heiress and Lady From the Sea. In addition, Off Broadway and even Off Off Broadway were struck by the antiquary fever, trying to revive plays as distant as Our American Cousin.

title: Stage: The Love of Don Perlimplin
description: The Love of Don Perlimplin and Belisa in Her Garden isn't usually counted among Garcia Lorca's major plays; mainly because it is short. But in its brevity it manages the same quicksilver turns on desire and frustration as Yerma and The House of Bernarda Alba.

title: Glenn Loucks Games Summaries
description: Glenn Loucks Games Summaries

title: Borman to the rescue
description: Last January, Frank Borman spent a day loading baggage onto a conveyor belt outside the Miami International Airport. The astronaut who commanded Apollo 8, now the president of Eastern Air Lines, wore his habitual white shirt and tie as he assisted Eastern's skycaps, who were being overworked because of strikes at other airlines. His labor was publicrelations gesture, pure and simplea wildly flamboyant one by Borman's standardsbut it was also indicative of a leveling process at Eastern that Borman hopes will help save his airline from financial disaster.

title: Apartment. House on Dodge Site Rejected by Community Board
description: The design of a 33story apartment building to replace the shuttered, sixstory Dodge Mansion on Fifth Avenue at 61st Street has been rejected by Community Board 8.

title: Westchester Road Tolls Are Less Likely
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 8The threat of new tolls on Westchester County's parkways appeared this week to have receded with a promise by the state to begin construction within two years of a final, threemile extension of the Sprain Brook Parkway.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Naked Angels
description: The emergence in the late 1950's of the major Beat writersGinsberg, Kerouac, Burroughswas and remains the most spectacular literary event in postWorld War II America, a storm of lurid publicity and livid critical counterattack like nothing ever known on these shores. To a remarkable extent, the Beats are still regarded today in the distorting frame of that moment of horror and shocked delight, as if it were still necessary to take sides either with disdainful mandarins like Norman Podhoretz (The KnowNothing Bohemians) or with the first, intoxicated young male audience of On the Road (young women weren't nearly so crazy about it, as I recall). There are reasons for this, and John Tytell admirably explores at least the main one in his flawed but essential book, Naked Arrgels.

title: A Bonus for Some
description: The move to a fee is not the only change under way in the credit card business. Some institutions, with new powers to offer credit services to their customers, are offering inducements to those who use those services.

title: Outbreak of Brawls in Baseball Puts Beanball Rule Under More Scrutiny
description: Baseball, a sport often criticized as tame alongside hockey and football, is looking for ways to strengthen its rules against violence on the field because of the recent outbreak of beanball wars and team fights.

title: UNPLEDGED VOTES COULD DETERMINE G.O.P. CANDIDATE
description: DETROIT, May 8Uncommitted delegates from a dozen states, including New York, could determine whether Pressident Ford or Ronald Reagan wins tha Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Humphrey, in Memo To Johnson in 1965, Warned of Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 8When Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was Vice President in 1965. he warned President Johnson of fears that escalating the United States involvement in Vietnam would be detrimental to the nation, according to a report published here tonight and confirmed by the Senator's aides.

title: Bridge: Triumph Over Adversity
description: THE most important contract bridge event In New Jersey, the Grand National Teams, ended recently, but only after a major auto accident had delayed the final match. The result was a triumph for a foursome that included 17yearold Martin Fleisher of Teaneck. He became the youngst player ever to win a District Grand National title.

title: BRITAIN TO MAKE HBOMB MATERIAL
description: The British Government has decided to manufacture tritium, an essential ingredient in the making of hydrogen bombs and to abandon the present reliance on United States supplies.

title: General
description: EDWARD KENNEDY AND THE CAMELOT LEGACY, by James MacGregor Burns. (Norton. $11.95.) Thorough, unauthorized biography of the Senator by one of the legacy's academic executors.

title: Ford Praises Truman as Man of the People
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 8  President Ford, mingling emotional affection with hope, looked back fondly here today on Harry S. Truman and 1948.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Representative Wilbur D. Mills says he thought he was dying of a brain tumor before he realized he was an alcoholic.

title: Book Ends
description: Words & Music. The recent announcement by the Chappell Music Co. that it will publish and distribute trade books seems a case of fair's fair, since book publishers have been increasingly involved in distributing and, in some cases, packaging songbooksthat is, collections of words and music. Not only have they been distributing songbooks, which are usually produced by music publishers, who hold the copyrights, but also producing their own packagespersonalityoriented collections ay rock star composerperformers; lavish coffee table books, such as those on the lyrics of Cole Porter and George and Ira Gershwin, for the adult market, or Knopf's elaborately designed collection of the songs of Bernie Taupin (Elton John's lyricist) for the rock fans; theme songbooks, such as Quadrangle's Great Songs of the Sixties; and pure personality songbooks, such as Chappell's The Judy Garland Souvenir Songbook, a sort of hybrid of the coffeetable and pure songbook genres, containing words and music of songs identified with Miss Garland and distributed in bookstores by Barnes & Noble and music stores by Chappell. The next step was obviously for the music publisher to produce mostly text trade book and distribute it to bookstoreswhich is just what Chappell doing with its first bona fide book. Flow I Write Songs, by Tom T. Hall, the Country and Western singercomposer.

title: Roots Can
description: With little or no special equipment, and at practically no expense, almost anyone can be a root sculptorthat is, collect appealing looking roots of trees or large shrubs and then clean, finish and mount them for display. The hobby combines outdoor exploration with perception and creativity as the enthusiast develops an artist's eye and a craftsman's skill.

title: MUSIC BY NIBLOCK DONE AT THE BROOK
description: Adjacent tones from strategically placed speakers cluster against one another and resolate with tones being played by a bassonist and cellist, who are slowly circling the room. The listener's attention drifts from process to process, here sizing up discrete differences hetween a live and taped bassoon note, there following a beelike swarm of strong harmonics. Occasionally the sound begins to shimmer like the horizon on a warm day, or to bum ominously like the vibrations of a vast machine.

title: Music in Review
description: There were a lot of young people on the stage of Alice Tully Hall last Wednesday night, but judging by the nature of the program and the performance, you would never have guessed it. The Bergen Youth Orchestra, founded eight years ago by its conductor, Eugene Minor, had crossed the Hudson from Paramus, N.J., to make its New York debut, and it was joined in the excursion by the Newark Boys Chorus.

title: Phone Calls About Sex Allegedly Monitored
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (AP)  Conversations about sex have been monitored and broadcast over loudspeakers at offices of Mill Valley's telephone company, according to a former operator there.

title: Searching For the Ox
description: Louis Simpson's seventh volume of poetry is a tremendously refreshing book, as entertaining and enlightening to read as a collection of short stories by Isaac Bashevis Singer or a short novel by Saul Bellow. So many modern poets, even some of the best, seem to want nothing more than to write in what Eliot called the first voice of poetrythe voice of the poet talking to himselfor to nobody. Simpson, by contrast, prefers Eliot's second voice, that of the poet addressing an audience.

title: Soccer Gains Fans
description: SOCCER has exploded into a widely popular sport for youngsters in New Jersey;

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, a quintessential Victorian building by Frank Furness, the Philadelphia master of the style's oldest extravaganzas, opened on April 24, 1876 for the nation's Centennial year. The cerulean blue ceiling of its grand stairhall was studded with silver stars, the walls were a gilded geometry of stylized flowers on a rich, red ground above incised floral patterns; ornamental bronze stair rails boasted bouquets of clusteredglobe gas lights sprouting from elaborate, spiky stems. Colors were plum, blue, gold, sand and olive green. There was no Victorian brown anywhere.

title: The Other Jersey Shore: No Boardwalks. Or Neon. Or Crowds
description: Mae Griffith, matriarch of the tiny bayside town of Sea Breeze, N.J., and proprietor of Mae's Seabreeze Tavern, leafs through ber collection of old photos and yellowed news clippings. We were second to Atlantic City once, she muses. She pulls out a picture of the steamship John A. Warner, which ferried hundreds of Philadelphians to Sea Breeze when it was a posh resort. In the 1SSO's and 90's the town boasted a boardwalk, hand pavilions and a festive carousel.

title: Missing The Green
description: IN an apparent effort to economize, the Carey administration has ordered that all stateowned golf courses be closed one day a week. Those courses scheduled for closing on the Island include five at Bethpage and three at Sunken Meadow.

title: Usually, Washington Does Only What Seems Necessary
description: PARISAs a continental power with more than adequate food supplies, natural resources and technology, the United States, perhaps better than any other nation, could survive a period of economic warfare. Yet, as oil price increases and several postwar recessions have shown, even American prosperity is not immune to damage.

title: PEOPLE
description: Wendell Hertig, Taylor, a Princeton graduate who now lives in retirement there, is a man of science. He worked in Nylon research for the duPont Company, taught chemistry and the history of science at Princeton and headed the science department at Lawrenceville School. So what is tie doing coediting, with Jacques Barzun, the mammoth Fifty Classics of Crime Fiction, 19001950? Well, Mr. Taylor has been a

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Headliners
description: Eugene Hollander, once one of New York State's most prominent nursing home operators, has been sentenced by a Federal judge to spend five nights a week in jail for up to six months, and ordered to sever all connections with any occupation connected with the care or custody of other people. The sentence was in connection with his pleading guilty to Federal charges of inflating Medicare reimbursement claims. Mr. Hollander still faces sentencing on similar state charges involving Medicaid fraud.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In 1931 when Jean Renoir's producers were given their first screening of La Chienne they were appalled. They had understood that Renoir would deliver a comedy. Instead they saw what they took to be a somber melodrama about a middleaged, middleclass man, a henpecked husband who murders the prostitute he has fallen in love with and who, after an innocent man is convicted of the crime, winds up as a jolly bum, a clochard of the boulevards surviving on tips handed out by the swells whose car doors he opens, scrambling for their cigarette butts when he happens to get lucky.

title: Notes: Hustling Lipstick, Chopping Classics, Rating Previews
description: LOS ANGELES When the audience at a Pasadena sneak preview saw the title, Lipstick, and the star billing of a fashion model, Margaux Hemingway, they expected a sequel to Shampoo, says the film's producer, Freddie Fields. What that audience did not expect was a violent rape scene. And what producer Fields did not expect was 200 people demanding their money back and uniformed policemen, two abreast, in the theater lobby to keep them in line.

title: Letters
description: As you can see [from the snapshot below, left]. I could have served as the model for the picture on the cover of The Times Magazine of April 11. But the description of this woman on the contents page is another matter entirely: American woman (nonlibber)  she and her sisters have been turning out in droves to vote down the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: C. U. N. Y. Championships
description: Onemle run1. Slimmer, Queens, 4 minutes 23.5 seconds; 2. Armeru, City College, 4:27.1; 3. Marton; Baruch, 4:29.4; 4. Carr, City College, 4:37.6; 5, Cea, Lehman, 4:38.4.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CONCORD DIGITAL WATCHES

title: Black Man and Baseball: A Melting Pot Is Dented
description: The brilliant success stories of such a variety of hyphenated Americans kept the myth of the American melting pot alive in baseball. Moreover, the success of such players mirrored the processes of invasion and succession that students of immigration advanced in support of the myth.

title: $65,000 Damage in Crash
description: SHEFFIELD, Pa., May 8 (AP) A truck carrying 30 tons of coal caused damages estimated at over $65,000 in this Warrior County community, but no one was injured. The authorities said that a tractortrailer rig driven by Diane Tingue, 24yearsold, of Great Valley, N Y., went out of control Wednesday on U.S. 6, crossed the road and hit two parked cars, then struck a tavern, tearing the front off the building.

title: Borg vs. Vilas: Friends Who Hate During Match
description: DALLAS, May 8They are more than doubles partners; they are friends. They practice together by day and party together by night. They are together so often they have begun even to resemble each other, down to the headbands both wear during tennis matches.

title: Merged Arab Forces
description: ABU DHABI, May 7 (Reuters) Leaders of the United Arab Emirates have agreed to merge their armed forces under, a central command. The commander of the forces of the sevenstate alliance will be Maj. Gen. Awwad alKhalidi, a member of the Jordanian armed forces assigned to the Emirates forces.

title: Some Have Faith, Some Skepticism About the Perfectibility of Technology
description: WASHINGTONOn June 8 the citizens of California will vote on an initiative proposal which could eventually end the use of nuclear reactors in that state.

title: PEOPLE
description: TO THE it of names of local sons and daughters making good, add those of Doris Kearns and Michael McKean. Miss Karns, who was born in Rockville Centro is the author of the muchspeculatedabout ??? Johmon & the American Dream ??? Jr. McKean, though born in Manhattan, was raised in Sea Cliff. Television viewers know him best as Lenny Kolowski in the ABCTV show Laverne & Shirley.

title: The Irish Look Back
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS The Bicentennial has aroused renewed pride among Bergen County's Irish community leading people of Irish descent have organized the Shamrock Guard of Honor, a social group that will hold a blacktie dinner at the Sheraton Heights Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights on Thursday.

title: Notes: Dance vs. Emmys and a New Nureyev
description: Two nominations for the television world's coveted Etnmy Awards have been captured by a couple of televised dance programsthe Jaffrey special which was presented in Channel 13's Dance in America series, and Three by Balanchine with the New York City Ballet, which was presented in cnannel 13's Great Performances series. The awards will be announced May 17. Even if on of these shows is named a winner, however, it won't be singled out as the best dance program of the year, but rather as the Outstanding Classical Music Program.

title: BRIDGE
description: The World Team Olympiad which begins today in Monte Carlo and continues for two weeks will be conducted on a new formula, one which most American observers regard with disfavor. The 46 competing countries, ranging from the Italian's, defending champions and favorites, to a team from New Guinea, making its first appearance on the international scene, will play a complete roundrobin of 16deal matches. But instead of using this as steppingstone to semifinal and final play, as in the past, this will be the end. The winner of the roundrobin will be the world champion.

title: Nathan Hale Fiance of Miss Skluth
description: Barbara A. Skiuth, who is working for a Ph.D. degree at New York University, and Nathan Hale, a partner in the New York City law firm of Casey, Lane & Mittendorf, will be married next month.

title: POLITICS
description: THE fortunes of politics: Today's winner is often tomorrow's loser and vice versa.

title: TV Deal Is Close, Woosnam Implies
description: Phil Woosnam, the optimistic commissioner of the North American Soccer League, predicted last Friday that four to five million youth will be involved in soc cer here in the next decade and that this country would be the center of soccer in the world. He also said he had been talking to all three national television networks about a contract and that We've got an offer.

title: Brown, on Stump, Reveals Style Marked by Paradox
description: BALTIMORE, May 8On his latest campaign swing across Maryland, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California faced a question at a packed and excited student rally, on the fu ture of the space program. The question touched on one of his enthusiasms and the apostle of lowered expectations in government was suddenly speaking about the prospects for space colonization.

title: Mafia Figure Convicted On Income Tax Charges
description: DETROIT, May 8 (UPI)A reputed Mafia leader, Anthony Giacalone, has been convicted on three counts of attempting to evade more than $103,000 in Federal income taxes.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: New research indicates that the danger of depletion of the earth's ozone layer by the fluorocarbons used in many spray cans and refrigerating systems may not be so grave as had been thought.

title: TrabertKing Team Gains in Doubles
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., May 8 It takes a time to oil up the oldsters. Tony Trabert and Billie Jean King, the defenders, needed JOB minutes to subdue burly Hugh Stewart and Martina Navatilova 57, 63, 75, in the opening round of the Vitalis and Clairol mixed doubles tournament.

title: The Shrinking Window
description: In some cases, they want to provide better views for luxury tenants, or to add variety to faades by altering patterns of perforation, or to reflect rather than disguise the uses of interior space.

title: Laurelton and the Integration Fight
description: With its rows of Spanishstucco and Tudorstyle houses, sitting behind thick hedges and carefully manicured lawns, Laurelton looks like a typical middleclass homeowner community.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The convertible lives, at least for a little while.

title: 2 ALUMNI RECALL FRESH AIR CAMP
description: Now that the sun shines stronger and longer, bringing city dwellers touches of green, ??? notes of bird song, glimpses of color in window boxes and whiffs of foul, unbearably hot air, the thoughts of youngsters who have been there turn to the Friendly Towns and camps of the Fresh Air Fund.

title: U.S. Wins at Bridge
description: The United States won the world bridge team championship yesterday in Monte Carlo, defeating the Italian Blue Team and breaking a 20year jinx. It was the 16th time the two countries had met in derisive world championship matches since 1957 Page 29.

title: Christine Semenenko Fiancee Of Anthony Michael Warrender
description: The engagement of Christine Semenenko to Anthony Michael Warrender has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Serge Semenenko of Boston and Wianno, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Lord and Lady Bruntisfield of Gstaad, Switzerland.

title: Volunteer Group Making Changes in Manhattan Valley, on Upper West Side
description: A volunteer, nonprofit community organization is slowly changing the face of Manhattan Valley, a poverty pocket on the Upper West Side blighted by abandoned and burnedout buildings.

title: Black Man and Baseball: Disillusionments of Youth
description: Every time I walk down St. Nicholas Avenue between 145th and 141st Streets, where I lived, the memories keep jumping out at me. The stickball games, the black Joe DiMaggios, the black Mel Otts, the black Harry Dannings; the great Mel Allen and Red Barber broadcasts of the Yankee and Dodgers games; running up to the newsstand every Friday afternoon to get the Sporting News, at that time an allbaseball publication.

title: Product Potential: Does Marisa Have It?
description: In cigarettes, one smokes the advertising. In fragrances, one wears the advertising. And in our case, one believes in the imagery.

title: CARLOS SANTANA PLAYS AT BEACON
description: Carlos Santana can probably be credited with the invention or at least the popularization of Latin rock. His San Franciscobased band, Santana, topped the charts just a few years ago, turning out lightly structured songs with repetitive catchverses and churning, surging percussion overlays.

title: Letters: The Little Train That Wasn't
description: I was amazed to discover that Amtrak advertises in its timetables and cells tickets for a nonexistent train. Recently, I had occasion to take the Coast Starlight from San Francisco to Seattle, with my ultimate destination being Vancouver, B.C.

title: ETHNIC RENEWAL
description: BALTIMORE On a recent morning, Mrs. Matilda Koval led her brigade of neighborhood women on an inspection tour of a dingy alley near Patterson Park. As her troops, called Community Taking Action, rounded the corner row house, garbage came pouring out the window. Who do you think you are? the grandmotherly Mrs. Koval shouted. She phoned downtown to the city health inspectors, who fined the culprit $40.

title: Janet Laughlin, Law Student, Will Be Bride
description: Dr. John Seth Laughlin of Starsdale N. Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Janet Judd Litighlin, to Charles Lynde Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Babcock of Brooklyn. The, wedding is planned for next month.

title: Albany State Police Used Rightist Data on Liberals
Notes: The Rewards of Being A Network ExPresident
description: One reason Robert Wood received a handsome fouryear deal to produce programs exclusively for CBS after his recent resignation as president of the network was that it would keep him from doing what Fred Silverman is doing. Silverman, who had been program chief for CBS until last spring, went to ABC in a similar capacity and is using all the skills he mastered at CBS against his old team.

title: Miss Stratton Wed to John Repola
description: The marriage of Catherine Nelson Stratton to Col. John Repola, U.S.A.F., retired, took place yesterday afternoon in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Charles Gaines, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the President's House on the

title: Flyers vs. Canadiens for Cup: A Matter of Styles
description: Two disparate philosophies of hockey will collide tonight at 7 o'clock in the Forum in Montreal when the Canadiens and the Philadelphia Flyers open their Stanley Cuo final series.

title: Marina Stern Has Nuptials
description: Marina Wallach Stern and Arthur Grover Newmyer 3d were married yesterday evening; by Rabbi Ronald Sobel in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: C. E. G. Lloyd Jr. Weds Sally Hill; 8 Attend Bride
description: St James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sally Baker Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Jerome Hill of Bridgehampton, L.I., to Charles E. G. Lloyd Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd of New Canaan, Conn.

title: DIRECTOR RESIGNS AT RIGHTS GROUP
description: ATLANTA, May 8George H. Esser Jr., executive director of the Southern Regional Council, has resigned after four years of leading the Atlantabased civil rights group through a major reorganization.

title: Picture credits
description: 4SHERRY WOLF

title: Carol Johnson Becomes Bride
description: Carol Ann Johnson and Steven John Beslity were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Bryant Kirkland. A reception was held at the Georgian Suite, 1A East 77th Street.

title: St. John's Streak Stopped by Post
description: GREENVALE, L.I., May 8 The strong pitching of senior righthander, Jeff Albert, and a fourrun outburst in the fourth inning powered C. W. Post to a 52 victory over St. John's, today. The Pioneers victory, their 19th against 6 defeats, stopped St. John's 22game unbeaten streak. The Redmen are now 2231.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  When the Butcher boys, Jake and C. H. Jr., walk into a bank they don't already own, the phone calls begin: Are the fastmoving brothers from Maynardville taking over?

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Women. This week's success story is about a book that was not really written, but rather evolved. Even its begetters  young women, married, single, inbetween are a bit hazy about the details. They recall that their consciousness was raised at a Boston women's conference back in 1969, a time when the feminist movement was percolating furiously. Some time after that some of them began conducting a course on Women and Their Bodies and assembled a mimeographed study guide to go with it. Later, calling themselves the Boston Women's Health Book Collective, a dozen of them issued a revision of the material in printed form. They are definite about what started happening in 1971, when Simon & Schuster took over their publication. In the next five years 850,000 copies of Our Bodies, Our Selves were sold in paper covers.

title: Engineers Ban on Dredging Splits Floridians
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla.Environmentalists are hailing the Army Corps of Engineers as the newest hero among government agencies, but the developer and many residents of this lush subtropical island are accusing the corps of betraying them.

title: JOHN J. BRUGGER SR.
description: John J. Brugger Sr., a retired photoengraver for The New York Times, died Thursday at the Peninsula Hospital Center in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 67 years old and lived al 10500 Shorefront Parkway, Rockaway Beach.

title: The Region
description: In the last 30 years, dozens of proposals to reform New York State's court system have been made, with little result. Governor Carey has now offered the Legislature the most cornprehensive program to date, incorporating concepts held essential by reform advocates. He is also expected to fail.

title: Changing Leaders of a Changing Church
description: O NE by one they are taking leave of the hierarchy of the Catholic Church in America. They are the bishops and cardinals who were fitted out to rule the church of the past.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: INFLATION is going to get worse before it gets better. The economic forecasters are unanimous on this point. Their unanimity itself might be reason for doubting the predictioncrystal balls have been as cloudy in fpretelling the pace of the recovery as they were in sensing the depths of the recession. But quite apart from the accuracy of forecasts, there is evidence already that more inflation is already happening. Only the longerrange implications remain uncertainas usual.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: This Thursday the prestigious American Numismatic Society will open its longanticipated Bicentennial exhibit, Money in Early America in the East Hall of the A.N.S. museum, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets. The free exhibit will be open until mid1977 during the museum's regular hours, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., Tuesday through Saturday, and 1 to 4 P.M. on Sunday (only the exhibit halls, not the library and coin rooms, are open Sundays). The museum is, of course, eminently worth a visit at any time of year, regardless of special exhibits, since the A.N.S. is one of the world's leading numismatic research institutions.

title: Work Starting on New Subway For Elevated Jamaica Section
description: Construction will start this week on the new subway line in Jamaica, Queens, to replace the easterly end of the Jamaica Avenue elevated line, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: Tale of Two Committees
description: The Interior and Insular Affairs Committee of the House seems determined to draw a contrast between itsplf and its opposite number in the Senateand one that does it no credit. On two bills important to the environmental integrity of the West, the Senate committee has successfully sponsored strong legislation only to See it watered down by subcommittees on the other side of the Capitol, with only a fighting chanch that the full committee of the House will undo the damage.

title: The Gashouse Gang
description: In 1934 the St. Louis Cardinals, known as the Gashouse Gang for their disreputable appearance, came from behind to win the National League pennant, and took the World Series from the Detroit Tigers.

title: THOMAS G. MacPHERSON
description: Thomas G. MacPherson, author and executive editor of Boys Life from 1951 to 1961, died Friday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 5 Hillside Avenue. Jamesburg, N.J.

title: Solti New York Can't Get Enough Of Him
description: Modesty ill becomes a master, and Georg Solti knows it. That was evident as the maestro surveyed the worldwide competition on the eve of three performances with his Chicago Symphony at Carnegie Hall commencing on Monday. The performances, sold out far in advance, will include a much anticipated concert version of Wagner's The Flying Dutchman.

title: Food
description: Each year when May draws near, my mind turns back a half century to the days when I was a small boy in southern Illinois and my father taught me about morels. My father was an itinerant Irish glass blower, a frustrated writer and a passionate mushroom hunter. He had been schooled in the knowhow and delights of mushroom picking by his father, and handed on what he knew to me as if it were a valuable family heirloom, which indeed it was.

title: Peter Penny's Dance
description: Long ago on a ship of the King's Navy there lived a sailor named Peter Penny, who could dance the sailor's hornpipe better than any other man. He danced in the galley instead of cooking and in the crow's nest instead of looking and he danced on the deck instead of scrubbing andbecause he was better at dancing than he was at being a sailorhe left the navy to dance around the world.

title: Harvard Crew Still Unbeaten As It Conquers Penn and Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS. Md., May 8, Rowing a fragile, low freeboard 66foot racing shell on the swells of the Severn River in the springtime is always an experience to be endured and the Harvard crew did best at overcoming adversity in the Adams Cup regatta today. The Crimson varsity eight defeated Penn and Navy to remain undefeated this season and it also recorded consecutive victory No. 26 of an ongoing streak that began in 1973 and may never end.

title: Godliness Off and Racing
description: It is a fact known to all the righteous that gambling is a base and sinful pursuit and that horse racing, being a vehicle for the vice, is art instrument of the devil. In the circumstances, it is heartening to note that when the collection plate is passed in the Church of Christ in West Mansfield, Ohio, the parishioner who gets it up most generousiy is a maw ma harness horse named Rambling Willie. Furthermore, next Saturday when the iniquitous are assembled in Baltimore for the 101st running of the Preakness, Stakes, something like 80 trotters and pacers at Monticello Raceway will be giving their all for St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, with full approval of Terence Cardinal Cooke, his vicar general, and the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: A. H. Marckwald 3d, Rollins 74, Weds Gertrude Freeman Kissel
description: Gertrude Freeman Kissel and A. Hunt Marckwald 3d were married yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay. A reception was given at the Colony Club.

title: FourAlarm Fun
description: NASSAU County has lined upan afternoon of firefighting nostalgia and high jinks in a Bicentennial Firemen's Salute at Eisenhower Park next Saturday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced the establishment of a task force on mental Hygiene service delivery to study the state's system of financing and delivering services to the mentally disabled and to recommend programs for the next legislative session to improve the system's effectiveness. The task force members, appointed by Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, were described in the announcement as representatives of state and local governmental units, program advocates, consumers, proyiders, professionals and laymen.

title: GARDENING
description: AREADER from Short Hills would like planting suggestions for a difficult area, one that is wet and poorly drained, mostly shaded but sunny at one end. What would grow in such a situation? she asks.

title: Herbert M. French Dead at 81; A Foreign Desk Editor at Times
description: Herbert M. French, who for many years had handled the editing of late foreign news for The New York Times, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 100 Bank Street in Greenwich Village.

title: Opera: Cosi at Hunter
description: The Bronx Opera, which regularly brings its productions to the Hunter College Playhouse, often tackles works that are rarely performed, and so contributes something special to the local musical scene. Its latest production, however, was of Mozart's Cosi fan tutte, which was given at Hunter on Friday night. What was interesting in this case was the staging of Louis Galterio, who has shown himself in the past to be unusually resourceful in directing comic operas.

title: PARK EXTENSION SOUGHT BY TRUMP
description: The extension of Riverside Park from 72d Street to 59th Street and the realignment of the West Side Highway are major components of a plan by Donald J. Trump to redevelop the 60th Street yards of the Penn Central railroad for housing.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: New Brunswick Tax Magic Circle All in Terminology

title: An Education Marathon Held at P.S. 175 in Harlem
description: You say to me educationl marathon, and I say yes! dedared Betty Ann Davis, a secand grade teacher at Public School 175 in Harlem. Every day should be one.

title: EAST BERLIN GETS VAST CIVIC CENTER
description: EAST BERLIN, May 4East Germany has opened a huge new civic center in the heart of East Berlin, a rectangular block of gleaming white marble and bronzetinted glass officially known as the Palace of the Republic.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Car Club of America races, at Pocono International Raceway, Long Pond, Pa. First heat of Formula 5,000, 12:30 P.M.; 98mile Formula 5,000 race, at 3:15 P.M.

title: City Council Schedules Hearings This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week:

title: Asking Uncle Sam for a Glass of Water
description: AFTER six years of faraboveaverage rainfall in the Northeast, scientists are completing what is described as the most ambitious study yet made of the water problems of the area, a study that indicates that serious water shortages are not a question of if, but of when.

title: The Guest Word
description: I've never been much of a hand to win a prize except for marriage. That's my favorite quote from a week of words, and came from Walter D. Edmonds (remember Drums Along the Mohawk 40 years back?) in response to his receiving the National Book Award for Children's Literature.

title: TALKS DUE TODAY IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: The two sides in the weekold apartment workers strike are to meet this afternoon in the offices of the State Mediation Board Chairman, Vincent McDonnell, at which time Local 32 of the Service Employees International Union is expected to present a counteroffer to one made last week by management representatives.

title: GUNMEN IN SPAIN ATTACK MARCHERS
description: MONTEJURRA, Spain, May 9 (AP)Terrorists shot into a crowd of 5,000 dissident monarchists, killing one and injuring three, as they scrambled through mud and boulders to a mountaintop rally here today.

title: New York City's Red Tape Snarling Fiscal Reforms
description: When several dozen public relations people who worked for New York City were laid off last winter as part of the city's costcutting plan, two of them were put on two different lists in reports that the city was preparing for submission to the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: M. B. SKAGGS, 88, SET UP SAFEWAY
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 9 (AP)M. B. Skaggs, a founder of Safeway Stores Inc., the country's largest supermarket chain, died yesterda# at Mertz1U Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Auto Layoffs Keep On Despite Overtime
description: ST. LOUIS, May 7  Bob Burkes, a worker who has been laid off since January 1974 from the Ford assembly plant here, is worried about whether he will be able to raise $40 to buy food stamps.

title: Playoff Results
description: World Team Tennis

title: Warren Receives Copernicas Prize For Life's Poetry
description: Robert Penn Warren has wor the 1976 Copernicus Award for lifetime achievement as a poet.

title: Sherry E. Sobelman Wed to Barry Blank
description: Sherry Ellen Sobelman, daughter of Harold L. Sobelman of Holliswood, Queens, and the late Mrs. Sobelman, was married yesterday afternoon to Barry S. Blank, on of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Blank of New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Wilbur Wood Out for Year With Broken Knee
description: Manager Paul Richards of the Chicago White Sox is going to have to dig deep into his young pitching staff. Yesterday Wilbur Wood, who annually starts at least 40 games and logs at least 300 innings pitched, was lost to the White Sox for, the remainder of the season.

title: Danish Royalty Arrives
description: Queen Margrethe and Prince Henrik of Denmark arrived in New York City today for a monthlong visit marking the Bicentennial. The royal couple flew into Kennedy International Airport and after a short stop were to go on to Norfolk, Va., On a U.S. Air Force jet. They will be the guests of President and ??? tomorrovi.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS

title: Parisians, Enjoying a Lull in Protests, Find joie de Vivre in Streets and Parks
description: PARIS, May 9  After months of watching organized Parisians demonstrate, unorganized Parisians have regained virtual control of the city's streets and squares.

title: East German Sets Women's 400 Mark
description: EAST BERLIN, May 9 (UPI) Christina Brehmer of East Germany set a world record today in the women's 400meter run at a national track and field meet in Dresden. Her time was 49.77 seconds.

title: Manes Fighting Mayoral Plans On Use of $102 Million in Aid
description: A bitter, behindthescenes dispute over allocation of $102 million in Federal communitydevelopment funds has held up for three months the city's application to Washington for the funds.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: DALEY URGES CURB ON MINORS FILMS
description: CHICAGO, May 9If Mayor Richard J. Daley has his way, as he often does. Chicago will soon become the first major city in the country to ban children under 18 years of age from viewing excessively violent films.

title: STEVEDORE CITED IN $100,000 BRIBE
description: The president of five major stevedoring companies operating on the East and Gulf Coasts has been charged with fraud and deceit in accepting a$100,000 bribe to unload ships of the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company during a longshoremen's strike in 1971, Waterfront Commission officials announced yesterday.

title: EGYPT TO LOOSEN CURRENCY CONTROL
description: CAIRO, May 8 (UPI)Egypt has decided to revoke some restrictions on its foreign currency market, making the value of the Egyptian pound subject to supply and demand, Economy Minister Zaki Shafei said today.

title: Little Is Victor By Shot
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., May 9Sally Little holed out a 75foot blast from a sand trap in front of the 18th green today and won the Women's International golf tournament.

title: Disastrous Policy Cited
description: When will they ever learn? the Citizens Budget Commission asked in its annual report, released yesterday.

title: About Dusters and DustUps
description: The most interesting thing about the brawls that have enlivened baseball's first month is the Identity of the combatants. The Giants have gone to battle at least twice and so have the Cardinals, and in recent years these have been among the most docile clubs in the game, making trouble for nobody. Back in the days when the Giants home base was New York and John McGraw was their leader, the manager punched more people in a social evening at the Lambs Club than the San Francisco team does in a season. And for the last naitaozen years the Cardinals have performed with a decorum that would bring a blush of shame to the St. Louis Gashouse Gang 40 years ago. There has been raffish deportment on the part of other habitually quiescent groups, too, like the Angels, Padres and Indians, but in one respect the combatants have been faithful to tradition: nobody has thrown a punch that would break the Mother Superior's glasses.

title: M. B. SKAGGS, 88, SET UP SAFEWAY
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 9 (AP)M. B. Skaggs, a founder of Safeway Stores Inc., the country's largest supermarket chain, died yesterday at Merritt Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: L.I. Man in Ad Urges Trial Of SoninLaw in Slaying
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., May 9 (UPI)A New York man whose daughter was killed placed a halfpage ad in today's FayetteVille ObserveiTimes asking the public to urge the United States Solicitor General to continue efforts to put her husband on trial for murder.

title: METHADONE FAILING, 2 RESEARCHERS SAY
description: CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI)Two medical researchers blame the Federal bureaucracy for the failure of methadone to live up to expectations in the rehabilitation of heroin addicts.

title: Oil Companies Resist Nigerian Controls by Reducing Activity
description: LAGOS, NigeriaNigeria, five years ago a compliant host to foreign oil companies, now rigidly controls their production and profits. New restrictions on pumping allowances and tax increases have become so severe, foreign oil executives say, that some companies are beginning to think that nationalization would be preferable.

title: Architecture Students Build Skill as Jobs Fade
description: Students in New York City schools of architecture have presented their teachers with a phenomenon confoundingly out of whack with the sense of balance central to the practice.

title: Nuclear Plants Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) Plans for two proposed nuclear power plants, in Tennessee and Wisconsin, were approved yesterday by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's advisory committee on reactor safeguards. One plant would be built by the Tennessee Valley Authority, on the Cumberland River near Hartsville, 40 miles northeast of Nashville, the other would be built by the Wisconsin Electric Power Company on Lake Koshkonong south of Fort Atkinson, Wis.

title: Ulrike Meinhof, an Anarchist Leader In Germany, Is Found Hanged in Cell
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, May 9 (AP)Ulrike Meinhof, on trial for nearly a year with three other members of the BaaderMeinhof anarchist group, was found hanged today in her maximum security cell, the Stuttgart prosecutor's office reported.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: States to Vote on AtomicPower Curb
description: LOS ANGELESProposals to restrict the growth of atomic power will be on the ballots of at least three states this year and possibly as many as 11.

title: Horacio Gutierrez Gives Engrossing Piano Recital
description: Horacio Gutierrez's pianism, is so fluent, powerful and polished that everything he played, in his recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall on Saturday night had an air of rightness about it. This young CubanAmerican virtuoso has an affinity with the keyboard that is given to few pianists, and it enables him to make distinctions of tone quality and dynamics that are not characteristic of most of the playing one hears.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is a rumble on the right that says Americans are tired of selfflagellation. A frontrunning candidate pledges that he won't mention Watergate during the campaign, and he may be relied upon not to belabor Vietnam, either. For the moment, that would appear to be paying off in the primaries: whether it is the best way to avoid new Watergates and new Vietnams is another question. Well, here is the story of another national crime, the wartime incarceration of 120,000 of our fellows because of their Japanese origin. It is a fascinating and shattering story, which no American who loves his country should ignore. Michiko Nishiyuro was a California teenager in February 1942 when President Roosevelt banished her to a concentration camp. Now Michi Weglyn, a costume designer, she recalls in Years of Infamy: The Untold Story of America's Concentration Camps: I believed, as did numerous Japanese Americans, that somehow the stain of dishonor we collectively felt for the treachery of Pearl Harbor must be eradicated, however great the sacrifice, however little we were responsible for it. In our immaturity and naivet, many of us who were American citizenstwothirds of the totalbelieved that this, under the circumstances, was the only way to prove our loyalty to a country which we loved.

title: Big Board Reports a Rise In Its 1975 Net Revenues
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its net revenues from operations jumped to $3.5 million last year from $287,000 in 1974. Record high levels of trading were largely responsible for the gain, the Big Board noted.

title: Auto Layoffs Keep On Despite Overtime
description: ST. LOUIS, May 7  Bob Burkes, a worker who has been laid off since January 1974 from the Ford assembly plant here, is worried about whether he will be able to raise $40 to buy food stamps.

title: GOV. BROWN TESTS DRIVE IN NEW YORK
description: With amiably spoken but bluntly worded allegations that Jimmy Carter is doing one thing and saying another, Gov Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California tested his new generation campaign for President in New York yesterday.

title: Princeton's Oarsmen Capture Carnegie Cup
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 Princeton's varsity eight won the Carnegie Cup today, beating Yale by one boat length and Cornell by a length and a half. The result left the Tigers ranked third in the East behind Harvard and Syracuse in advance of the Eastern sprint championships, which will be rowed here next Sunday.

title: Yanks Bow to A's, 43, in 12th
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 9 A clean sweep of California eluded the Yankees today even though they took a 32 lead into the ninth inning with Catfish Hunter pitching aaainst the Oakland A's.

title: Must Bills Add Urgency To Albany's Closing Rush
description: ALBANY, May 9  The languid pace of the last two weeks belies the urgency with which the legislative leaders are trying to whittle down their must listslists of bills that in their view absolutely have to be passed before the Legislature can end one of the grimmest sessions in recent years.

title: HospitalAide Work Urged for Juvenile Delinquents
description: The chairman of a State Assembly committee that has been studying juvenile delinquency recommended yesterday that youths convicted of violent crimes be ordered to serve as aides in hospitals where the impact of their conduct on victims would be clearly visible.

title: Giscard Says U.S. Difficulty In World Is Creating Anxiety
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (Reuters)President Valry Giscard d'Estaing says that the apparent difficulties of the United States in carrying out its foreign policy have created anxiety in the world.

title: Corporate Profile
description: On past form. Semon E Knudsen the 63yearold chairman of the beleaguered White Actor Corporation, always lands on his feet.

title: Grace Silvestre Bride of Robert Ivler
description: Grace Concepcion Silvestre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Atamicio Silvestre of Bacnotan, the Philippines, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Stephen Ivier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Ivler of Stamford, Conn.

title: U.S.OUTSPENDING SOVIET IN BIG SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A Central Intelligence Agency analysis made public today by Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, shows that in the last five years the United States outspent the Soviet Union almost 2 to 1 in the construction of major warships.

title: French Conservative Wins in Vote for Parliament Seat
description: TOURS, France, May 9 (Reu ters)The conservative Mayor of Tours, Jean Royer, won a surprisingly strong victory in a parliamentary byelection here today in which the leftist opposition captured a relatively low vote.

title: Advertising
description: This is going to be one big week in Lockhart, Tex., ending with the annual Chisholm Trail Roundup, a festival that includes a reenactment of the Battle of Plum Creek. That fight, in case it doesn't immediately stand out in your memory, was the last one between the settlers and the Comanches. The year was 1840.

title: REAGAN BROADENS LEAD OVER FORD IN DELEGATE RACE
description: Ronald Reagan widened his delegate lead over President. Ford by picking up 30 national convention votes from Oklahoma, Louisiana and Kansas over the weekend, while the President took 17 in Kansas, Missouri and Minnesota.

title: Tax Assessor Found Guilty
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 (UPI) The Buena Vista Township tax assessor was convicted this weekend of conspiring to take bribes from developers in return for keeping their assessments low. A jury in Atlantic County Court returned the verdict against Cosma Leone, who had been charged with conspiracy, misconduct in office and bribery.

title: Tonight's Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed in order of Post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Voters in a Prosperous Nebraska Town Are Not Excited by Primary Candidates
description: YORK, Neb., May 9There is an air of bustle about this wellscrubbed little town in eastern Nebraska, and the smell of prosperity hangs over it.

title: About New York
description: Saturday at 6 P.M. was the start of one of those rare, perfect evenings in Manhattan in May when all things seemed possible, so it wasn't altogether surprising that when Gov. Edmund (Jerry) Brown Jr. stepped out of the car that had brought him to fundraising cocktail party at a townhouse on East 62d Street, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was on the sidewalk waiting to greet him.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: It is, perhaps, all toe apparent that we can savor the learning of word origins with almost the same relish commonly reserved for smoked salmon, cold herring or caviar. Thus, we were intrigued a short while ago with a conversation shared with Narcissa Chamberlain, widow of the distinguished food authority, architect and etcher, Samuel Chamberlain.

title: A Lebanese Who Shuns Publicity Elias Sarkis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9Elias Sarkis has led a socially secluded life, making it a point to avoid publicity. It was not until April 29 that that he held his first news conterence  to announce that he was a candidate for the presidency of Lebanon. His resistance to publicity had been so successful that his supporters could not come up with a good photograph to use for his posters, even though he ran for president in 1970.

title: Regional Planners Repeat Criticism of Highway Plan
description: The Regional Plan Association, a private research agency concerned with the development of the New York New JerseyConnecticut greater metropolitan area, has ??? its criticism made a year ??? of highway construction proposals for New Jersey.

title: Recital: Polish Violin Bill
description: Hanna Lachert is a Polishborn violinist who is currently a member of the New York Philharmonic. But Miss Lachert has not abandoned her solo career in joining an orchestra, and in fact her solo recitals have been more interesting than most. That is partly a matter of her performing ability. But it is even more a question of programming.

title: Ford Adds a Day
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) President Ford decided today to add an extra day's campaigning in his home state this week.

title: National Public Radio Network Downplays News
description: W.ASHINGTON. May 8  A shift of emphasis away from news coverage and toward topics of personal interest to listeners, such as job satisfaction and astrology, Is under way at National Public Radio, a network of 190 stations largely fbranced with Federal money.

description: There are more than 3,000 summercamp counselor jobs for college students listed with the state, Philip Ross, the New York State Industrial Commis. sioner, said yesterday.

description: The following is a supple mentary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown refleets prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Goldwater States Ford Case in Nebraska
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 9President Ford left Nebraska yesterday after two days of campaigning, but he will not be unrepresented in the last 48 hours before the voters choose between him and Ronald Reagan in Tuesday's primary.

title: Kissinger Calls for an End Of U.S.Israel Wrangling
description: BALTIMORE, May 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kisinger said tonight that although peace negotiations must continue in the Middle East, the United States recognized that Israel faced serious dilemmas and risks in making further territorial concessions in return for less tangible Arab political moves.

title: ISRAEL TO ORDER SETTLERS TO QUIT A WEST BANK SITE
description: JERUSALEM, May 9  After a marathon 10hour meeting, the Cabinet decided tonight that the ultranationalist settlers encamped in an Army base in the heart of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan must move to a new site. But the Government deferred for several weeks the crucial question of where the new site would be.

title: Bogus $1.00 Bills Totaling $20 Million Seized in the Bronx
description: Secret Service agents yesterday seized more than $20 million in counterfeit $100 bills and arrested six men in a Bronx printing plant. About $5.5 million worth of the bills was ready for circulation, and the remaining $15 million was partly nrinted officials said.

title: Three Car Crash Kills 4, Injures 3 Near Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 9 (UPI)Four persons were killed and three others were injured today in a threecar crash near here in Parma the police said.

description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Cuban Refugee Program Split by Reports of Director's Political Activity
description: MIAMI, May 8The United States Cuban Refugee Program, founded 15 years ago as a nonpartisan social agency, has been involved in the last four months in a bitter and divisive political controversy.

title: 2 French Climbers Killed
description: KATMANDU, Nepal. May (Reuters)  A French mountaineer has died at a highaltitude camp on the Himalayan peak of Gurja Himal after a fall that killed a fellow climber, the expedition leader said here today. Christine Ertlen, the only woman on the French team, died while in a coma, Friday after an accident in which Francois Soubrane was killed instantly.

title: Congressmen Were Bugged by F.B.I. Indirectly
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)Information regarding contacts between members of Congress and foreign officials was picked up by F.B.I. wiretaps and bugging devices and forwarded to Presidents Johnson and Nixon. according to a staff report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities.

Christine Ertlen, the only woman on the French team, died while in a coma, Friday after an accident in which Francois Soubrane was killed instantly.

title: DurrEmerson Take Mixed Doubles Final
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., May 9 Roy Emerson, the young oldster at age 39, paired with Frangoise Durr today and defeated Tony Trahert and Billie Jean King, 64, 64, for the $20,000 first prize in the Clairol and Vitalis mixed doubles tournament at the La Costa Club. Eight teams competed, with a leading woman player paired with a past men's champion.

title: Burning Tree Golf Club Admits Its First Black
description: BETHESDA, Md., May (UPI)The Burning Tree Club, where President Ford plays golf, has admitted its first black member, Charles T. Duncan, dean of the Howard University law school. Burning Tree has come under increasing attack recently for its unofficial policy of banning women and for not having black members.

title: Railbird on Coast To Hail Hilarious
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 9 (UPI)Hail Hilarious closed fast and pulled away to a sevenlength victory today in the 14th running of the $34,050 Railbird Stakes for 3yearold fillies at Hollywood Park.

title: Pakistani Aides Hopeful On New Talk With India
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 7As Pakistan prepares to go back to the bargaining table with India for their first formal talks in a year, officials in this capital are hopeful but wary, expressing a distrust that is the product of an ancient enmity.

title: A Pulitzer Playwright Is Predicting ResilveredScreen Lining for State
description: OAKLAND, May 8  New Jersey is well on its way toward recapturing some of it. former fame as the movie; capital of the worid, according to Sidney Kingsley, the Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright who is chairman of the state's motionpicture and television committee.

title: Tom Waits Clouds Clever Rock Songs With Affected Style
description: That Tom Waits, the raspyvoiced neohipster whoappeared at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night, is a mannered artist goes without saying. His affectations of style are so extreme and so limited that one cannot imagine him lasting long beyond his current novelty success unless he very quickly and very cleverly broadens his concerns.

Saturday and rapidly spread to adjoining stores in a business section of this Union County city.

title: VOTE SHIFT FOUND AWAY FROM PARTY
description: Three political scientists have concluded after a study of voting patterns that the American public is more detached from political parties than at any time in the past 40 years, and is deeply dissatisfied with the political process.

description: The Public Broadcasting Service has proposed to its member stations a carefully devised fall schedule that its officials say, will provide each program with a favorable time slot and will make PBS overall a more effective alternative to commercial television.

description: Jerome Robbins, the choreographer and one of the New York City Ballet's ballet masters, was presented last night with the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award.

title: Bombs Kill 2 in Malaysia
description: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia, May 9 (AP)A dozen homemade bombs exploded during the night in the state of Sabah. killing two persons and wounding two, authorities said today. No reason was given for the explosions.

title: Levitt Report Is Highly Critical Of School Lunch Program Here

description: TOKYO, Monday, May 10Yoshio Kodama, a rightwing lobbyist and agent for Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, was indicted today on charges of violating Japan's foreigncurrency control law by receiving secret payments totaling almost $1.5 million from Lockheed.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 9Frank G. Zarb, Federal Energy Administrator, said today that the Iranian Government had been holding talks with United States companies about bartering billions of dollars worth of Iranian oil for American products.

title: PATH Roadblocks Are Imposing
description: Is the state's ambitious but controversial PATH project an extension or a contraction? Or an amputation? Is it an unqualified boondoggle that would dump the great bulk'of Jersey's expected Federal transit aid into one poorly planned project as vigorous critics contend? Or is it, as the Byrne administration insists, practical way to provide frequent and fast service without transfer between communities in the PlainfieldNewark corridor and Manhattan and to give a new stimulus to troubled urban areas?

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: GUS LANNA, 61, DIES; TOP TENNIS UMPIRE

August Lanna 2d, a labor mediator more widely known as Gus Lanna, a leading tennis umpire, died Saturday evening, apparently of a heart attack, on the Tennis World courts in Caldwell, N.J., where he was playing in a benefit for the Congregational Church of Shore Hills, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived at 345 Park Street, Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Determined to protect the elegance of their Sutton Place neighborhood, more than 50 demonstrators went to the West Side yesterday to denounce the Lefrak orgnization's plan to build a 29story apartment tower on East 55th Street. Picketing in front of the Lefrak offices at 40 West 57th Street, the demonstrators vowed to continue their fight at a hearing tomorrow on the realty organization's request for a zoning variance to allow highdensity occupancy of the planned building. The hearing will be held at 10 A.M. at the State Board of Standards and Appeals on the ninth floor of 80 Lafayette Street.

title: Hospitals in New York City Balk at Drive on Unneeded Surgery

Before opening at the Ambassador Theater here last week in Marguerite Duras's Des Journees Entieres dans les Arbres. she and her husband, Jeanlouis Barrault, had had a ?brisk two weeks in Moscow and Leningrad with Paul Claudel's Christopher Columbus and Harold and Maud, by Colin Higgins. From here she goes to Canada and then, on June 1, the word vacation turns up in her diary.

description: Ronald Reagan widened his delegate lead over President Ford by picking up 30 national convention votes from Oklahoma, Louisiana and Kansas over the weekend, while the President took 17 in Kansas, Missouri and Minnesota.

title: Questions and Answers on Disputed Status of the Panama Canal
description: PANAMA, May 6For some years, students of United StatesLatin American relations have been predicting that the Panama Canal would become an explosive hemispheric issue.

title: Suns, in Overtime, Subdue Warriors
description: PHOENIX, May 9 CAP)Keith Erickson scored 8 points in the second overtime today, pacing the Phoenix Suns to a 133129 victory over the Golden State Warriors in the Western Conference championship playoff of the National Basketball Association. The teams are now tied at two victories apiece an the fourofseven series, which resumes Wednesday night in Oakland, Calif.

title: Borg Beats Vilas, Takes W.C.T. Title
description: DALLAS, May 9  It seemed to go on and on, almost like a chant, never really building to a climax. Two men sparring instead of slugging, A match speckled occasionally with bits of flash, but dulled overwhelmingly by repetition.

title: Film: 'Underground,' a Documentary:Survivors of 'Village' Bombing Interviewed
description: Six years ago, a stock of explosives blew up in a Greenwich Village house, killing three young people and causing five others who escaped to go into hiding.The eight were members of Weatherman, a small but highly militant segment of the protest movement. From the time of explosion the five survivors, calling themselves the Weather Underground, have eluded the authorities and carried on what they term "armed propaganda." This has consisted of a number of bombingsno injuries occurred; the object was to inflict material damage on symbolic targets  and the publication of a book and a news sheet.Early last year Emile de Antonio, a documentary film maker who is himself a radical, though scarcely a violent one, managed to get in touch with the Weather Underground. Mr. de Antonio and two associates, Mary Lampson and Haskell Wexler, spent two days in a Los Angeles house with the five, talked with them and filmed the talk.The result is "Underground," which opened yesterday at the Regency Theater. It suffers from the crippling difficulties under which it was made. It is a film in chains. It is a series of failures, but they are not stupid or careless ones. They are intelligent failures, and if Mr. de Antonio's effort is largely a defeat, it is a defeat that he conducts with skill and integrity.His intention was to have the fiveKathy Boudin, Bernardine Dohrn, Cathy Wilkerson, Billy Ayers and Jeff Jonesreveal something of themselves. His sympathetic question is: What is a white, middle - class revolutionary group doing in America in the mid-70's?The answers he gets, despite his efforts, are largely schematic and abstract. The five have schooled themselves to be impersonal. They seem to understand that for a film they must come out a bit, but they rarely manage to.There are a few breakthroughs. Kathy Boudin recalls her dismay in Havana in 1961 when she found herselfa peace marcherapplauding a parade of Cuban tanks. Bernardine Dohrn gives a curious insight into her long journey from a comfortable middle class to armed concealment: "I was more afraid growing up than I am now. Then it was paranoid; now it's real fear."There is a hand wielding a coffee pot, and the red ribs of Bernardine Dohrn's sweater. They provide visual life, evidence that in fact we are seeing a film about five people. So do the faces of the three film makers; Mr. de Antonio's eye following that coffee pot has the impact of a cavalry charge.This is not intended to be facetious. The film makers have done marvelously well with these details, but the fact is, they have hardly anything else to film. The five will not allow their faces to be shown. So the camera shows their backs and their elbows.Talking faces, used by a film maker of Mr. de Antonio's skill and sensitivity, would have told us a lot about the five. But without the faces we have only the talk. It is good to have itWeatherman played a small but significant part in the American radical movement, if only, paradoxically, to weaken it by violencebut the effect is claustrophobic.The film makers use clips of the war in Vietnam, peace marches and police charges to illustrate the talk and vary its pace. There is also a scene in which the five leave the house and interview people anonymouslywe still don't see their facesat an unemployment center. The unemployed are angrywhat else would one expect?  and the five draw encouraging conclusions about an American revolution.This is nave. It is frail. Weatherman got its name from the Bob Dylan line about not having to be a weatherman to know which way the wind is blowing. Now it has changed its name to Weather Underground. But how do you tell the wind's direction underground?The film doesn't ask this question, but, despite its sympathy, it doesn't try to conceal it either. That is its honesty.

title: Paper Says Doctor Financed Mexican Jail Raid
description: DALLAS, May 9 (UPI)A jail break in a Mexican border town that freed 14 American prisoners last March was directed and financed by a Dallas psychologist and carried out by former marine sergeant turned soldier of fortune, according to a Dallas newspaper.

title: Defense Payload
description: Concern over a soaring defense budget led the Congress to create a sevenmember Defense Manpower Commission a few years ago to seek ways to reduce the biggest single element in military costs. The Pentagon, it was noted, was scheduled to pay $22 billion more fiscal 1974 than a decade earlier, preVietnam, for the pay and allowances of 400,000 fewer personnel.

title: The Ballet: Miss Seymour in Mahon
description: One thing that can be said for Kenneth MacMillan's Manon, which concluded a series or four performances by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon and evening, is that it provides, despite all its longueurs, three really strong roles for its protagonists.

title: HEAVY FINANCINGS DUE BY 5 STATES
description: The credit markets, which have just completed a week of heavy Treasury financing activity and suffered the sharpest setback in prices this year, now face unusually heavy ???rowing by state governments. Five of them, including New York State plan to sell ??? $400 million o bonds this week. It may turr out that the states will dis cover some respite in the pro flounced swing toward higher interest rates and lower fixed. income security prices that have been underway since April 22.

description: Mayor Beanie's decision to award pay raises to 104 budget employees represents a merited exception to the city's vital wanefreeze policy.

description: WASHINGTON, May 9  In 1937, at the age of 13, a boy named Ede Horvath started work in a privately owned factory in Gyor, Hungary, that made railroad freight cars. His father was a foreman in the plant, and most of his family worked there.

title: Mountain Climbers Bodies Sighted on Alaskan Peak
description: ANCHORAGE, May 9 (AP)Three Japanese mountain climb. ers, apparently dead, have been sighted 16,500 feet high on Mt. Touracre in central Alaska, the National Park Service reported yesterday.

description: DALLAS, May 9 (AP)Mark Hayes scrambled his way to a twounderpar 69 in the final round and gained the first victory of his pro career today in the Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9Lebanon's politicians today were wavering in their choice between war and peace.

The gyrations of the mannequins prove that the new order of fashion is built for action. The colors glow under the special lighting, Thus far, with the fall showings only about halfway through, a number of designers have emerged maior talents.

description: MAIANO, Italy, May 9A steady, dreary rain drenched this devastated corner of northern Italy today, and Sunday became a day of mourning.

He was discharged yesterday morning from Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream L.I., after having suffered a sprained neck and a shoulder bruise.

description: BARCELONA, Spain, May 7 The contradictions of a country where almost all political activity is illegal and most has become possible are nowhere more striking than they are here in Spain's second city and the capital of Catalonia.

J., May 9Seton Hall University won its fourth straight Metropolitan Conference baseball championship and its seventh in eight years by trouncing Fairleigh Dickinson today, 185.
