title: Freedom and Restraint
description: In the occasional clash of valid competing interests, commonsense solutions can frequently be found. This is what happened recently when the right of privacy and the freedom to broadcast collided. The outcome, balancing principle with selfrestraint, is worth examining for similar controversies in the future.

title: Pure as the Driven Slush
description: A myth is an idea people need to believe in, whether or not it is true. All societies, from the primitive to the overcivilized, are held together by such ideas. One of the most powerful of these ideas is the myth of decline, the conviction that the present is inferior to the past. Today, American society is finding a new set of symbols to express a peculiar version of the myth of declinesymbols derived from the experience of ethnic groups.

title: Astaire and Kelly in Spotlight Again
description: HOLLYWOOD, May 9At the age of 76, Fred Astaire does not care to dance any more, and he hates a top hat, white tie and tails. At 63, Gene Kelly hates umbrellas, and jokes that dancers share a great deal in common with prizefighters. We're both masochists, he says.

title: Music: Stern on Mozart
description: The English Chamber Orchestra's plan to present all of Mozart's piano and violin concertos in a series of nine concerts reached its seventh stage last night at Carnegie Hall, where Isaac Stern joined the enterprise for the first time. Mr. Stern, with Daniel Barenboim conducting the orchestra, made the evening into a violin festival, the entire program being given over to three concertos for that instrument.

title: Udall Takes Some Time off To Appeal for More Funds
description: EAST WINDSOR, Conn., May 9Representative Morris K. Udall broke off from his allimportant battle with Jimmy Carter in Michigan last night to fly East for a little campaigning here and, on the way some urgent fundraising.

title: Mary B. Sanger Wed to Harry Katz
description: Mary Bryna Sanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maury D. Sanger of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Harry Alan Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman I. Katz of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Transit in San Francisco Operating After Settlement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 (UPI)  Champagnecarrying tourists hopped aboard the cable cars today as San Francisco's public transit system returned to normal after a 39day city craft workers strike that had stranded an estimated 250,000 daily riders.

title: ISRAEL TO ORDER SETTLERS TO QUIT A WEST BANK SITE
description: JERUSALEM, May 9  After a marathon 10  hour meeting, the Cabinet decided tonight that the ultranationalist settlers encamped in an Army base in the heart of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan must move to a new site. But the Government deferred for several weeks the crucial question of where the new site would be.

title: Brooklyn Gets New StreetCrime Unit
description: A street crime prosecution unit, designed to get faster indictments and trials as well as harsher penalties for muggers and rapists, has gone into operation in Brooklyn.

title: CARDINAL IN BOSTON RETRACTS CRITICISM
description: BOSTON, May 9 (Reuters)Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, the head of the Boston Archdiocese, apologized for criticizing the people of South Boston and their dedication to the Roman Catholic faith.

title: Miss Guthrie Still Idle at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 9 (AP)Janet Guthrie is the first woman to enter the Indianapolis 500, but the question is will she ever drive here. For the second day in a row, mechanical problems in her VollstedtOffenhauser delayed her first drive in practice at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

description: George A. Suter, former resident manager of the Savoy Plaza Hotel who later operated the Beau Rivage Restaurant in Spring Lake, N.J., and was manager of the New Weston Hotel in New York, died yesterday at home in Spring Lake Heights, N.J. He was 79 years old.

description: UDINE, Italy. May 9A major tremor shook this area in northeast Italy this morning, causing new panic among villagers still in shock from last Thursday night's earthquake.

title: Mother's Day: For Some, Tears for Others, Corsages

description: GARDENVILLE, Pa.  If President Ford's vegetable garden had been planted as planned, Derek Fell might well have gone down in history as the man responsible for the White House leeks.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Committee on Civil Practices, appointed by the New Jersey Supreme Court, recommended the establishment of panels in each county to resolve fee disputes between lawyers and their clients. The committee, composed of 20 judges and lawyers, cited increasing complaints about legal fees, especially in divorce cases.

title: Kissinger Calls for an End Of U.S.Israel Wrangling
description: BALTIMORE, May 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kisinger said tonight that although peace negotiations must continue in the Middle East, the United States recognized that Israel faced serious dilemmas and risks in making further territorial concessions in return for less tangible Arab political moves.

title: ExGov. Otto Kerner Dies; Convicted While a Judge
description: CHICAGO, May 9 (AP)Former Illinois Gov. Otto Kerner died today, ending a twoyear battle with cancer and a fight to clear his name after conviction in a racetrack scandal three years ago. He was 67 years old.

title: Estate Tax Reform
description: Because inflation has destroyed the meaning of exemptions and limits established by Congress back in 1942, the taxwriting committees have under consideration a major revision of the estate tax. Under existing law, a person may leave onehalf of his estate taxfree to his spouse and on the other half, there is an exemption from taxes of the first $60,000. In effect, therefore, the ordinary estate is taxed if its net worth exceeds $120,000.

title: Marmureanu Wins Eastern Net Crown
description: GARDEN CITY, L. LPeter Marmureanu, a former Rumanian Davis Cup player now living in Glen Head, L. I., defeated Bob Tanis of Wayne, N.J., 63, 6.2, in the final of the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championship at the Roosevelt Field Tennis Club today. The winner received $750.

title: Trapping the Law
description: The recent Supreme Court decision upholding a conviction for selling narcotics even though undercover agents were both providers and purchasers of the drug raises two questions about the criminal law. First, does such conduct by law enforcement personnel meet acceptable standards of decency and fairness? Second, is any rational law enforcement purpose served by such conduct? We think the answer to both questions is no.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TRIO SIGNOFF But Not for Me, a new oneact comedy by Tom Topor, will be the last production of the season, today through Friday at 12:15 and 1:15 P.M., and repeated next week, at Theater at Noon. At this midday showcase with its informal atmosphere, audiences are Invited to bring their own lunch to minishows at 16 East 56th Street. Tea and coffee are included in the $1 admission.

title: Bridge
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 9  The world team Olympiad began here tonight with 45 teams competing in the open championship and 22 teams in the women's championship. Italy will be attempting to defend the two titles won four years ago in Miami Beach, but American supporters have strong hopes since both American teams have scored victories in Monte Carlo in the last four days.

title: Europe's Customs Delays Linger
description: AACHEN, West Germany When the first train load of duytfree coal crossed from Germany to Luxembourg in February 1953 under the European Coal and Steel Community, it was held up for three hours by a suspicious Luxembourg customs official who didn't understand the new system.

title: GEORGE A. SUTER

title: Three Attorneys General
description: WASHINGTONEverybody did it is no excuse for wrongdoing, but the Church committee reports demonstrate conclusively that the seeds of Watergate were planted and nourished in two Democratic administrations.

title: SINGING THE EARTH', ENLISTS AUDIENCE
description: Saturday evening, this reviewer and several other critics and composers found themselves stretched full length on a loft floor, along with other audience members, uttering spontaneous vocal sounds according to directions from vibrations in the building's structure. At least that was the idea of Annea Lockwood's Singing the Earth one of several performance pieces that the composer and her audience actualized at the Brook. With filmy hangings shifting in the breeze, Flights out and candles burning, the atmosphere was appropriately nocturnal and subdued. And although the vocal sounds of the Earth piece seemed to have been dictated more by choice than by group sensitivity, some of the other pieces worked very well. A group humming session, for example. produced delicate, intersecting planes of pitch and timbre that resonated enchantingly in the stillness.

title: KENNETH L. HUTCHION
description: Kenneth L. Hutchison, for whom the faculty lounge at Pace University was named on his retirement, in 1974 as professor of accounting after 43 years on the faculty, died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived at 8 Bristol Place, Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Mets Records
description: Mets Records

title: Chicago Day Care Centers Troubled by Veto of Funds
description: CHICAGO, May 9  While romping and running at play, the children at the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal day care center were as oblivious to the troubled looks on the faces of their teachers as they were to the cars that darted by on South Michigan Avenue.

title: More Company Bribery Cases Forecast by S.E.C.'s Chairman
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va. (UPI)The scandal of corporate bribes and illegal campaign contributions is not over, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said over the weekend.

title: Highly Trained Called Targets of Malpractice Claims
description: Despite a prevailing public view that poorly trained physicians are the prime source of medical malpractice claims, a new study by the association of state insurance regulators has found that the majority of cases of malpractice and claims for them involve the most highly trained doctors in the medical field.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There has been a good deal of talk about declining political party loyalty and the mushrooming of political independents, by James Reston [column April 25] as well as others. There is no question that this is true. Ticketsplitting alone substantiates the thesis. For example, in 1964 in Rhode Island, while Democrat Lyndon Johnson was beating Barry Goldwater approximately 2 to 1 for the Presidency and Democrat John Pastore was beating his Republican opponent about 2 to 1 for U.S. Senator, Republican John Chafee beat his Democratic opponent for Governor by nearly 2 to 1considerable independence.

title: Landmark Maps Available
description: Maps showing officially designated landmarks in each of the city's 52 community districts have been prepared by the landmarks Preservation Commission. The maps are available at the commission's offices at 305 Broadway for 25 cents for a district map or $2.50 for a set of maps of districts in any one borough except Staten Island, which is $1. A complete, citywide set is $7.50.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A.B.A. Drops Squires For a Lack of Funds
description: Time finally ran out on the Virginia Squires yesterday.

title: Study Calls Health Gain Slow In Territories Held by Israel
description: GENEVA, May 10A special committee of the World Health Organization has reported that medical care in the Arab territories occupied by Israel has shown slow but steady improvement in the nine years since the 1967 war.

title: Commonwealth in Listing
description: Commonwealth Edison Company registered 5 million shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith; Bache Halsey Stuart Inc. and First Boston Corporation.

title: Newsweek Raising Price To $1 Starting July 5
description: Newsweek magazine will raise its price to $1 a copy beginning with the July 5 issue, the company announced yesterday. The weekly news magazine now sells for 75 cents.

title: R. E. Scruggs, Economist At Standard & Poor's, 49
description: Richard E. Scruggs, chief economist of Standard & Poor's Corporation, financial publishers, died of cancer Saturday in Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I. He was 49 years old and lived at 939 North Greene Avenue in Lindenhurst, L. I.

title: A Times Editor Sues Nixon and U.S. Aides Over 1969 Wiretap
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Hedrick Smith, deputy national editor of The New York Times, filed suit today against former President Richard M. Nixon and several other past and present Government officials allegedly responsible for placing a wiretap on Mr. Smith's home telephone in 1069.

title: Bridge:
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 10A political storm erupted here tonight when the Indonesian team did not appear to play South Africa.

title: Underwater Walk Recora
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 10 (Reuters)A team of five Australian Navy divers has claimed a world underwater walking record after covering 41 miles in relay for 20 hours on the floor of Sydney Harbor.

title: For Sholom Aleichem, There's Will and a Way
description: Sholem Aleichem, the Yiddish writer and idol of the East European Jewish masses, died in the Bronx just 60 years ago, but he left a will that seemed to make him come alive on Park Avenue Sunday night.

title: Strikes Held in Spain to Protest Shootings at a Rally of Carlists
description: PAMPLONA. Spain, May 10 (Reuters)Strikes and protests broke out in Navarre Province today to protest the shooting yesterday that disrupted a mountaintop rally by followers of exiled Prince Carlos Hugo de Barbn Parma.

title: Private Trade Flourishing in Soviet Georgia
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., May 6The old peasant held a small bunch of fresh scallions in his leathery hands, cradled them, fondled them, offered them gently to a smoothfaced young man. Thirty kopecks, the peasant said.

title: Honest Pleasure Shipped To Pimlico, Foe Goes Today
description: The thehe of yesterday morning's conversation around Belmont Park's barn area could have been titled, On to Maryland, as some trainers began aiming for Pimlico.

title: BIRTH CURB STUDY BACKS DIAPHRAGM
description: A study, of more than 2,000 women who used the diaphragm as their birth control method has found that it can be as effective in preventing pregnancy and as acceptable to users, including teenagers, as the more modern contraceptives.

title: $235 Million Relief Planned
description: ROME, May 10 (Reuters) The Government agreed tonight to allocate the equivalent of $235 million for relief and reconstruction in the earthquake area. Labor Minister Mario Toros said later that the money would be a first installment.

title: Americans Help Israel to Open Tennis Center
description: RAMAT HASHARON, IsraelEight months ago it was a strawberry patch. Today, thanks to the efforts of four American tennis addicts who also share an addiction for Israel, it is the finest new sports facility in the country.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israel is planning to establish numerous additional settlements in occupied Arab territory over the next several years, Government officials said yesterday. The new settlementssome will be small agricultural villages and others industrial townswill be in the Golan Heights, Jordan Valley, West Bank of the Jordan, and the Rafah area of the Gaza Strip. Since the 1967 war Israel has established 68 settlements in Arab territory. The Government announcement followed a Cabinet vote of 17 to 2 approving a resolution banning illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank, but emphasizing that the Government would continue to establish settlements in areas of its own choice. One of the illegal settlements is occupied by a group of extreme Israeli nationalists in an army camp at Kadum, near Nablus. The Cabinet authorized the removal of the camp's inhabitants. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: U.S. Again Acting On Bids to Adopt Vietnam Orphans
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Governmerrt announced today that it was resuming action on resident applications that could lead to formal adoption of Vietnamese orphans who were brought to this country last year.

title: Death Bill
description: A new assault on liberalized abortion rights faces a critical test in Albany tomorrow when the Assembly Health Committee is scheduled to act on a Senatepassed measure that would require all women under 18 to have parental consent for a legal abortion. While the aims of the proposed legislation may appear reasonablethe cooperation of parents is certainly desirable when such a serious decision is contemplatedthe effects of this bill could be tragic for thousands of young women New York, and for their parents.

title: Landmarks Agency Fights Zoning Bid By Planning Panel
description: New zoning legislation drafted by the City Planning Commission to encourage developers to preserve landmarks is being opposed by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Screening Recaptures Old Hollywood
description: The shrillest cheers were for Cary Grant, silverhaired and trimly tuxedoed. Whistles and shouts greeted the stars of the evening, Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly. And there were whoops for Johnny Weissmuller, who returned the favor with his own shrieking Tarzan cry of the jungle.

title: FordReagan Race Focusing on Arms Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Somewhere between the snows of New Hampshire and the sunny climes down in Florida, President Ford observed somewhat ruefully in a recent speech at Tyler Junior College in Texas, the focus of this year's Republican campaign for the Presidency began to shift away from the growing strength and prosperity of the American economy to a new and more complex issuethe strength of America's military force.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO PROTECT A RIVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 10By a vote of 12 to 0, the House Interior Subcommittee on National Parks and Recreation approved today a bill to place 26.5 miles of the New River on the North Carolina Virginia border in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: April Retail Sales Level With March But 14% Above 75
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Retail sales leveled off in April after their strong surge of the past year, the Commerce Department reported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

title: Kidnapping Warrant
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP) A warrant for the arrest of Sara Coner, 28 years old, of. Phoenixville was issued today, charging her with kidnapping two Vietnamese girls for whom she had been caring. The chilldren, age 5 and 12, were last seen April 27 at their schools.

title: Government Rests Manslaughter Case Against Captain Who Kept 2 Out of Boat
description: CAMDEN, May 10The manslaughter case today against a sea captain charged with having refused to put his dog out of a lifeboat to make room for two crewmen who died of exposure after clinging to the boat for 10 hours in wintry Atlantic waters.

title: Credit Markets Register Sharp Declines in Prices
description: Credit markets declined, sharply in price again yesterday pushing interest rates substantiallv higher as Wall Street became convinced that the Federal Reserve would move towardtighter money this year as economic expansion continues. Three month Treasury bills were sold yesterday at an average rate of 5.07 percent, their highest level since March 1.

title: 1,333 Tents Given by U.S. For Italian Quake Victims
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (Reuters)The United States has donated 1,333 tents to house more than 9,000 of the Italians made homeless by last week's earthquake.

title: Yankees Impress Rivals
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 When the New York Yankees left here last night, after one of their most successful Western trips, they left behind some very positive impressions on rivals who can afford to be objective because they don't play in the same division.

title: BUMPER HARVESTS IN GRAIN FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 10A record corn crop and the nation's second largest crop of winter wheat were forecast today by the Department of Agriculture in two reports that reinforce predictions of relative stability in food prices.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: VOL. CXXV ..No. 43,207

title: Citibank Gives $300,000 to Aid Cultural Groups
description: Citibank, formerly the First National City Bank, announced yesterday it would distribute $300.000 over a threeyear period to several New York City cultural organizations that have lost funds under the city's budget cutbacks.

title: Captain Critical of Honor Code Is Asked to Leave West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y May 10Capt. Arthur Lincoln, an Army lawyer who has criticized the alleged abuse of the West Point's honor code by officers and cadets, is being asked to leave the United States Military Academy.

title: Con Edison Rates Called The Most Costly in U.S.
description: NEWARK, May 10 (UPI) Consolidated Edison has the highest electricity rates of any utility in the United States, according to a survey by an energy consulting firm.

title: Civic Tyrants
description: The insolent treatment of New York's householders at the hands of John DeLury's sanitationmen's union during the current building service employees strike once again raises the question: Who runs this city? It's apparently not the Mayor; is it Mr. DeLury?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MARCUS HELITZER
description: Marcus Helitzer, a past president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers and president of Helizer Brothers, maker of women's sportswear, until 1950, died yesterday of a heart attack in Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had resided for 25 years. He was 78 years old.

title: Grace Says It Rejects Illegal Political Acts
description: BOSTON, May 10 (AP)W. R. Grace & Company officials today assured shareholders that the company had not engaged in illegal political activities in any of the countries in which it operates.

title: McFeeley to Resign
description: Kenneth McFeeley, head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for two years, declared his intention to resign, saying he would give his reasons at a news conference this morning. Page 10.

title: 7 Writers Words Barred By Congressional Record
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Congressional Record, citing a rule against publishing obscenities, refused today to publish excerpts from the works of Kurt Vonnegut Jr., Bernard Malamud, Langston Hughes and four other books banned last March by the Board of the Island Trees School District on Long Island.

title: People in Sports
description: Bobby Richardson, the New York Yankee second baseman from 1957 through 1966, entered the game of politics yesterday. The 40yearold Richardson, who played on seven American League pennantwinning and three World Series championship teams, announced his candidacy to run for Congress in South Carolina's Fifth District. He will oppose the incumbent Democrat, Kenneth C. Holland. Although Richardson will run as a Republican, he said he did not plan to a partisan campaign.

title: Flood of Smuggled Cash Is Enriching Swiss Banks
description: PARIS, May 10Money is on the run in Europestuffed into suitcases, tucked into moneybelts, packed under the seats of automobiles, in greater quantities than ever before in the postwar period.

title: Structure and Justice
description: Except for those involved, there's usually nothing very exciting about a bureaucratic shakeup. Nevertheless, the facelifting recently announced by the New York County District Attorney's office is of particular interest, partially because it is the first restructuring since Thomas E. Dewey's tenure 38 years ago. More important, the changes are bound to improve the quality of justice dispensed in Manhattan.

title: Pargas Suit Accuses Empire Of Violations in Tender Offer
description: Pargas Inc. of Waldorf, Md., filed suit yesterday against the Empire Gas Corporation in Federal District Court in Baltimore, charging that Empire was in violation of the Federalsecurities laws and Maryland law in connection with its tender offer to buy two million shares of Pargas cemmon stock at $18.50 a share.

title: New York City Is Advised to Look to Atom Power
description: New York City's energy future must rely mostly on increasing use of nuclear power, Robert C. Seamans Jr., the Federal Energy Research and Development Administrator, said yesterday.

title: Atom Bombs for Sale
description: WASHINGTONAt a Moscow conference on nuclear proliferation last summer, the scientist who built Russia's first Abomb in 1949 turned to an American visitor.

title: 19 AFRICAN LEADERS MEET WITH GISCARD
description: PARIS, May 10 (Reuters)A meeting of French and African leaders, devoted to economic and political problems, opened here today with the participation of 20 nations.

title: Court Denies Appeal Of James Earl Ray In Dr. King Shooting
description: CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP)James Earl Ray's appeal from his plea of guilty in the shooting death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was denied today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: JerryComeLately
description: The belated entrance of California's Governor, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., is a dramatic event in the Democratic Presidential contest. Because he delayed making his move for so long, Governor Brown can only run In three of the remaining primariesMaryland on May 18, Nevada on May 25, and his native California on June 8.

title: LANDLORDS REJECT UNION'S PROPOSAL
description: The Realty Advisory Board, representing New York City landlords, rejected a counterproposal put forward yesterday by striking apartment house employees in a new effort to settle the eightday walkout.

title: Credit Prices Off
description: Credit market prices declined sharply again yesterday as Wall Street became convinced that the Federal Reserve will move toward tighter money this year as economic expansion continues. Page 50.

title: Principals Nearing Pact on Longer Day In New York City
description: The New York City Board of Education and the school supervisors union are near agreement on a new contract that would add an hour to the work day of the city's principals and other supervisors.

title: Dudley's Hand Fractured
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 (UPI)Charles Dudley of the Golden State Warriors suffered a hairline fracture in his left hand during yesterday's National Basketball Association playoff game at Phoenix. He will play in Wednesday night's game with a protective covering on the hand.

title: Wallace Cancels a Visit To Site of His Shooting
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10 (UPI)  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has canceled a scheduled appearance at Laurel, Md., next Saturday, four years to the day after he was shot at a shopping center while campaigning there.

title: New York Principals Reported Ready to Lengthen Work Day
description: The New York City Board of Education and the school supervisors union are near agreement on a new contract that would add an hour to the work day of the city's principals and other supervisors.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SOYBEANS RISE
description: Strength in soybean and soybean meal futures price continued yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, still influenced by reports of European need for both commodities.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey's water supplies are being tested for possible cancercausing chemicals, state water resources officials said. There's no immediate cause for alarm these things are in the water, they've been there for years, said John Wilford, assistant director of the state division of water resources. We're not sure what impact these substances have and that's why we're testing. Water resources officials plan to take periodic samples from 200 water supplies, rivers, streams and lakes and bring them to Trenton for analysis. They'll be looking for traces of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) and other industrial byproducts that are known to cause cancer when given to laboratory animals and are widely believed to be harmful to humans as well.

title: Fred McLeod, Golfer, 94, Dies; Won United States Open in 1908
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Fred McLeod, winner of the 1908 United States Open golf tournament and an honorary starter of the Masters tournament last month in Augusta. Ga., died Saturday. He was 94 years old.

title: Anne Klein Goes Broadway: Fall Line Joins Chorus Line
description: It was the apotheosis of the fashion show as theater. Other designers have taken their opening productions offBroadway. The Anne Klein organization booked the Winter Garden Theater, where Pacific Overtures is playing, and filled it. Two dozen models were trained to dance and show clothes with the precision of the Rockettes. They had almost as much rehearsal time.

title: 72 Wallace Voters Lean To Reagan in Michigan
description: WARREN. Mich., May 10Neither Gerald Ford nor Ronald Reagan knows Bob Vavro or Bill Cross or Don Hafner. But Mr. Fords fears them nonetheless, and Mr. Reagan's forces are wooing them avidly.

title: Street Musicians Play for Spring Muses
description: The city's music is varied. On dreary days it is the stutter of jackhammers and the groan of traffic. But of art afternoon in the sun, it is harmonica and steel drums and streetcorner violins. It is a guitar on 49th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, a saxophone penetrating the oppression of Times Square. It is the warbling of a flute on a rock ledge in Central Park mill the oompah of a brass ensemble on its way the zoo. The city's street musicians play for money, for the smiles of passersby, but mostly they play for themselves and their spring afternoon muses.

title: Quake Area Gains Superficial Normality
description: UDINE, Italy, May 10The long process of healing the earthquakestricken region of Friuli in northeastern Italy began today, with scaffolding springing up around lightly damaged walls and cranes clearing away the rest.

title: Advertising
description: To at least one member of the audience Pope Paul VI's statement on advertising on April 28 was a very positive one.

title: A Campaign That's Still Wide Open
description: The Presidential campaign of 1976 has turned into the most volatile and wideopen race since that of 1952or maybe even further back into political antiquity. With two months to go until the Democratic convention and the primary season halfover, nothing is clear and nothing is settled, despite all claims to the contrary.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: COOP CITY LOSES FORECLOSURE SUIT
description: New York State housing officials won a court fight yesterday to foreclose the $436 million mortgage of Coop City in the Bronx, whose residents have been refusing to pay a 25 percent increase in carrying charges retroactive to April, 1975.

title: RECORDER IS FOUND IN SPANISH CRASH
description: MADRID, May 10 (UPI)The Spanish Army today recovered an Iranian Air Force 747 cargo jet's flight recorder, which may reveal whether the plane exploded before it crashed yesterday. Nearly a score of persons, including four Americans, were killed.

title: A Finishing School Students Hate to Leave
description: The minute one enters the big bright loft on East 87th Street there is the clean, pungent smell of wood and paint and lacquer. Women are hard at work on furniture. And at a big table in the center, looking somehow as if enthroned, sits Isabel O'Neil who could be part empress, part goddess, from the way everyone approaches her.

title: McFeeley to Resign
description: Kenneth McFeeley, head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for two years, declared his intention to resign, saying he would give his reasons at a news conference this morning. Page 10.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fish Are Migrating Early
description: This spring's unusual early warmth has triggered some offscheduled movements by salt water fish.

title: LOSS NARROWED AT VW DURING '75
description: WOLFSBURG. West Germany, May 10Volkswagenwerk, which lost a record $323 million in 1974, sharply narrowed its deficit to $62 million last year and was strongly in the black in this year's first quarter, the auto maker reported today.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: The Tranquil Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 10There is the joke about the pilot coming in for a landing at Salisbury Airport. He tells his passengers the altitude, the weather conditions, the temperature, and then he says: Don't forget to set your watches back 10 years.

title: Stock Prices Up Broadly; Dow Pushes Ahead 11.26
description: Stock prices rose smartly across a broad front yesterday as the market posted its best advance and heaviest trading volume in nearly three weeks.

title: Bank Robber Suspect Seized
description: NEWARK, May 10 (UPI)A Jersey City man was arrested today on charges of participating in a robbery of a Union City bank earlier this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. An F.B.I. sookesman said that Juan Castillo, 23 years old, had been picked up in Hoboken by two city patrolman and been turned over to Federal authorities.

title: FordReagan Race Focusing on Arms Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Somewhere between the snows of New Hampshire and the sunny climes down in Florida, President Ford observed somewhat ruefully in a recent speech at Tyler Junior College in Texas, the focus of this year's Republican campaign for the Presidency began to shift away from the growing strength and prosperity of the American economy to a new and more complex issuethe strength of America's military force.

title: Nassau County Is Investigating Printing of Sealed Jury Reports
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 10An investigation has been started into the disclosure of four sealed grand jury reports handed up by a Nassau County grand jury, Denis E. Dillon, the District Attorney, said today.

title: Arab Leaders Call Meeting On EgyptianSyrian Discord
description: CAIRO, May 10 (Reuters) The Prime Ministers of Egypt, Syria and Kuwait will meet in Saudi Arabia next week, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, said here tonight.

title: WORLD BANK LIFTS ITS RATE ON LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The World Bank announced today an increase in the interest rate on its loans to the less developed countries and a new formula that could lead to further increases in the future.

title: Six Iraqi Aides Ousted In a Shuffle of the Cabinet
description: BAGDAD, Iraq, May 10 (Reuters)  Six Iraqi Ministers were relieved of their posts today in a Cabinet shuffle, the Iraqi news agency reported.

title: COOP CITY LOSES FORECLOSURE SUIT
description: New York State housing officials won a court fight yesterday to foreclose the $436 million mortgage of Coop City in the Bronx, whose residents have been refusing to pay a 25 percent increase in carrying charges retroactive to April, 1975.

title: Helping New York
description: Juan Soto, a reptile handler at the Bronx Zoo, held up a freshly shed python skin for the inspection of 11 fourthand fifthgrade girls from Public School 6 in the Bronx. The girls momentarily discarded their scientific curiosity and in unison exclaimed, Yech!

title: Flood of Smuggled Cash Is Enriching Swiss Banks
description: PARIS, May 10Money is on the run in Europestuffed into suitcases, tucked into moneybelts, packed under the seats of automobiles, in greater quantities than ever before in the postwar period.

title: Ford Favored in West Virginia Primary
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 10West Virginia's Republican voters will make a choice tomorrow between President Ford and Ronald Reagan but it will be strictly a popularity contest that is not binding on the 28 convention delegates to be chosen separately in the same primary.

title: WOMEN TO ACCUSE 40 STATES OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) A national feminist organization said today that it would file sex discrimination complaints with the Federal Government against 40 states and the District of Columbia laccusing them of violating the 1972 Education Amendments.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 10For a number of months, there have been allegations that inmates could buy their way out of state prisons.

title: REPORT OPTIMISTIC ON ATOMIC WASTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The safe management of radioactive wastes from increased nuclear energy production is feasible, according to Federal Government report issued today.

title: U.S. Immigrants TapeRecord Grim Memories of Nazi Holocaust
description: On May 18, 1944, Frances Epstein, a young Czechoslovak woman, arrived at Auschwitz. Soon a cousin found her and stunned her by telling her about the crematoriums at the concentration camp.

title: Carter Group Wins Review of Statute Covering Primaries
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn approved yesterday the convening of a threejudge court to rule on the constitutionality of those sections of the New York State eluction law dealing with primaries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest energy supplier, was ordered by the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners to refund $6,187,000, plus 10 percent interest, to gas customers as result of overcharges in the first three months of the year. Joel R. Jacobson, the P.U.C. president, who ordered the refunds, said overcharges resulted from allowances made for the utility's cost of raw material passed along to consumers without application for rate increases. The utility explained that the use of natural gas last winter was less than expected, and that it had been able to make spot purchases of natural gas at prices lower than synthetic gas it had expected to buy.

title: Top British Liberal Quits Over a Homosexual Furor
description: LONDON, May 10Jeremy Thorpe resigned today leader of the Liberal Party, accusing some British newspapers of having conducted a sustained witch hunt involving allegations of homosexuality.

title: Regulators and the Regulated Gather At Federal Power Group's Party
description: WASHINGTON, May 10A grin on his face, James G. Watt, the newest member of the Federal Power Commission, surveyed the several hundred people around him who were drinking shoulder to shoulder.

title: Responding to Juvenile Violence
description: Frightened by reports of frequent and serious juvenile violence, New Yorkers are questioning whether having a separate juvenile justice system makes sense today. It appears that no part of that systemprevention and treatment programs, the police, the Family Court, probation, the New York State Division for Youthworks effectively.

title: HEARSTTRIALDATE FACES NEW DELAY
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Prisons has refused to release Patricia Hearst to the state authorities for a June 1 trial here, her prosecutor said today.

title: Juilliard Ensemble Gives Ellis Island, A Sokolow Dance
description: Among the thoughts prompted by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble concert on Sunday was that the group, though it graduates personnel with a certain inevitability, retains a distinct performing style. It is characterized by a high dramatic intensity that is most suited to works that partake of the same energetic esthetic. Anna Sokolow, who has been notably loyal to the developing group, prepared a touching tableau, Ellis Island, for its current appearance at the lovely Juilliard Theater.

title: Top British Liberal Quits Over a Homosexual Furor
description: LONDON, May 10Jeremy Thorpe resigned today as leader of the Liberal Party, accusing some British newspapers of having conducted a sustained witch hunt involving allegations of homosexuality.

title: Smithsonian Revives Centennial of 1876
description: WASHINGTON, May 10As if the hundreds of events and exhibits planned for the Bicentennial were not enough, the Smithsonian Institution has recaptured a piece of the American Centennial of 1876.

title: Albany Gets a Bill to Give Agencies Right to Cut Public Employee Benefits
description: ALBANY, May 10Governor Carey today introduced a bill that would give public employersgovernments and school districtsthe right to reduce employee benefits once a contract had expired, even if negotiations for a new contract were still going on.

title: TV: Splendid Flying Dutchman Is on Channel 13
description: If the mating of grand opera and television has so far proved somewhat unsteady, consider the potential for disaster in the fulllength production of a work by Richard Wagner. But, brilliantly demonstrating the unpredictability of the electronic medium, the British Broadcasting Corporation has taken Wagner and created a TV event of powerful beauty that will be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: FURTHER CHARGES SEEN FOR KODAMA
description: TOKYO, May 10Yoshio Kodama, the 65yearold Japanese lobbyist, remained in seclusion today after being formally charged with having? illegally received almost $1.5 million from abroad.

title: Helping New York
description: Juan Soto, a reptile handler at the Bronx Zoo, held up a freshly shed python skin for the inspection of 11 fourthgrade and fifthgrade girls from Public School 46 in the Bronx. The girls momentarily discarded their scientific curiosity and in unison exclaimed, Yech!

title: BROOKE IN WARNING TO CITY ON U.S. AID
description: Citing what he called a new realism, among the nation's taxpayers, Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusett warned a gathering of top city and state officials here last night not to expect further Federal loans should the city fail to adhere to its strict threeyear financial plan.

title: Flights to Quake Area
description: TORONTO, May 10 (UPI)Alitalia Airlines has announced that it is offering free flights to Canadian Italians who were born in the northeastern sector of Italy that was stricken by an earthquake last week. The airline said the free flights, for persons seeking word of relatives, will be available until Thursday.

title: GUNMEN MURDER WOMAN, INJURE 3
description: Two gunmen walked up to four persons sitting on the front steps of a Brooklyn apartment house last night and in a rapid burst of gunfire killed one of them and wounded three others.

title: Temporary Release Sought For Seoul Opposition Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 10 The wife of South Korea's 1971 opposition presidential candidate, Kim Dae Jung, has appealed to President Park Chung Hee to release her husband temporarily from prison.

title: Lockheed Agent Had Contacts Among Top Japanese
description: TOKYO, May 10After years of obscurity, the name of Yoshio Kodama has become a household word in Japan.

title: New York Project Cuts Village Power Costs 28%
description: RICHMONDVILLE, N.Y., May 10A 28 percent cut in the electric bills of the 758 customers of the municipally owned power system here went into effect today as current began to flow from the stateowned Niagara Power Project, 250 miles to the west.

title: New Albany Law May Cut 11,000 From Relief Aid
description: Eleven thousand people under the age of 21, including 7,000 in New York City and the rest lupstate, are threatened with being dropped from homerelief rolls this Friday under a new state law that the city said yesterday would be impossible by then to carry out administratively or judicially.wrote the State Department of Social Services yesterday to appeal for new legislation to delay the deadline on the ground it could not be met here.

title: State Department Calls Beirut Election Welcome
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (Reuters)The United States expressed official optimism today that the election of Elias Sarkis as President of Lebanon would help toward a political solution of the civil strife in the country.

title: R. E. Scruggs, Economist At Standard & Poor's, 49
description: Richard E. Scruggs, chief economist of Standard & Poor's Corporation, financial publishers, died of cancer Saturday in Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I. He was 49 years old and lived at 939 North Greene Avenue in Lindenhurst. L.I.

title: Cominco Increases Price For Its Lead in Canada
description: Cominco yesterday raised its price in Canada for refined lead by 1.5 cents to 23 cents a pound. In April the company, along with competitors, raised its United States price by 2 cents to 23 cents a pound.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: 1,333 Tents Given by U.S. For Italian Quake Victims
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (Reuters)The United States has donated 1,333 tents to house more than 9,000 of the Italians made homeless by last week's earthquake.

title: U.S. Anticrime Project Scored; Study Urges Agency's Abolition
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) An independent study of the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration concludes that the agency has performed poorly in its $4.4 billion effort to combat crime and should be abolished.

title: Good Progress by Industry Is Found in Saving Energy
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Substantial progress has been made by industry in conserving energy voluntarily, according to a Commerce Department report to be released tomorrow.

title: Surge in Gasoline Use Raises Issue Of Possible Shortage in the Summer
description: Gasoline consumption, after several laggard years following the Arab oil embargo and sharp price increases, has surged recently, raising the question of whether there will be a gasoline shortage this summer.

title: VOTE BILL MAY AID FORD BY MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, May 10By signing the campaign bill later this week, as he is expected to do, President Ford will give his primary campaign a financial boost of nearly $1 million over his Republican challenger, Ronald Reagan. Reports submitted to the Federal Elections Commission today showed both campaigns very close to deficit operations as of May 1, with the President enjoying a marked advantage in frozen campaign subsidies that will become payable when he approves the measure.

title: Stars Shine For Benefit Of Library
description: James Lipton's The Star Spangled Gala was starry, spangled, gala and long. ?? lasted four and a half hours and took place at the Metro politan Opera House on Sunday night. It opened with the divine Twyla Tharp, ended with the equally divine Julie Harris and crammed as much in between as to make a club sandwich seem like a fortune cookie. It was a gala designed not only for the gourmet, but also the gourmand in all of us.

title: MARCUS HELITZER
description: Marcus Helitzer, a past president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers and president of Helitzer Brothers, maker of women's sportswear, until 1950, died yesterday of a heart attack in Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had resided for 25 years. He was 78 years old.

title: Palestinians Are Critical Of Syrian Role in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10A new test of strength between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization today cast a shadow over efforts of Lebatiese politicians to end their yearold civilwar.

title: Books of The Times
description: The description of the epidemic of bubonic plague in Daniel Defoe's A Journal of the Plague Year and the reconstruction of fiscal plague in Fred Ferretti's The Year the Big Apple Went Bust are separated by the divide of cities and centuries. But reading or rereading both, you will come away holding your head and feeling your pulse. The plague is pretty much a thing of the past; but the Municipal Assistance Corporation and similar symptoms of municipal stomach distress are still hard to swallow.

title: Fisk Commencement Hears Alumni Report on Endowment Drain
description: NASHVILLE. May 10The 102d graduating class of Fisk University received their degrees this morning and they were also informally told that their school, considered the aristocrat of black colleges, lost millions of dollars and possible income during recent years because officials used multimiiliondollar endowment to pay school expenses.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW DESIGN Tmes change and so do bars, the garment area included. Take the Fabric Factory, not what it sounds like. This is a quietly pleasant cocktail lounge and eatery on the site of the former London Bar, once a favorite hangout for mechanical workers of the old New York Herald Tribune. The Artists and Writers Restaurant (Bleeck's), the bestknown newspaper oasis in the old days is still open opposite the new place and farther west of Seventh Ave40th Street.

title: Argentine Terrorists Kill 2
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 10 (UPI)Terrorists shot to death the manager of a glass factory and a high police official in separate attacks here today.

title: Hertz Signs Consent Order On Used Rental Car Sales
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced that the Hertz Corporation had signed a consent order that prohibited the company from misrepresenting the condition of used rental cars it offered for sale.

title: GARBAGE PICKUPS SPURRED IN STRIKE
description: Department of Sanitation crews, despite the accusations of some angry apartment dwellers, actually are picking up more garbage during the strike of building service employees than they did before the walkout., Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarello said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL PLANNING TO SETTLE MORE OF OCCUPIED LAND
description: JERUSALEM, May 10Israel is drawing up plans for the establishment of a large number of new settlements in occupied Arab territory over the next several years, government officials familiar with the plans said today.

title: Fed Plan on Pooled Savings Is Opposed by Wage Council
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)  The Council on Wage and Price Stability today opposed efforts to bar small saver from pooling deposits for the purpose of investing in high denomination and relatively high yielding bank time deposits.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: theater off of the industrial section.

title: Delta Air Buys 13 Planes
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday it had bought an additional 13 Boeing 727 aircraft from the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company. The price was notdisclosed, but trade sources said they were worth $10 million each. The airline announced also that it had negotiated with FBA Aircraft S. A. of Geneva Switzerland to sell its remaining 19 DC851 transports.

title: CASTRO RESUMES ATTACKS ON U.S.
description: HAVANA, May 10 (Reuters) With relations between Cuba and the United States strained over Angola, Prime Minister Fidel Castro is again rallying his people against what he de?? as Yankee imperialism.

title: Pollution in the Delaware Is Blow to Shad
description: ROSEMONT, May 10One clue to why retail markets charge $3.90 a pound for shad is held by James Friedersdorff, who heads the joint fourstate and Federal fish research project near the Delaware River here.

title: Music: Elan of Orpheus
description: Are conductors really necessary? Not for the Orpheus Chamber Ensemble, which completed an eightconcert New York season at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night with nary a podium insight. Founded in 1972, Orpheus is a rare example of musical democracy: Its members formulate their own artistic policies, have equal voices in rehearsal decisions and even rotate seating positions to give everyone a crack at serving as section principal.

title: Baseball's Most Memorable Ballot
description: Sports of The Times ?? more home runs than Babe Ruth over career and Roger Mans has hit more home runs than Babe Ruth over a season, but Babe Ruth has endured as baseball's most memorable personality. In the next few weeks, another Babe Ruth revival probably will occur as Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office holds an election to select baseball's most memorable personality and its most memorable moments. More than 5,000 baseball writers, sports editors, radioTV sports directors and baseball officials are expected to respond to the ballot. The winners will be honored at the AllStar Game in Philadelphia on July 13. The losers will be honored in conversations by baseball fans everywhere.

title: Street Musicians Play for Spring Muses
description: The city's music is varied. On dreary days it is the stutter of jackhammers and the groan of traffic. But of an afternoon in the sun, it is harmonica and steel drums and streetcorner violins. It is a guitar on 49th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, a saxophone penetrating the oppression of Times Square. It is the warbling of a flute on a rock ledge in Central Park and the oompah of a brass ensemble on its way the zoo. The city's street musicians play for money, for the smiles of passersby, but mostly they play for themselves and their spring afternoon muses.

title: LEGISLATOR QUITS G.O.P. IN DUTCHESS
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 10The only woman Republican member of the Dutchess County Legislature switched political parties today, tipping the balance in favor of the Democrats.

title: Connors, Tanner Advance
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 10 (UPI)Roscoe Tanner, last year's winner, sstruggled to survive the opening round of the $150,000 Las Vegas Tennis Classic against Sherwood Stewart today and Jimmy Connors easily dispatched Tom Koch of Brazil.

title: Budget Requests for 1977 Screened by City Council
description: City agency heads explained and defended their 1977 expense pense budget requests before the City Council's Finance Committee yesterday in a daylong session that was characterized by imponderables.

title: Teamster Pact Ratified By 41 in Mail Referendum
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) Some 400,000 teamsters voted 4 to 1 to accept a new national master freight agreement negotiated during a threeday nationwide strike early in April, the union president, Frank Fitz. simmons, announced today.

title: G.A.O. Finds Security Is Lax At U.S. Computer Installations
description: WASHINGTON, May, 10 (AP) Many of the Federal Government's 9,000 computers are insufficiently protected against sabotage, vandalism, terrorism, or natural disaster, Congressional auditors said today.

title: U.S. Rests Case Against Yacht Captain
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 10The Federal Government rested its manslaughter case today against a sea captain charged with having refused to put his dog out of a lifeboat to make room for two crewmen who died of exposure after clinging to the boat for 10 hours in wintry Atlantic waters.

title: TRUDE GUERMONPREZ
description: Trude Guermonprez, whose weaving won the Craftsmanship Medal of the American Institute of Architects in 1970 and who had taught at the California College of Arts and Crafts since 1960, died Saturday in San Francisco, where she lived.

title: 5th Ave. Residents Ask Parade Limit
description: After years of fruitless pleadling, the Fifth Avenue Association warned the city yesterday that unless something was done about the hellish nightmare of holiday parades its members would strike at City Hall where it hurtst the pocketbook.

title: Issues in Building Strike
description: Local 32B of the Service Employees Union, representing 20,000 superintendents, handymen, elevator operators, porters, mechanics and guards in 4,000 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten in land. The Realty Advisory Board represents the building owners.

title: Cornell Trio Is Rated High in Lacrosse
description: Lacrosse records have not been compiled as well as statistics in some other college sports, so it is not possible to name the highestscoring player or line in the game's history. But Cornell has as good a scoring line as anyone can remember in Mike French, Eamon McEneaney and Jon Levine. French is one of the highest individual scorers since colleges borrowed the stick game from the American Indian late in the 19th century.

title: $6.1 Million Refund Ordered in Jersey On Gas Overcharge
description: NEWARK, May 10The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest supplier of energy, was ordered today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to refund $6,187,000plus $618,700, representing 10 percent interestcollected as overpayments from its gas customers.

title: In Memoriam
description: RABINOVICHAlics B. In loving memory of a cherished & beloved wile, mother & grandmother who lives forever in our hearts. Joy, Joyce & Frances.

title: Woman Finally Drives at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (UPI)Janet Guthrie, on her third try, finally made her debut on the track at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, but her ride was cut short by mechanical problems in her car.

title: 30SECOND MOVIE: ATOMS IN ACTION
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (AP)Two University of Chicago physicists showed today what they said was the first movie of atoms in action.

title: Justice Department Indicates It might Not Defend 3 F.B.I. Agents in Suit by Socialist Workers Party
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Justice Department has raised the possibility that it will not defend in a civil lawsuit three agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who allegedly took part in or approved burglaries of the Socialist Workers Party's New York City offices in the early 1960's.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted moderate advances yesterday in heavier trading.

title: S.E.C. Sues General Tire; Company Agrees to Settle
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Securities and Exchange Commission leveled today against. the General Tire and Rubber Company the broadest array of charges it has brought against any company in its postWatergate drive to expose questionable corporate payments.

title: Off Field, Tarkenton Is Still Business
description: The Delta Air Lines people in Atlanta tell Fran Tarkenton that he flies in and out of his hometown twice as often as any other business executive they serve.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MAY 11, 1976

title: Glenn Says He Would Run On Jimmy Carter Ticket
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10 (UPI)Saying that Jimmy Carter has the Democratic Presidential nomination locked up, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, has indicated that he would be available as a running mate for the former Georgia Governor.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: D'OYLY CARTE OPERA COMPANY, Gilbert and Sullivan's The Pirates of Penzance, Uris Theater, 8.

title: Checking at Savings Banks Voted in Assembly, 9145
description: ALBANY, May 10The State Assembly tonight passed a bill to allow savings banks to offer free checking accounts, after defeating a handful of attempts to amend the bill with requirements that the banks also invest more in poor neighborhoods and in the state.

title: 2 Convictions Challenged In Broadway Pub Slaying
description: Two men convicted in a gangland murder three years ago may win new trials based on a written confession by a mar who is in prison for the paid killing of a rock music arranger. The arrangers wite has been convicted of setting up his murder for insurance money.

title: Notes on People
description: Sailing into the Washington Navy Yard aboard the royal yacht, Queen Margrethe II of Denmark and her husband, Prince Henrik, were welcomed yesterday by a 21gun salute and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. With him was the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs, K. B. Andersen. The visitors had traveled overnight from Norfolk, Va., and went directly to Blair House.

title: Tunnel Blast Kills 9 in Japan
description: TOKYO, May 10 (UPI)A gas explosion in an irrigation tunnel under construction in northern Japan killed nine workers today, the police said. The blast occurred near Yamagata city, about 190 miles north of Tokyo.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: The Face Game
description: It was an ominous development for Jimmy Carter last week when his face appeared on the cover of Time. Looking at the newsstand, you suddenly realized that something momentous had happened to Mr. Carter. He had become an old face.

title: Stavisky Asks Nadiari Inquiry On Summons Flood in District
description: State Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, Democrat of Flushing, Queens, has asked Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, to investigate reports that the Police Department has stepped up the writing of traffic summonses for residents of his district in reprisal cur a new law the Assemblyman sponsored.

title: Israel's Dilemma
description: Prime Minister Rabin may have bought a few weeks time for his tenuous coalition leadership, but the painstakingly contrived compromise on the settlements in the West Bank leaves totally unresolved a deep ideological clash inside Israel. By underscoring a misguided determination to move ever more Israeli settlers into the occupied Arab territoriesa concession to the militant hardlinersthe Rabin Cabinet is only piling up problems for future pcilicyinakers and for the course of IsraelUnited States relations.

title: Private Trade Flourishing in Soviet Georgia
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., May 6The old peasant held a small bunch of fresh scallions in his leathery hands, cradled them, fondled them, offered them gently to a smoothfaced young man. Thirty kopecks, the peasant said.

title: Landmarks Agency Fights Zoning Bid By Planning Panel
description: New zoning legislation drafted by the City Planning Commission to encourage developers to preserve landmarks is being opposed by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: ALBANY REENTERS MARKET AND SELLS $59 MI WON BONDS
description: ALBANY, May 10New York tate went into the bond market today for the first time since the fiscal crisis began more than a year ago, and successfully sold $59 million of its own long term bonds to a group of underwriters headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: DOCTORS CRITICIZE METHADONE RULES
description: Two doctors who helped develop and promote the use of methadone as a drug to treat heroin addiction have renewed their longstanding attack on Federal and State regulatory agencies which, they assert, have so restricted methadone programs that the bright future once forecast for the drug has not been realized.

title: RECORDER IS FOUND IN SPANISH CRASH
description: MADRID, May 10 (UPI)The Spanish Army today recovered an Iranian Air Force 747 cargo jet's flight recorder, which may reveal whether the plane exploded before it crashed yesterday. Nearly a score of persons, including four Americans, were killed.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO PROTECT A RIVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 10By a vote of 12 to 0, the House Interior Subcommittee on National Parks and Recreation approved today a bill to place 26.5 miles of the New River on the North Carolina Virginia border in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Valentino Cut Bobs Up; DryItYourself Lesson
description: The woman who is already tired of the wedge cut might consider a really sleek change, which the Lintermans salon at 21 East 62d Street calls the Rudolph Valentino. Depending on which decade one remembers, it's very much like the boyish bob of the 20's and 30's (remember Mary Astor?), or the barber shop haircut Norman Norell's models always wore and which Geoffrey Beene revived for his recent showing.

title: Striker Is Injured in Fall While Assisting a Tenant
description: A 42yearold striking building employee suffered critical head injuries Sunday afternoon when he fell down an elevator shaft in an Upper West Side building as he tried to take an elderly tenant to her apartment.

title: TRUDE GUERMONPREZ
description: Trude Guermonprez, whose weaving won the Craftsmanship Medal of the American Institute of Architects in 1970 and who had taught at the California College of Arts and Crafts since 1960, died Saturday in San Francisco, where; she lived.

title: Solti's Chicagoans Stimulate a Yen to Yell
description: It is pretty well agreed now, among decibel collectors, that the audiences at Chicago Symphony concerts make more noise than anybody. If you happen to pass Carnegie Hall tomorrow or Friday night and notice that sturdy old monument rocking slightly on its foundations, do not worry: It is only the Chicago orchestra's fans going happily mad over a performance conducted by Sir Georg Solti. (Don't run out to buy tickets, by the way; Chicago Symphony concerts are invariably sold out as soon as they are announced.)

title: Fred McLeod, Golfer, 94, Dies; Won United States Open in 1908
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Fred McLeod, winner of the 1908 United States Open golf tournament and an honorary starter of the Masters tournament last month in Augusta. Ga., died Saturday. He was 94 years old.

title: Flyers, Canadiens Study Strategy for Game 2 Tonight
description: MONTREAL, May 10The battle of the blackboards was waged today as two of hockey's best tacticians, Fred Shero and Scotty Bowman, prepared their teams for the second game of the National Hockey League's final round for the championship and the Stanley Cup.

title: A Reporter's Notebook The Tranquil Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 10There is the joke about the pilot coming in for a landing at Salisbury Airport. He tells his passengers the altitude, the weather conditions, the temperature, and then he says: Don't forget to set your watches back 10 years.

title: Baseball Negotiators Hope to Restart Stalled Talks on Pact
description: The possibility of a strike has been talked about from time to time, John Gaherin said yesterday, but any of our people who feel strongly about that possibility are ina vast minority. A strike now is unlikely.

title: Zambia University Reopens
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 10 (Agency FrancePress) The University of Zambia, closed by the Government following student demonstrations against the Government in February, was reopened today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Smithsonian Revives Centennial of 1876
description: WASHINGTON, May 10As if the hundreds of events and exhibits planned for the Bicentennial were not enough, the Smithsonian Institution has recaptured a piece of the American Centennial of 1876.

title: ISRAEL PLANNING TO SETTLE MORE OF OCCUPIED LAND
description: JERUSALEM, May 10Israel is drawing up plans for the establishment of a large number of new settlements in occupied Arab territory over the next several years, government officials familiar with the plans said today.

title: Tremor in Massachusetts
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 10 (UPI)A very slight earth tremor ran through the New Bedford area late, yesterday, the police said. The tremor, the second one to strike the area in the last two months, rattled windows, but did no damage.

title: Connecticut Democrats Vote Today in Delegate Selection Process
description: HARTFORD, May 10Connecticut has been turned into a quaint and confusing battleground for the voting tomorrow in the delegate selection process for Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is highly tempting to read letter like Dr. Imperato's (April 29) and not really hear what he is saying.

title: McFeeley Declares Intention to Resign P.B.A. Post
description: Kenneth McFeeley, who became president of the Policemen's Benevolent Association in an election upset two years ago, served a new surprise late yesterday by declaring his intention to resign, effective today.

title: Hertz Signs Consent Order On Used Rental Car Sales
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced that the Hertz Corporation had signed a consent order that prohibited the company from misrepresenting the condition of used rental cars it offered for sale.

title: Symphony Opens With Vintage Pieces
description: If science ever devises a computer with a soul, it probably will be something like the Chicago Symphony Orchestra as conducted by Sir Georg Solti. The priceless blend of precisiontooled technical skills and warmblooded artistry, which the Chicagoans have made their bench mark, went on display again last night when Sir Georg and his band opened their annual Carnegie Hall series.

title: Ford Aides Reported Critical of White House Staff
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 President Ford met with key campaign aides on political strategy today amid reports that some of his closest and most trusted advisers have complained about the political performance, of the White House staff.

title: Soviet, in U.N., Charges Israeli Genocide
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10The Soviet Union charged in the Security Council today that Israel had resorted to racial genocide in putting down unrest in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON. May 10 (UPI)The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that sponsors said would make the Federal Reserve System more responsive to the public interest. The bill, approved 279 to 85, with virtually no floor debate, would make the fouryear term of the Federal Reserve chairman roughly coincide with that of the President. This would trot apply until the present chairman, Arthur F. Burns, leaves office. His term expires in February, 1978.

title: Chess
description: James Tarjan, in winning the Subotica, Yugoslavia, International Tournament, revealed a new development toward greater sophistication in his positional play to go along with his penchant for involved tactical adventures. The blend enabled him to score six victories, one loss (to Karoly Honfi of Hungary) and four draws.

title: Stage: Shorter Titanic
description: When Titanic, an insane farce by Christopher Durang, a young Yale Drama School graduate, was given a showcase production Off Off Broadway several months ago at the Direct Theater, praised Mr. Durang's ferocious comic talent and suggestedabout the playthat, cut to one hour, this ship would float.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Northwest Pipeline Corporation of Salt Lake City filed a legal memorandum with the Federal Power Commission today in an attempt to make a belated entry into the competition for a naturalgas pipeline route trom Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, to the lower 48 states.

title: HARVEY FITE DIES; SCULPTOR WAS 72
description: SAUGERTIES, N.Y., May 10 (AP)Harvey Fite, a sculptor, died yesterday after a fall into quarry that he had been converting into a sprawling sculpture garden. He was 72 years old.

title: Ending the Strike
description: The negotiations between striking Local 32B of the Service Employees Union and the landlords appear to have been needlessly slowed down by militant representatives of rentcontrolled and rentstabilized apartments. Although the Realty Advisory Board managed to heal an earlier split in its negotiating team, a new impasse developed when the owners rejected a counterproposal by the union.

title: Captain Critical of Honor Code Is Asked to Leave West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10Capt. Arthur Lincoln, an Army lawyer who has criticized the alleged abuse of the West Point's honor code by officers and cadets, is being asked to leave the United States Military Academy.

title: New StopCarter Drive: Foes Seek a Series of Upsets
description: HASTINGS, Neb., May 10The outlines of a new theory of how to deny the Democratic Presidential nomination to Jimmy Carter have emerged during the two weeks since the Georgian's decisive victory in Pennsylvania  a victory that drove to the sidelines his principal declared opponent, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, and principal undeclared opponent, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota. Few party leaders expect Mr. Carter to be stopped; most agree with the candidate's own assessment, delivered in Nebraska last week, that it's too late to head him off. But this has been a year of startling reversals of form, and yet another remains possible if quite improbable.

title: LISBON REDS URGE CIVILIAN PRESIDENT
description: LISBON, May 10 (Reuters) The Portuguese Communist Party said today that it believed support could still be rallied for a civilian candidate in the presidential elections next month.

title: DEADLINE PASSES IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: Mayor Beame's midnight deadline for settlement of the apartment workers strike passed last night without word from either side in the deadlocked contract negotiations on whether it would submit the dispute to arbitration, as the Mayor had requested.

title: Amex Options Trading Under S.E.C.'s Scrutiny
description: Apparently dissatisfied with the results an American Stock Exchange investigation into options trading irregularities, the Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a fullscale investigation of its own, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Tuition Protest Mars Dedication of Medical School
description: NEWARK. May 10While hundreds of students marched today to protest projected tuition increases at the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry, state and Federal officials dedicated the new $189 million campus of the college to the goals of health research, education and care.

title: Free Ads for Free Enterprise
description: Here we go again on the free enterprise system. Dun's Review in September will begin to publish each month a free ad from some American corporation that uses the space to communicate the importance and advantages profits and the free enterprise system.

title: 9 SOVIET CLERICS ARRIVE ON A VISIT
description: A delegation of Soviet clergymen, including a rabbi, arrived here yesterday on a 10day goodwill visit in which they said they hoped to observe religious life in the United States.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ?? pictured himself and other members of the board as firmly resolved to prevent an expansion of money supply and credit that might release a new wave of inflation.

title: NBC to Run People Special as a Pilot
description: On Saturday night, Aug. 21, NBC will offer a 90minute special entitled People, marking the second attempt by TimeLife 1Films to develop a television series based on People magazine. This year, the company produced a 30minute film on AnnMargaret, the actress and singer, as the pilot for a proposed syndicated series entitled People.

title: EAT INSPECTORS TELL OF BRIBERY
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) Two former military meat inspectors told a Senate hearing today of receiving thousands of dollars in bribes to enable Bostonarea meat packing concern to substitute cheap meat for prime cuts in military shipments.

title: HARVEY FITE DIES; SCULPTOR WAS 72
description: SAUGERTIES. N.Y., May 10 (AP)Harvey Fite, a sculptor, died yesterday after a fall into quarry that he had been converting into a sprawling sculpture garden. He was 72 years old.

title: Bernhard Cleared In Lockheed Case, Dutch Paper Says
description: AMSTERDAM, May 10 (AP)A Dutch investigative panel has cleared Prince Bernhard of accepting bribes from Lockheed, but it said he must have known that payouts were made to that payout were made to some of his associates, the Netherlands second largest newspaper reported today.

title: TWO UNION LOCALS TOLD TO END BIAS
description: Two union locals have been told by a Federal judge that they must end a pattern and practice of discrimination that prevents blacks and Puerto Ricans from obtaining construction jobs in New York City.

title: 28 Faculty Women Sue Stony Brook In SexBias Case
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., May 10A group of 28 women faculty members and other professionals at the State University of New York's center here today filed a suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn charging the university with sex discrimination in hiring, salaries and promotions.

title: 28 Faculty Women Sue Stony Brook In SexBias Case
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., May 10A group of 28 women faculty members and other professionals at the State University of New York's center here today filed a suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn charging the university with sex discrimination in hiring, salaries and promotions.

title: Hockey Owners, Players Sign Pact
description: MONTREAL, May 10 (AP)A fiveyear agreement between National Hockey League owners and players, agreed upon last Oct. 6, finally was signed today, The delay was caused by three major decisions involving other sports, that could have affected player stances on labor issues, according to Clarence Campbell, the president of the N.H.L.

title: German Printers Offer Deal
description: BONN, May 10 (UPI)The West German printers union said today that it would go ahead tomorrow with a 12day strike against the nation's large newspapers, but would allow smaller ones to publish. The union said printers would go back to work at newspapers with circulations under 50,000 and staffs of fewer than 50 persons if employers agreed not to print newspapers that are still struck.

title: Citizens Union Asks Community Boards Get Role in Budget
description: The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization, urged Mayor Beame yesterday to begin immediately a new management planning system requiring budget officials and community planning boards to work together to set explicit standards and objectives for delivering services.

title: ALBANY REENTERS MARKET AND SELLS $59 MILLION BONDS
description: ALBANY, May 10New York tate went into the bond market today for the first time since the fiscal crisis began more than a year ago, and successfully sold $59 million of its own long term bonds to a group of underwriters headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank

title: Assistance Is Offered In Getting Quake News
description: ROME, May 10 (AP)The International Social Service said today that it was prepared to help Italians living abroad get information about relatives in the earthquakestricken area.

title: Amex Stock Prices Show Sharp Gains; 0TCIsUp Slightly
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted a sharp advance yesterday while the overthe  counter market finished with small gains.

title: Dinah and Kaye Among 22 Winners Of Daytime Emmies
description: The third annual Daytime Enuny Awards were presented yesterday at the Vivian Beaumont Theater by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, with Another !World selected as the outstanding . drama series, First !Ladies Diaries: Edith Wilson was the best drama special, $20,000 Pyramid was the top game or audience participation show and Dinah! was the winner in the talk, service or variety series.

title: Market Cheering to Some, Though Dow Rally Falters
description: A late rally ran out of steam yesterday as the stock market triedbut failedto establish a 39month high.

title: Ashe and Smith Lead Advance in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 11 (UPI)Arthur Ashe, shaky at the start, beat India's Anand Amritraj, 75, 61, in the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament today.

title: HERMAN PERL
description: Herman Perl, of Short Hills, N. J., chairman of Guardian Industries Inc. of Florham Park, N. J., died in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 53.
