title: Foreign Aid Veto
description: Once more President Ford has resorted to the veto and once more his explanation is unconvincing at best. This time, the issue was foreign aid, and money was not the stated reason for the President's disapproval. What Mr. Ford objected to was inclusion in the legislation provisions to give Congress a more active role in shaping foreign policy. The intent of this entirely appropriate Congressional participation was portrayed by Mr. Ford as an unconstitutional limitation on his ability to conduct foreign policy.

title: Bellevue to Sell Valuable Art Legacy
description: Bellevue Hospital, deciding to trade sentiment for cash, is going to sell part of its inheritance a painting by Arshile Gorky called Soft Night, which the hospital hopes will bring as much as $150,000.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: $413.3 Billion Top Is Voted by Senate On Budget for 77
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) A $413.3 billion Government spending ceiling for 1977 was approved by the Senate today with a stern warning to President Ford that Congress's role in budget making must not be violated.

title: Jaialai Dates Set
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 12  The Connecticut Commission on Special Revenue granted Bridgeport Jaialai, Inc., its official dates for 1976 today. The $16 million fronton, with a capacity for 7,000 fans, will open June 1 and run through Dec. 31.

title: Marc Slonim, 82, Is Dead; EuropeanLetters Critic
description: Marc Slonim, the Russianborn American critic and author who enjoyed an international reputation as an expert on European literature, died May 8 at BeaulieusurMer, on the French Riviera, while on vacation, it was disclosed yesterday in Geneva, where Mr. Slonim had lived since 1963. He was 82 years old.

title: DETAILS SOUGHT INLIQUOR PAYOFFS
description: A report that a liquor distributorship partly owned by Matthew Feldman, the president of the New Jersey State Senate, illegally paid $6,400 in bribes to Emersons Ltd., restaurant chain, to obtain its business prompted requests for further information from Federal and state prosecutors yesterday.

title: Bethlehem Raising Prices Of Varied Steel Products
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steelmaker after the United States Steel Corporation, went along with all the other major steel companies yesterday and announced price increases of jabout 6 percent effective with shipments June 14.

title: United Brands Making Payments When Legal
description: BOSTON, May 12 (AP)The United Brands Company will continue to make customary payments in foreign countries as long as they are legal there, Max M. Fisher, the company's chairman, said today. He told stockholders at the food and chemical company's annual meeting the board will decide each payment on a casebycase basis.

title: . . . and the Democrats
description: Former Governor Carter also encountered defeat Nebraska. Senator Frank Church is an admirable public servant, but his victory there had as much to do with the intensity of his campaign effort as with the virtues of his record. Senator Church spent a total of 12 days In the state during the past month while Mr. Carter spent only one. On this point, however, Mr. Carter has no grounds for complaint as he won his critical early victories by the same kind of intensely focused, personal solicitation of a relatively small number of voters.

title: Sellers Not Invited to Olympic Tryouts
description: Phil Sellers, Ed Jordan, Mike Dabney and the other Rutgers basketball players had the best possible season. Remember? They were undefeated. Then came the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and Rutgers won three more times to reach the semifinal round at Philadelphia. Then came defeat, the 8670 loss to Michigan that seemed to be more easily remembered than the 31 straight triumphs.

title: The Dance: Baryshnikov in Ailey's Ellington Piece
description: What makes a gala a gala? Is that rhetorical? Probably not. Of course, one can easily see gala packagesa little bit of this brilliance added to a little bit of that genius, a parade of talent passing across a stage with breathless speed and a wary elegance. But the real gala is one that offers the unrepeatable occasion.

title: Aides Say Carter Is Courted by Russians
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Jimmy Carter's aides and advisers say that Soviet Embassy officials have made numerous contacts with them, expressing interest in the Presidential race and implying that they could possibly pursue policies that might influence the outcome.

title: Music: Lyric America
description: A Brooklyn journalist with keen ears once reported, in a phrase that somehow got past his editor, I hear America singing, the varied carols I hear. He is by no means the only person to have detected a lyric strain in his countrymen, of course. During this very season Town Hall has been presenting a Bicentennial salute to the country's song composers, entitled Sing Out, America.

title: SIX HUGHES WILLS DISCLOSED SO FAR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12Two more purported wills of the late Howard R. Hughes were filed today in Las Vegas, Nev. making four on file there. A fifth purported Hughes will is on file in Houston, and a sixth, existence of which has not been previously disclosed, is in the possession of The New York Times. It was mailed from Washington to the Times editors in New York.

title: For Luanda Regime the Spoils of War Are a Big Pack of Peacetime Problems
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 12The Angolan capital still rings with revolutionary slogans: for people's power, the struggle continues, the victory is certain.

title: Supplies of Gasoline Continue to Drop, But Pace Lessens
description: Gasoline stocks in the United States continued to decline in the latest week although the drain on supplies was less than it had been in recent weeks, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: JOHN FRANCIS RYAN
description: John Francis Ryan, who retirel in 1970 after 20 years as general counsel for the American Petroleum Institute, died Tuesday in White Plains Hospital. He lived in White Plains.

title: Primary Results
description: Following are the latest vote tallies on Tuesday's Presidential primaries in Nebraska and West Virginia:

title: PERU GOVERNMENT GRANTS 34 AMNESTY
description: LIMA, Peru, May 12 (AP)Peru's leftist military Government has granted amnesty to four prominent journalists and 30 other political prisoners.

title: Bridge
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 12The gods of bridge that have watched over the members of the famous Italian Blue Team for many years were on duty again here this afternoon, when the world bridge team Olympiad continued.

title: Bolivia Tightens Security
description: LA. PAZ, Bolivia, May 12 (Reuters)Bolivia today tightened security around those involved in the 1967 campaign to kill Ernesto Che Guevara following the murder of General Zenteno Anaya in Paris.

title: G.O.P. Leader in Brooklyft Gives Support to Reagan
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Brooklyn Republican leader, dedared yesterday his support for Ronald Reagan for his party's nomination for President and predicted that 14 other delegates to the national convention from Brooklyn's 18member group would follow his lead.

title: City's Community Boards Back Rules Expanding Their Powers
description: Representatives of community boards in various parts of New York City gave general approval yesterday to new procedures requiring the 62 boards to exercise greater authority beginning July 1 in virtually all matters relating to land use within their districts.

title: BUILDING OWNERS BAR PANEL'S PLAN TO SETTLE STRIKE
description: The Realty Advisory Board, which represents apartmenthouse landlords, yesterday rejected the recommendations of a special panel for settling the 10dayold walkout of building service employees.

title: HYMAN KIRSCH, 99, MADE DIET SODAS
description: Hyman Kirsch. a beverage industry pioneer and originator of sugarfree soft drinks, died yesterday in the Manhattan apartment of his son. He was 99 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox Recall Otten
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)The Chicago White Sox replaced today their injured pitcher, Wilbur Wood, on the roster with Jim Otten of the team's Iowa farm club. Wood suffered a broken kneecapSunday when he was hit by a line drive. Otten, a righthander, has appeared in five games this spring in the American Association, winning two and losing one.

title: Screen: Maximilian Schell's 'End of the Game' Opens
description: "End of the Game" is a metaphysical cuckoo clock of a movie, full of talent and fog. But the mechanism is deranged. Instead of every hour or half-hour, the cuckoo pops out every minute and a half.It jangles us. There's too much writing, too much acting, too many symbols, too much paradox, too many significant camera angles. The author thinks of lots of clever ways to do each scene; instead of choosing he does them all.The author, mostly, is Maximilian Schell, who directs, produces and has written the screenplay. The co-writer on the screenplay is Friederich Duerrenmatt, who wrote the original novel, "The Judge and His Hangman," and who also  in more ways than one this movie is like an evening of charades among friends  acts a part.Other well-known people drop in briefly, as if paying a social call. There's Pinchas Zukerman, a profile swirled in fog, playing for 30 seconds or so on an autumn lawn. Donald Sutherland is even briefer; he is the photograph of a dead man, but when the dead man appears as a corpse some other actor has taken over.Casualness, sloppiness, excess; yet a lot of "Game" is entertaining, and there is an outrageous vitality to it that gives it a bumpy appeal.It is half allegory, half mystery. Thirty years ago two young Swiss men sit in a cafe in Istanbul. Gastmann bets Baerlach that he can murder a girl drifter they have picked up without anyone's being able to prove it on him. He pushes her into the Bosphorus.That is the prologue. When the film proper begins, we are back in Switzerland. Gastmann has become a master businessman-criminal, who wears the Swiss Government around his wrist like a thin watch. Baerlach is a decrepit, ulcer-plagued, cantankerous police detective whose life is a futile effort to catch and punish Gastmann.Then Schmid, a subordinate of Baerlach, who has been investigating Gastmann, is found murdered. Baerlach brings in Tschanz, a young detective, to help him and the two slowly move in on Gastmann. Gastmann is finally brought down although the death of Schmid is the one crime he didn't commit. The identity of Schmid's killer is the film's one real surprise.Baerlach is played by Martin Rittusually known as a director  Gastmann by Robert Shaw and Tschanz by Jon Voight. All three overact but it is a fine, joyful overacting. Perhaps overacting is appropriate to allegory; in any case their inspired hamminess is the film's real meat.Mr. Ritt is a fat, shaggy stomach ache. Lethargic and deadly, he is an untidy version of Porfiry in "Crime and Punishment." Mr. Shaw, who lives in a grand mansion complete with two black-coated stranglers, a leopard who prowls loose, and a wheel-chaired mother, is bouncily evil.Mr. Voight is apple-cheeked, righteous and passionate; when the role calls for more complexity he provides it. Jacqueline Bisset, as an Irish dryad whose function is to seduce and confuse, seduces and confuses."End of the Game," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie Theater, is rated PG.

title: Texas Paper Names Editor
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 12 (UPI) Ray Mariotti, editor of the West Palm Beach Post, in Florida, has been named to succeed Sam Wood as editor of The Austin AmericanStatesman, Jim Fain, publisher said today. Mr. Wood is retiring effective May 28 after 50 years with the newspaper concern.

title: Dow Off by 0.94 to 1,005.67 As Trading Shows a Drop
description: Stock prices eased slightly yesterday, but the market's main indicators showed only nominal changes.

title: Ashe Sets Back Smith; Connors, Richey Gain
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 12 (AP)Arthur Ashe fought off three match points in posting a 75, 36, 75 victory over Stan Smith and gaining the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament today.

title: Changes Backed in House On Synthetic Fuel Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The House Science and Technology Committee approved today a modified synthetic fuels support bill that included authority for $4 billion of Federal loan guarantees for various types of projects.

title: Bill on Checking Accounts in Savings Banks Gains
description: ALBANY, May 12The Republican majority on the Senate Banking Committee brought the bill to allow checking accounts at savings banks closer to final passage today when it overcame Democratic objections and voted to report the measure to the floor.

title: EXM.P. DESCRIBES THORPE CASE ROLE
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., May 12A former member of Britain's House of Commons today described his part in what he said was a 10year coverup conspiracy to protect the Liberal Party leader, Jeremy Thorpe, against accusations that he had a homosexual relationship with a former model.

title: CARTER IS GREETED ON NEW YORK VISIT
description: New York Democrats gave Jimmy Carter 12 percent of their votes in the primary election, but their leaders welcomed him to New York City yesterday as the acknowledged frontrunner for the party's Presidential nminaton.

title: In Memorium
description: GREENFIELD Ann. Devoted. unselfish, missed. Spiritually near always. SADIE.

title: RUDOLF KEMPE, CONDUCTOR, DIES
description: GENEVA, May 12Rudolf Kempe, the Germanborn orchestra conductor, died in a Zurich hospital last night at the age of 65.

title: Carey Proposes Wagner Do Key Cunningham Jobs
description: Governor Carey proposed yesterday that former Mayor Robert F. Wagner take over many of the duties of Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, in what was interpreted by some political leaders as a signal to Mr. Cunningham to quit his post.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Curfew Is Imposed By Jamaica in Bid To Curb Violence
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 12 (AP)The Jamaican Government has imposed a dusktodawn curfew in an effort to halt a continuing wave of violence variously attributed to political militants, common criminals and widespread frustration over Kingston's severe housing shortage.

title: Portuguese Socialists Back Army Chief
description: LISBON, May 12 (Reuters)Portugal's powerful Socialist Party today backed the army chief of staff, Gen. Amnio Ramalho Eanes, for the Presidency.

title: Documentary on Soviet May Aid Reagan
description: A documentary on the buildup of Soviet naval forces, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation a year ago and being syndicated now to local stations in this country, may have inadvertent implications for the Presidential campaigns.

title: City Ballet Evening Puts Ravel's Music With Stravinsky's
description: The New York City Ballet has warmly celebrated the genius of Igor Stravinsky and Maurice Ravel on separate occasions, but one wonders how wise it was to bind them together in a tight bundle of three short ballets on Tuesday evening at the State Theater. Monumentum Pro Gesualdo, with Movements for Piano and Orchestra, contains some of Stravinsky's sparest music, while the nostalgic romanticism of Ravel's Rapsodie Espagnote is almost unseemly in its lushness.

title: 3 Black Representatives Back Brown for President
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  Three black members of the California House endorsed Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. for President today because of what they termed the new excitement and enthusiasm he had brought to the race for the Democratic nomination.

title: Professor Contends Medical Schools Standards Have Dropped Because of Rise in Minority Students
description: Academic standards in the nation's medical schools have fallen in recent years because of the rise in the number of admissions of minority students with substandard academic qualifications, a leading medical educator has charged in a scientific journal.

title: Losers Complain About Outlay On Jay Rockefeller's Campaign
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 12Losers in West Virginia's Democratic gubernatorial primary complained bitterly today about the alleged expenditure here of Rockefeller millions in the landslide victory of John D. Rockefeller 4th. But there were no documented accusations against the wealthy, 38yearold candidate and there was little to dim the shine of his nearly statewide sweep.

title: Captain Says He Feared Lifeboat Upset
description: CAMDEN, NJ., May 12The captain of a schooner that sank off Brigantine with the subsequent death of two young crewmen testified today that if he had brown his 80pound Labrador retriever out of an 11foot lifeboat, the boat would have capsized.

description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Leroy Haley: 138 pounds, Las Vegas, outpointed Rafael Nunez, 138, Mexico. 8 rounds; Roxell Mosley Jr., 150, Las Vegas, knocked out Juan Ramirez, 148, Mexico, 3.

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

description: More than 6,700 people received degrees at Columbia University yesterday, under the tightest security in several years, at commencement events during which Governor Carey asked for Federal aid to solve the problems of New York and the Northeast.

title: A Veterinarian Busy on Barn Calls
description: You have to love your work to stay in this business, Dr. Wallace F. Knight, a veterinarian, said during a round of barn calls the other day. A bull has injured Dr. Knight's back, a falling horse has crushed his leg, and a buffalo has kicked him in the head. Dr. Knight, like the few other largeanimal veterinarians in Hunterdon County, is a necessity in the heart of New Jersey's livestock industry.

title: FORD POSTPONES FORMAL. SIGNING OF A SOVIET PACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The United States and the Soviet Union quietly initialed a treaty today in Moscow putting limits on the size of underground nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes, but the formal signing ceremonies originally planned for tomorrow at the White House and the Kremlin were postponed.

title: Mrs. Abzug Says I'm Running for Senate. Period.
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Representative Bella S Abzug. Democrat of Manhattan, today disavowed any interest in retaining her House seat as she prepared to announce formally on Monday her candidacy for the party's nomination for the Senate seat held by James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican.

title: Kallinger Loses Request For Trial Outside Bergen
description: HACKENSACK, May 12 (UPI) Judge Theodore W. Trautwein of Superior Court has turned down a defense motion to move the site of Joseph Kalinger's murder trial outside Bergen County.

title: Simmons of Cards Signs 3Year Pact
description: ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) Ted Simmons, a switchhitting catcher and the National League's second leading batter in 1975, signed a threeyear contract today with the St. Louis Cardinals that is believed to make him the highest paid player in the club's history and only the second to receive such a longterm contract.

title: New Bronze Age Date Reported
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 13A lively, prosperous Bronze Age culture has been found to have flourished on a remote plateau of northeastern Thailand more than 5,600 years agoa surprising discovery that, archeologists believe, challenges many longheld assumptions about the beginnings of technology and civilization.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday approved increases in fares on bus service to race tracks and charter bus rates for Transport of New Jersey. The increases will raise roundtrip fares on buses to Monmouth Park, Garden State Park, Atlantic City and Freehold race tracks by $1. They will also raise fares by smaller amounts where there is only a short distance between the point of departure and track. For example, a roundtrip fare between Atlantic City and the race track would go up by 50 cents.

description: WASHINGTON, May 13The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee today made the smallest cut in a military budget in a decade, reducing the Ford Administration's request for $106.7 billion in military appropriations by only $800 million.

title: Preview of a Movable Feast On 9th Ave.
description: WHATEVER anyone else may be doing this weekend, the activity most likely to attract bonafide eaters has to be the Ninth Avenue International Festival, taking placethe, weather permittingfrom 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Running from 37th Street to 57th Street, in the area once known as Paddy's Market, the festival will celebrate the worldwide array of foods regularly available in the shops and restaurants along the avenue and on the side streets.

title: For La Selva, Music Is the Food of Life
description: Verdi created so many operatic masterpieces that it was never considered necessary to revive those earlier works in which the composer was learning his craft. That is, until recent decades. The Verdi genius was found still present, at least in part, in these early works, and they seemed well worth doing. Tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon, operagoers will get their first chance to see a fully staged production of Giovanna d'Arco (Joan of Arc), the seventh of the composer's 26 operas, dating back to 1845. It will be given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which has one of the city's finest auditoriums for opera.

title: Total Business Inventories Rose a Bit Again in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Total business inventories rose moderately again in March in a continuation of the underlying pattern of the recovery of the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Weekend Gardening: Terrace Tomatoes
description: PROBABLY the ultimate in New York terrace lunching is a bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwich, with sunripened tomatoes plucked from a nearby vine at the very moment the bread slides down its slot in the toaster. Lettuce is a coolloving crop; you'll have to get it at the greengrocer's. And the bacon, of course, will have to be storebought, too. But oh, those tomatoes! They bear no resemblance at all to the green wax balls currently sold in the supermarket as hard ripe tomatoesan appellation whose only truth lies in the word hard.

title: There just wasn't room in our lives now for another baby
description: We were sitting in a bar on Lexington Avenue when I told my husband I was pregnant. It is not a memory I like to dwell on. Instead of the champagne and hope which had heralded the impending births of our first, second and third child, the news of this one was greeted with shocked silence and scotch. Jesus, my husband kept saying to himself, stirring the ice cubes around and around. Oh, Jesus.

title: Miss Vesell Plays Mixed Recital
description: Victoria Vesell has had many distinguished teachers here and in ItalyMichelangeli among them and she has won many awards. Now a teacher at the New School as well as a performer, the pianist gave a recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

description: BEIRUT Lebanon, May 13Some of the heaviest ground fighting and artillery exchanges in Lebanon's 13monthold civil war flared today as peace efforts were stalled. The Beirut radio reported that 300 people were killed or wounded in the last 24 hours.

title: $1.2 Million Given To Soccer in U.S.
description: Soccer programs for youth in the United States will receive at least $1.2 million from the CocaCola Company, according to a joint announcement here and in London yesterday. The company will also give $5 million more to the International Federation to promote youth soccer programs throughout the world, and will also assist in the staging of the Bicentennial tournament later this month.

title: March on Eritrea Denied by Ethiopia Despite Evidence
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 13 (Reuters)Ethiopia's military rulers have strongly denied that they plan a peasants' march into Eritrea, but evidence reported by usually reliable sources suggests that some major initiative is being considered against secessionist guerrillas in the Red Sea provnice.

title: 486 to Try Out for Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 13 (AP)A total of 486 players have registered for freeagent tryouts to be conducted by the New York Jets this week the National Football League club said today. The Jets will look at 85 kickers tomorrow

description: TRENTON, May 13The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered today that the state's 2,500 public schools be closed on July 1 unless the Legislature came up with a constitutional method of financing them.

title: Report On a Goofy Town
description: WASHINGTON, May 13When the Presidency is up for grabs, this town goes a little goofy. It knows precisely what to do about bandwagons (get aboard) or sinking ships (get overboard), but right now it's in a state of subdued confusion.

title: Nuggets, Up by 22 Points, Lose, 112106, in Sixth Game
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 13 In an astonishing comeback from a 22point deficit with 17 minutes left in the game, the New York Nets defeated the Denver Nuggets, 112106, tonight and won the championship of the Argerican Basketball Association for the second time in three seasons.

title: Planners O.K. Film House at Plaza Hotel
description: The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a special permit for construction of a 212seat movie theater in the basement of the Plaza Hotel.

title: China's Stress on Modernization Transforms the Farm Commune
description: CANTON, May 7  in the main street of the Hsinhua commune 22 miles north of here, a whiteuniformed policeman directs a steady stream of chugging tractors and honking trucks with the aid of a shiny new traffic light.

title: North Europe Fears Lessening of U.S. Role in NATO
description: OSLONations of northern Europe are privately expressing fears that the United States will diminish its links to the Atlantic, alliance and that West Germany will accelerate its powerful and growing role in Europe if Communists gain a share of national power in Italy.

title: Art: Heizer's Sculptural World
description: MICHAEL HETZER painter, sculptor, master builder on a scale undreamed of by Ibsenspends most of his time now near Complex I, the enormous construction he built in the Nevada desert, north of Las Vegas. To see Complex I is for our generation what seeing Easter Island or Angkor Wat was for our grandfathers: an experience that leaves those who undergo it both enlarged and exhilarated.

title: KISSINGER VOWS EFFORT TO CHANGE RULE IN RHODESIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger sought to assure the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Ford Administration would act energetically to carry out its new policy of seeking an end to white minority rule in Rhodesia.

title: Screen: Cukor's U.S.-Soviet 'Blue Bird'
description: TECHNICALLY "The Blue Bird," the new screen version of Maurice Maeterlinck's old, numbingly high-minded fairy-tale parable, is an American-Soviet co-productionthe firsta single film made by the pooling of American and Soviet talents.The movie was produced entirely in the Soviet Union, mostly in Leningrad and environs, under the direction of an American (George Cukor), with American and English actors (Elizabeth Taylor, Ava Gardner, Jane Fonda, Cicely Tyson, Robert Morley, Harry Andrews), with Soviet performers (Oleg Popov, Nadejda Pavlova, members of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet Company), with one English cameraman and one Soviet, and with dozens of Soviet technicians.What is being shown at Radio City Music Hall, where "The Blue Bird" opened yesterday, is one movie. Yet as you watch it you keep seeing two films that want to compete but don't, everyone being polite, accepting compromise, effectively neutered.One of these films is blandly American, like the sort of processed cheese sold in jars that can later be used as water glasses. The other is dimly Russian but without any real Russian character, except for the sets, which aren't great. They look like stuff left over from the Bolshoi Opera's last road tour.Though the film has about it a kind of lumbering tackiness that I associate with Soviet stage spectacle, I suspect that the Russian version of this co-production might be a lot more interesting than ours. For one thing, Russian audiences apparently love "The Blue Bird," the chef d'oeuvre of the Belgian-born playwright who allowed Stanislavsky to stage the world premiere at the Moscow Art Theater in 1908. This love and familiarity with the work might possibly have inspired Soviet film makers to bring to it a consistency of character and style, as well as a decisive point of view, completely absent from the hyphenated production we have here.Spectacle for spectacle's sake no longer is the rage in this country. It can still work sometimes if it's put on a large patch of ice, but the romantic notions that motivate "The Blue Bird" are enough to send most American children, to say nothing of the ancients who may accompany them to the film, into antisocial states beginning with catatonia and ending in armed rebellion."The Blue Bird" is the story of Tyltyi and Myltyi, two poor peasant children who are instructed by the Queen of Light to seek the Blue Bird of Happiness. To help them on their quest. Light gives the kids a hat decorated with a magic diamond that permits them to call forth the souls of all things, animate and inanimate. Thus Tyltyi and Myltyi set off on their journey accompanied not only by Light (Miss Taylor in head-to-foot stage jewels) but by people representing Bread, Milk, Water, Sugar, Fire, Cat and Dog.At this point I'm afraid that I'm going to have to give away the ending of the film: before the children learn that the Blue Bird of Happiness is in their own backyard, they visit the kingdom of the past and the future, and the queendoms of night and luxury, at each stop learning some bit of wisdom. The film is not very old before you're longing to see a nice, self-absorbed Munchkin who wouldn't know an aphorism from a spitball.Mr. Cukor, a director of wit and immense verve ("Holiday," "Pat and Mike," the Judy Garland "A Star Is Born") seems to have had less chance to direct in this case than to act as the goodwill ambassador who got his actors on and off the sets on time.The English-language screenplay, by Hugh Whitemore and Alfred Hayes, would tax the inspirations of anyone. What could Mr. Cukor possibly have suggested to Miss Taylor to help her read a line like, "I am the light that makes men see/The radiance in reality"? Keep a straight face, perhaps. The actress has some creditably funny moments as a witch and some not-so-good as a peasant mother who darns socks.None of the English-speaking actors can do much but behave as if he was in a very unlikely pageant. This includes Miss Gardner (Luxury), Miss Fonda (Night), George Cole (Dog) and Cicely Tyson (Cat). However, the two childrenTodd Lookinland as the boy and Patsy Kensit as the girlare quite charming in situations that make the adults look ridiculous.The Soviet cast members, who speak in badly dubbed English, are no better except when they are given a chance to dance. Nadejda Pavlova is briefly, truly radiant in a tiny snippet from a ballet in which she dances the Blue Bird, but we see a lot less of it than I'm sure the Soviet audiences will. Members of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet are also featured in other dances, all of which appear to have been abbreviated for our consumption.We are also given several dreadful, Disney-esque songs, including one stunner called (I think) "The Blue Halloo."Why the film suffers from so many technical problems, I have no idea. The color quality of the footage involving the major characters often doesn't match the material shot, I assume, by the Russian cinematographer. Then there are all those blue birds we see from time to time. Some look like black birds and some are simply pigeons dyed blue.No New Yorker in his right mind would cross a street to look for a pigeon.

title: Rampage in St.Etienne
description: ST.ETIENNE, France, May 13 (UPI)Angry French soccer fans went on a rampage to avenge the defeat of their soccer team by West Gerfinal, gripping this grimy industrial city with mass hysteria into the early hours today.

title: Perspective
description: PARISBusiness is picking up in Europe too, but there is little Euphoria because of increasing realization of the deep meaning of the bond between economics and politics and the limits of each upon the other.

title: Newspaper Cites Growing Evidence Of Torture in Spain
description: LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) the London Times said today that throughout Spain, and es??ecially in the Basque provinces, ??here was increasing evidence of police torture of suspected political offenders.

title: DiFalco Politically Powerful for 2 Decades
description: Manhattan Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco, Who for two decades has held what is supposed to be a nonpolitical and essentially nonpartisan judicial position, has nevertheless managed to accumulate considerable amounts of political influence and power simply by virtue of that position.

title: State Sales Tax on Cable TV Might End Before It Begins
description: ALBANY, May 13A state sales tax on cable television, which was incorporated by the Legislature into the budget it passed two months ago, may be repealed as a result of protests from the cable television industry and consumers.

title: Caldwell Festival Stars Opera Airs
description: Opera and symphony will be served in generous portions tonight at the Caldwell College Fine Arts Music Festival. The program begins at 8 at the college's student center.

title: Darius Explores Mime
description: The blurred frontiers of mime start in a twilight zone where conventional drama leaves off but before dance really begins. Adam Darius sees that border lying closer to dance than mimes reared in the tradition of Decroux, and he presented his case entertainingly and somewhat astringently on the Interludes series at Town Hall early Wednesday evening.

title: Antiques
description: ART DECO ivory and bronze figurines are as popular now in revival as when they were newly minted between World War I and II, and in terms of dotlars, they could be considered an even greater success.

title: Nets Capture Title
description: The New York Nets won the American Basketball Association title last night for the second time in three years, beating the Denver Nuggets, 112106, and 4 games to 2. Page A21.

title: Election Panel Funds Sought
description: WASHINGTON. May 13 (UPI) President Ford asked Congress today for $250,000 for salaries and expenses of the newly revived Federal Election Commission. Mr. Ford reluctantly signed a bill Tuesday that put the commission back in business after the Supreme Court ruled that selection of some members of the panel by Congress was unconstitutional.

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Lawyer Pictures Captain As Hero in Lifeboat Case
description: CAMDEN, May 13The attorney for a schooner captain whose ship sank with the subsequent loss of two lives depicted the captain today as a hero for saving four lives in a lifeboat.

title: A Report to the Hospitals Corporation Calls for Keeping City Institutions Open
description: A confidential report commissioned by the board of directors of the New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has called for a reversal of the board's earlier decision to close some municipal hospitals as an economy measure.

title: Advertising
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13As the first business session of the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies got under way today, Stuart B. Upson, chairman of DancerFitzgeraldSample, who was presiding, promised that the threeday program would include discussions of two most important, overreported and most highly misunderstood subjects. He was talking about agency compensation and comparative advertising and promised to clear up the confusion.

title: WILLIAM K. BAKER
description: William Kinnicut Baker, a freelance music critic who had made his home in Vienna for the last several years, died, apparently of a heart attack, in New York on Wednesday evening. He was 50 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Beame and Public Events Commissioner Angier Biddle Duke may now address each otherand be addressed as  Commander. Both received that Danish rank Wednesday in the Order of the Dannebrog, named for the Danish flag. ConsulGeneral Erik KrogMeyer presented the decorations at Gracie Mansion in an advanced celekration of Queen Margrethe's coming visit here and in recognition of Mr. Duke's 196869 service as Ambassador to Denmark. Decorated as Knights of the Dannebrog were Walter Terry, the dance critic, for his longtime coverage of Danish ballet; John Heistein, a Norwegian who is president for North America of Scandinavian Airlines, and Jens Rommerdahl, a DanishAmerican since 1945, who is director of the new passenger terminal on the West Side piers.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: CAR SALES RATE UP 46,870 MAY 1 TO 10 AS SURGE GOES ON
description: DETROIT, May 13The daily selling rate for domestic new cars was up 46.8 percent in the first third of May from last year, as the American automobile industry's comeback went into its eighth straight month, the four companies reported today.

title: Nets' Backup Center Takes Center Stage
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.. May 13 Jim Eakins stood in the center of the crowded Nets' dressing room tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, champagne dripping from his skinny, 6foot11inch frame.

title: Broadway
description: KERMIT BLOOMGARDEN, who, as a producer, has always been involved in every part of his productions, will bring Poor Murderer to Broadway next fall. Mr. Bloomgarden first saw Poor Murderer, which is by Pavel Kohout, a Czech, at Herbert Berghof's studio last summer and then spent months trying to acquire the rights. Besides Mr. Berghof s studio, it has also played in Germany, Austria and Greece, and it is, Mr. Bloomgarden insists, one of the most exciting plays I've ever known.

title: American League
description: Friday, May 14, 1978

title: Restructuring L. E. A. A.
description: Before Congress approves the Ford Administration's bill to invest $6.8 billion over the next five years in the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, it had better take a very hard look at how this agency has used the first $4.5 billion since it was created with great hopes and hullabaloo seven years ago. The avowed purpose of its enabling legislationthe Omnibus Crime and Safe Streets Actwas to help the states and cities reduce crime. On that broad test alone, something is amiss; last year there was an 18 percent increase in reported crimes.

title: W. A. STANBURY, EDITOR, DIES AT 65
description: Walter A. Stanbury, who retired last October as senior vice president of the McGrawHill Publications Company, died Tuesday evening in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Panel Says It Has New Evidence On Why Oswald Shot Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities said today that it had new evidence as to why. Lee Harvey Oswald shot President Kennedy and recommended that the investigation into the role of the nation's intelligence agencies in the assassination be continued.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, May 13, 1976

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 14, 1976

title: Belmont Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Thursday, May 13. 10th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Concorde: Economic Puzzle
description: The script is a financially painful departure from what French and British engineers had in mind when they settled on the Concorde design 15 years ago.

title: Security Bank Jury Acquits All but One
description: The nowdefunct Security National Bank and three of its former top officers were cleared yesterday of charges that they had illegally diverted $200,000 of the bank's funds for political contributions.

title: Rodent Antihero Turns Super Rat
description: I want to make a mouse, said Sidney Brenner some years ago, in trying to explain what he did in his Iaboratory and the questions that scientists try to answer: How does it work? How is it put together? How does it get that way?

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 203.5 from 202.9 last week.

title: CONTEMPT IS RULED IN BOMBING INQUIRY
description: Lureida Torres, a member of the Puerto Rican Socialist Party, was held in civil contempt yesterday for having refused to answer questions before a Federal grand jury investigating a series of bombings attributed to a Puerto Rican terrorist group known as F.A.L.N.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)The Federal Home Loan Bank Board opposed today a further extension of the moratorium on conversions of mutual savings and loan associations to stock ownership. Mutual savings and loan associations are owned by persons who deposit money in the institutions.

title: A FleaSize Uptown Follies Reprise Proves a Butterfly of a Production
description: Follies works surprisingly well in a revival through May 30 at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. It can't touch the visual splendor on Broadway in 197172, framing two couples who unraveled old emotions and showstoppers at an onstage reunion  party. With classy wrappings and buoyant music by Stephen Sondheim and a performer named Alexis SmithFollies ran for 522 performances at the Winter Garden.

title: Out of the OrdinaryCases 851 and 853
description: Case 849 in Manhattan's First Precinct yesterday morning was a man picked up for peddling umbrellas on the street without a license.

title: Butz Denies Pressing Agency to Reverse Stand on Callaway Resort
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz denied today that he had pressed the United States Forest Service to reverse its recommendation against letting Howard H. Callaway's Colorado ski resort expand onto Federal land.

title: A Spring Flowering of Fashion: artful Ideas, Distinct Talents
description: He doesn't make a point of it, because that's not what you talk about in fashion today, but Geoffrey Beene has the most sophisticated seams in town. They hold together his playful clothes in gray sweatshirt fabric as well as his elegant ones in such sybaritic stuff as silk jersey. Never mind the howto approach. What those seams accomplish is clothes of surpassing elegance.

title: Manhattan Cable Bars Obscenity
description: Manhattan Cable Television, which serves the lower half of Manhattan, yesterday suspended all publicaccess and leasedchannel programs that have habitually dealt with material that it considers obscene. The suspension will continue pending clarification from regulatory agencies of rules prohibiting cable companies from interfering with the content of programs.

title: Balanchine's Union jack
description: THE New York City Ballet and its general director, Lincoln Kirstein, have always been amiably Anglophiliac. It was in London a quarter of a century or so ago that the company enjoyed its first international triumphs, and what nonBritish company other than the City Ballet would have celebrated the Queen's coronation night with a ballet loyally called Fanfare?

title: SURROGATE POST SOUGHT BY MANY
description: With nearly a dozen Democrats interested in the post of Manhattan surrogate, the regular and reform wings of the party in the borough appear destined for another hectic primary fight over the nomination to succeed Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco.

title: Beame Is Reported Ready To Give Support to Carter
description: Mayor Beame has decided to endorse Jimmy Carter for the Democratic nomination for President, according to authoritative party officials. The Mayor's decision, which was reportedly reached yesterday on a visit by Mr. Carter that left some politicians confused about what he had told them, could help Mr. Carter's image among urban voters. It could also add fresh complexity to the fractious Democratic politics of New York.

title: DI FALCO, SAYPOL ACCUSED OF PLOT TO TRADE FAVORS
description: Manhattan Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco and Justice Irving H. Saypol of the State Supreme Court were charged yesterday with illegally steering $20,000 in commissions to Justice Saypol's son, an appraiser and auctioneer, in exchange for the justice's appointment of lawyers to lucrative court assignments.

title: Brown Backed by Machine in Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, May 13In the two and a half weeks since Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California flew here to begin his belated national campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the politically unorthodox, 38yearold former seminarian has turned the Maryland primary, which will be held next Tuesday, into one of the most intriguing stops on the way to the party's convention in New York in July.

title: SANDMAN UNSURE OF FORD STRENGTH
description: TRENTON, May 13Former Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., a leader of Republican conservatives in New Jersey who is a statewide delegate candidate supporting President Ford's renomination, said today that the President should withdraw as a candidate if he loses to former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California in next week's Presidential primary election in Michigan.

title: The Pop Life
description: JAMES TALLEY, who winds up his first New York engagement this weekend at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, is a big, softspoken country singer with a difference.

title: FORD PLAN GIVES 4 YEARS TO REFORM REGULATORY UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13President Ford asked Congress today to adopt a mandatory fouryear timetable for approving or rejecting the most extensive reform of the Government's regulatory programs and agencies ever attempted.

title: 125 Questioned by Investigators On Intelligence Study Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The detectives hired by the House ethics committee to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of the report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence have questioned 125 persons but have yet to identify the source, the chairman of the inquiry said today.

title: Deer Run Seared Through Towns, Causing Damage
description: FREEHOLD, May 13  The combing tion of harassment by wild dogs and the encroachment of feeding areas by suburban development was blamed today for an increasingly common phenomenon of frightened deer running through towns in central New Jerscy.

title: GEORGE E. LEDERMAN
description: George E. Lederman, president of Local 370, Shochtim Union of Greater New York, Amalgamated Meat Cutters & Butcher Workers of North America, died Wednesday at the Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 68 years old and lived at 60 East Eighth Street.

title: TERMINAL RENT PUT OFF BY CITY
description: New York City, in a gentlemen's agreement with the Arol Development Corporation, has allowed it to withhold 43.5 percent of the rent owed to the city for the Bronx Terminal Market since a fire hit the terminal's powerhouse in 1973. Officials are taking a new look at the agreement.

title: Unveiling
description: CARLSONHelen Zuckerman. Sunday, May 16, 1975. 11 A.M.. Osceola Gardens, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla. N.Y.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: NEW LONDON and Groton have been shaped and salted by the sea and the river that divides them in a way that Manhattan forgot when the highway builders descended with their ring of concrete.

title: Chinese Call Explosion At Embassy Sabotage
description: PEKING, May 13 (Reuters) An explosion outside the gates of the Soviet Embassy here last month was an act of sabotage by a counterrevolutionary who was killed on the spot, an official Chinese spokesman said tonight.

title: When Folkloric Ensemble Dances, Old Japan Lives Again
description: TOKYO When the lights dim and the drums and flutes begin to play in New York City's Felt Forum tonight, the American audience will witness a performance of an ancient Japanese art form struggling to survive in its own homeland.

title: Petrocelli in Harness
description: BOSTON, May 13 (UPI)Rico Petrocelli, a third baseman for the Boston Red Sox, was released today from the Hahnemann Hospital wearing a harness. Petrocelli, 32 years old, was admitted to the hospital on Monday suffering from back spasms. Doctors said the 12year veteran would be able to play after a few days of rest.

title: OilTheft Trial Postponed
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 13 (AP)The start of the trial in the $4 million oil theft at the Exxon Bayway Refinery has Dbeen posponed until Sept. 13 to allow a defense attorney to recover from an illness. Judge Joseph Barbieri of Union County Court put off the trial after a doctor testified yeserday that lawyer, Robert Lewandowski, could not withstand the strains of a lengthy trial.

title: Udall, Lacking TV Funds, Seeking Free Time on Air
description: DETROIT, May 13Several times each day, Representative Morris K. Udall sits in a radio or television studio somewhere in this state to answer questions and make his pitch. Some days, it seems as if he spends more time talking into microphones than to live voters.

title: They're From Russia, With Jump Shots
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 13Some words come easily, words such as soda, gum and bathroom. The members of the Soviet Junior basketball team have had no trouble drinking, chewing and locating the men's room on their tour of the United States. But the street jargon that dominates American basketball gets lost in translation. And what we have here is a failure to communicate.

title: School Custodians Under Investigation
description: Investigators for the New York City Board of Education are looking into allegations of fraud as well as nepotism involving school custodians, including one who employs both his wife and a son for a total family income of more than $70,000 a year.

title: Ikle Criticizes Agency
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 A highranking Administration official criticized the International Atomic Energy Agency today as an institution with a split personality  administering nuclear safeguards on the one hand and spreading nuclear technology on the other.

title: Museum Opens 8Month Laff Riot
description: NOBODY ever dared shove a pie in Gloria Swanson's face. Nor did that dignified actress ever deign to slide on a banana skin or skid off a cliff in a jalopy steered by a crosseyed Keystone Kop. I loathed being in comedy, passionately proclaims Miss Swanson, the timid participant in more Mack Sennett ribticklers than she cares to recall. I had no sense of humor. I was a very serious young lady, and most comedies in those days were very vulgar.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Gottfried Advances With Moore
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 13 (AP)  Adrian Panatta of Italy defeated Bob Lutz, 64, 36, 63, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament.

title: Ford Pledges U.S. Will Remain Guarantor of Israel's Freedom
description: WASHINGTON. May 13President Ford pledged today that the United States will remain the ultimate guarantor of Israel's freedom but encouraged Israel to make more territorial concessions to the Arabs.

title: Charges Dropped Against Cadet Who Called Cheating Common
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 13 The United States Military Academy dropped all charges today against a cadet who faced expulsion because he had told Norman R. Augustine, Under Secretary of the Army, that cheating was more widespread at the Academy than officials had acknowledged.

description: EOrta, Dent. DPChicago 1. LOBChicago 6, Kansas City 8. 2BOtis, Stinson. 3BMcRae, Cowens, Mayberry. HRG.Brett (1), Garr (2). SBBradford, F.White.

title: A Satisfying Crop
description: There are five problems about tomatoes to solve before they start growing:

title: Critic's Notebook: Harmonious Discord
description: THOSE who care about Broadway musicals, great big Broadway musicals, may need something to soothe their nerves. The loudest sounds heard this spring have come not from the political hustings or entirely sensible thunderstorms, but from outoftown stage doors, where composers have parted company with librettists, directors have parted company with their companies, actors have walked off stage in midperformance, and producers have gone begging on bended knee for the hundreds of thousands of dollars needed to salvage enterprises ripe for the wrecking crew. It's all been duly reported to us, often at the tops of gossips' voices, and it's already been followed in some cases by a nastier noise still, the thud of collapse on Broadway after all that preparatory passion. Not pretty, not pretty at all.

title: Catholic Relief Services Sets Up a Fund for Italy
description: Catholic Relief Services has established a special fund to centralize collection of aid for victims of the recent earthquakes around Udine, in northern Italy.

title: Red Sox Find Another Star
description: It's very difficult to step into the cleats of Fred Lynn, but Rick Miller of the Boston Red Sox did that successfully last night at Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times last Sunday on the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation, a sponsor's fee awarded to the corporation was incorrectly given as $500,600. The correct figure is $5,600.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Management
description: In the world of corporate management, it's pretty easy to locate the fastest game in town. Just follow the invitations to the conferences and count the reports written on a given theme.

title: Public Workers Worried About Support
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 13Leaders of many municipal unions around the country are worried that public employees are losing public support and bargaining powers only recently securcd, as voters seek an end to rising local taxes and city officials attempt to balance budgets while revenues are decreasing.

title: Two Sides of Boulez
description: The final weekend of the New York Philharmonic's season, which started last night in Fisher Hall, saw Pierre Boulez conduct his orchestra in music composed in Vienna during the first decade of this century.

title: South African Aide Bars Military Role in Rhodesia
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 13A senior South African official, going beyond previous public statements of Prime Minister John Vorster and other Government leaders, has declared that the Pretoria administration foresees no circumstances under which South Africa would intervene militarily to save the white minority Government in Rhodesia.

title: Is Carmilla Really an Opera?
description: Now that Carmilla, that extraordinary theater piece created by Wilford Leach and Ben Johnston, seems to have become firmly established in the La Mama E.T.C. repertory, has been performed at half a dozen major European festivals and has been recorded, isn't it time we acknowledged once and for all that it is an opera? Too many people have been mesmerized by Carmilla to be turned off by that term, and in any case, the word opera does not strike the terror in the hearts of the theatergoing public that it once did.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: The Labor Scene
description: The United Automobile Workers, a union which through three postwar decades has often put a made in Detroit label on American industrial relations, is making quiet headway toward greater worker participation in areas of corporate decisionmaking that were once the jealously guarded domain of management.

title: Italian Reds Urge Emergency Coalition
description: ROME, May 13Enrico Berlinguer, the Communist Party leader, today called for the creation of an emergency government, including the Communists, immediately after next month's elections.

title: Business Trends
description: BUFFALOIt is perhaps symbolic that the tallest building in this city belongs to Marine Midland Banksa troubled institution that suffered nearly $12 million in losses over the last six months.

title: Catholic Relief Lawyer Seized by Chilean Junta
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 13 (AP)A former Chilean consul in Britain who works as a lawyer for a Roman Catholic agency aiding families of political prisoners has been arrested, the agency said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times last Sunday on the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation, a sponsor's fee awarded to the corporation was incorrectly given as $500,600. The correct figure is $5,600.

title: House Clears $413 Billion As Budget Target in 1977
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) The House completed today Congressional action on a compromise resolution calling for a $13.3 billion Federal budget target for 1977.

title: PACTS REPORTED BY BUILDING UNION
description: The union representing striking apartment house employees said yesterday that it had begun to sign separate agreements with individual landlords and cooperatives that incorporated settlement terms recommended by Mayor Beame's special panel.

title: ANGOLAN OIL TALKS WITH GULF RESUME
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 13Prime Minister Lopo de Nascimento announced today negotiations with Gulf Oil Compaly for a new contract under ??ew conditions.

title: Tellers Work 24Hour Day, And Never Breathe a Word
description: ATLANTA, May 13  She looms over Atlanta on a hundred billboards, pinkcheeked, flaxen  tressed, china  blue eyes wide and smiling, halfway between Kewpie doll and chorus girl. Wind her up and she gives you money.

title: COUNCIL APPROVES PINBALL MEASURE
description: The City Council acted yesterday to legalize pinball machines. By a vote of 30 to 6, with one abstention, it agreed that the bellringing, lightflashing machines outlawed here for more than 30 years could be operated in new York City's movie theaters, hotels and bars and grills.

title: A $23 Million Plan To Repair Housing In Queens Is Voted
description: An unusual $23 million plan to rehabilitate three deteriorating housing developments in Kew Gards Hills, Queens, with public and private funds received final approval yesterday from the Board of Estimate.

title: Garbage Pickups Still Pose Problems
description: The picket outside 277 West End Avenue was adamant. No health certificate, he said, no garbage pickup. So the men on Sanitation Department Truck 287101 waited for a superior officer. Within minutes, District Superintendent Charles Grey appeared on the scene.

title: Records: Epic Elgar Oratorio
description: Elgar's two related oratorios, The Apostles and The Kingdom. very likely had some performances in this country after their premieres in England, in 1903 and 1906, respectively. They were the sort of works that big Midwestern choral festivals delighted in. They are sung here no longer, which may be understandable considering their nature, but which is also unfortunate. Now at least they are available on recordings for the first time, to satisfy those with a taste for largescale English choral works of the Victorian and Edwardian eras. The Apostles has just been released, following by a few months The Kingdom.

title: HOUSE BACKS PLAN FOR 200,000 JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The House of Representatives, laying a political foundation for the November election campaign, approved today a public works construction bill designed to create more than 200,000 jobs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Wurf Backs Arbitration
description: SEATTLE, May 13 (UPI)Jerry Wurf, head of the American Federation of State, Counsaid yesterday that policemen, firemen and others involved in settle contract disputes through compulsory arbritration and not by strikes.

title: NEW YORK GIVEN RENT ASSURANCES
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A high Treasury Department official told the New York City Congressional delegation today that the Ford Administration would not insist that the city abolish rent control as a condition for future Federal loans.

title: Stage: Ashley Yup, Play Nope
description: There were production problems last night at the opening of Legend, Samuel Taylor's new romantic comedy about the old West. In the middle of one scene, a curtain started to fall. Several times, scrims stayed locked in place. And at one point, Elizabeth Ashleythe star, and unquestionably the heroine of this particular misadventurepicked up a bottle, and it crumbled in her hands. Unabashed, Miss Ashley adlibbed, They don't make bottles the way they used to. And, one might add, they don't make Broadway shows the way they used to.

title: Ford's Chief Again Raises Sales Forecast
description: DEARBORN, Mich., May 13Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, told stockholders today that the economy had bounced back from the recession more strongly than he had anticipated, and he again increased his forecast for car sales this year, this time to 10.6 million units.

title: Publishing: Jimmy Carter's Own Words
description: BANTAM BOOKS, the mass paperback house, knows a promising author when it comes across oneespecially if the man is a Presidential aspirant who came from nowhere in a Southern state and now looks as if he might go all the way.

title: Dempster's Ensemble Studio Invests in Plays and People.
description: In his new play, Money, which is running at 7:30 every evening this weekend at Curt Dempster's Ensemble Studio Theater, Arthur Giron is attacking a monumental subject  nonprofit foundations. He is asking tantalizing questions about matters of life support: Where does the money go? Where should it go? And what effect does it have?

title: New Treatment Reported For Immune Deficiencies
description: Two new treatmentstransplants of live cells from a human fetus and periodic transfusions of red blood cellsreportedly can save the lives of some children born without the ability to fight off infectious organisms and other foreign cells.

title: . . . to Kahn
description: Almost simultaneously Herman Kahn and his Hudson Institute colleagues have mounted an optimists' counterattack in their new book, The Next 200 Years. They look forward to the world of 2176 which, they think, may have a population stabilized at around 15 billion peopleagainst 4 billion nowand a per capita income then of $20,000 against $1,300 now. It is a euphoric vision of a world that is simultaneously much more crutvded and much more effluent, yet existing comfortably within the environmental and other constraints of this planet.

title: Pretrial Detention Upheld if Juvenile Is Found Dangerous
description: ALBANY, May 13 (UPI)The Court of Appeals, the state's highest bench, ruled today that a juvenile delinquent could be detained before his trial if there was a danger that he would commit a criminal act before his court appearance.

title: Restaurants
description: THE entrance door of the restaurant at 113 Macdougal street is centered in the vertical plane rising at right angles above the hypotenuse of the horizontal equilateral triangular area created by well, start over. You know how the corners of some old buildings are chopped off that way?

title: U.S. ACTED TO BAR A '75 SAIGON COUP
description: WASHINGTON, May 13William E. Colby took steps last year, to while he was Director of Central Intelligence, to head off a possible assassination of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam by officials of the Saigon Government who were displeased by the worsening military situation there, according to Central Intelligence Agency messages made public today.

title: DR. CARLOS MUNOZ
description: Dr. Carlos Muoz Pizarro, a leading Chilean botanist, died Wednesday while addressing a scientific symposium at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. He was 63 years old and a resident of Santiago, Chile.

title: 17 Minority Organizations Form A Federation on Urban Problems
description: Leaders of 17 Asian, Hispanic, black and poor people's organizations announced yesterday the formation of the New York Federation of Urban Organizations with the goal of giving their constituencies a voice, a strong voice, in the drastic reductions in community services.

title: Sunday Highlights
description: Mayor and Mrs. Beame will accompany a parade of costumed youngsters on a walk from 57th Street, down Ninth Avenue shortly after noon. At 37th Street the Mayor will be joined by Commissioner Arlene Wolff from the Department of Civic Affairs and Public Events to conduct an awards ceremony.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The union representing 40,000 service employees at 52 nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area presented demands for a 10 percent, or $20aweek, pay increase, whichever is greater, to the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes at a bargaining session at the Commodore HoteL Leon J. Davis, president of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital Care Employees, told the employers, You have made up your mind that there's no solution to this except a confrontation, but I hope you're wrong. Last week the employers presented 26 demands for pay and benefit reductions. Mr. Davis declared yesterday: We reject them totally as a package, and we reject them individually one by one. The contract between the union and the league expires June 30.

title: LAWYER PICTURES CAPTAIN AS HERO
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 13The attorney for a schooner captain whose ship sank with the subsequent loss of two lives depicted the captain today as a hero for saving four lives in a lifeboat.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: For Children
description: Plays

title: Is Oversight Enough?
description: The Senate has reached agreement on an independent committee to oversee the budget and operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, and to share such power over the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other security agencies. That's better than doing nothing about the documented abuses of the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and others, but skepticism about the new committee still is in order.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Patients Irradiated Years Ago Sought Because of Cancer Peril
description: PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) Medical authorities have begun a search for 10,000 persons in the Greater Pittsburgh area who were exposed to possibly cancercausing radiation treatments more than 20 years ago.

title: Excerpts From Carter Speech on Nuclear Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. May 13Following are excerpts from the text of Jimmy Carter's address on nuclear policy as prepared for delivery at the United Nations.

title: South African Aide Bars Military Role in Rhodesia
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 13A senior South African official, going beyond previous public statements of Prime Minister John Vorster and other Government leaders, has declared that the Pretoria administration foresees no circumstances under which South Africa would intervene militarily to save the white minority Government in Rhodesia.

title: Beame Is Reported Ready To Give Support to Carter
description: Mayor Beame has decided to endorse Jimmy Carter for the Democratic nomination for President, according to authoritative party officials. The Mayor's decision, which was reportedly reached yesterday on a visit by Mr. Carter that left some politicians confused about what he had told them, could help Mr. Carter's image among urban voters. It could also add fresh complexity to the fractious Democratic politics of New York.

title: Events and Openings
description: Today

title: Soviet Journalist Held In Tokyo in Spy Cose
description: TOKYO, Friday, May 14 (Reuters)The Tokyo police today arrested Aleksandr Matchekhine, a correspondent with the Soviet New's feature Agency, Novosti on suspicion of attempting to purchase United States miljtary secrets from an American sailor. hey said he was being held at police headquarters.

title: The Blue Bird
description: THE BLUE BIRD, directed be George Luker; screenplay be Hugh Whitemore and Alfred Hayes, based on the play by Maurice Maeterl??ck; produced by Paul Maslansky; executive producer, Edward Lewis; directors of photography, Freddie Young and toms Gritzus; musk composed and conducted by Irwin Kostal; songs and ballet music composed by Andres Petrov; lyrics by Tony Harrison; supervising film editor, Ernest Walter; editors, Tatvana Shapiro and Stanford C. Allen; distributed by 70th CenturyFox. Running time: 47 minutes. At the Radio City Music Halt, Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street. This film has been rated G.

title: Singer Expects '76 Profit; Chief Says Worst Is Over
description: BOSTON, May 13The Singer Company, which lost $452 million last year, can expect a good profitable 1976, Joseph B. Flavin, chairman, told about 250 steckholders at the company's annual meeting in the Colonnade Hotel here today.

title: Inventories Again Rise
description: Total business inventories rose moderately again in March in a continuation of the underlying pattern of the recovery of the economy, the Commerce Department reported. Page D3.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATION OF EDITOR REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  A journalist dismissed last week by a Nashville newspaper after her alleged connections with the Federal Bureau of Investigation were disclosed is reportedly being investigated by the bureau in connection with meetings she held with a Soviet diplomat.

title: Lisbon Bomb Wrecks Airport Radar Station
description: LISBON, Friday, May 14, (Reuters)A bomb exploded at a radar installation at Lisbon's international airport early today, causing heavy damage but no casualties, the police said.

title: ETALS FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: The Bank of England yesterday asked the London Metal Exchange to bar further speculative trading in zinc futures, and the action had immediate repercussions on futures prices in metals, cocoa and sugar in the United States. All showed significant price declines.

title: COUNCIL APPROVES PINBALL MEASURE
description: The City Council acted yesterday to legalize pinball machines. By a vote of 30 to 6. with one abstention, it agreed that the bellringing, lightflashing machines outlawed here for more than 30 years could be operated in New York City's movie theaters, hotels and bars and grills.

title: ASARCO LIFTS PRICE ON ITS REFINED LEAD
description: Asarco Inc said yesterday that it was increasing the base spot sales price of refined lead by half a cent a pound. The new price, effective immediately, is 23 cents a pound, delivered in carload lots.

title: Tigers Subdue Yanks, 32, On Staub 3  Run Clout in 8th
description: Have you ever heard of the socalled baseball rule that says you never purposely put the potential winning run on base? Billy Martin naturally has and he confronted it head on last night at Yankee Stadium. He lost.

title: Where Sam Plays It Again
description: The frequent replays of Casablanca on television are as responsible as anything else for the weekend plethora of singing pianists who begin murmuring their songs around town almost before the sun goes down. Every time Dooley Wilson turns to the keyboard in the smoky atmosphere of Rick's Place and starts singing You must remember this... more converts are created for a room where a pianist can sing of love and other sorrows.

title: Carter's Nuclear Plan: A Blend of Old and New
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Jimmy Carter's speech today on nuclear energy and world order appealed for international solutionsbased on national selfinterest  to the problems of energy development and the spread of nuclear weapons. His formula would seek to change established notions of national self  interest. The means Mr. Carter proposes is a blending of some Old and some new measures  unusual, in this year's political debate, only for his eventual comprehensiveness and sense of commitment. His formula would seek to change established notions of national self  interest. The means Mr. Carter proposes is a blending of some Old and some new measures  unusual, in this year's political debate, only for his eventual comprehensiveness and sense of commitment.

title: About Real Estate
description: The causes of housing abandonment and what to do about them has been a recurring subject of news coverage, conferences, governmental policies and public debate for years. The widely accepted view is that the heart of the problem is that building maintenance costs have significantly outpaced tenants' incomes.

title: Nets Capture Title
description: The New York Nets won the American Basketball Association title last night for the second time in three seasons, beating the Denver Nuggets, 112106, and 4 games to 2. Page A21.

title: Rediscovery of Columbus
description: It is the place to be, said Kate Selover the other day, sitting in the whitewashed balcony of her bookshop on Columbus Avenue. The only place, as far as I'm concerned.

title: Warriors a Step Closer to Last Year
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 13 A year ago today, the basketball world wasn't paying much attention to the Golden State Warriors, who had established themselves as a perennial disappointment during the 1970's. The big news was that the Washington Bullets had eliminated the Boston Celtics, defending champions of the National Basketball Association, in the semifinal round.

title: Congressmen Back Ford
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Senator Jacob K. Javits and 10 of the 11 Republican members of the House of Representatives from New York State today endorsed the reelection campaign of President Ford.

title: U. S. DISCOURAGES TRIPS TO RHODESIA,
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 13The United States today strongly advised Americans not to travel to or within Rhodesia and warned that those already here should make contingency plans for leaving.

title: Saturday Matinees Are Different
description: The sun was warm at 5 P.M., slanting down West 45th Street. This is a street where people move fast once the sun goes down, rushing to make the opening curtain, rushing to catch a train home. But on one particular Saturday afternoon, hundreds of people stood in small groups debating what to do next.

title: KISSINGER SCORES REAGAN ON CANAL
description: BOSTON, May 13 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has criticized the Panama Canal views of Ronald Reagan and says that they have certainly not helped the negotiations, according to The Boston Herald American.

title: ELECTION FUNDING DELAYED FURTHER
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Hope that $2 million in frozen Federal subsidies could be made available to hardpressed Presidential candidates this week vanished today as President Ford declined once again to reestablish the Federal Election Commission.

title: BENEFITS WILL RISE FOR RETIRED IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)The Government formally announced today a 6.4 percent increase in monthly benefits for 32.6 million retired persons and other Social Security recipients effective with July's checks.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Meeting About a Murder Leaves Theory and Practice Far Apart
description: When Sanford Goin, a librarian at Teachers College of Columbia University, met yesterday with policemen and private security officials to discuss the recent murder of a colleague, the meeting was an unusual one.

title: Comedy Tickets, Times
description: Tickets for screenings in the Museum of Modem Art's Bicentennial Salute to American Film Comedy, are included in the price of museum admission ($2 for adults, $1.25 for students and 75 cents for children and the elderly). Seating is limited, however, and the museum recommends that tickets for showings be picked up at least an hour in advance. For Saturday and Sunday noon screenings, there are no ticketsit's firstcome firstseated

title: Soviet Quietly Drops Ceremony To Sign U.S. Nuclear Accord
description: MOSCOW, May 13The Soviel Union, apparently caught off guard by President Ford's decision to postpone signing a new agreement on peaceful nuclear explosions, discreetly scratched its own carefully planned signing ceremony here today.

title: O'Hagan, Citing Overtime, Seeks Rehiring of Firemen
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that he would ask Mayor Beame's office to end the emergency hiring freeze in his department on the ground that it was costing more in overtime to maintain service than it would with a larger force working regular shifts.

title: Wurf Backs Arbitration
description: SEATTLE, May 13 (UPI)Jerry Wurf, head of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal employees, said yesterday that policemen, firemen and others involved in protecting the public should settle contract disputes through compulsory arbitration and not by strikes.

title: Playoff Results
description: N.B.A.Playoffs

title: Market Comforted by Reserve's Data
description: The credit markets looked at the money supply figures published yesterday afternoon and breathed a sigh of relief that they were not larger. Bond prices rose late in the day as traders speculated that the Federal Reserve might not move quite so quickly as they had feared to bring down the rates of growth for the monetary aggregates.

title: Paris Turns aSoccer Defeat Into a Parade of Pride
description: PARIS, May 13  The French, who have not had much to cheer about lately, somehow managed today to turn an international sports defeat into a day of national pride.

title: Tours Behind Scenes
description: The crowd in the lobby of the Morosco Theater the other morning looked like the usual assortment of Broadway theatergoers but the tickets they had were to see the theater and not the show.

title: Bishop LeGrand Indicted in Killing of 2 Wives and 2 TeenAge Girls
description: Devernon LeGrand, the selfstyled bishop of a Brooklyn church, was indicted yesterday on charges of having murdered two of his wives, one in 1963 and one in 1970.

title: William Lowell Jr., Is Dead; An Industrial Packager, 78
description: William Lowell Jr., a former manufacturer of golf tees and an industrial packaging specialist, died Wednesday at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Fanwood. N.J.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Books of The Times
description: AH ME, yes. It's an all too familiar set of questions that prompted the philosopher and cultureanalyst Michael Novak to write The Joy of Sports: End Zones, Bases, Balls, and the Consecration of the American Spirit. How could I be 40 years old and still care what happens to the Dodgers? How could I have thrown away three hours of an evaporating life, watching a ritual, an inferior dance, a competition without a socially redeeming point?
