description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Federal Election Commission has been asked to investigate two charges that President Ford has evaded legal limits on his spending in the primaries by not including certain political expenditures in his campaign reports.

title: Cash From Parley Delegates Helping Develop Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 14 So far Kenya is the only developing country to have gained any tangible benefit front the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development that opened here May 5.

title: The TwoFaced Lulu
description: In a Janusfaced decision that looks at both sides of the lulu controversy but avoids the inevitability of its own reasoning, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has ruled that Albany legislators are prohibited under the Constitution front voting themselves extra money during a current term of office. In the next breath, the court adds that they can keep the money already received in this manner because the Attorney General says it's O.K. and the legislators have grown used to their selfvoted, politically rooted bonuses.

title: Russians Demand Release
description: TOKYO, May 14 (UPI)The Soviet Union today demanded the immediate release of Mr. Machekhin.

title: Court and Legislature in Showdown Over Schools
description: TRENTON, May 14Yesterday's State Supreme Court decision that ordered the closing of public schools in New Jersey on July 1 if the Legislature failed to finance a new school

title: The New European Socialism
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Western Europe is celebrating our Bicentennial in its own wayby declaring independence from the United States' model of economy and society. The fundamental struggle in Europe is over a new type of society.

title: ARMY OPENED MAIL IN WEST BERLIN
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Army intelligence officers stationed in West Berlin have opened firstclass mail between there and the United States and may be continuing to do so, according to two affidavits recently filed in civil court cases by Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann.

title: Citibank Increases Prime Lending Rate To 6% From 6
description: Citibank, which stood alone for two weeks in charging a base interest rate of 6 percent on corporate loans, rejoined other banks yesterday by raising its rate to 6 percent.

title: Blackout on Strike Talks
description: CHICAGO, May 14 (UPI)A Federal mediator has imposed a news blackout on negotiations between the United Parcel Service and teamsters' union members who have been on strike in 13 states since May 1. Sherman Warady of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said the news blackout, imposed yesterday morning, would continue indefinitely.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 15, 1976

title: Federal Employment Drops
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) Employment of the Federal Government dropped 2,121 in March, to 2,856,998, the Civil Service Commission reported today. The decrease was due in part to fewer fulltime permanent and intermiittent employees in the U.S. Postal Service and fewer fulltime permanent employees in defense, the commission report said.

title: TV VIEW
description: Ten years ago, the claim was made that the full realization of cable television would be the most revolutionary development in the ensuing decade. Other vested interests, primarily the commercial networks and their wellheeled lobbyists, said it couldn't be done. They were right, at least in terms of the time factor. Stymied by technological snags, political shenanigans and soaring installation costs, the concept of a wired nation with unlimited distribution channels and all sorts of service capabilities is still a gleam in the eye of cable interests. Yet, the idea of cable has survived; it has even crept forward in development enough to generate increasing cries of outrage and occasional hysteria from the National Association of Broadcasters.

title: BIG EAR OR BIG BROTHER?
description: Room 6510 at the State Department is a warren of windowless offices with a special cipher lock on the door. Scrambler teletypewriters, shielded by special walls so that none of their radiation can escape, tick out a stream of material. Another door bars an inner area to all but perhaps 5 percent of the officials at State. This is the LDX roomlongdistance Xerox. Here, the scourings of the globe's electronic environment flood in.

title: 101 Elocutionist Is Preakness Winner by 3 Lengths
description: Elocutionist Triumphs Elocutionist won the 101st Preakness yesterday at Pimlico Race Course, finishing 3 lengths ahead of Play the Red. Bold Forbes was third. Elocutionist paid $22.20. Details in Section 5.

title: French Raising Gas Price
description: PARIS, May 15 (Reuters)The price of gasoline will rise slightly Monday, French officials said this week. In Paris, supergrade gasoline will cost about $1.60 a gallon and standard about $1.50.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Regionalism

title: The expected bloodbath did not happen
description: It is difficult to place a simple label on Tiziano Terzani. He carries an Italian passport and writes for the German news magazine Der Spiegel. Different Vietnamese have come up with different judgments about him. In March 1975 the Thieu regime called him a Communist and banished him forever, or so they thought, from Vietnam. They had found fault with his reporting of the fall of Ban Me Thuot, the event that precipitated the end of the war. He defied the blacklist in the last few days of April by arriving on the last Air Vietnam flight to enter the country. By that time most of the immigration police had fled and no one paid any attention to someone apparently foolish enough to be arriving in Vietnam when so many others were desperate to leave. Once there he resisted the panic of the evacuation because I had never shared the principles and policies of the Americans' intervention in Vietnam and therefore saw no reason now to share the risks and emotions of their flight. He stayed for 94 days, watching, listening and questioning the new Communist authorities. They eventually decided, contrary to the judgment of Thieu's police, that he was a susceptible bourgeois. His book makes it clear that if nothing else he is a hard working reporter. Giai Phong! (which means liberation in Vietnamese) is a vivid, intensely readable, provocative account of Vietnam and the Vietnamese during an extraordinary episode in their hostory.

title: Lower Taxes and Better Government Called Keys for City to Hold Industry
description: What New York City needs most to attract and hold the head offices of America's biggest industrial corporations, are lower personal taxes, low er business taxes and a more efficient, less costly city government, according to leaders of such companies who responded to a New York Times survey.

title: A History Buff Makes His Own
description: I THINK Thomas Jetferson has always been my favorite, said Michael Voikovitsch, a Harborfleids High School senior, recalling the historical biographies he has been reading for as long back as he can remember.

title: PEOPLE
description: Dr. Grant F. Walton has been na.ned dean of Rutgers University's Cook College and director of the state's Agricultural Experiment Station. The appointment of the 51yearold Dr. Walton, who received a bachelor of science degree in wildlife ecology and management from Rutgers in 1955, was announced by Dr. Henry R. Winkler, acting president of Rutgers. Dr. Walton is an authority on Arctic polar and desert soils, and his studies have taken him on a dozen expeditions to the North Slope of Alaska, Siberia, Greenland, Baffin Island and the CanadianAlaskan archipelago. Cook College evolved in 1973 from what was the College of Agriculture and Environmental Science, to become Rutgers's agriculture and environmentoriented undergraduate unit.

title: The Hidden Health Bomb
description: I wish to call attention to a publichealth problem in Suffolk County that seems to be consistently increasing in scope and that is being treated by the authorities with neglect and disregard in an unrealistic hope that perhaps it will go away.

description: HONG KONG, May 15 (Agence FrancePresse)China has set up a nationwide microwave telecommunications trunk  line network with Peking as the center, according to Radio Peking.

title: Doubts on Africa
description: Secretary of State Kissinger made clear in his report to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he intends to hold firmly to his new policy of working for a rapid, just and African solution in pivotal Rhodesia. What remains in doubt is whether President Ford, buffeted by the rightwing attacks of Ronald Reagan, will follow through on the policy Mr. Kissinger has enunciated.

description: AFTER reading the article (April 11) on Greenwich I began thinking. It would be a horrible disaster if the village is ruined.

description: NEW DELHI, May 15 (Reuters)The government of the strategic northeast Indian state of Nagaland has announced the release of all political prisoners, including two selfstyled generals of the banned Naga Nationalist Army, according to press reports.

title: $7.40 Lord Rebeau Wins by 6 Lengths
description: In a wiretowire demonstration of speed that caused even rival jockeys to marvel, Paul Cresci's Lord Rebeau was a surprisingly easy winner of the 33rd running of the Roseben Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: DINING OUT
description: YOU can't rely on first impressions at La Tavernetta, Take the name. It means little tavern, and indeed, from the outside the place looks quite small. The dining room is fairly spacious however, seating close to 100 people, and despite a rustic brick wall, rather elegant. This is clearly a ristorante regardless of what they have named it. One glance at the prices confirm that impression.

description: WE have entered a period in which the financial resources for higher education will continue to be seriously limited; a period in which we will continue to face tough choices about how to allocate the limited resources available in the most effective and responsible way.

description: Leon Russell's first reputation was that of a consummate rockandroll sideman whose every note fit perfectly into place. His second was that of a selfstyled master of space and time, a cosmic rocker whose mysterious power over audiences was exceeded only by the earthiness of his music. During the last few years both reputations have suffered, as album after disappointing album failed to live up to the promise of Mr. Russell's performances with Mad Dogs and Englishmen and at the Concert for Bangladesh.

description: Catfish Hunter isn't atone in chewing tobacco, although the New York Yankee pitcher is probably the most famous chewer. Shipments and a sales of moist smokeless tobacco have soared, making 1975 the record year for what most consider just an oldtimer's kick.

description: DETROIT, May 15Representative Morris K. Udall called on Mayor Coleman A. Young today to apologize for linking him with the racial policies of the Mormon Church, saying, I believe in this instance he has made a mistake.

It still remains a good ballet, Mr. Beatty is a sure craftsman, but over the years some of the originality has dissipated.

title: Scientific Areas
description: In the world scientific community, specialists in each field speak the same language and generally know each other personally from having met at conventions and symposiums; so there is a vast international network of scientists who maintain personal contacts. exchange ideas and compare points of view. Bilateral relations, the backbone of this system, are enriched and made all the more productive by these supplementary scientific activities and by the climate of open friendship among the nations involved. This is indeed the case with the United States and France, whose ties in the scientific and technical domains can well be called exemplary.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The phonograph has always fascinated composers and few of them have missed an opportunity over the past 75 years to visit the recording studios themselvesas performersto document how they wanted their music to sound. Sir Edward Elgar, for example, was one of the first to recognize the importance of recording: between 1914 and 1934 he conducted many of his principal works before the microphones, leaving an invaluable body of material for future generations to study.

title: The voice that could not be silenced
description: The denial of human and political liberties in parts of southern Africa may well be as offensive to the makers of American foreign policy as the denial of similar freedoms in areas that have fallen under the influence of Communists. However, to ordinary readers of the daily press, evidence of this has not been abundantclassified information being what it is. About recent developments in Angola, where the interests of democracy and dtentewere seriously undermined by the activities of Moscow and Havana, the United States declared itself in the strongest and clearest terms.

description: Those $2 bills are causing a 1776 flap.

title: Michigan's Trackmen Capture Big Ten Title
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 15 (AP)  Wisconsin lost its premier sprinter, Tariq Mughal, before the events even began today and Michigan captured the Big Ten track and field championship held at the University of Illinois. Michigan scored 111 points, followed by Wisconsin with 97 and Indiana with 68.

title: Ethnic Rebirth in Riverhead

title: There are no churches for atheists
description: A few weeks ago, while families everywhere were preparing for their Easter and Passover observances, a few score atheists held a convention in New York City and found that it is not easy for serious atheists to attract attention at a time when there is so little serious religion around, rather like trying to play handball without a wall.

title: When the Weather Acts Up In Miami
description: The woman unfolded the beach chair, positioning it into the wind blowing cold off the Atlantic at twilight, and hunched down to read a pictorial map of Dade County attractions. She shivered deeper into the mink collar of her brown suede coat as I walked by in a swimming suit still wet and sandy from a January sail down to the flats off Key Biscayne where I had scooped up conch and starfish at low tide. Both of us wore goosebumps; neither of us was about to give in to the dismal weather.

title: The Gospel according to Chayym Zeldis
description: That cumbersome, retarded child, the novel, is beginning to wag its ungainly head. Throughout the 1960's the novel was pushed aside by journalists and novelists themselvesNorman Mailer, Truman Canute, Tom Wolfewho supposed that the modulations of history were more brutal and inventive than the conundrums of traditional storytellers. The novel became a naughty word, or uglier than that, an appendage of the new journalism. So we had nonfiction novels about historical creatures and actual events: Mafia chiefs, KoolAid acid tests, the siege of Chicago in 1968, moon shots, and Muhammad Ali.

title: WILLIAM V. ABBATE
description: William V. Abbate, a breadcasting engineer for the National Broadcastina Company or 25 years, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. Brownville N.Y. I??e 55 years old and lived at 03 Jervis Road, Yonkers.

description: NEW Jersey is the most densely populated state In the nation. If all of the proposed nuclearpower plants are eventually built, it would have more such plants than any other state. This, of course, does not include the socalled nuclearenergy parks proposed for Ocean County.

description: The most ambitious single work of new art that has come my way since I started to live in New York is Rhapsody by Jennifer Bartlett at the Paula Cooper Gallery.

description: IN a discussion among stockmarket watchers a few days ago, one puzzled commentator wondered aloud why the market had been performing so blandly for the last two months in the face of so much favorable economic and business data.

title: FrontRunning Carter...
description: Former Governor Jimmy Carter claims the support of about 700 delegates, which is less than half the number1505needed to win the Democratic Presidential nomination at Madison Square Garden in July. On this arithmetic, his rivals believe that they can still block his path.

description: NABLUS, Israel  Occupied Jordan, May 15 (AP)Israeli soldiers wounded a 16yearold Arab today when he defied a curfew, military sources reported.

In at least two other recent years, he also appears to have paid less Federal income tax than most people with a small fraction of his income.

title: GARDENING
description: THE most beautiful iris gardens in the United States are undoubtedly in Upper Montclair. Fortynine years ago the Presby Memorial iris Gardens were laid out by the Town of Montclair as a memorial to Mr. Frank Presby, nationally known horticulturist and irisarian. They are along Upper Montclair Avenue in Mountainside Park.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: In past columns you have mentioned the need for vents in the attic. Can you tell me whether it is necessary to have vents in the peaks at both ends of the attic and why two are now necessary. A friend of mine claims that one vent is enough, but I don't agree. Who is right? E.W.R., Lincoln, Mass.

title: FISHING
description: IF variety is the spice of life, things should be pretty hot for New Jersey fishermen this week. The first striped bass of the season are starting to move up along the beaches and into the rivers on the tail end of an unusually long mackerel run.

title: Would You Pay $150 for a Postcard?
description: People have been collecting picture postcards since the late 1800's when they were first introduced. The hobby has had its ups and downs over the years since then, but it seems to be in one of its most popular periods at this time.

title: Corporate Populism
description: Senator Adlai Stevenson of Illinois has proposed creation of a Federal Oil, Gas and Coal Corporation as a yardstick against which to measure the performance of the oil companies. Representative Henry Reuss of Wisconsin has suggested allocation of credit through the Federal Reserve on the basis of social needfor example, to stimulate the housing industry without a general interest rate reduction.

title: MarseillesFos
description: The expansion of MarseillesFos Europort South, a unique port and industrial project, is helping the southern region of France to overtake the traditional locations in Paris and northern France as a choice site for American and European business investment.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: When Daniel Barenboim, last week, brought to a conclusion his series of all the Mozart piano and violin concertos, the cheers that resounded through Carnegie Hall were well deserved. Barenboim and the English Chamber Orchestra had given New York an experience that seldom had graced local concert halls. It is true that back in the early 1930's the respected pianist and teacher Clarence Adler had played a sizable group of Mozart concertos. In more recent years Lili Kraus has been identifying herself with the Mozart cycle. But where every pianist will play the Beethoven sonata cycle at the drop of a hemidemisemiquaver, surprisingly few have the desire to tackle the Mozart concerto series, popular as the music is. Of course Mozart did compose 25 piano concertos, plus one for two and one for three pianos.

title: Food
description: The menu on this page is for a typical dinner for six to eight people at my house, served in or out of the kitchen, and it sounds far more elaborate than it actually is because of the franglicized titles. I always have three courses when I entertainthe usual beginning, main course and dessertor it doesn't seem like a party. I also almost always have a cheese course available at room temperature, but whether or not I serve it depends on the mood of the guests and the state of the wine at that particular moment.

title: FOOD
description: ORANGE FOR days now, husbands and wives have been bustling in and out of the stainlesssteel kitchen at St. Constantine and St. Helen, a Greek Orthodox church at 510 Linden Place. All have been laden down with provisions, pans and other delectable signs that the third annual Grecian Festival is at hand.

title: Ostolozaga Sets Mile Mark
description: HARTFORD, May 15Luis Ostolozaga said he won the big one today after barely edging Steve O'Connell in the onemile run in a meet record time of 4 minutes 10.6 seconds at the fifth annual Hartford High School invitation track meet.

title: POLITICS
description: ARE Ralph G. Caso's days as Nassau County Executive numbered? Surprisingly, there are some, and maybe many, of his fellow Republicans who hope so.

description: 1970, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Saturday, May 15. 12th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Queens Company Is Expanding
description: A Queens manufacturer of containers for cosmetics is investing $2.4 million in a 200,000squarefoot plant that will permit it to add 150 workers to its work force of 300.

title: BRIDGE
description: It would be interesting to know the identity of the best American player each year. measured by some objective standard. The traditional McKenney Trophy race does not provide a satisfactory answer. An Award is made for the best performance in each of the three National Championships, but these receive little public attention.

title: Art Workshops
description: The 1976 Carl Schmalz workshops run June 28July 9; July 1223 and July 26Aug. 6; tuition for each workshop is $100. Cars are virtually a necessity, as is warm clothing and rain gear. Application forms mention several inns and motels used by former students and suggest that applicants write to the Kennebunk Chamber of Commerce, 11 Main Street, Kennebunk, Me. 04043, for other rec ommendations. Dick Keeps a supply of art materials for sale, but students should bring favorite tools of their trade. Each workshop is limited to 20 students. Write to Carl Schmalz Watercolor Workshops, R.F.D. 2. Arnold Road, Amherst, Mass. 01002.

title: Fashion
description: Short, shorter, shortest. The newest haircuts for summer are as closely cropped in back as an oldfashioned barbershop cut. The front may barely touch the forehead or it may cover the eyebrows, the hair may be straight or curly, but the cut bares the neck and shows the shape of the head in back. This is not as drastic as it may sound. Inch by inch, year by year, women's hair has been getting shorter in the 1970's. Many a woman who had waistlength hair in the late 60's has had it cut progressively shorterto shoulder length and then to chin length. When Dorothy Hamill skated across all those television screens last winter, she inspired thousands of women to emulate her earbaring haircut. Now the hairdressers are ready, scissors in hand, to go one step further.

title: The World
description: The Israeli Government has announced plans to expand its policy of establishing settlements in Arab territory occupied in the 1967 war. The decision was taken despite the domestic political difficulties the policy has caused for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, criticism from the Ford Administration and antiIsraeli resolutions in the United Nations.

title: Dhaulagiri in Nepal Scaled
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 15 (UPI)Two members of an Italian expedition have scaled the 26,810foot Dhaulagiri peak in the Himalayasthe seventh tallest peak in the worldthe Nepal Foreign Ministry has announced. The climbers were not identified.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The Chicago City Council is expected soon to enact a law that would make Chicago the first major American city to prohibit persons under 18 from seeing films containing scenes of harmful violence.

title: ShortChanging Hempstead Town
description: THE residents of the Town of Hempstead have been duped. They have been denied muchneeded funding for housing by a politically motivated and intransigent town government. A longstanding battle has been waged by the Town of Hempstead and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, with the people of Hempstead losing the battle.

title: Plastic Tin?
description: When better tin cans are built, they may be made of Plastic.

title: New York Bonds Find Buyers Again
description: At noon last Monday, New York State sold $59 million in bonds. The event symbolized substantial improvement in the state's financial health and in the health of the entire market for state and city bonds.

title: Reds Top Seaver, Mets, 20
description: CINCINNATI, May 15 Was he safe or out? If Tony Perez of the Cincinnati Reds had been called out trying to steal second base in the second inning of today's game with the New York Mets, the Reds wouldn't have scored two runs and defeated Tom Seaver. 20.

title: Henry Blackiston 3d, Lawyer, To Wed Pamela Schall, Editor
description: Pamela Gordon Senail, a senior fashioiifeatures editor of Women's Wear Daily and of W, a newspaper published every other week in New York, and Henry Curtis Blackiston 3d, a lawyer with the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, plan to be married in the fall.

title: Fashion with a French Accent
description: She is between 18 and 40 years of age, lives in a large U.S. city or its suburbs, has money to spend on clothes and likes to set herself a little apart from other women. He is young, has a good income, lives in a big city and has a lively interest in fashion. Together, they represent the kind of client who is making French readytowear apparel an ongoing concern in the United States.

title: DeEnergizing the Home
description: BROOKHAVEN NESTLED among the futuristic exhibits of hydrogen  fueled cars, models of floating nuclearpower plants and methane digesters at the Bookhaven National Laboratories energy fair are two energyconserving houses, on display to show the purportedly simple, ordinary changes they incorporate that any conventional builder could feasibly use tomorrow.

title: May's Profundity
description: MidMay is a time of tremendous fundamental happenings and miraculous matters, all spread before us as though they were everyday incidents. Buds open, more buds than there are numbers with which to count. The apple blossom, the dogwood, the buttercup are no more mysterious than sunrise, yet through them the season speaks in the language of life.

title: Where the Corporate Money Goes
description: WASHINGTONOn Dec. 3, 1975, Jimmy Carter's fund raisers were informed that the LTV Corporation's Active Citizenship Campaign Fund was contributing $15 to their candidate's political war chest. It was one of three contributions from the fund to the Democratic Presidential aspirant. The total: $39.80.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE sun was just beginning to rise when the children descended upon me. Is today the day? they asked.

title: A Banker's Five  Year Plan for the
description: With the perspective of time, it is quite likely that actions taken in New York, Philadelphia and certain other cities will be considered as absurd and counterproductive as Herbert Hoover's efforts to alleviate the depression by attempting to balance the budget in 1929, 1930, etc.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EAST BRUNSWICK I THINK Governor Byrne's plan to save a paltry $6 million by eliminating the staterun motor vehicle inspection stations is going to rob the people of New Jersey of an important source of fun, games and relaxation.

title: Leading Seoul Critic, in Trial, Meets Questions With Silence
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 15 Kim Dae Jung, former opposition presidential candidate in South Korea, refused to answer all the prosecution's questions today and his defense lawyers walked out in protest against what they termed an unfair trial.

title: A House That Reflects The Moods of America
description: For most of my life I'd never heard of Henry Davis Sleeper. Now I equate his name with enchantmentthis after a single visit to his house, Beauport, on Eastern Point Road, in Gloucester, Mass. Too late, alas, to meet Mr. Sleeper, to mingle with friends and frequent guests like Glasgow, Wister, Benet or TarkingIton . . . to catch a glimpse of Ruth Draper, Amy Lowell, Lady Gregory or Henry James . . . to exchange a bit of badinage with Gluck, Zimbalist, Astor or du Pont . . . or even to try to cheer up Eugene O'Neill. But fortunate in that the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities now possesses and opens the doors of this house with its 50odd rooms, embodying Henry Sleeper's stunning interpretation of our nation from its earliest days in Plymouth right up through its birth as a republic. Such is its reputation that representatives from New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art visited Beauport when setting up their American Wing.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EHarrah. OPOakland 1. LOBTexas 9, Oakland 5. 2BWilliams. 3BRandle. HRHowell (2). SBNorth.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices moved lower last week in the stock and credit markets where investor hesitancyreflected in quiet, moderate tradingcontinued. Contributing to the hesitancywhich has persisted for a number of weekswere the familiar unknowns of whither interest rates, money supply, monetary policy and inflationary prospects.

title: TUNA GROUP FIGHTS PORPOISE RULING
description: SAN DIEGO, May 15Operators of the American tuna fishing fleet announced today that they would go into court in Washington next week to challenge a Federal judge's order aimed at halting the accidental trapping of porpoises in the fleet's huge seining nets.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: The Bottom Line
description: When the stockholders of the Northrop Corporation foregathered in Hawthorne, California, last week for their first annual meeting in three yearsthe meeting had been long delayed by the scandals in which the aircraft manufacturer was involvedthey were delighted to hear the news that all was well on the bottom line. Profits for the first quarter were up 83 percent over the same period last year, and total sales are expected to rise to over $1 billion this year. The company's chairman, Thomas V. Jones, was warmly applauded for this performance.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Last night when the curtain fell on the final Swan Lake, Britain's Royal Ballet concluded its 15th New York season. Some people seriously believe that it will be its lastthat New York will never see the Royal Ballet again Unthinkable? Well, certainly not unthinkable, but perhaps unlikely. Yet that niggling doubt remains.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: I ordered cracked ice and Perrier water at 2:40 A.M. I demanded extra washcloths from housekeeping and noted how rapidly they were brought. I pestered the front desk with an endless array of questions: How long does it take for a letter to get to Peshawar? Are you sure there's no Charles Darnay registered at the hotel?

title: Albert Grafmueller Weds Diana Clark
description: Diana B. Clark. widow of Fred G. Clark, was married in St.. James's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday afternoon to Albert M. Grafmueller, a widower and retired president of GrafmuellerClark Industries. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Hill performed the ceremony.

description: Anne Foster Nicholas, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry R. H. Nicholas 3d of Morristown, N. J., was married there yesterday afternoon to William Craig Dodd, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Allison Dodd of Montclair. The Rev. Thomas S. Mutch performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian ChurchontheGreen.

description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 5 (AP)William L. Calley Jr. and Penny Vick, daughter of a Columbus jeweler, were married tonight in a candlelight ceremony at St. Paul United Methodist Church.

title: All about Eva
description: This is the blues that lost control. This is the rhythmic, monotone lamentation of one woman, Eva Medina, who is nobody I have ever known.

title: City U. Study Challenges View On Reduction in Black Students
description: An independent study of the new City University admission standards has challenged assertions that the rules adopted in the Board of Higher Education's retrenchment plan will eliminate most black and Hispanic students from the senior colleges.

title: Christians Fight Arab Boycott of Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Several major Christian denominations have notified American corporations in which they own stock that they would withdraw their investments if the concerns submit to the Arab boycott against Israel or discriminate against Jews, it was disclosed today at the American Jewish Committee's 70th annual meeting.

title: Red Sox Get 8 Runs in 7th, Extend Winning Streak to 4
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)Jim Rice and Carlton Fisk sparked an eightrun seventh inning with home runs, as the Boston Red Sox scored a 94 victory over the slumping Milwaukee Brewers today. It was Boston's fourth straight.

title: Owner of Missing Trimaran Is Planning to Build Another
description: Warm, clear and a deep Indigo, the Gulf Stream knifes northward along the East Coast through the murky, cold Atlantic Ocean. It fascinated Philip Weld.

title: A Professional Calls the Tune
description: GREAT NECK CRANDALL DIEHL didn't really need the few dollars, or all those hours on the Long Island Rail Road. He had enough to do most evenings with the revival of My Fair Lady, for which he is the choreographer. But he was curious to see what high school students are like today.

title: STORM OVER THE CANAL
description: On Feb. 7, 1974, Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and the then Panamanian Foreign Minister, Juan Antonio Tack, initialed a public agreement explicitly stating that a new treaty would be concluded that would set a date for the termination of United States jurisdiction over the Panama Canal Zone and ultimately the canal itself. Since then, there has been a storm of protest. Whether or not to renegotiate the original 1903 treaty has become something of a hot issue in the Republican Presidential primary race, and, depending upon who eventually become the Presidential candidates, the Panama Canal may even emerge as the QuemoyMatsu of the 70's.

title: Kissinger, as Well as His Policies, Is Now an Issue
description: WASHINGTONA month ago, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived to brief the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the crisis in Lebanon. He was ten minutes late. No Senators were there. Hurried calls were placed, and two senators arrived. Mr. Kissinger's appearance before the committee, even in closed sessions, used to draw a full room of senators.

title: Future Social Events
description: ??kets to the following events may be obtained from the ??eficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: A. H. Barclay Jr. Weds Miss Sutphin
description: Agatha Reid Sutphin and Albert Hampton Barclay Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in Indianapolis. The Rev. Russell B. Staines performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: For young readers
description: History is Interesting when it becomes the record of people rather than events, and historical novels work best when they deal with interesting characters. Without the human factor, history can seem barrenand The Porcelain Pagoda is a case in point. Set in 1822. it purports to be the journal of a girl named Kitty McAllister who travels with her family from New England to China on a trading ship. Kitty has a lively, inquisitive mind and wants to document everything she learns. Unfortunately, the author lets her do it.

title: A Whiff of Bribery on the Home Front
description: Overseas bribery and kickbacks have been getting headlines, but the same thing is going on right here at homeprobably on an even broader scaleaccording to Sales & Marketing Management magazine, a trade publication.

title: FollowUp on The News.
description: From the day it opened in 1970, the 110story World Trade Center in lower Manhattan became a favorite target of environmentalists. Every time someone washed his hands or flushed a toilet in the skyscraper, the raw sewage  two to three million gallons a day  flowed directly into the Hudson River.

title: JAVITS SEES G.O.P. HURT BY REAGAN
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits declared yesterday that the nomination of Ronald Reagan as the Republican candidate for President could put the party on the, way to extinction as a national governing alternative before the year is out

title: Protected Against a Strike
description: Lightning is one of nature's most awesome destructive forces. It is not only responsible for a high percentage of the forest fires which break out in remote areas each year, it also causes thousands of structural fires, hundreds of deaths and injuries, and millions of dollars worth of property damage. So it is understandable that many homeowners are concerned about the advisability of installing lightning rods to help protect themselves against nature's artillery.

title: Chance for a Child to Get Out of the City
description: For 9yearold Carla Tanner, the two weeks of summer vacation arranged by the Fresh Air Fund is necessary therapy for the rigors of city life.

title: ART
description: WHEN we think of capitals, we naturally think of Hollywood, Rome. London, Paris and Fort Lee. Fort Lee? Isn't that a Western flick starring John Wayne and his burly outsiders? Or the site of an epic battle between the British and the American colonialists?

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS' CAFETIMMER, 263 Central Avenue. East OrangeThe Lion in Winter. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 67501881.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The American Electric Power Company sells more electricity to more custom ers than any other utility in the nation. Its subsidiaries cover a good chunk or the rural South and Middle West, but its headquarters is in Manhattan. From there, Donald C. Cook used to blare out his outrage over oil imports, Federal policies on energy and clean air, state regulators and investment analysts.

title: Epitaph to a generation
description: The autobiography of the man who wrote The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit seems to promise some unpromising confessionsselfhatred, divorce, alcoholism, middle  aged romantic yearnings, nostalgia about a faded WASP propriety, hapless vanity, Internal Revenue problems, an uneasy Harvard boy now lurking in the body of a grandfather. And, indeed, it delivers this load of splintered kindling. Yet this book, after eight novels, which led many readers to think Sloan Wilson had no surprises in him, is finally touching, charming, and revelatory in the best wayit tells what the author knows and also more than he knows. It is a near miss at summing up the experience of a generation, marred mostly by a hastily sentimental running down at the end, which is itself a symptom of the life his career has attempted to define. (Lithium controls the manic depressive cycle and the drink. A good woman understands him. A happy marriage is usually an unearned miracle. Alas, hasn't he learned more than this?)

title: N.A.S.L. Stars on U.S.Club
description: Imagine a trio of Georgie Best, Giorgio Chinaglia and Pete, a soccer fan said the other day. No country in the world has three guys like that to play forward. Certainly not. Also, no country in the world has players like Bobby Moore, Rodney Marsh and Ramon Mifflin to play on the same team. These players are masters in their craft, but they are also of different nationalities. As a result, they could never play for the same country in an official soccer game.

title: Life Returns to the
description: IT was only a small sign the hatching of a marsh hawk in the Hackensack Meadowlands last autumn. But it was an event that had not been observed in 35 years. Added to other clues that have been emerging since 1971, it has led environmentalists to decide that the Hackensack River is coming back.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Diving for treasure
description: If David and Gail Sanders were real people, rather than the protagonists of Peter Benchley's The Deep. the odds are that they would buy the book, read it with a pleasure mitigated only by the degree to which they thought the purpose of reading novels to be moral or intellectual selfimprovement, and then stand in line a year'or so from now to see the movie. Author Benchley, whose first novel Jaws converted bathers in the relatively domesticated precincts of the Long Island seashore into wilderness adventurers and provoked shark sightings in Nebraska, may have done it again. While no one could predict a repeat of the remarkable commercial success of Jaws, Benchley's novel shows that besides being a very competent writer of fictional entertainments he is what they call one shrewd cookie.

title: Crossover Voting Makes Primaries More General
description: Conservative Democrats, many of them former supporters of Alabama Governor George C. Wallace, have resurrected Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign by providing the margin of victory for him in several recent Republican primaries. In the same manner, they could defeat President Ford in his home state of Michigan next Tuesday and possibly assure the nomination for Mr. Reagan in the process. Should they fail in Michigan, they have additional opportunities in Arkansas, Idaho and Tennessee on May 25, in Montana and Rhode Island on June 1 and in New Jersey and Ohio on June 8.

title: Whalers Score; Tie Aero Series
description: HARTFORD, May 15 (UPI)Cap Raeder, a rookie goalie, turned back 39 shots tonight to lead the New England Whalers to a 61 World Hockey Association playoff victory over the Houston Aeros.

title: Visual Art Shapes Young Minds
description: THIRTY second  graders sit on the floor in a hushed and darkened room, their attention focused on the images on a huge movie screen.

title: 10 ExAides Rehabilitated By New Laotian Authorities
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 14 (AP)After several months of indoctrination, 10 officials of the former Laotian government have returned home saying that they clearly understand the new realities in Laos, the Vientiane radio reports.

title: 9,827 Dogs Are Expected at Eight Shows
description: Local fanciers will be showing on two fronts this week. There are three allbreed events and a specialty in New Jersey, together with Queensboro's 52d fixture, and three allbreeders in New Hampshire. The eight shows have drawn a total of 9.827 dogs. Union County and the Cocker Spaniel Club of New Jersey start, the Garden State circuit on Friday. Union, at the Warinance Park iceskating center in Roselle, has 1,301 dogs, up 205 from last year, while the cocker specialty, at Ryland Inn, Whitehouse, has 160.

title: Charles Reznikoff, 18941976
description: Charles Reznikoff's spare lines have been with us longer than most poets influenced by him have been alive. Eightyone years old when he died in January, a central figure and elder statesman of that group of poets labelled objectivist, he remained austerely beyond fashion, committed as ever to that which Louis Zukofsky noted about his work in Poetry magazine in 1931, the sincerity which has seen, considered and weighed.

title: Bishop to Be Honored
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 15 (AP)The University of MassachusettsAmherst has added Roman Catholic Bishop Christopher J. Weldon of Springfield to its list of honorary degree recipients at the May 22 commencement.

title: New Plays Are My Primary Interest
description: Los ANGELES To conclude its 197576 season, the Mark Taper Forum is introducing three new playstwo of which are having their world premieresto Los Angeles theatergoers. In its first nine years, the Mark Taper has presented several other world premieres, including Daniel Berrigan's The Trial of the Catonsville Nine and Conor Cruise O'Brien's Murderous Angels. But this is the first time that the Taper has gambled on so many new plays as part of its regular season. This spring's program represents a declaration of independence by the Taper's artistic director, Gordon Davidson, who in effect is announcing his refusal to rely on Broadway or Off Broadway for new material.

title: Eastern Sprint Rowing Today
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 The Eastern Sprint championships will be held here tomorrow with the Harvard varsity eight the favorite as usual to win the major event. But among the coaches and others of the rowing establishment it is customary to designate the long shot that might have a chance to beat the Crimson.

title: A MEATLESS DAY BEGUN IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, May 15A campaign begun this month to save meat by having meatless Thursdays in Moscow restaurants, cafes and cafeterias is being pushed by authorities as intended to improve the variety of Russian diet.

title: Concert: Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic's Prospective Encounter in the Cooper Union Great Hall on Friday night was a concert, of course, but it also qualified, in a way, as a literary event. The program Pierre Boulez had arranged for this last Encounter of the season consisted of pieces based on or inspired by literature of one sort or another.

title: Yorkie Is Best in L.I. Show
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., May 15 A Yorkshire terrier, the smallest competitor in the ring, showed today that size is no handicap at a dog show. The 534pound Ch. Mayfair Barban Loup de Mer. owned by Ann Seranne and Barbara Wolferman of Newton, N.J., gave a lesson in showmanship to his bigger rivals when he was named best of 1,562 dogs at the 70th event of the Ladies Kennel Association of America.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Antitrust and the Overseas Payoffs
description: WASHINGTONBig Government's left hand sometimes doesn't know what its right hand is doing, but the hands that enforce the Federal securities laws and those that work with antitrust are trying.

title: Miss Bosher, Clifton Maloney Marry in South
description: The marriage of Carolyne Jane Bosher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Bosher of Virginia Beach, Va., to Clifton Harlan Wells Maloney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Maloney of Bryn Mawr, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Soviet Data to Aid Shepherd
description: MOSCOW. May 15 (UPI)Computers will be used to help Kazakhstan shepherds find the best feed routes for their flocks en route to summer pastures. Tags has reported. The Soviet press agency said the computers would process photographic information provided by planes on the ripening stages of grasses and the results will he communicated to the shepherds.

title: How Outlaw Basketball Colleges Cheat and Why They Succeed
description: While opponents were looking on in awe, they were also looking on in suspicion. Oral Roberts University's meteoric ascent in basketball was too hard to believe. In the whispers of opposing coaches and the indirect accusations of sports writers, Oral Roberts University was branded an outlaw school.

title: 1,300 Neighborhood Activists Attend First Citywide Convention of New York City Block Associations.
description: More than 1,300 neighborhood activistsleaders of block associations scattered throughout the five boroughsheld their first citywide convention yesterday and they debated community issues with the zest, and frequently the contentiousness, of an electionyear political convention.

title: BIG OIL CONCERNS TARGET IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, May 15The oil industry is suddenly finding itself in political difficulty in France, as leftist opposition parties accuse oil companies of abusing their rights and privileges in French society.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I wish that the BrechtWeill Threepenny Opera had been an opera so that we might have listened to music the night long without interference from that interminably moralizing libretto, and I wish that 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue had never happened at all. You may suppose that I mention both ventures in the same breath because they opened during the same week. There's a little more to it than that.

title: LETTERS
description: Leonard Wolf's article, In Horror Movies, some Things Are Sacred (April 4), attempts to explain that the mysticism of the horror film is the lurking religious content which gives many of them their special powers to attract, but his thesis seems underdeveloped and oversimplified.

title: Choices Pay Price For Match Racing
description: BALTIMORE, May 15 There were no roses, no Blackeyed Susans and no excuses for Angel Cordero and Braulio Baeza, the two jockeys who fought it out so strenuously in the 101st Preakness that somebody else's horse won the race.

title: Michigan, a slippery Ground Where Mr. Ford Must Not Slip
description: DETROITThe automobile has shaped the politics of modern Michigan. As the plants of the Big ThreeGeneral Motors, Ford and Chryslerhave drawn hundreds of thousands of immigrants from Central Europe and even larger numbers of black and white Southerners, the state has been transformed into one of the industrial centers of the world.

title: Design
description: Both as a hobby and as a professional necessity, I spend a great deal of my life in the kitchen, and in discussing its design I shall naturally be looking at it from that point of view. However, I do think a growing number of us in this country share at least some of my kitchen interests, and I presume to speak for those of who love to cook.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: In an unusual display of Congressional cooperation, a senior House member, Representative James C. Wright Jr., Democrat of Texas, has lent his subcommittee to a freshman, Representative Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, in an effort to find out what has gone wrong with the troubled Southwest Sewer District project.

title: Jan Richards Is Bride Of Malcolm Starring
description: Jan Lee Richards, daughter of the Rev. Roger L. Richards, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Pineville, La., and Mrs. Richards, was married yesterday afternoon to Malcolm F. Starring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason B. Starring 3d of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Met. Track Summaries
description: TRACK EVENTS

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Ann V. Boulton, Douglas Patton, Bankers, Wed
description: Ann Vincent Boulton and Douglas Charles Patton, assistant vice presidents with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, were married yesterday evening in St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: War Is Not Forgotten
description: LONDON  Several months ago, one of Britain's highest officials was chastised by a West German politician who said somewhat gruffly that Britain needed Germany far more than Germany needed Britain. The furious British official told a colleague later: I thought we got rid of that kind of German a long time ago.

title: JoAnne McEntegart Wed to J. E. Goett
description: JoAnne McEntegart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Steven McEntegart of. Saddle River, N. J., and Tequesta, Fla., was married at noon yesterday to James Edward Goett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goett 3d of Franklin Lakes, N. J.

title: Cuban Troops, Numerous but Discreet, Give Angola's Leaders Vital Support
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 15Occasionally they appear in town wearing olive green uniforms, bearing gifts of cigars and whisky and voicing complaints about Angolans' lack of discipline.

title: In World of Planners, Two Kinds of Reality
description: Planners in the region's suburbs, long accustomed to a lowprofile advisory role in local government, are emerging u significant, sometimes dominant partners of elected officials in the shaping of public policy.

title: Carol Shasha Plans Nuptials
description: Carol Diane Shasha, a freelance designer in the Boston area, and Joseph Benjamin Green, who expects to receive a Iaw degree next month from the Harvard Law School, will be married on June 6 in Mamaroneck, N. Y.

title: Adelphi Captures Met. Track; Thomas, F.D.U., Takes Sprints
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 15While a hot team battle raged between C. W. Post and Adelphi, Joe Thomas of Fairleigh Dickinson stole the show today at the Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships with a superb sprint double.

title: Job Market:
description: STONY BROOK ANYONE who advises young people not to go to college because of the tight labor market is doing them a tremendous disservice, Herbert Bienstock, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said here last week.

title: The I.C.C., an Exhibit in Mr. Ford's Case
description: WASHINGTONThe present chairman of the board of the American Trucking Association, a successful West Coast executive named Lee R. Sollenbarger, knows what he dislikes and speaks his mind plainly. One thing he dislikes is President Ford's pending proposal to change the rules by which the Interstate Commerce Commission regulates trucking.

title: Lynda B. Moecker Married To Richard Edmond Blacque
description: The marriage of Lynda Busch Moecker, who is with Policy Studies in Education, to Richard Edmond Blacque, a vice presidentinvestments with Scudder. Stevens & Clark, took place yesterday afternoon in Utica, N.Y.

title: France the Face and Essence of Beauty
description: It started with Eve, the world's first irresistible woman; her first garment was probably the fragrance of flowers. Today, a welldressed woman wouldn't think of walking out the door without the use of fragrance. The French are undoubtedly the most knowledgeable creators of fragrancesperfumes, eau de cologne, toilet waters. France offers the best in fragrances  as well as an astounding array of beauty products and toiletries.

title: France and America:
description: France has shared over 450 Years of history with the American continent. 200 of them with the United States. The two countries have been friends and allies during all these years. There have been times in each country's history when one's aid seemed vital to the other's survival. There have been other times when harsh words were exchangedas happens between friendsbut they have always stood side by side. fighting every war as allies, sharing their cultural experiences, their discoveries and their economic resources. Throughout these 200 years they have influenced, helped and tried to unanother.

title: Economic Ties Are Strengthening
description: Economic relations between France and the United States have come a long way from the discussions of political economy in comfortable drawing rooms to the determined negotiation by heads of state of an exchange rate agreement al Rambouillet.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Wedding Held For Ann Stutz
description: Ann Stutz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Stutz of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward S. Van Winkle, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Kingsland Van Winkle of West Hartford, Conn., and Squam Lake, N. H.

title: The Fight That Everyone Lost
description: ON the surface, Suffolk County's ambitious $60 million farmland preservation program was the only casualty when the County Legislature voted last week to table the controversial measure, in effect killing it for now.

title: The Hispanic Influx:Mi Casa, Si!
description: The signs along Fifth Avenue, a teeming commercial artery in South Brooklyn, tell the story of the Sunset Park area almost like a genealogy.

title: THE FRENCH MOOD: VAGUE UNEASINESS
description: PARIS, May 15President Valry Giscard d'Estaing will take a supersonic Concorde flight to Washington on Monday for a state visit, leaving behind a France uneasy about the future.

title: Camille Wilson, W. S. Broadbent To Wed Sept. 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L Wilson Jr. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., have made known the engagement of. their daughter, Camille C. Wilson, to William S. Broadbent. son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Broadbent of New York, formerly of Shaker Heights, Ohio. A September 11 wedding is planned.

title: Connors, Rosewall In Final
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 15 (AP)Jimmy Connors, unruffled by gusty winds and muggy 93degree heat, registered a 62, 62 victory over Ray Moore and reached the final of the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament today.

title: If Pros Are Amateurs at Heart, Should They Be in the Olympics?
description: According to the dictionary, the word amateur is derived from French and Latin and means lover, or one who loves. An amateur is one who cultivates an activity without pursuing it professionally. The International Olympic Committee emphasizes that an amateur is one who participates for the love of the game, for the joy of competing, for the sheer delight of physical ecpression.

title: MIKI AGAIN DEFIES BID TO TOPPLE HIM
description: TOKYO, May 15Prime Minister Takeo Miki appeared today to have ridden out, for the moment at least, the latest, wave of discontent within his own fractious Liberal Democratic Party.

title: The Sayings Of Chairman Peter
description: MARKETING is a fashionable term. The sales manager becomes a marketing vicepresident. But a gravedigger is still a gravedigger even when is is called a mortioianonly the price of burial goes up.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, May 16, 1976

title: COLLEGE BUILDING TO RESUME SOON
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 15Resumption of construction on the Nassau County Community College campus is expected to start soon as a result of an agreement worked out between the county and the State Dormitory Authority last week.

title: Snipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Natalie Eldredge Bride of Student
description: The chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Natalie Eldredge to Robert Greig Crichton of Washington.

title: Students in City, Despite Slump, Work on What Might Be
description: Not long ago, members of the City Planning Commission and other city officials, planners and architects met to discuss proposals for a new apartment project at Madison Square, a development beneath the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge, redevelopment schemes for the Manhattan civic center area, Jamaica, Chelsea and Union Square, and plans for a convention center at 30th Street and an apartment house at 61st Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Anna Felmly Bxide Of Gregory Lawton
description: Anna Tallman Felmly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd M. Felmly of Salem, N. Y., was married there yesterday to Gregory E. Lawton, son of H. Cranston Lawton of Glastonbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. Lawton. The ceremony was performed in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Edward Durkin.

title: AL FLOSSO
description: Al Flosso, magician, carnival performer and puppeteer, died Thursday at Bath Israel Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 4501 Broadway.

title: Sweet William
description: In this new novel by the remarkable British writer Beryl Bainbridge, the old story of the innocent heroine victimized by a nogood man is cleverly stood on its head. When we first see Ann she is drifting into marriage with Gerald, an unpleasant academic who manages to be at once coarse and stuffy. A life of safe, if pallid domesticity stretches before her, yet 10 days after seeing him off to a job in California she had encouraged

title: What Made Hollywood Hop Back in the Saddle Again?
description: Moviemakers have their sixsnooters drawn once more.

title: National Medals Sales Report
description: The American Revolution Bicentennial Administration reports the following updated sales totals (as of May 3) for the seven different sizes and metals of its official National Bicentennial Medal:

title: Rutherford Qualifies at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15Johnny Rutherford, the 38yearold Mr. Nice Guy of Indianapolis racing, led the qualifers with a speed of 188.957 miles an hour today in the first day of time trials for the 60th running of the Indianapolis 500 on May 30.

title: GARDENING
description: PEOPLE take summer vacations to recuperate from the rigors of winter; why not houseplants? Most houseplants thrive outdoors in our summer climate and often require less care as well.

title: Luck of an Irish Cop
description: BALTIMORE, May 15Eugene Cashman, a Chicago cop who made it big in soybeans, went to the FasigTipton yearling sales in Lexington, Ky., in July of 1974 with checkmarks beside the names of two of the 46 horses listed in the catalogue. He paid $15,000 for one, a son of Gallant Romeo and Strictly speaking that he named Elocutionist, and an hour or so later Esteban Rodriguez Tizol bought the other, a colt by Irish CastleComely Nell, for $15,200. Elocutionist was a bargain, finishing as far back as third only twice in his first 11 races, but when Bold Forbes won the Kentucky Derby. it was clear that Cashman had picked the wrong horse.

title: PRESIDENT STUMPS MICHIGAN BY TRAIN
description: ABOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL EXPRESS, in Michigan, May 15  President Ford, in search of a badly needed primary victory in his home state, turned back the political clock today to conduct an oldfashioned whistlestop train campaign across Michigan.

title: Young Audiences Benefit
description: A recital by Maralin Niska, operatic soprano, accompanied by Jacquelyne Silver, has been arranged for tomorrow evening. The event, to be held in the ballroom at the former Burden Mansion, 7 East 91st Street, will benefit the New York Committee for Young Audiences. Reservations may be made through the beneficiary at 400 West End Avenue. Admission will be $40 for subscribers, $75 for patrons.

title: Sunday Observer
description: This shoe store sold me a pair of yellow shoes. I didn't want yellow shoes. Nobody wants yellow shoes. This store sold them to me anyhow.

title: The Class of 1976
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., May 15In the next couple of weeks, we will be launching a new class of high school and college graduates into the third century of the Republic. Not into the world of Vietnam and Watergate, Adam Smith or Karl Marx, but into a vague and ambiguous world, haltway between Jimmy Carter and Jerry Ford, wherever they are.

title: Nate Thurmond
description: When even those who knew how good he once was had almost forgotten him, has contributed a gallant dignity to the National Basketball Association playoffs. He is 34 years old now, a muscular, sinewy center who appears to be constructed of aging leather and rope battered by 13 seasons under the backboards. He was content to play about 20 minutes a game for the Cleveland Cavaliers until Jim Chones suffered a broken toe in a practice before the Eastern Conference final with the Boston Celtics began. In the emergency, is now playing 40 minutes a game and neutralizing Dave Cowens, younger and swifter, in the fourofsevengame series that resumes today in Boston with the teams tied, 22.

title: Railroad Car Float Is Becoming Bicentennial Barge
description: The job of transforming an old railroadcar float into the state's official Bicentennial barge is nearing completion at a Staten Island shipvaid. The 250foot barge, as yet unnamed, is to be dedicated officially on June 3 in ceremonies at the South Street Seaport Museum, Fulton Street and the East River. Governor Carey is expected to cut the ribbon.

title: Olympics Not Sold Out
description: MONTREAL, May 15 (AP)  Olympic glamciur sports have captured the attention of the public at the expense of many other events at the 21st Summer Games, an Olympic organizing committee spokesman says.

title: Six Attend Marjorie A. Morris At Her Wedding to Robert Cave
description: Marjorie Alden Morris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon in the First Church of Christ (Congregational) to Robert Arthur Cave, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Cave of Wayne, Ill. The Rev. George M. Milne performed the ceremony.

title: ART
description: CRANGE is the lifeblood of art. It is the vital force that provides the creative energy for the realization of new ideas, the spark that illumines the way for fresh discoveries. Without change there would be a stagnation of visual forms.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The mystery is how a man can write so poorly at one time and so skillfully at another. The English writer Michael Butterworth in the past has turned out Gothics in a manner, as previously noted here, that even puts ladyprose to shame. But last year he provided a surprise with The Man in the Sopwith Camel a sensitive, merry example of escape fiction on a Walter Mitty theme. Was this the new Butterworth, or was it temporary? Part of the answer is found in Butterworth's most recent book, REMAINS TO BE SEEN (Doubleday, $5.95).

title: The Market Vanishes
description: I wouldn't know how to go about it if the National Stock Exchange in New York hadn't liquidated itself a few years ago, said George White, president of the Detroit Stock Exchange when he announced that the 69yearold securities market would close.

title: Armed Forces Parade Recalls 1776
description: Green Berets shouting marching slogans in rhythmic catrence and rifletoting female and male midshipmen from the United States Merchant Marine Academy marched on Fifth Avenue yesterday for the Armed Forces Day parade.

title: Derfla Collins Wed to James Patterson
description: Derfla Jean Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Howes Collins of Essex. Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to James Arthur Boynton Patterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Arthur Patterson of Bucksport, Me. The ceremony was performed in the First Congregational Church by the minister, the Rev. Joshua Crowell.

title: U.S. Approves $23.4 Million For LowIncome Subsideis
description: The Ford Administration has formally approved $23.4 million a year for use in New York City to help subsidize the rents of 8,000 lowerincome families.

title: JordanSoviet Arms Talk Arouses Concern in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The scheduled visit to Jordan next week of a highlevel Soviet military delegation has aroused considerable concern in Washington that the Jordanians are about to turn to Moscow for weapons.

title: Rich Jazz Piano By Randy Weston With the Collective
description: For more than 20 years, Randy Weston has been an unusually creative and easily accessible jazz pianist and composer. But his spare, strongly rhythmic keyboard style, richly colored with an Ellington influence, and the catchy appeal of his delightfully melodic cornpositionsLittle Niles. Hi Fly, Berkshire Blues, Willie's Tunehave not brought him as wide an audience as might be expected.

title: The Wild Boy of Aveyron
description: Crimes against humanity are not on the wane in modem times. Yet the hardpressed principles of Western civilization, which strive to safeguard the life and integrity of every individual human being, have generally restrained us from the one experiment that might reveal something significant about the mysterious amalgam of nature and culture in man. The experiment would be to deprive a child of all social contact from birth, or at least after the age when solitary survival becomes possible. However, the accidents of history have delivered a few such children into our hands. It is understandable that some of the most astute modern works concerned with the balance of nature and culture should open with a reference to the best documented case: the Wild Boy of Aveyron. (For example: Ruth Benedict, Patterns of Culture, 1934; Claude LeviStrauss, The Elementary Structure of Kinship, 1949; Roger Brown, Words and Things, 1958.) Yet none of them pauses to reexamine the case with care.

title: DR. LOUIS DLUGASCH
description: Dr. Louis Dlugasch, a physician here for 65 years and a specialist in diseases of the ear, nose and threat, died Thursday at his home, 230 Central Park West He was 90 years old.

title: ... Embattled President
description: President Ford's position in the Republican Party is the converse of Governor Carter's. Although Ronald Reagan leads in pledged delegates, the President is still the frontrunner in the Republican race because he has a big edge among the nominally uncommitted delegates from Pennsylvania and New York. But the arithmetic and the momentum of the situation are not working in his favor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Encounter: An Aging Ferryboat Amid a Raging Samoan Hurricane
description: I woke early to catch the ferry to the neighboring island of Upolu. Western Samoa's only large town. Apia, was located there, and I felt the need for a recent movie and a Chinese dinner. Savai'i Island, where I was visiting, lacked such amenities. The sun was flickering through the everpresent billowy white cumulus clouds on the horizon as I turned on the morning weather report: There is a convergent zone off the Tokelaus. No problem. He had been saying the same thing for two weeks.

title: Rockefeller Accepts Tribute in Germany On U.S. Bicentennial
description: FRANKFURT, May 15In an outpouring of gratitude, pride in its own democracy, and simple curiosity, West Germany is celebrating the Bicentennial of the American Revolution almost as if it were its own.

title: Miss Bowen Married on L.I.
description: Barbara Pace Bowen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Loveridge Bowen of Lloyd Harbor, L. I., was married yesterday to Roland Daniel Zimany, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Zimany of Toms River, N. J.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: IN the 1920's, when the opening of King Tut's tomb was front page news all over the world, a previously obscure American photographer named Harry Burton achieved international celebrity when his photographs of the excavation gave newspaper readers their first look at the rare and beautiful treasure being uncovered. Today Harry Burton is once again virtually unknown except to Egyptologists, and when his photographs are seen by a larger publicfor instance, as black and white illustrations in Christiane DesrochesNoblecourt's 1963 book Tutankhamun  they usually play second fiddle to dazzling fullcolor illustrations of the eminently photogenic statues, furniture and shrines that filled the royal tomb.

title: Yanks Down Orioles, 73, on 4Run 7th
description: If it weren't for the bubbling enthusiasm of little Fred Stanley, who never even scared the pitchers when he was playing for Rio Hondo College, it would be difficult to realize that the Yankees scored a 73 victory yesterday over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: New York State 7th In Average '75 Income
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)New York State was seventh while Alaska, spurred by increased construction on the oil pipeline there, rose to first in the list of average incomes for 1975, the Government says.

title: 2 Who Flew Over
description: RAY ROACH was serene, a Zen monk surrounded by the passionate, the excited, the surprised. Three generations of guys from The Corner were boozing, laughing, jabbing, stomping, and it seemed for a moment that all of them, at once, were clapping Ray Roach on his venerable shoulders.

title: The Measure of Greatness
description: Julius Erving can do things with a basketball that may never have been seen or thought of before.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Trains, Not Highways, Will End Traffic Jams

title: Christina Hartmann Is Married on L. I.
description: Christina Beck Hartmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank William Hartmann of Roslyn Harbor, L. I., and Grantham, N. H., was married yesterday afternoon to Alfred A La Fountain 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. La Fountain Jr. of Rumson, N. J.

title: Agostini Tops Trial Mark
description: MUGELLO, Italy, May 15 (AP)Giacomo Agostini of Italy, riding a 500 cubiccentimeter Suzuki, broke his onedayold track record today in the official trials for the World motorcycling championship events in this velodrome near Florence. Agostini was timed in 2 hours 08.08 minutes in averaging nearly 92 miles an hour. His record time yesterday was 2:08.77.

title: Who Isn't Here? All of the Guests Marveled
description: There was a little game played in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel Wednesday night. It was called Who isn't here?, which, translated from the chic to the understandable, meant, Which of our friends aren't here? Precious few.

title: DORIS MADDEN
description: Doris Madden, Australianborn concert pianist and accompanist for the late Dame Nellie Melba, the operatic so prano, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital after a heart attack. She was 90 years old and lived at 67 West 68th Street.

title: Artists' Theater Is Happening Again
description: The fresh, ragtag kind of theater, loosely known as Happenings, created by painters and sculptors in the 'sixties had been quietly interred in the 'seventies until revivified by Robert Whitman's current retrospective now playing at a truck depot in Greenwich Village.

title: Family
description: On the campus of a university in the Eastern United States are assembled, for enigmatic experimental purposes, 23 assorted apes. Four of them, Moses, Dylys, Lollipop and Sasha, one day escape and go off to live wild in the countryside.

title: A Pilling Editorial Charges Rightists Are Still Powerful
description: PEKING, May 15 (Reuters)China's leftist radicals charged tonight that rightwing revisionists still held a large share of power in the Chinese leadership and were trying to strike hack despite the downfall of former Deputy Prime Minister Tens Hsiaoping.

title: STAMPS
description: A Bicentennial souvenir card for Thomas Jefferson, whose immortal words gave definition to the creation and existence of the new nation 200 years ago, is being put oat by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at Interphil 76, the International Philatelic Exhibition taking place May 29June 6 at Philadelnliia.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Visit to Canton Illumines Only the Surface of Chinese Politics
description: CANTONAfter finishing their shift in the Canton Heavy Machinery Factory one afternoon this week, a dozen young workers gathered around their lockers for a political study session.

title: Books: Peter Drucker, in Detail
description: Early in his book, Mr. Tarrant observes that it is impossible to fit [Peter] Drucker into any neatly defined compartment. He is a European who has, for many years, commented on many facets of American life. He is frequently thought of as an economist, but his degree is not in economics, and he is often caustic about economics and its practitioners. He is a consultant and a highly successful one, but he rarely imparts to his clients any specific advice about operating methods. He is known as Mr. Management, but he has never met a payroll. He has devoted years to the study of organizationsand he has had enormous effect on the structure and functioning of organizationsbut he has, himself, no organization, and has never had one.

title: NOOSE DEMOCRATS SEEK MORE JOBS AND CUT IN TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Democratic majority in the House of Representatives has proposed a massive realignment of legislative priorities for the next five years aimed at restoring national economic prosperity by creating 12 milllion new jobs and cutting taxes by $10 billion.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Peace treaties and trade pacts are international agreements arrived at through compromise. Movies are not. The Blue Bird, the first (and possibly the last) AmericanSoviet motion picture coproduction, isn't good and it isn't a disgrace. It's not much of anything, but movies that are not much of anything are the most difficult to endure. They never give you something truly outrageous to hiss at. There's no opportunity to let off steam. You can't gracefully stomp out of the theater. You have to sit there and squirm. You look at your watch, listen to the fidgets of nearby children and remember with longing getting your adrenaline up while watching something like The Straw Dogs. The Blue Bird isn't a movie. It's covenant with boredom.

title: Tenants Outwit Vandals
description: AN experiment in tenant management at Jersey City's three nighrise public housing projects is proving so successful it may be advanced as a model for similar programs around the coontry.

title: Vacations for the Aging
description: New York's leastknown and mostoverlooked minority are its one million elderly citizens who live on the side streets of anonymity, behind the locked doors of deteriorating buildings, hungry for companionship as well as a little more than daily bread, scraping by with marginal incomes on the cheap cuts of life.

title: Miss Twyeffort Wed to Clergyman
description: Katherine Blackwell Twyeffort of New Paltz, N. Y. and the Rev. Richmond Kent Greene were married yesterday afternoon in the United Methodist Church in New Paltz. The Rev. James Moulton Thomas and the Rev. Ronald Law officiated.

title: Political Action Committees of Large Corporations
description: Companies are listed in order of rank in the top 100 of Fortune Magazine's 500 largest industrial corporations. Reports of cash on hand are submitted at various intervals, and the newer committees had not reported any as of April 28.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ADDS TOVIEW ON RHODESIA
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 15 (Reuters)South Africa could change its policy of refraining from military interference in Rhodesia's affairs if developments warranted the change, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Detroit Races From Recovery Into Boom
description: DETROITRemarkable, said Mike Quillin, the sales manager at Superior Oldsmobile here glancing at a sheet that shows the dealership sold 225 new cars in April. That's two more than in April of 1973 when the auto industry rolled to its record year, and double the 111 sold by Superior in April last year.

title: Miss Latta Is Bride Of Charles Coyne
description: Paula Jane Latta and Charles Cole Coyne. Republican candidate for the Pennsylvania State Legislature from the 187th District of Philadelphia, were married yesterday afternoon in the Upper Octoraro Presbyterian Church in Parkesburg, Pa., by the Rev. James Brown.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: City Council Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held this week by City Council committees:

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Northern New Jersey Region. S.C.C.A. national races at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, 1 P.M.

title: Jennifer Reed Married
description: Jennifer Irene Reed, daughter of Jacqueline Smyth Reed of Weston, Conn., and the late Harlow J. Reed, was married yesterday to Harris Laskawy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Laskawy of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Edwin A. Lane performed the ceremony on the grounds of the Unitarian Church in Westport, Conn. The bride is an actress and model. Mr. Laskawy, a stage, screen and television actor is cofounder of the CSC Repertory Theater.

title: TV VIEW
description: For the second time this season, 60 Minutes has gotten itself into trouble, which is exactly where newsmagazines, electronic or otherwise, should be more often than they are. Anyway, it takes our minds off Louise Lasser and her cocaine bust. (Did you know that in Miami Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman is on the public television channel every weeknight at 7:30? How's that for family viewing?) First, there was the flap about Syrian Jews having been portrayed on 60 Minutes as somewhat happier than Syrian Jews are supposed to be.
