And now there is a flap about whether the program was playing fair with the Jewish Defense League on Sunday, May 2.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: NEW JERSEY, it would appear, has a long and quite unforgiving memory, and apparently has decided that Lord John Cavendish remains unworthy of pardon. Although Georgia, Virginia, Texas, Pennsylvania, Illinois, New York, Nebraska, Wisconsin and even Hawaii have found it in their governmental hearts to forgive Lord Cavendish, New Jersey has refused, and Ted Jones and Clive Allen are disturbed.

title: McCartneyThe Beatle With the Charm Is Back
description: On August 29, 1966. the Beatles gave a concert at Candlestick Park in San Francisco. Most of us Beatlemaniacs who were there realized that this was the final concert of their American tour that summer, and a few may have heard rumors that future touring was becoming problematic. But not manycould have anticipated that that performance would be the group's last, or that it would be nearly 10 years before Paul McCartneythe band's leader, if anybody could claim the titleagain performed in this country.

title: Miss Conway Wed To M. G. Timchula
description: Alexandra Conway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Granville ??lliot Conway of Morristown, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael George Timchula, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Timchula of Denver. The Rev. Albert Gallaten Edwards, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Conway residence.

title: PEOPLE
description: Off to the Philippines and Hong Kong in the fall will be John D. Maguire, president of the State University of New York College at Old Westbury. During a sabbatical leave he will be visiting professor of humanities at Silliman University In the Central Philippines and visiting lecturer at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. He will be back at Old Westbury next May 1. During his absence, the vice president/provost, Edward S. Todd, will be acting president. Says Mr. Maguire: This trip represents a kind of wedding: of the East with the West, of the classroom with administration, of reflection with action. I'm enormously excited by the prospect returning to teaching for this period, and for the opportunity to learn more about what is rapidly becoming perhaps the most crucial part of the world.

title: Playoff Results
description: N.B.A. Playoffs

title: POLITICS
description: POLITICAL officials from both parties in New Jersey had been predicting the worst. that there would be so many candidates in the June 8 primary election that voting machines would not be able to accommodate all of them, and that in counties where they could, the ballot would be so crowded as to make it almost impossible for voters to sort out the ones they wanted nominate.

title: A Sound Bridge Is Still an Unsound Idea
description: THE New York Times' poll of Nassau and Suffolk residents indicated that a majority of residents favored a bridge across Long Island Sound. This may have some statistical validity, but lacks logic and reason. It has been emphasized previously that the major beneficiaries of such a bridge would be the industrial and trucking interests. Ironically, however, the major portion of the cost would be borne by the individual taxpayer.

title: No One's ShootingIt Must Be Athens
description: ATHENSA salesman for a large American manufacturer was gazing out of his window in the Athens Tower, Greece's first and only highrise building, and talking about the good old days in Beirut. It really was an easy life, he mused. We were all set in our ways. But now we've been uprooted and we have to get back into the real world.

title: The Ford Campaign Shows Signs Of Disarray
description: When Gerald Ford was Vice President, one of his friends, former Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York, said: Ford is a solid, inertial guy. He is not fast on his feet, but he is an intelligent hardworking guy . . . it took him a year or two to adjust to being minority leaderhe continued to act as if he were still just a Congressman from Grand Rapids. It will be a slow transition to national leaderthat's the way it is.

title: Devouring the Children, as in Swift's Essay
description: JONATHAN SWIFT offered in his Modest Proposal a horrifying solution to the threat of resource scarcity in a community. As certain as we were that Swift's solutionthe cannibalization of the community's childrencould never merit the practical consideration of a civilized society, we are, as residents of New Jersey, about to choose a less violent, yet more sinister variety of Swift's proposal.

title: ART VIEW
description: The day will come, no doubt, when New York will see a proper retrospective exhibition of the art of Agnes Martin. The fine retrospective that Suzanne Delehanty organized at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia three years ago never did make it to New Yorka fact more damaging to the reputation of our museums than to that of the artist. Miss Martin's is, to be sure, a sometimes difficult art. It does not perform for a crowd. It cannot be described as brilliant. It is quiet, elusive, contemplativemost elusive, perhaps, where it seems most obvious. Yet any understanding of the vicissitudes of abstract painting in America over the last decade or more remains incomplete without some grasp of her work.

title: Adm. Morison, 88, Historian, Is Dead
description: Samuel Eliot Morison, the undisputed Grand Old Man of American historians, died yesterday in the Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, from the effects of a stroke. He was 88 years old and lived in Boston during the winter and in Maine in the summer.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: STATE SENATOR James H. Wallwork may have opened Pandora's Box again last week. This painfully earnest Republican, who lives in Short Hills, said he would allot $1,000 from his legislative salary for ideas from state employees on how to improve the government. To Mr. Wallwork, improvement is synonymous with saving money.

title: UNREST PERSISTS IN WEST SAHARA
description: RABAT, Morocco, May 15 (Reuters)  Although Morocco and Mauritania have changed the political map of Africa by carving up the former Spanish Sahara between them, they still face problems and scattered violence.

title: Adele Ginzberg, at 90, Says, So What?
description: She was inundated with good wishes for her 90th birthday Tuesday, and she was fed up. I wish I'd lied about my age, Adele Ginzberg said.

title: Council Seeking Reforms on U.S. Housing Funds
description: The Citizens Housing and Planning Council has called for reform in the city's procedures for spending Federal communitydevelopment funds.

title: Ford Is Found Preferred By Uncommitfed Delegates
description: DURAND, Mich., May 15President Ford appears to have substantially more strength than his challenger, Ronald Reagan, among uncommitted delegates already chosen for the Republican National Convention.

title: Creative Courses For Every Palette
description: What color is seaweed in late July along the Maine coast? Under a brilliant sun 15 vacationing amateur artists in floppy hats struggle to capture on paper that elusive shade of purplishbrown.

title: Hopefuls Await Incumbents' Decisions
description: Four Manhattan Democrats are nervously trying to read Representative Bella S. Abzug's mind. Does she really mean it when she says she will quit her House seat to run for the nomination for United States Senator? If so, they might run for the Democratic nomination for her seat in her solidly Democratic district.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Concorde supersonic passenger jet will make its first trip to, the United States in two years Monday when President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France begins a sixday visit.

title: THAIS ARE TARGET OF ARMS SELLERS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 15 Thailand, since the American withdrawal, is rapidly becoming one of the largest purchasers of arms in Asia, in an attempt to fill the new strategic vacuum in the region.

title: Army Alters Bayonet Drills After the Death of a Soldier
description: FULDA, West Germany, May 14 (UPI)The United States Army's 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment has stopped using unsheathed bayonets in tactical training because of the death of a soldier during the exercises, an army spokesman says.

title: Race and Wallace Sentiment May Condition the Voting
Deborah Slocomb, Photographer, Wed
description: Deborah Farrington Slocomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nelson Slocomb of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to William Francis Dohme Jr., son of Mrs. William Francis Dohme of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Dohme.

title: The U.S. Elections Add to the Problem
description: WASHINGTONAfter more than two years of intensive efforts to achieve a settlement between the Arabs and Israelis, the diplomats and the politicians have quietly all but given up the game for the foreseeable future. The involved parties have been distracted by other, more immediately pressing matters.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: O, Delaware!
description: SANDYSTON TOWNSHIP. N.J.Cardinals, catbirds and redWinged blackbirds sang from the shores, a flock of Canada geese passed overhead, mergansers flew low over the water in twos and threes, and John B. Boniface was a study in delight as he battled a sixpound roe shad on light spinning tackle.

title: Flyers' Magic in Spectrum To Get Biggest Test Tonight
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15The telephone operator's voice is crisp and almost saccharine: Philadelphia Spectrum home of the Stanley Cup Champions. By tomorrow, however, unless the Philadelphia Flyers can withstand the gale forces of the Montreal Canadiens, the Spectrum could he simply the home of the Flyers after two championship seasons.

title: The Blob comes to Arizona
description: WOLF HOLE, Ariz. Obvious Arizona, as Nabokov called it in Lolita, has been part of my life for most of my life. Arizonadrida zona in Espanol forced itself on my attention when I tried to hitchhike across it eastward bound during the summer of '44. No luck. I had to hop a freight in Needles on the California border and never got off till I hit Gallup, N. M., 48 hours later. I might have ridden that train all the way to Home, Pa., where I come from, but was scared off when two other bums crawled into my personal boxcar. Eyes on me with calculating interest, one of them began combing his greasy hair with a switchblade knife. I had $30 hidden in my shoe. Not to mention other valuables about my person. I left.

title: Not Well Enough To Be Bored
description: PARISThis week's official visit to the United States by France's President Valry Giscard d'Estaing marks a peculiar phenomenon in America's relgions with its oldest ally. When de Gaulle came, despite a political frost in Washington, we were awed by his impressive personality.

title: Nigeria Head Tells Of Executions of 7 In February Plot
description: LAGOS. Nigeria, May 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Nigerian Government executed seven people today for their alleged roles in last February's abortive coup and fatal shooting of Gen. Murtala Ramat Muhammed, the head of state.

title: Whither America?
description: PITTSBURGHBehind all the rhetoric of our current liolitical perplexities there stand in stark outline some national issues scarcely mentioned, much less seriously debated.

title: The Nation
description: The Senate has reached a comproanise that will put into effect the central recommendation to come from its committee's inquiry into intelligence activities: a single oversight committee with legislative and budgetary authority. However, the new committee will have to share its authority with four standing committees whose past performance as intelligence watchdogs the inquiry criticized.

title: TAX RELIEF TIED TO BENEFITS BILL
description: ALBANY, May 15Plans to increase workmen's compensation benefits this yeara move that both Democrats and Republicans agree is necessaryhave become entangled in Republican attempts to link any increase to portions of their controversial businesstaxrelief plan.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT
description: IF ANY restaurant in North Jersey could be called landmark, it would have to be Pals Cabin. Founded in 1932 in what was then an almost rural part of Essex County, Pals today is surrounded by gasoline statiuns, shopping centers, other restaurants and a ceaseless stream of traffic from which it profits handsomely.

title: State Wins At the Track
description: SINCE 1942, horseplayers at New Jersey tracks have pushed $10 billion through the parimutuel windows as their contribution to the effort known as improving the breed. Of this $10 billion, more than $760 million has gone to the State Treasury and an equal amount or more has gone to the racetrack owners for profit and for distribution to the horse owners.

title: At last the star of the show
description: Ah, the longago summer of 1928 at Alexander Woollcott's rented seaside villa in Cap d'Antibes. Nothing but one fun party after anothera threemonth binge interrupted only by an occasional poker game and latenight skinny dipping in the Mediterranean. Harpo Marx, Ruth Gordon and Alice Duer Miller were staying at the villa with Woollcott. Guests included everyone from H. G. Wells, Peggy Hopkins Joyce, Charles MacArthur,

title: Leading Qualifiers for IC4A Track
description: TRACK EVENTS

title: Union Square a Hard Test for City's Recycling Efforts
description: As she hurried from work to catch an IRT express to her home on East 46th Street, Monica Jarmyn paused momentarily in front of the subway entrance at 14th Street and Broadway to explain why she would never shop or live in the Union Square area.

title: OneWoman Roadblock
description: GRIGGSTOWN HER friends call her The Lady Who Stops Highways, but Lee Bullitt, a member of the Delaware and Raritan Canal Commission, protests the appelation vehemently.

title: A memoir and two novels
description: A writer in his early sixties spends a day and a night on Long Island with a woman half his age. He thinks: I should like to describe this day. just this day, our weekend together.... And again: I should like to be able to describe this weekend, this thin present moment, exactly as it is, without inventing anything. . . I want to know what 1 notice and think when I am not thinking of possible readers. . . .

title: Mailbox: Check List For Coach
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jesse Hill Ford's Yoknapatawpha
description: Like William Faulkner, Jesse Hill Ford has discovered that his own little postagestamp of native soil contains more than enough of life and death, of love and hate to sustain a writer and create a cosmos. Ford's Yoknapatawpha is west Tennessee between the great river that gives the state its name and the Mississippi. In prizewinning stories and such novels as The Mountains of Gilead (his first), The Liberation of Lord Byron Jones and now The Raider, Mr. Ford portrays this region and its people with clarity, power and considerable narrative skill.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: High Court to Rule in Test Suit Against Retirement at Age 50
description: ANDOVER, Mass.  Bob Muria joined the state police in l948 and soon, like his uncle before him, he was a good cop.

title: East Brunswick
description: THE story of East Brunswick's exclusionary zoning ordinances is the story of an expanding suburban community that was trying to survive in a state where the cost of education is supported by property taxes.

title: Notes: Making Chamber Music in The Colonies
description: Few events seem more appropriate in the Bicentennial year than the forthcoming trip by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to Charleston, S.C. It was Charleston, after all, which balanced Boston as an artistic center in the days before our Independence, and the first public, concerts in the Colonies were held there in 1731, A reminder of the city's early cultural life is the fine, small theater built on bock Street in 1736 which stands today  restored, airconditioned, and seating 480 people.

title: Major League Averages
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: U.S. Investigating Navajos Over Handling of Millions
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., May 15The United States Attorney's office in Arizona is conducting a major investigation into alleged mismanagement of millions of dollars in Federal funds by officials of the Navajo Nation, the country's largest Indian reservation.

title: Europe's Communists: The Ideology Is Shaky
description: PARISWhile Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and other leaders are worrying about a swelling tide of Communism in Western Europe, at least some Western Communists are worrying about what they consider the decay and deformation of their movement.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Argot. Like the truckers who swap information on their citizenband radios, paperbounders speak a jargon all their own. Herewith a start at a compilation of the trade's everchanging lexicon.

title: Belmont Entries Today
description: FIRST$7,500, cl., 4YO and up, 1??M (chute).

title: Miss Hunsiker, Michael Farnum Have Nuptials
description: Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Melissa Lufkin Hunsiker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Whiting Hunsiker of Pittsburgh, to Michael Farnum, son of Mrs. Ralph Farnum of Washington and Montego Bay, Jamaica, and the late Mr. Farnum.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The second suspect in the fatal stabbing of a 49year old physician during a robbery in Lincoln Terrace Park in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn was arrested early yesterday, the police reported. The suspect, Gregory Sapp, 23 years old, of 1438 Eastern Parkway was arrested at the home of a friend on Gates Avenue. On Friday, Roosevelt Kinred, 22, of 1400 East New York Avenue in Brownsville, surrendered to the police. The two men, who are unemployed, were charged with the murder of Dr. Walter Blumenson, who had an office in his home at 1128 Foster Avenue in Flatbush.

title: Juliana Mellick Is Bride of Francis Hallowell 2d
description: Juliana Mellick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Drew Mellick Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., was married in Gladstone, N.J., yesterday afternoon to Francis Jackson Hallowell 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Hallowell of Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories.

title: Possible Move by Levi on Busing Is Debated in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 15  White antibusing activists here were encouraged today by reports that the United States Attorney General, Edward H. Levi, was considering urging the Supreme Court to reconsider busing as a solution to school segregation, but blacks expressed fear that the move could spur more violence.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: An era of rapid change will be in store for Wall Street after William M. Batten takes over this week as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, the world's biggest securities market. Mr. Batten, who will succeed James J. Needham on Tuesday in one of the most important and sensitive jobs in the financial community, could prove to be the most influential leader of the exchange in modern times.

title: Correction
description: The Times failed to state last Sunday that the report from which two articles on the laws of incorporation were excerpted is copyrighted by Ralph Nader. W. W, Norton & Company is publishing the report as a book Taming the Giant Corporations  in September.

title: Music: Solti Hollander
description: Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra maintained tradition by presenting an opera in concert form Friday night in Carnegie Hall. Ever since Sir Georg came to New York with Das Rheingold, he has been careful to devote one of his annual appearances here to an opera, generally a German one.

title: Notes: Boom Time For the Bard
description: The Delacorte Theater in Central Park rang to the pounding of hammers and the whine of electric saws; an $800,000 rebuilding project was under way. On the uncompleted stage stood Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, gazing at a mockup of the setting for Henry V, the play he is scheduled to direct as the opening production of his ShakespeareinthePark series this summer. The first rehearsal was set for May 24, the first public performance for June 24, but Mr. Papp seemed unconcerned by the chaos around him as he pondered the tabletop world of Henry V.

title: Rutgers Group Fights Pornography
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ARE pornographic movies sexist? A group of 50 Rutgers University students contend that they are and has formed a committee that is actively trying to convince people not to attend these films.

title: A CITY IN ONTARIO AWAITS INDUSTRY
description: KINGSTON, Ontario  This historic lakeside city, best known for campuses, penitentiarigs and yacht races, is in the midst of a drive to become a regional industrial center as well.

title: HUNDREDS MARCH FOR MARIJUANA
description: Hundreds of teenagers streamed up Fifth Avenue from Washington Square Park yesterday afternoon smoking marijuana as police officers assigned to the area watched from the curbs.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Flowers for The Apartment Gardener
description: Apartments are overflowing with plants, and many of the showiest, being tropical in origin, do best indoors. But even with the countless indoor plants available, there comes a time when the apartment gardener feels a twinge of jealousy for his country cousin's marigolds or summer petunias.

title: IC4A Whips Up a Production In Honor of 100th Track Meet
description: From the listing of parades, banquets, bands and ceremonies, it sounds more like a football bowl game than a track meet. But this week's Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor championships are a proper occasion for unusual festivitiesthe 100th annual edition of the oldest major track meet in the United States.

title: Headliners
description: The leader of Britain's Liberal Party, Jeremy Thorpe, has resigned because of publicity over an alleged homosexual affair some years ago. Mr. Thorpe has denied the charges, but said he was resigning for the wellbeing of the party. The accusations against Mr. Thorpe have been made by a former male model, who has produced no evidence and who has now withdrawn a defamation suit against Mr. Thorpe. Mr. Thorpe has led the party for nine years, during which he increased its influence but never managed to bring it to equality with the Labor and Conservative Parties. Jo Grimond, Mr. Thorpe's predecessor, has been named interim leader.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: Knock knock Who's there? Feiffer
description: An Upper West Side apartment. In the living room, framed comic strips, among them Gasoline Alley and Terry and the Pirates, cover the walls as do contemporary paintings, a blownup photograph of Gerald Ford, Henry Kissinger and associates taken after the Mayagez incident, a Hogarth engraving, David Levine caricatures and a child's drawings. Under a window with a view of the Hudson River is a draftsman's table. Beside another window, opening onto a terrace, is a 2foothigh suit of armor holding a shield and a battle ax, a white plume thrusting from its helmet. The door to bedroom is open. Visible past the piles of clothes on the floor are a drawingtable, a biggerthanlifesize Humphrey Bogart poster and a queensize bed. Jules Feiffercartoonist and playwrightis just waking up.

title: CHESS
description: When Aaron Reinganum picked the name Benoni Defense for the flank opening he investigated in his book, which came out in 1825, he had in mind its sobriquic meaning, Son of Sorrow. He wanted to record that his work on chess relieved his melancholy. But, judging from what has been happening to this defense lately, it could better have been named Father of Sorrow.

title: GERALDINE ANNUNZIATA
description: Geraldino Mary Annunziata, wife of Dr. Frank Annunziata, proressor of American history at Fisenhower College in Seneca Falls. N.Y., died Friday of cancer et the University Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 33 years old.

title: JEWS SAID TO EASE VIEW ON MARRIAGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Many Jews appear to be softening their attitude toward Jews who marry outside their faith, according to researchers.

title: Miss Hollerith, Nathan Laffoon Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hollerith Jr. of New York and Harbor Springs, Mich., have announced the engagement of Mr. Hollerith's daughter, Catharine Louise Hollerith, to Nathan Powell Laffoon, son of Emily Allen Laffoon and Polk Laffoon 3d of Cincinnati.

title: Islamic Talks End With Stress On Assistance for Insurgencies
description: ISTANBUL, May 15Foreign ministers and other representatives of 42 Islamic countries expressed strong support today for the Palestinians, the Turkish Cypriots and a variety of insurgent groups from the Philippines to southern Africa.

title: Americans Savor
description: The FrenchAmerican Kitchen Alliance a treaty unrecorded in any history bookhas bound France and the United States in their love of good food and influenced American cuisine.

title: San Quentin Has Opening
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., May 15 (UPI)The San Quentin News says it has an opening for an experienced reporter. Either experienced in journalism or experienced in life at San Quentin, the prison paper said Tuesday, adding: the job has a $20.50 pay number to go with it, and excellent opportunities for meeting people.

title: The Life of Raymond Chandler
description: Raymond Chandler's first mystery novel, The Big Sleep (1939), was an immediate success. So were his next three, Farewell, My Lovely (1940), The High Window (1942) and Lady in the Lake (1943). By the mid1940's his reputation as a mystery story writer was tremendous and he had also become wellknown as a screen writer. His script for Double Indemnity (1943), written in collaboration with Billy Wilder, was nominated for an Academy Award. In the serious literary world his reputation was also very good. Even Edmund Wilson and W. H. Auden admired his work. Eventually Chandler could speculate on his prospects for the Nobel Prize: Do I wish to be a great writer? Do I wish to win the Nobel Prize? Not if it takes too much hard work. What the hell, they give the Nobel Prize to too many second raters for me to get excited about it.

title: CHINA MAY BUILD AN ATOM SMASHER
description: There are indications that China is considering the possibility of building a large, and possibly very large, atom smashing machine.

title: Uneasy Homecoming
description: Both practically and symbolically, Tuesday's primary in Michigan may prove the most significant of the Presidential year thus far for the Republicans. The outcome of the contest between Ronald Reagan and President Ford, in Mr. Ford's home state, is likely to determine whetherdespite the advantages of incumbencyMr. Ford continues to be considered his party's most likely nominee.

title: Carol Hardy Has Nuptials
description: In Memorial Church in Harvard Yard, Cambridge, Mass., Carol Ruth Hardy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Arthur Hardy of Silver Spring,. Md., became the bride yesterday afternoon of Dr. Christopher Glen Fanta, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Fanta of Brooklyn and Ringwood, N. J.

title: The Lottery Rose
description: The writer who takes on a subject like child abuse faces a problemwhether to show the deed in all its headline horror or to soften it for young readers. Irene Hunt in The Lottery Rose has opted not to soften the facts.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Divorced Catholics
description: NOT too many years ago, a number of Roman Catholic men and women faced a seemingly untenable situation. They were totally unhappy in their marriages and wanted out, but they also wanted to remain within their church.

title: Deaths
description: ABBONDANDELOReggie J., on May 14th, 1976, formerly Postmaster of Greenvale, L.I. Post Office, beloved husband of Petricia, deer father of Gary and Les, also survives be two grandchildren brother of MeI and Margarita Heyres. Resosing at the Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc. ??5 Mineola Ave., Roslyn Hts., L.I. mass of Cnristian Burial Monday. Mar 17th. 10 A.M. 5:. Mary's R.C. Church, Bryant Ave., Roslyn Harbor. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. L.I. Visiting hours 24:30 and 79:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contribulions to the Lutheran School for the Deaf, Middle Neck. L.I. or Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Princeton Medics
description: WHEN exam time rolls around at Princeton University, some student reactions are predictable.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MAY 16, 1976

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15  The groundbreaking ceremony was held in front of Dillon Field House today marking the start of Harvard's massive enlargement of athletic facilities, a $30 million program to benefit participant rather than spectator athletes.

title: Tire Supplies Thinning
description: DETROITThe automobile makers are just beginning to feel the pinch of the strike against the four big tire producers which began April 20.But the rubber strike isn't letting the air out of Detroit's big boom yet. Just last week Chrysler Corporation and Ford Motor Company began shipping some  but not all models without spare tires. The General Motors Corporation says it will be shipping vehicles without spares this week. Skipping the spare, which will be delivered later, can stretch the tire inventory by 20 percent.

title: Once and for All
description: Cid Corman's characteristic poem of the last 10 years (roughly the period since he went to live in Japan) has a somewhat Oriental look about it: brief lines, measured by syllabic count, with much interplay of tones and accents, usually turning on a point of acute perception. But don't mistake it for the schmaltz that passes as Orientalism in most American translations and imitations. Corman came from New England originally, he lived in Europe for some years before moving to Japan, and I detect in his work a Yankee toughness and existential lucidity that raise it far above trivia.

title: Engagements
description: CohnGottlieb

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Listening to Uncle Remus

title: Iran Backs Friendship Pact With Iraq
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15The Iranian Government made a fresh gesture of amity toward the Arab nationalist leaders of Iraq by approving an IranianIraqi friendship treaty this week after negotiations had resolved various longstanding issues between the two adjoining oil producing states.

title: Warriors May Need Home Court Today
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15 For the first time in 99 games, the Golden State Warriors face a game they cannot afford to lose when they play the Phoenix Suns in the seventh game of the National Basketball Association's semifinal playoff round tomorrow afternoon.

title: Births
description: Bassin

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, May 15 (UPI)The Indian Government freed a former Cabinet minister and noted opposition leader today who was one of thousands of persons jailed since Prime Min. ister Indira Gandhi proclaimed a national emergency last June 26.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A RECORD CORN CROP of 6 billion to 6.7 billion bushels this year was forecast by the Agriculture Department as against 5.8 billion bushels in 1975. The winter wheat crop is expected to slip 12 percent from the 1975 record, to 1.5 billion bushels... Tota business inventories rose $1.6 billion in March to $269.54 billion, compared with the 1975 low $263.35 billion in July... Auto makers sold 26,438 units In the first 10 days of May, a daily selling rate that was 46.8 percent over the yearearlier period.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE rooms and hallways of Temple BethEl in Cranford have been transformed into boutiques, bazaars and cafes for an Israeli fair that opens today.

title: Romanov, the Party Chief of Leningrad, Viewed as a Man With a Political Future in Soviet Hierarchy
description: LENINGRADThe red flag of revolution, unadorned with hammer or sickle, flies atop Leningrad's Smolny Institute. It was from the butterscotchcolored institute, built in the early 19th century to school young noble women, that Lenin carried out his successful Bolshevik Revolution.

title: What Would F. Scott Think Of Fitzgerald in Hollywood?
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald's infatuation with Hollywood was in many ways like his infatuation with Zelda. He learned a great deal from both of these loves; he wrote well about both, and he injured and was injured by both. Hollywood hurt Fitzgerald by hiring him as a screenwriter and then abusing his talent. But he revenged himself upon Hollywood by giving it a movie called The Great Gatsby, which ruined several studio careers, and now he strikes again by having inspired posthumously a new madeforTV movie entitled F. Scott Fitzgerald in Hollywood, which will be shown this evening at 9 on ABC and which is not likely to do anyone any good either. Fitzgerald and Hollywood never could stay away from each other even though they were no good for each other.

title: U.S BRIDGE TEAM FALLS TO EIGHTH
description: MONTE CARLO. Monaco. May 15The United States bridge team tell further behind the leaders in the World team Olympiad today. The American sextet seems unable to reproduce the form that brought it the Bermuda Bowl Title try world play against Italy last week.

title: Coping With Zoning
description: WHEN is an lite community not an lite community? Apparently when it is East Brunswick, and a Superior Court Judge says, in a landmark housing decision, it is lite and the Mayor, citing a substantial bluecollar population, says it is not.This geographically ragged 23squaremile Middlesex County township is not one that proclaims elegance or affluence to its visitors, as Far Hills or Harding Township might. But Judge David D. Furman has decided that East Brunswick is lite, at least in the sense that its zoning ordinances effectively screen out low and moderateincome families and are thus in violation of the State Constitution.

title: A Rich Heritage Lures Tourists
description: This year, Americans are invited to help celebrate 200 years of FrenchAmerican friendship by participating in an extravaganza of cultural festivals and a whirlwind of exciting tours in France. The inauguration of Concorde supersonic jet flights, the introduction of a 20minute express train service between Charles de Gaulle Airport and Paris and new cross country turbotrain services will all contribute toward making this a special year for tourism in France.

title: A Watcher In the Woods
description: Who is the watcher in the woods? Only Anne Aylwood, the arthritic old woman who sells her house and forest to the Carstairs family, can see its immaterial figure. Jan Carstairs feels the watcher's emotions and her sister Ellie hears its thoughts.

title: Echeverias Are Easier To Grow in the Sun Than Pronounce
description: Few house plants can rival the Mexican echeverias for beauty of leaf color and textures. Rosettes of upturned leaves, many are a soft bluegreen, several spectacular reds and blues. Often they are stemless and form dense, low cushions. Others are tiny, branching shrubs. Their small, bellshaped, flowers hang above the rosettes on long stalks.

title: Paperbacks
description: NICE GUYS FINISH LAST, by Leo Durocher with Ed Linn. (Pocket, $1.95.) The classic saga of the streetwise small guy who learned to use his brainin this case to achieve glory as the manager of the Dodgers and the Giants: an exuberant tale related by a firstrate raconteur.

title: Written in lights
description: Theater people write books for various reasons: profit, vanity, the urge to bring some esthetic or pedagogic message to the world. But most often, I believe, they write to satisfy their own need to relive and, if possible, to preserve in a more durable medium, the crises and triumphs of their exhilarating but ephemeral occupation. Joshua Logan has had more than his share of both: the number of his Broadway hits exceeds that of any living American director except possibly the venerable George Abbott.

title: Uncommon Schools With a Common Problem
description: The following article was written by Gene I. Maeroff and Leonard Buder. THERE is an ironic quality to the financial bloodletting that now threatens to drain the excellence out of many of the Island's embattled publicschool districts. After all, without the promise of that excellence, many of the families comfort. ably settled in Nassau and Suffolk Counties might never have been drawn to their suburban communities in the first place.

title: JUDGES WARNED ON PLEA DEALINGS
description: A warning that Federal judges should stay out of pleabargaining negotiations has been issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the second Circuit.

title: Tractor Rigs Return to Tolls
description: Tirned off by the sharp increase in tolls effective last May at bridges and tunnels of the Port authority of New York and New Jersey, those big tractortrailer rigs are coming back with a roar.

title: The Making of Tests: A Very Inexact Science
description: The statements may be marked true or false: (1) Every year, 200 million standardized achievement tests in mathematics, reading, science and social studies are administered to American schoolchildren. (2) The tests yield an objective measure of learning that helps school officials set educational policy. (3) Test scores are misleading, and the tests themselves are detrimental to many youngsters.

title: Letters
description: Black selfdevelopment

title: The Dance: Odori Festival of Japan
description: From the land of the Honda, the Minolta and the Toyota comes the Odori Festival of Japan a dance company that deals with a folk tradition that the classical groups such as Noh and Kabuki dance theater have not shown us.

title: Notes: Auditions for A HighFlying Cast
description: The two days of auditions had something of the atmosphere of A Chorus Line. The applicants, young and slim, were seeking recognition in an overcrowded profession. The scene was not a bare stage in a darkened theater near Times Square, however, but a carpeted conference suite on the second floor of the New York Hilton. The nearly 1,500 hopefuls who filed into it recently to be briefed, fill out application forms and undergo preliminary interviews were responding to advertisements placed by Trans World Airlines for flight attendants. Among the requirements: minimum age, 20; height, 5 feet 2 inches to 6 feet 2 inches with proportionate weight; high school diploma or equivalent. Our acceptance rate is very low, said Robert E. Randell, manager of T.W.A.'s Inflight Services Personnel Selection. Only about 175 of these applicants will be selected for indepth interviews and 40 or 50 will be offered jobs.

title: Debate on Shifting Genes Nearing a Critical Phase
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 15 Biologists, who have recently discovered the potentially revolutionary technique for creating new forms of life, believe they have acquired such a fundamental power, promising great benefits to society and threatening massive disaster that they face major ethical dilemmas.

title: Jane M. Shanholt Is Betrothed To Orlando Antonio Sacasa
description: Mrs. Sayre McFarlane of Washington and East Hampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jane Meredith Shanholt, to Orlando Antnio Sacasa. He is a son of Nol Sacasa Sevilla, Nicaraguan Ambassador to Argentina, and Mrs. Sacasa of Managua, Nicaragua and Buenos Aires.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY friend Stan, who has a lovely home in Muttontown, is a great believer in analysis. Some time ago, I went with him to a gardening emporium, where he had taken a soil specimen to be analyzed. The other day I visited Stan again when you have as attractive a home as he has you have to look cordial when unsolicited dropins make the sceneand he was drawing a water specimen from his new pool.

title: UNUSUAL WORKS BY PHILOMUSICA
description: The New York Philomusica is a diversely constituted ensemble including such eminent instrumentalists as the violinist Felix Galimir and the flutist Samuel Baron. Its variable sizeas few as three performers or, with guests, as many as 20equips it to concentrate on unconventional chamber music fare. Friday night's Philomusica concert at the Hunter College Playhouse included two works of unusual interest: Earl Kim's Exercises en Route. a New York premiere, and Kurt Weill's rarely heard Frauentanz.

title: Scars of Vietnam War Linger in Coast Suburb
description: AZUSA, Calif.  When a television newscaster began a report the other day marking the first anniversary of the Communist victory in Vietnam, Sally Munoz rose quickly from a chair in her living room and snapped the set off.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONCongress has successfully completed the first stage of its complex new budget control process for this yearthe first year of full operation for the promising new system. The potentially more difficult second stage lies ahead in September, but it is fair to ask now what are the implications of what has been done so far for the nation's fiscal policy and hence for the course of the economy.

title: RETIRING MEXICAN IS NOT SO RETIRING
description: MEXICO CITY, May 15 With just six months left of his administration, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez is emerging as one of Mexico's strongest lameduck presidents.

title: Worried Class of '76
description: THE MUSIC from the Adelphi senior Dinner could be heard throughout the Crest Hollow Country Club. Students danced the hustle, the hump and the walk. They drank cocktails from a roaming bar and selected sweets from a Viennese table.

title: PARKS TO BUSTLE AGAIN IN SUMMER
description: The park grasses may not be as lush this year, and there is little hope that the boardwalks of Coney Island and Rockaway Beach will be spruced up. There will be fewer lifeguards at city pools and the litter will stay untouched on Parks Department land a little longer on those mornings after big events.

title: What's Doing in KANSAS CITY, MISSOURI
description: DISPELLING THE MYTHUntil recently few people have been anxious to acquaint themselves with Kansas City. Mo. After all, why would anyone voluntarily visit a place once called the capital of cowtowns? The exposure that Kansas City will receive during the 1976 Republican National Convention  August 1519  should dispel any myths about its being cornfed and onehorse. Currently embarked on an ambitious $5.3billion revitalization program, it is becoming a bustling place with new entertainment and sports facilities, retail complexes, new restaurants and recreation areas. It is also a town of historical import, having served (1) as a river outpost for trappers, explorers and settlers heading west on the Santa Fe and Oregon Trails. (2) as the birthplace of the influential Kansas City jazz style and (3) as the starting point of Harry Truman's political career.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Fulfilling its Congressional mandate to support Bicentennial activities throughout the country, the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration has inaugurated a wholesale quantity discount sales plan for the official ?? Bicentennial Medal. The more than 12,000 Official Bicentennial Communities in every state have already received or are receiling financial aid from their respective state A.R.B.A. commissions. With this new plan they will be able to generate their own local promotional funds.

title: The Program
description: CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Sir Georg Solti, conductor. Chicago Symphony Chorus Margaret Hillis, director. Norman Bailey, barltone (Dutchman); Janis Martin, soorano (Senta); Marni Talvela, bass (Daland); Rene Kollo, tenor (Eric); Werner Krenn, tenor Steersman); Isola Jones., contralto (Mary). At Carnegie Hall.

title: G. E.'s Campaign Chest
description: Last June 11, Reginald H. Jones, the $520,000ayear chairman of General Electric, sent a letter to the 531 G.E. executives who earn $50,000 a year or more.

title: Parent and Child
description: Every year some 7,500 to 10,000 American families experience the ultimate nightmare of new parents: They put their apparently normal, healthy baby down in the crib or carriage for a nap or a night's sleep. Hours, or perhaps only minutes, later, they find the baby dead. There has been no warning; the baby made no cry.

title: Many Studies, One Inconclusive Answer
description: In 1973, a young woman in Boston was doused with gasoline and set afire by teenagers. The night before, a local television station had featured a movie in which a derelict was murdered in exactly the same way. Coincidence  or inspiration?

title: Groups Accepting Donations for Aid In Italian Quake
description: As relief operations went on in northern Italy for victims of the recent earthquake that killed more than 900 people. American organizations continued to accept donations for the relief effort. Among those oganizations are:

title: The Region
description: In the best of all political accommodations for New York's Governor Carey, Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman who is the subject of a grand jury investigation, would simply step down. But so far Mr. Cunningham has refused to do so. Mr. Carey's response increasingly has been to treat Mr. Cunningham as if he were not there: Last week the Governor assigned two of Mr. Cunningham's most important duties, the handling of patronage and legislative matters to Robert F. Wagner, former New York City Mayor.

title: T. J. Lomperis Weds Miss Turner
description: Ana Mari Turner and Timothy John Lomperis, who received M.A. degrees last year from the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Study, were married yesterday afternoon in Linville, N. C.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: 67:55 A.M., WNYCFM: Choral Festival. Faust, Part III, Schumann; Carmine Burana, Orfi.

title: Recession and the Underdogs at G. M.
description: More evidence of the effect of the recession on women and blacks is beginning to appear. In the automobile industry, General Motors Corporation, with half the business, reports its minority total went to 92,706 on the job in 1975 from 113,121 in 1973. Women dropped to 79,602 from 96,882. While employment dropped generally at the big auto maker, the women and minority workers (black, Oriental, American Indian and Spanish surname) were hit harder. The percentage of minority workers went down to 16.9 percent in 1975 from 17.7 percent in 197.3. while the women dropped from 15.2 percent to 14.5 percent.

title: Sen. Buckley's Vulnerability May Only Be on Paper
description: Governor Carey echoed the Democratic Party line and got a laugh when he offered recently his opinion of Senator James L. Buckley, who is campaigning for reelection this year. I don't know why everybody is mad at Jim Buckley, the Governor said, he hasn't done anything.

title: John Kobacker to Wed Miss Chapin on Aug. 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Barton Chapin Jr. of Westbrook and Phippsburg, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Gansevoort Chapin, to John Shepard Kobacker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kobacker of Toledo, Ohio.

title: New Train to Virginia Is Planned by Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)Amtrak has announced that it will begin passenger train service this summer between New York and Newport News, Va.

title: The Real Star of
description: FORT LEE FELIX THE CAT breezed into New York last month, leaving in his wake exhilarated film critics and a whole new generation of Felix fans.

title: South Africa's Television Bars Film on Nazi Camps
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 16 (AP)  The South African Broadcasting Corporation has decided not to televise an episode of the British television series The World at War showing the extermination of Jews in Nazi death camps.

title: William K. Allison, Official Of L.I. Episcopal Diocese
description: William Kelby Allison, a partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Cullen & Dykman since 1949, died Tuesday at Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived at 170 Wellington Road, Garden City, L. I.

title: Mrs. Bretherton Bride of Herbert Machol
description: Myralee Shiff Bretherton of Syosset, L.I., widow of Norman Bretherton, and Herbert M. Machol of Brookville, L.I., were married yesterday in Marblehead, Mass. Rabbi Robert Shapiro of Temple Emanuel performed the ceremony in his study.

title: Ford Scored on Drug Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI)  Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, contended today that President Ford had weakened an effective program for punishing drug traffickers while calling for a new one. Mr. Vanik, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's Oversight Subcommittee, said financing for a crackdown on drug traffic had been cut drastically under the Ford Administration.

title: 4 Philadelphia Firemen Die Fighting Restaurant Blaze
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (UPI)Four firemen were killed today while fighting a fire in a restaurant in a shopping center on Bustleton Avenue in the city's northeast district.

title: Belmont Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Sunday, May 16. 13th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: A Era Ending for Fisher Hall
description: Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic finished their performance of Mahler's Seventh Symphony at 10:42 on Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall. Fifteen minutes later a crew of 30 stagehands moved into the auditorium and started dismantling the seats. The $5 million acoustic renovation of the hall, which will keep it closed until Oct. 15, had started.

title: A Priest in the Basque Country of Spain Tells of Trying to Understand Violence
description: BILBAO, Spain, May 13Violence justifies counterviolence, the Roman Catholic priest said. Since we live in violence and the violence of the establishment is so great, socalled subversive violence is sometimes the only form of defense.

title: Cresskill Revives an Old Colonial Custom
description: CRESSKILL, May 15Thirtysix acres surrounding Cresskill High School became a Colonial village today as residents, many dressed in the attire of the Revolutionary period, attended a fair sponsored by the Cresskill Bicentennial Committee.

title: Women From 30 States Carry E.R.A. Fight to Land of Lincoln
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16 About 8,000 supporters of the equal rights amendment from 30 statesfrom Maine to Californiaconvened in front of a statue of Abraham Lincoln here today and rallied for passage of a 24wordlong addition to the United States Constitution that one speaker called part of the second American revolution.

title: Aeros Advance To W.H.A. Finals
description: HOUSTON, May 16 (AP)The Houston Aeros overcame the acrobatic goaltending of Cap Raeder tonight and beat the New England Whalers, 20, advancing to the World Hockey Association World Cup finals.

title: 14 Cars Qualify for Indy 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16Fourteen cars were added today to the field for the 60th running of the Indianapolis 500 on May 30.

title: Warren Chiasson Leads Jazz Trio With Chuck Wayne
description: Because the emphasis in most contemporary jazz groups is directed toward solo performances, ensemble style tends to be minimized. So it is refreshing to find that the trio led by Warren Chiasson at Gregory's, 63d Street at First Avenue, bases its performances on a distinctive blend of Mr. Chiasson's vibraharp and Chuck Wayne's electric guitar, backed by Wilber Little's bass.

title: Hockey TV Delay Stirs Fans' Ire
description: Several hundred hockey fans in the metropolitan area telephoned complaints to WORTV (Channel 9) last night when the telecast of the Stanley Cup hockey game between the Philadelphia Flyers and the Montreal Canadiens was not shown at 7 P.M., as scheduled.

title: MILITARY FLOUTED CIVILIANS' RIGHTS, SENATE UNIT SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 Military intelligence agents have violated the rights of United States citizens in the agents' investigations of domestic political and protest groups, and in the process have threatened to violate the traditional and legal restraints which govern the use of military forces in the civilian community, the staff of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has concluded.

title: Bill Opposes Bottle Ban
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) Representative John Flynt Jr., Democrat of Georgia, said today that would seek legislation to prevent the Environment Protection Agency from banning the sale of beverages in throwaway bottles on Federal installations.

title: Eastern Regatta
description: HEAVYWEIGHT

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: EAST Tonight at 8 o'clock members of the Miyagikai one of the most famous koto schools of Japan, will perform on the traditional harplike instruments at Japan House, 333 East 4th Street (between First and Second Avenues). Admission is $3.

title: Bride:
description: MONTE CARLO. Monaco, May 16  The United States made no gain in play at the World Team Olympiad here today, but Sweden overtook Britain at the head of the standings. The Americans won two matches narrowly, 146 against Jamaica and 128 against Australia, but then suffered an unexpected disaster, losing 020 to South Africa.

title: Evasion in Albany . . .
description: As the State Legislature rushes toward hopedfor adjournment at the end of this month, there are growing signs that the lawmakersand the Carey Administration are determined to sidestep two of the most critical issues facing the current session, issues that vitally affect the future of New York City and communities throughout the state, both of which were referred to the Senate Banking Committee's report released yesterday. They are public employee pensions and rent control.

title: HONDURAS SETS UP FORESTRY PROJECT
description: CANCUN, Mexico, May 16A Latin American multinational project to invest $400 million for development of huge, untapped forestry resources in Honduras was set up here today by the InterAmerican Development Bank, the Venezuelan Investment Fund, and the Government of Honduras.

title: Hungary Finishes Sweep
description: BUDAPEST, May 16 (Reuters)Hungary completed a 50 sweep of Egypt today in a European Zone A Davis Cup quarterfinal.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Jersey Briefs
description: State Senator Matthew Feldman, the Senate President, is scheduled to appear tomorrow before a Federal grand jury in Newark investigating charges that his wholesale liquor dealership paid bribes to an East Coast restaurant chain. The Bergen County Democrat said that he was not aware of the nature of the investigation. The Securities mid Exchange Commission charged in a complaint filed last week that a salesman for Mr. Feldman's concern had paid $6,400 in kickbacks to Emersons Ltd., a restaurant chain, in 1974 and 1975 to influence liquor producers.

title: Playoff Results
description: N.B.A. Playoffs

title: Bicentennial Visitor From France
description: Two centuries ago, Adm. Count Charles d'Estaing sailed to America at the head of the first French expedition backing the rebellious American colonists against their British sovereign.

title: Women From 30 States Carry E.R.A. Fight to Land of Lincoln
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16 About 8,000 supporters of the equal rights amendment from 30 statesfrom Maine to Californiaconvened in front of a statue of Abraham Lincoln here today and rallied for passage of a 24wordlong addition to the United States Constitution that one speaker called part of the second American revolution.

title: Harvard Varsity Crew Wins Eastern Sprint Title
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 We just breezed right by them, said Bruce Larson, the coxswain of the Harvard varsity heavyweight crew today in describing the key moment of the Eastern sprint regatta on Lake Carnegie. The Crimson boat passed Wisconsin at 1,200 meters of the 2,000meter course (1.4 miles) and won its championship by a boat length from the Badgers.

title: Catholics and Jews Mark a Happy Decade
description: How good life is, for those who live together like brothers expressed the sentiments of the more than 200 people who gathered under the mosaic dome of Holy Family Roman Catholic Church on Flatlands Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday, to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the founding of the CatholicJewish Relations Committee.

title: Panama Canal Stirs Questions As Trade It Handles Declines
description: Charges by Ronald Reagan that the Ford Administration is negotiating a giveaway of the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone have raised questions as to the waterway's importance in terms of world trade.

title: Urban League Pays Bicentennial Tribute To Black Americans
description: The National Urban League, as a part of its participation in the Bicentennial, will this month distribute to political leaders, schools, colleges and churches 4,500 copies of an eightpound, 1,206page reference book The Black American.

title: In Memoriam
description: NAVARETTAJohn A. (Custom Tailor, 129 E. 56 St.) Died May 20, 1975, A ceibrated mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral Our Lady Chapel) Thurs., May 20, 10:30 A.M., to celebrated his first anniversary In heaven. Wife, Josephine; children, John Jr., Robert, Donna Marie, Stephen and Vincent.

title: Miss Roberts Triumphs
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 16 (UPI)Sue Roberts, in her first victory in more than a year, shot a twounder par 70 today to win the $45,000 American Defender Classic, a Ladies Professional. Golf Association tournament.

title: Beirut Suffers Heavy Toll In New Surge of Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, May 17  The Lebanese capital and its suburbs went through one of the most violent days of the 13month civil war yesterday.

description: Morning

description: EDEN by Steve Carter. Directed by Edmund Cambridge; setting by Pamela S. Peniston; costumes by Edna Watson; lighting by Sandra L. Ross. Presented by the Negro Company. Douglas Turner Ward, artistic director. At the Theater De Lys, 121 Christopher Street.

title: WEST BANK GIRL KILLED BY ISRAELI
description: TEL AVIV, May 16An Israeli soldier shot and killed a teenage Arab girl on the staircase of an apartment house in occupied Nablus this morning. Later two of her friends, demonstrating outside the victim's house, were injured when Israeli forces fired to disperse the crowd.

title: One Killed in Kobe Riot
description: KOBE, Japan, May 16 (Reuters)A news photographer was trampled to death and 25 policemen and another person were injured last niiht when a mob rioted in this western Japanese port, the police said today. The riot began in one of the city's main streets shortly after a cornival procession passed.

title: Tally on Soviet Emigration Shows Drop of 3,600 in '75
description: GENEVA, May 16 (Reuters)  About 3,600 fewer people were allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union last year than in 1974, according to the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration.

title: BEAME IS DEFIED ON SEXFILM HOUSE
description: The New York City Buildings Department, disregarding instructions from the Mayor's office, has issued a permit allowing the owners of Broadway's de Mille Theater to convert It into three small theaters that, according to city officials, will show pornographic films.

title: Trucks on Way for Fisher Organ
description: Late last week three 40foot trailertrucks loaded with prunes and raisins left Southern California headed for the East Coast. This week they will return, carrying the large Aeolian Skinner pipe organ that the Community Church of Garden Grove, Calif., has purchased from Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Recent Criticism of Israel Worrying Jewish Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 Criticism of Israel by Jews and nonJews is causing considerable uneasiness among many; Jewish leaders in this country.

title: Mike Glick Sings Folk With Suni Paz And Band at Kitchen
description: I Mike Glick, who shared a (concert with the Chilean singer and songwriter Suni Paz at the Kitchen on Saturday, has sidestepped the authenticity problems of the typical citybred, protestoriented folksinger. For the most part he avoids rural folk idioms, preferring to couch his original songs in the musical languages of the ghetto and the underdeveloped world.

title: Opera: Verdi Tradition
description: Vincent LaSelva is no doubt to be congratulated for organizing for his New York Grand Opera a miniseason at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and for continuing his attentions to Verdi with what are being billed as the first American stage performances of Giovanna d'Arco, the American premiere of Stiffelio and the Requiem.

title: Americans Cool to the French, But It's a Feeling That's Mutual
description: PARIS, May 16Frenchmen and Americans think of each other with distinct coolness, suspicion and above all indifference, it was disclosed here today on the eve of President Val6ry Giscard d'Estaing's flight to Washington aboard the Concorde.

title: Book of The Times
description: Being of a generation too young to have been swamped by the tidal wave of violet and vitriol that is said to have surged from Alexander Woollcott from the 1920's through the 1940's, I have never understood what all the fuss was about. He was, of course, New York City's most influential drama critic when daily theater journalism was still a competitive field. He was the founding father of the Algonquin Round Table of witticism valid wisecracks; radio's first oneman show; the model for the Kaufman and Hart character Sheridan Whiteside in The Man Who Came to Dinner and a charismatic person known, loved and f cuded with by other charismatic people. Yet few words of his wit or wisdom have come down to us from him no lasting observations on the theater; no essays to be read and savored. And in the best of the biographies of the period (say, Thurber's The Years With Ross. Brendan Gill's Here at the New Yorker and Lillian Hellman's Pentimento) he remains undefined in the background, a cantankerous blob.

title: SENATORS BID U.S. WEICH END OF AID TO NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 The Senate Banking Committee unanimously urged the Federal Government today to seriously consider ending its $2.3 billion in annual, seasonal loans if New York City failed to maintaro its threeyear wage freeze.

title: U.S. Says Iran Must Share Atomic Fuel Plant Control
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 In. what officials say is a stiffening of policy, the United States has told Iran that it must share with at least one industrial country control over any nuclear fuel reprocessing plant built in Iran.

description: Since it used to be saidand may have been truethat baseball was America's national pastime, and since William Schuman did, early in the 1950's, compose a baseball opera called The Mighty Casey, it was almost inevitable that the work would be revived for the Bicentennial. It was, at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night.

title: An AntiBusing Brief?
description: Solicitor General Robert Bork is reportedly urging the Justice Department to file a friend of the court brief asking the Supreme Court: (1) to overturn the Federal District Court's order in the Boston school desegregation case; and (2) to reconsider its ruling in the 1971 North Carolina case approving transportation (busing) as a remedy for unconstitutional discrimination against black schoolchildren. The recommendation is reckless, foolish and destructive.

title: Stoyan Pribichevich Dies at 71; Reporter and a Fortune Editor
description: Stoyan Pribichevich, a former associate editor of Fortune magazine and foreign cor?? spondent for Time and Life during World War II, died Satterday of cancer at St. Barns??as Hospital in the Bronx. He was 71 years old and lived at 233 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

description: Wendy S. Wolk daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene U. Wolk of Orange, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Harvey James Berger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Berger of New York. Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg performed the ceremony at Temple Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn.

title: U.S TO END SOME OF PAYMENTS DATA

title: KISSINGER WANTS TO GIVE UP OFFICE EVEN IF FORD WINS
description: WASHINGTON, May 16Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who for eight years has been the main architect of American foreign policy, said in an interview released today that even if President Ford won the November election, he would prefer to leave office.

title: No Comment by Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15No comment was immediately forthcoming from the Iranian Government about a report from Washington that the United States had told Iran it must share control over any nuclear fuel reprocessing plant set up in this country.

description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI)About 200 to 300 persons, including Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and other Cabinet officers, were on hand at Andrews Air Force Base for Mr. Ford's return home tonight. They applauded as he left Air Force 1 for an automobile ride to a Virginia suburb for a fundraising party.

title: Stage: Black Militancy
description: Black racism and the stirrings of black militancy are the undercurrent to Eden, an interesting new play by Steve Carter, which the Negro Ensemble Company brought to Off Broadway at the Theater de Lys last night.

title: Agreement Reached in Farmingdale Teachers' Strike
description: Tentative agreement on a new twoyear contract was announced early this morning by the Farmingdale, L.I., School Board and the striking Federalion of Teachers.

title: Simon Says He'll Ask U.S. Not to Cut Aid to Chile
description: CANCUN, Mexico, May 16Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today that he would ask Congress to maintain economic aid to Chile, without further cuts, on the basis of assurances from the head of the ruling junta there that humanrights conditions would be improved.

title: An Era Ending for Fisher Hall
description: Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic finished their performance of Mahler's Seventh Symphony at 10:42 on Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall. Fifteen minutes later a crew of 30 stagehands moved into the auditorium and started dismantling the seats. The $5 million acoustic renovation of the hall, which will keep it closed until Oct. 15, had started.

title: French Socialist Leaders Agree to Cooperate With Communists.
description: DIJON, France, May 16 The Socialist Party, hailing itself as the first party of France, confirmed its willingness today to continue to cooperate with the Communist Party in order to gain eventual, control of the Government.

title: ULSTER TOLL RISES TO 11 OVER WEEKEND
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Monday, May 17 (AP)Two killings at midnight last night bloody the casualty toll in a bloody weekend of bombing and shooting in Northern Ireland to 11 dead and at least 55 wounded. The dead included four policemen and a police reservist.

title: Carey's Style Shown in Wagner Choice
description: Governor Carey's nudging aside of Patrick J. Cunningham as Democratic state chairman last week to make room for Robert F. Wagner at the top of the party hierarchy provided New York an interesting study of how the Political Governor operNotes ates behind the scenes and why, some politicians contend, the Governor often has problems in communicating with other politicians.

title: Magical Sequel to 'That's Entertainment'
description: From the opening creditsSaul Bass's witty montage of various fashions in movie creditsuntil the closing reprise of the "That's Entertainment" production number from "The Band Wagon," "That's Entertainment, Part 2" is 997/10 percent pure magic. The three-tenths that aren't so great are the connectives between the film's individual sequences, which are drawn from 72 M-G-M features (dramas and comedies as well as musicals) and from the studio's short Subjects, representing the M-G-M output from 1929 through 1962.Even if you share my feeling that there is something morally wrong about ransacking old movies to make such anthologies, the objections become academic in the presence of the salutes to the good old days of Metro"That's Entertainment," released in 1974, and "That's Entertainment, Part 2," which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld.If one seriously cares about films (I tell myself piously), one should be wiling to work at them, to sit through all of the films represented here and not rely on excerpts made by someone else. But the 72 features in "Part 2" would require approximately 6 days of steady viewing with no time out even to go to the refrigerator. If astronauts were provided with In-Flight entertainment, they might be able to survive the lot, but the rest of us, even movie critics, aren't properly trained and equipped.Also, though it may be morally wrong to take movie scenes out of context, most of the films in "That's Entertainment, Part 2" would have a tough time qualifying as moral statements of an order in need of our protection. The greater part of the material comes from musicals and, with the exceptions of "Singin' in the Rain," "The Band Wagon," "Meet Me in St. Louis" and a couple of others, none of the musicals is so great that we can't afford to miss the stuff used to bridge the gap between the production numbers.The straight comedies and dramas are something else. Watching several sequences from "Adam's Rib" and "Pat and Mike," those splendid collaborations of Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon (the writers), and George Cukor (the director) with Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn, one aches to see the entire films, though the individual scenes hold up beautifully. Mr. Tracy may never have had a finer moment than the one in "Pat and Mike" when he admires Miss Hepburn with the statement, "Not much meat on her, but what's there is cherce."Such films are too good to be cut up. So is "A Night at the Opera," from which "Part 2" purloins the classic state-room scene.Mostly, however, "Part 2" has been compiled with the kind of intelligence and affection that allow us to get some purchase on the Hollywood history made by M-G-M without spending our whole lives at the job. Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald are not everyone's idea of stars-of-the-ages, but the "Lover Come Back" number from "New Moon" is as much Hollywood operetta as can be stood by those of us not on the gloriously lunatic fringe with the other Eddy-MacDonald buffs.Other highlights include the great Judy Garland-Gene Kelly "Be a Clown" number from "The Pirate"; Fred Astaire and Cyd Charisse doing Cole Porter's "All of You" from "Silk Stockings" (which just about convinces me she was his best partner); two magnificently manic, almost surreal Busby Berkeley numbers (the finales of "Girl Crazy" and "Easy to Love," shot at Cypress Gardens); a surprisingly little-girlish Lena Horne singing "The Lady Is a Tramp"; a montage of sequences from films about composers composing, climaxed by a virtually classic bit of Hollywood nonsense from "The Great Waltz"; Gene Kelly's fine roller-skating number from "It's Always Fair Weather"; a montage of Frank Sinatra sequences, highlighted by another great Cole Porter number, "You're Sensational," sung to Grace Kelly in "High Society."The film is so studded with highlights that I suppose we should be grateful for the ordinary contemporary footage that is used to connect the old material. It gives us time to breathe. This new footage features Mr. Astaire; 76 when it was made, and Mr. Kelly, 63, as television-style hosts. They also sing a little, dance a little and kid a little. They are still vital talents, but they should sue the make-up men who have attempted to erase the years of their careers under layers of paint and borrowed hair.

title: SANFORD STANTON, NEWSPAPERMAN, 92
description: Sanford E. Stanton, political writer for the old New York American and The New York JournalAmerican from the 1930's through the 1960's, died yesterday at the Eden Park Nursing Home in Albany, where he had lived for the last six years. He was 92 years old.

title: U.S. Banks Close Some of Their Branches in Europe
description: LONDON, May 16  A decade ago several of the biggest United States banks opened scores of branches at prestigious addresses around Europe to lure retail customers. But now they have closed some of the branches and are discouraging retail business at many of the others.

title: Illinois Rejects OTB Proposal
description: CHICAGO, May 16 (UPI)The Illinois Racing Board has rejected a proposal to have Illinois races included in New York's offtrack betting system.

title: Rockwell's World of Scouting Still Exists
description: The Cub Scouts and Boy Scouts stood in front of the Norman Rockwell paintings  modern boys with their hair sweeping down to their Scout neckerchiefs; boys who do ecology projects, boys who can't possibly remember how Norman Rockwell creations were on the cover of The Saturday Evening Post 318 times, shaping the selfimage of a nation.

title: Canadiens Win Cup
description: The Montreal Canadiens won the Stanley Cup in hockey by beating the Philadelphia Flyers, 53, for a fourgame sweep. In the National Basketball Association playoffs, the Phoenix Suns gained the final round by defeating the Golden State Warriors in the seventh game, 9486. Page 35.

title: Ford Finds It Hard, Even in Own State, To Convey Vision That Inspires Voters

title: Shells Stir Turmoil at Beirut Airport
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16 Middle East Airlines Flight 252 from Athens was the last plane into Beirut today.

title: Bond Analysts Expect Rates to Rise Further
description: The springtime slump in the credit markets moved through its fourth consecutive week last week, and there still appeared little reason for it to end. With the Federal Reserve encouraging higher shortterm interest rates, with signs of business loan demand at last beginning to strengthen and with a heavy. (volume of new corporate and taxexempt bonds for sale this, week, the credit markets generally assume that interest rates will keep rising this week.

title: Investigation Pressed in Slaying Of a Jersey Lawyer's Wife, 42
description: Detectives continued their investigation yesterday into the murder of Beverly Manol., the wife of a prominent Springfield, N.J., lawyer, who was stabbed and bludgeoned to death in her home Friday morning.

title: WEST BASK GIRL KILLED BY ISRAELI
description: TEL AVIV, May 16An Israeli soldier shot and killed a teenage Arab girl on the staircase of an apartment house in occupied Nablus this morning. Later two of her friends, demonstrating outside the victim's house, were injured when Israeli forces fired to disperse the crowd.

title: Memorial Services
description: LOSCHTiIIy. A memorial service for Tilly Losch, who died Christmas Eve., 1975, will bo held in the Lady Chattel of St. Patrick's Cathedral at 4:30 P.M. Tuesday, May 18.

title: ALBANY BILLS DUE ON UTILITY CURBS
description: ALBANY, May 16Evidently with one eye on the voters and the other on the issues, the Legislature's Democratic leadership has drawn up a list of 18 bills that would close loopholes in utilities' spending, reduce electricity costs for most homeowners and increase public involvement in the utilities regulation process.

title: Celtics Win, 9994; Lead Cays by 32
description: BOSTON, May 16  Red Auerbach unofficially and dramatically returned to coaching the Boston Celtics today.

title: Cincinnati Editor Named
description: CINCINNATI, May 16 (UPI)James E. Schottelkotte, sports editor of The Cincinnati Enquirer, has been named managing editor of the paper, William J. Keating, president and editor, announced yesterday.

title: Suns Oust Warriors, 9486, Gaining N.B.A. Playoff Final
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 16 Another incipient sports dynasty came crashing down in less than a year today as the Golden State Warriors were eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs by the Phoenix Suns, who won the seventh and deciding game of their semifinal series, 9486.

title: Dr. Shlomo Bardin, 77, Dies; Founded Brandeis Institute
description: Dr. Shlomo H. Bardin, founderdirector of what is now the Brandeis Institute, a center for training collegeage Jews in the traditions of Judaism, died yesterday at Westlake Hospital in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 77 years old and lived at the institute in Brandeis. Calif.

title: MAURICE F. WILLIAMS
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 16Maurice F. Williams, retired State Commissioner of Finance and Administration, and an administrative assistant to five Maine Governors, died yesterday in Augusta General Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Bucknell President Named
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 16 (AP)George O'Brien, 45 years old, the dean of faculty and professor of philosophy at Middlebury College, was named president yesterday of Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa. He will take over the office in July, succeeding Charles Watts who resigned in December after 12 years as Bucknell president.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In a recent column, we spoke with some rapture of the Reuben sandwich, that grilled, multiflavored modern classic made with dark bread, corned beef, sauerkraut and cheese. We stated wistfully we would be pleased to learn the origin of the dish.

title: Building Services Union Meets Today With Realty Board and State Mediator
description: The building services union and the Realty Advisory Board will meet with a state mediator today for their first joint session since the landlords rejected a factfinding panel's recommendations last week for ending the apartment house strike.

title: Nice and Quiet and Relaxed
description: The plane dipped out of the fog and it seemed to be skimming the rooftops of Flushing. It had waited on the ground at Friendship Airport and circled in the soup over Jersey, but now in a matter of seconds it touched clown at La Guardia. We made it that time, said Laz Barrera. It's more important than winning the Preakness. Nothing in the demeanor of Bold Forbes's trainer could have told a stranger whether the Kentucky Derby winner had won the Preakness or lost it. Behar Barrera wins a lot of rares and loses a lot and remains the same warm, cooperative, articulate gentleman willing to keep on answering the same questions even when nothing remains to be said. I don't got nothing left in my brains, he had confessed on Saturday.

title: Beth E. Wladis, a Librarian, Bride
description: Beth Elaine Wladis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Wladis of Elmira, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Richard Himmelstein, son of Mrs. Leonard Weinroth of New York and the late Dr. Aaron Himrnelstein.
