Everything they played in their return concert in the same hall on Monday night confirmed this opinion. Each artist seemed to know down to the smallest rhythmic detail what the other was going to do. They matched each other in style, intensity and rhythmic energy.

First he played with the Byrds, who more or less invented the folkrock of the mid60's. Then came the Flying Burrito Brothers, Manassas and, more recently, Souther, Hillman and Furay.

These proceedings are confidential, Mr. Feldman said. I'm finished [testifying] until hear from the United States Attorney's office.

title: The Screen: 'Loose Ends' Unravels Regional Life
description: Billy (Chris Mulkey) sometimes acts as if he were 14, though he's in his early 20's. Divorced from a wife he never loved, he lives in a one-room apartment, sleeps on a convertible couch, plays the radio too loud and keeps a couple of cats. He seems surprised when he calls a girl for a date at 1 o'clock in the morning and she asks him if he knows what time it is. He does but he's at loose ends.So is Eddie (John Jenkins), a mechanic who works with Billy at a local garage. Eddie is married, more or less happily, to Jen (Linda Jenkins). They have one child and another on the way. Jen wants to move to the suburbs. Eddie doesn't. Jen wants a dog. Eddie doesn't. They regularly have furious fights, after which Eddie stalks out and joins Billy at a bar called The Club. They play pool and pinball and drink beer. Life for Billy and Eddie is a series of six-packs.Unlike "Goin' Down the Road," a 1970 Canadian film that ultimately patronized the aimless lives of its two blue-collar friends, "Loose Ends" rides along with Billy and Eddie, seeing just about what they see when they see it without imposing on them heavy sociological significance. The filmmakers, let Billy and Eddie speak for themselves, and that's mostly about cars. Says Billy of a woman he's met, "She has this Caprice that's loaded with options," which is what they don't have."Loose Ends," which opened a week's run at the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday, is a remarkably good, level-headed movie about friendship and marriage and the limitations of each when, like Billy and Eddie, the people have never had to develop the means of conceptualizing experience. Neither Billy nor Eddie is dumb. Each is like an under-developed country whose highest aim is to become a consumer society. There are plenty of middle-class people with the same dimly realized ambitions."Loose Ends" was made on a shoestring in Minneapolis by David Burton Morris and Victoria Wozniak, who wrote, directed and produced the film. They are, I'm told, in their 20's, which is amazing in light of the exceptional discipline in avoiding both overstatement and an easy recourse to jazzy photographic and music techniques.The performances also are extraordinarily good, especially that of Chris Mulkey as the more loose of the two friends, a guy speeding through life with a transistor radio turned on full and two cats asleep in the back seat. When Billy gets wherever he's going, he won't even recognize it."Loose Ends" is the most interesting regional American film I've seen in years.

Hoffman, the State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, assailed today what he called the systematic bribery of foreign officials by United States corporations and urged that penalties for such conduct include fines, imprisonment and temorary disqualification from bidding on Federal contracts.

title: Latin Nations Seek More Bank Assistance
description: CANCUN. Mexico, May 18Latin America's heavy load of foreign private debt, which some financial observers regard as dangerously high, is the re suit of a drastic cutback in official foreign aid to the region, according to the president of the InterAmerican Development Bank.

title: HOUSING STARTS DROPPED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Housing starts dipped in April for the second consecutive month as homebuilding continued as a fairly sluggish element in the overall economic expansion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: VORSTER IS EAGER FOR FORD SESSION
description: CAPE TOWN, May 18Prime Minister John Vorster responded eagerly today to the idea that he might meet with President Ford at some point to discuss the tense situations in southern Africa.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it had filed counterclaims against the Polaroid Corporation alleging that Polaroid's patents on instant film and cameras were invalid. The suit denied infringement of the Polaroid patents.

title: Members of Navajo Tribe Hold Protest on Alleged Fund Misuse
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., May 18  More than 600 persons from all over the 25,000squaremile Navajo Indian reservation gathered peacefully here in the tribal capital today to protest Alleged corruption in the tribal government.

title: Longtime Appeals Judge Loses To Newcomer in. Alabama Vote
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 18 The vulnerability of elected state judges was demonstrated recently when a virtually unknown assistant state attorney general defeated a veteran Appellate Court judge who was accused during the campaign of dealing too leniently with criminals.

title: NASA Fund Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) The Senate has approved a compromise bill authorizing nearly $3.7 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administrationincluding $2.2 Million to build a facility to store the moon rocksfor the fiscal year beginningOct. 1.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Simon Ties Loans To Salary Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that the Federal Government would end its $2.3 billion in annual, seasonal loans to New York City if the city failed to maintain its threeyear wage freeze.

title: William Martin Hill, 71, Dies; League of Nations, U.N. Aide
description: William Martin Hill, a British subject who held high posts in the Secretariat of both the League of Nations and the United Nations, died yesterday in Princeton (N. J.) Hospital of a stroke. He was 71 years old and lived at 260 Snowden Lane, Princeton.

title: Box Scores and Standings
description: Wednesday, May 19, 1976

title: Albany Senate Minority Leader Makes Much Out of Almost Nothing
description: ALBANY, May 8Anyone who wants to be minority leader of the New York State Senate has to be prepared to make something out of almost nothing.

title: Georgia Balloonist Killed
description: TOCCOA, Ga., May 18 (AP)A hotair balloonist was killed today when his balloon crashed into a power line, the authorities said. Peter Hodkinson 3d, of Clarkesville, and a passenger were thrown more than 30 feet 1 to the ground when the balloon hit the line, the Stephens County sheriff's office said. The passenger, Hugh Raney of Stone Mountain, was admitted at a hospital with several fractured ribs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Eritrean Rebels Stall Northward March by Thousands of Ethiopian Peasants
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 18Guerrillas fighting for the independence of the northern province of Eritrea have stalled an army of peasant volunteers that has been seat to oppose them, according to reports reaching Addis Ababa today.

title: The Runner Stumbles Marked by Fine Acting
description: Milan Stitt's The Runner Stumbles is, simultaneously, a love story about an impossible love, a psychological mystery and a reflective study of the strictures of religion. The new drama, which opened last night at the Little Theater, offers some sobering judgments on the relationships of men and women whose lives are devoted to God.

title: Campaign Just Beginning,
description: BALTIMORE, May 18Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of Cali; fornia, winner of the Maryland Democratic Presidential preference primary, told a crowd of jubilant supporters here tonight, This campaign is just beginning.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Army Uses Teaching Machine To Improve Soldiers
description: The Army reports significant Improvements in individual training as a result of the extended use of a training aid known as the Training Extension Course, or TEC.

title: PROBATION GIVEN IN MEDICAID CASE
description: Eugene Hollander, the nursing home operator, was sentenced yesterday to five years probation for Medicaid fraud on condition that he pay New York State $1 million in restitution and $250,000 in fines within six months and that he remain outside the nursing home field or any related activity.

title: A Satisfied $25 Winner To Get at Least $10,000
description: TRENTON, May 18When Herbert Fannell of Brooklyn cashed in his winning New Jersey lottery ticket May 3, he did not know just how lucky he was.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 18 (AP)Flying a Learjet in his roundtheworld trip, Arnold Palmer arrived today from Paris. He gave 16yearold Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi United States Bicentennial flag and a bronze reproduction of the Declaration of Independence. The golfer did the second leg of his attempt at a world record in 51/2 hours, which was on time. Because of headwinds over the Atlantic, he said, he had to land in Wales for refueling before going on to Paris. He took off here for Colombo, Sri Lanka, his next stop.

title: Food Prices In Slight Dip
description: The cost of feeding a fam ily of four in New York City dropped again last week, though the decrease for last week was less than in previous weeks. A 38item market basket dropped from $70.62 for the week ending May 7, to $70.49 for the week ending last Friday, a 0.2 percent decrease.

title: Train Kills Deaf Man
description: ATLANTA, May 18 (AP)A! deaf man who stopped at a railroad crossing while a northbound train passed by was struck and killed by a southbound train today when he attempted to cross the tracks, the police said. Bobby Quisenberry, 27 years old, was not able to hear the train's whistle when he crossed the tracks near Fort McPherson in Southwest Atlanta.

title: A New Era Dawning?; Transit Pact Offers Goad for Efficiency, But Whether It Sets Pattern Is Unclear
description: The end of the suspense over the transit contract may be the beginning of a new era of publicemployee labor relations in New York City. Raises for public workers will be tied to productivity. There will be incentive News for municipal efAnalysis ficiency. The publicthrough the Emergency Financial Control Boardintends to guard the city treasury. And beneath it all, in a low rumble, are fears for the future of free collective bargaining.

title: Foes of Projected Nuclear Utility Pressinterior Agency to File Suit to Protect the Indiana Dunes
description: CHICAGO, May 18 A numbe of politicians, environmentet groups and public interest organizations here are putting pressure on the United States Department of the Interior to: take legal action to protect thel delicate ecology of the Indiana dunes on Lake Michigan, an unusual combination of tufted sand hills and fecund marshes and bogs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: May 19, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee meets at 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee for Program and Coordination10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Children's Fund  10:30 A.M.

title: Probation for Hollander Tied to $1 Million Refund
description: Eugene Hollander, the nursing home operator, was sentenced yesterday to five years probation for Medicaid fraud on condition that he pay New York State $1 million in restitution and $250,000 in fines within six months and that he remain outside the nursing home field or any related activity.

title: GWEN DAVIES
description: Gwen Davies, a retired children's art teacher at the Dalton, School, 108 East 89th Street,! died Monday. She was 86 years; old and lived in Woodstock, N. Y.

title: FORD STEEL PLAN BARRED BY E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, May 18The European Economic Community announced today that it had rejected President Ford's demand to negotiate an orderly marketing agreement to limit its exports of specialty steels to the United States.

title: About Education
description: A Westchester County school district that has been partly run without principals for one year is formally proposing the elimination of that traditional position and the transfer of its duties to teachers, called leaders, who function in teams.

title: Typhoon Triggers Mudslide Killing 9 on Pacific Island
description: AGANA, Guam, May 18 (UPI)  Tropical typhoons today touched off a mudslide in the eastern Caroline islands and whipped the east coast of the Philippines.

title: Books of The Times
description: There's a reason why New York hasn't been host to a national political convention in over half a century. In i924, thanks largely to a bid of $255,000 from the city, the Democratic Party reluctantly agreed to return to what was widely regarded as cold and unfriendly place to hold its first convention there since 1868, when Horatio

title: Germans Hope Troubles of Neighbors Aren't Contagious
description: BONNIn a time of uncertainty and increasing Communist strength hi the Latin countries of Europe, West Germany sa an island of relative social, economic and political stability.

title: India Says It Is Holding 7,000 In Clandestine Publishing Cases
description: NEW DELHI, May 18 Seven thousand people have been arrested in a drive to halt the flow of objectionable literature attacking the Indian Government, according to an official statement issued last night.

title: U.S. THINKS MEXICO WILL NOT JOIN OPEC
description: CANCUN, Mexico, May 18Mexico has no apparent intention of joining the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries even though its oil exports may exceed one million barrels a day by 1980, the Assistant United States Secretary of the Treasury, Gerald L. Parsky, Laid here today.

title: CHARLES D. TIDERMANN
description: Charles D. Tiedemann, technical director for forestprodloot loans for the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Monday. He was 51 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: 3 Key Democrats Stress Jobs In Platform Committee Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Three of the heaviest hitters in the Democratic political lineup Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Huberf H. Humphrey and Representative Thomas P. Jr.went before the party's Platform Committee today with the same basic message.

description: I think of leaky atomic reactors and windchill factors the collapsing Era Gandhi Indira and world peace no nearer. Kuwait New York's bond rate the Hudson's pollution no Middle East solution. There's worldwide inflation Princess Margaret's separation topped by. Wilson's resignation Kissinger's indignation no arms limitation fluoridation. There's swine flu the drought's not through oppression in Chile Humphrey, will he? I read about the Brazilian bee student apathy anomie the C.I.A. conspiracy the end of NATO the P.L.O. Castro Wayne Hays laser rays the militaryspending mania canine schizophrenia revenue sharing, should we? the Bomb, would we? Rhodesia, how could we? I fear for the Lockheed loan and the Canal Zone the San Andreas fault disagreement at SALT Patty Hearst's mistake Bo Callaway's take. Is Carter's smile a fake? And what, for heaven's sake

title: NBC and Union Agree on Pact To End Strike Begun on April
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The National Broadcasting Company and a union representing 1,700 newswriters, en, gineers and technicians reached agreement today on a fouryear contract that provided for pay increases of about 33 percent.

title: Met to Open Series In Parks on June 19 At Yankee Stadium
description: The Metropolitan Opera, also known as the New York Met, will play at Yankee Stadium on Saturday June 19. The company will perform Puccini's Madama Butterfly with Anna Moffo in the title part as a feature of the Met's twoweek series of eight free outdoor concerts.

title: Orantes and Dibbs Advance in Tennis
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 18 (AP)Topseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain and secondseeded Eddie Dibbs of the United States easily advanced in the second round of the $100,000 German tennis tournament today. Seven Americans were knocked out in the Grand Prix event.

title: H. K. PORTER LIFTS BID FOR FANSTEEL
description: The H. K. Porter Company raised its hid yesterday to purchase all shares of the commor stock of Fansteel Inc. to $23.50 a share and Lear Siegler Inc. withdrew its offer for Fansteel. The new Porter bid for the 1563.934 shares of Fansteel outstanding, tops the offer of Lear Siegler. which on Monday said it was considering an offer of $22 a share for the Fansteel stock.

title: Reagan Aide Pleased
description: DETROIT, May 18 (AP) John P. Sears, Mr. Reagan's campaign manager, said: The approximately 40 percent of the vote which we have received tonight in Mr. Ford's home state of Michigan means we will receive over 30 of Michigan's delegates to the Republican National Convention.

title: City Surplus Sales Would Be Ended By New Charter
description: New York City will have to cancel its monthly auctions of surplus property, beginning in July, unless the State Legislature delays implementation of a Charter reform adopted by the voters last November, Municipal Service Administrator John T. Carroll said yesterday.

title: Halston's Groupies: Sweeticakes
description: Amanda Burden has just left, Kay Graham is waiting downstairs. The telephone gives a polite whirr. Will he speak to Margaux Hemingway? Of course, and will his secretary bring him a cup of tea?

title: Pageantry Marks Year of Torah Education
description: Jewish scholars and children were joined yesterday by brass bands, clowns and pageantry on floats to make the usually solemn study of the Torah an occasion for joy.

title: BUILDING ACCORD IS BELIEVED NEAR IN A REVISED PLAN
description: A possible break in the strike of apartment house employees that started May 3 appeared imminent yesterday as both sides were reported to be considering a formula for resolving their differences.

title: Dow Up 1.81
description: The stock market edged high er on a slight pickup in trading volume yesterday to register its first advance in six sessions. A number of issues rose after plans were disclosed for either stock splits or dividend increases.

title: Top Mine Union Aides Cleared On Charges of Mismanagement
description: WASHINGTON, May IS (AP) Top officials of the United Mine Workers were cleared today by the Labor Department 4f charges that they had mismanaged the union's finances.

title: WINE TALK
description: Italy sends more wine to the United States than any other wineproducing country, so it irritates the Italians when they see other countries, particularly France, getting most of the wine publicity.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The country's two leading manufacturers of antiperspirants containing the metallic element zirconium have agreed, under pressure from the Food and Drug Administration, to reformulate their products and make them without the controversial substance.

title: Pound Again Slips Below $1.80 Level, But Closes Higher
description: LONDON, May IR (UPI)The British pound dropped below $1.80 for the second consecutive day today but recovered to close well above that level.

title: Jersey Woman Found Dead
description: WALKER, Mich., May 18 (AP)A 22yearold New jersey woman who had been missing for two weeks was found dead in a field here about. 10 miles south of Grand Rapids, the police said. The  body of Lois DeRitter, who lived near Paerson, was found yesterday by two boys riding bicycles in a field, the police said. They refused to comment on the cause of death, pending an autopsy.

title: Power Triumphs In Relay
description: METUCHEN, N.J., May 18 Power Memorial's twomile relay team, with Maurice Weaver running the anchor 880yard leg in 1:53.3, posted the fastest time in the country this year when it clocked 7 minutes 44.5 seconds at the rainswept sixth annual Jersey Relays on St. Joseph's High School track tonight.

title: Cairo Bill Would Curb Drinking of Alcohol
description: CAIRO, May I A (AP)The Egyptian People's Assembly has adopted a bill forbidding Egyptians to drink any alcoholic beverage in public. Supporters said the bill would curb violence and make society conform to Islam, the state religion.

title: S.E.C. Opposes Flat Ban Against Bribery Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that Senate bill seeking a flat ban against bribing foreign officials and an enumeration of overseas payments of more than $1,000 threatened to distort the commission's role and might obfuscate more important issues.

title: 2 U.S. Frigates Due to Visit 4 West African Ports
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (Reuters)Two United States warships will visit several West African ports late this month lonO their way to the Indian Ocean to relieve ships of the U.S. Middle East Force, the Navy said.

title: BRIBERY IS LAID TO 3 POLICEMEN
description: Three police officers were charged yesterday with having operated an organized pador payoff systemfor more than a year, and receiving more than $10,000 for overlooking gambling activities in Harlem. The three officers, who were assigned to the 28th Precinct, were indicted on conspiracy and bribereceiving charges by a special grand jury impaneled to hear cases developed by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor investigating corruption in the city's criminaljustice system.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS CASE FOR REVIEW OF BUSING ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, May 18President Ford has directed Attorney General Edward H. Levi to look for an appropriate and proper case in which to ask the Supreme Court to reexamine the use of busing as a means of integrating schools, Mr. Ford's press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: PSYCHIATRIST HURT IN FALL DOWN SHAFT
description: A 45yearold doctor was scciously injured last night I when he plunged 25 feet down an elevator shaft in his East! 86th Street apartment building) that has been without normal elevator service during the building employees strike.

title: 13 Free Agents Are Signed by Jets
description: The New York Jets of the National Football, League signed 13 free agents yesterday, including Willie Thompson, a defensive back from San Francisco State, who was on the San Diego Chargers 1974 roster.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 20, 1976

title: Inquiry Asked by West Point Legal Staff Is Ruled Out by Secretary of the Army
description: WESTPOINT, N.Y., May 19Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann has denied a request by 10 members of the legal staff of the United States Military Academy for an investigation of the procedures being used by West Point in handling its cheating scandal.

title: A New Black Arts Center Holds GroundBreaking
description: A new black arts institution the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Artspiritually broke ground yesterday at its quarters in the Lincoln Center area, with the blessing of the African Methodist Episcopal church, a small grant from Exxon and 200 seats from Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Bangladesh Reports Attack By Force of 100 From India
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 19 (AP)About 100 armed people crossed into eastern Bangladesh from India yesterday and attacked the frontier post at Matirban with the support of mortar fire from Indian border forces, Bangladesh officials, said today.

title: Dr. X
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 19 Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, 48yearold New Jersey surgeon who has been referred to as Dr. X, has been indicted on charges of murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell a decade ago.

title: Continuing Recovery in Business Forecast for 1976 and Into 1977
description: Business recovery will show a quarterbyquarter improvement for the balance of 1976 and well into 1977, the National Association of Purchasing Management Inc. predicted yesterday.

title: Oldsters Turn Out to Mark Good New Days
description: WEST ORANGE, May 19Who wants to dance? yelled Michael Bruno of Newark to a group of women sitting on folding chairs at the South Mountain area here.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: The Ballet
description: There is a curious, warlock quality, a doomed and romantic impishness to Niels Kehlet that makes him peculiarly credible as James in Bournonville's La Sylphide, in which he made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House with the Royal Danish Ballet.

title: MOST LANDLORDS AGREE ON TERMS IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: The 17day apartment house strike ended at most buildings yesterday following an agreement that will provide $35 in Increased wages for workers and result in higher rents for many tenants.

title: Poll Links Udall Strength To Low Vote in Michigan
description: Representative Morris K. Udall's surprisingly strong showing in the Michigan Presidential primary may have been due more to the low Democratic turnout and unexpected thinness in the attraction of Jimmy Carter than to any substantial broadening of Mr. Udall's appeal to Democratic voters, according to an analysis of voting returns and a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Frederick Schaefer Dies at 84; ExHead of Brewing Company,
description: Frederick Maximilian Emile Schaefer, a former president of the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company, died Tuesday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Anaconda Holders Told the Company Expects 76 Profit
description: CHICAGO, May 19All Anaconda Company divisions operated profitably in March and April and the company should report a profit for all of 1976, John B.M. Place, chairman, president and chief executive, told the annual meeting in Chicago today.

title: Liverpool Wins Cup
description: BRUGES, Belgium, May 19 (UPI)Liverpool of. England held F. C. Bruges of Belgium to a 11 tie today and won the European Federation Soccer Cup for the second time in three years with a 43 aggregate score. Liverpool, which clinched the English championship earlier this month, won the first leg, 32, in England three weeks ago. The victory was the sixth by a British club in the last eight

title: Stalin Is Still Revered as a Hero in His Home Town
description: GORI, U.S.S.R.Open tributes to Stalin, which have been virtually obliterated throughout most of the Soviet Union in the last 20 years, continue to thrive in Georgia, and especially here in Gori, where he was horn.

title: JERSEY HOSPITAL HAILS INDICTMENT
description: ORADELL N.J., May 19The executive director of Riverdell Hospital here, where Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich allegedly murdered five patients while serving as chief of surgery 10 years ago, hailed the physician's indictment on murder charges as a vindication for the hospital and for the medical profession.

title: Reagan Is in Nevada to Change His Luck
description: RENO, May 19Ronald Reagan came to the gambling state of Nevada today to try to change his luck after suffering heavy losses yesterday in Re1 publican Presidential primary elections in Michigan and Maryland.

title: White Plains to Get Traffic Computer,
description: The city of White Plains is planning to pay $1.2 million toward a $4 million computerized trafficcontrol system for its central business district.

title: Foods Children Love
description: It is not really difficult to figure out what children like to eat. In any city, among children of all ages and backgrounds, there is almost total agreement on favorites. It is a tribute to the Italian kitchen that its specialties, such as pizza, meat balls, meat sauce, spaghetti, lasagne and ravioli make up a sort of gastronomic Esperanto, understood by all palates.

title: Exchange Seat $89,000
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $89,000, up $1,000 from the previous sale on Mav 14. Seats are now quoted at $85,000 bid, $100,000 offered.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers. The reports show a large number of company officials exercising options to buy stock.

title: Researchers Find Large Doses of Vitamin C May Damage Gene Material
description: Canadian researchers have found indications that large doses of vitamin Cnot much higher than the amounts some people take to ward off colds and flucan damage the genetic material of human cells.

title: Gallo Ordered Not to Coerce Wine Dealers
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)  Gallo, the nation's largest wine seller, has been ordered not to coerce its dealers into selling the more than 40 different brands of wine it produces, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Remembrance at Yorktown
description: YORKTOWN, Va., May 19President Giscard d'Estaing paid an hour's visit to the site here of the decisive battle of the Revolutionary War, and said that Yorktown would forever remind us, friends to this day, of what we can accomplish. together in the name of liberty.

title: Conventional Foolishness
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  As the horses round the far turn and enter the final third of the run for the Rose Garden, some lastminute side bets can be made against conventional wisdom:

title: Belanger Stays on Hit Tear As Orioles Defeat Brewers
description: Mark Belanger, Baltimore's shortstop for 11 straight seasons, tripled home one run and scored another in the first inning last night to pace the Orioles to a 53 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers in Memorial Stadium.

title: Cairo Sees Syrian Split
description: CAIRO, May 19Diplomatic sources here said today a split had apparently developed in Syria's Government over the planned talks in Riyadh and the issue of the Sinai agreement.

title: Leo V. Lyons, 84, a Founder Of National Football League
description: ROCHESTER, May 19 (UPI)Leo V. Lyons, a founder of the National Football League, died at Rochester General Hospital yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Angolan Asserts Cuba Is Main Ally
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 19Angola's Prime Minister said last night that his Government's foreign policy was based on nonalignment with any bloc but at the same time on preferential relations with what he called the socialist countries, particularly Cuba.

title: Winter Is the Star Of Spring Rerun
description: It was May, the merry month when April showers should have brought only flowers. But when Rosalyn Maxwell looked out her window in Oswegatchie in upstate St. Lawrence County yesterday morning, she knew she was one of her village's lucky ones.

title: Jersey Income Tax Killed In Senate for Sixth Time
description: TRENTON, May 19  The New Jersey Senate tonight rejected a proposed state income tax for the sixth time in two years.

title: Democratic Planners Attack Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The Democratic Platform Committee turned its attention to foreign affairs today and heard a series of party specialists denounce the policies of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Mullen Has Surgery
description: Tom Mullen, a tetrayear offensive lineman with the New York Giants, underwent surgery yesterday at River View Hospital in Red Bank, N.J., to repair a ruptured bicep in his left arm. Mullen will be out of action for 10 weeks. The Giants expect him at training camp during the first week in August, about three weeks after training begins.

title: Abuses in Nursing Homes Could Recur, Panel Finds
description: ALBANY, May 19  The Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes ended its investigation of the state's system of caring for the elderly today with the warning that the scandal that led to the establishment of the commission 15 months ago would inevitably erupt again in a society which celebrates youth and denigrates age.

title: Doctor Is Censured In Taking Stitches Back From Patient
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 19 (AP)lhe State Board of Medical Examiners censured today and placed on a year's probation a white doctor accused of removing freshly sewn stitches from the arm of a young black patient who was unable to pay the doctor's $25 fee.

title: Ford Is Recalling Cars For Gas Pedal Defect
description: DETROIT, May 19 (UPI)The Ford Motor company said today that it was recalling nearly onehalf million currentmodel Ford and LincolnMercury cars because quick acceleration might cause the gas pedal to stick.

title: SPAIN TO REPLACE FRANCO PORTRAITS
description: MADRID, May 19 (UPI)The Spanish Government today ordered pictures of King Juan Carlos to replace those of the late Francisco Franco in government offices.

title: Ford Elated by Victories; Sees FirstBallot Sweep
description: WASHINGTON, May 19President Ford proclaimed renewed confidence today about a firstballot nomination as hill strategists began designing overtures to Repubican moderates in the crucial last round of Presidential primaries.

title: Kiick, ExDolphin, Signed by Broncos
description: DENVER, May 19 (UPI)Jim Kiick, the running back who left the Miami Dolphins to join Memphis of the nowdefunct World Football League, signed today a series of oneyear contracts with the Denver Broncos of the. National Football _League. Bronco officials refused to disclose the terms or number of the contracts.

title: Radio
description: 7:30  8:55 A.M., WNYC  FM: Mornings With Music. Suite No. I, Handel; Harp Partite in A. Bach;. Concerto in D minor, Albinoni; Carmen Suite No. 1, Bizet; Sonata No. 4. for Two Violins, Leclair; Night On Bald Mountain. Mussorgsky.

title: Beame Opens Campaign To Greet the Convention
description: Mayor Beame, predicting that the summer of 1976 would be the most exciting for New York City in our lifetime. yesterday opened a campaign to welcome the Democratic National Convention.

title: Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: U.S. Officials Split on Aid to Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 19United States officials in Addis Ababa and Washington are engaged in a sharp debate about the American military commitment to Ethiopia and the use of American arms against Eritrean rebels.

title: The Boston Schools
description: BOSTON, May 19There is no use pretending that school busing in Boston will work out just fine if things are allowed to go on as they are. Anyone with eyes to see in this city knows how tense it is. The controversy has worrying implications for race relations, public education and the role of the Federal courtsand not in Boston alone.

title: 30 HURT IN CLASH IN UPSTATE PRISON
description: Great Meadow Correctional Facility in upstate New York was the scene of a serious disturbance Monday evening in which more than 30 inmates And guards were injured.

title: Dr. X
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 19 Dr. Mario E. Jescalevich, a 48yearold New Jersey surgeon who has been referred to as Dr. X, has been indicted on charges of murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell a decade ago.

title: HIM COURT CURBS A WITNESS RIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Th Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a lower Federal court decision requiring that suspects called to testify before grand juries must be given the same right to remain silent and to have a lawyer that the police must give to suspects in custo dy.

title: FUTURES ADVANCE IN SOYBEAN MEAL
description: In a lastminute buying rush by traders holding short positions who wanted to even their holdings, soybean meal prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The rise came after a oneday hiatus Tuesday when prices declined a little for most contracts after many days of rising prices.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Rangers have signed John Bednarski, their 23yearold defenseman, to a twoyear contract. Bednarski appeared in 59 games with the club last season scoring one goal and eight assists, while accumulating 77 minutes in venalities.

title: NBC Union Says Roving Pickets Helped Get Tentative Contract
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California gave a National Press Club speech on the sidewalk; George Meany and other labor leaders refused to appear at the Democratic platform committee hearings, and television film crews were excluded from an A.F.L.C.I.O. luncheon for Rose Kennedy that was ad dressed by her son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Scandals
description: LONDON, May 19Britain is either on the verge of another controversy involving the alleged sexual irregularities of a prominent politician or it is indulging itself in a monumental and embarrassing waste of time and energy.

title: Palmer's World Flight Ends in Record Time
description: DENVER, May 19 (UPI)Arnold Palmer, the golfer, flew over the cloudcovered peaks of the Rocky \fountains and landed at dusk today, completing a recordsetting aroundtheworld flight in 57 hours 25 minutes.

title: Albany Aides Say Banks Were Hurt by Own Stand

title: 'Missouri Breaks,' Offbeat Western
description: "The Missouri Breaks" is a western set in the fine, high hill country of Montana in the 1880's and is about a rich, literate rancher (he reads "Tristram Shandy" to relax) trying to cope with horse thieves who are stealing him blind. It's about the rancher's pretty, bright exceedingly bored daughter, who quotes Sam Johnson and once seduces an outlaw by suggesting he get down off his horse. "What for?" says the outlaw, suddenly prissy. "We'll talk about the Wild West," says the girl, "and how to get the hell out of it."It's about that same outlaw, a horse thief, and his pals, who aren't bad fellows really, nor especially successful, just guys trying to make ends meet under increasingly difficult circumstances. Also about the eccentric "regulator," or private gun, hired by the rancher to bring law and order to his territory."The Missouri Breaks," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, stars Marlon Brando as the regulator and Jack Nicholson the horse thief and has a cast of superb supporting actors, including Kathleen Lloyd as the rancher's outspoken daughter, Harry Dean Stanton and Randy Quaid as two of Mr. Nicholson's more prominent partners in fumbled crime and John McLiam as the rancher.More important, "The Missouri Breaks" was directed by Arthur Penn ("Bonnie and Clyde," "Little Big Man") and written by Thomas McGuane. All of the credits associated with "The Missouri Breaks" are impressive. Yet I liked it better when it was called "Rancho Deluxe.""Rancho Deluxe," which was also written by Mr. McGuane, was a much smaller, similarly wise-talking version of virtually the same story, though set in contemporary Montana. The anachronisms in "Rancho Deluxe" (cattle rustling with a pickup truck, riding the range in a helicopter) were funny and moving partly because they emphasized the disconnection between a romantic past and a motorized present that's lost all ideals, all purpose.You might think that Mr. McGuane, by setting the same situation in the 1880's, would give us the romantic side of the story. Not at all. In the 1880's of "The Missouri Breaks" the characters are just as bored, confused and directionless as they are in 1975, and they, too, look back to some dimly remembered period when the old days were good. Instead of being elegiac and funny, however, the anachronisms in "The Missouri Breaks" too often seem like camp.This, I suspect, is principally because of the out-of-control performance given by Mr. Brando. He enters the film hidden behind a horse, which he at last peeks around, and then spends the rest of the movie upstaging the writer, the director and the other actors. Nothing he does (affecting the Irish accent he used earlier in "The Nightcomers" and wearing odd costumes, including frontierswoman drag at one point) has any apparent connection to the movie that surrounds him. He grabs our attention but does nothing with it.In their earlier films both Mr. Penn and Mr. McGuane have demonstrated a fondness for eccentric characters whose impulses have a kind of grandeur about them. There's no grandeur to Mr. Brando's character. Nor much mystery. He behaves like an actor in armed revolt.One has no way of knowing whether "The Missouri Breaks" would have been a good film without this peculiar presence as its center, but there are so many arresting things in the rest of the movie that one can speculate  a raucous kangaroo-court sequence in which the defendant, a horse thief, becomes just as giddy and rowdy as the men trying him; a scene in a frontier whorehouse that, for once, looks depressingly grim; a marvelous caper in which several none too bright outlaws steal a corralful of horses from the Royal Canadian Mounties, who are otherwise occupied. They are in church singing "Bringing in the Sheep."The film conveys a fine sense of place and period, of weather and mood and the precariousness of life, which are things that Mr. Nicholson responds to as an actor. Yet the plot, along with Mr. Brando, keeps intruding and throwing things out of balance. It's one of the film's oddities that as "The Missouri Breaks" proceeds to its bloody climax, with the scenes of violence increasing in intensity until one man slits the throat of another, it becomes increasingly trivial.The killing of a rabbit on screen earlier in the movie (which has been rated PG) is more brutal and more shocking than the climactic confrontation of the two superstars, which doesn't seem important at all.

description: ALBANY, May 19  The Assembly today passed a bill allowing for the equitable distribution of property in separations and divorces and the possibility of either party's receiving alimony.

title: Strange Advances In Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 19 (UPI)  Curtis Strange, the defending champion, and Fred Ridley, the 1975 United States Amateur champion, each won two matches today and advanced to the quarterfinals of the 76th annual North and South amateur golf championship.

title: Hints From Peking That Mao Is Failing
description: HONG KONG, May 19Atter years of steeling themselves against rumors that Chairman Moa Tsetung was about to die from some mys tertous malady, analysts here are growing conrerned that the S2yearold Chairman's health may now indeed he seriously deteriorating.

title: AntiCigarette Drive Asked
description: GENEVA, May 19 (AP)The World Health Organization called on governments today to restrict cigarette advertising, strengthen warning notices on cigarette packages, enforce smoking bans in public places and protect the rights of nonsmokers.

title: Top Secret Service Official Is Relieved of Duty by Bonn
description: BONN, May 19 (Reuters)West Germany announced tonight it had suspended from duty one of its top secret service men.

title: Grooming Is Shown As an Art
description: The dogs had their day at the Dog Fanciers Club. After the club's luncheon at the Statler Hilton last week, five experts gave demonstrations in the secrets of groom

title: Market Place
description: Generally rising interest rates promise to turn new attention to the securities of the Federal Government and its agencies as individuals continue to seek safe investment havens.

title: Youth, 15, Wins Math Olympiad With a Perfect Score
description: A 15yearold sophomore at Stuyvesant High School, a younglooking prodigy who favors jeans, sneakers and a polo shirt, scored highest in the country on a threehour test of mathematical reasoning and creativity given to the top math students from coast to coast.

title: Rye Mayor Takes a Stand Over a Slippery Question
description: RYE, N.Y., May 19Mayor John Carey zigzagged down the City Hall parking lot tonight on a red plastic skatehoard.

title: BEAME IS FACING A BUDGET REVOLT
description: The City Council delegations from Manhattan and the Bronx informed Mayor Beame yesterday that they wouldattempt to block passage of the 1977 expense budget unless his orders to close Fordham Hospital in the Bronx and Sydenham and Gouverneur Hospitals in Manhattan were rescinded.

title: Cavalry Charge in Belmont?
description: Now that Bold Forbes and Honest Pleasure have proved themselves capable of destroying each other, trainers of rival 3yearolds are showing sudden interest in the 108th Belmont Stakes.

title: For the Basque Nationalists, Madrid Is Still the Enemy
description: BILBAO, Spain, May 14In the Basque country, where ethnic separatism and a high degree of labor militancy combined to produce the sharpest opposition in the 36 years of 1Franco's dictatorship, the liberalization that followed the general's death last November has been least felt.

title: Kissinger in Oslo for Parley Of NATO Foreign Ministers
description: OSLO, May 19 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight for the annual conference of North Atlantic Treaty Organization foreign ministers.

title: School LunchUtopia? NoImpossible Dream
description: School food does not have to be bad. As hard as that may be to believe, considering the food served in most New York City schools, there is a good deal of encouraging evidence to the contrary. Many schools throughout the country achieve more than minimum standards of palatability, all on limited budgets and within the requirements of the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Icelandic and British Aides Meet Over Fishing Dispute
description: OSLO, May 19 (Reuters)The Icelandic and British Foreign Ministers had a surprise meeting here last night on their countries dispute over fishing rights. British sources said,, however, that there had been! no change in the positions of the two nations.

title: The Screen: Elliott Gould in 'Whiffs'
description: If Elliott Gould doesn't stop making awful movies, the notion is going to get around that he is a poorish actor.A few months ago he was seen here in an awful movie called "I Will, I Will . . . for Now." He played a man who was impotent. Now he is in a movie called "Whiffs," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Victoria Theaters. He plays a man who is impotent."Whiffs" is about a soldier invalided out of the Army after serving as a guinea pig for experiments with gases. He steals gas and uses it to hold up restaurants, bars and eventually a whole town. The experience makes him rich, gets him a girl and restores his potency.It is a brutally tortured comedy, potholed with intervals of the most embarrassing bad taste.The rating is PG, which in this case stands for Pathetic Garbage. If Elliott Gould doesn't stop making movies about impotence, the notion is going to get around that he is a poorish actor.

title: JUDGE REAFFIRMS EVICTION ORDER
description: Judge Benjamin J. Nolan of Bronx Civil Court yesterday reaffirmed his order for the eviction of a merchant from the Bronx Terminal Market.

title: A Beirut Funeral Reflects Agony of Divided Nation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 19 A funeral service today in St. Joseph's, a small and pleasant ocher church in the Christian section of Beirut, reflected the deep human divisions that 13 months of civil war have caused in the Lebanese capital and in its press.

title: Soviet and Canada in Pact
description: MOSCOW, May 19 (Reuters) The Soviet Union and Canada today signed a treaty insuring Soviet recognition of a 200mile fishing zone planned by the Canadian Government. Under the agreement, Soviet ships, under special license will be able to catch fish beyond Canadian needs.

title: Soviet Denies Its Spending for Defense Is Increasing
description: MOSCOW, May 19 (Reuters) The official Tass press agency today dismissed Western allegations of growing Soviet military spending as propaganda intended to insure higher defense budgets in certain North Atlantic Treaty countries.

title: The Newer Faces Won in Maryland
description: BALTLMORE, May 19The changed political chemistry that Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California correctly sensed might carry him to victory over Jimmy Carter in Maryland was at work, too, for other candidates here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)The collective income of all Americans in April rose $11.6 billion, marking the fourth consecutive month personal income has posted doubledigit increase. The Commerce Department said today that the 0.9 percent rise in personal income last month was largely a result of a $5.4 billion increase in private wages and salaries.

title: A Beirut Funeral Reflects Agony of Divided Nation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 19 A funeral service today in St. Joseph's, a small and pleasant ocher church in the Christian section of Beirut, reflected the deep human divisions that 13 months of civil war have caused in the Lebanese capital and in its press.

title: CANDIDATES SEEM IN VOTE STANDOFF FOR NEXT 3 WEEKS
description: The Republican and Democratic Presidential campaigns, each of which seemed to be turning into a rout at different points in the last two months, now appear likely to remain unresolved at least until the completion of primary balloting three weeks from now.

title: Brown, in Oregon, Seeks WriteIn Votes
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 19Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California arrived here today from Baltimore looking for a way to turn his solid victory over Jimmy Carter in the Maryland primary into a winning streak that could alter the course of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Carter Gets Big Lead In Poll Held in Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19 (UPI)Jimmy Carter holds a wide lead among Democrats competing in the New Jersey Presidential primary June 8, according to a poll released today.

title: Orantes, Dibbs Gain At Hamburg
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 19 (UPI)Manuel Orantes of Spain had trouble beating Kjell Johanson of Sweden, 46, 60, 97, but Eddie Dibbs of Miami easily defeated Georges Goven of France, 60, 61 in the third round of the $100,000 German tennis championships today.

title: 1,840 VOTERS POLLED IN MICHIGAN SURVEY
description: The New York Times and CpS News polled 1,840 Michigan voters yesterday as they left the polling places. Of these, 1,002 were Republicans and 838 were Democrats.

title: F.P.C. RIGHTS ROLE IS FOUND LIMITED
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Rejecting the arguments of several civil rights groups representing minorities and women, the Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that the Federal Power Commission has only limited authority to deal with job discrimination on the basis of nationality or sex by the industries it regulates.

title: Senate Votes Weather Bill
description: WASHINGTON, aMy 19(AP) By voice vote, the Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill directing the Secretary of Commerce to develop a comprehensive and coordinated national weather modification policy. The bill calls for a study to determine if weather modification technology can be used to reduce loss of life and property destruction in severe storms.

title: Matthews Captures L.I. Golf in Miserable Weather
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., May 19David Matthews, a former University of Arkansas linebacker, could not remember playing football in weather as bad as it was today for the last two rounds of the 52d annual Long Island Golf Association open tournament at the Westhampton Country club.

title: Reform Through TV
description: The Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes, which formally disbanded yesterday will long be remembered for a series of televised hearings in the spring and early summer of 1975. On their home screens citNews Analysis izens saw dramatic testimony by witnesses citing bad treatment, massive Fraud and a rejection of responsibility by New York City and state officials. Experts in the field agree that these hearings, keeping warm the climate for corrective action, were the chief and considerable contribution of the commission in its brief lifetime.

title: Housing Council Urges Ending of Rent Control.
description: The Housing Council of New York, a coalition of 14 real estate groups from various parts of the state, called ye sterday on the Legislature and Governor Carey to enact a threeyear phasing out of New York City's rent control and rent stabilization programs. Such prog rants limit rent increases in a total of 1.3 million apartments. The council proposed decontrol of different groups of apartments at different times over the three years, and urged Federal rent subsidies for tenants who showed they would be hurt by decontrol.

title: RULING PARTY WINS BERMUDA ELECTION
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 19 (Reuters)The more conservative United Bermuda Party today emerged as victor in this selfgoverning British colony's general elections, but saw its majority reduced in the House of Assembly.

title: Philadelphia Also Facing Crisis of Funds Shortage
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 19Like New York and other troubled cities around the country, Philadelphia is having serious financial problems, and like all the others its survival now seems dependent on radical relief measures.

title: Canada Begins New Search to Buy a Patrol Plane; Lockheed, in Urgent Talks, Trying to Salvage Deal
description: Canada announced yesterday an immediate new search for a modem longrange patrol plane after Tuesday's collapse of plans to buy 18 such craft from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for $750 million.

title: Talks Pressed to Avert Post Strike Today
description: Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and The New York Post met for four hours last night and then adjourned until noon today to continue their efforts to avert a strike at The Post threatened for 5 o'clock this afternoon.

title: Ford's Hurrah...
description: No matter how his bid for his party's nomination finally turns out, President Ford will remember May with pleasure, for on that date his fellowcitizens Michigan gave him a resounding vote of confidence.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, May 19, 1976

title: CUBA SAID TO AID PUERTO RICO FOES
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Gov. Rafael HernandezColOn of Puerto Rico contended today that Cuba was training and aiding terrorists to overthrow the government of the island commonwealth.

title: PRICE PRESSURES EXPECTED IN OPEC
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 19 Buoyed by economic recovery in industrial nations, the mem bers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have largely avoided further oil price cuts this spring, oilmen here report, and are confident that their overall oil production will continue to rise.

title: 10 Rebels and 4 PassersBy Killed in Teheran Clashes
description: TEHERAN, Iran May 19 (AP) Ten guerrillas and four passersby were killed by gunfire yesterday at three hideouts northwest of Teheran, officials announced today. They said those In the hideouts had connections with foreign countries and foreign terrorist groups.

title: Botanists Warn of Threats to Habitats of Rare Plants
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 19 Some of nature's rarest plant species grow in New Jersey, but their habitat must be protected if they are to survive,. a leading botanist said today.

title: Film: 'Smile Orange,' Jamaican Story
description: The tourist is funny and crass; the native who serves and exploits him is crass and funny."Smile Orange," a Jamaican film, is based on a play that must have been pungent and witty. The film has some pungency and lilt left in it, but it is terribly awkward.It is about Ringo, a picaresque hero who works at a tourist hotel, cons the tourists, sleeps with their wives and daughters, doctors the crabs for the crab races that are part of the hotel's slam-bang entertainment and imparts tactics and a kind of gallows philosophy to a younger colleague."If you're a black man and won't play a part you're going to starve to death," he counsels his busboy disciple, while giving him lessons in how to be suave and use deodorants.As Ringo  he played the same role in the extremely successful reggae film "The Harder They Come"Carl Bradshaw makes a funny and rather noble swindler. He has, not courage but equanimitythat is, grace under pressure under a hot sun.The film makes fun of the lumpiest and palest set of tourists ever to carry plastic shoulder bags. It makes fun of an upwardly mobile hotel manager, married to a lecherous blonde. It makes fun of the blacks' own version of the anti-postcolonial struggle: If you can't beat them, scalp them.Its best parts are the good lines from the play. Ringo rationalizes his getting his two brothers-in-law jobs as lifeguards, even though they can't swim. "Tourists can all swim," he says. "It's we Jamaicans who are afraid of the water." He scornfully describes the foppish mulatto assistant manager as "a zebra looking over a whitewashed fence."But there is too much literal carry-over from the play. Head talks to head, back and forth, on and on. The cuts are rough, the photography turns everything to orange and cabbage color. The story goes nowhere, and the humor eventually loses its sharpness and becomes inane and too local.The freshness is like the breeze blowing through a half-built house  enjoyable for a while, but you lose patience with the holes, gaps and splinters."Smile Orange," which opened yesterday at the Festival and New Yorker Theaters, is rated PG. It is quite harmless; there's some talk about sex but no action.

title: All Training HardTo Restore Image
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 19 (UPI)Muhammad Ali, looking much trimmer than in his mediocre fights against Jimmy Young, said today that he let the public down in the last defense of his world heavyweight title, and that Richard Dunn would have to pay for it.

title: Mets Strand 12 In Loss to Phils
description: The Philadelphia Phillies won the opening skirmish in the battle for first place last night at Shea Stadium tvhert they survived the wintry weather and three late rallies and beat the New York Mets, 21.

title: Rickover Wants Shipyards To Comply With Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Adm. Hyman G. Rickover advocated today that shipyards be forced to comply with their contracts with the Navy rather than being given a settlement on what he described as their inflated claims against the Government.

title: Sales Rise by 12.1%
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the country's largest operator of department stores, had a small gain in profits, amounting to only 3.1 percent, in its first quarter ended May 1 on a sales advance of 12.1 percent, the Cincinnatibased company reported yesterday.

title: Canadian Stake of 25% Will Be Set for Oil Fields
description: OTTAWA, May 19 (Reuters) Canada plans to require minimum 25 percent Canadian participation as a condition for allowing new oil and natural gas fields to go into production.

title: Former Representative Irwin Seeking Weicker's Senate Seat
description: HARTFORD, May 19Donald J. Irwin, a former Mayor of Norwalk and for three terms a Democratic member of Con1 gress, declared today that he was a candidate for the United States Senate. He charged that, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Republican incumbent, dispensed warmedover Watergate, while the country's strength waned and people were without fobs.

title: Typhoon Changes Course And Now Threatens Guam
description: AGANA, Guam, Thursday, May 20 (AP)A typhoon that has already killed 10 people shifted course slightly today and threatened to sweep over this Pacific island of 87,000 people tomorrow morning.

title: Cosmos Set Back Boston
description: FOXBORO, Mass., May 19 Giorgio Chinaglia's soccer performance tonight was not equal to his New York recital two nights ago, but the towering Italian scored two goals as he led the Cosmos to a 21 victory over the Boston Minutemen.

title: Output and Supply Of Gasoline Down In U.S. Last Week
description: Both production and stocks of gasoline in the United States fell last week, according to statistics announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Winter Returns
description: An unseasonable wave of cold air brought winterlike weather back to New York State yesterday. The city broke a 94yearold record when the temperature fell to 38 degrees. Upstate, snow fell across a wide area, with Mohawk County reporting up to 18 inches. Page 39.

title: Jersey Income Tax Killed In Senate for Sixth Time
description: TRENTON, May 19  The New Jersey Senate tonight rejected a proposed state income tax for the sixth time in two years.

title: ... Apartment Accord
description: Settlement of the apartment employees strike ends fortnight of severe inconvenience for hundreds thousands of tenants in NeW York's towering residential buildings. The revisions in the wage formula that were recommended last week by Mayor Beame's mediation panel go so far toward meeting landlord objections to the original package that there is little warrant for continued holdout by dissident owners.

title: Sudanese Leader Orders Aides to Stop Drinking
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, May 18 (AP) President Gaafar alNimeiry warned his ministers and legislators today either to give up alcoholic drinks or resign:

title: Statutory Recognition of Brain Death
description: Governor Carey has included a statutory definition of death in his proposed health program. Such a statute would recognize that death can be pronounced on the basis of complete destruction of the brain as well as on the basis of cessation of heartbeat and respiration. The need for such law in New York State is strongly felt by many members of the medical and legal professions but is not generally appreciated and requires some explanation.

title: BOSTON DECISION LIKELY THIS WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May 19President Ford said today that Attorney General Edward H. Levi would decide this week whether to select Boston as the appropriate case to test courtordered busing of school children to help achieve integration.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 20, 1976

title: Pope Plans to Canonize Three Saints on Monday
description: ROME, May 19 (Reuters)Pope Paul will announce next Monday his intention to canonize three new Roman Catholic saints, the Vatican said today.

title: The Bus Stops Here
description: Guess Where the Bus Is Going to Stop, long the most annoying nowin game in town, may at last be on the way out. Defying the tradition of keeping wouldhe passengers speculating, running and cursing, the Transportation Administration has at last installed 161 bus stop and information signs which are a model of clarity.

title: Philharmonic to Open in Park on July 4
description: The New York Philharmonic's 12th season of free concerts in the city's parks will be opened with a gala Bicentennial program on July 4 in Central Park's Sheep Meadow, with Leonard Bernstein conducting. For the first time, the Exxon Corporation will be a principal funder of these concerts, which in the 11 previous years were supported by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee.

title: Aurelio Is Agent for Concorde's Maker
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Richard Aurelio, former Deputy Mayer of New York, has registered with the Justice Department as a foreign agent in connection with his work as a representative of the manufacturer of the Concorde supersonic airliner.

title: U.S. Plan on Lake Rejected By Vermont and New York
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 19 (AP)Vermont and New York officials have refused to accept a policy proposal of the Environmental Protection Agency for controlling pollution in'ake Champlain.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three men were arrested for allegedly trying to steal $2,000 from a Bond's clothing store at 1530 Broadway, near 45th Street. A police spokesman said the men broke, into the store from a window near the roof of the threestory building. After forcing open a safe on the top floor, the suspects tried to break open a groundfloor safe, but tripped an alarm that brought the police and private guards. A twohour search that ended at 4:30 A.M. led to the suspects, who were found hidirtg in a crawl space. between the topfloor ceiling and the roof. The suspectswere identified only as Edward Rodriguez, 23 years old, his brother, Emil, 18, and Edgar Ramos, 21.

description: In Memoriam

title: About the Yanks
description: Otto Velez. a Yankee outfielder, was passing around cigars in the clubhouse before the game. His wife, Haydee, gave birth to their first child, a boy, in San Juan earlier in the day. . . . Willie Randolph, the rookie second baseman, sat out the game with a cold acquired in Tuesday night's 16inning 42degree victory. . . . Billy Martin said Mickey (Quick) Rivers, out five games with a jammed left ankle, should be ready to play in the Boston series at the Stadium. . . . Carlos May will wear No. 38 and Ron Guidry No. 26; both joined for the Boston series. Ed Figueroa is scheduled to pitch against Bill Lee tonight, Dock Ellis against Luis Tian't Friday night, Catfish Hunter against Dick Pole Saturday night and Rudy May against Ferguson Jenkins Sunday afternoon.

title: Blackouts Facing A Permanent Ban
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  SenateHouse conferees agreed in principle today to make permanent the sports antiblackout television law, but not before Senator John 0. Pastore upbraided his colleagues for having accused him of having made a deal with football's commissioner. Pete Rozelle.

title: Public Service Dividend Up
description: NEWARK, May 19 (UPI) Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, declared its first quarterly dividend increase in four years yesterday. It said its firstquarter dividend would be 45 cents per share, a 2cent increase over its dividend for the final quarter of 1975. PSE&G said it was the first quarterly increase in dividends since 1972.

title: House Panel Bars Stamps For Use in FastFood Store
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) The House Agriculture Committee overwhelmingly rejected today a proposal to allow use of Government food stamps in hamburger, chicken and other fastfood carryout stores.

title: Angolan Refugee Plans Public Birth as Protest
description: LISBON, May 19 (Reuters) A woman refugee from Angola plans to give birth on the steps of the Government's Sao Bento Palace here to draw attention to the plight of former colonial settlers.

title: Japanese Says U.S. Pledges Aid in Lockheed Case
description: A special envoy of the Japanese Government has said that Washington has promised close; cooperation in action seeking; a quick resolution of the Lock. heed scandal, which has brought a prolonged political crisis in Japan.

title: Talbert Out As Director Of Open
description: With some reluctance and much chagrin. Bill Talbert made it official yesterday; he is no longer the chairman and director of the United Stales Open tennis tournament.

title: State Barge Sails June 3 To 36 Ports
description: The Bicentennial Barge, a floating exhibition cf historical memorabilia dealing with the political and cultural character of New York State from 1765 to 1789, will be launched on June 3 at 1 P.M. at the South Street Seaport Museum in Manhattan.

title: ANESTHETIC MAKER WINS DAMAGE SUIT
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 19 (UPI) The Nebraska Supreme Court refused today to hold the manlufacturer of the anesthetic drug Innovar responsible for brain damage to the mother of three children who has been technically alive but unconscious for the last five years.

description: The financially troubled Burmah Oil Company has made an agreement with R. J. Reynolds Industries whereby Burmahs United States oil and gas business will be acquired by Reynolds for $520 million in cash, the two companies announced jointly yesterday.

description: The creation of a regional Reconstruction Finance Corporation similar to the Federal agency that saved failing enterprises in the New Deai era was proposed yesterday by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to help rebuild the sagging economies of the Northeast.

description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 20At the time of the war in Vietnam, Jimmy Carter was a strong supporter of the American involvement there. Earlier this month, at a black church in Indianapolis, he characterized the war as racist) saying that becauie the skins of Vietnamese were yellow we did not regret their deaths as much as if they had been white.

description: TRENTON, May 20Stephen J. Foley of Deal, the only challenger to Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.'s bid for renomination in the Democratic primary, says he is atttracting a lot of attention from voters with a lowkey antiabortion platform.

title: Newspaper Group Selects
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)  Robert Lewis, Washington correspondent for the Michiganbased Booth Newspapers group, was elected yesterday as president of the Washington chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, the society for professional journalists.

title: Campbell Soap Co.
description: Earnings of the Campbell Soup Company rose 11 percent in the third fiscal quarter ended May 2, to $26.1 million, or 79 cents a share from $23.5 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales totaled $416.9 million, up 10 percent from $379.1 million, lifting ninemonth volume to $1.26 billion, up 6.8 percent from $1.18 billion a year earlier. Ninemonth net climbed 18.8 percent to $78.6 million, or $2.38 a share, from $66.2 million, or $1.98 a share.

title: Publishing: Letters From Tara
description: THERE will, after all, bea second book by Margaret Mitchell. Forty years after Gone With the Wind was published and 27 years after the death of its author, a collection of her letters is being readied by the Macmillan Company for October publication. The collection will be edited by Richard Harwell, and all the letters in it will be connected in some way with the novelletters to reviewers, readers, publishers, movie people and the like.

title: Company Profits Up
description: MI measures of corporate profits rose in the first quarter over the final quarter of 1975 and were above the recession low a year earlier. Page D2.

title: To Improve the A.P.A.
description: Governor Carey's proposal for changes in the law governing the operations of the Adirondack Park Agency is not in itself a threat to that highly useful but hardpressed arm of the state. On the contrary, if the Governor's two bills are enacted substantially as he submitted them, they should make easier the task the agency, which in fact helped to draft them. They might even undercut those members of the Legislature whose real purpose is to wreck the agency altogether.

That was the lead of a story on the sports page of a New York daily about 45 years ago when Londos, then regarded by all rightthinking persons as heavyweight rassling champion of the world, was preparing to defend his title against Rats Steele in a ereat match in Yankee Stadium. title: New Endorsements Aid Carter Chances
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A littlenoticed series of endorsements from key Democratic officials in the larger states has enhanced Jimmy Carter's prospects of winning his party's Presidential nomination despite his recent primary losses and the probability of more to come.

Race for a Swine Flu Vaccine Began
