Richard Condon, starting with The Oldest Confession and The Manchurian Candidate, that cult book of the McCarthy era, has concocted a string of cynical, hip political thrillers that contain an extravagance of invention uniaue with him. Also unique

title: ExNATO Deputy Commander Runs On Communist Slate in Italian Election
description: ROME, May 20For years, Nino Pasti, a general in the Italian air force, sat in the highest councils of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, sifting secrets and providing advice. Today, he is a candidate , for the Senate on the ComImunist Party slate.

title: Morale of Justices in New York Is Low
description: There WAS a time when conversation in the judges lunchroom atop the State Supreme Court Building in Manhattan centered on fine legal pointsthe handling of a motion, say, or the implications of a decision.

title: Olivier Better, Plans to Do TV
description: LONDON, May 20 (UPI)Laurence Olivier said today that he had recovered sufficiently from a skin and muscular disease to go ahead with plans to help produce and appear in an NBCGranada Television production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.

title: Rochester Owner Of a Nursing Home Indicted as Cheat
description: ROCHESTER, May 20Albert S. Christiano Jr., a nursingtome owner who is president of the New York State Health Facilities Association, was indicted today on charges of illegally obtaining $200,000 in Medicaid funds from the state.

title: The Who, What and When of 2 Journalism Teachers
description: Legend, like a jaunty halo, was shaped. Wednesday night around a feisty 78yearold man who, from 1928 to 1955, as faculty adviser to the newspaper of DeWitt Clinton High School, chastised, with a ruthless blue pencil, the writings of such proteges as James Baldwin, the novelist and essayist; Paddy Chayefsky, the playwright, and Maurice H. Nadjari, the special prosecutor.

title: Leaders in Lebanon Hold Talks In Effort to Arrange CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20Presidentelect Elias Sarkis and leaders of the leftistMoslem alliance were seeking a minimum agreement today that would permit them to announce another ceasefire in the fighting here.

title: A Politics of Decimation
description: My Favorite Unannounced Presidential Candidate put in a couple of sleepless nights this week, after Gerald Ford's comeback in Michigan and Jimmy Carter's comeuppance in Maryland.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Delaware Shad Scrutinized
description: ROSEMONT, N.J.  The American shad, a bony but sweetfleshed fish whose roe is highly prized by gourmets, is the subject of study by biologists of the Delaware River Basin Anadromous Fish Project here.

title: JaiAlai in Hartford Opens With WalltoWall Optimisrn
description: HARTFORD, May .20 Connecticut's late  starting joyride into legalized gambling accelerated to 150 miles an hour here tonight as pelotas began bouncing like rifle shots off the granite front wall of the Hartford JaiAlai Fronton.

title: INOUYE AND CASE TO HEAD SPY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) Senators Daniel K. Inouy& of Hawaii and Clifford P. Case of New Jersey were named today as the senior Democratic and Republican members of the newly created Senate committee to monitor United States intelligence activities.

title: Burlington Mayor Says State Imperils a Federal Grant
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP. May 20Mayor Herman T. Costello of Burlington told state offcials today that a twoyear delay by the state in approving an application by the municipality for a Federal grant to upgrade a sewage treatment plant was jeopardizing millions of dollars in sorely needed construction.

title: Records: Women Composers
description: This anthology of music by famous women composers was assembled by Mamie Hall of the Vieuxtemps Quartet and suffers from a number of failings, all of which taken together don't detract from the interest of the project or its ultimate musical appeal.

title: Candidales in Both Parties  Campaign Hard in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore.President Ford and Jimmy Carter appear to hold substantial leads as Presidential campaigning focuses on this state, the most hotly contested of six where prima ries will be held next Tuesday.

title: The Faithful Pay Homage to Franco at His Tomb
description: VALLVY OF THE FALLEN. Spain, May 20Six months after the tleath of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, his most ervent folinwec; ioined his widow in a commemorative tonth today.

title: Committee to Draft Humphrey Is Set Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Political supporters of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, encouraged by setbacks to Jimmy Carter in the last 10 days, announced today the formation of a committee to draft the Minnesotan for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Senate Unit Votes Tax Aid In ChildCare by Relatives
description: WASHINGTON. May 20The Senate Finance Committee approved today a change in the tax laws that would permit working couples or single parents to write off part of the cost of paying a relative to care for their children, even if the relative lived in the same household.

title: Management
description: Five business and financial executives who are helping New York City resolve its financial difficulties agree that in many respects managing a city is more difficult than managing a business.

title: F.B.I. Bars Data on Ties To a Nashville Journalist
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Federal Bureau of Investigation refused today to answer specific Congressional question about its special relationship with a former Nashville newspaperwoman and how she came Into possession of a highly sensitive document that the bureau had reportedly authenticated.

title: The Who, What and When of 2 Journalism Teachers
description: Legend, like a jaunty halo, was shaped Wednesday night around a feisty 78yearold man who, from 1928 to 1955, as faculty adviser to the newspaper of DeWitt Clinton High. School, chastised, with a ruthless blue pencil, the writings of such protgs as James Baldwin, the novelist and essayist; Paddy Chayefsky, the playwright, and Maurice H. Nadjari, the special prosecutor.

title: Robber Seizes, Then Frees 7 Hostages
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 20A gunman released seven hostages and surrendered to :gents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation early this afternoon after firing several shots at city policemen and agents who had interrupted his attempted bank holdup.

title: On the First Amendment
description: BETHESDA, Md.The freespeech and freepress provisions of the First Amendment are getting quite a workout these days. Lawyers have been citing them on behalf of everything from bottomless dancing to freeing Federal election campaign subsidies.

title: Watch on Intelligence . .
description: When the temporary Senate intelligence investigating committee goes out of business in two weeks after fifteen months of productive and responsible work under the chairmanship of Senator Church, it will be succeeded by a permanent watchdog committee with real powers to oversee the disparate intelligence communityfirst such committee in the nation's history.

title: Shell Gasoline Up a Cent; Canadian Steel Is Higher
description: The Shell Oil Company increased its price for automotive gasoline yesterday by one cent a gallon in line with similar moves by competitors. The increase applies nationwide to all classes of trade resellers and consumers.

title: A Shortage of Monkeys Curbing Medical Research
description: GENEVA, May 20 (UPI)A shortage of monkeys for experimentation could reduce the safety of drugs and vaccines and seriously hamper medical research, the World Health Organization's Assembly has reported.

title: Jets Win, Lead Final Series, 10
description: HOUSTON, May 20 (UPI)Bobby Hull took the puck from a faceoff and fired it past Ron Grahame, the goalie, with 3:17 to play, lifting the Winnipeg Jets to a 43 victory over the Houston Acros tonight in the first game of the World Hockey Association championship series.

title: RADIO
description: 67:30 A.M., WNYCFM: Masterwork Hour. Sonata in C, Vejvanovsky; Slovak Suite. Novak; Piano Concerto No. 1, Brahms. 7:308:55, WNYCFM: Mornings With Music. Peter Schmoll Overture, Weber; Sonata in A minor for Recorder, and Violin, Telemann; Organ Concerto No. 13, Handel; Divertissement. Ibert; Flute Sonatine, Sancan.

title: Radioactive Material Found in Oceans
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A Federal scientist has reported discovering traces of plutonium and cesium contaminating the ocean floor off the east and west coasts of the United States.

title: Legal CellingIn of Foster Children
description: Foster care in New York State, which costs taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year, is a barbaric system in which adults, cloaking themselves in good intentions, commit injustices on children.

title: A TENTATIVE PACT REACHED AT POST
description: A tentative settlement was reached early today in negotiations between the New York Post and the Newspaper Guild, the guild announced.

title: RELATIVE OF HUGHES SUES TO BAR WILL
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev., May 20 (UPI)Annette Gano Lummis, the closest living relative to Howard R. Hughes, said yesterday in a court petition that the purported will of the late billionaire found in Salt Lake City was a forgery and a fraud.

title: Money And Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The cynical view of this capital is that it blathers a lot about the evils of money and secrecy but does very little about either of them. The popular charge is that it cannot or will not correct its own weaknesses, but the indictment 3 not quite true.

title: VINCENT SWEENEY, 92, RETIRED MAGISTRATE
description: Vincent J. Sweeney, a policeman who rose to second deputy commissioner and was appointed a magistrate in 1935 by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, serving until 1951, died May 13 in the Barnhill Convalescent Center, Newton, N. J. He was 92 years old and lived on Sweeney Road, Glen Spey, N.Y.

title: Dancing in the Air at Guggenheim
description: Man's desire to move through the air is as old as Icarus. Among those who have taken to the air more recently is the Multigravitational Aerodance Group, which will perform at 8 o'clock tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Justice Dept. Politics Decried by Bar Group
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)  The American Bar Association recommended to Congress today that it deny the post of Attorney General to anyone who has worked for the election of a President, and that it set a fixed term for the Director of the. Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE FIRST time the Beatles came to do American tour, this was the place we came to. Paul McCartney recalled at his staid East Side hotel room before his first performance in the New York area in 10 years tonight at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island. Mr. McCartney and his new band, Wings, will also be at Madison Square Garden Monday and Tuesday. The nearly 60,000 tickets for all three shows were sold out within hours weeks ago, and scalpers prices are likely to reach $100 by show times.

title: FUTURES IN SUGAR SHOW SHARP GAIN1
description: Two major purchases, one from the United States and one from South America, apparently. animated the world sugar market yesterday, sending prices higher. The July delivery on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange closed at 14.40 cents a pound, up from 14.08.

title: Egypt Said To Rebuff Demand
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20Informed Arab diplomats said that Egypt had demanded the postponement of the meeting in Saudi Arabia aimed at an EgyptianSyrian reconciliation.:

title: Denial by Kennedy
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, asked if a published report was true in stating that he had changed his mind and decided to accept a draft for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said: No.. My position is unchanged. Page A 16.

title: Critic's Choice: Most Royal Dane
description: Peter Martins is living proof that for every dancer there seems to be a time for greatnessa time, rather, when the promise of greatness is fulfilled. Sometimes it will be an individual performance, sometimes a season, sometimes, almost imperceptibly, simply time. For Mr. Martins, the Royal Danish star of New York City Ballet, greatness may be said to have been a long time growing.

title: CHURCH OPENS BID FOR OREGON VOTES
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 20Buoyed by his recent Nebraska victory, Senator Frank Church of Idaho began a fiveday campaign here today in an attempt towin the Democratic primary next Tuesday.

title: On Saturday, VIP's Are Just Folks
description: For Bella Abzug, one answer is swimming in a friend's pool in Connecticut. For Diane Von Furstenberg, it's gallery hopping in SoHo. And for Bobby Short, it's bicycling to Greenwich Village for lunch at Trattoria da Alfredo, better known as Alfredo's.

title: A Boycott of Coffee Urged by Supermarket
description: NEWARK, May 20 (UPI)In a move to force down rising prices, a supermarket chain wants its customers to stop buying coffee.

title: Arabs Try to Revive EgyptSyria Talks
description: RIYADH. Saudi Arabia, May 20The Foreign Minister of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, were reported to be planning to visit Cairo soon to attempt to salvage a reconciliadon meeting between Egypt land Syria that was canceled at the last minute yesterday.

title: Politics Hobbles EuropeanArab Talks
description: LUXEMBOURG, May 20Representatives of the European Common Market and the 20member Arab League today ended three days of talks during which the Arabs demanded political support in return for economic cooperation.

title: SUSPECT IS GUILTY OF KNIGHT MURDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP)A jury convicted Salvatore Soli of firstdegree murder tonight in the stabbing of John S. Knight 3d, an heir to the KnightRidder newspaper fortune and an editor for The Philadelphia Daily News.

title: Saudi King Urges Freeze Of West's Export Prices
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 20King Khalid of Saudi Arabia urged industrial nations today to freeze the prices of their [exported] products hinting that Saudi Arabia might switch its stand to favoring oilprice rises if this were not done.

title: Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn Is Accused of Taking Gifts
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with accepting gifts from a law firm whose members regularly appeared before him and with lying under oath to a judicial disciplinary group that was investiaatine him.

title: U.S ASSURES NATO POLICY STAYS FIRM
description: OSLO, May 20Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger promised the North Atlantic allies today that United States foreign policy would support a firm defense of the West against Soviet military and ideological aggression, no matter which candidate won the Presidential election this fall.

title: Money Supply Up Steeply, By $2 Billion, Last Week
description: The nation's basic money supply showed a steep $2 billion increase in the week ended May 12, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Mott St. Sunday Mornings
description: Soon Leong was saying over yum chah early Sunday morning that he's just about ready to retire.

title: India's Economy Is on the Rise, World Bank Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A study by the Woria Bank has found a substantial improvement in the economy of India but has warned that generous foreign aid will be essential if the present opportunities are to he exoloited.

title: Anything Goes at the. Galleries
description: WHAT Philip Johnson said not long ago of architecture is equally true of art. Let us celebrate the death of the ide fixe, he said. There are no rules, only facts, There is no order, only preferences.

title: Chicago Symphony Sets Radio Series
description: Largely on the strength of Sir Georg Solti's soaring reputation as one of the country's foremost conductors, performances of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under Sir Georg's leadership are to be syndicated weekly next fall to radio stations in nearly 100 cities. The Chicago orchestra thus will join the New York Philharmonic and the symphony orchestras of Boston, . Cleveland, Philadelphia and St. Louis in national radio distribution.

title: SEC , PLANS SUIT OVER PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to bring suit shortly against one of the comIpanies that have come forward under its socalled voluntary program for admitting quetI tionable payments, a senior enIforcement official said today.

description: Grace Glueck

description: Horses listed In order of nost Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: P.U.C. Approves Request To End 6 Transport Lines
description: NEWARK. May 20 The State Board of Public Utility ConunLssioners approved todays request by Transport of New Jersey. New Jersey's largest bus company, to discontinue six routes in the northern part of the state but denied the company's plans to end service on five other routes.

title: How to Get There
description: The area is crisscrossed by subway lines and bu routes. Perhaps the most convenient place to begin would be to take a subway to the Atlantic Avenue station (or the Pacific Street station right next to it).. Almost all of the subway lines stop at one of the two stations, but the most enjoyable trip with a panorama of the harbor is on the D or N train over the Manhattan Bridge. The Long Island Rail Road also goes to Atlantic Avenue. By car from Manhattan, the Manhattan Bridge to Atlantic Avenue is the most direct route.

title: Exxon Votes 2for1 Split; Divestiture Plans Scored
description: BOSTON, May 20Stockholders at the annual meeting of the Exxon Corporation were treated here today to the unexpected announcement that the directors of the company had voted to recommend a 2for1 split of the company's stock.

title: Judges Will Review Conviction of Manson
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 (UPI)A threejudge appellate panel agreed from to review the convictions of Charles Manson and three members of his cult, now serving life prison sentences for the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six other persons.

title: Ground Bone in Meat Products Called Peril by Nutrition Expert
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UN) A nutrition spokesman warned today that there may be dangers for consumers in a new Agriculture Department proposal to let processors include traces of groundup bone in meat products.

title: New Endorsements Aid Carter Chances
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A littlenoticed series of endorsements from key Democratic officials in the larger states has enhanced Jimmy Carter's prospects of winning his party's Presidential nomination despite his recent primary losses and the probability of more to come.

title: Regional Proposal
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, proposed yesterday the creation of a regional Reconstruction Finance Corporation to help rebuild the sagging economies of the Northeast. Page A18.

title: Art: Cletus Johnson's Theaters
description: TWO years ago, an unknown artistCletus Johnson  caused a bit of a stir in a show of New Talent at the A.M. Sachs Gallery with his astonishing theaters. These were shadowbox constructions of imaginary moviepalace entrances and facades painted a ghostly monochrome gray and embellished with beguiling architectural details and eerie, tiny lights.

title: The Labor Scene
description: Among the sweatsuited joggers in Central Park these spring mornings is the man who may cast the critical vote on the union side when contract negotiations between the General Electric Company and its 113,800 unionized employees reach the showdown stage June 27.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 21, 1976

title: TKTS Is a Hit in Duffy Sq.
description: One day last week 200 people arrived in New York from Cleveland, Tenn. They went over to the Times Square Theater Center (TKTS) in Duffy Square (Broadway at 47th Street) andat half the boxoffice pricepurchased 150 seats to the musical Shenandoah and 50 tickets to other shows, primarily The Norman Conquests.

title: Gotbaurn Hopeful Unions Will Agree on Productivity
description: The head of the Municipal Labor Committee, in the first substantive response to the tough wage policy laid down by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, said yesterday that the municipal labor unions in New York could live within the board's rules, which require that any increase in pay be financed by productivity.

title: H. Carlton Brett Jr. Marries Amy Gold
description: Amy Gold, manager of the New York, Employees Store of Burlington Industries, was married here. yesterday afternoon to H. Carlton Brett Jr. of Darien, Conn., a marketing services consultant with Jim Sant'Andrea Inc.

title: Texas Greets Giscard and His SST With Open Arms
description: HOUSTON, May 20It slid into Houston like one of those skinny loaves of French bread they used to fly in from Paris in the oil boom days when conspicuous consumption still mattered and oilfield barons like the Schlumbergers dismissed the local loaf as gauche.

description: BASEBALL

title: Philadelphia Story
description: The Mayor and City Council this week are trimming millions of dollars from the budget for the next fiscal year, imposing big increases in old taxes and creating several new ones, freezing workers salaries, authorizing longtermiloans to pay shortterm debts and still wondering if all that would be enough to keep the city afloat.

title: Agreement at Post
description: Tentative settlement on a new contract was reached early this morning by negotiators for The New York Post and the Newspaper Guild, according to a union spokesman. Details were not disclosed. Page B 18.

title: NEW YORK'S G.O.P. REPORTED MOVING TO ENDORSE FORD
description: New York Republican leaders are preparing to abandon their uncommitted stance and endorse President Ford to bolster his candidacy, state Republican officials said yesterday.

title: Superintendent and Dog: Friends Take Their Side
description: A 6yearold girl, a 75yearold man and ramerous people whose age fell between showed up in Criminal Court in Queens yesterday to defend the character of the defendants in case No. Q613987. involving a Kew Gardens building superintendent and a large, aging red dog.

description: The British Broadcasting Corporation announced yesterday that it will produce for television all 37 plays by Shakespeare over a sixyear period, with a view toward creating a recorded library for future educational use.

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE was a point late in Stanley Elkin's latest novel, The Franchiser, when the slumbering beast of my curiosity over what happens next to Mr. Elkin's hero, Ben Flesh, began to yawn and stretch and shake itself awake, when I suddenly found myself reading little faster. This point came just after Flesh had decided to give up some of his franchisesto close down his H. & R. Block office, his Fotomat, his Evelyn Wood (They're reading so fast now they're reading us out of business. Publishing's in hot water . . . IT we want to keep up with the times we have to slow down, go back to the old We have to teach them to move

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report in The Times on Tuesday on the arrival of President Valdry Giscard d'Estaing of France, the Society of the Cincinnati was incorrectly identified. The society, which includes the descandants of both American and French officers who fought in the American Revolution, was formed by George Washington and his officers.

title: PARENTS / CHILDREN
description: The 24yearold mechanic inhaled, then exhaled, thenprolonging the first syllable in the sentencehe fluently recalled the first time he started to worry about his stuttering.

title: Microwave Landing System For Jets Is Demonstrated
description: POMONA, N.J., May 19 (AP) Officials at the Federal Aviation Administration's testing facility here have unveiled a $60 million experimental microwave landing system that they hope will become standard in the jet planes of the 1980's.

title: Barry Lyndon
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 (UPI)  In characteristic dry humor, The Harvard Lampoon released its 36th annual list of movie worst awards.

title: Greece to Give Bribe Data
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (Reuters)Greece today became the sixth nation to enter an .agreement to exchange evidence with the Justice Department in the Lockheed Aircraft Coriforation bribery scandal.

title: DR. PAUL CROSSER, ECONOMIST, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Paul Crosser, a former economics professor at Ade1phi University and City College of New York and author of several books on economics, died Wednesday night of cardiac arrest at Roosevelt Hospital. He lived at 140 West End Avenue.

title: Marti Cards a 65, Takes 2 hot Lead
description: MEMPHIS, May 20 (AP)Fred Marti chipped the ball in on consecutive holes, then set up a tapin eagle as he played his last five holes in six under par today and captured the lead with a 65 in the $200,000 Danny ThomasMemphis Golf Classic.

title: Building Service Nearly Back to Normal
description: Building service operations were close to normal in most apartment buildings yesterday following the settlement of the 17day strike and the return of employees to their jobs.

title: Back Home to Peoria and a Sequel to eminine Mystique
description: PEORIA, Ill.Betty. Goldstein, a young girl who thought so fast that she tripped over her words, and who had to be given a nonspeaking role in her high school play, left Peoria more than three decades  ago. She returned in 1963 for her 25th class reunion, a Smith College graduate, wife, mother and justpublished author. The name on her book jacket was Betty Friedan, and the book was called The Feminine Mystique.

title: THE SUNSHINE BILL GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 20The Assembly overwhelmingly approved a. bill today requiring school boards, city councils and other public bodiesincluding the New York City Board of Estimate and the Emergency Financial Control Boardto open all but a few of their deliberations to the public.

title: About Real Estate
description: There is a certain dismal pequence of community events that has become increasingly familiar in recent years. A neighborhood of apartments and owneroc.cupied homes is stable and Attractive, but suddenly one major property starts to slide downhill. There is a rapid tenancy turnover and maintenance declines.

title: Excerpts From King Khalid's Written Answers

title: Fast Dutch Campus Reform Has Made Some Furious
description: AMSTERDAMStudent demands for university reform in the Netherlands achieved more immediate and farreaching results than elsewhere in Western Europe. So farreaching are the results that protests are not largely limited to teachers who believe that the changes are threatening their freedom to teach.

title: Mike Casale, Racing Writer And Handicapper, Dies, 73
description: Mike Casale, a thoroughbredracing writer and handicapper for more than half a century, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Tully Houselights Dim for Mostly Ushers
description: The ushers at Alice Tully Hall, who have to listen to concerts night after night, sometimes feel that they lave as much right to be onstage as ,,the performers they hear. Now nine of them will have that chance. They will give a free chambermusic concert in the hall at Lincoln Center at 2 P.M. tomorrow

Women, for instance, have been making great social and economic gains in recent years, but Bach scholars have simultaneously been working to put them in their placethe place, that is, that women occupied in church music before the liberating influences of the 19th century began to be felt.

title: Strange, Ridley Gain In NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 20 (AP)  Fred Ridley, who never led until the final hole, and Curtis Strange, who fell behind briefly for the first time in the tournament, recovered today to reach the semifinal round of the 76th North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: Cheating Charge Held .Unfounded
description: MONTE CAIILO, Monaco, May 20Allegations of cheating at bridge brought against some members of Italy's world champion team have been judged to be unfounded.

title: Arabs in Jerusalem Stone Israeli Bus, Driver Fires Pistol
description: JERUSALEM, May 20 (AP)Arab youths in Israelioccupied East Jerusalem attacked an Israeli bus with stones today and the driver fired a pistol into the air to break through makeshift roadblock.

title: Oil Slick Moving in Gulf
description: MIAMI. May 20 (UPI)A 30 mitesong oil slick moved northward from Key Largo in the Gulf of Mexico today but a Coast Guard spokesman said it appeared to have moved a little farther away from shore. The Coast Guard has a team of oil spill specialists in Miami, zwaiting deployment if the slick changed its course and headed toward Florida Gold Coast beaches.

description: FRIDAY, MAY 21, 1976

title: Carter's Nuclear Blast
description: Former Gov. Jimmy Carter's call a few days ago for summitlevel approach to the leaders of West Germany and France to halt the export of plutonium reprocessing plants, which produce atomic explosives, raised a campaign issue of major importance.

description: BASEBALL

title: Film Forum: Owl Weds Goose
description: THE SECOND part of the Film Forum's anthology of new cartoons opened yesterday. It shows signs of running out of steam. That could be a tribute to the completeness of the effort, perhaps there Was not that much left to show.

title: Osborne Angry At U.S. Mores
description: LONDON. May 20 (Reuters) John Osborne, the British playwright who was called an angry young man orthe 1950's, returned today ftom a visit to the United States and said: It is utterly ludicrous over there. They are so idiotic it almost makes you hope that if there was a war, the Russians would win.

title: WALTER R. MILLER, 72, LED A SAVINGS BANK
description: Walter R. Miller, former] chairman of the Metropolitan Savings Bank, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: Around the Clock With Jazz Interactions
description: Hundreds of jazz musicians will be playingthree groups at a time in three separate rooms. They, will be, playing everything from recreations of early secordings by Louis Armstrong and Beiderbecke to swing, bebop, free form, and jazz/ rock, and they will keep playing from 5 in the afternoon on Sunday until sometime in the wee hours Monday morning.

title: Weiss Will Seek Seat to Be Vacated By Abzug's Plans
description: Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, who has represented a West Side district in the Cocacil since 1962, announced yesterday his candidacy for the seat in the House of Representatives being vacated by Bella S. Abzug. Mrs. Abzug is seeking. the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

title: Ashe. Rallies to Defeat Rosewall in Four Sets and Advance to Challenge Cup Final
description: HONOLULU, May. 20Ken Rosewall gave. away six inches in height, 15 pounds in weight and 11 years in age last night in his winnertakeall, 550,000 World Championship of TennisAvis Challenge Cup semifinal match against Arthur Ashe. But it was Ashes superior tirepowerrather than Rosewall:s age or physical limitations that meant the difference as Ashe turned back the 41yearold Australian veteran, 26, 64, 62, 6.2, before a crowd of 5,000 at the Blaisdell Center here.

title: R. H. Macy Shows Profit; It Had Loss in 75 Quarter
description: R. H. Macy & Company, the metropolitan area's biggest retailer, reported yesterday a $347,000 profit in the third fiscal quarter to May 1 in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $1.2 million.

title: EXECUTIONS OF TWO DENIED BY PEKING
description: PEKING, May 20 (Agencel FrancePresse)The Informa1 tion Department of the Chinese Foreign Ministry today denied that two persons alleged to have taken part in last month's Tien An Men Square riots had been executed.

title: 3 Senior Cadets Charged With Possessing Marijuana
description: Three senior cadets at the United States Military aeademy have been charged with marijuana possession. school officials in West. Point confirmed according to United Press International.

description: BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP)1 Frank Roberts, a Baltimorearea sportsman and tennis player,, died today at the age of 75.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Chrysler Corporation is moving closer to a position that would permit it to resume dividend payments, the two top officers of the nation's thirdranking automotive company said yesterday.

description: Daniel Yankelovich, the social. scientist, and Cyrus R. title: Last Smallpox Cases

title: Screen: Chabrol On Love's Wars
description: WHEN WE first meet Philippe (Paul Gegauff) and Esther (Danielle Gegauff) they seem an ideally happy couple. They're handsome, healthy, loving, exceedingly well-off. They've been together eight years. They have a bright, sweet daughter, who is 6, and they live in a fine old country house surrounded by lawns, rose hedges and orchards. On weekends friends come out from Paris for good talk and food and companionship.Even after eight years Philippe and Esther seem to be as sexually excited by each other as they were when they first met. Philippe has the kind of self-absorption carried easily only by the talented or the truly upperclass. His arrogance and conceit have been a form of reassurance for a middleclass girl whom Philippe has transformed into a perfect wife-mistress. Esther listens to everything Philippe says. He listens to her when it amuses him.On its surface Claude Chabrol's "Une Partie de Plaisir," which has opened at the Juliet 1, is the report of what happens when Philippe decides that after eight years both he and Esther should be secure enough in each other's love to have outside affairs. "Preventative medicine," is what Philippe calls them. The film is much more interesting and more haunting, though, as a meditation on love, on the complex system of balances that work in any love relationship, and on the furies that can be let loose within such relationships when the balances are disturbed.Almost all of Mr. Chabrol's recent filmsmost importantly "La Femme Infidele" and "Just Before Nightfall"have dealt with the revelation of hidden flaws in supposedly perfect relationships, but always in the virtually abstract terms of melodrama. I say abstract because unlike the characters in these Chabrol films, few of us are driven to murder, and those few who do don't then go to such extraordinary lengths to hide the deeds. For most of us murder is a concept as remote as the Pythagorean proposition."Une Partie de Plaisir" is not a melodrama. Nor is it remote. It's almost a comedy, and it's intensely bitter and cruel. The film focuses mostly on the demonically egocentric Philippe, but it's Esther who emerges as the more interesting character. In the course of the film it's Esther who grows up and away from Philippe, even though torn by her old dependence on him to the point where she actively participates in his humiliation of her.Not since "Les Biches" has Mr. Chabrol so wittily (and mercilessly) examined the wars that are fought in life's living rooms and bedrooms, in kitchens and over dining room tables with friends as neutral, sometimes amused, sometimes appalled observers. It's a fascinating film and a very harrowing one.Mr. Gegauff, who has written many of Chabrol screenplays, including those for "Les Biches" and this film, is supremely self-confident and alienating as Phillippe, for which he even has the right physique  fastidiously cared for but not so successfully that the first signs of age aren't apparent in the clothes he wears. They are always just a little too tight, a little too young and modish for the fellow he really is. He's a man who would spend more time doing his hair than his wife would.Miss Gegauff, whom I've never seen before and who is Mrs. Gegauff in private life, is a stunning actress with large gray-green eyes, almost like a cat's, and a beauty that has as much to do with manners and expressions as with nose and jaw lines. That she remains for us someone almost as mysterious as she becomes to her husbandwho never has the slightest understanding why she finally leaves himprevents the film from turning into a predictable treatise on open marriage. "Une Partie de Plaisir" explores emotional territories  dependencies, actually  much closer to home and much more dangerous.

title: Asikloe Greeted In Style
description: The Ashanti Bazaar celebrated an asikloe recently. A Ghanaian band played on a drum, a guitar and a stringed gourd called a shakarey, as models swirled by in caftans and bubus made of batiks and the fascinating embroideries of the African tribes. The guests drank champagne punch since the traditional palm wine wasn't available.

title: Phils Top Mets And Seaver, 53
description: Hours before the Yankees played the Boston Red Sox in the Bronx last night. New York lost the Queens half of a rare interborough doubleheader when the Philadephia Phillies defeated Torn Seaver and the Mets, 53, for sweep of their twogame series.

title: Antiques
description: GLASS dazzlerslacy plates, emeraldgreen sugar bowls and cobaltblue candlesticksare what Jennie H. Sinclair scoured New England for in her chauffeurdriven Locomobile a half century ago. And that is what she found among hundeds of other examples of 19thcentury American pressed and molded glass, all of it equal in quality to the stunning and larger collection on view at the Sandwich (Mass.) Museum on Cape Cod.

title: David Smith Art at Storm King
description: In a sleepy hollow nestled in the rolling hills that overlook the Hudson River, the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville is waking from its winter nap.

title: Gotbaum Hopeful Unions Will Agree on Productivity
description: The head of the Municipal Labor Committee, in the first substantive response to the tough wage policy laid down by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, said yesterday that the municipal labor unions in New York could live within the board's rules, which require that any increase in pay be financed by productivity.

title: East Germans, Living Well, Hope for Further Gains
description: EAST BERLINTwo East German delivery foremen, both Communist Party members, finished a hot day's work the other day and dropped in at a small cafe off the Friedrichstrasse for a cold pilsner beer brewed in Dresden.

title: Events and Openings
description: Today

title: Beame Won't Resist Transfer Of School Funds to Districts
description: Mayor Beame indicated yesterday that he would not veto the reallocation of several million dollars to community school boards from the Board of Education's proposed 1977 budget. This money would go toward restoring full school days and reducing class sizes.

title: O'Casey's Juno Sings
description: NEW HAVEN, May 20 Marc Blitzstein's Juno, a musical version of Juno and the Paycock, failed on Broadway in 1959. A successful revival of the original O'Casey play was done at the Long Wharf Theater in 1973, starring Geraldine Fitzgerald. Now Long Wharf revisits O'Casey with a new version of the Blitzstein musical, retitled Dearlin Juno. The show opened last night and will continue through June 11.

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Advance
description: Buoyed by some encouraengi economic news prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Legislative Leaders Call Save Income Tax
description: TRENTON, May 21Legislative leaders today scheduled al Save the Income Tax meeting for 10 A.M. Monday.

title: Met Opera Board Revamps Organization
description: The Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday tlie first reorganization of its board of directors in 18 years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was reported erroneously in The Times yesterday that Sister Maryellen Harmon, the newly appointed school superintendent for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit, was the first woman to head a major parochial system. The first was Sister Elinor R. Ford, a school superintendent in the New York Archdiocese from 1972 through 1975.

title: FUTURES UP k BIT IN SOYBEAN MEAL
description: Heavy selling of soybean meal by Cargill Inc. led to a busy 30 minutes of liquidation on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, but then prices moved up to close a little higher on the day, continuing their long uptrend.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: NBC Union Votes to Accept New Pact, Ending Stoppage
description: News writers, engineers and technicians of the National Broadcasting Company voted yesterday to ratify a fouryear contract settlement reached. last Tuesday and will report back to work next Monday, ending a work stoppage that began on April 1, union spokesmen in Washington reported last night.

title: ACCORD AT POST AVERTS A STRIKE
description: The New York Post and the Newspaper Guildrepresenting news, business and circulation employeesreached an accord early yesterday on a new twoyear agreemnt, thereby averting a strike.

title: Jersey Acts to Lift License Of SurgeoninCurareCase
description: The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners acted yesterday to suspend temporarily the license of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the 48yearold surgeon who was indicted this week on charges of murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, N. S., a decade ago.

title: Mayor of Italian Quake Area Quits After Press Criticism
description: UDINE, Italy, May 21 (Reuters)The Communist mayor of a northeast Italian town hit by the violent earthquake two weeks ago has resigned over newspaper allegations that he may have been responsible for the collapse of an apartment house that killed 92 people.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 22, 1976

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Con Ed Gets Rate Rise

title: Filly Triple Crown
description: While racing's top 3yearold colts await the final leg of the uppercase Triple Crown, its best 3yearold fillies will square off today at Belmont Park, in the first leg of the lowercase At the triple crown. When raoeRace trackers talk Tracks about best 3yearold fillies, they mean Optimistic Gal and Dearly Precious. These two and seven others are entered in the $55,900 Acorn Stakes, the onemile test that begins what the New York Racing Association calls the filly triple crown.

title: GrassRoots
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 21 It takes strong convictions to run as a delegate supporting Ronald Reagan in New Jersey's Republican Presidential pimary election.

title: Consumer Notes
description: A new group has been formed in New Jersey to clarify labeling information on food products that a majority of women in a recent Gallup Poll found confusing.

title: Personal Whistle Alerts Fireman if Air Runs Low
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Breathing apparatus that was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has attracted wide interest as emergency equip ment for firemen. Compressed air is delivered to the wearer through a face mask, in which a whistle warns him if the pressure is getting low. The inventors named in Patent 3,057,044 are John L. Sullivan. Eugene A. Giorgini and Milo R. Simmons, engineers for the Scott Aviation division of ATO Inc., Lancaster, N. Y.

title: Notes on People
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke flew to Venice yesterday to visit earthquakedamaged sites in northern Italy before going to Rome for Monday's Consistory, ttte ceremonies relating to the creation of new cardinals.

title: NATO SAYS SOVIET IMPERILS DETENTE
description: OSLO, May 21A strong warning that the Soviet Union is endangering detente by continuing a military buildup in Central Europe and by lack of restraint elsewhere concluded the twoday meeting of 13 foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here today.

title: LANDLORD GROUP CHALLENGES PACT
description: A group of landlords dissatisfied with the new contract with apartment  house employees planned yesterday to challenge the Realty Advisory Board, which had conducted negotiations for the employers.

title: G.M. Sees 2dBest Sales Year in 1977
description: DETROIT, May 21Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that the new smaller cats the corporation will introduce next fall should help the automobile industry have its second best sales year.

title: Principals in Quinlan Case Shun Initiative on Decision
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 21 Seven weeks after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that Karen Anne Quinlan should be allowed to die, her parents and physicians appear to be moving with reluctance and caution toward letting that happen.

title: Conflict in Lebanon Sharpens Rivalries Among the Arab Countries
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 21The Lebanese civil war has sharpened old rivalries in the Arab world and created some new ones, and the seemingly United Arab camp at the time of the 1973 war

title: Marti 133 Leads Golf By 2 Shots
description: MEMPHIS, May 21 (AP)Fred Marti, again saving his best until the end, birdied the last two holes for a 68 and regained a twoshot lead today in the second round of the $200,000 Danny ThomasMemphis golf tournament.

title: St. John's Edges Rutgers Nine, 10
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 In a game shortened by rain; St. John's topped Rutgers, 10, in the first round today of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference baseball playoff at Clark Field.

title: A Migrant Labor Pool
description: OSLOWest Europe's impressive economic recovery after the disruption and destruction of World War II depended upon four key factors: (1) provision of adequate investment funds, as initially made possible through the Marshall Plan; (2) systematizing markets and tariffs as provided in the European Economic Community (E.E.C.); (3) availability of ample supplies of reasonably priced energy; and (4) a generous reservoir of labor.

title: Crime Control Board Head Is Sworn In by Governor
description: Richard L. Gelb, president and chief executive officer of the BristolMyers Company, who was appointed by Governor Carey as a member and chairman of the Crime Control Planning Board, was sworn in yesterday at the Governor's offire here

title: Mail Union Chief to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) James A. Rademacher, head of the 200,000member National Association of Letter Carriers. announced today that he would. retire as president in January because of union disunity.

title: The Other News
description: Internatiohal

title: Books of The Times
description: Quick, name an outstanding living mathematician. If you're an average Amercan, the chances you can do this are almost zero. Mathematicians are perhaps the last large important group of Americans to retain their privacy in this postWatergate world. Even the press has virtually given upon trying to report about who's who and what's what in the mathematical world. Reporters who are fearless when asked to expose the mysteries of DNA's double helix, or of quasars, pulsars and plate tectonics, quail and flee when faced by the challenge of category theory or functional analysis.

title: BILL HOROWITZ SINGS AT FOLK CITY STAND
description: Bill Horowitz, who performs at Folk City through tomorrow, has been acquiring a reputation as one of the more promising young singers and song writers around town. If the set this reviewer heard is an accurate indication, his more personal songs are the basis of his reputation, not his nautical ones.

title: Mews Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 22, 1976

title: Miss Cook Is Wed To Joel Garreau
description: Adrienne Cook, consumer columnist for The Saturday Times, and Joel R. Garreau, a senior editor of The Evening Times, both part of The Trenton Times publishing group, were married yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's farm in West Amwell, N.J. Mayor John Williamson perfrmed the ceremony.

title: MARITIME DAY MARKED AT GOVERNORS ISLAND: Wreaths being cast from the Coast Guard cutter Sauk to honor those who have died at sea.
description: The New York limo/Tyrone Dukes National Maritime Day, a tribute to the merchant marine, commemorates first transatlantic voyage by a U.S. steamship, the Savannah, in 1819.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein has recommended that law enforcement officials develop tough policy in dealing with those who use firearms commit crimes. In remarks to local and state law enforcement officials at the 25th Eastern Regional Armed Robbery Conference in South Plainfield. Mr. Goldstein said criminals who usa firearms should be given mandatory prison terms. Mr. Goldstein recommended eliminating pleabargaining or compromising with those convicted of using firearms to commit a crime.

title: State Board Is Seeking Changes In Rules on Financial Disclosure
description: The State Board of Public Disclosure established by Governor Carey to oversee his order that certain state officials disclose their financial assets agreed yesterday to ask him to modify some aspects of the directive.

description: The Democrats are likely to run for the Presidency this year on the best economic issue left to them jobs.

title: END OF BAN URGED ON LAKE ERIE GAS
description: The immediate repeal of th state law that bars drilling for natural gas in Lake Erie was urged yesterday by the Council on the Economy, the new group formed by Governor Carey to strengthen business and em ployment in the city and the state.

description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 21 (AP)The Muhammad AliRichard Dunn world heavyweight title fight was turning into one of boxing's major financial busts today, with the loss to its West German promoters estimated at close to $500,000.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The International Trade Commission for the first time cut off today an antidumping case in its early stages under a new provision of the 1974 Trade Law. The commission found that there was no reasonable indication of injury to the domestic industry from imports of multimetal lithographic plates from Mexico, even if they were sold in the United States at dumping pricesprices lower than in the home market.

title: ANGOLA DISCLOSES PLAN ON MILITARY
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 21A plan published here today calls for the Central Committee of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola to assume direct political control over the armed forces, in the pattern of political party control over the armed forces in Communist countries.

title: 65 Pianists Put Fortes Forward for the Leventritt
description: Simply put, Andrew Willis was playing his heart out.

title: Insurance Adjuster Jailed
description: BELVIDERE, N.J., May 21 (AP)Ari insurance adjuster as been given a oneyeartotwoyear prison sentence in connection with a pair of 1974 fires that destroyed the home of Netcong's former police chief and a Belvidere diner. Judge Bertram Polow of Superior Court imposed the sentence yesterday on Samuel Moccio of Flanders, who had been convicted of conspiracy arson Ind fraud. Last month, Judge Polow sentenced former Police Zhief Andrew Gugliemini, Mr. Moccio's codefendant, to twoyearstothreeyears in jail for his role in the conspiracy.

title: B1 Politics (Cont.)
description: President Ford's political exploitation of the B1 bomber has been delivered a welldeserved rebuff in the Senate. The story is far from over, but a thin margin of Senators was assembled on Thursday to postpone until the next Administration a decision whether to put this costly strategic aircraft into production.

title: Selling on Sunday Rising Despite Confusing Laws
description: In New Jersey, shoppers scurry from one county to another, or even into Delaware, to shop on Sunday. In Atlanta, major supermarket chains, including the A.&P., have recently adopted allnight and sevenday hours. And in New York City alone, tens of thousands of businesses each year, with the tacit complicity of the authorities, blithely ignore Sunday selling bans that go back to the 17th century.

title: MOLLY CUNNINGHAM, LEGISLATOR, 88, DIES
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 21Mary V. Z. (Molly) Cunningham, a former state repreIsentative from New Canaan in the Connecticut General Assembly and former executive director of the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. John Nickerson 3d, on Valley Road here. She was 88 years old.

title: Liggett Group Told To Divest Company Of Perk Foods Unit
description: The Liggett group said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had ruled that the company must divest itself of its Perk Foods subsidiary. The F. T. C., which made its first complaint regardine the acquisition in June1973, said the acquisition violated Section 7 of the Clayton Act, which prohibits mergers that tend to limit competition. Raymond J. Mulligan, president of Liggett, formerly named Liggett & Myers, said that the acquisition was lawful and the company expected to file an appeal with the United States Court of Appeals.

title: ELECTION AGENCY OPERATING AGAIN; SUBSIDIES RESUME
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The flow of political subsidies to Presidential candidates and major parties was resumed today after a twomonth freeze when the Federal Election Commission was reconstituted by Congress and President Ford.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 21 (AP) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans to drill for natural gas in the middle of its production complex here and says that if the first effort succeeds, it has additional sites in mind.

title: Newark Bridge Closed
description: NEWARK, May 21 (AP)The Clay Street Bridge linking this city and East Newark will be closed Monday for 18 months so extensive repairs can he made, officials say The bridge across the Passaic River was opened to traffic in 1908. It one of three within a onemile section of the river that slated for renovation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, May 21 (AP)Houston McTear, a Florida schoolboy sensation who calls himself the best in the world at 100 yards, faces an elite field in a slightly longer race tomorrow in the eighth Martin Luther King International Freedom Games. The track and field meet, loaded with Olympic hopefuls, has drawn most of the world's top sprinters for a 100meter dash that could provide a recordshattering time under 9.9 seconds.

title: Weld Cracks Found In Alaska Pipeline; CoStlyDelayFeared
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Government officials disclosed today that they were reviewing what they called 3,955 problem welds on the Alaska oil pipeline.

title: Sale of Powerful Pill
description: An unemployed. man was charged yesterday with selling miniature explosive devices that look like cold pills but am capable of blowing up automobiles.

title: FORD MEETS LEVI TO DISCUSS BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, May 21President Ford met with Attorney General Edward H. Levi for about an hour this afternoon to discuss the Boston school busing case, but the meeting produced no final decision on whether the Ford Administration should intervene in the case.

title: Sutter's Closing After 50 Years in Village
description: Sutler's bakery and cafe, a Greenwich Village sweettooth landmark for 50 years, will close tomorrow. he allure or negouatioas on a new lease. which would have called for a sharp increase in rent, led to the decision on closing.

title: Dividend Notice
description: The Board of Directors has declared a quarterly dividend of 1212e per share on the Series A 5% preferred stock and 171/2c per share on the Series B and C 7% preferred stock of the Corporation. A dividend of Me per share was declared on the common stock.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES THE HEART BILL
description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Carey today, citing the need to wait for broad reform of the state's pension laws, vetoed measure that would have permanently established the presumption that heart ailments among policemen and firemen were job related.

title: HARRISES LOSE PLEA ON F.B.I. EVIDENCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 (AP)The State Supreme Court has rejected by 4 to yesterday efforts by William and Emily Harris to suppress evidence found in their San Francisco residence last Sept. 18.

title: 122 Yachts Set Sail at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21Under a clear, blue sky and with ideal weather conditions, a fleet of cruising yachts set sail from Larchmont Breakwater late this afternoon on the Larchmont Yacht Club's 21st annual distance race.

title: U.S. GETS WARNING ON URBAN NEEDS
description: Government in the United States has spread itself too thin in dealing with problems of urban areas and must realign responsibility for dealing with the needs of large cities, group of experts in the public and private sector agreed yesterday.

title: Ill Wind Blows No
description: GRANTS, N. M.On many a spring day, an ill wind blows no good through the high, dry open spaces of northcentral New Mexico.

description: BEVERLEY HILLS. Calif.. May 21  Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation told shareholders today that he expected the company's depressed earnings level to improve sharply this quarter, possibly doubling the firstquarter total of $20.4 millicn.

description: A fourweek payless furlough of City University workers, which was supposed to start next week, was tentatively called off yesterday by the university chancellor in the hope that further negotiations for emergency state aid might result in sufficient funds to carry the university through the end of June.

description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Nlay 21Italy has substan, tial hopes of a double victory iri,the world team Olympiad here, repeating its result in Miami Beach four years ago.

title: Film: 'Guernica,' Arrabal's Civil War
description: Fernando Arrabal is a precocious 43-year-old child who sits on the floor and tells totally made-up stories about the outside world. They eddy and change color, from ridiculous to obscene to puerile; but stars keep falling into them.As a playwright, Mr. Arrabal has his own lodging in the Theater of the Absurd: It is called the Theater of Panic. As a novice film maker, he charges the medium head on.There is a lot of damage any halfway competent movie director could have warned him about; and a measure of splintered brilliance that no halfway competent movie director could have dreamed of.In "Guernica," which opened at the 68th Street Playhouse yesterday, Mr. Arrabal, an exiled Spaniard, has given us his Civil War. It is grotesque and painful, absurdly obvious in parts, rough and chaotic almost throughout. It is almost totally one-sidedand yet in its own highly personal way it is authentic. It is the Civil War as nightmare, but its obscenity and ferocity are metaphors for tenderness.The setting is an imaginary village called Villa Romero, set in Extremadura, the most barren and backward of Spain's regions. With no subtlety at all, the film sets out its cast of characters.Vandale, played by Mariangela Melato, is a beautiful hermit, half-witch. Count Cerralbo is the rural landlord who rails against the Republic and the loss of his authority. He has three brutal sons who ride around assaulting peasant women and meeting in a cellar to plan their part in the Franco uprising.The fourth son, Goya, is a Surrealist artist who despises politics. He breaks up first-communion services by telling the children the wine is poisoned, paints obscene crucifixion scenes and sits through a scolding by his father while masturbating quietly into his brandy glass.The Nationalist rising takes place, but in Villa Romero it fails. The landlord's sons flee to join Franco's troops, the landlord climbs into the village school and is hidden by the schoolmaster, a Republican but an advocate of nonviolence.Vandale and Goya flee separately for France. They meet in the town of Guernica, fall in love instantly (a dove flies in slow motion from one to the other to symbolize it), and are separated when Guernica is bombed.She returns to Villa Romero and, no longer a hermit, rallies the villagers to fight the oncoming Franco troops. He gets an airplane and machine-guns the besiegers' cannons. Ultimatly the village falls, Vandale and Goya are made prisoner, and he is tortured. She manages to escape and free him. They climb to the mountains and against an enormous setting sun, embrace: symbols of a future Spanish liberation.That is the plot, with all its farfetched melodrama. The film's strength is elsewhere; in images that express the savage yearnings and excesses that were the fuel of a terrible civil war. Many of the villagers are dwarfs: Arrabal uses them to symbolize the oppression of a people. "Now we will be like everyone," one dwarf declaresit is a flash of painwhen the village invades the landlord's castle.There are other blinding sights. Children move in a slow-motion procession up a hill; the soundtrack alternates their guttural chanting with an anthem; the effect is to bind up in one image churchgoing and church-burning Spain. There is an unbearable but inspired scene after the Republic is defeated: A bullfighter, using all the gestures and postures of his art, fights and kills five dwarfs lashed to wheelbarrows. The audience is the army, the church, the upper classes; the national anthem plays.These things, intolerable as they may seem, succeed beyond all reasonable expectations. Many other things fail; and the film's technical carelessness (it is filmed in Italy but even the Italian dubbing is sloppyat one point Miss Melato is speaking Italian and the crowd is answering in Spanish drags it down further.Miss Melato is a good actress but she doesn't have the force for the role. Her singing of one of the great Civil War songs is almost prim. On the other hand the American actor Ron Faber, playing Goya, makes a first-rate Spaniard.Rough, ridiculous, arbitrary: "Guernica" is a film designed to make the spectator fight it. The remarkable thing is that it frequently wins.

title: Grievances Muted on Juan Carlos Tour of Realm
description: OVIEDO, Spain, May 19Whatever the political grievances of the Spanish people, they are not raised in the (presence of King Juan Carlos when he tours his realm.

title: Reagan Says He Opposes Limited War
description: NASHVILLE, May 21Ronald Reagan declared today that he was opposed to the concept of limited war, but in answer to a question as to whether he would use nuclear weapons to end a war quickly, he would say only, Everyone hopes and prays that never will the world come to a nuclear confrontation.

title: People in Sports
description: The Buckey twins, Dave and Don, who were chosen on consecutive picks in the 12th round of the National Football League draft have both signed contracts with the New York Jets. The two played at North Carolina State under the Jets coach, Lou Holtz. Dave, a quarterback, broke Roman Gabriel's school career total offense record by gaining 4,787 yards, while Don, a wide receiver, set two school career records with 102 catches and 1,735 total yards.

title: Earl Hindman Weds Molly McGreevy
description: Molly Paine McGreevy, an actress of Kansas City, Mo., and Earl Warren Hindman, an actor, were married yesterday in Kansas City at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Strauss. The Rev. Richard C. Meyers of the All Souls Unitarian Church in Kansas City performed the ceremony.

title: INTERSTATE CHIEF EXPECTED TO QUIT
description: Herbert B. Siegel, president and chief executive officer of Interstate Stores, a retail chain in bankruptcy proceedings, is expected to resign shortly to devote more time to reorganize the company, industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: New Haven Seeks To Set Right Tone For Its New Bells
description: NEW HAVEN, May 21Tol add the last few notes of gracel and distinction to the hells the city has ordered for the recon1 strucled tower on the old City; Hall, New Haven will start al competition tomorrow to com1 pose an original set of four,l musically related tunes to ring out each quarter hour.

title: Giscard Speaks of Confidence
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 21President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France said today, in his final address of a weeklong stale visit to the United States, that doubt has been cast on its strength and degree of commitment. But, he added, his own strongest impression is one of confidence in America.

title: BLOEDEL TO RAISE NEWSPRINT PRICE
description: MacMillan Bloedel, a major Canadian pulp and paper producer, said yesterday that it planned to raise its newsprint price by $20 a ton, effective July 1. This would bring its price on the West Coast to $300 a Price Changes ton, while the price in western Canada would be $285 to $290 a ton. A MacMillan spokesman in Vancouver, British Columbia, blamed rising labor costs for the increase. He noted that the company's employees were scheduled to receive wage increases of nearly 26 percent over the life of a twoyear contract, effective July 1.

title: Estelle Takes Travis Medal With 72
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21Chris Estelle, who has been playing the game for 25 years, won the medal by two strokes with a 72 as the 66th annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament began today.

title: KENYA TALK UPSET BY PRICE DISPUTE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 21The issue of how to regulate commodity prices has touched off quarrels among both rich and poor nations attending a United Nations economic conference here, and both groups are trying to restore inner order in time for the final week of negotiations.

title: Nuclear Darkness
description: The word for the proposed floating nuclear plant off Atlantic City should be cautionwhich is properly the spirit in which the State of New Jersey is approaching the prospect. The report of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commissionactually the first draft of an environmental impact statementis more affirmative in its conclusions than in some of its findings on the plan of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark to build such a plant 2.8 miles off the Jersey coast. The commission is even less reassuring for what it leaves out of the report altogether.

title: Ocean Dumping Act Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Senate approved today a twoyear extension of the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. A major provision in the act established an ocean dumping permit program under which the Environmental Protection Agency was authorized to establish criteria for dumping materials into the oceans.

title: The Social and Political Stability Of West Germany
description: BONNI am often surprised at how many people outside of the Federal Republic of Germany comment on the social and political stability of our country. I believe this social peace is primarily an achievement of our welldeveloped system of social security, combined with the principle of autonomy under which the labor unions and employers associations are allowed to pursue their interests and negotiate their differences.

description: A 36yearold Brooklyn man was shot in the thigh yesterday when he allegedly lunged at Police Officer James Ralph who had been chasing him and several other men who had been involved in a street fight at 29th Street and Mermaid Avenue, in Coney Island. The suspect, Charles Bayard of 2828 West 28th Street, was reported in satisfactory condition at Coney Island Hospital.

description: RICHMOND, May 21 (AP)Life Science Products, a defunct chemical company in Hopewell, Va., and six individuals pleaded not guilty today to indictments charging violatioh of Federal antipollution laws in producing the pesticide ingredient Kepone.

title: PRICES IN NEW YORK ROSE DURING MONTH
description: Consumer prices in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area edged up 0.2 percent from March to April, the Department of Labor reported yesterday.

description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Carey, in line with his oneyearold executive order requiring detailed, annual financial statements by public officials, today disclosed that his net worth was $130,458 at the end of 1975.

description: WASHINGTON. May 21The Senate Finance Committee voted today to disallow part of the deduction that is now permitted on Federal income tax returns for state and local gasoline taxes.

title: French Press Strike
description: PARIS, May 21 (UPI)France went without its daily newspapers today because of a 24hourstrike of journalists and printers. The strike was called to hack demands for higher wages, longer vacations and better job security.

title: Moscow's Trade Deficit
description: Traditionally a major Soviet boast has been that the system of centralized economic planning has made it possible to insulate the domestic Soviet economy from the chaotic fluctuations of the world capitalist economy.

title: FIANNA PULLS OUT OF SENATE CONTEST
description: UTICA, N.Y., May 21 (AP)Edward Hanna, the Mayor of Utica, pulled out of the United States Senate race and started a new campaign today that might take him to Albany or Washington by a different route.

title: State Sees a Greater Deficit Than New York City Expects
description: A preliminary New York State review of Mayor Beame's proposed 1977 $12.5 billion expense budget contends that New York City's deficit for the next fiscal year has been underestimated by more than $255 million.

title: Insurance Adjuster Jailed
description: BELVIDERE, N.J., May 21 (AP)An insurance adjuster has been given a oneyeartotwoyear prison sentence in connection with a pair of 1974 fires that destroyed the home of Netcong's former police chief and a Belvidere diner. Judge Bertram Polow of Superior Court imposed the sentence yesterday on Samuel Moccio of Flanders, who had been convicted of conspiracy, arson and fraud. Last month, Judge Polow sentenced former Police Chief Andrew Gugliemini, Mr. Moccio's codefendant, to two. yearstothreeyears in iail fot his role in the conspiracy.

title: Hijackers Seize a Philippine Jet, Ask for Cash and Flight to Libya
description: MANILA, Saturday, May 22 (AP)Hijackers holding more than 100 persons on an imobilized Philippine Air Lines jet at the Zamboanga airport threatened to kill the hostages unless their demands for a flight to Libya were met, airline sources said.

title: In Memoriam
description: MELLISLenore. Forever In hearts THE FAMILY.

title: ArtificialHeart Calf Dies
description: CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP)The Hereford calf that set longevity record of 145 days for life with an artificial heart died this week, according to the Cleveland Clinic.

title: Trade Deficit Forseen
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)  A Commerce Department economist says he expects the nation's trade accounts to show deficit for this year as a result of the strength of domestic economic recovery in comparison to recoveries of United States trading partners.

title: Beirut General Resigns, Urging That Franjieh Yield Presidency
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21Brig. Gen. Abdel Aziz alAhdab, the Moslem officer who announced a military coup here two months ago, and named himself military governor, said tonight that he was resigning, increasing pressure on President Suleiman Franjieh to do likewise.

title: Janet Gaynor's Pictures Are on Canvas These Days
description: Janet Gaynor, who in 1928 was a sweetfaced ingenue who won the first Academy Award ever presented to an actress, was back in the spotlight here the other night: This time as an artist who paints flowers and vegetables.

title: India Moves to Shield Press Curbs Farther
description: NEW DELHI, May 21The Indian Government, moving to make its control over the press even more secure, today introduced a constitutional amendment that would shield the censorship regulations from review in the courts.

title: Citibank Holds 6% Rate
description: Citibank said yesterday that it was holding its prime rate at 6 percent, for the coming week. Citibank last raised its prime on May 14 to 6 percent from 6.

title: CAHN IS CONVICTED OF BILLING FRAUD
description: William Calm, the former Nassau County District Attorney, was found guilty by a Federal court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of mail fraud in billing the county and various law enforcement associations for trips he took to conventions. The conviction ended Mr. Cahn's second trial on, the doublebilling charges. His first trial ended Feb. 27 with a hung jury that had voted 11 to 1 for conviction.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES THE HEART BILL
description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Carey today, citing the need to wait for broad reform of the state's pension laws, vetoed a measure that would have permanently established the presumption that heart ailments among policemen and firemen were job related.

title: The Times and Kissinger Discuss Book and Column
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The New York Times Company has informally discussed with Secretary of State Henry A, Kissinger a possibility of publishing his memoirs and of syndicating a column when hr leaves office, a Times executive said today.

title: Regional R.F.C.
description: The proposal by Felix G. Rohatyn to create a regional Reconstruction Finance Corporation to spur economic revival in the Northeast merits serious consideration in state capitals from Harrisburg to ,Montpelier. The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation is clearly right in warning that, unless the Northeastern states stop fighting each other over a shrinking job base and start instead to cooperate, we could all still go down together.

title: Open Interest
description: Firday, May 21, 1976

title: Stage: John
description: Before Philip Barry won his reputation as a master of urbane comedy with such plays as Holiday and The Philadelphia Story, he wrote John, a cldssical tragedy abotit John the Baptist. John ran only 11 perfor. mances on Broadway in 1927. According to the Joseph Jefferson Theater Company, its production of John (in a straightforward staging by Cyril Simon) is the first New York revival of the play. The Jefferson company is performing a definite service.

title: One War Over in Angola's Capital, Another On Against Thefts, Assaults and Shortages
description: LUANDA, Angola. May 21 As far as anyone can remember, there have never been so many armed assaults and robberies here in the Angolan capital. I wasn't scared during the 13 years war for independence or even through last year's battles in Luanda, but I am now, a militant of the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola admitted the other day. She said her apartment had been ransacked three times in recent months.

title: SPANISH KING MEETS WITH EXILED FATHER
description: MADRID, May 21 (AP)King Juan Carlos I met privately today with his exiled father, Don Juan, and was reported to have sought his support for a more liberal policy in running postFranco Spain.

title: Orioles Win on a Slam by De Cinces
description: Brooks Robinson may find himself on the bench for a long stretch this season. On Monday, the finefielding third baseman, who at the age of 39 is having trouble at bat, was taken out of the Baltimore Orioles starting lineup.

title: 28 in School Choir Killed in Bus Crash in California
description: MARTINEZ, Calif.. May 21A school bus smashed through a guard rail on a bridge ramp, fell 30 feet and landed in a marsh today, killing 28 members of a high school choir on a last excursion before summer vacation.

title: Scranton Assails Action
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21The chief United States delegate, William W. Scranton, today denounced recent action by the World Health Organization regarding Israel as agross political interference in matters of health care.
