title: Royal E. Ingersoll Dead; Headed the Atlantic Fleet
description: Mm. Royal E. Ingersoll, who commanded the United States Atlantic fleet for almost three years during World War II, died Thursday in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital at the age of 92. He had been retired since 1946.

title: Rep. Macdonald, 58, Dies; Led Election Law Reform
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)  Representative Torbert H. Macdonald, the Massachusetts, Democrat who asked that lifesustaining devices be turned off after he was hospitalized earlier this month, died tonight at Bethesda Naval Hospital, an aide said. He was 58 years old.

title: Concert
description: Amateur choral groups, if one remembers correctly, used to get together a couple of times a year to mumble through the Messiah and Elijah. But musical sophistication has raised the sights of both listener and performer in recent decades, thanks chiefly to the longplaying record. It is no longer unusual, though still most welcome, to come upon a chorus eager to take on the sort of difficulties that faced the Oratorio Society of New York at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night.

title: Catskills Food Tests Amity Of the French
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., May 20It was a culture clash to boggle the mind: haute cuisine meets heartburn. Eat three desserts! a woman guest shouted 101 members of one of France's most classic cooking schools plodded through Grossinger's vast knottypine dining room on their way to their first kosher meal.

title: NASA Funds Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The House approved today and sent to the White House compromise legislation authorizing $3.7 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the 1077 fiscal year. The vote was 255 to 20. The total approved is about $1,8 million less than the Administration request.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: This is uranium country, where the nation's richest known recoverable reserves of the mineral used in nuclear fuel are concentrated. Twenty uranium mines and three processing mills are in operation near Grants.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When in the course of athletic events it becomes necessary for one sport to take its rightful place with the others in society, soccer holds these truths to be self evidentthat all teams are created unequal, that they are endowed by their capitalists with certain incomparable players, that among these are Pele, Giorgio Chinaglia and George Best Team America who will be among the signers (with their feet) of soccer's declaration of independence in the American Bicentennial Cup tournament that begins tomorrow.

title: Scranton's 2Month Report Card at the U.N. Shows High Marks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21The French Ambassador remarked at a reception the other day that the new chief United States delegate, William W. Scranton, was much superior to his immediate predecessors.

title: Canadian Labor Plans to Take A More Activist Role in Politics
description: QUEBEC. May 21Organized labor in Canada has formally adopted a new activist role in politics, reversing a previqus policy.

title: NATO SAYS SOVIET IMPERILS DETENTE
description: OSLO, May 21A strong warning that the Soviet Union is endangering dtente by continuing a military buildup in Central Europe and by lack of restraint elsewhere concluded the twoday meeting of 15 foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here today.

title: Wilkins Bids Ford Meet Croup To Discuss School Integration
description: Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Associa: tion for the Advancement of Colored People, urged yester; day that President Ford meet immediately with a delegation of leaders from civil rights, labor, church and fraternal organizations 'to discuss the school desegregation posture of your Administration and its implication.

title: Dual Purpose Funds

title: Soviet Journalist Freed By the Japanese Police
description: TOKYO, Saturday, May 22 (AP)Japan freed a Soviet journalist today, 10 days after he was arrested and charged with trying to buy military secrets from a United States Navy petty officer. Japanese prosecutors had no immediate explanation for the decision to release the journalist. Aleksander Matchekhine, 38 years old.

title: A Homosexual Ensign Receives Other Than Honorable Release
description: Ens. Vernon E. Berg 3d, who has waged a public battle to stay in the Navy despite his acknowledge homosexuality, said last night that he had received notice of discharge from the Navy under conditions other than honorable.

title: C.I.A. KEEPS COPIES OF MAIL IT OPENED
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Copies of letters illegally opened and photographed by the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation in the United States over 33 years are still on file at C.I.A. headquarters, according to a Senate intelligence committee staff report.

title: PAYMENTS ABROAD DISCLOSED BY OTIS
description: The Otis Elevator Company has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that an incomplete review of its foreign payments, voluntarily begun last December, indicates some questionable payments were made by some parts of the corporation to foreign government employees between 1971 and 1975.

title: People and Business
description: Frank Wile, who recently completed a sixyear term as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, will join the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft on June 1, a regulatory source said yesterday. A family member confirmed the report.

title: Ford Expects to Meet Vorster of South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)President Ford said today he undoubtedly would meet with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, at a date yet to he decided, but would not meet with Prime Minister Ian D.. Smith of Rhodesia.

title: Adrift twixt Coolidge And Hoover
description: If Richard Nixon was Warren Harding and Watergate was Teapot Dome, then Gerald Ford is Calvin Coolidge, which means we still have Herbert Hoover to look forward to, which makes you wonder why anybody wants to be President this year.

title: Dollar Shows Strength
description: BRUSSELS, May 21 (UPI)The dollar gained sharply on European money markets tolday, hitting eightmonth highs in some cities.

title: Pound Below $1.80; Loan Rates Raised By Bank of England
description: LONDON, May 21The Britsh pound fell sharply today, hitting yet another record low of $1.7782 before a slight recovery caused by the Bank of England's decision to raise the basic lending rate for the second time in less than a month.

title: Weld Cracks Found In Alaska Pipeline; Costly Delay Feared
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Government officials disclosed today that they were reviewing what they called 3,955 problem welds on the Alaska oil pipeline.

title: Pound Below $1.80; Loan Rates Raised By Bank of England
description: LONDON, May 21The British pound fell sharply today, hitting yet another record low of $1.7782 before a slight reIcovery caused by the Bank of England's decision to raise the basic lending rate for the second time in less than a month.

title: Dibbs and Orantes Advance
description: HAMBURG, West Germany. May 21 (AP)Eddie Dibbs of the United States advanced to the men's singles semifinals in the 70th German International tennis tournament today by beating Jose Higueras of Spain, 46, 62, 63.

title: U.S. CURBS STATUS OF ARAB STUDENTS
description: First it was a son of Saudi Arabia's King coming here as a student more than 20 years ago, with a request that he be given something more than student visa status because he might carry out official business. Then it was another princely brother and another, and next cousins of royal blood. So it has grown to some 5,00C Saudi and Kuwaiti student: holding A2 United States visas conferring on them a form of diplomatic status different from that of all 75,000 othet foreign students in this country, according to Representative Joshua Eilberg of Pennsylvania.

title: Associated Press
description: CAR TROUBLE: Janet Guthrie and Rolla Vollstedt, the ownerbuilder of her car, in garage area at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway yesterday, after the car had mechanical difficulties. Miss Guthrie, the first woman to attempt to qualify for the Indianapolis 500, is doubtful qualifier because of the troubles.

title: Books of The Times
description: Quick, name an outstanding living mathematician. If you're an average American, the chances you can do this are almost zero. Mathematicians are perhaps the last large important group of Americans to retain their privacy in this postWatergate world. Even the press has virtually given upon trying to report about who's who and what's what in the mathematical world. Reporters who are fearless when asked to expose the mysteries of DNA's double helix, or of quasars, pulsars and plate tectonics, quail and flee when faced by the challenge of category theory functional analysis.

title: NADJARI ACCUSED OF RAIDING OFFICE
description: The law partner of Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, yesterday accused members of Maurice H. Nadjari's staff of having illegally broken into the two men's law office by covert operation in the manner of Watergate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: FORD BARS REAGAN AS A RUNNING MATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) President Ford, heading back onto the campaign circuit this weekend, said today that he was not considering Ronald Reagan as a running mate if he defeats him for the Presidential nomination.

title: Mobil to Move a Unit Out of New York
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it was moving its major domestic operating division, which employs 800 people, out of New York City to the Washington area.

title: Carter Schedules Weekend Campaign For Western Votes, Mostly in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 21Jimmy Carter has decided to throw himself into three unscheduled days of campaigning in Western states, mostly in Oregon, where he will face all his remaining rivals for the Democratic Presidential nominadon.

title: DUTCH REVIEWING CAPE TOWN DEAL
description: BRUSSELS, May 21  The Dutch Government, under strong pressure from groups opposed to South Africa in the Netherlands, is considering withholding a $260 million credit guarantee to three Dutch companies taking part in a large nuclear reactor sale to South Africa.

title: Selling on Sunday Rising Despite Confusing Laws
description: In New Jersey, shoppers scurry from one county to another, or even into Delaware, to shop on Sunday. In Atlanta, major supermarket chains, including the A.&P., have recently adopted allnight and sevenday hours. And in New York City alone, tens of thousands of businesses each year, with the tacit complicity of the authorities, blithely ignore Sunday selling bans that go back to the 17th century.

title: New York Gets U.S..Aid For Convention Security
description: New York City yesterday received Federal grants of morel than $4 million to pay for overtime that it is expected to incur in providing security at the Democratic National Convention in July and to rehire 60 policemen for special operations against street crime.

title: Concert Tonight Honors A Cantor for 65 Years
description: David Putterman was a 10yearold member of the choir at Chav Zadek Synagogue on Norfolk Street when lie became a boy cantor. Tonight he will be honored with a concert at the Park Avenue Synagogue by Tan Peerce marking his 65 years in music as a religious leader radio singer (under an assumed name) and patron who helped bring new works by contemporary composers into the synagogue.

title: Ballet: New,
description: In 1957, George Balanchine created a delightfal ballet that combined clreisic technique with a hoedown spirit and called it Square Dance. Now he has taken the square out of Square Dance and converted it into a beautifully serene puredance ballet.

title: Market Place
description: The current series of takeover bids for major companies suggests to some in Wall Street a possible return to the freewheeling days of the late 1960's, when it seemed that no company, however large, was safe from a corporate takeover.

title: Excess School Profits
description: The most dismal aspect of the latest investigation into alleged overspending and profiteering by some of the city's school custodians is that it all sounds like a rerun of a decade ago. The worst criticism to be leveled any system may well be that it fails to reform itself even after the cause of its shortcomings has been exposed and diagnosed.

description: MARTINEZ, Calif., May 21A school bus smashed through a guard rail on a bridge ramp, fell 30 feet and landed in marsh today, killing 28 members of a high school choir on a last excursion before summer vacation.

description: Concern over rising interest rates and the money supply weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

description: ALBANY, May 21 At a time when tenants and landlords have been lobbying here for changes in the state's Rent Control Law, the Legislature has become the scene for a less public, but no less hotly contested battle over the future of cooperative apartments.

title: MUNICH FEARS RISE OF FARE TO 65 CENTS
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportadon Authority, said yeserday that power and fuel costs and a sharp cutback in Federal aid could force an increase in the transit to 65 cen M.T.A. late spring of 1977. The M.T.A. projects an $108 million budget gap by then, and Mr. Yunich said that barring an increase in subsidies the fare would have to go up.

title: Gifts by Diversified Corp.
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The International Diversified. Corporation made political contributions in the Bahamas totaling some $75,000 for the years 1972 through 1975, according to a docUment made available today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) Harold E. Stassen, a Republican who four times sought the Presidency, announced today he might try again.

With two out and the winning run on third base, the Yanks batter is Kerry Michael Dineen, who a few hours before was taking batting practice in Syracuse.

title: Birth Pill Hormones Found to Affect Rat Brains
description: BERKELEY, Calif. May 21The hormones used in birth control pills have been found to decrease the thickness of the cortex of the brain in adult female rats and may impair the animals brain development, according to a scientist at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: IC4A Titles. Go ToKirbyandPost
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21Jim Kirby of Maryland and Jim Post of C. W. Post won throwing titles today in the 100th IC4A outdoor track and field championships. Maryland, the favorite in the field of 75 colleges, moved closer to the team title.

title: New Today
description: Floyd Kalber, a Chicagobased correspondent for NBC News and coanchorman of the evening newscast on the NBCowned station there, will replace Lew Wood as the permanent newscaster on the Today program, Monday, June 28. NBC officials said Mr. Wood will remain on the program covering sports, weather and special roving field assignments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was reported erroneously in The Times yesterday that Sister Maryellen Harmon, the newly appointed school superintendent for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit, was the first woman to head a major parochial system. The first was Sister Elinor R. Ford, a school superintendent in the New York Archdiocese from 1972 through 1975.

title: Gems to Wear on Starry Summer Nights or Sunny Days
description: Abandoning, at least temporarily, the frankly fake jewelry that has brought him fame and fortune, Kenneth J. Lane, has done his first collection in semiprecious stones. He was inspired, he says, by the new Hall of Minerals and Gems at the American Museum of Natural History, which he inspected well in advance of the official opening.

title: ELECTION AGENCY OPERATING AGAIN; SUBSIDIES RESUME
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The flow of political subsidies to Presidential candidates and major parties was resumed today after a twomonth freeze when the Federal Election Commission was reconstituted by Congress and President Ford.

title: Planned Hospital Layoffs Are Put Off Until Monday
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday put off until Monday a final decision on the planned layoff of 3,200 workers, and most hospitals continued to function normally as job actions failed to take place. .

description: WASHINGTON, May 21New orders for durable goods, an important leading indicator of the economy, continued to rise in April but at a slower pace than the surge in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: WASHINGTON, May 21Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger contended in sworn testimony released today that he played a substantially passive role in the wiretapping of 17 Government officials and newsmen, undertaken from 1969 to 1971 purportedly to stem unauthorized disclosures in the press.

title: Home Clinic

The patio is down to the bare concrete again and we would like to find paint that will adhere for at least one season.

I hope I can help lot of people. I hope to use the money for the betterment of mankind. One project he had in mind was building a youth center to keep tat of kids off the streets.

In this performance a phonograph played the FleisherSzell recording of Brahm's First Piano Concertoan inspired choice, for Brahms's ponderous grandeur and Mr. Cage's bouncy tincan rhythms made a delightful concoction.

Most of the injuries occurred when firemen opened the door of a fourthfloor apartment, where the fire apparently started, and flames burst out at them. Three of the injured were admitted to Harlem Hospital for treatment of chest pains or possible carbon monoxide poisoning. title: Painting a Cosmic Conversation
description: Jennifer Bartletrs birthday falls on the same date as Albert Einstein's (March 14), a fact that pleases her, though it has no relevance whatever to her work. Nevertheless, the conjunction should not be passed over lightly; like Einstein, Miss Bartlett is given to largescale thinking. Her current show at the Paula Cooper Gallery consists of Rhapsody, an environmental painting in 988 parts cited last week by John Russell as the most ambitious single work of new art that has come my way, and she is writing a 1000page novel called The History of the Universe.

title: Headliners
description: The consensus at the United Nations Is that the new chief United States delegate, William M. Scranton, has made a favorable impression during his two months in the job. Comments from other delegates stress his courtesy and restraint, and credit him with having brought about a lessening of the confrontationalatmosphere that was apparent during the tenure his predecessor, .Daniel P. Moynihan. As evidence the more relaxed mood, diplomats point to the ease with which the United States obtained postponement of a decision on United Nations membership for Angola, which was unwelcome to Washington right now. The many delegates who have met privately with the former Pennsylvania Governor, a lawyer by profession, say he appears to do his homework and displays the political talents and negotiating skills he was reputed to be bringing to the world organization.

Unsurprisingly, their conversations are similar to a lifechanging encounter myself had with Bob Dylan in a Village hangout years ago. Like Weatherby. I memorized

title: Subways
description: New York's subway system opened on Oct. 27, 1904, and New Yorkers have been complaining about it ever since. Still, more than 3.5million riders use the subway every weekday, for it is unarguably the best and cheapest way to get around town fast. And, for an outoftowner, a tour of some of its 27 lines provides a special insight into how New Yorkers live. In this article each of the lines is rated on such aspects as speed, scenery, historical interest, notable features, rhythmical track music and whether there is something worth seeing or doing at the end of the run. New York's subways are not the world's safest, but there are simple precautions the visitor can take to minimize the danger. These are presented on Page 22.

FIELDS is beginning to crumble at the edges, the Ziegfeld Follies of 1922 once had Will Rogers but is beginning to lose him, The Cat and the Canary is all but gone and the Moscow Art lies in ruins. One hundred other important entertainers or entertainments, including the seminal black musical called Shuffle Along, are in immediate danger of vanishing forever. A little money would cure the ailment, provided it is applied fast enough, but where is it?

title: The Harm of Save Harmless
description: THIS year, as we have so many times before, we witnessed the annual spring ritual in Albany frequently referred to as The State Aid to Education Funding Battle. The word leaks out that aid to education will be reduced. The P.T.A. starts a letterwriting campaign and prepares marches on Albany. School boards struggle with budget preparation without knowing what their revenue will be. Budgets are presented to voters based upon mythical figures and, finally, the Long Island representatives work feverishly to put together a political coalition to pass the annual state aid bill. This year we had an additional ingredient of a Governor's veto, followed by the eventual passage and signing of the bill.

Their experience of philosophy is an active process of discovering the principles of reasoning and the discipline of thinking for oneself.

title: M. J. Mistretta Fiance Of Nancy Goldsmith
description: The engagement of Nancy Diane Goldsmith, who graduated today from Smith College, to Mark J. Mistretta, on of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J Mistretta of Winfield, Ill., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Goldsmith of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Music in Review
description: Robert Black, a Texasborn pianist now working for a doctorate at the Juilliard School, has already become wellknown for his performances with orchestras of contemporary music. On Thursday night, he presented a program of prizewinning piano solos in what was a recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Chance for Fewer Guns
description: Not even the shock of John F. Kennedy's assassination In 1963 was enough to move the Congress to enactment of effective gun control legislation, It took five years and an additional heavy toll of political assassinations before the overly modest Gun Control Act of 1968 could be approved. Since then there has been a proliferation of the most obvious menace to public safetycheap handguns, the Saturday Night Specials, manufactured both in the United States and imported from abroad. As many as 40 million hand guns are at large In the United States. Easily concealable, they are common accessories to crime.

title: Unbeaten Harvard Defeats Yale Crew
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 22 The only close moment at the HarvardYale crew race today came at the end of the grinding fourmile trip up the Thames River when the thoroughly beaten Eli oarsmen came alongside the Crimson shell, stripped off their blue shirts, and handed them over to their Harvard counterparts.

title: Brown Cites Differences With Carter In Quest for Oregon WriteIn Victory

title: Headhunters
description: The last laps of the primary course are likely to end only at the doors of this summer's nominating conventions. That, at least, seems to be the message of last week's voting. President Ford won in Michigan by a large margin over Ronald Reagan, and thus averted disaster; Jimmy Carter almost lost Michigan to Morris Udall and did lose the beauty contest in Maryland to a fresh face, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.

description: MEDFORD, Ore., May 22President Ford, locked in a close struggle with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination, campaigned in the West today with his aides hoping for a standoff in six primary contests next Tuesday.

title: Court Rejects New Methods For Disciplining of Lawyers
description: A proposal to change the way lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx are disciplined was rejected last week by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the First Department.

title: Food
description: Although souffles are counted among the most elegant, if not sublime, conceits of the kitchen, they are not all that difficult to make it is, in fact, easier to turn out a successful, wellpuffed souffle than a perfectly scrambled egg or a succulent, golden brown roast fowl. One of the critical points in soufflemaking is the folding in of the beaten egg whites. This is simplified if a portion of the beaten whites is beaten into the basic mixture and the remainder folded in quickly but deftly with a rubber spatula. Two excellent souffles are outimea nere a crab and eggplant dish plus a cheese souffle that is baked on a base of creamed salmon. There is one thing for certain. Souffles must be served with the greatest dispatch the moment they arc taken from the oven.

title: BUDDHA RELICS FIND IS REPORTED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, May 22 (UPD) An Indian Government archeological team says it believes it has found a part of Gautama Buddha's corporeal relics'bits of charred bones and ashes. buried in a north Indian villave.

title: The Film Treats People Unfairly
description: It seemed a little unreal to sit in the theater and watch All the President's Men. I observed not only the film but the audience.

title: A Brush Dipped In Japanese Ink
description: The most helpful report on Japanese Ink Paintings from American Collections: the Muromachi Period, an exhibition at the Art Museum of Princeton University, would take the form of bus, train and road information that would get you there. Second best would be an inspection of the catalogue, which is so well illustrated that it comes close to taking you there and adds the advantage of comparing the 37 paintings with related ones, in mostly Japanese collections. This is an exquisite showthe adjective has been pondered, and settled on as the most accurate onean exquisite show and is playing its single engagement at Princeton through June 13.

title: DINING OUT
description: HOI MING is a Cantonese restaurant. Repeat, Cantonese. Not Hunan, Szechuan, Mandarin, Peking. The dishes of these cuisines are scarcely in evidence here. Nor is Hot Ming given to the flames and flourishes that characterize PolynesianPreparations.

title: Proxmire Rains Coals On Forecasters

title: If You Go
description: to Hilton Head Island, the nearest large city is Savannah, Ga., and the next nearest is Charleston, S. C. National Airlines has three direct flights daily (except Saturday, when there are two) to Savannah from the New York City area. Delta Air Lines has no direct connections to Savannah, but many flights to Atlanta. There are eight flights daily from Atlanta to Savannah, and a small airline called Air South has at least one flight a day from Atlanta to the Hilton Head Island airport At the Savannah airport, there are limousines to the island and rental cars. National operates four flights daily (except Saturday, when there are three) to Charleston, where you can rent a car. Eastern Air Lines has one flight a day to Charleston.

title: Phil Jackson and the Knicks, Past and Present
description: RED HOLZMANRed's style is soft and gentle. Red is also very slick, and he can con a man into playing well. He is a gentleman, and the attitude he communicates is that the Knicks can win basketball games only if the players do the best job they are capable of doing. Instead of telling a substitute to relax and not try to do everything the first minute he's in the game, Red will simply say, Run through a few. offensive plays until you get the feel of the ball. Red is a diplomat rather than a tyrant, but the Knicks hear his imprint.

title: Conscience or No, Customs Has a may of Making Cowards of Us All
description: Thus conscience, said the Bard, does make cowards of us all. Perhaps. But there is something that happens to me and so many other travelerswhen we find ourselves going through customs that throws our moral senses into confusion. Either we give sway to conscience and declare all we should, meanwhile cursing ourselves for cowardice. Or we turn from being lawabiding citizens and take on the guise of highwaymen.

title: GARDENING
description: HAVE you ever wondered what a Long Island spring would be like without the azalea? Everywhere one looks in midMay, there are masses of white, pink and red often clustered around the base of a flowering dogwood. Some gardens are built entirely around masses of azaleas; others use them as accents, or, if you will, punctuation marks in the landscape. There is little doubt that they are the most colorful feature of our spring landscape.

title: The Secretary of State sweepstakes
description: You can see them, if you've got the entree, at any number of foreignpolicy seminars or conferences around the country. The faces are usually the same. There'll be a New York attorney named Cyrus Vance, who, like as not, will be listening intently to a presentation by a Columbia University professor named Zbigniew Brzezinski. Elliot Richardson might be doodling on his napkin, waiting for his turn to speak. A vice president of Reader's Digest named Melvin Laird would be sure, at some point, to poke the man next to himperhaps a New York investment banker named George Balland the two would have a good laugh about something. The others would wonder a little uneasily what they were laughing about. All except think  tank veteran named James Schlesinger. He would be leaning back wreathed in pipe smoke and thoughts of his own. A Washington lawyer named Paul Warnke and a onetime business boy wonder named Peter Peterson would seem a little impatient with the proceedings.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused today to stop the (supersonic Concorde aircraft from landing at Dulles InternaItional Airport, clearing the way for the supersonic jet's first commercial flights to the United States starting Monday.

title: For DoItYourself Plumbers
description: A new type of flexible plastic pipe and matching fittings makes all types of indoor and outdoor plumbing installations easier than ever before for doityourselfers. Utilizing a new type of plastic pipe made of polybutylene, it is currently the only flexible one approved for use in both het and cold water lines. The pipe has been approved by the National Sanitation Foundation for deliv ery of hot or cold potable water and it has been accepted by the FHA for use in government financed housing (one and two family units and rehabilitated structures not exceeding six stories in height).

description: One of yachting's biggest plums soon should fall into some naval architect's lap. The winner of the New York Yacht Club's design contest for a new N.Y.Y.C. class boat

title: Soviet Ballet Is Down At the Heel
description: If you want to get the record straight about where the greatest ballet in the world is to be found, go to Russia. You won't find it there. It is possibleeven probablethat you will find better ballet right here at home. No, I'm not being chauvinistic. Don't even take my word for it. Ask some Russians. Ask Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova, Mikhail Baryshnikov. They know where the hest ballet is to be found. Not Moscow. Not in Leningrad, which they left behind them. They were not defecting from Communism, even though many Americans would like to think they were; they were escaping a statecontrolled ballet system that suffocates choreographic creativity and strangles ballet enterprise.

title: Balanchine's Union Jack Barely Flutters
description: When Leonide Massine choreographed Le Tricorne for the Diaghilev Ballet in 1919, he did something that was very peculiarpossibly unique in the history of ballet. He learned Spanish dancing from a Spanish gypsy dancer, Feliks. To be sure, Michel Fokine before Massine had done a considerable amount or nistoncai research before mounting such ballets as Daphnis and Chloe, but to explore a living dance tradition was something new. Not that Le Tricorne is a direct exposition of Spanish dance; when genuine Spanish dancers, such as Antonio, have mounted their own versions of the Falla score, the result was always totally different in tone. However, there Is a very wide difference between the type of Spanish dancing you find in Petipa's Don Quixote or the Gorsky choreographed Spanish dance in the Third Act of Swan Lake, and what Massine created in Le Tricorne.

title: Subway Crime
description: While it can be said that New York's subways are safer than its streets, and that subway crime is simply an extension of the city's crime in general, the fact remains that it exists. According to the Transit Authority's latest figures, the greatest number of felonies occur between 4 and 6 in the afternoon. The early morning hours, which can be tne mos'l frightening, show the hienst proportion of telons to riders, although the T.A. says its statistics for these hours also include considerable crime against T.A. property (defacing of cars and stations with graffiti, for example).

title: A Specialist In Weirdo Roles Goes Straight
description: He played a transsexual in his first film, a rapist in his second. And now, Chris Sarandon is about to begin a gothic horror film here called The Sentinel, in which he plays a very normal, upstanding heterosexual Manhattan lawyerquite a radical departure for an actor who made his reputation playing sexual misfits.

title: School Desegregation Is Pressed in Chicago Area
description: CHICAGO, May 21In recommending voluntary metropolitan desegregation between city and suburban schools here, the State School Superintendent, Joseph M. Cronin, is walking through a thicket that most public officials go out of their way to avoid.

title: Even Cowgirls Get the Blues
description: Even Cowgirls Get the Blues is a Whole Earth narrative, a laid back Tristram Shandy, a barbershop quartet of Vonnegut, Brautigan, Pynchon and Ishmael Reed doing a hymn to the White Goddess, a meditation on the rule of thumb, a manifesto for magic, and a retelling of Another Roadside Attraction, Toni Robbins's first novel, now something of a hippie classic. Cowgirls has a mascot (the amoeba), a favorite recipe (stew) and 121 chapters plus interludes. Shiva couldn't keep all these balls in the air, but Robbins's blurhanded performance definitely worth the admission.

title: Andretti Tops Indy Qualifiers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP)  Mario Andretti, who vowed he wouldn't go all out in qualifying, couldn't resist the temptation of almost ideal conditions today as he surpassed Johnny Rutherford's poleposition speed in trials for the May 30 Indianawns 500 auto race.

title: The U.S. Tries to Tighten Controls On Nuclear Sale
description: The United States is attempting to impose on the Government of Iran a slight but important addition to the controls Washington normally requires as part of a bilateral nuclear cooperation agreement. The American proposal is an expression of Washington's continuing concern, expressed in various ways at various international forums, about the dangers of nuclear proliferation, and to persuade other countries to tighten their controls on fissionable materials. What the United States fears is the proliferation of nuclear weaponry; India, in 1974, exploded a nuclear weapon with material intended by Canada, the supplier, for peaceful uses.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: At this very moment workmen, like termites, are nibbling away at the interior of Fisher Hall. The balconies are already gone, the seats have long been removed, and perhaps by now the interior has been stripped to the bare walls. For the next six months a crew under the direction of Cyril Harris (the acoustician) and Philip Johnson (the architect) will struggle to undo the acoustic sins of their predecessors. In October, perhaps, the new Fisher Hall will open. It. will look different. It better had sound different.

title: Marx defended, rescued and applied
description: In the last century substantial scholarship was frequently combined with great political activism and was even thought a prerequisite. The formidable examples are Marx and Engels themselves. In this age of snecialization

title: Laurie Earnheart. Leffal Aide. Married
description: Laurie Jeanne Earnheart and Richard Alan Williamson were married yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins.

title: What Conrail Plans
description: THE advent of Conrail as the new railroadfor 77,000 North Jersey commuters brings promises of longrange service improvements, but also much more immediate perils of fire increases and some service cutbacks. The key to operations is the state's willingness not lust to continue its present $50 million annual subsidy for commuter trains, but to raise it.

title: Letter From Dublin
description: Spring days, at 53 degrees north latitude, wax eerily long, the wind intermittently drops its chilling edge, against a gunmetal sky magnolia blossoms struggle. Poet Patrick Kavanagh's friends have carried their St. Patrick's Day libations to his memorial bench by the Grand Canal (O Commemorate me where there is water/Canal water preferably). There were no official moves to commemorate Sam Beckett's 70th birthday, but some friends improvised something. Sam wouldn't be enticed out of Paris.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Now that the economic recovery seems welllaunched in the United States and appears to be started in most other parts of the Western world. some economic and political analysts are beginning to worry about other things  like renascent inflationary pressures, tightening Federal Reserve monetary policy, possible shortages in productive capacity and more competitive international trade developments.

title: SHOP TALK
description: OCEANSIDE

title: Farmers Opposing Plans For Controlling Rivers
description: SHUSHAN, N.Y.  Three embattled farmers stood beside a rusty railroad bridge on the banks of the Batten Kill here and fired some verbal shots at the State Department of Environmental Conservation and its new proposals for regulating rivers in the state

title: BRAZIL IS WINNER AT WORLD BRIDGE
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 22In an astonishing upset Brazil won the world contrict bridge team championship tide here today, overtaking the defending champion Italians, who had appeared certain winners.

title: Who's Afraid of Broadway? Not Ben Gazzara
description: When I looked up, 10 years had gone by, Ben Gazzara was saying..I couldn't believe it. Year after year, I'd think about doing a play, but nothing would look good, and I'd get another movie gig, another television gig. The money would be splendid, and I'd say, Next year for sure. But next year there would be a picture in Rome or someplace else that was very appealing....

title: Taxis
description: Taxicabs are popularly viewed as battered yellow monuments to New York City's most hectic and selfdestructive instincts and cab drivers as men of nearly mythic seediness. It is taken as a Mum by many New Yorkers and outoftowners alike that (a) cabs are hard to find, that (b) if found, the driver may refuse to take you where you want to go, that (c) if he does not refuse, he'll take you the long way around or otherwise rip you off.

title: Paperbacks
description: A BILLION FOR BORIS, by Mary Rodgers. (Harper/ Trophy, $1.50.) Annabel's brother Ape Face has a TV set that tips off tomorrow's race results today, enabling their friend Boris to get rich at Off Track Betting; a witty fantasy for children 10 and up. CELEBRATION, by Harvey Swados. (Dell/Laurel, $1.95.) Six months of the journals and dreams of Samuel Lumen caught, in his 90th year, between pressures from establishment friends who wish to celebrate his exploits in longago progressive causes and from his grandson who seeks his endorsement of presentday radical movements: a compound of irony and fable, this posthumous novel may well be its author's best work.

title: Miss Kennedy Wed To C.F. Everhart
description: Caroline Hubbard Kennedy, daughter of Douglass James Kennedy of South Hadley, Mass. and the late Lucille Marsh Kennedy, was married yesterday to Claude Francis Everhart, son of Mrs. Audley Everhart of Hagerstown, Md., and the late Mr. Everhart.

title: The Campaign: F.E.C. Finally Is Back in Business
description: The payment of Federal subsidies to Presidential candidates has finally resumed. But not until Friday was clear that the latest installment in the Federal Election Commission story woul4 turn out to be the last.

title: BIG SOVIET DEBATE ON ARMOR IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 22An Intense debate has broken out within the Soviet Army, which has long stressed the use of armored forces, over whether new antitank weapons must force a change in Soviet military doctrine, a defense analyst has concluded.

title: The Glass Palace
description: By Mary Ann Gibbs. 183 pp. New York: Mason/Charter. $6.95.

title: Lookin for that something else
description: Its a pleasure, occasionally, to get away from the mayhem, violence and mania that are so vividly depicted in much of today's fiction; and Al Young's Sitting Pretty provides just such an opportunity. In this novel, Young introduces Sidney J. Prettymon, aka., Sitting Pretty or just Sitone of the most charming and engaging characters I've encountered in time.

title: Judith Coulter Married to Broker
description: Judith Lloyd Coulter and Hunter Goodrich Jr.. a partner of Loeb Rhodes, the stockbrokers, were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony.

title: Of Things To Come
description: In describing his own works of fiction, Graham Greene takes care to distinguish between two kinds of books: his serious novels, like The Power and the Glory and The Heart of the Natter. and what he calls his entertainments, like Stamboul Train and The Confidential Agent. By signaling his intentions so clearly, Greene has saved readers and critics a lot of trouble. Serious literature may be entertaining, but that is hardly its primary function: we may be abashed or uplifted by a book without being amused. When entertainment is the author's avowed purpose, however, different expectations are aroused and different standards of taste apply.

title: New York's Information Law Termed in Need of Overhaul
description: New York State's Freedom of Information law is a failure and in great need of overhaul, according to officials of the New York Public Interest Research Group, which has conducted a test of the law's effectiveness.

title: Soviet, Rebutting Bonn, Affirms Detente
description: MOSCOW. May 22The Soviet Government issued a statement today defending its corn. mitment to dftente in Europe and criticizing unidentified political elements in West Germany which still live by the dogmas of the cold war.

title: Poor Man's BigGame Fish
description: IF there was any one thing that disinguished the 1975 fishing season from any other, it was tip incredible increase in the number of people fishing for sliarks.

title: The Wage Gap is Closing

description: For James Johnson, a 28yearoh: program administrator at Manhattan College in Riverdale, the Bronx, it was a matter of moving from a deteriorating West Bronx neighborhood in which his wife, Lorraine, no longer felt safe.

description: The controversial investigation into the activities of the Democratic state Chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, and the purported sale of judgeships in the Bronx was the accidental byproduct of an undercover inquiry into organized crime.

title: Again, No N.J. Income Tax
description: When the New Jersey Assembly passed a state income tax bill in March, it was widely believed that the Senate would finally go along, because the measure included a socalled sweetener: property tax relief. Not true. Last week the Senate voted down the income tax for the sixth time in two years. The tax is apparently still so politically distasteful that sufficient votes could not be found.

title: Read it for the science, pass up the economics
description: Barry Commoner is best known for The Closing Circle, which detailed the ominous impact of modem technology on the environment. The five years since its publication have substantiated Commoner's fears, making P.C.B., vinyl chloride and red dye #2 into household words and turning the 11 o'clock news into a nightly chemistry class. What was unique about the

title: Good Riddance For Pesky Garden Weeds
description: Some weeds occur in great numbers but are easily controlled by readily available methods. Although dandelion and plantain are all over some lawns, they can be controlled by occasional spraying with 2,4D. Cultivation in the garden or use of herbicides on lawns before weed seeds germinate will control crabgrass, plgweed, lambsquarters and most annual weeds.

title: INSURERS OPPOSE URBAN PLAN SHIFT
description: Efforts to expand a fire insurance program that was set up by the Federal Government for homes and businesses in urban areas are being vigorously fought by a major fire and casualty insurance association.

description: One of the most frequent causes of dull home movies is the failure of the movie maker to take full advantage of the interest and excitement that can be added by making use of unusual angles while shooting.

title: SETBACKS FEARED FOR CIVIL RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The President and Congress, in their own ways, are taking steps to undo some of the important civil rights gains of the 1960's, in the view of civil rights experts here.

title: LI.R.R. TO SHIFT RUNS FOR SUMMER
description: The Long Island Rail Road's new summer schedules, effective tomorrow, include an expansion of train service from New York to the Hamptons and Montauk and elimination of the problemprone bus service to those points.

title: Polluted Watershed
description: Nearly eleven hundred charges have been levelled massive indictments against the Allied Chemical Corporation, its Life Science Products Company (a corporate offshoot) and the city of Hopewell, Va. If convicted, the companies could be fined more than $20 million. Their executive officers could be individually fined and sent to prison for committing, and conspiring to cover up, gross and prolonged discharges of Kepone, an ant and roach poison, into the James River.

title: Tax Options Are Listed
description: PERSONAL state Income tax as a centerpiece of a taxreform package is often talked about as inevitable in New Jersey. But the State Senate last week put the inevitable off for at feast. two years by rejecting such a levy for the sixth time in 16 months.

title: City Ballet Offers Its Young Dancers In Symphony in C
description: The New York City Ballet presents at least a dozen craative faces to the world so that it is difficult to decide in exactly which guise it will revcai its ta!ented young dancers. The buoyant Symphony in C has become one of the major vehicles because it combines both lyrical and friendly precise solo work On Friday evening at the State Theater, Heather Watts, Adam Liiders and Debra Austin appeared in it for the first time.

title: Marie Duffy Wed to Francis McClure
description: Marie Louise Duffy, an assistant secretary with Manufacturers Hanover Trust Ccmpany, was married yesterday afternoon in Blauvelt, N,Y.. to Francis Gregory McChire, a regional sales manager with Uniflow Manufac

title: And All Between
description: And All Between is the selfcontained successor to the author's earlier Below the Root. (It is so selfcontained, in fact, that the first 125 pages are devoted to a recapitulation of previous action from a different point of view.) Once the story proper gets under way, we find that it winds

title: Criminals At Large
description: Several authors in recent years have taken to writing historical mystery stories set in Queen Victoria's time. It was just a month ago, for instance, that Francis Selwyn's Sergeant Verity and the Imperial Diamond was reviewed here. Now comes anotner nistoricat mystery also of the Victorian period, set in the London of 1871. It is the author who is somewhat of a surprise. Up to now, H.R.F. Keating has been concentrating on his Inspector Ghot.? mysteries, Ghote being the little Indian cop who is one of the more endearing personalities of contemporary crime fiction. But in A REMARKABLE CASE OF BURGLARY (Double. day, $5.95) Keating goes backward in time to give us what is in effect the case history of a 100yearold crime..

title: Figueroa Of Power Wins Dash
description: Power Memorial's outstanding running duo of Maurice Weaver and Al Fiorentino won as expected, but it was the Panthers Gilbert Figueroa who broke a record yesterday in the Catholic High School Athletic Association New York Diocese track and field championships at the Mount St. Michael track in the Bronx.

title: POLITICS
description: RONALD. REAGAN picked Suffolk County for MI first Presidential foray last fall into New YorkVice President Rockefeller's turf. The Californian received a very warm welcome at the Suffolk County Republican dinner then.

title: How to Lose the Election
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 22The Presidential campaign seems to he turning into a test of which party has the best formula for losing the election, on this negative proposition, the Republicans are ahead, but not by much.

title: Belmont Charts
description: 1976 by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Raring Form) Saturday, May 22. 18th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: What's Doing in VIENNA
description: FESTIVAL  The Vienna Festwochen, one of the oldest of Europe's art festivals, begins today and runs through June 20. As usual, in keeping with the city's image as the world's music capital, it emphasizes musical events. There will be opera performances almost every night at the Staatsoper, the Volksoper and the Theater an der Wien. Besides the Vienna Philharmonic and the Vienna Symphony, there will be such visiting orchestras as the Leningrad Philharmonic and the Bavarian Rundfunk Symphony. On June 12 in the gigantic Stadthalle sports arena, which seats 11,000, Leonard Bernstein will be piano soloist and conductor with the New York Philharmonic in a program devoted to American composers. To celebrate its 200th anniversary, the Burgtheater will stage Witold Gombrowicz's Die Trauung (The Wedding) in German, starting June 5. Tickets for festival performances range from 55 cents to $39 and can be ordered from the Austrian Travel Agency, 7 Friedrichstrasse, A1043 Vienna.

title: Reds 3, Padres 2
description: SAN DIEGO, May 22 (AP) Pat Zachry, a rookie righthander, scattered nine hits tonight to pace the Cincinnati Reds to a 32 victory over the San Diego Padres and snap a threegame Reds losing streak.

title: Drive on Crime Falters
description: TRETON APLAN to intensify the state's efforts in its drive against organized crime has been postponed for at least a year because of the fiscal situation.

title: N.C.A.A. Tennis Is Rescheduled
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 22 (AP)Officials have rescheduled this year's National Collegiate tennis tournament to spread the quarterfinals, semifinals and finals over the threeday Memorial Day weekend.

title: John Lowrey Weds Miss Nassikas
description: In St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington at noon yesterday, Elizabeth Lynn Nassikas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Nassikas of McLean, Va., became the bride of John Lane Lowrey. He is the sort of Dr. and Mrs. Jack B. Lowrey of Indian Hills, Colo.

title: Anger in the Ramapos
description: ANGER and frustration are being expressed these days by the descendants of a group of racially mixed people who, since the mid1800's, have lived in relative isolation in the hollows and ridges of North Jersey's Ramapo Mountains.

title: Obedience Classic Set for Weekend
description: It's the educated dogs turn to take the spotlight. On Saturday, and next Sunday, 120 top performers from across the country will compete in the United States

title: Bars
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif., May 22  Howard Bathrick manages Pat's Lounge here. a dark, neighborhood bar that opened a few days after Prohibition ended in 1933. He likes to boast that it's a friendly place.

title: Wardlaw Triumphs In Hawthorne Derby
description: CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) Wardlaw, a 7to5 favorite. scored a fivelength victory in the 12th running of the $122,200 Hawthorne Derby before a crowd of 21,742 today at Hawthorne.

title: Gunmen Hold Hostages 2 Hours To Protest Hospital's Cutbacks
description: Two men held 12 persons hostage for two hours yesterday at Van Etten Hospital in the Bronx and then surrendered to the police. The men were discharged from the hospital's alcohol detoxification center on Friday, and they returned to demand more treatment.

title: Parent and Child
description: Consider Johnny's illformed graffiti. That Johnny can't write distresses highschool and college teachers. That Johnny can't handwrite, either bothers them much less. Johnny will grow up, acquire a secretary or at least typewriter. One or the other will translate his thoughts into legibility, it not parsahility. Yet some parents, often admitted illegibles themselves, do worry and complain about the scriptorial decadence of their children's lands. Schools, however, tend not to recognize the problem or take it seriously. Considered against the real educational trauma of cut and bleeding midgets, handwriting would seem to have a curriculum priority somewhere below Playdoh and jungle gyms. Americans, child and adult, are writing like spiders, crabs and worse, hentracking ballpoint pens across unreadable pages.

description: Reagan

title: Wind Rose
description: Suppose a big warm wind rose up the day you were giving birth? Would you name your child Wind Rose? Crescent Dragon% agon did, or at least the firstperson narrator of Wind Rose did.

title: KISSIKER MEETS WITH NORWEGIANS
description: OSLO, May 22Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who has said he would like to leave office at the end of this year whoever wins the Presidential election, is starting to act like a man who knows he may not be hack this way again.

title: FISHING
description: NEW JERSEY fishermen are keeping close eve on the water temperatures. A rise of just a few degrees should bring in the first wave of summer fish striped bass and fluke, with the bluefish not far behind.

title: Indian novels
description: In his amazing montage of history, In the American Grain, William Carlos Williams took time out from his flaying of the Puritans to praise Daniel Boone for seeing the truth of the Red Man, not an aberrant type, treachei ous and antiwhite to be feared and exterminated, but as a natural expression of the place, the Indian himself as right, the flow. er of his world. When American whites say such thingseven Dr. Williamsthere's always the suspicious tone of patronizing, of selfconsciously guilty idealization of a culture our ancestors smeared, uprootannihilated.

title: West Point Easing Procedures In Administering Honor Code
description: WEST POINT, May 22West Point officials have quietly modified confinement procedures and made it easier for cadets to consult lawyers in recent weeks, apparently in response to growing pressure over the administration of the honor code.

title: Paper Says an Aide To House Unit Calls Its Head Her Lover
description: WASHINGTON, May 22A staff member of the House Administration Committee has told The Washington Post, according to its Sunday issue, that she is the mistress of the committee's chairman, Representatives Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio.

title: Williams Conquers Top Runners in 2 Sprints at King Games
description: ATLANTA, May 22Steve Williams drew first blood in this year's battle of America's top sprinters today. The Florida Track Club star won the 100 and 200meter dashes at the Martin Luther King games and defeated three of the leading contenders for places on the United States Olympic team in those events.

title: Kristin Forsberg Is a Bride
description: Kristin Forsberg, chief of the Congressional liaison office cf the State Department's Passport Office, was married yesterday afternoon to John Edward Williams, a lawyer with the Washington film of Patton, Boggs & Floe.

title: The Vote on Nuclear Power
description: When Carl Horn Jr., chairman of the Duke Power Company in North Carolina, was asked recently by several business associates to contribute to the California campaign, he promptly responded by sending $9,000 of company funds.

description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 22Two Westchester schoolboys, Art Monk of White Plains and Walt Kirkland of Mount Vernon. were double winners while New York City Public School Athletic League teams took four relay victories today at the Eddy Memorial Track and Field Games.

title: Fresh Idea in '77 Becomes Fun Fund for City Children

description: Somewhere between Gage & Tollner's clam chowder and Top of the Park's pheasant pate. Marcus and Priscilla Lamb began to get the knack of it.

description: HONOLULU, May 22Ille Nastase, the controversial Rumanian tennis star now playing for the Hawaii Leis of World Team Tennis, came under criticism here this week for bypassing two matches in order to resta pulled groin muscle before his $100,000 winnertakeall match with Arthur Ashe tomorrow.

title: Nursing Home Report: Things Are Still Bad
description: The Moreland Act Commission set up last year to investigate and propose reform of the New York State nursing home industry has concluded its work with a pessimistic assessment of the results, and a prediction that abuses in the $3billion industry are so extensive that another inquiry will be necessary before too long.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT was 5:30 A.M,, Peking time, when I took my first walk through Tien an Mert Square. It is an immense plaza just a few minutes walk from my hotel, opposite the Gate to the Forbidden City. The full rush of bicycle traffic had not yet begun and I glimpsed a few elderly shadowboxers doing their nocturnal Taichi.

title: Point of View
description: This is the lost of a series of articles on the effect of racial change on housing and communities in the city. The writer is the chief housing economist of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.

title: Alexandra M. Miller Engaged To Henry Ernest Cooper 4th

title: The Uses of Enchantment
description: Each fairy tale is a magic mirror which reflects some aspects of our inner world, and of the steps required by our evolution from immaturity to maturityby the light of this axiom Bruno Bettelheim has written a charming book about enchantment, a profound book about fairy tales. He begins by observing, as an educator and therapist of severely disturbed children, that folk fairy tales remain the most satisfying and revelatory type of children's literature; that, though set in nevernever lands and dealing with palpably fantastic events, fairy tales conduct a moral education subtler and richer than any other type of story within a child's comprehension.

description: NTWPORT, R.I., May 22 (AP) Vice President Rockefeller will address the Synagogue Council of America here tomorrow in commemoration of the ?? 50th anniversary.

title: The Racial Clashes Involve Much More Than Busing
description: BOSTONJuly 27, 1919 was an oppressive Sunday in Chicago, the temperature in the 90's. Four black teenagers sought the cooling refuge of Lake Michigan. As their homemade raft drifted toward the white beach at 26th Street, rocks were hurled, at them, killing Eugene Williams. His death touched off five days of bloodshed, releasing years of accumulated racial hate and fear. White and black mobs, armed with clubs, knives and pistols, roamed the streets, attacking isolated victims. When rain and several regiments of militia finally brought calm, the mobs and gunmen had killed 16 blacks and 15 whites. The police had shot to death seven other blacks. More than 500 Chicagoans of both races had been

title: Environment And the Law
description: T HE Environment, to most people, conjures, up visions of green woods, clear streams and singing birds. But the 15 lawyers who are entrusted with protecting these amenities for New Jerseyans work in the same sort of windowless, artificially climatecontrolled offices as their counterparts at Jersey Central Power and Light or American Cyanimideenvironmental bad guys with whom they occasionally clash in court. The lawyers work on the third floor of the New Jersey State Banking Buflding in Trenton, under the direction of Morton Goldfein, Deputy Attorney Gcneral, Environmental Protection Section Chief. Mr. Goldfein and his staff are actually a part of the Attorney General's department, but they work exclusively for the Department of Environmental Protection, headed by David Bardin. They handle litigation for the department, just as a private law firm does for any client. If the department turns up a company that is polluting something, or several towns that refuse to regionalize their sewage treatment facilities, or a deer killed out of season, the case is turned over to Mr. Goldfein's Legal

title: U. S. Prisoners in Mexico Assert Protests Have Not Eased Plight
description: MEXICO CITY, May 22 (AP) Nearly two years after they staged a hunger strike to draw attention to their charges of extortion, police brutality and what they called United States Government indifference. American prisoners in Mexican jails say they continue to be treated unfairly under the Mexican judicial system.

description: By the last week in May the season is established. Summer is at hand. Solstices are matters of astronomical measurement, but the seasons are the consequence wind and weather here on earth, of sunlight and warmth and the hours of daylight and darkness.

description: ALBANYThe cynics here like to say, from time to time, that the New York State Legislature could make falling off a log look hard, and the history of the savings bank checking account bill seemed like one of those times.

title: FISHING
description: LONG ISLAND fishermen had their first glimpse of striped bass last week, although weakfish and fluke are expected to dominate in the Peconic and Great South Bays. Offshore, the party boats are continuing to fish the bottom this week, with some outstanding seabass catches reported.

description: COOS BAY, Ore., May 22As his campaign symbol, Senator Frank Church of Idaho has adopted Aesop's tortoise, who won its race with the hare with a slow determined effort.

title: AliDunn Isn't the Greatest at German Box Office
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 22Muhammad Ali's world heavyweight title fight with Richard Dunn was selling so well that the champion had to buy $100,000 worth of tickets today or the challenger might have been kicked out of his hotel.

title: Design
description: James Amster's house, at the back of the landmark Amster Yard (a planted courtyard in Manhattan surrounded by four 19thcentury buildings of varying heights), has undergone a renovation. Mr. Amster, who is a decorator, moved his office out of the building and appropriated the space to enlarge his living quarters, For the past 12 years, he had lived over the office in a cramped, if charming, apartment, which had a tiny kitchen, a dining room and a bedroom. A parlor (used both for client con_ sultations and as a living room) adjoined the office on the garden level. With the help of architect Kaymona wing Jean, Mr. Amster created a new kitchen and dining room downstairs in the old office space. He turned the upper floor into two bedrooms and a large bathroom. Mr. Amster put his Biedermeier furniture collection in the dining room, which looks like a country sitting room. In contrast to this room, the parlor is quite formal, furnished with newly upholstered Louis XIV antiques.

That's a picture of the class taken with Samuel, uh, the headmaster, uh, Samuel, what was his name, wait a minute, Samuel . . . Ferrand! When we graduated, he was in charge of the Newark Academy; afterwards his son Wilson took charge. That's when they were up in High StreetHigh and Williamthe old building there.

title: In Memoriam:The 6 Million
description: THE objects lie together in a tumbled pile on the table: torn hooks, ritual prayer bindings, the tattered nightgown and striped wool concentrationcamp jacket, the silver candlestick, the family photograph. A hand reaches forward to tuck a worn leather belt into place in the display and a small, tattooed number is revealed on the wrist. Like the artifacts, the men and women who sit around the table are survivors of the Holocaust.

title: Teachers Group on Coast Sues to Block a Plan to Integrate Faculties by Means of Mandatory Reassignments
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22A teachers organization has sued in Federal District Court in an attempt to stop the school board's plan to integrate faculties by means of mandatory reassienments.

title: Encounter: A Shock of Recognition Aboard the Orient Express
description: Outside our train the low moan of ships returning from a day on the Bosporus muffled the wail of muezzin calling the faithful to evening prayer. Dusk and haze mingled to soften the skyline of Asia just across the strait. The engine sighed as it coupled with a passenger car, sending a shudder down the line of couchettes and situps awaiting the start of the 16hour journey. In a few minutes the Direct Orient Express would depart Istanbul for the overnight trip to Sofia, Bulgaria..

title: Four novels
description: People talking books refer too easily to fiction's faculty of making order out of chaos? The fact is, there may be no chaos other than what we don't see or don't know, and that fiction's job is rather to discern the order in life, as a naturalist does. Chaos, after all, has causes. Often, what makes us catch our breath in a novel is its recognizably lifelike sequences.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A mysterycall it the case of the missing medalis beclouding the U.S. Mint's 10piece series of America's First Medals. The first two medals were offered in 1974; the ordering period for the *nal pair is expected soon. The series is described in the Mint's own promotional hrochures as comprised of 11/2tnch reproductions, struck in antiquefinish pewter, of the first 10 medals authorized (and originally issued in gold and silver) by the Continental Congress . . . to honor le outstanding Revolutionary War commanders and their exploits. But the Continental Congress authorized 11 medals, a fact that vi as brought to our attention in a letter from an internationally known coin dealer.

title: Intelligence Oversight
description: The Senate acted as the nation's conscience when approved creation of a permanent committee with powers to watch over the activities of the country's foreign and domestic intelligence agencies. Together with a new toughness shown by Attorney General Edward H. Levi in supervision of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, these moves represent important steps toward return to national sanity.

title: Calls Report Untrue
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Mr. Hays, asked about The Post's report, said through an aide: It's not true; it's just not true. The girl is under psychiatric care. This is Pmy reward for trying to help somebody who's sick.

title: A Chess Master at the Age of 13
description: JUST like Bobby Fischer some 20 years ago, Michael Wilder of Princeton is tearing up chess tournaments these days, knocking off grandmasters and other Goliaths of the board. And, like Fischer, he has earned the coveted master's rating at the age of 13.

title: Hilton Head's Foremost Product: The StraightArrow Good Life
description: Some years ago on a trip to visit relatives in the South we stopped for lunch in the little town of Bishopville, S.C. The children doodled on place mats bearing pictures of places in the state that visitors were urged to see. One of them was Hilton Head Island, and in boldfaced type it was referred to as the millionaires playground.Hardly the spot for us. The incident faded from memory until good friends suddenly moved to the island from suburban New York. Come on down. they said, and we havefor the past five years, usually in the spring during school vacation.

title: The Nation's Past Has a Pale Future In TV Specials
description: If the Bicentennial had been a television series, it would have been cancelled after 13 weeks. Of the 241 specials that the three networks used to spice up their schedules for the 197576 season, about two dozen were specifically aimed at celebrating the American spirit. The only one of this number to place in the top fourth of the Nielsen rankings was Eleanor and Franklin, ABC's twopart adaptation of the Joseph Lash book on the Roosevelts. And, even so, it was only Part II of Eleanor and Franklinwhich scored that well, ranking 43d; Part I was 87th. After that came ABC's Celebration: The American Spirit, the 90minute celebritystudded flagwaver, and Collision Course, the docudrama about Truman and MacArthur, both just squeaking in among the top 100.

title: The problem of the Absent God
description: These two books are almost twins, although at first sight they may appear very remote from each other, since they emerge from very different cultural backgrounds. Both authors are now in their early sixties and use French as their literary language, though it is not in the full sense, native to either. Edmond Jabes is a Jew who, according to the biographical details given on the cover of his book, spent the first 44 years of his life in Egypt and only moved to Paris after the Suez Crisis. E. M. Cinran is the son of a priest of the Sreek Orthodox Church in Carpathia, And appears to have lived most of his writers, then, are examples of linguistic alienation and reintegration; both, presumably, have chosen a medium which is to some extent foreign to them, and yet they have made it their own to the point of being hailed as remarkable French writers by certain wholly French critics.

title: PEOPLE
description: At Fort Lee High School, where she is a senior, she's known as Phyllis Tishberg, but to her fellow members of the Screen Actors Guild, and to TV commercial casting directors, the 17yearold is Phyllis Taylor. Miss Tishberg/ Taylor was thrilled enough, and so were her parents, Henrietta and Morris Tishberg, when she was recently accepted for the freshman class at Princeton this fall. Now comes more good news: The young actress, with some eight years of work in commercials behind her, has been named one of six recipients the guild's John L. Dales Scholarship Fund awards. She has a law and journalism career objective.

title: Me, Alice
description: Every man is to himself the centre of the whole worldthe axle on which it turns, Anthony Trollope wrote a century ago. Reporter Geoffrey Stokes and show biz phenomenon Alice Cooper agree today. To describe the making of a single rock album, Stokes presents dozens of these human axles at work in StarMaking Machinery.Cooper spins his own story In Me, Alice. None of the axles in either book go like clockwork.

It almost acts as a critical gloss upon both play and score, and it introduces undercurrents  the remorse of a drunken Tybalt at accidentally slaying Mercutio, for examplethat Shakespeare does not appear to have dreamed of But it is bright and intellectually challenging.

Its 20,000 residents are more prosperous and, because of the 22 schools and colleges located there, better educated than most West Bankers.

title: To Intervene or Not to Intervene: That Is the Government's Question
description: WASHINGTONIn the spring of 1962, a price increase for steel touched off a confrontation between the Kennedy Administration and business. Steel backed down, at least temporarily. Steel recently posted another price markup, 6 percent, effective June 1, for the mills most widely used product, flatrolled sheets and strips, The Ford Administration's response was confined to a perfunctory expression of concern by the President and a lowkey announcement of a study by the Council on Wage and Price Stability.

Also, how often they call me for minor repairs and adjustments or cleaning which they could easily have done themselves  usually when the shop is jammed with work and all my men are tied up with emergency calls.

description: Richard Condon writes how  to books. In The Manchurian Candidate, the most famous of his previous 13 novels, we learned how to brainwash, and how to make a Communist plot by means of making an antiCornmtmict witehhunt. In Mile High we By Richard Condon. 279 pp. New York: The Dial Press. 38.95. learn how to get rich bootlegging; you start by organizing the Prohibition movement. In his latest, The Whisper of the Axe, Condon tells us how to do all kinds of things: plan a bicentennial revolution in which millions will be killed; take over the international drug trade; plant agents inside Chinese war colleges; become a United States Senator; go from South Vietnam to northern Laos; brainwash double agents by making them perfect schizophrenics; make nuclear bombs, outwit masterminds, buy Haiti, be doublecrossed, make untold millions of dol

title: Going by Cable Car
description: New York City has a new connection between two of its islands: an aerial tramway shuttling from Roosevelt Island, the brand new community in the East River, to Manhattan. While most Roosevelt Islanders tend to enjoy their geographical, and psychic separation from Manhattan, many nevertheless expressed delight last week when the longawaited cable cars began regular quick runs to and from the city.

description: Dr. Theodore R. Roble, psychiatrist who was an early advocate of electroshock therapy and later chemotherapy in the treatment of certain mental illnesses, died yesterday in the emergency room of Mountainside Hospital Montclair, N. J., apparently of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: American Flock Strays Beyond Catholicism
description: From an institutional point of view, the news within American Catholicism has been almost unrellevedly bad for the last decade: Ichool closings, fewer worshipers, declining financial support, nuns and priests exiting from the active ministry, challenges to traditional authority. Through most of its travail, the church has maintained poise, including in 1968 when the former Archbishop of Washington. D.C., Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, and 50 priests clashed publicly on the birthcontrol issue. Now however. there are signs that composure may be giving to recrimination.

title: Portuguese Campaign
description: Without making any effort in his own behalf, the chief of staff of Portugal's Army has the backing of democratic parties representing 75 percent of the voters for the popular election of a President June 27. General Antonio Ramalho Eanes, always a man of few words, had not even consented to run until the Socialists last week joined the Popular Democrats and the Social Democratic Center in supporting his candidacy.

title: Tudor City Salutes Spring
description: Befitting the size and sequestered nature of Tudor City, its tenants yesterday held a Salute to Springthey refused to call it a block partywith more than 100 booths lining the streets of the 14building complex on the East Side.

title: The Movie Had An Unreal Quality
description: I went to see All the President's Men hoping to enjoy it, determined to overcome my prejudice. I failed. I found myself wishing the movie would end, not because reliving these times was personally painful (I have read almost every Watergate book) but because alas. I was bored.

description: ST. LOUIS, May 22 (UPI)AnheuserBusch Inc., hoping to resolve the issue blocking setdement of its two and one half  month teamster strike, has made a new proposal that reduces sanctions against strikers who committed violence in the walkout. It involves a panel to assess penalties.

After visiting Santiago, Mr. Simon said he could make such a recommendation because the junta had assured him that human rights conditions would be improved in Chile.

description: NEW DELHI, May 23Rama Chander, a 31yearold secretary in a large modern office here, has just joined a tiny but rapidly growing minority in Indiaby getting divorced.
