description: Above: The Battle of Paulus Hook being reenacted at Roosevelt Stadium

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Giscard Aims to Please
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing flew home to Paris this weekend after a weeklong state visit to the United States in which he followed. an agile line between the conflicting demands of French and American politics. In the end, he managed to please, if not fully satisfy, both sides.

title: Williams Finds Cannes Festival a Crass Menagerie
description: CANNES, FranceTennessee Williams is having a harrowing time as president of the jury of the film festival here, which he says he considers a vulgar, commercialized event. Nevertheless he is sitting through two movies a day, mostly detesting them, and has managed to finish work on one new piece of writing and start another.

title: What New York Banks May Offer
description: The New York Times/May 24, 1976

title: Red Sox Gain a Series Split in Sloppy Game
description: After 3 hours 19 minutes of less than championshipstyle baseball at Yankee Stadium yesterday, the Boston Red Sox found they had beaten the Yankees, 76, and gained a split of their fourgame series.

title: Ancient Title Victor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 23 (AP)Ancient Title, oddson favorite got up in the final strides and won the ~110,300 Californian today for the second straight year. The 6yearold beat Pay Tribute by a head, earning $65,300. The return was $3.60 for $2.

title: T.A. Accuses the City on Bus Franchises
description: The Transit Authority charged yesterday that the city's Bureau of Franchises repeatedly awarded the best bus routes to private bus companies, and it called on Mayor Beame to investigate.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 23The post office manager here reports that the volume of letters to Legislators has been extremely heavy in recent weeks. Legislators report that most of the mail is in opposition to a state income tax.

title: CONTINUING RISE SEEN FOR RATES
description: Interest rates have been climbing for four weeks, and they have reached their highest levels so far in 1976. But, even so, the dominant view among bond dealers and investment bankers is that rates are headed still higher. Once; Markets again, however, some money market analysts believe that the upward push in rates could well pause as the Federal Reserve stands back and surveys what impact it has made on the growth of the money supply.

title: Jacob Starr, 87, President Of Artkraft Strauss, Is Dead
description: Jacob Starr, president of thel Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation for the last 50 years and a pioneer in the electronic advertising industry, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 1095 Park Avenue.

title: Miss Diserio Bride Of T. S. Alexander
description: Eugenie A. Diserio and T. Steven Alexander, painters and students studying for Master of Fine Arts degrees at Columbia University, were married yesterday afternoon in Waveny House, a former New Canaan, Conn., private estate now owned by the town.

title: Zaire Leader Said to See Inevitable War in Rhodesia
description: Time magazine, in its current issue, quotes Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, as saying that he expects war in whiteruled Rhodesia.

title: joint Custody: Is Sharing the Child a Dangerous Idea?
description: Sixyearold Tommy Mastin, the central figure in a controversial childrearing arrangement known as joint custody, leads something of a double life in Gainesville, Fla.

title: Exhibit on Solar Energy Set in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Americans who visit the capital this summer for the Bicentennial will have a chance to see a free outdoor exhibiton of the energy source that may become the workhorse of the American economy in the third century of independencesunshine.

title: Brown, Dependent on Oregon WriteIns, Presses Massive VoterEducation Drive
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 23My big job, said Walter McGuire, the 30yearold manager of Gov. Edmund. G. Brown Jr.'s campaign in Oregon, is to con vince everyone in this state that Jerry's real first name is writein.

title: Memorial Services
description: MARTIISANEZDr. Felix. A fourth annversary Memorial Mass in loving memory of Dr. Felix MartiIbanez will be offered, at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A.M., on May 21, 1976.

title: GUAM TYPHOON LOSS PUT AT $300 MILLION
description: AGANA, Guam, May 23 (UPI) Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo said today that a typhoon that struck Guam over the weekend had caused more than $300 million in damage, leaving 80 percent of the island's buildings in ruins, three persons dead and 60 injured.

title: Brazil Beats England, 10
description: LOS ANGELES, May 23 (UPI)Roberto scored with less than a minute to play to give Brazil a 10 victory today over England before 32,495 fans in a Bicentennial Cup game at the Coliseum.

title: Horace W. Wilkie, 59, Dies; Chief Justice in Wisconsin
description: PITTSBURGH, May 23Horace W. Wilkie, Chief Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, died here today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Nadjari May Retain Post Beyond June 29 Deadline
description: There is a chance that Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, may have his current tenure extended beyond Tune 29 deadline, according to at least one high official.

title: Maryland Gains Final in Lacrosse
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 23 (AP)Maryland, led by Ed Mullen's recordbreaking performance, won the right to defend its university division lacrosse title by overwhelming Navy, 2211, today in a semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: TV Review
description: Television has reached the season of filler material. The flood of reruns is being desperately sandbagged with pilots for series that never made it, with limitedrun series that might make it in some future season, with single specials anxious simply to reach the status of a limitedrun series. Among the latter is Charo, a musicvariety halfhour that can be seen on ABCTV tonight at 8.

title: San Francisco Club Wins
description: The San Francisco Athletic Club defeated Ridgewood InterGuiliana, 10, Sunday at Maspeth, Queens, and won the challenge cup, the openplay soccer championship of the United States.

title: The Boston Schools: II
description: BOSTON, May 23For a decade after the Supreme Court held school segregation unconstitutional in 1954, the Federal judges of the South struggled almost alone to carry out the decision. With little help from Washington, they stood up to massive political resistance and personal attack in their own communities. A book on their performance, by J. W. Peltason, is called FiftyEight Lonely Men.

title: Susan N. Goldberg Wed to Fred Isquith
description: Susan Nora Goldberg, daughter of Samuel Goldberg of Lebanon, Pa., and the late Rose Goldberg, was married yesterday to Fred Taylor Isquith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Santley Isquith of New York.

title: How Futile Mission Led to Clues to Graft
description: One June evening in 1974, two secret police agents began negotiations to buy a Bronx discotheque, which they planned to use as a base for spying on the Mafia. But, instead of being solely an undercover mission against organized crime, that investigation put lawenforceIment officials on the trail of possible major corruption scandals in the courts and at the State Liquor Authority.

title: A Chance for Justice
description: In the final days of the session in Albany, the legislators might well recall the words of one of the great pioneers of legal change, the late Chief Justice Arthur Vanderbilt of New Jersey: Judicial reform is no sport for the shortwinded or for lawyers who are afraid temporary defeat.

title: FORD ASKS RETURN TO MORAL QUALITY
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., May 23President Ford ventured today into oratorical territory heretofore occupied by Jimmy Carter when he discoursed on the Bible at a school sponsored by a fundamentalist Christian group.

title: New Banking Bargains Likely With CheckingAccount Law
description: No sooner had the New York State Senate passed the savings bank legislation the other day when Citibank, New York's largest commercial bank, announced new nofee checking plan requiring only that a customer keep $500 in a savings account.

title: City Ballet Evokes Coppelia Panache
description: One of the main reasons the New York City Ballet production of Coppelia. with choreography by George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova, is so wholeheartedly attractive must he simply its sense of unity. It all seems to grow, as of one piece. I was aware of this all the more seeing it again at the New York State Theater on Saturday night.

title: A.M. A. Reaffirms Advertising Right But Bars Soliciting
description: CHICAGO, May 23 (UPI)Physicians may advertise but they should not solicit patients, overcharge or pay kickbacks, the judicial council of the American Medical Association said in a statement on medical ethics published today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: After they exploded grenades on the plane setting it afire, three of the six hijackers who seized the Philippines Air Lines jet Friday were killed yesterday with 10 of their 86 hostages when a gun battle broke out between the hijackers and troops in Zamboanga. 530 miles south of Manila, where the plane's captors had forced it to land. Twentytwo other passengers were wounded, and 54 escaped through emergency exits. Seventeen other hostages had previously been released by the hijackers. The three remaining hijackers were captured, but were seriously wounded. They had identified themselves as members of a Moslem separatist movement. [Page 1, Columns 1.4.]

title: Teacher Weds Miss De Paoli
description: Deborah Jeanne De Paoli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael De Paoli of Brookfield, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel Francis Verdery, son of the Rev. Dr. John D. Verdery, headmaster of the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., and Mrs. Verdery.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The New York Times on Saturday in an account of radiouranium waste piles that uranium yellowcake not radioactive. It is radioactive.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: A Gift of Love, by Gall Magruder (A. J. Holman, Philadelphia, $7.95). Keeping a family together after the imprisonment of Jeb Magruder.

title: Guards Bitter After Prison Riot
description: COMSTOCK, N. Y., May 21Correction officers at Great Meadows Correctional Institution, the huge maximum security prison here where some 150 inmates rioted last Monday, charged yesterday that the administration knew the disturbance was coming but refused to add guards because or possible overtime expense.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EXOTIC GROOVE At his keyboard in the New York Hilton Hotel's Kismet. Lounge, Ben Dino's music adds to the escapist aspect of this atmospheric room, at the far end of the hotel's northside concourse on the main floor. A few steps down and you're on thick, Far East carpeting with clusters of tables, chairs and banquettes. Twilight illumination conies from red candle jars and small conethe walls.

title: Hull Does It Again
description: HOUSTON, May 23 (AP)Bobby Hull, for the second straight game, knocked in the winning goal in a 54 victory by the Winnipeg Jets over the Houston Acros in the World Hockey Association championship playoffs tonight. Winnipeg holds a 20 lead in the fourofsevengame World Cup series.

title: Lois Posner Married To William G. Baetz
description: Lois Posner and William George Baetz were married yesterday in Miami, where Rabbi Joseph Narot performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

title: Unhealthy Charade
description: The selfrighteous farce which Arab governments and their thirdworld allies are imposing upon international specialized agencies reached a new pinnacle of hypocrisy at the Geneva assembly of the World Health Organization.

title: People
description: John J. Caggiano, Robert W. Mackall and Michael Uris have been elected senior vice presidents and creative management supervisors of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.

title: Garcia of Cuba Takes Lead In Capablanca Chess Match
description: HAVANA, May 23, (Reuters)Guillermo Garcia of Cuba took the lead in the Capablanca chess tournament: after the fifth round that was played last night in Cienfuegos, east of here.

title: U.S. Asks DC10 Changes To Combat Intake of Birds;
description: The Government has proposed mandatory modification of DC10 engines in an effort to insure against a repetition of the accident here last fall in which one of the jumbo jets was destroyed after seagulls had been ingested into an engine on a takeoff run.

title: Democratic Alternative
description: Political parties have habitually in the past put together their platforms in the week leading up to the national convention, hearing witnesses and haggling over language, while halfdistracted by the fight for the Presidential nomination.

title: Rep. Abzug Backed for Senate By New Democratic Coalition
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug was endorsed in her bid for the Senate yesterday by the New Democratic Coalition at a meeting of its state delegates that was unusually devoid of controversy.

title: 3 Hijackers and 10 Hostages Die As Philippine Plane Is Set Afire
description: MANILA, May 23A Philippine Air Lines jet seized Friday by six hijackers exploded in flames early today in an exchange of fire between the gunmen and attacking Philippine troops. Three of the hijackers and 10 of the hostages died in the battle. The three other hijackers were captured.

title: Port Authority Stages Party for Bicentennial
description: Entertainers, military units In colorful historical uniforms, a fifeanddrum team, a circus calliope and a cannon that fired blanks were marshaled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on the roof parking lot of its midtown Manhattan bus terminal at 41st Street and Eighth Avenue for a Bicentennial community day party yesterday afternoon.

title: Advertising
description: Wells, Rich, Greene may be losing a little Love, but It's going to get a bang out of life.

title: Duran Wins by Knockout
description: ERIE, Pa., May (UPI) Roberto Din an of Panama, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, successfully defended his title today by knocking out his challenger, Lou Bizzarro in the 14th round of a scheduled 15rounder.

title: Miss Guthrie's Bid At Indy Abandoned
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (AP)  Janet Guthrie's dream of becoming the first woman starter in the Indianapolis 500 ended for at least one year today when A.J. Foyt withdrew his backup Coyote from Qualifications.

title: Moths at a Dark Bulb
description: Weintraub was slipped into the room at the last moment and found a place in the corner. He had read about White House press briefings, of course, but had never been near one. The man in charge began with confidence.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: PAUL McCARTNEY & WINGS, rock, Madison Square Garden, 8.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M, MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER NASSAU NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE CONNECTICUT 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487761.

title: West Point Acknowledges Cheating Is Widespread
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. May 23  The Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, Lieut. Gen. Sidney Berry, acknowledged today that cheating at West Point was more widespread than previously indicated.

title: On a Fine Sunny Afternoon in Spring, New Yorkers
description: Teaberry, the only trained attack poodle in America, stood by and watched yesterday as Abricot, a smaller beige poodle, was spraydyed black. Abricot's last scene had required five takes. In yesterday's bright sunshine, her ersatz black coat had begun to look dull gray. Since Abricot's next scene would be a closeup, the director wanted to insure that she would look her best.

title: U.S. Tests Reaction in Mideast To France's Troop Proposal
description: STOCKHOLM, May 23The United States is quietly sound ing out Israel and Arab governments in the Middle East for reactions to France's offer to send a peacekeeping force to Lebanon, according to high ranking American diplomats.

title: Return to Forever Band, at Beacon Ends U.S. Tour
description: Return to Forever ended its most extensive American tour with three concerts of the Beacon Theater on Saturday and yesterday. Although the jazz rock group is more popular now than ever before, its members will be taking a long vacation to work on individual solo projects following the Beacon concerts, and one wonders whether they will be reuniting.

title: About New York
description: More than 700 people attended Asher Miskel's funeral last Tuesday. Many of thern were the owners, managers, wailers, bartenders, cooks and customers at bars on the East Side and in Greenwich Village.

title: Diana Roberts Married in Capital
description: Diana Byron Roberts and Thomas Price McCarley, both of Washington, were married there yesterday afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church, Georgetown, by the Rev. Jo Cowin Tartt Jr.

title: Second M.A.C. Offer of Bond Swap Begins
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation's second offer to exchange its bonds for New York City notes will get under way today.

title: NOEL FRANCIS SHEELEY
description: STAMFORD, Cont., May 23Noel Francis Sheeley, of Thistle Lane. Rye, N.Y., a merchandising department head with the T. C. Penney Company in New York, died yesterday in a Stamford nursing home.

title: Mattwell Cantures Travis Final, 2 and 1
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 23Mike Mattwell, a 52yearold energy conservation engineer who plays out of the Hampton Country Club, won the 66th annual Travis Memorial golf tournament today. The Glen Cove resident defeated Jerry Courvine of Connecticut's Shore Haven Club, 2 and I, in the final.

title: Swan Is Victim of 2Run 7th in 54 Loss
description: MONTREAL, May 23The Mets scrambled back twice to take the lead against the Montreal Expos today at rainswept Jarry Park but could not do it a third time and lost. 54.

title: Dr. George Lowe Weds Miss Judge
description: In Temple Shaaral Shomoyim in Lancaster, Pa., yesterday afternoon, Elizabeth Scott Judge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Scott Judge of Arlington, Mass., became the bride of Dr. George Everett Lowe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lowe of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was Incorrectly stated in The New York Times on Sat. urday in an account of radio. active uranium waste tailing piles that uranium yellowcake WAS not radioactive. It is radioactive.

title: Bridge:
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 23The dramatic finale to the world championships here yesterday, when six jubilant Brazilians edged past the defending Italian champions to take the title, demonstrates several important truths.

title: User y Says Pay Increases Will Not Be Inflationary
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (Reuters)W. J. Usery the Secretary of Labor, says he believes Wage increases this year will average less than 10 percent and will not prove inflationary to the economy.

title: FRENCH IN DISPUTE ON LEBANON ROLE
description: PARIS, May 23President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's tentative proposal to send French troops to Lebanon began to assume the proportions of a national political dispute today, as prominent officials of the leftist opposition assailed the President's initiative.

title: Italy Routs U.S., 40, In Soccer
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Italy trounced Team America 40, today in the opening game of the Bicentennial Soccer Cup at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium before 33,455 fans.

title: Beame Administration Plans to Press Case on Bronx Terminal Market Rent
description: After a sixmonth string of financial disputes in which New York City quietly abandoned claims against the Arol Development Corporation, the Beame administration has decided to take at least one case to court if necessary.

title: Acquittal Thwarts Appeal On Home Marijuana Use
description: FREEHOLD, May 23  Ronald L. Sage, a 32yearold Freehold lawyer who had hoped to argue a landmark case to void state laws against the personal use of marijuana in homes, has failed in his appeal by winning in the courtroom.

title: Byrne fo Allow July 1 Jersey School Closings
description: Gov. Byrne said yesterday that he would abide by the rule of law and allow the state's public schools to close July 1 under a state Supreme Court mandate if the Legis lature failed to support a new schoolfinancing system.

title: Sets Turn Back Golden Gaters, 3020
description: UNIONDALE, L. L., May 24 The New York Sets defeated the Golden Gaters tonight, 3020, before 2,374 fans at Nassau Colisernu it was the Sets fourth straight World Team Tennis victory.

title: SOVIET CONCEDES ARMS VIOLATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Soviet Union has acknowledged to the United States a technical violation related to a 1972 strategic arms accord and has taken steps to rectify the infraction, Administration officials said today.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Bert Miler

title: VICTORY IN OHIO FORECAST BY UDALL
description: CINCINNATI, May 24Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona today said he was flatly predicting a victory in Ohio's June 8 primary.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ATTIC ALCHEMY Two exhibitions opening today should disprove the notion that playthings and comic strips are only for the very young. The Museum of the City of New York is opening its new Toy Collection, over 2,000 items ranging from whimsical to scientific and assembled some 50 years ago by H. Samuel Gold, a local businessman, and now presented to the museum in his memory by his son, Gordon K. Gold.

title: Schaefer Festival Opens On June 14 With Mancini
description: Henry Mancini and his orchestra, along with Morgana King and the rock harmonies of Sailor, will open the 11th summer Schaefer Music Festival on June 14 at Central Park&s (Fifth Skating Rink Theater, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Bridge
description: Politics has an impact on international bridge nowadays, as it does unfortunately on other sports and recreations. The problems in the world team Olympiad in Monte Carlo, Monaco, earlier this month fell into two categories forfeits and visas.

title: EDWARD M. SWINBURNE
description: Edward M. Swinburne of Garrison. N.Y., chairman of athletics at the New York Athletic Club from 1942 to 1958 and a former member of the board of governors, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: De Sapio and Fitzgerald Plead Not Guilty to Perjury and Assail Nadjari Tactics
description: Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Tammany Hall leader, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge that he had lied to a special grand jury investigating how information of a conI fidential investigation by Maurice H. Nadjari's office had been divulged to targets of the investigation.

title: U.S.INVESTIGATING CHARGES ON HAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Department of Justice is investigating charges that Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, placed a woman in a $14,000ayear Government job in exchange for her sexual favors, senior Federal officials said today.

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A powerful firecracker exploded in a glassencased fire extinguisher cabinet yesterday in the Cliffside Park, N.J., High School, spraying a hallway with glass shards that killed a 14yearold girl and injured two other students, the police said. The dead girl was Elizabeth Hennessy, a freshman and honor roll student. When the firecracker went off, the hallway was filled with students walking to their seventhperiod classes. The two injured students were treated at Englewood Hospital and released. They were identified as Denise Davino, 14, of Cliffside Park, and Anthony Cancian, 16, of Fairview.

title: Fitzgerald Role in the City Is Recalled
description: One constant in Thomas I. Fitzgerald's long career in city governmentand in the shadow government of the Democratic organizationhas been his informal title: A close friend of Carmine De Sapio.

title: TV: Woman Rebel, a Portrait of Margaret Sanger
description: The Woman Rebel on public television tonight, at 8, is Margaret Sanger. As a _key figure in the developmerit of the birthcontrol movement in this country, she is the subject of the latt hourlong production from Nova  the generally exceptional science series being put&, together by Boston statron.

title: Olympic Soccer Groups Drawn
description: MONTREAL., May 24 (UPI)Poland will open defense of its Olympic soccer championship July 18 against Uruguay, the International Federation of Football Associations announced today. In other opening day competition, East Germany will meet Brazil, Spain will play Zambia and Iran will face Nigeria. In the draw conducted by I.F.F.A., the 16 teams were divided into the following groups:

title: Testimony by Fitzgerald
description: Following are excerpts from the grand jury testimony of Thomas I. Fitzgerald concerning a charge that Carmine G. De Sapio sent a messenger to Mr. Fitzgerald on Dec. 16, 1975 to warn him about a possible wiretap on his telephone by the special state prosecutor:

title: Potato Futures Defaults Loom
description: For the first time COMmodity brokers can recall, massive defaults on a commodity futures contract are expected this afternoon on the 104yearold New York Mercantile Exchange where Maine potatoes, platinum, silver bullion and coins are traded.

title: U.S.INVESTIGATING CHARGES ON HAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Department of Justice is investigating charges that Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, placed woman in a $14,000ayear Government job in exchange for her sexual favors, senior Federal officials said today.

title: 2 Postal Aides Held In $800,000 Theft
description: Two Postal Service employees at Kennedy International Airport were accused yesterday of stealing $800,000 and then going on a spending spree totaling nearly $150,000. The rest of the money still is missing. The theft of the currency was considered to be the largest in the history of the post office.

title: Media Events
description: Presidential primaries are inevitably media events. Although these contests select delegates and the rollcall of the delegates at the national conventions will ultimately be decisive, the primaries in this age of television also have a kind of instant significance depending upon how the press interprets them.

title: City Hall Budget Making Is Mostly for Show
description: Budget day at City Hall be symbolically enough for the City Council and the Board of Estimate, the two institutions that have been reduced by the fiscal crisis to the near relic status ot serving as the yestigial organs in the city&s body politic. Council members, curious about is budget that they were to act on but that actually had been composed beyond their power according to state emergency Vdictates, sent an aide to fetch a copy. Struggling with the heavy, fourinchthick book, the iaide lost control in midBroadway and some of the 1,327 pages began blowing away wildly in the morning sun. The frazzled aide complained, Don&t they use glue on this thing?

title: Dibley, ElShafei Advance in Tennis
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, May 24 (AP)Colin Dibley of Australia and Ismail ElShafei of Egypt, posted straightset victories today in the first round of the $50,000 Duesseldorf international Grand Prix tennis tournament. Shafei beat Ivan Molina of Colombia, 64, 75, and Colin Dibley of Australia topped Antonio Munoz of Spain, 64, 62.

title: Helping New York
description: It is noisy in the brightly painted basement at 359 Madison Street, housingproject building on the Lower East Side. Electric saws whine and sewing machines whir. There is a constant hammering. But neighborhood people who take their broken televisions, wellworn shoes and broken furniture to be repaired there don't mind. They save a lot of money.

title: Woman's Drive for DrugPrice Ads Ends Victoriously After 2 Years
description: RICHMOND, May 24On the day two and a half years ago that her lawsuit went to trial here, challenging the Virginia State Board of Pharmacy's prattice of forbidding druggists to advertise prescription drug prices, Lynn B. Jordan was in the hospital undergoing surgery.

title: Rizzo Man Is Elected Head Of Philadelphia Democrats
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (UPI)Mayor Frank L. Rizzo's handpicked candidate for head of the city's Democratic Party, Martin Weinberg, a former city solicitor, won election to the post tonight.

title: Yankee Records
description: Yankee Records

title: Moon's Sect Pushes ProSeoul Activities
description: A number of individuals and organizations connected with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the wealthy Korean industrialist and evangelist, have intimate ties with and have received assistance from the South Korean Government and the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, according to former Korean and American officials and former members of the Moon organization.

title: All Knocks Down Dunn Five Times, Wins in Fifth Round and Keeps Title
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Tuesday, May 25  Richard Dunn, who dreamed he would win the world heavyweight championship from Muhammad Ali this morning, can sleep well, even if dreams don&t always come true.

title: have Anderson
description: Instincts. Some baseball players have them, some don&t. But the really good ones usually have them from the beginning and Willie Randolph keeps displaying the proper instincts, off the field as well as on. After the 76 loss to the Boston Red Sox ort Sunday, the New York Yankees rookie second baseman walked over to the locker of Kerry Dineen and consoled the rookie center fielder who had been blinded by the sun on a short fly ball that fell for an embarrassing error. Willie Randolph didn&t realize that Billy Martin had noticed his thoughtful ness. He&s a winner, the manager mentioned later. That&s the type of thing a winner does. That&s also the type of thing that an experienced player does, not a rookie. But six weeks short of his 22d birthday, Willie Randolph is that rarity an established player as a rookie. He has established himself as the Yankees second baseman, perhaps for the next 15 years, And when the firstplace Yankees opened a twogame series with the Milwaukee Brewers last night, Willie Randolph was their leading batter with a. 319 average.

title: Ali Praises Dunn And, of Course, Ali
description: MUNICH. West Germany, Tuesday, May 25Muhammad Ali paid respect to the lionhearted Richard Dunn, and Dunn praised Ali. As far as the fighters were concerned, they did about as well as they had expected. And both went home proud men this morning.

title: Market Place
description: Alarm over the wave of corporate takeover efforts has accelerated efforts by states to protect their jobs and shareholders.

title: One Small Step
description: While everyone awaits some dramatic breakthrough in energy technology to end this country's dependence on foreign oil, real relief is more likely to come in a dozen less spectacular waysseemingly trivial adjustments in routine economic behavior that collectively can add up to significant reductions in demand for oil.

title: HOSPITALS CAUGHT IN CRISIS MIDDLE
description: Ordered to trim $240 million from its operations by mid1978, the Health and Hospitals Corporation decided last January to phase out some old and inefficient facilities and to lay off 3,200 more workers.

title: Pat Herman Wed To Daniel Ferro
description: Pat Herman, a former journalist, and Daniel Ferro, who is on the faculty of the Tuilliard School and chairman of the voice department of the Manhattan School of Music, were married in the city yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride by Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger and Cantor Lawrence Avery.

title: 3 British Banks Increase Base Rates of Interest
description: Three British banks announced yesterday increases in their base interest rates for sterling loans, following action last Friday by the Bank of England, which raised its central bank rate to 111/2 percent from 10 1/2.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: May 25, 1976 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11:30 A.M. on Middle East.

title: France Updates Centennial Gift
description: France Updates Centennial Gift

title: El Pitirre Registers 2d Straight Triumph
description: Enrique Ubarri's El Pitirre, a 4yearold Kentuckybred colt who went through his first 10 outings this season Without reaching the winners circle, scored his second straight triumph at Belmont park yesterdy. He won the featured $25,000 Northern Dahcer Handicap.

title: Xerox Discloses F.T.C. Is Studying Its Pricing
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating possible antitrust violations in some of its copier pricing plans.

title: Seats at $25 Apiece Offered at Battery To Watch Big Ships
description: If you're eager to watch the parade of international sailing ships through New York Harbor July 4, and have not found an accommodating friend with a terrace overlooking the Hudson River, you can find a perch on the landfill site of the proposed Battery Park City housing development, for a $25 admission price.

title: Advertising
description: Things at Kurtz & Symon are beginning to return to normal or as close to normal as things can be at an ad agency.

title: Business Records
description: OMNIFACTS PUBLICATIONS INC. 635 South Columbus Ave., Mount Vernon, N.Y. Petitioners are Panorama Press Inc.; Village Press Inc. and the Dolvrn Platemaking Corporation.

title: Mary Handlin, Historian, Dies; Coauthor of Books on America
description: Mary Plug Hamalin, historian and coauthor with her husband, Prof. Oscar Handlin of Harvard University, of six books on the experience and development of American civilization, died yesterday of cancer in the university's infirmary. She was 62 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Besides being a slickly plotted, fastpaced, allaround professional job of novelwriting, The Company, by John D. Ehrlichman, the former assistant to the President for domestic affairs, has two things in particular going for it. First, it's a roman a clefthat is, a novel in which the characters seem to resemble certain actual peopleand an especially clever one at that, because not only do the characters wear sandwich boards that make them as easily identifiable as people in a Jacqueline Susann story but they also bear little labels that give you the feeling you are being let in secret by who knows.

title: Police in Two Cities To Test Compact Cars
description: DALLAS, May 24 (AP)The police here and in New Orleans will test a $10,000 compact car to see if it can stand up to police work and save gas and money.

title: MICHIGAN U. BACKS GENETIC RESEARCH
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 24 (AP)A controversial type of genetic research, capable of creating new life forms and considered potentially dangerous by its critics, has received the goahead from the University of Michigan regents.

title: 4 Olympians Selected
description: Nancy Lieberman of Far Rockaway and Gail Marquis of St. Alban's, both of Queens College, have been chosen for the 12member United States Olympic women's basketball team. Also selected were Mary Ann O'Connor and Sue Rojcewicz, both of Southern Connecticut State College.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Beaverkill Reflections
description: ROSCOE, N.Y A difficulty in staying at Doug Bury&s Antrim Lodge when fishing the Beaverkill, the Willowemoc or the east branch of the Delaware is that the faces of friends surface out of the crowd in the main dining room like Mayflies on a trout stream.

title: President's Choice For Consumer Unit Rejected by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The Senate rejected today President Ford's nomination of S. John Byington to the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which decides whether products are safe to sell.

title: Data for New Rises Asked By Rent Guidelines Board
description: The city&s Rent Guidelines Board is requesting tenants and landlords in New York City to submit information that might be considered in developing new maximums for rent increases for the 700,000 rentstabilized apartments here.

title: Arniram Pi gai in Uneven Piano Recital
description: There are pianists who play so adeptly and with such evident love of their instrument that a listener finds it difficult to concentrate on the music. Glittering scales and dazzling arpeggios come to teem the end, rather than the means. Amiram Rigai, an Israeli pianist who gave a recital at Alice Tully. Hall on Sunday night, is too good a musician to be carried quite that far, but the tendency was always there and it diluted one&s appreciation of his generally impressive playing.

title: French Embassy Compound In North Vietnam Robbed
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 24 (Agence FrancePresse)A burglary occurred at the French Embassy here on Saturday.; with the thief or thieves breaking a storeroom window and escaping with spare parts for automobiles, bicycle tires, tools and household appliances.

title: DIVORCE GROUNDS EXPANDED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, May 24 (AP) The Indian Parliament passed a new marriage bill today making desertion, cruelty or a single act of adultery sufficient ground for divorce.

title: In memoriam
description: GARRETTFroddioOur loving Freddio, our beautiful son and brother, today is your 22nd Birthday. Always with us. Play ball. Daddy, Momma and Todd.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Threatening the Sick
description: Members of Local 420 of District Council 37, State, County and Municipal Employees have good cause to be dismayed by the prospective layoff of an additional 3.200 employees from a Health and Hospitals Corporation staff that has already been reduced by 5,889 workers. But it is futile and irresponsible for the union to attempt to forestall this essential and longcontemplated economy measure by threatening to strike against the sick at 18 municipal hospitals.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 25, 1976
description: Hearings in the House of Representatives will be held next month on the political activities in the United States of the religious movement of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the wealthy Korean industrialist and evangelist. Mr. Moon's central organization in the United States is the Unification Church, which claims 30,000 American members. According to former South Korean and American officials and former members of the Moon organization, a number of persons and organizations connected with Mr. Moon have intimate ties with and have received assistance from the South Korean Government and the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency. Representative Donald M. Fraser, Democrat of Minnesota, whose subcommittee on international organizations has been investigating the operation of the Korean C.I.A. in the United States, said that our information shows a pattern of activity that raises serious questions as to the nature and purpose of Moon's various organizations. [Page 1, Columns 67.]

title: Two Concordes Open Passenger Runs to Washington
description: CHANTILLY, Va., May 24Britain and France, their Concordes barred, from New York in a legal conflict over noise, opened transAtlantic supersonic service today to Washington, their destination of second choice.

title: Kennedy Says 1,350 Votes Is All Carter Should Need
description: BOSTON, May 24 (UPI)If Jimmy Carter goes to the Democratic National Convention with 1,350 committed delegates, then the stopCarter coalition should stop itself, according to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Dance:McBride and Bonnefous in Piano Concerto
description: It is not so much the depth of George Balanchine that impressesalthough he can certainly be deep but the breadth. Probably no choreographer in history had had quite this man&s extraordinary range  a range engendered perhaps by his jour neying from St. Peterrsburg to New York, via Paris, London and Copenhagen. I here are people who are world citizens; George Balanchine is a world choreographer.

title: Suspicion of Perjury Is Found For Japanese in Lockheed Case
description: TOKYO, May 24 (UPI)A Parliamentary committee passed a resolution today charging the president of Japan's largest privately owned airline with suspicion of perjury in connection with the Lockheed payoffs scandal.

title: Eva Popper Gets New Post at Met
description: Eva Popper has been named director of development for the Metropolitan Opera; it was announced yesterday by Anthony A. Bliss, executive director. Miss Popper will seek support from current Met donors and new sources of funds from among foundations, corporations and private benefactors. She succeeds Floyd Landis, director of development since 1971, who is leaving to become a freelance fundraising consultant.

title: SOVIET CONCEDES ARMS VIOLATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Soviet Union has acknowledged to the United States a technical violation related to a 1972 strategic arms accord and has taken steps to rectify the infraction, Administration officials said today.

title: Quick Shift of World's Oil In Emergency Is Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, May 24If a new oil shortage occurred as a result of a Middle East war or other cause, the International Energy Agency could begin redistributing available supplies within two weeks, the agency's executive director, Ulf Lantzke, said today.

title: Drop Is Biggest in More Thany Year
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday to post their biggest loss in more than a year as the recent rise in interest rates, coupled with fears of higher rates still to come, touched off moderate selling in Wall Street Moving steadily lower throught the day, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 971.53, with a decline of 19.22 points.

title: Clive Davis Guilty In Tax Evasion
description: Clive Davis, former president of CBS Records, pleaded guilty yesterday to failing to report $8,800 in income on his Federal tax return for 1972.

title: Demolition of Part of West Side Highway May Start in September
description: Wrecking crews are expected to start teartng down a 17block section of the dilapidated I old structure carrying the West Side Highway in September. First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: LACHOWICZ (Polish), Grata June 12; sails from Port Newark, N.J.

title: Jewelry With Rhythm, and Sound
description: Sound and movement are important to Joanne Cooper, a painter who has carried over the rhythms of her figuralive impressionism to the medium of jewelry. As the wearer moves, some of her bold silver and vermeil ornaments, particularly leaf necklaces and chokers, tinkle like wind chimes in the breeze.

title: Bitter Congressional Primary Divides Republicans in North Bergen County
description: RIDGEWOOD, May 24Republican leaders say there has not been such a bitter Congressional primary fight in Bergen County in a long time, so much so, in fact, that the odds have multiplied against the party's recapture of the Seventh District seat won two years ago by Representative Andrew Maguire.

title: Death With Dignity Move Delayed in Quinlan Case
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 24 The ability of Karen Anne Quinlan to breathe without a mechanical respirator has temporarily halted efforts to allow her to die with dignity, in line with ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court, and could force the case back into court, according to people close to the case.

title: People in Sports
description: Julius Erring of the New York Nets arrived 30 minutes late and Larry Robinson of the Montreal Canadiens was ?? minutes early yesterday to receive the Sport MagazineAmerican Motors Company Most Valuable Player awards for the American Basketball Association and National Hockey League playoff finals.

title: MRS. EDWIN CORNING
description: Louise Maxwell Corning, widow of Edwin Corning, who was a former Lieutenant Governor of New York, and mother of Mayor Erastus Corning 2d of Albany, died yesterday in the Eden Park Nursing Home in Albany. She was 91 years old and lived in Glenmont, N.Y.

title: Democrats intrenton Fail To Agree on New Tax Bill
description: TRENTON, May 24Senate Democrats could not agree in caucus today on a new version of a proposed state income tax to balance school budgets.

title: De Sapio Scoffs At Court Charge
description: A lifetime in the turbulent politics of New York State and a decade at the peak of power sounded in Carmine G. De Sapio's throaty voice yesterday as he scoffed at the indictment against him.

title: Project Is Moving National Power Grid Near Reality
description: STEGALL, Neb.The establishment of a nationwide electric power grid is moving closer as construction here nears completion on the first permanent tie between the huge Eastern and Western power grids.

title: ExRedskin Testifies in Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)Jim (Yazoo) Smith testified today he had to settle for a very, very low salary as the Washington Redskins first  round draft choice in 1967, but conceded he never publicly voiced anger or dissatisfaction about it. As the opening witness at a Federal court trial of his antitrust damage suit against the National Football League and the Redskins. Smith related he had received queries from seven teams before the Redskins drafted him mid ended his negotiating levag?.

title: Walter Prude Leaving Hurok After 31 Years
description: After 31 year Walter Prude will leave his post as vice president of Hurok Concerts Inc. to join Sheldon gold, former Hurok president, at ICM Artists Ltd., a newly formed concert management concern.

title: Ramirez Ousted In Italian Tennis
description: ROME, May 24 (AP)Tomas Smid, a 19yearold Czechoslovak, trounced secondseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico, the defending champion, 63, 64, today and knocked him out of the $180,000 Italian open tennis tournament in the first round.

title: U.S. COURT ORDERS GAS PRICE REVIEW
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 24 (AP) The Federal Power Commission must reconsider its refusal to grant the Shell Oil Company a price increase on billions of cubic feet of natural gas, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

title: Democratic Delegates Are Held High in Income and Education
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The first groups of delegates selected for the Democratic National Convention are more educated and have higher incomes than Americans in general, an Associated Press survey shows.

title: Kaunda Foresees Danger Of Rhodesian Bloodshed
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 24 (AP)President Kenneth Kaunda said today that intensified guerrilla warfare will lead to a bloodbath in Rhodesia unless Prime Minister Ian D. Smith surrendered power to the black majoritv.

title: Pick4 Pays $97,858
description: WESTBURY, L.&, May 24One unidentified bettor won the entire OTB pickfour pool of $97,858.80 tonight on the combination 8232 at Roosevelt Race. way.

title: STEEL OUTPUT ROSE 0.1 % FROM WEEK AGO
description: Steel production continued to edge ahead in the week ended May 22, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association said that production in the latest week had hit this years high of 2,728,000 tons, up 0.1 percent over the 2,725,000 tons poured in the preceding week.

title: Jazz Combination Of Organ and Piano Is Used by Holmes
description: The history of the organ in Jazz has not been particulari felicitous. Fats Waller and, on rare occasions, Count Basie have shown the organ to be very valid, colorful and subtle jazz instrument, and Milt Buckiner plays it with a happy, raffish charm. But ever since Jimmy Smith turned organ jazz into a roaring, violent???hletic event in the 1950&s, the instrument has been used for the most part in loud, heavyhanded fashion, usually with an aloetrio guitar or a tenor saxophone the alternate instrument.

title: TIGHTER MONEY DISCLOSED BY FED
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee took its first step toward a modest tightening of monetary policy at the committee's April 20 meeting, it was disclosed today.

title: HIGH COURT BARS STATE RESTRAINTS ON DRUG PRICE ADS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that states may not forbid pharmacists from advertising the prices of prescription drugsa ruling that may save consumers millions of dollars a year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MAY 25, 1976

title: Two Concordes Open Passenger Runs to Washington
description: CHANTILLY, Va., May 24Britain and France, their Concordes barred from New York in a legal conflict over noise, opened transAtlantic supersonic service today to Washington, their destination of second choice.

title: St. John's Advances In Baseball
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 24 (AP)  St. John's beat the University of Buffalo, 93, at Clark Field today in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference baseball playoffs.

title: A PHILIPPINES DIKE STARTS GIVING WAY
description: MANILA. Tuesday, May 25 (UPI)  Sections of a major dike 60 miles north of Manila collapsed today, causing floods to reach the roofs of house and endangering 10,000 residents nearby.

title: Archbishop of Hanoi Among 20 New Cardinals Installed by Popp
description: ROME, May 24Pope Paul VI today installed 20 new cardinals, including the Archbishop of Hanoi, whose selection had been kept secret until the ceremony.

title: Sportswear: A Passport to Fall Fashion
description: Sportswear is the code word for fashion these days. The umbrella term, embracing such standard categories as coats, suits and dresses, serves as chic, elegant or architectural did in other times.

title: Notes on People
description: Harry Woolf, the provost of Johns Hopkins University since 1972, announced yesterday that he had accepted appointment as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J. The selection, first reported three weeks ago followed Dr. Woolf's refusal of the presidency of Tufts University in Boston.

title: Enid the Green Hills of Third Avenue, Advice to the Leaflorn
description: Virginia Goldenzweig is jungle doctor.

title: Mourning Farm Town Buries Choir Members Killed in Crash
description: YUBA CITY. Calif., May 24 (UPI)This grieving farm town today began burying the 27 members of its high school choir killed in last Friday's bus crash. Pope Paul. VI and the head of the Mormon Church sent personal condolences.

title: Angolan Leader Pledges Nonalignment
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 24President Agostinho Neto as serted today that his country would be politically independent regardless of aid received.

title: Adulterated Choice
description: The open, or crossover, primary, which has muddied the results in several states this spring, has a chance of doing more mischief today not only in Tennessee but also in Arkansas, Idaho and three more states thereafter. The crossover is that electoral quirk that allows a Democrat a vote in choosing the Republican candidate and a Republican a reciprocal privilege in the Democratic primaryas long as each confines himself to one party's ballot.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD VOTES A BUDGET OF $125 BILLION
description: The Board of Estimate last night passed a $12.5 billion expense budget, the most austere in the city's history, by a vote of 16 to 6.

title: COLLEGE CONCERTS UPSET BY ROWDYISM
description: Brooklyn College said yesterday that it was reassessing its policy of renting its auditorium for rock concerts as a result of assaults and robberies that followed two held there Saturday night.

title: UNESCO in Plea to Israel on Arab Rights.
description: PARISR, May 24The Executitre Board of UNESCO today approved an urgent appeal to Israel to insure educational and cultural rights in IsraelioccuPied Arab territories.

title: Some Oregon Voters Apparently Taking Second Look at Democratic Candidates
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 A week ago Deidre Middlebrooks and Ann McKinney had a strong feeling, amounting to a certainty, that they would vote for Jimmy Carter in the Democratic primary here. Now, with only one day left before the voting, Miss Middlebrooks no longer knows what she will do and Mrs. McKinney has ruled out the frontrunner from Georgia.

title: The Man Who Isn't There
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 24The man who isn't there in the Oregon primaryno one could call him the little manis Representative Morris Udall of Arizona. That absence tells you something about Mo Udall. His name is on the ballot, but he hasn't campaigned here, both to give the other Democratic candidates a better shot at frontrunner Jimmy Carter, and to pursue his own quixotic ways elsewhere.

title: Whole Thing Is Ludicrous, De Sapio Says of Court Charge
description: A lifetime in the turbulent politics of New York State and a decade at the peak of power sounded in Carmine G. De Sapio&s throaty voice yesterday as he scoffed at the indictment against him.

title: Where There's a Will
description: He once toyed with the idea of taking up whisky but rejected it after noticing that many other millionaires were regular topers. Hughes wanted to be different. He was proud of the press's favorite description of him as the eccentric millionaire, and he took great pains to avoid being like anybody else.

title: A Connoisseur of Hands Gets Keepsakes of Unusual Ones in His Taxicab
description: When Erika Hoernig stepped into Bernard Korman's taxi outside the Amer ican Hotel the other morning, the cabby took a long look at her hands.

title: Seats at $25 Apiece Offered at Battery To Watch Big Ships
description: If you're eager to watch the parade of international sailing ships through New York Harbor July 4, and have not found an accommodating friend with a terrace overlooking the Hudson River, you can find a perch on the landfill site of the proposed Battery Park City housing development, for a $25 admission price.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, May 24, 1976 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Issue and Debate
description: They are smoothfaced, not more than 14 or 15 years old. Yet nothing they see on television is more violent than their daily lives.

title: RABIN REJECTS PLEA BY ARABS ON LAND
description: TEL AVIV, May 24 (Reuters) Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today refused a request by a group of Israeli Arab leaders to cancel government plans to take over Arab land in the Galilee area for development.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of a member of the White House staff was given incorrectly in an article and an accompanying photograph caption that appeared in The Times yesterday. The correct name is Michael RaoulDuval.

title: Building Blocks
description: if civic spirit can make a differenceand we are convinced it canthere is hope for this fiscally stricken city.

title: 11 Hurt on Jet Flight
description: KENNER, La., May 24 (UPI) Severe air turbulence jostled a National Airlines DC10 jet yesterday, injuring 11 persons on the flight between Miami and New Orleans. None of the injuries was serious.

title: N.B. A. Gets Merger Spur
description: Consolidation talks between the National and American Basketball Association may have been helped along yesterday by a promise of almost $5 million in television money.

title: Kansas Sprinter Granted Injunction
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 24 (AP)  A preliminary injunction until July 1 was granted today to Clifford Wiley, a University of Kansas sophomore sprinter, permitting him to compete in three impending national track meets.

title: Our Second Chance
description: One would never learn it from the scare rhetoric of an election campaign, but some persuasive arguments can be made for an optimistic judgment about America's future role in the world. The decline in this country's global stature may well have bottomed out, along with the loss of selfconfidence suffered by Americans and their friends abroad.

title: Indian Ace Masters Orioles
description: Although Dennis Lee Eckersley, Cleveland&s 21yearold righthander, has been in the major leagues for only two seasons, he is already building quite an impressive record against Baltimore. Last night Eckersley and Stan Thomas combined to pitch a onehit 40 shutout against the Orioles in Baltimore.

title: Ruling Postpones Nadjari&s Efforts to Study Records
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, won a delay yesterday in yielding records of his law firm to Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: Levitt Corp. Reports Profit Of $159,000 for Quarter
description: The Levitt Corporation, a new operating company being created from Levitt & Sons, showed a firstquarter profit of $139,000 on sales of $9 million, its courtappointed trustee reported yesterday.

title: 2 Postal Aides Held In $800,000 Theft
description: Two Postal Service employees at Kennedy International Airport were accused yesterday of stealing $800,000 and then going on a spending spree totaling nearly $150,000. The rest of the money still is missing. The theft of the currency was considered to be the largest in the history of the post office.

title: STOCKS IN SLUMP ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Continuing apprehension over rising interest rates and a tighter credit policy by the Federal Reserve Board dropped prices sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: 119 New York Delegates, In Switch, Endorse Ford
description: ALBANY, May 24  In al move to bolster President Ford on the eve of six crucial primaries, 119 New York Republican delegates, or 77 percent of the state delegation, voted today to endorse the President.

title: 2d Trial in Knight Killing
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (UPI) Steven Maleno, the second or two suspected killers of John S. Knight 3d, goes on trial for murder this week. Salvatore Soli, 37 years old, was convicted of firstdegree murder last week and sentenced to life imprisonment in the killing of the newspaper executive.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: rot high tide at Asbury Palk and Belmar deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook lime. For 5105 Ilk at Atlantic City (Steel Pier). deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout). deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook

title: Letter Purporting to Be President's Asks Foundation for Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A mysterious fund raising letter over the purported signature of President Ford has invited at least one foundation to make a 1976 campaign contribution, a move that would automatically threaten the tax exempt status of any foundation that complied.

title: S.E.C. CRITICIZED ON PAYMENT DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Questionable payments by three more corporate giants  E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the Celanese Corporation and the Wm. Wrigley. Jr. Companywere detailed today by a House Commerce subcommittee looking into the handling of this issue by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Archbishop of Hanoi Among 20 New Cardinals Installed by Pope
description: ROME, May 24Pope Paul VI today installed 20 new cardinals, including the Archbishop of Hanoi, whose selection had been kept secret until the ceremony.

title: Ford and His Advocates Seek Votes in California
description: SAN DIEGO, May 24 President Ford, cheered by his delegate gains in New York State, sought political support in California today by discussing national issues while his advocates ranged the state, attacking Ronald Reagan directly.

title: Kosygin Will Visit Baghdad And May Go to Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24 (UPI)Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union will pay an official and friendly visit to Iraq toward the end of this month, the Iraqi Foreign Ministry has announced.

title: Ali Stops Dunn in 5th
description: Muhammad Ali stopped Richard Dunn of England in the fifth round in Munich and retained his world heavyweight title. Page 29.

title: Coaches Fear Malpractice Cases
description: TARPON SPRINGS, Fla., May 24 (UPI)Southeastern Conference athletic directors discussed today the possibility of malpractice insurance for football coaches sued by players. The coaches expressed concern over a growing numberof lawsuits filed by athletes who attributed injuries to their coaches techniques. A blanket protection was considered.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Saudi Arabian Airlines announced it would purchase three 1:1011 Trlstar jet planes worth in excess of $100 million from the LockheedCalifornia Company, a division of the Lockheed Aircraft Company.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Always a Socialist, Says Guyana Prime Minister
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, May 19Back in 1964, when destabilization was not part of the English lexicon and cloakanddagger operations still had a romantic ring, the provisional Government of Dr. Cheddi Jagan was toppled in the wake of strikes and riots covertly encouraged by American and British intelligence services.

title: Safeguards Against Variety of Disorders Are Ready for Democratic Convention
description: Three separate sets of politically attuned security forces are focusing on Madison Square Garden to insure that the Democratic convention that begins there July 12 will be safe, serene and a good television advertisement for a party that wants to elect a President and a city that wants to erase its recent image as a municipal disaster.

title: LAWMAKERS SEEK CITY U. REVISIONS
description: ALBANY. May 24State legislative leaders have begun proposing alterations to Governor Carey's plan to reorganize the City University.

title: SURGE IN BUYING LIFTS SOYBEANS
description: Heavy local buying, speculative enthusiasms and a rush of shorts to buy to cover positions combined yesterday to send soybean futures up the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. The buying surge appeared to be a followthrough on Friday's strong closing prices.

title: McCartney&s Wings Bring National Tour to Garden
description: Paul McCartney and Wings, Who will be performing their second and last Manhattan show in Madison Square Garden tonight, come complete With all the trappings of a major rock band on the road. Clever lighting effects illuminate the musicians, a huge, state of the art sound systern bombards the hall with decibels, and the audience dutifully tosses firecrackers, pets off Roman candles, and pars.

title: Companies Offer Van Service During Energy Crisis
description: PRINCETONWhile companyorganized carpools are still in force at more than 100 New Jersey companies as a carryover of the energy shortage of two years ago, a growing number of establishments are using vans instead of cars.

title: MANILA DESCRIBES HIJACKING SLAYINGS
description: MANILA, May 24 (AP)Filipino troops rushed a hijacked airliner with 93 persons aboard and opened fire only after the leader of the six young Moslem rebels holding the plane shot two women passengers at close range, the Philippine Government said today.

title: ABRAHAM ROSENBERG
description: Abraham Rosenberg, who retired in 1968 as executive director of the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Medical Center, died there yesterday at the age of 76. He lived at 1056 Fifth Avenue.

title: Cow Dung Approved As Source of Gas
description: WASHINGTON, May 24me Federal Power Commission authorized an interstate pipeline today to tap a new source of gascow dung.

title: Leventritt Picks 5 Young Pianists
description: Five young pianists were selected yesterday to compete in the finals of the Leventritt International Competition. They were Steven DeGroote, Marian Hahn and Santiago Rodriguez, all of New York; Lydia Artymiw of Philadelphia, and Mitsuko Uchida of London.

title: No Progress in DeCamp Bus Dispute
description: CLIFTON, N.J., May 24A strike by drivers and garage workers against the DeCamp Bus Lines entered its third day today with little prospect of a quick settlement.

title: 60 Are Killed in Lebanon As Fighting Flares Again.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24Fighting intensified last night and today on all fronts of the Lebanese civil war, threatenling to end five days of relative calm that had given rise to cautious hopes that a political discussion might be getting under way among the opposing factions here.

title: Dish of Modern Chamber Music And Jazz Concocted at Kitchen;
description: Contemporary chamber music and jazz were stirred together at the Kitchen on Sunday evening, when three composers from the EuroAmerican tradition  Frederic Rzewski, Christian Wolff and Garrett List  and three improvising musician/composers  Ornette Coleman, Karl Berger and Carla Bleypresented recent works for chamber ensembles of varying size and composition.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: May 23Roston 98, Phoenix 87.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor As they begin to formulate national party platforms, let's hope both the Democratic and the Republican Party can find room for transportation as an issue for national debate. While there is every indication that transportation will continue to be ignored, it should not be.

title: FOES SEEK OUSTER OF JAPAN PREMIER
description: TOKYO, May 24A critical week for Prime Minister Takeo Miki and for Japanese politics began today as Parliament closed its sixmonth session.

title: Sports
description: People in Sports: Erving, Robinson get cars. Page 28

title: Baeza Found; Faces Inquiry
description: Braulio Baeza, one of the nation&s top jockeys, was reported in good health yesterday after his wife had told the police he was missing.

title: Mills Approved in Albany Requiring RentRise Data
description: ALBANY, May 24A bill that requires the New York State Housing Commissioner to inform tenants of all the reasons for a rent increase in statesubsidized housing projects received final passage in the Senate today and was sent to Governor Carey for his signature.

title: 2 Killed on Thruway
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., May 24 (UPI)Two members of a Connecticut army reserve unit on its way to Fort Drum were; killed Saturday in an accident on the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. The state police said Daniel G. Grega, 28 years old, Fairfield, Conn., and Robert J. Prusak, 33, of Shelton, Conn., had been hit by a dump truck while standing on the roadway after changing a flat tire on the truck they were driving.

title: GUERRILLAS BLOW UP A TRAIN IN RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 24 (AP)  Black nationalist guerrillas have blown up a train on Rhodesia's line to South Africa that runs through the independent state of Botswana, security headquarters announced today.

title: U.S. Seniors Beiten
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., May 24 Canada won the North American zone final in the Dubler Cup senior team tennis competition by defeat:iv; the United States, 3.2, yesterday at the Mellon Cricket Club.

title: Moon's Sect Pushes ProSeoul Activities
description: A number of individuals and organizations connected with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon the wealthy Korean industrialist and evangelist, have intimate ties with and have received assistance from the South Koreati Government and the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, according to former Korean and American officials and former members of the Moon organization.

title: Stock Prices Drop
description: Stock prices posted their largest loss in more than a year yesterday as fears of still higher interest rates touched off moderate selling. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 19.22 points at the close. Details on page 47.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 24Members of the State Economic Policy Council said today that, while the nation's econprovement in the last 12 months, New Jersey's economy continues to lag.

title: De Sapio and Fitzgerald Plead Not Guilty to Lying
description: Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Tammany Hall leader, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge that he had lied to a special grand jury investigating how information of a confidential investigation by Maurice H. Nadjari's office had been divulged to targets of the investigation.

title: Stock Prices Drop
description: Stock prices posted their largest loss in more than a year yesterday as fears of still higher interest rates touched off moderate selling. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 19,22 points at the close. Details on page 47.

title: Chess :
description: The international tournament in Orense, Spain, saw a triple tie for first place among Gudmundur Sigurjonsson of Iceland, Guillermo Garcia of Cuba and Kenneth Rogoff of the United States. Each scored 73.

title: Schoolboy Acquitted in Shooting
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., May 24 (UPI)A jury acquitted Howard McNeill, an Abington High School basketball star, of a murder charge in the shooting death of a teammate. The jury, which deliberated about three hours, found the 6foot9inch McNeill, a 16yearold sophomore, guilty on a firearms violation charge. The defense contended that the shooting of Mitchell Led, 16, at a party last Feb. 14 was accidental. Thirteen character witnesses testified at the trial in Montgomery County Court that McNeill was known as a peaceful, lawabiding person. His coaches testified that if McNeill had a weakness, it was lack of aggressiveness.

title: DR. CLARK HOPKINS
description: Dr. Clark Hopkins, a retired professor of classical art and archeology at the University of Michigan, died Friday at University Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 80 years old.

title: Trial Lawyers Assail Medical Society
description: A trial lawyer's group asked the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to bar the Medical Society of the State of New York from what it called further false advertising related to pending medicalmalpractice legislation.

title: Queensboro K.C. Chief Awards
description: VARIETY GROUPS

title: MARY SIMS, 90, DIES; Y.W.C.A. HISTORIAN
description: Mary S. Sims, an honorory member of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association, of which she was a longtime staff member and historian, died Saturday in Midland, Tex, where she lived. She was 90 years old.

title: Continental Group Bids For Stock of Richmond
description: The Continental Group, formerly the Continental Can Company, announced yesterday that it was offering a new issue of cumulative convertible preferred stock for all of the outstanding shares of the Richmond Corporation of Richmond, an insurance holding company. Under terms of the offer, Continental will exchange 0.2 share of the new issue of $7 cumulative preferred for each of the 13.26 million common shares of Richmond.

title: Undercover Agents Found Evidence of Renewed Association of Mafia and Police
description: Project Scotch, a secret Fed, eralcity investigation of organized crime turned up evidence two years ago that police officers were associating with Mafia figures and that there were signs of a return of systematic police corruption in New York City.

title: Delia Peters Beguiling in Dances at a Gathering
description: Dances at a Gathering found a receptive home in the New York City Ballet repertory at its first performance in 1969, and it has continued to enjoy favor through numerous cast changes and some bewildering reallocations of its various parts. Throughout it has retained a song of affirmation as its pulse beat. At the State Theater on Sunday, Delia Peters beguilingly assumed the role of the woman in green for the first time.

title: A Second Figure In British Scandal Retracts His Story
description: LONDON, May 24A second prop in the sex and politics scandal that has been raging in the British press was knocked away yesterday.

title: Testimony by Fitzgerald
description: Following are excerpts from the grand jury testimony of Thomas 1. Fitzgerald concerning a charge that Carmine G. De Sapio sent a messenger to Mr. Fitzgerald on Dec. 16, 1975 to warn him about a possible wiretap on his telephone by the special state prosecutor:

title: NASA Calls Weather Pattern Stable on Jupiter.
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW. Calif., May 24 (UPI)Jupiter was pictured by the National Space and Aeronautics Administration today as a planet where general weather patterns rarely change.

title: People and Business
description: E. Robert Kinney, currently president and chief operating officer of General Mills, will become president and chief executive officer on June 1 of the Minneapolis company, a major producer of cereals and other food and feed products.

title: HARRY MABEL
description: Harry Mabel, a partner in the law firm of Goodman & Mabel & Kirsch, died yesterday in Pompano Beach, Fla, to which he had retired recently. He was 77 years old.

title: Literati Rub Elbows at Party for Literary New York
description: Some literary people came together at a party last night for a new book called Literary New York. They drank, talked, waited for George Plimpton to show up, and exchanged confidences. As literary people will, they made friends too.

title: HIGH COURT BARS STATE RESTRAINTS, ON DRUG PRICE ADS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that states may not forbid pharmacists from advertising the prices of prescription drugsa ruling that may save consumers millions of dollars a year.

title: Top 3 Democrats Make Final Appeals in Oregon

Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)The Supreme Court approved today an agreement between the Federal Government and the State of Florida regarding offshore rights, including valuable oil leasing rights, in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico. The agreement settles details stemming from a decision of the court on March 17, 1975, which general affirmed the dominance of the Federal Government over the ocean bed more than three miles from shore. At that time, the court directed a senior United States circuit judge, Albert B. Maris, of Philadelphia, who had been appointed a special master in the case, to give further consideration to some objections raised by Federal authorities to his original report. He had recommended recognition part of Florida Bay as a historic bay and recognition the Dry Tortugas as inland waters, thus extending the coastline from which the limit of state offshore jurisdiction would be measured. After hearing further evidence, Judge Maris concluded that there was no historic bay between the upper Florida Keys and the Florida mainland and that the narrow waters were territorial seas. The FederalFlorida agreement incorporated this finding. In general it provides for a threemile limit on the Atlantic Coast and a limit three marine leagues on the Gulf Coast.

title: Kissinger in Sweden: Vietnam Echoes
description: STOCKHOLM, May 24The Indochina war, which deeply chilled relations between the United States and Sweden from 1972 to 1974, was on the minds of many people during Secretetary of State Henry A. Kissinger's visit to Sweden today.

title: Strikes Disrupt Italy Travel

With contract negotiations under way for almost half of Italy's 20 million work force, teachers and, hotel, restaurant and bar workers also threatened walk outs in the next five days.

title: Critic's Notebook: An Evening With 2 Walking Anachronisms
description: It was possible the other night to have cocktails with Ross MacDonald and dinner with Lillian Hellman. Both have new books out this month, and their publishers gave them parties. Listening to Mr. MacDonald tell a fist of admirers how had he felt at not having paid much attention to ecology until the Santa Barbara oil spill, and watching Miss Hellman attended by such glittering people as Mike Nichols, Maureen Stapleton, Jules Feiffer, Katherine Graham, Carl Bernstein, Nora Ephron and Norman Mailer, it was also possible to think about St. Augustine and guilt.

It seems a sad picture, yet composers could hardly sing about it enough.

They also opposed imposition of the financialneed factor in the awarding of athletic scholarships. Last January the N.C.A.A. restricted football staffs to a head coach, eight fulltime and two parttime assistants, with two additional parttime assistants if the school had a junior varsity schedule. Basketball teams were limited to a head coach, two fulltime assistants and a graduate assistant.

title: Drilling for a Law
description: Representatives who want to see offshore drilling for oil proceed in a safe and sane way are scheduled to try again today to pry a bill to that end out of the Rules Committee. The measure, which is being guided through the parliamentary maze by Representative John M. Murphy of New York, is the product of a select committee drawn from the Interior, Merchant Marine and Judiciary Committees. For lack of an additional couple of votes, the Rules Committee, under fierce pressure from the major oil companies, has been keeping the bill from the floor, presumably planning to delay action until the Presidential conventions are imminent and Congress has no further mind for controversy.

title: Man Tried for Slaying Mother Wins Bequest
description: A 34yearold man who three years ago was tried on a charge of having killed his mother and was acquitted on the ground of insanity has been granted more than $11.000 in death benefits that his mother left to him.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

Mrs. Hodge was convicted in April of hiring two men to kill her husband and fake a robbery in their Lincoln Towers apartment in October 1973. Both men are now serving prison terms.

title: British Unemployment Rises
description: LONDON, May 25 (Reuters) British unemployment in May rose 14,700 from April to 1.2 million seasonally adjusted and excluding school leavers and adult students, the employment department said today. The total represents 5.3 percent of the working population, compared with 5.2 percent in April and 3.6 percent In May last year.
