title: Macmillan Ailing
description: LONDON, May 27 (AP)Former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, 82 years old, has been hospitalized with a blood infection, an aide said today.

title: . . . Aiding OPEC
description: Internationally, however, the years since the oil embargo have not been a total loss. The Parisbased (and Americansponsored) International Energy Agency is now confident that its emergency stockpiling and allocation program could insulate its 19 members, most of the industrial world, from a crippling energy shock for the first months of another oil embargo. Yetwhile consumer cooperation may have advanced at government levelsactual dependence on Arab oil exports has risen dramatically.

title: Accord Ends Garment Strike; 23% Raise Over 3 Years Won
description: The garment workers union and various employer groups in he sportswear and coat and uit industry have reached agreement on new threeyear ontracts that will provide vage increases totaling 23 pertent for 110,000 workers over he three years.

title: CORN FUTURES UP ON EXPORT PLANS
description: When Richard E. Bell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, talks, traders on the Chicago Board of Trade are listenand react. Yesterday they bought corn, pushing prices up almost 4 cents a bushel in terms of the only delivery, which closed at $2.94.

title: 3 Major Drug Suspects Are Arrested at Kennedy
description: Three narcotics suspects who allegedly channeled multimilliondollar shipments of heroin and cocaine into this country from Latin America were arrested yesterday when they arrived at Kennedy International Airport aboard a jet chartered by the United States Government.

title: Screen: Tall Blond Adman
description: The Daydreamer, at the Juliet 2, is a French farce that fails 83 percent of the time. The 15 percent that succeeds is not enough to support 90 minutes of even Pierre Richard. He's the manic beanpole who was very funny in the earlier The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe, directed by Yves Robert. The problem with The Daydreamer may be that Mr. Richard decided to direct himself. The Daydreamer is about the idiocies of French advertising

title: Salute From Dearest Enemy
description: While the nation is celebrating its Bicentennial, the Goodspeed Opera House, in East Haddam, Conn., is celebrating its centennial with the presentation of a Revolutionary War musical, Rodgers and Hart's Dearest Enemy

title: 77 CUBA PULLOUT IN ANGOLA IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Max 27 (AP) Prime Minister Fidel Castro has implied that he will complete the withdrawal of all Cuban combat forces from Angola in about a year, reporters on Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's plane flying from London to Washington were told today.

title: Navy Begins Oil Sales From Coast Reserves
description: TAFT, Calif., May 27 (AP) The Navy has conducted the first domestic oil sales from its Elk Hills reserve, officials announced today.

title: Staying the Course
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In his OpEd article The Retreat of the Liberal Sages, Orde Coombs tells of a reunion of his class at Yale where he was overwhelmed by the realization of how much had changed since the bright, confident morning of his graduation in 1965.

title: New Publisher at Business Week
description: The latest management change at the McGrawHill Publications Company has R. Bernard Alexander, the 58yearold associate publisher and advertising sales director of Business Week, moving in as publisher of the company's flagship publication. Charles C. (Jim) Randolph, 49 and publisher for 10 years, becomes a group vice president and part of the executive staff.

description: The whine of electric saws and drills and clouds of sawdust filled the air in the red and gold Albert Hall in the Americana Hotel.

title: CHEATING CASES MAY INVOLVE 250
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27Army lawyers have told West Point officials that they expect at least 250 cadets to be tried for violating the honor code by cheating or by tolerating cheating.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Back on a Binge . .
description: The Pacific isle of Bali can hardly rank very high the thoughts of America's motorists as they set off on the first holiday weekend of the Bicentennial summer which is a pity, for a lot of people now gathered on Bali are giving a great deal of thought to America's motorists, and the energy consumption they represent. The Indonesian island is the setting for this season's oil pricefixing meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the OPEC cartel.

title: MORE QUESTIONING FOR CUNNINGHAM
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the indicted Democratic state chairman, will be asked to testify about any role he may have had in Governor Carey's attempt last December to dismiss Maurice H. Nadjari as special state prosecutor, a deputy state attorney general said yesterday.

description: TOKYO, May 27Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson said here today that he had told President Park Chung Hee of South Korea directly of the Ford Administration's continuing concern with the issue of human rights in his country.

title: U.S. Is Opposed to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (Reuters)Ron Nessen. the White House press secretary said today that the United States did not believe that OPEC oil ministers meeting in Bali would be justified in raising oil prices again.

description: To the Editor:

title: Army Authorizes a Jewish Chapel at West Point
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Army Secretary Martin Hoffmann today authorized construction of a Jewish chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y.. capping a 20year campaign by Jewish cadets and alumni.

title: People and Business
description: Gerald L. Parsky, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said yesterday that a department study shows that a breakup of the major oil companies would cause a rise in the prices of domestic oil products and a decline in domestic energy supplies.

description: A pornographic bookstore in the heart of Times Square would be replaced by a police substation and a new visitors bureau! under a plan being considered by the Police Department and the 42d Street Redevelopment Corporation.

description: Hours after Governor Carey signed into law Wednesday a bill allowing thrift institutions to offer checking accounts, a raft of savings banks opted for the new privilege with plans sure to save consumers money.

description: TRENTON, May 27The New Jersey Supreme Court agree?? today to discuss a petition from a group that is trying to stop steps to allow Karen Anne Quinlan to die with dignity.

description: WASHINGTON SQ. ART

description: WASHINGTON, May 27The Senate Finance Committee voted today to make permanent all but one aspect of the individual income tax cuts that have been in effect sinco March 1975.

title: Bridge
description: Two famous players who helped each other to win world titles more than 20 years ago are likely to be in opposition in the Reisinger knockout team championship final to be played today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: For the Memorial Day weekend, there is a place no farther than Westchester County where it is possible to spend a pleasant day or two playing at an amusement park and beach, getting in touch with nature and exploring the past. That place ?? Rye, an affluent, peaceful and friendly community. with curving treeshaded streets, grand old houses and a strong sense of history.

title: Prime Rate Rise Is Expected
description: Pressure for an increase in the prime rate intensified this week, figures reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of Newt York indicated.

title: Sister of Moslem Leader Is Murdered in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27The sister of Kamal Jumblat, Leader of the alliance of leftists and Moslems in the Lebanese civil war, was killed by an unidentified gunman in her apartment in the Christiancontrolled sector of Beirut today.

title: How to Get There
description: The Goodspeed Opera House operates on a Tuesday through Sunday schedule. During the week, performances are at 8:30 P.M., with a matinee Wednesday at 2:30. On Saturday there are shows at 5 and 9 P.M. and on Sunday at 5 P.M. For reservations, telephone (203) 8738668.

title: Ban on Interstate. Bets Gains Support
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The House sub committee on transportation and commerce has approved legislation prohibiting interstate parimutuel wagering. The full House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee is expected to take up the, bill next week. The measure, which was sent to the full committee yesterday with only technical changes, would prohibit one state from using the races in another for its offtrack wagering.

title: Richmond Corp. Rejects Merger Offer
description: The board of the Richmond Corporation, parent of several insurance companies, unanimously rejected yesterday proposed merger offer by the Continental Group as inadequate. Richmond added, however, that it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company and Wheat First Securities Inc. to make an independent evaluation of the offer.

title: Warm Holiday Weekend Should Improve Outlook for Anglers
description: Sharp easterly and northeasterly winds and unstable and unseasonably cold weather the past week or so disrupted what promised to be one of the most successful early seasons for bluefish and striped bass along the Northeast coast in many years.

title: EuropeanAmerican Bank To Fight Ship Loan Suits
description: The EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company, responding to lawsuits arising from the reported default by the Colocotronics tanker group on a $100 million loan, declared yesterday that the bank acted reasonably and honorably and intends to defend these actions to the fullest.

title: Tokyo White Paper Says Defense Is Linked to U.S.
description: TOKYO, May 26A new white paper on defense shows that Japan intends to continue relying on the United States for its primary military security and plans no major arms buildup of its own.

title: Article on Dorothy Schiff Biography Stirs Controversy
description: The publication yesterday of direct statements by Dorothy Schiff suggesting that she had had a close relationship with President Franklin Delano Roosevelt and her subsequent denial that it was sexual has stirred confusion and controversy.

title: TEAMSTERS GROUP ATTACKS LEADERS

Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Perez Solo A Dance for Tinhorns

System, his new moving solo, was given its first performance on Wednesday evening at Marymount Manhattan College, along with a new group dance, Update.

description: The New York Times/CBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted from May 19 to May with 1,501 adult men and women across the continental United States.

description: Friday

title: Furniture Moves Off the Porch, to Give Each Room a Rustic Note
description: The country has come to the city Go into the furniture department of almost any of the large stores, and you'll see such rustic items as Windsor chairs, rush seat ladderbacks, trestle tables, Welsh dressers and lots of pieces in pine. But more than anything else, you'll find rattanin all its variety of forms.

title: At the Movies
description: AFTER acting in a movie and winding up a lecture tour, Truman Capote, who has trouble sitting still, is trying to sit still in California and finish Answered Prayers. The book, whose chapters Esquire magazine caused tiny havoc on the East Side with their account of socially prominent misbehavior, has been unfinished for a very long time.

title: Management
description: Bow much Mom in top management should there be for members of a family that controls a corporation?

They were out in enthusiastic force for her appearance at Town Hall on Wednesday at the last of this season's Interludes series. and she responded with one of her more polished and confident performances.

title: China Conciliatory Toward India During Bhutto Visit
description: PEKING, May 27 (Reuters) China's Prime Minister, Hua Kuofeng, called tonight for an easing of tensions on the Indian subcontinent at state banquet here for Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: Man Here Hooked on Fight Game
description: How did you make this match? Jerry Perenchio was asked at lunch, and his answer was another question: What are you doing for dinner tonight? For a moment he was silent, reflective. I'm thinking of writing it as a serial, he said, say about 13 installments. But I'll try to condense. Perenchio is the boy booking agent who got his first sniff of fight Promotion in 1971 when he landed the first Joe FrazierMuhammad Ali bout, came up with a $20 million closedcircuit production and was hooked. The entertainment business is where he lives, packaging shows like All in the Family and Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, but every once in a while he gets strung out and has to conic back to the fight game for a fix. Like now, when he is back in New York after a fiveyear lapse to present Frazier and George Foreman in the Nassau Coliseum June 15.

title: Luzon Flood Waters Are Leveling Off
description: VALENZLIELA, Luzon. May 27Floods that reached height of 22 feet in some parts of Luzon in the last nine days appeared today to be leveling off as the storm that had had brought them moved out to sea.

title: Does It Really Matter?
description: WASHINGTON, May 27It's fairly obvious now that nobody in the Presidential race is going to sweep into the White House as a popular hero of the Republic, and people are asking: Does it really matter? All the candidates are stumbling for the moment and over twothirds of the eligible voters haven't even bothered to go to the polls in the primary elections. So maybe the main question is not personal but rather how to get a team together in the White House, the Cabinet and the Congress on a sensible program for the last years of the Seventies.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Record
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the last week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion tonmlies, a high for the year, and 7.7 percent above the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 490,748, also a high for the year, ?? a rise of 5.7 percent over last year. The American Truckintercity Associations Inc., reported intercity truck ?? was 14.8 percent higher that last year.

title: Artists Protest Iraq as Parley Site
description: Fortyfour artists signed a statement protesting the selec tion of Baghdad, Iraq, as the site of the Eighth World Congress of the 22yearold International Association of Art. By meeting in Baghdad, the statement said, the I.A.A. has in effect closed ?? eyes to Iraq's long history of brutal racist atrocities, of execution without trial and of victimization of its ethnic and religious minorites.

title: HUMPIIREY,BROWN BACKED IN JERSEY
description: EAST BRUNSWICK. N. J., May 27New Jersey's uncommated delegates voted tonight. to support both Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Governor Edmund G. Brown of California in the state's Democratic Presidential primary election June 8.

title: Drivers Test Cars For 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27The still call it Carburetion Dayeven though it's been nearly 25 years since carburetors gave way to fuel injectors at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. But the idea still is validto give the cars a dressrehearsal workout in preparation for the race itself.

title: Winner Take All
description: SAN DIEGO, May 27When California Republicans choose between Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan on June 8, the winnereven if by only one votewill get all 167 of the state's delegates. That's the biggest haul to be made this year and one that Mr. Reagan almost certainly has to have if he is to take the nomination from Mr. Ford.

title: Robert Shaw Opens At Carnegie Tonight
description: Robert Shaw, at 60, communicates a kind of missionary zeal about music that is not Common to symphonic conductors. His enthusiastic faith in the art, hacked by years of hard work, has now brought him to what he must regard as one of the peaks of his careerthe presentation this weekend of a threeevent Beethoven Festival at Carnegie Hall with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, the Westminster Choir and seven vocal and instrume.ntal soloists.

title: Uncertainty Clouds The Optimism on Oil
description: Although 1976 is expected to be the most stable year since the Arab oil embargo as far as the energy situation is concerned, the generally optimistic outlook is eroded by underlying uncertainty.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: Screen: Camels In the Old West
description: "HAWMPS" is a long march on light provisions. Based on a tiny historical curiosityan experimental use of camels by the United States cavalry in Texas in the mid-19th centuryit should have been a nice small movie.Instead it stretches into an underpopulated two hours and five minutes. Joe Camp, the producer-director, who previously made "Penji," seems to have a neo-Victorian idea of children's entertainment. You give the little things some small toy and they are to enjoy it quietly for a whole afternoon.A plump and febrile lieutenant, comfortably stationed in Washington, finds himself arriving at a bleak Texas cavalry outpost to try out somebody's notion that camels would provide ideal military transport for the region.The troops, who have been told only that they will be mounted on "genuine Arabian steeds," greet him enthusiastically. The colonel, an artilleryman who hates his job, greets him sourly.The arrival of the camels produces universal despair, and some pleasantly ludicrous scenes. The troops learn to love the beasts, the despair abates, and so does the movie. To test the worth of the project, a 300-mile race is set up with a rival horse-mounted detachment. There are tangles with Indians and outlaws, with the camels gaining an eventual, though Pyrrhic, victory.The jokes, the comic devices, are distended, repeated, italicized. A barroom brawl is stretched out so that it comes to seem longer than the war in Vietnam.EverybodyJames Hampton as the lieutenant, Denver Pyle as the commanderoveracts. As the leader of the horse detachment, Slim Pickens, who sometimes makes overacting a joy, only manages to make it a chore.Mr. Camp seems to think that subtletylike properly seasoned food in that hypothetical Victorian householdis unsuitable for children. He feeds them mush: It will occupy them and do them no particular harm, but if they continue on this kind of diet they will grow up awfully boring.

title: A BOARD IN HARLEM OUSTS SCHOOL CHIEF
description: Ignoring the shouts of parents supporting Luther W. Seabrook as superintendent of District 5 in East Harlem, the community school hard voted last night. to replace him when his contract expires on June 30.

title: Consumer Victory
description: By deciding that states must permit the advertising of prescription drug prices, the Supreme Court has achieved a significant victory for consumers. In the virtual absence of price competition, drugs tend to be excessively costly, a matter of genuine concern in the budgets of the elderly who purchase a disproportionately large share of prescription drugs.

title: Stage: New Deal for Faust
description: T HEFAUST legend, which will probably be retold when civilization is established in the stratosphere and in the oceans, has turned up once more in a nicely sardonic musicaltheater piece at the Cubiculo called Stauf.

description: At this stage of the 1976 campaign, voter support for the leading candidates for the Democratic and Republican nominations appears to divide more sharply along regional lines than on issues or on matters of political ideology.

title: Some Hail Petrofunds For Results
description: A number of prominent businessmen said in interviews yesterday that they had little reason to be unhappy with their investment in Petrofunds, a Texas oil and gasdrilling tax shelter which has been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with defrauding investors.

title: I. M. Pei Proposes a Rebirth for New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 27  If I. M. Pei has his say, downtown New Brunswick will be transformed from a decaying business area into an urban showplace.

description: Thursday, May 27, 1974 (In bushels, 002 Omitted)

title: Stanford Sets Pace In N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 27 (AP)  Stanford, paced by fourthseeded Pat DuPre, remained undefeated today in singles play and expanded its early lead in the 92d National Collegiate tennis tournament.

title: Leader of Nation's Orthodox Jews
description: FALLSBURG. N. Y., May 27Many of Walter S. Wurzburger's colleagues called the rabbi, who is the newly elected spiritual leader of America's 1.5 million Orthodox Jews. a Tiberal exponent of Orthodoxy. But Rabbi WurzburNews ger rejects that appellation. H calls himself an unlabeled individual who has set his sights on counteracting what he describes as a false image of Orthodox Judaism.

title: Beverly Rohlehr A Singing Find
description: Ragtime Jack Radeliffe and the New Viper Revue are the theoretical headliners at Tramps, 125 West 15th Street, but the real point of interest is an unheralded opening act Beverly Rolllehr, a young singer from New Marlboro, Mass., making her first solo appearance in New York.

title: Carter Assails Opponents Who Seek to Block Drive
description: CINCINNATI, May 27Jimmy Carter, speaking with more than usual force, said today that those critical of him wished to thwart his dreams for a better America and to maintain at all costs their own entrenched, unresponsive, bankrupt, irresponsible political power

title: Art: Focus on Photo Shows
description: H ISTORIC breakthroughs are not, alas, what they used to be  at least in the world of art. Take the exhibition of photographs by William Eggleston that opened this week at the Museum of Modern Art (through Aug. 1). We are invited by John Szarkowski, director of the department of photography at the museum, to look upon this as a very significant event. To underscore the point, the museum has prepared a poshy, hardcover book of 112 pages ($12.50, M.I.T. Press) to accompany the showa fairly unusual procedure for the first solo exhibition by an artist few people have ever heard of. In his text for the book, Mr. Szarkowski throws all caution to the winds and speaks of Mr. Eggleston's pictures as perfect.

title: SYRIANS CONSENT TO U.N. EXTENSION OF BUFFER FORCE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 27Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that Syria had agreed to extend the United Nations observer force on the Golan Heights for another six months.

title: Theater for a Holiday Mood
description: Are you one of the many people who simply despair of ever getting a ticket for a Broadway show? It is amazing how many people do. Yet there are some times that are better than others to go to the theater. And this long Memorial Day weekend, today to Monday, happens to be one of the best. Why? Simply because so many people leave town that the ticket situation on Broadway traditionally loosens up.

At a year's perspective, it becomes easier to appreciate the variety within a festival dedicated :o a composer whose music seemed undanceable and so marked with his special imprint that its choreographic potential seemed limited.

description: WASHINGTON, May 27The White House press secretary Ron Nessen, said today that President Ford made a mistake last night when he said that his Administration might seek a review of the landmark school desegregation case. Brown v. Board of Educadon.

title: MEXICAN KIDNAPPERS: GET PLEA FOR TIME
description: MEXICO CITY, May 27 (UPI) The Belgian Ambassador to Mexico, Andro Chaval, today asked the kidnappers of his 16yearold daughter to extend for 36 to 48 hours the deadline for delivery of the $800,000 ransom they had demanded in exchange for her life.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: El Salvador's military chief of staff and five other men pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to an indictment charging them with Conspiracy to sell 10,000 submachine guns to undercover agents posing as underworld figures in the United States. Another defendant, Miguel D. Celis, who was described as a Panamanian businessman, pleaded guilty late Wednesday to a charge of making false, fictitious and fraudulent statements that the guns and 1.5 million rounds of ammunition were to be used by the armed forces of El Salvador. Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, the 48yearold chief of staff of El Salvador armed forces, remained Federl custody in lieu of $3 million bail, which was set after he was arrested on May 15 in Mount Kisco, N. Y.

description: WASHINGTON, May 27Executives of four of the Alaska pipeline oil companies met for two hours today with highranking Federal officials and agreed on procedures for checking welds of questionable or unknown quality in the 800mile line.

title: Antiques

They're trick toys, John Noble explained with a wave that encompassed a wonderland within a gallery at the Museum of the City of New York, a setting transformed to show one man's absorbing interest in illusionfilled peep shows, zoetropes, stereopticons and kaleidoscopes. And this may well be the definitive collection.

Otherwise Engaged is by Simon Gray, who wrote Butley, and it will be directed by Harold Pinter, who directed the play when it appeared in London's West End. It will be produced here by James M. Nederlander and Frank Milton, along with Michael Cordon, who did it in London.

Of all the bands currently performing improvisational music in lofts and clubs downtown, Earthforins Rituals is probably the best place for the beginning listener to begin listening.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The unemployment rate in New Jersey increased from 11.3 percent to 11.6 percent of the work force between March and April, the State Department of Labor and ?? try reported. Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman said that the number of unemployed people rose to 390,700, but that the figure was substantially below the high of 467,500 last September, during the peak of the recession. Mr. Hoffman said that despite the slight increase in the number of people out of work, the number of those employed continued on rising trend that began last July. He said that employment declined in both manufacturing and nonmanufacturing industries between March and. April and that the number people working was 2,665,200.

description: DETROIT. May 27  The American Motors Corporation. whose sales of small cars have slumped recently, announced today that it would close most of its Milweukee and Kenosha Wis.facilities next week and lay off 6,000 workers.

title: Drive Is Onto Divest Hays Of House Chairmanships
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 Some members of the House of Representatives, stung by the public furor over the Elizabeth Ray disclosures, today opened a quiet hut determined drive to divest Representative Wayne L. Hays of his committee chairmanships.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE evening last winter or maybe the winter before, the way time guts. had some of the worst food and one of the most dismal times in our entire dining experience. at Monsignore. a restaurant at ?? East 55th Street. We learned later that not only the chef but the second chef as well were out with the flu, which helped explain the food but not the shabbiness and the air of disorganization and discouragement in the dining room. Among contributory disasters, somebodythis diner, in factkicked over an illbalanced wine cooler placed too far out in the aisle, drenching a couple of other guests with ice water and chablis. A trio of strolling violinists squeaked away all evening with desperate smiles on their faces pretending everything wasn't awful. But it was.

title: Screen: 'Down Everest'
description: THE MAN Who Skied Down Everest," which opened yesterday at the D. W. Griffith and Regency Theaters, is the filmed record of the 1970 expedition led by Yuichiro Miura, the Japanese skier, sports promoter and television personality whose object was to ski at least partway down Nepal's Mount Everest, the world's highest peak. At times the expedition involved as many as 800 persons. It cost approximately $3 million, as well as the lives of six Sherpa guides.Yet the film, which was awarded this year's Oscar as the best feature-length documentary, has about as much to do with serious skiing as one of Jim Moran's more famous escapades had to do with bringing relief to the Arctic. Mr. Moran, you may remember, is the man who once sold a refrigerator to an Eskimo.It makes no difference that the expedition was a dangerous one, that real hardships were experienced in placing Mr. Miura just several thousand feet below Everest's 29,000-foot summit, which was the start of his something more than two-minute descent, or that that descent down sheer ice most of the time required extraordinary skills. The movie makes the whole think look very much like an Evel Knievel stunt that mankind could survive without.With the exception of the climactic run, which is shown twice, and some footage showing Mr. Miura practicing in conventional, low-altitude snow, most of the film is as doggedly banal and nonskiing as one of those Fitzpatrick travelogues that are kidded in "That's Entertainment, Part 2."We are shown what seems to be endless footage of the expedition hiking through the pretty Himalayan foothills and stopping at quaint mountain villages. We see Mr. Miura keeping in trim with various exercises, and we see the Japanese members of the expedition astonishing the Sherpas with a videotape showing of "The Seven Samurai."What's even worse is the virtually nonstop soundtrack narration, spoken in English but said to be based on Mr. Miura's diary. If he had put some of his prose on the bottom of his skis he'd probably still be stuck to the face of Everest. "Skiing is my doorway to adventure," he tells us early on. He looks at an absolutely vertical snowfield and observes without a giggle, "A bit steep, but what a downhill run."When the six Sherpas are killed in the cave-in, he has some thoughts about Destiny's way, but he only achieves a truly lyrical nuttiness when he attempts to describe the mysterious compulsion that has brought him all the way to Everest: "I dreamed of skiing on the virgin snows of the Himalayas. It's almost like the beginning of loveyou can do anything."With this kind of buildup, the final two-minute run becomes something of an anti-climax.It, at least, is well-photographed, but much of the rest of the film isn't. The cameramen never seemed to have got the knack of panning across a wide angle of landscape without creating the impression that the scenery was falling toward the center of the screen.If this film won the Oscar, how dreary were the contending features?

title: Fire Destroys Factory
description: UNION CITY, N.J., May 27 (UPI)  A generalalarm fire, fed by leaking natural gas, destroyed a Union City handbag factory today. The police said there were no reports of injuries. Firemen brought the fire, at the Apex Handbag Manufacturing Company at 4810 Broadway under control soon after 1. A.M., three hours after it broke out.

description: CHARLESTON, W. Va.. May 28 (UPI)The West Virginia Court of Claims today exonerated the state of any negligence or liability in the 1967 collapse of the Silver Bridge into the Ohio River at Point Pleasant in which 46 persons died. The three judge court handed down a 39page opinion explaining why no damages would be awarded to any of the plaintiffs in suits totaling $6.5 million against the state.

The total cost of the new program was estimated at $8,000 a day. We believe, Mayor Beame said, that this modest expenditure will help encourage visitors and shoppers and will provide substantial economic benefit the merchants in these areas.

title: The Screen: Parks's Elegiacal 'Leadbelly'
description: Huddie Ledbetter, better known as Leadbelly, the great American folk singer and 12-string guitarist who died in 1949 at the age of 60, is evoked in beautiful, soft, dreamlike images in Gordon Park's elegiacal new film, "Leadbelly," which opened yesterday at Loews State 2 and Cine Theaters.Leadbelly's life was hard and violent. He was born black at a time when blacks were "darkies," in the Deep South in which "darkies" were supposed to know their place, which, for Leadbelly's family, was sharecropping. But Leadbelly never did know his place for long.He served one sentence for murder on a Texas chain gang and another sentence on a Louisiana chain gang. In 1939, after he had gained his reputation as a folk singer (sometime after the period covered by this film), he was once more up against the law, this time in New York, where he was sentenced to a year in prison for a stabbing.In the meantime he was always refining his music, which provided the order in a life that was in every other respect chaotic, more, perhaps, because of his terrible temper than because of the kind of black militancy that "Leadbelly" suggests.Mr. Parks and Ernest Kinoy, who wrote the screenplay, have imposed their own very particular kind of order on the Leadbelly story. It's as if the film were a recollection of the legend, rather than of the man. It's done in bold, broad strokes of incident and color that are as carefully balanced as the images in one of the better post-office murals of the 1930's. This Leadbelly is bigger than lifeand serenely removed from it. Which is why, I think, one attends to the film carefully and is never very moved."Leadbelly" is less a failure in execution than a mistake in conception, for if you accept this conception, you must go along with its more or less immaculate vision of triumph over degradation.You must also accept the performance of Roger E. Mosley in the title role. Mr. Mosley is a big, heavily muscled actor, but the muscles look more as if they came from lifting barbells in some neatly tended gym than from the random heaving of bales of cotton. The performance, like the physique, seems the result of careful study, not the eruption of furious passions. The character is about heroism, not its demonstration.The film was shot on location in Texas, which the cameraman, Bruce Surtees, often makes to appear so pretty that you can't believe that it's not a stage set by Oliver Smith. This, I suspect, is not because Mr. Parks didn't know exactly what he was doing, because the director has chosen this method, which worked beautifully in "The Learning Tree," Mr. Parks's film about his own idyllic, mostly untroubled childhood, but is at odds with Leadbelly's life.It's also at odds with the Leadbelly music, sung on the soundtrack by HiTide Harris so effectively that it has no connection to the Leadbelly that we see on the screen. There are vitality, wit, sorrow and joy in this music, but it remains a kind of voice-over commentary to the events we witness.Two sequences in the film stay in the mind: an early country dance where Leadbelly plays as two dancers whip themselves into a sexual frenzy, and, toward the end, a chance encounter between Leadbelly and a once proud, now exhausted Shreveport madam (Madge Sinclair) who had been an early benefactor. The sequences are not realistic at all, but achieve a legitimate theatricality missing from the rest of the movie.The film has been rated PG, though its scenes of violence are so stylized that the horrors are removed, neutralized.

title: 'Man Who Fell to Earth' Is Beautiful Science Fiction
description: There are quite a few science-fiction movies scheduled to come out in the next year or so. We shall be lucky if even one or two are as absorbing and as beautiful as "The Man Who Fell to Earth," which opened yesterday at the Cinema I and Cinema II Theaters.When science-fiction writing enlisted such authors as Ray Bradbury, the emphasis on space machines, time warps and little green men gave way to more philososhical and emotional approaches. It was man or Martian, not as physical but as metaphysical travelers. Space was filled with loss and melancholy as well as gadgets."The Man Who Fell to Earth" makes some use of far-planetary landscape, of extrahuman physiognomy and even of space machinery. Sparingly, though; as a touch of color. Mainly it is about exile, about being an alien. Its story of an extraterrestrial visitor from another planet is designed mainly to say something about life on this one.Nicholas Roeg, who made the powerful but grotesque "Don't Look Now," is an elaborate and mannered director. He does nothing simply; he uses indirection and ambiguity paced with sudden shocking effects. His complexity, his baroque style, is redeemed by a considerable though not total precision and control. His idiosyncracies overweighted the story of a grief-hallucinated couple in "Don't Look Now": they are extraordinarily well suited to this space allegory.Mr. Roeg has chosen the garish, translucent, androgynous-mannered rock-star, David Bowie, for his space visitor. The choice is inspired. Mr. Bowie gives an extraordinary performance. The details, the chemistry of this tall pale figure with black-rimmed eyes are clearly not human. Yet he acquires a moving, tragic force as the stranger caught and destroyed in a strange land.The story is complicated. It is set up as a near-total mystery that unfolds bit by bit, leavingit must be saida few small unexplained gaps. The price paid for this method is a certain confusion; the gain is the spectator's tingling desire to have the puzzle work out.There is an explosive splash in a Western lake, and soon Newton  David Bowie  is walking into a town. Immediately the film's theme is set. He passes, and is alarmed, by a garishly painted fun-park gondola in which a drunkard sits, gibbering. Where is Oute Space? Right here on earth.Newton pawns an immense collection of gold rings for $10,000. He takes the money and a sheaf of papers to Farnsworth, a top patent lawyer, played by Buck Henry. The papers are nine major electronics inventions. Farnsworth can't believe what he sees: "For starters you can take General Electric, Polaroid and I.B.M.," he tells his strange black-garbed visitor. He is worth hundreds of millions of dollars, he tells him. "Is that all?" Newton asks.Newton gives Farnsworth complete authority to set up a huge corporation. He takes shelter in a radio-equipped car, then in a motel, then in a lavish lakeside house, then in a desert shack. He is accompanied by a lovely, simple and increasingly tormented woman whom he picks up at the motel. All his contact with the outside world is by telephone through Farnsworth.Newton's empire grows, but is eventually sabotaged by a shadowy, C.I.A.-like group that enlists all those around himhis mistress, his bodyguard and a brilliant, cynical scientist, played by Rip Torn.Alongside this plot, giving it texture, are the gradually revealed mysteries. Why does Newton drink so much water? Why is he intrigued by railroad trains? Why does he continually watch television? Why does he use all the resources of his vast empire to build a one-man spaceship?The movie has its incoherences. Sometimes the mannerisms  overlapping shots, for instanceare excessive. Once Newton is broken, and his homeward drive is fully revealed and fully frustrated, the ending drags on for too long.But it is a first-rate achievement; helped by stunning performances not only by Mr. Bowie, but by Candy Clark, as his mistress. Buck Henry as the lawyer and Rip Torn, the scientist, are subtle and impeccable.

In fact, the $15 million which still remains in the university's treasury out of the current budget may not suffice to pay the bills for services already received in May.

The Superior Court suit charges that work delays allegedly caused by the E. Lionel Pavlo Engineering Company increased the cost of $114 million bridge in Philadelphia.

title: Where Branch Rickey is Not Forgotten
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, May 28He's virtually forgotten now, but he shouldn't be. Branch Rickey has been dead since 1965 and major league baseball doesn't have an award or a stadium or anything named in his memory. But north of Columbus in this leafy college town, Ohio Wesleyan University is completing the Branch Rickey Physical Education Center in honor of its famous alumnus. The site of the mod structure is on land where Branch Rickey played and coached baseball as a student, where his relationship with a black player influenced his eventual signing of Jackie Robinson, where his innovative philosophy of baseball organization was developed. Branch Rickey, now in the Baseball Hall of Fame, was primarily responsible for building the St. Louis Cardinals, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates into dominating teams over a span of nearly four decades. But when Ohio Wesleyan was searching for donors to its $3 million physical education center, the Cardinals, the Dodgers and the Pirates couldn't spare a dime. The only major league team that contributed was the nearby Cincinnati Reds with a $10,000 gift. Bob Howsam, the Reds president, reveres Branch Rickey and was the Cardinals general manager in 1964 when Branch Rickey was their consulting genius.

title: Coop City Group Seeks Reassurance

title: 'Eat My Dust' Is a Demolition Derby
description: "Eat My Dust," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is an exuberantly idiotic movie about a chase touched off when the teen-age son of a California sheriff steals the best of stock cars from a race track at the behest of a girl in tight sweater, hot pants and boots.What follows is a demolition derby with minimal bloodshed in an atmosphere of humor. The music by David Grisman is appropriately bouncy. The photography by Eric Saarinen is suitably pretty. And the cast, directed by Charles Griffith, who wrote the screenplay, acts as though "Eat My Dust" matters. It doesn't. It's simply another slick-looking Roger Corman time-killer for the summer kiddie trade.The PG rating seems to be attributable to the language.

His wife of three weeks also was injured. Officials at the Burden.ko military hospital said both were in satisfactory condition, and doctors said Kharlamov would play again in two months. The 28yearold Kharlamov was the leading scorer for the Soviet team in its tour against National Hockey League teams last winter. He also plays for the Central Army Sports team.

title: Air Force Aide Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)President Ford said today that he was nominating assistant Air Force Secretary David P. Taylor to be an Assistant Defense Secretary for Manpower and Reserve Affairs. He would succeed William K. Brehm, who has become Assistant Defense Secretary for Legilative Affairs.

title: AMERICAN'S RELEASE BY YUGOSLAVIA SEEN
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28An American serving sevenyear prison sentence here on spying charges stemming from photographs he took of a sugar refinery has been pardoned and will be released soon, Yugoslav sources reported today.

title: Fund Proposed to Spur Public TV Documentaries
description: The Ford Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts are proposing to establish a special fund, amounting to $500,000, to encourage the production of documentaries for public television by independent Producers.

title: Helen Humes's Melodies Bubble at the Cookery
description: It was almost a year and a half ago that Helen Humes made her first appeirance at the Cookery and changed a singing career that was dwindling toward semiretirement into an autumnai round of acclaim and busy activity. Before that engagement in January 1975, Miss Hume, who had been with Count Basic's band from 1938 to 1944 and later developed !notable career on her own, had clone little singing for a decade. Yet her voice, at the age of 61. was as fresh and buoyant and responsive as it had been at any time in her earlier days.

title: Why NATO Is Losing the Edge
description: PARISThe North Atlantic alliance, whose ministers have just finished meeting in Oslo, is not only in a condition of political anxiety but its military .forces increasingly reflect the failure of any sensible arms standardization to evolve. As a result, the impressive economicindustrial base and qualitative technological advantages of the coalition over the Sovietdominated Warsaw Pact have to sad extent faded away.

title: U .S  Economic Indicators UP for March and April
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy rose briskly in April, and the preliminary estimate of a move downward in March was revised to an increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 4 Groups Pledge Funds to Aid La Scala Visit in September
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The Kennedy Center gave credit yesterday to a tobacco company, a department store, a local foundation and its own stagehands for helping to pay for a tour of the United States this September by La Scala opera company of Milan.

title: Reagan Wants Concessions if He Is Loser
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28 Ronald Reagan indicated today that if he lost his bid for the Republican nomination he would seek to win concessions from President Ford on conservative issues in return for his full support in the general election.

title: Cadets of the Past Return to Cheer Long Gray Line
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 28 Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the former Chief of Staff, and more than 600 other gracluates of the United States Military Academy returned today for June Week, with many of them indicating their support for the institution in one of its darkest hours.

title: Brainwashing, Psychiatry and the Law
description: Buried as a foreign menace more than twenty years ago, exhumed, examined and reinterred once or twice since then, brainwashing has risen again, this time take its Mace on the stage of domestic horrors.

title: Text of the U.S.Soviet Treaty on Underground Nuclear Tests
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Following is the official text of the treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union on underground nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes. It does not include the 10article protocol attached to the treaty detailing inspection procedures. The peaceful explosions treaty complements the treaty on underground nuclear weapons tests signed July 3, 1974. by Richard M. Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Kallinger Is Ordered To Shave Off His Beard
description: Joseph Kallinger, a Philadelphia shoemaker charged with the murder last year of a 21yearold Leonia, N. J., nurse, was ordered by judge yesterday to shave his beard for the trial, which is expected to start in the fall.

title: Poor, Conservative Area Is Now Sold on Federal Aid
description: BOONE, Ky., May 26To hear Ronald Reagan, Jimmy Carter and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. tell it, the American people are sick of big government, the Federal bureaucracy and Washington's giveaway programs.

title: Blow to M.A.C.
description: The ratings are not the whole answer, Jackson Phillips, executive vice president of Moody's Investors Service once told an interviewer. They are just one tool in what should be a much broader evaluation process.

title: Music: Robert Shaw Leads Beethoven
description: The nostalgia was hipdeep on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, where the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra gave the first of three Beethoven programs. There at the head of the orchestra and a splendid chorus stood that institution of American music. Robert Shaw, in the familiar hunchct.dshoulder conducting stance, his face a ruddy study in seriousness, as always.

title: U.S. AIDES DENY PLAN FOR FULL PEKING TIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) State Department. officials are denying suggestions by a ranking member of the House of Representatives that the Ford Administration has secretly decided to establish full diplomatic relations with China after the November elections.

title: Montclair in Finals
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, May 28Montclair State College won a Division 3 regional tournament today by defeating Glassboro State, 81. It moved Montclair into the Division 3 World Series June 4 through 6 in Marietta, Ohio.

title: Philippines Floods Ebbing
description: MANILA, May 28 (Reuters)  Week long floods in the northern Philippines started receding today after leaving at least 175 people dead, hundreds of thouhands driven from their homes, and damage estimated at more than $60 million.

title: Irish Student Bar Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 28 (AP)A bomb explodad tonight in a bar where about 200 university students were celebrating the start of their summer holiday. The police said that one man died of injuries and 19 persons were injured, five seriously. The bar, in a mixed Roman CatholicProtestant section, is a gathering place for students from nearby Queens University.

title: Cunningham Arrested,Charged With AlcoholImpaired Driving
description: JERICHO, L. I., May 28Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, was an rested here early this morning and charged with violating traf tic laws by driving while his ability was impaired by alcohol.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Securities and commodities markets throughout. the country will also be closed.

title: TEAMSTER REBELS DOUBT A SHAKEUP
description: Despite the massive report issued by insurgent truck drivers on corruption and suppre.ssion of internal democracy in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the leadership of the 2.3millionmember union is unlikely to encounter any major difficulty in winning reelection at its quinquennial convention in Lus Vegas next month.

title: RUBY HILLMAN STERN
description: Ruby Hillman Stern, a past president of the National Council of Jewish Women in Essex County, in New Jersey, died Thursday at her home in South Orange, N. J. She was 79 years old.

title: Boston Heeds Judge, Ends School Closing Threat
description: BOSTON. May 28 (AP)The threat of the early closing of Boston's schools because of the expense of racial integration has been averted by city offcials, who say they have the money and the legal authority to pay teachers salaries.

title: Hialeah Park Is Sold
description: MIAMI, May 28 (AP)  Hialeah Park stockholders voted unanimously today to sell all stock in the financially troubled thoroughbred track to Martin DeMatteo Jr., a former owner of the Green Mountain Tack in Vermont.

title: Jonathen Donnson Sings 16Part Cycle
description: In his recital in Town Hall on Thursday night, Jonathen Donnson gave a quite special performance of Schumann's Dichterliebe. The tenor sang the 16part song cycle with a light lyric voice that had plenty of room for nuance and color. His sensitivity to the text and musical phrase was constant, and his voice was consistently appealing. Together with Elizabeth Rodgers's fine playing of the piano part, Mr. Donnson's singing made the work an impressive experience.

title: People and Business
description: The nomination of David M. Lilly to serve as a member of the Federal Reserve Board was confirmed by the Senate yesterday. Mr. Lilly is chairman of the Toro Corporation of Bloomington, Minn., Which produces lawn and turf maintenance equipment, irrigation and underground sprinkling systems and playground equipment.

title: French Arrest 4 Charged In 72 Hijacking in Florida
description: PARIS, May 28 (AP)  The French police said today that they had arrested four Americans charged with hijacking a Delta Airlines DC8 over Florida in 1972 and extorting $1 million, and then forcing the plane to fly to Alpiers.

title: Sun Never Shines in School But Don't Tell the Plants
description: The long, low building under the elevated subway tracks on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx has no windows. An American flag flies over the door. It is flanked by a funeral home and a discount furniture warehouse. Pasted on the door is a crude, handlettered sign that says P.S. 26 Annex.

title: U.S. Senator Charges Piracy In Panamanian Seizure of Yacht
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Senator Jesse A. Helms charged today that a Panamanian gunboat committed piracy in seizing an Americanowned, yacht in waters of the Panama Canal Zone on May 23.

title: CALIFORNIA GIVEN $2 MILLION BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 The National Endowment for the Humanities announced today several grants to individuals and institutions in California totaling more than $2 million.

title: American U. Hospital In Beirut Shy of Funds
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28 The American University Hospital, which handled more than 500 major war casualties in the first three weeks of this month alone, Was unable to fully meet its monthly payroll today.

title: BlueLaw Sociology
description: THE first blue laws in the United States were published in 1781. They were printed on blue paper, which is how they got their name, and they listed the Sabbath regulations of New Haven, Conn., forbidding regular work, buying, selling, traveling, sports or public entertainment on Sunday.

title: Miss Spagna Bride of Robert Levinson
description: Susan Lynn Spagna and Robert R. Levinson, 1975 graduates of the Delaware Law School, were married yesterday afternoon in Grymes Hill, S. I.

title: Breathing Space
description: Secretary General Waldheim can take considerable satisfaction from the successful accomplishment of his rather risky mission to Damascus last week. He flew there, against the advice of some concerned diplomats secure Syria's assent to a sixmonth extension of the United Nations Disengagement Observation Force on the Golan Heights, which acts as an indispensable buffer between Syrian and Israeli troops.

title: Newark Museum: Art of the 19th Century
description: NEWARK

title: Hofstra Makes a Bet
description: IN a time of economic crisis for higher education, colleges and universities have turned for help to alumni, government grants and offcampus programs. This week Hofstra University, with its fingers crossed, is  turning to circus clowns, elephants, daredevil exhibitions and ostrich races.

title: Douglas Defection Underlines Olympian Task of Choosing U.S. Five
Greek Festival Planned
description: A Grecian Festival and Bazaar has been announced for next weekend to be held under a sprawling tent at the Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral at 64 Schermerhorn Street, near Court Street, in downtown Brooklyn. The festival will run from 11 A.M. to midnight on Friday and Saturday, June 4 and 5, and from 1 P.M. to 9 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is free.

title: FISHING
description: FISHING for striped bass and fluke off the New Jersey beaches and in the rivers as picked picked up. but fishermen could be rigging for bluefish this week. Temperatures are borderline, and mild weather with subsiding winds could herald the arrival of the blues.

title: Helen L. Hoart, B. D. Sterrett 3d Wed in Capital
description: Helen Lorraine Hoare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Hoart of Manhasset, I. I., was married yesterday Afternoon in Washington to Bailey Dunlap Sterrett 3d. He is the son of Lieutenant Commander Sterrett Jr., U.S.N., retired, of Staunton, Va., and Paulette Sterrett of Odenton, Md.

title: GARDENING
description: EACH spring, many New Jersey gardeners begin an exciting voyage of plant discovery. It seems to me, though, that not enough of them ever discover one of the great garden plants, the herbaceous peony.

title: AsianAmericans in New York Found Dynamic and Growing
description: New York City's AsianAmericans of Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Philippine origins were depicted last week as a dynamic, rapidly growing group determined to share fully and equally in the fruits1 of our society.

title: The Guest Word
description: I last saw Tony Godwin one afternoon early in March. On a quick trip to New York, I sought him out in his office at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and we drifted down to a neighborhood bar tor drinks, as was our habit, as years ago in London we used to drink in a pub around the corner from Weidenfeld & Nicolson, We gossiped about books, the literary world, mutual friends in London, his children, mine. Tony was enormously pleased with Edna O'Brien's new book on Ireland. He was charged with enthusiasm for another book, a political book he had commissioned from Richard Reeves. It was light banter mostly. He didn't know, I didn't know, there was so little time. We were going to have lunch together on my next trip to Nev York.

title: Yorkie Is Chosen Best In Show at Wellesley
A Windmill Whose Only Real Job Is to Warm Dutch Hearts
description: SCHERNIERHORN, The Netherlands  When neighbors in this small farm town 30 miles north of Amsterdam want to know if Nelleken Muysken is home, they just see if her blades are turning.

title: POSITION OF U.S. ON ILO. CLEARER
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 Lane Kirkland, the secretarytreasurer of the A.F.L.C.I.O., says that the support of other industrial countries"our natural allies"is the key to whether the United States withdraws from or remains a member of the International Labor Organization.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox:When Is $180,000 Worth $40,000? Ask OTB
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FILM VIEW
description: fter seeing That's Entercainment two years agn, MGM's first anthological tribute to itself. I couldn't believe that there would be enough firstclass material in tha studio vaults to make the inevitable sequel. Having now seen the sequel, That's Entertainment, Part 2, I'm shutting up about the possibilities of Part 3. It may be that the MGM archives are magically replenished. No matter how much material is wititcral.vn, there still appears to be more where that came from. Certainly That's Entertainment, Part 2 is as much fun as the first film, and perhaps even more interesting as Hollywood history. It covers more ground in that the 72 features that are represented in Part 2" include comedies, dramas and melodramas, as well as musicals plus odds and ends of short subjects.

title: Islam Stirs Controversy in West Africa
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 29 In West Africa, where debates about heritage rapidly turn political, a schism has erupted over the question of whether black African culture embraces the world of Islam.

title: MOYNIHAN CITES U.N. VOTEBUYING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29 Daniel P. Moynihan, former United States represntatiye at the United Nations, says he was aware his term here last fall that vote on critical General Assembly resolutions were bought and sold by diplomats.

title: Memories Of Franco Are Fading
description: EL FERROL DEL CAUDILLO, Spain, May 26  In this naval city on Spain's northwest corner where Francisct Franco was born, the memory of the man who dominated this nation for 40 years appears as dim six months after his death as it is elsewhere.

title: Stop That Rod
description: The Supreme Court may at last be confronted with a case concerning corporal punishment of schoolchildren that will make it difficult to condone the practice as a benign application of oldfashioned pedagogy. As recently as last October, the Court upheld state laws authorizing corporal punishment. To outlaw the practice, thcourt then held, would run counter to a settled tradition of countenancing such punishment when reasonable.

title: Mail Call Just Won't Be the Same
description: Shades of The Stepford Wives, they've found the perfect office mail girl. This one never calls in sick, never misses a stop and won't stop to chat with the secretaries along the way.

title: National Affairs
description: PHILADELPHIA, May. 29 (AP)  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has urged young people to continue demanding change.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: WITH voters everywhere said to be discontented about the bigness of government, members of the Long Island delegation in Congress are looking for ways to show (1) Concern and (2) Efforts To Do Something About It.

title: Daley Tells City Workers To Live in Chicago or Quit
description: CHICAGO, May 29Mayor Richard J. Daley cannot understand why anyone would prefer the suburbs to living in CMcago.

title: Aleksandr Frumkin Dies at 80; Pioneer Soviet Electrochemist
description: MOSCOW, May 29, Reuters Aleksandr Frumkin, regarded here as a founding father of modern theoretical electrochemistry, died on Thursday, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 80 years old.

title: POLITICS
description: IF I get on early and he wins and he is President, that can't hurt, said the Island's youngest Congressman, 27yearold Representative Tom Downey of West Islip, as he explained why he had endorsed Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination, one of the first New York public officials to do so.

title: Traditional Jazz Is Jumping
description: Traditional jazz bandsgroups specializing primarily in jazz styles of the 1920's and earlierare springing up in San Antonio, Dayton, Detroit, Chicago, Boston, New York, Newark, Allentown, Atlanta, New Orleans, Mendota, Minn. and points south, east, west and north. Some are notable principally for their enthusiasm. But others are extremely good and dig up interesting material instead of relying on the standard Dixieland warhorses.

title: Karen Genkins Has Nuptials
description: Karen Lee Genkins and Robert Fairbank, secondyear students at the New York University Law School and members of The Law Review, were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by Robert Berson of the Ethical Culture Society in the church parlor of the West End Collegiate Church.

title: Who Needs the Energy Agency?
description: WASHINGTONNobody loves the Federal Energy Administrationnobody in Congress, nobody in the executive branch, nobody in the oil industry, nobody in the state capitals.

title: Executives Named
description: David C. Gold, chairman; Jerry Sterner, president, and Israel Zipes, executive vice president, David C. Gold & Co. Mr. Gold was formerly president, Mr. Sterner joined the concern in 1972 and Mr. Zipes was formerly vice president of W. Osborne Smith, Inc.

title: Notes: 27 Countries Contribute To a Contemporary Music Festival
description: The International Society for Contemporary Music. formed in 1022 by a group of Viennese composers including Schoenberg, Webern and Berg, has held a festival of contemporary music every year since then, interrupted only by the sixyear hiatus of World War II. This year for the first time the ISCM concerts will take place in the United States, under the auspices of the New England Conservatory in Boston.

title: Papa
description: The two most famous American novelists of the 20th century are in grave need of rescue. If the fictions of William Faulkner and Ernest Hemingway were intended in part as rudders through life, as justifications of lives endured, as prayers for comprehension, then their lives are in greater danger now, nearly 15 years after their deaths, than ever before. The threats to both life and work are strongFaulkner lies flat beneath the midden of misconstruction and indiscriminate praise heaped on him by tardy academic critics in eternal quest of an American WorldGenius and by Joseph Blotner's admiring but undiscerning biography; Hemingway suffers the opposite, critical deflation and the subtly hostile biography of Carlos Baker,

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: The sculptures of Carol Anthony stand somewhere on a very tall ladder that starts at the bottom with fabric bears and bunnies (subDisney in tone) and ends way, way up with the Little Dancer of Edgar Degas. When Degas put that little dancer into a real skirt he started something that has still not yet worked itself out completely: the interpenetration of art and life.

title: Le Bus Est Plus Facile
description: Over the twin eyes of the headlights on many Paris buses there is a poster displaying a second pair of huge, very feminine, human eyes. From the bus, the slogan says, I can see Paris.

title: GuardDog Trainers Set High Standards
description: Concerned that anyone can set himself up as a trainer of guard dogs, professionals in the field are flocking to the United States Professional Dog Trainers Association.

title: Athent Riot Trial Begins
description: ATHENS, May 29 (Reuters) Thirtyseven people went on trial before a civil court today in connection with riots in Athens last Tuesday, in which one woman was killed and more than 150 people injured.

title: NAVY MAN GRANTED STAY OF DISCHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)  Federal District Judge Edward F. Corcoran of the District of Columbia has barred the Navy from discharging Ens. Vernon Berg 3d, a selfdescribed homosexual.

title: HOUSE IS ASSAYED ON ENVIRONMENT
description: New England's Representatives in Congress stand highest, and Representatives from the Southwestern region are lowest in environmental perception, according to the League of Conservation Voters.

title: Capitol Putting an End To SelfGuided Tour
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) After less than a week, the heralded selfguided walking tour of the Capitol has been scrapped because it created almost a logjam of humanity in the corridors, according to Kenneth R. Harding, the House sergeantatarms.

title: For young readers
description: In a decaying house on a forested hill live two dreaming women, a 17yearold recluse and her mad, beautiful mother. Deirdre, the mother, wanders the rooms of the vast sheltering house in flowing bathrobes, some medicinestained and ragged, some more presentable. The daughter, Jean, short for Eugenia, feels safe in the womb of my house where I am alone. Always. She lies awake all night dreaming with her eyes open, and feels the forestroutside, waiting. There is no. one between the trees, only spaces for me to fit into. If I go in I may never come out again.

title: TV Ads Revive Yesterday's Stars
description: Petula Clark, Connie Francis and The Platters are being recycled. Or at least some of their songs are.

title: California RaceProfile in Complexity
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29 The political tides seem to run in favor Of the home towners as the wave of Presidential primaries crests in California June 8.

title: New York City Council Schedules 2 Hearings
description: New York City Council committees will hold the following public hearings this week:

title: P.L.O. Pressing Waldheini On 1977 Israeli Withdrawal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29 (Reuters) The Palestine Liberation Organization told Secretary General Kurt Waldhelm today that the starting point for a Middle East settlement should be Israeli withdrawal within a year from occupied Arab territor.

title: Harold S. Stern, Writer And Editor, Dies at 53
description: Harold S. Stern, a syndicated writer and contributing editor of After Dark magazine, died Tuesday at his home. He was 53 years old.

title: PEOPLE
description: FRANK WRIGHT of Lake Success, the horse trainer who will serve as the CBSTV racing analyst for the Belmont Stakes next Saturday, has 23 horses under his care during the current meeting. But his wife, Katie, prefers backing her own skills at the backgammon board to wagering on thoroughbreds. She seems to have absorbed the philosophy embodied in the old saying Frank Wright likes to quote: You can beat a race, but you can't beat the races.

title: What Makes Jimmy Win?
description: FIERY RUN, Va., May 29The most interesting thing about the Presidential election is that so many people in this secularized and largely agnostic country have given their votes to A devout evangelical Southern Baptist.

title: TOP ITALY PARTIES SEEK CREDIBILITY
description: ROME, May 29 As the Italian election campaign struggles on in its final weeks, the main contenders are encountering a credibility problem that has left the outcome very much in doubt

title: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse To Cornell
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.In the game billed by many as the lacrosse game of the decade, unbeaten Cornell captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship today by downing topranked Maryland, 1613, in a thrilling overtime contest. The victory marked the second national championshirilor Richie*Moran, whose 1971 team defeated Maryland for the first N.C.A.A. title.

title: Bob Hope in ProAm
description: CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP)  Bob Hope will play in the Jim Graner Memorial proamateur golf tournament June 22, preceding the Babe Zaharias Invitational Classic in suburban Chagrin Falls.

title: Cuban Gang Leader Of 1940's Is Found Slain Near Miami
description: MIAMI, May 29 (AP) Thei leader of a political gang during the chaotic 1940's in Cuba! was found shot to death today in a field south of Miami. He was the fourth prominent Cuban! here in 14 days.

title: An Embarrassment of Riches
description: Can an executive become too successful for his own good? He can if he's Paul C. Koomey and public stockholders are about to learn just how good a job he's doing.

title: Hotel Towers Sprout In Bergen
description: ACOW was tethered in a field across from the Marriott hotel in Saddle Brook when Olof Arnhelm went to work there 10 years ago as restaurant manager. A vacant lot occupied the steep field between Route 17 and Interstate 80 in Hasbrouck Heights in 1968 when Arthur Sherman and August R. Caiazzo emerged from a lunch: at Guido's restaurant, just across the line in Hackensack, and Mr. Sherman blinked and said. Boy, would I like to open a motel there.

title: Abraham Pais Weds Sara E. Via in Jersey
description: Sara Ector Via, assistant professor of Romance languages at Princeton University and a member of its European cultural studies program, was married yesterday afternoon to Abraham Pais, professor of physics at Rockefeller University.

title: FRIENDS PERFORM IN OCHS CONCERT
description: The concert tribute to the late Phil Ochs that was held in the Felt Forum on Friday offered few surprises, except foc the number of absentees. Of the star performers rumored to be considering appearances  Bob Dylan, Joni Mitchell and Joan Baez had been mentioned, though not by the concert's organizersnone showed up.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Edward Kennedy

title: Indian Bus Plunge Kills 40
description: NEW DELHI, May 29 (Reuters) Forty people were killed when a bus skidded and plunged into the Ganges River near Rishikesh. 150 miles north of here yesterday.

title: One Case Too Many
description: LYNDHURST, Ohio, May 29 (UPI) Robert W. Gibbons, 20 years old, had boasted that although he had not gone to law school or passed the state bar examination he had lost only one of 36 cases he handled in court. Yesterday the law caught up with him. He was convicted in municipal court of charges of falsification and practicing law without a license.

title: The fall and rise of Main Street
description: Main Streetas American as apple pie; a stage set by Sinclair Lewis frozen in time and cultural mythology. Fourstory brick fronts; shops below, offices above. The drugstore, the quick lunch, tha fiveandten. the movie theater. Eternal, unchanging middle America.

title: Postal Service Now Facing Union Leadership Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  Vincent Sombrotto, whose New York local gave the nation its first big postal strike in 1970, is in hot pursuit, with a great deal of support, of his union'P presidency. And if he wins in the election this summer, labor relatiorrs in the huge United States Postal Service are likely to become far more turbulent than ever before.

title: Jean Jackson Is Betrothed to Ed Moore
description: Leanna Browning of Seattle and the Rev. Willie Gaskins a Baptist minister of Savannah, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Jean Gaskins Jackson of Brooklyn, to Ed N. Moore, chief fiscal officer of Harlem's HARYOUACT Community Corporation. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edgar B. Moore of Montgomery, Ala.

title: Laura Morgan Bride in South
description: Laura Wilson Morgan and Geoffrey Howe Waggoner, a law student, were married last evening in the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Decatur, Ga., by the Rev. Richard W. Millner.

title: New Poems
description: Eugenio Montale is by common consensus Italy's greatest living writer and, with Jorge Gulllen, one of the few surviving members of the modernist movement, which changed the form and substance of poetry in our century. But it is only since he was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature last year that the 79yearold poet's work has begun to attract the sustained attention here it has long deserved. A modest man who shuns selfadvertisement, Montele has brought out only five collections of verse in the course of his career, but each has signaled important changes in the development of his work and of contemporary Italian poetry, which he has dominated, along with Ungaretti and Quasimodo, since he started to publish.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The National Bank of North America has leased 45,000 square feet of office space at 80 Pine Street for 10 years at an aggregate rent of more than $3 million.

title: Kate DoordanWed To Ross Klavan
description: Kate Doordan, a newscaster for WINS Radio, was married in New Yorkyesterday morning to Ross Klavan. a WINS writereditor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene.Klavan of New York. Thebridegroom's father is the host of the Gene Klavan Show on. WNEW Radio. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John E. Doordan of Concord, Calif.

title: Soviet Denies Christenings Are Religiously Motivated
description: MOSCOW, May 29 (Reuters)  Most young Soviet parents who have their children christened in church do so for reat sons that are not religious, Pravda has renorted.

title: Metric Can Be Fun!
description: Munro Leaf's book goes right to the heart of the matter, with a quotation from Alexander Graham Bell: Ali the difficulties in the metric system are in translating from one system to the other, but the moment you use the metric system alone there is no difficulty. It's rather like learning a languagecomes a moment when you stop translating into English and start thinking in, say, French. After that it's easy.

title: Censored in Israel
description: Sometimes a book is more interesting for the news it creates than for the information it contalins. Such is the case with Matti Golan's longawaited account of Henry Kissinger's Middle East diplomacy.

title: I.L.O. WON'T ADMIT P.L.O. AT PARLEY
description: GENEVA, May 29 The governing body of the International Labor Organization rejected today by one vote a bid by the Palestine Liberation Organization for observer status at the forthcoming World Employment Conference of the United Nations agency.

title: Tigers Down Yankees, 41; Mets Lose, 32 ,in 10 Innings
2 Jockeys Thrown
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. May 29 (UPI) Rudy Campas. arm and Francisca Mena, was shaken up when they were thrown from their mounts during the first race at Hollywood Park today. Mena's mount, Expression, was leading when he suffered a broken leg and threw mena over his head. Campas's mount, Jovial Judge, struck the fallen horse, and Campas tumbled.

title: Welfare Integrity
description: JOHN A. HAMILTON'S article, It Pays to Advertise for Welfare Cheats (April 25), requires comment, if only to put into some reasonable perspective the issues he considers. Granted that we are all obliged not to cheat the government, even that we should discourage if not prevent others from doing so. And granted, of course, that welfare officials have a specific responsibility to detect and prevent welfare fraud. These assumptions apply under any circumstances, let alone under economic conditions that compel fiscal constraints, at the very least to insure the most equitable distribution of limited financial resources.

title: LEVI, IN REVERSAL WON'T USE BOSTON AS TEST ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 Reversing his tentative decision of three vreelis ago after strong protests from civil rights leaders and other persons, Attorney General Edward H. Levi decided today not to use the Boston school busing case as the Ford Administration's vehicle for seeking reconsideration by the Supreme Court of busing as a means of integration.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: In the summer of 1947, nearly three decades before he became the New York State Superintendent of Banks, a youthful John G. Heimann spent the night in the Johnson City jailhouse in upstate New York after being picked up as a union organizer.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: ... Carter as Man of Integrity Is in a Classic Mold
description: Jimmy Carter's credibility and truthfulness have become issues in the 1976 Presidential campaign because he made them so. The former Georgia Governor realized very early in the planning stage of his campaign that there was what he calls 'a deep hunger for assurance among voters shamed by Watergate, by revelations of illegality by the C.I.A. and F.B.I. and a decade of evasion and halftruths about the Vietnam war.

title: Reading The Bard
description: I I'S 10 o'clock on a Monday night in one of Morristown's gracious old houses. Shifting slightly in their chairs, about 18 people are sitting around in formal evening clothes and reading a Shakespearean play, just as has been the for the last 100 years.

title: Work on Gateway Project Awaits Final Legal Approval
description: Work on the Gateway National Recreation Area, which could pump between $75 million and $150 million in Federal development funds into thei New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan economy, is awaiting final clearance of legal obstacles and completion of planning.

title: BRIDGE
description: In the past 40 years many prominent figures in Washington have been bridge enthusiasts. The late Senator Clinton P. Anderson of Albuqurque, N.M., onetime Secretary of Agriculture, was a prominent tournament player. His record was later surpassed by the late John P. Kunkel. a Pennsylvania Congressman who won nine regional titles.

title: New &
description: By Jon Cleary. 285 pp. New York: William Morrow 8c Co. $7.95.

title: The pull of Sun Moon
description: This Tuesday evening, God willing, and perhaps helping, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon will join such illustrious ancestors as Babe Ruth, Joe Louis, Johnny Unitas, Pope Paul VI, and Billy Graham as a featured performer at Yankee Stadium. Over the past few weeks New Yorkers have grown accustomed to Moon's face smiling at them from thousands of leaflets handed out by cheerful young Moonies. The leaflets, posters, and radio and TV ads invite evetyone to attend Moon's Bicentennial God Bless America Festival. Moon hopes to draw 200,000 people to the stadium (even though it will hold only 60,000). Those who get in will be treated to a rousing revival meeting, with classical fan dances by the Korean Folk Ballet, inspiring songs by Moon's New Hope Singers, and a lengthy, energetic speech in Korean by Moon. The leaders of Moon's Unification Church say the rally will promote the spiritual significance of the Bicentennial, and help restore confidence in the American dream. But it will also celebrate the Second Corning of the millionaireevangelist who proclaims himself the new Messiah.

title: Robert E. Slaughter, 65, Dies; McGrawHill Education Officer
description: Robert E. Slaughter, a director, consultant and retired executive vice president of McGrawHill Inc., died Friday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived in Greenwich. Conn.
